And I did tutorial->fast->slow cause I hadn't thought about it beforehand. But yeah, I'm happy to get a fluent fast solve right away. I really didn't want to waste time with many attempts until one good one comes along... Cheers! Stefan

5. (OT) Re: Math competition!
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 02:15:42 -0000

This has been giving me great enjoyment all weekend!

I dusted off my java skills and have been pounding away at the
problems. Now that I'm back into the groove of programming in java,
they are falling much more quickly.

Problem 12 is giving me serious fits though. I can't seem to find a
quick way to find the number of divisors of a VERY large number...if
you guys have any tips ;)

Thanks again to the original poster of this! It's a freaking blast.

-Daniel

PS- I just remembered I have to do the Sunday contest! You all should too.

9. 4x4 Corner sorta Parity error
From: giraffeboy13 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 03:20:32 -0000

So, i think im the only one who solves a 4x4 this way but for some
reason i keep getting this corner parity error on the last layer where
two corners have switched positions. I solve a 4x4 by first solving
the centers, then joining edge pieces up, then solving the 3x3. I
think that it may just be how i solve the final 3x3 but i was
wondering if anyone maybe had encountered the same problem and maybe
has an algorithm for it.

~John~





10. (OT) Re: Math competition!
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 03:20:24 -0000

> Ha, after solving that one they already tell me "Your current rating
> is 1% genius."!!!
>
> What is a "very large number" for you?
>
> Stefan
>

Well I just naturally assumed that any number with over 500 divisors
must be pretty dang big... is this an incorrect assumption?

I have tested all triangle numbers up to 13999986 so far (the 5291st
triangle number) with the highest number of factors up to this point
being 320. The testing has become quite slow at this point.

What am I missing?







11. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 Corner sorta Parity error
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Oct 2005 19:24:01 -0800 (PST)

well i use an algorithm to swap the edges that are "in between" the switched corners and then use a t-permuation as seen on http://bigcubes.com/4x4x4/finalsolve.html the one all the way at the bottom, on the left side --- giraffeboy13 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > So, i think im the only one who solves a 4x4 this > way but for some > reason i keep getting this corner parity error on > the last layer where > two corners have switched positions. I solve a 4x4 > by first solving > the centers, then joining edge pieces up, then > solving the 3x3. I > think that it may just be how i solve the final 3x3 > but i was > wondering if anyone maybe had encountered the same > problem and maybe > has an algorithm for it. > > ~John~ > > > > __________________________________ Yahoo! 17. square one is the devil
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Oct 2005 23:28:30 -0800 (PST)

so i've messed with it for about a week and i can
always get everything to where it needs to be except
the final edge permute. (as in all corners are
permuted and oriented, edges are in the correct layer)
i finally gave up and started looking for sequences
online but notation doesn't seem to be consistent
among sites. can anyone give me a site with
definative notation instructions or explain to me what
is what (like 2,0 is that 2 lines over or what) i
understand the simple 1,0 0,-1 and such, but the even
numbers i don't get and the 5's confuse me, so all in
all i'm a big mess. i'm looking at jaap's site on the
part where you move edges within their own layer.




__________________________________
Yahoo! Mail - PC Magazine Editors' Choice 2005
http://mail.yahoo.com


18. Re: [Speed cubing group] square one is the devil
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 09:43:24 +0100

Hello, The notation (1;0) can be translated into (30°, 0°) The first number is for the upper layer, the second is for the bottom layer. So, for example : (6, 4) = (180° (=U2) ; 120° ) Between two sequences, you have to turn the right part of the cube (usually writed / ). It's important that usually, thse scrambling/solving sequences are usable only if the "seperation line of the midle layer" is on the left. I hope this is intelligible, because it's very important. Good luck ;-) 2005/10/31, Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>: > so i've messed with it for about a week and i can > always get everything to where it needs to be except > the final edge permute. (as in all corners are > permuted and oriented, edges are in the correct layer) > i finally gave up and started looking for sequences > online but notation doesn't seem to be consistent > among sites. can anyone give me a site with > definative notation instructions or explain to me what > is what (like 2,0 is that 2 lines over or what) i > understand the simple 1,0 0,-1 and such, but the even > numbers i don't get and the 5's confuse me, so all in > all i'm a big mess. i'm looking at jaap's site on the > part where you move edges within their own layer. > > > > > __________________________________ > Yahoo! Mail - PC Magazine Editors' Choice 2005 > http://mail.yahoo.com > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >

20. Re: [Speed cubing group] Silicon spray on the plane or in the suitcase ?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 00:54:08 -0800

Hi Gilles,

You're probably better off putting it in your checked baggage. The
United States airline security can be pretty tight these days. You're
not even supposed to bring nail clippers on board because they have a
blade.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

21. Re: Pics of the Dutch Champs 2005
From: "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 10:01:59 -0000

I had to laugh about your comment on the size of the trophies you got. That reminds me a lot of when I came back from Amsterdam after the European Championships. The trophy I got back then was huge. We didn't have a bag or case that was big enough and we had to walk a fair distance with our lugage to get to the station and change trains 4 times so I couldn't just hold it in my hands all the time. In the end I managed to stuff it in one of our bags but it was still hanging out. It was also quite a heavy trophy. If you look closely at some of the EC pictures, you'll notice (from my facial expressions) that I was having big difficulties keeping it up in the air while people were taking photographs. Those are the things you have to take into your stride when you're the champion ;) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > This must be the most unusual speedcubing picture ever (except that > > other one which doesn't count cause it was on purpose): > > http://tinyurl.com/7mgem > > > > Nice picture report, thanks! > > Stefan > > > Yeah.. 4 females at the competition area... I almost wanted to make a > comment about that myself :).. >

29. Re: [Speed cubing group] square one is the devil
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 08:10:45 -0800 (PST)

thanks for your response, gilles. i understand the 1's and 4's, is a 2 basically moving from one side of a corner to another? and what is a 5. i'm holding it with the square one text on the left side. so would -2,0 be moveing the other side of the corner the flip line? are there any applets that demonstrate these moves? the specific one i'm looking at fixes a z type permutation in the top layer and the notation is: /(3,3)/(0,3)/(1,1)/(-1,-4)/(-3,-3)/ so does this one make it not square then shift it back or what? and then this one that swaps fu and fd edges (0,-3)/(0,3)/(1,0)/(2,-2)/(4,0)/(4,0)/(-4,4)/(0,1)/(0,3)/(-3,-1)/(1,-2)/(-1,0) i don't get the 2's in this one. if anyone could make a slow video of these 2 algs, i would be eternally greatful. i like this puzzle, but it might not make it through the day if i don't get this notation down. :) --- Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...> wrote: > Hello, > > The notation (1;0) can be translated into (30ï¿½, 0ï¿½) > The first number is for the upper layer, the second > is for the bottom layer. > > So, for example : (6, 4) = (180ï¿½ (=U2) ; 120ï¿½ ) > > Between two sequences, you have to turn the right > part of the cube > (usually writed / ). > It's important that usually, thse scrambling/solving > sequences are > usable only if the "seperation line of the midle > layer" is on the > left. I hope this is intelligible, because it's very > important. > > Good luck ;-) > > 2005/10/31, Clancy Cochran > <perscription_death@...>: > > so i've messed with it for about a week and i can > > always get everything to where it needs to be > except > > the final edge permute. (as in all corners are > > permuted and oriented, edges are in the correct > layer) > > i finally gave up and started looking for > sequences > > online but notation doesn't seem to be consistent > > among sites. can anyone give me a site with > > definative notation instructions or explain to me > what > > is what (like 2,0 is that 2 lines over or what) i > > understand the simple 1,0 0,-1 and such, but the > even > > numbers i don't get and the 5's confuse me, so all > in > > all i'm a big mess. i'm looking at jaap's site on > the > > part where you move edges within their own layer. > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > > Yahoo! Mail - PC Magazine Editors' Choice 2005 > > http://mail.yahoo.com > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ Yahoo! FareChase: Search multiple travel sites in one click. http://farechase.yahoo.com
30. [Speed cubing group] Blindfold solving
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 16:41:11 -0000

Hi,
Just a general ramble.
I just came back from a week on holiday in Greece where I set myself the
target of trying blindfold solving again after a break of about 22 years! I
had a look at Bill McGaugh's site before I went
(http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh/) and then sat down on the 3 1/2 hour
flight to think my way through it - trying out little bits of the method.
On the subsequent days I had spare time here and there while wife and kids
were doing other things and altogether I've attempted about 10 solves with
about 50% success. When its wrong its usually a 3-cycle or so because I
just can't quite always remember the right edge permutations.
I now see how the blindfold times are so fast - which isn't to say I don't
think they are very impressive! I was there at the first blindfold world
record of about 20 minutes in 1982 (I think!) and I remember the effort that
John White the solver had to put into it. The new methods make it almost
easy (almost but not quite!). My times are generally around ten minutes
with this method and could clearly be faster with practice and confidence.
Anyway fantastic method and well thought out.

Anyone got any way to improve my ageing memory of edge permutations I'd be
glad to take their advice!

Good luck to all blindfold solvers at the WC.

Duncan






31. (OT) Re: Math competition!
From: "karekrig" <karkr936@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 16:41:21 -0000

675 points for 53 solved problems. Anyone who has studied computer science should be able to solve quite a few of the ones with high points. Problem 107 is at 19 points but is a standard problem with algorithms that are not to hard to implement. /Kåre --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > I'm 14% genius. 8-) > I've gotten 227 points for 23 solved problems. > > /Gunnar
32. PLL probabilities
From: "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 16:59:21 -0000

Hey, folks!
I came up with something similar to this question a while ago, but I
have another doubt...

I was wondering about the PLL probabilities. One way I've found to
know it was:

check the number of probabilities for each case and make the % of the
total. So, for example, the U perm have 8 possible cases:
-each of the 4 colors can be the correct side and we have clockwise
and counter-clockwise direction, so 4x2=8

for the A is the same thing...and etc

I got 73 cases in total, but I think something is wrong, cause my %
do not match with the probabilities on Fridrich's site...

here's what I got:

%
U - 8 10.96
A - 8 10.96
Z - 2 2.74
H - 1 1.37
E - 2 2.74
T - 4 5.48
V - 4 5.48
F - 4 5.48
R - 8 10.96
J - 8 10.96
Y - 4 5.48
G - 16 21.92
N - 4 5.48

Total - 73 100.00

So, where I'm wrong? Anyone knows?

Pedro

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 17:00:50 -0000

Anyone planning on updating a blog during the World Championships?? I

great competition - but I know I (and many others) would probably like
to follow along in semi-real time??

So, if there's a blog coming up out here, let us know!

thanks,

yeff






34. Re: PLL probabilities
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 17:13:41 -0000

Your mistake is in the N-perm. Each of the N-perm cases has probability 1/72 (it is the same situation even when you rotate), so N should be 2 (1 for the N and 1 for its mirror). Also, don't forget the solved case. This makes a total of 72 cases. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Hey, folks! > I came up with something similar to this question a while ago, but I > have another doubt... > > I was wondering about the PLL probabilities. One way I've found to > know it was: > > check the number of probabilities for each case and make the % of the > total. So, for example, the U perm have 8 possible cases: > -each of the 4 colors can be the correct side and we have clockwise > and counter-clockwise direction, so 4x2=8 > > for the A is the same thing...and etc > > I got 73 cases in total, but I think something is wrong, cause my % > do not match with the probabilities on Fridrich's site... > > here's what I got: > > % > U - 8 10.96 > A - 8 10.96 > Z - 2 2.74 > H - 1 1.37 > E - 2 2.74 > T - 4 5.48 > V - 4 5.48 > F - 4 5.48 > R - 8 10.96 > J - 8 10.96 > Y - 4 5.48 > G - 16 21.92 > N - 4 5.48 > > Total - 73 100.00 > > So, where I'm wrong? Anyone knows? > > Pedro >
35. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: PLL probabilities
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 14:19:30 -0300 (ART)

Each of the N-perm cases has probability 1/72 (it is the same situation even when you rotate), so N should be 2 (1 for the N and 1 for its mirror). Also, don't forget the solved case. This makes a total of 72 cases. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Hey, folks! > I came up with something similar to this question a while ago, but I > have another doubt... > > I was wondering about the PLL probabilities. Acesso Grátis: a cada hora navegada você acumula cupons e concorre a mais de 500 prêmios! Participe! [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
36. Re: [Speed cubing group] Blindfold solving
From: "Bill McGaugh" <bmcgaugh49@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 09:31:58 -0800

Hi Duncan,

Thanks for studying my method, and congratulations for succeeding with it

As far as edge permutations, as I described on the web page, I identify the edges
as letters and make a sentence or two, using the edge letters as the first letters of words.
I also sometimes put 3 letters together into a word. Other people just memorize everything
as numbers. I think the more advanced solvers just remember the path with pure spatial visualization.
I think it depends on your particular mental strengths. Sometimes I do 6 or 7 edges with a sentence...and
then just visualize the rest.

As with everything, its all about practice. I find remembering the edge perms many times easier than I did a few
months ago. I have a few common themes that I use to construct sentences..a library of possible words...
and the construction of a meaningful sentence is quick and easy...and I am 56 years old.

I may write up the more advanced (3-cycle) extension of my method soon...world class times should be
very possible with the advanced method (for people who can perform all the algs as fast fingertricks). I think, in
the near future, I will be able to average 1-2 minutes for memorization and 2-4 for execution with the improved method...and I have very slow hand technique.

Bill




----- Original Message -----
From: Duncan Dicks
Sent: Monday, October 31, 2005 8:44 AM
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Blindfold solving

Hi,
Just a general ramble.
I just came back from a week on holiday in Greece where I set myself the
target of trying blindfold solving again after a break of about 22 years! I
had a look at Bill McGaugh's site before I went
(http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh/) and then sat down on the 3 1/2 hour
flight to think my way through it - trying out little bits of the method.
On the subsequent days I had spare time here and there while wife and kids
were doing other things and altogether I've attempted about 10 solves with
about 50% success. When its wrong its usually a 3-cycle or so because I
just can't quite always remember the right edge permutations.
I now see how the blindfold times are so fast - which isn't to say I don't
think they are very impressive! I was there at the first blindfold world
record of about 20 minutes in 1982 (I think!) and I remember the effort that
John White the solver had to put into it. The new methods make it almost
easy (almost but not quite!). My times are generally around ten minutes
with this method and could clearly be faster with practice and confidence
Anyway fantastic method and well thought out.

Anyone got any way to improve my ageing memory of edge permutations I'd be
glad to take their advice!

Good luck to all blindfold solvers at the WC.

Duncan

I've tested the first 10400 triangle numbers with the highest that I remember so far being 480 factors. Grrr, I know it should be easier than I'm making it! And I definately agree, Kåre. The problems don't seem to be hard in and of themselves, I just royally suck at programming! 42. (OT) Re: Math competition!

43. (OT) Re: Math competition!
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 2005 21:50:16 -0000

Got it with my slightly more efficient algorithm. The fact that I was running it on my ti-89 during class probably didn't help the speed, but it got from the 10400th triangle number to the answer in about 10 minutes. I'll have to port it to java to see how fast it does it there. Instead of checking all numbers between 1 and n/2 to see how many divisors n has, I now do this: if n = P1^n1 * P2^n2 * ... * Pr^nr with Pi prime and for all i=1,...,r , and ni integers. Then the number of divisors = (n1+1)*(n2+1)*...*(nr+1) Worked quite a bit better :) -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" > <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > > > Still haven't gotten stoopid number 12 though. But I did make a > > slightly more efficient brute force alg. I've tested the first > 10400 > > triangle numbers with the highest that I remember so far being 480 > > factors. > > How are you doing it now? > > Stefan >

Practicing blindfold in airplane is the best way to pass time. A week ago I did Blindfold solve for more than 25 times in a 7 hours journey time. Seeing me practicing very seriously, the airhostess gifted me a gift bag consisting of a blindfold, a pair of woolen socks, ear plugs and few more cosmetics. 48. Re: I had a great time today!!
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

50. Re: [Speed cubing group] Blindfold solving
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 1 Nov 2005 09:00:55 -0000

OK so this is what we were doing 20 odd years ago: We wouldn't memorize the state of the cube - but the moves required to put each piece back in place. If a move chosen moved other pieces around we would have to remember where they moved to and build that into the calculations. That is much, much harder than memorizing the orientation and permutation of edges and corners and then having a couple of standard algorithms. I think 20 minutes blindfold using that approach is probably a very good time! So when I say fantastic method I mean in comparison. Its the structure of the method that I like and I agree that with practice doing 3-cycles, orienting and permuting at the same time and other tricks will definitely be within my scope. At the moment it feels like a lot to hold in my head at one time! Thanks Bill and Matt for tips on edge memorizing. I tried using the "Major" memorization method while I was on holiday for the edge cycles - so far as I know this is one of the techniques top memory guys use for number memorization but in principle very similar to what you are suggesting. I need more practice! For edge orientation I remember 3 binary numbers. For corner orientation I create a sentence based on a (anticlockwise), b (blank i.e. no twist required) and c (clockwise) e.g.All Children Buy Cherries And Chew Constantly Choking. For corner permutation I usually have no problem remembering spatially. But I usually memorise the numbers as a double check which is one way having extra confidence will considerably reduce my times. I've tried a few things for edges - the Major method, spatial memory, strings of numbers. I get it right about half the time but I'm hopefully still at a point on the learning curve where it will improve quickly. Thanks for you comments. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Joï¿½l van Noort" <joel_vn@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, October 31, 2005 8:04 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Blindfold solving Fantastic method? If you use two cycles for permuting the edges, why not solve orientation and permutation of edges at the very same time? :) But I agree, bld solving is pretty cool.. I hope to practice it in the airplane a bit tomorrow... - Joï¿½l. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > > Hi, > Just a general ramble. > I just came back from a week on holiday in Greece where I set myself the > target of trying blindfold solving again after a break of about 22 years! I > had a look at Bill McGaugh's site before I went > (http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh/) and then sat down on the 3 1/2 hour > flight to think my way through it - trying out little bits of the method. > On the subsequent days I had spare time here and there while wife and kids > were doing other things and altogether I've attempted about 10 solves with > about 50% success. When its wrong its usually a 3-cycle or so because I > just can't quite always remember the right edge permutations. > I now see how the blindfold times are so fast - which isn't to say I don't > think they are very impressive! I was there at the first blindfold world > record of about 20 minutes in 1982 (I think!) and I remember the effort that > John White the solver had to put into it. The new methods make it almost > easy (almost but not quite!). My times are generally around ten minutes > with this method and could clearly be faster with practice and confidence. > Anyway fantastic method and well thought out. > > Anyone got any way to improve my ageing memory of edge permutations I'd be > glad to take their advice! > > Good luck to all blindfold solvers at the WC. > > Duncan > Yahoo! Groups Links
51. Re: Blindfold solving
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Nov 2005 13:48:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > > Thanks Bill and Matt for tips on edge memorizing. I tried using the "Major" > memorization method while I was on holiday for the edge cycles - so far as I > know this is one of the techniques top memory guys use for number > memorization but in principle very similar to what you are suggesting. Yes, that's correct, but keep in mind that they get numbers as input! They don't memorize them as numbers, instead they translate them to mental images using the major method. It's because numbers are too abstract. I guess I'll never really understand why any blindcuber would want to translate a cubie to a number, then the number to a mental image, instead of simply translating the cubie to a mental image directly, which looks safer and faster to me. Cheers! Stefan
52. self-correcting algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Nov 2005 16:31:52 -0000

A while ago I posted an E-perm algorithm, now I noticed I can make a
mistake and still get it right. Actually I don't remember which
version I posted, but here are both that I found to work now:

l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' l' U
l' U' L' U R U' L U R' U' L U R U' L' U

Ok, so it's not really self-correcting of course. But I can get the
worst l/L wrong and fix it easily at the end (where it's obvious cause
the cube is right before being solved). Confusing single and double
layer twists was one of the larger reasons I had trouble learning this
alg. I think I posted the first version back then. So if you didn't
like that one, try the second one now...

Cheers!
Stefan






53. Re: 1978 cubes
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Nov 2005 17:12:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > Ton is a strange guy. If you have a collection of 600 or more different pieces, and you have your special moment where you can show one item to the audience on live tv, which would you show? Well, Ton showed the world an old, worn out light blue box with a Politechnika cube from 1978... Booooooring. :-) Why not your solid silver cube, or your signed cube or your most expensive cube?????? > > Ron Hi Ron, I can easily see Ton showing off his 1978 cube since cubes from that year are very rare. Ton's cube rates highly among other cubes because 1978 was the first year of manufacture. Most of those other cubes of his were made after the name "Rubik's Cube" was coined. Let me tell you about my 1978 cube. In 1978 Bela Szalai, the owner of Logical Games Inc, discovered the cube while visiting Hungary. One of the cubes that he took home with him (to the USA) he sent to a professional game analyst, Sid Sackson, to check it over and estimate whether it would be successful. I now have this cube. After the cube got the OK, Mr. Szalai got more cubes from Hungary and began selling them, and later he began making them. The cubes he made were marketed first in 1979. It wasn't until the next year, 1980, that Ideal began making them and named them "Rubik's Cube." Before that they were called "Magic Cube" and "Charm Cube." Anyway, my 1978 cube was one of the first cubes in the USA. Because of the stickers and the paperwork, you can tell that it's from an earlier batch than Ton's 1978. As you might expect it's #1 in my collection. I enjoyed the videos. Thanks for posting them. And of course, congratulations all around! Have fun in Orlando! David J
54. Supercube parity correction
From: giraffeboy13 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Nov 2005 17:45:56 -0000

So i was told to use the orientation correction algorithm that i use
for a 4x4 to correct the parity error inside of the last center of the
super 5x5. The way that i solve a 4x4 though i don't end up with an
orientation error. Can anyone post the agorithm that works?

~John~

60. Re: [Speed cubing group] Blindfold solving
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 1 Nov 2005 10:20:35 -0800

Hi Jeff, I think my method for solving the 3x3x3 cube is exactly the same as most people out there. Uh, just 3-cycles. I orient the corners, orient the edges, permute the corners, permute the edges. I use the same method as Macky and Leyan. I don't really do anything advanced like Dave Orser or anything special. I have a very limited set of algorithms. My fast times are due to my memorization time which I can sometimes do under 40 seconds and also the smoothness of executing the algorithms. If the memorization is solid, then I don't ever have to sit and "think" about what the next set of moves are. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Nov 1, 2005, at 9:59 AM, Jeff Soesbe wrote: > Tyson -- > > Out of curiousity, what "method" do you use? I'm sure part of your > times is due to your fast times in 3x, but any special "speed" aspects > to your method (if you want to share)? > > Since you are the current world record holder and one of the top > blindfolders, I'm sure many would be interested in your approach. > > Thanks! > > yeff > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> >> My blindfold times have been quite poor lately so I've been trying > to >> practice a lot. I didn't get much practicing done in the last few >> weeks unfortunately. I think, though, after about 8 solves, my >> blindfold ability starts to decline as the mind gets tired... but >> that's just me. >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology > > >>>> had a look at Bill McGaugh's site before I went >>>> (http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh/) and then sat down on the > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > >

63. Re: Supercube parity correction
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Nov 2005 18:56:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, giraffeboy13 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > So i was told to use the orientation correction algorithm that i use > for a 4x4 to correct the parity error inside of the last center of the > super 5x5. The way that i solve a 4x4 though i don't end up with an > orientation error. Can anyone post the agorithm that works? > > ~John~ > Hey John, For me this alg is by far the fastest super5x5 parity fix. Look at the "+" edges in relation to the centralmost centerpiece. If those edges are in an odd permutation you have parity. So you can solve parity before you even think about starting to solve edges. The algs is (R'r' U2)x4 R'r' It messes up edges a bit and it switches centers as (blU <-> frU) (flU <-> brU) (lsU <-> rsU) Plus it is very fast to execute. Hope that helps. Chris
64. Re: Supercube parity correction
From: giraffeboy13 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Nov 2005 19:39:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, giraffeboy13 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Wow, nevermind! I just knew there must be something > wrong but I didn't know what, and my post was my way to say so. What > is it that you figured out now? > > The way you solve 4x4 is not unusual, btw, it's how most of us do it. > And we all end up with the orientation parity half of the time, that's > why it seemed strange you don't. > > Cheers! > Stefan > thanks. I do end up with some orientation parities at the end of solving a 4x4 but in trying to see what other people did to solve them, i was never quite able to find a solution to my corner error. I do almost always have to execute a dedge flip (gotten off of your website stefan because my algorithm was ridiculously long) Only that corner error seemed to be the one thing that no one else returned. that's why i figured i must be doing something different. ~John~

But I can get the > worst l/L wrong and fix it easily at the end (where it's obvious cause > the cube is right before being solved). Confusing single and double > layer twists was one of the larger reasons I had trouble learning this > alg. I think I posted the first version back then. So if you didn't > like that one, try the second one now... > > Cheers! > Stefan > So you have that the commutator [U R' U' L U R U',Ll'] is the identity.

I don't really do anything advanced > like Dave Orser or anything special. I have a very limited set of > algorithms. > > My fast times are due to my memorization time which I can sometimes do > under 40 seconds and also the smoothness of executing the algorithms. > If the memorization is solid, then I don't ever have to sit and "think" > about what the next set of moves are. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 1, 2005, at 9:59 AM, Jeff Soesbe wrote: > >> Tyson -- >> >> Out of curiousity, what "method" do you use? I'm sure part of your >> times is due to your fast times in 3x, but any special "speed" aspects >> to your method (if you want to share)? >> >> Since you are the current world record holder and one of the top >> blindfolders, I'm sure many would be interested in your approach. >> >> Thanks! >> >> yeff >> >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> >> wrote: >>> >>> My blindfold times have been quite poor lately so I've been trying >> to >>> practice a lot. I didn't get much practicing done in the last few >>> weeks unfortunately. I think, though, after about 8 solves, my >>> blindfold ability starts to decline as the mind gets tired... but >>> that's just me. >>> >>> Tyson Mao >>> MSC #631 >>> California Institute of Technology >> >> >>>>> had a look at Bill McGaugh's site before I went >>>>> (http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh/) and then sat down on the >> >> >> >> >> >> >> >> Yahoo! Groups Links >> >> >> >> >> >> > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle > Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of > Service. > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > --------------------------------- > Promoção Yahoo! Acesso Grátis: a cada hora navegada você > acumula cupons e concorre a mais de 500 prêmios! Participe! > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > Yahoo! 68. Re: [Speed cubing group] Blindfold solving

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 1 Nov 2005 21:18:45 +0000 (GMT)

What??!! Solving corner orientations in 1 alg?? Is that posible? Pedro Tyson Mao <tmao@...> escreveu: Just like... solving corner orientations in like... 1 algorithm or something. I'm not sure. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Nov 1, 2005, at 12:50 PM, Pedro wrote: > What kind of advanced thing do Dave Orser do? Man, solving a cube > blindfolded in less than 1:30 is really incredible! Sometimes I *just > memorise* the cube in 1:10 or 1:20...I really want to know how to get > faster... > > Pedro > > Tyson Mao <tmao@...> escreveu: > Hi Jeff, > > I think my method for solving the 3x3x3 cube is exactly the same as > most people out there. Uh, just 3-cycles. I orient the corners, > orient the edges, permute the corners, permute the edges. I use the > same method as Macky and Leyan. I don't really do anything advanced > like Dave Orser or anything special. I have a very limited set of > algorithms. > > My fast times are due to my memorization time which I can sometimes do > under 40 seconds and also the smoothness of executing the algorithms. > If the memorization is solid, then I don't ever have to sit and "think" > about what the next set of moves are. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 1, 2005, at 9:59 AM, Jeff Soesbe wrote: > >> Tyson -- >> >> Out of curiousity, what "method" do you use? I'm sure part of your >> times is due to your fast times in 3x, but any special "speed" aspects >> to your method (if you want to share)? >> >> Since you are the current world record holder and one of the top >> blindfolders, I'm sure many would be interested in your approach. >> >> Thanks! >> >> yeff >> >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> >> wrote: >>> >>> My blindfold times have been quite poor lately so I've been trying >> to >>> practice a lot. I didn't get much practicing done in the last few >>> weeks unfortunately. I think, though, after about 8 solves, my >>> blindfold ability starts to decline as the mind gets tired... but >>> that's just me. >>> >>> Tyson Mao >>> MSC #631 >>> California Institute of Technology >> >> >>>>> had a look at Bill McGaugh's site before I went >>>>> (http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh/) and then sat down on the >> >> >> >> >> >> >> >> Yahoo! Is that posible? > > Pedro > > Tyson Mao <tmao@...> escreveu: > Just like... solving corner orientations in like... 1 algorithm or > something. I'm not sure. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 1, 2005, at 12:50 PM, Pedro wrote: > >> What kind of advanced thing do Dave Orser do? Man, solving a cube >> blindfolded in less than 1:30 is really incredible! Sometimes I *just >> memorise* the cube in 1:10 or 1:20...I really want to know how to get >> faster... >> >> Pedro >> >> Tyson Mao <tmao@...> escreveu: >> Hi Jeff, >> >> I think my method for solving the 3x3x3 cube is exactly the same as >> most people out there. Uh, just 3-cycles. I orient the corners, >> orient the edges, permute the corners, permute the edges. I use the >> same method as Macky and Leyan. I don't really do anything advanced >> like Dave Orser or anything special. I have a very limited set of >> algorithms. >> >> My fast times are due to my memorization time which I can sometimes do >> under 40 seconds and also the smoothness of executing the algorithms. >> If the memorization is solid, then I don't ever have to sit and >> "think" >> about what the next set of moves are. >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology >> >> On Nov 1, 2005, at 9:59 AM, Jeff Soesbe wrote: >> >>> Tyson -- >>> >>> Out of curiousity, what "method" do you use? 72. F(n-1)L columnar solution to 20x20x20 supercube
From: "Rob Butler" <futuese@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Nov 2005 22:25:10 -0000




Columnar F(n-1)L for really big cubes.

For anyone who might have any interest, here is a brief description
of the technique I used to solve the 20x20x20 Gabbasoft Supercube.
I have uploaded a series of representative screenshots to the photos
section so you can also see how the solution comes together (folder
name: "20x20 Supercube"). The technique can be applied to both
regular cubes and supercubes and can be used on even or odd cubes of
any size. I include in [brackets] the readings of the move counter
and clock at the end of each stage. To spare you the suspense the
whole solve required just over 9,500 moves and took just under 12
hours. N.B.: for this solve I kept White on BOTTOM and Yellow on
UP, thus Red, Blue, Green, and Orange are sometimes referred to
as 'middle' faces.

Step 1: solve white centers on bottom (black arrows)
[move counter: 1255, timer: 50min, 27 sec]
Step 2: set up white corners together with middle edges
(orange/blue, red/blue, orange/green, red/green)
[move counter: 1476, timer: 1hr, 15 min, 16 sec]

Step 3: solve an entire column of centers along with the white edge
piece. With just a little practice and forethought this can be done
intuitively. Repeat this step as often as necessary until three of
the four middle sides are complete. To make piece recognition a
little easier for a cube as large as the 20x20x20 I started with the
outermost columns and worked my way towards the middle. For the
20x20x20 supercube solve this step was repeated 54 times until the
red, blue, and green faces were all complete.
[move counter: 5812, timer: 7 hrs, 27 min, 48 sec]
Step 4a: solve half the columns of the remaining F19L middle face
(orange) intuitively.
[move counter: 6413, timer: 8 hrs, 12 min, 55 sec]
Step 4b: solve as many of the remaining (orange) centers intuitively
as possible and then solve the remaining centers using three-cycles.
[move counter: 7248, timer: 9 hrs, 11 min, 33 sec]

F19L Complete - move to LL (yellow)

Step 5: solve LAST LAYER CORNERS. (N.B.: on the 5x5x5 cube it is
usually advisable to simply use OLL and PLL moves to solve both the
corners and the middle edge of the last layer  thus one only has
the remaining 8 edges left to three-cycle. On the 20x20x20 this
tactic will not work so simply solve the corners as you will using
either COLL or OC, PC).
[move counter: 7294, timer: 9 hrs, 15 min, 33 sec]
Step 6: solve the LAST LAYER EDGES using three-cycles where possible
and a pair swap when necessary due to parity. On the 20x20x20
supercube I started with the orbit adjacent to the corners and
worked my way systematically towards the middle edge pairs. (N.B.:
On a standard cube this will complete the solution but on a
supercube we still have one more step to perform.)
[move counter: 7857, timer: 9 hrs, 52 min, 41 sec]
Step 7: solve the LAST LAYER CENTERS using three-cycles. Again I
started with the outermost `circle' of centers and worked my way
systematically towards the very center of the yellow face.
[move counter: 9519, timer: 11 hrs, 55 min, 56 sec]


NOTE 1: There are many shortcuts and minor adaptations that can be
applied to make a 5x5x5 solution faster but I use the steps as
outlined above when solving really big cubes.
NOTE 2: Steps 1-4a can all be performed intuitively, while steps 4b,
6, and 7 can all be solved using very similar three-cycles. Thus
the entire cube can be solved, regardless of its size, using just a
handful of algs.
NOTE 3: If anyone wishes to make use of these pics please feel free,
though I would appreciate being informed. I actually have many more
pics showing the solution in greater step-by-step detail  64 pics
in total of which I only posted here just enough to hopefully make
the solution path clear to all viewers. Again the pics are in the
photos section under the folder title "20x20 Supercube".



Enjoy solving really big (super) cubes,

Rob









73. Re: [Speed cubing group] Blindfold solving
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Nov 2005 23:05:02 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > What??!! Solving corner orientations in 1 alg?? Is that posible? > > Pedro Yes. Using symmetries you can reduce corner orientation to 66 non-isomorphic algorithms - or less with inversions. If you use set-ups (conjugation) you can take that down, although you'll have to think the conjugation up on the fly, ensure it is correct and probably lose time on both of those. You can use 76 non-isomorphic algorithms (without set up moves) to solve the edge orientations (or, of course, 6 if you use set up moves). I taught Dave to blindfold cube on the chat here and I sent him a lot of algorithms. I'm not sure what Dave uses now and I can only speculate, but he learned a lot of my intermediate system and he used more of it than most people - in particular, he might have learned all the corner orientation moves from my "intermediate" system which does corner orientation in one algorithm and also edge orientation in one algorithm. I know that he had learned a lot of moves from the middle stages. I'd told him that I believed that this sort of time (well under 2 minutes) was possible with that system and he learned an impressive amount of it. I sent him some specific permutation moves too, bespoke to his situation, that were in my advanced system but not my intermediate one but not too many of those. I guess he probably uses a lot of other moves too from other sources or of his own. Alternatively, I guess he might have switched to a completely different method like a cycle method. Of course, you can use one of 94,518 non-isomorphic algorithms to do both corner and edge orientations in one go... > > Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> escreveu: > Just like... solving corner orientations in like... 1 algorithm or > something. I'm not sure. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 1, 2005, at 12:50 PM, Pedro wrote: > > > What kind of advanced thing do Dave Orser do? Man, solving a cube > > blindfolded in less than 1:30 is really incredible! Sometimes I *just > > memorise* the cube in 1:10 or 1:20...I really want to know how to get > > faster... > > > > Pedro > > > > Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> escreveu: > > Hi Jeff, > > > > I think my method for solving the 3x3x3 cube is exactly the same as > > most people out there. Uh, just 3-cycles. I orient the corners, > > orient the edges, permute the corners, permute the edges. I use the > > same method as Macky and Leyan. I don't really do anything advanced > > like Dave Orser or anything special. I have a very limited set of > > algorithms. > > > > My fast times are due to my memorization time which I can sometimes do > > under 40 seconds and also the smoothness of executing the algorithms. > > If the memorization is solid, then I don't ever have to sit and "think" > > about what the next set of moves are. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Nov 1, 2005, at 9:59 AM, Jeff Soesbe wrote: > > > >> Tyson -- > >> > >> Out of curiousity, what "method" do you use? I'm sure part of your > >> times is due to your fast times in 3x, but any special "speed" aspects > >> to your method (if you want to share)? > >> > >> Since you are the current world record holder and one of the top > >> blindfolders, I'm sure many would be interested in your approach. > >> > >> Thanks! > >> > >> yeff > >> > >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > >> wrote: > >>> > >>> My blindfold times have been quite poor lately so I've been trying > >> to > >>> practice a lot. I didn't get much practicing done in the last few > >>> weeks unfortunately. I think, though, after about 8 solves, my > >>> blindfold ability starts to decline as the mind gets tired... but > >>> that's just me. > >>> > >>> Tyson Mao > >>> MSC #631 > >>> California Institute of Technology > >> > >> > >>>>> had a look at Bill McGaugh's site before I went > >>>>> (http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh/) and then sat down on the > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> Yahoo! Groups Links > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle > > Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > > > --------------------------------- > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of > > Service. > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > Promoção Yahoo! Acesso Grátis: a cada hora navegada você > > acumula cupons e concorre a mais de 500 prêmios! Participe! > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > --------------------------------- > Promoção Yahoo! Acesso Grátis: a cada hora navegada você > acumula cupons e concorre a mais de 500 prêmios! Participe! > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] >
74. how to search the yahoo groups
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Nov 2005 00:59:24 -0000

Here's a nice little trick to search the yahoo groups faster than by
the ridiculous 30 at a time (are you reading this, yahoo developers???)

http://www.google.com/search?
q=inurl:games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube+%22R%22+%
22F%22+%22L%22+%22B%22+%22D%22+%22U%
22&num=100&hl=nl&lr=&c2coff=1&as_qdr=all&filter=0

This is a search for 'any algorithm', but you creative people can
probably invent other uses.

Michiel

Pedro, Tyson's just a freak, so don't worry. It usually takes me over a minute to memorize the cube as well, so you're in good company. Tyson just gets lots of practice by stalking girls and memorizing their phone numbers :-P Leyan Pedro wrote: > What kind of advanced thing do Dave Orser do? Man, solving a cube blindfolded in less than 1:30 is really incredible! Sometimes I *just memorise* the cube in 1:10 or 1:20...I really want to know how to get faster... > > Pedro > > Tyson Mao <tmao@...> escreveu: > Hi Jeff, > > I think my method for solving the 3x3x3 cube is exactly the same as > most people out there. Uh, just 3-cycles. I orient the corners, > orient the edges, permute the corners, permute the edges. I use the > same method as Macky and Leyan. I don't really do anything advanced > like Dave Orser or anything special. I have a very limited set of > algorithms. > > My fast times are due to my memorization time which I can sometimes do > under 40 seconds and also the smoothness of executing the algorithms. > If the memorization is solid, then I don't ever have to sit and "think" > about what the next set of moves are. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 1, 2005, at 9:59 AM, Jeff Soesbe wrote: > > >>Tyson -- >> >>Out of curiousity, what "method" do you use? Hmm...but...I was wondering...in how much time do Dave memorise? To do a 1:30 total time, he have to memorise in like 35 seconds...or does he just have a fast execution? Pedro PS.:I'm a slow executer. I usually memorise on 1:10 or 1:20, and execute in 2:10 or 2:20...So, I'm around 3:35-3:40 times on good solves. Is there a way to accelerate execution? Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...> escreveu: Pedro, Tyson's just a freak, so don't worry. It usually takes me over a minute to memorize the cube as well, so you're in good company. Tyson just gets lots of practice by stalking girls and memorizing their phone numbers :-P Leyan Pedro wrote: > What kind of advanced thing do Dave Orser do? Man, solving a cube blindfolded in less than 1:30 is really incredible! Sometimes I *just memorise* the cube in 1:10 or 1:20...I really want to know how to get faster... > > Pedro > > Tyson Mao <tmao@...> escreveu: > Hi Jeff, > > I think my method for solving the 3x3x3 cube is exactly the same as > most people out there. Uh, just 3-cycles. I orient the corners, > orient the edges, permute the corners, permute the edges. I use the > same method as Macky and Leyan. I don't really do anything advanced > like Dave Orser or anything special. I have a very limited set of > algorithms. > > My fast times are due to my memorization time which I can sometimes do > under 40 seconds and also the smoothness of executing the algorithms. > If the memorization is solid, then I don't ever have to sit and "think" > about what the next set of moves are. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 1, 2005, at 9:59 AM, Jeff Soesbe wrote: > > >>Tyson -- >> >>Out of curiousity, what "method" do you use? 79. Re: [Speed cubing group] Blindfold solving
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 2 Nov 2005 02:57:09 +0000 (GMT)

So, where are your systems? I'm really interested on accelerating my CO... Pedro GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > What??!! Solving corner orientations in 1 alg?? Is that posible? > > Pedro Yes. Using symmetries you can reduce corner orientation to 66 non-isomorphic algorithms - or less with inversions. If you use set-ups (conjugation) you can take that down, although you'll have to think the conjugation up on the fly, ensure it is correct and probably lose time on both of those. You can use 76 non-isomorphic algorithms (without set up moves) to solve the edge orientations (or, of course, 6 if you use set up moves). I taught Dave to blindfold cube on the chat here and I sent him a lot of algorithms. I'm not sure what Dave uses now and I can only speculate, but he learned a lot of my intermediate system and he used more of it than most people - in particular, he might have learned all the corner orientation moves from my "intermediate" system which does corner orientation in one algorithm and also edge orientation in one algorithm. I know that he had learned a lot of moves from the middle stages. I'd told him that I believed that this sort of time (well under 2 minutes) was possible with that system and he learned an impressive amount of it. I sent him some specific permutation moves too, bespoke to his situation, that were in my advanced system but not my intermediate one but not too many of those. I guess he probably uses a lot of other moves too from other sources or of his own. Alternatively, I guess he might have switched to a completely different method like a cycle method. Of course, you can use one of 94,518 non-isomorphic algorithms to do both corner and edge orientations in one go... > > Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> escreveu: > Just like... solving corner orientations in like... 1 algorithm or > something. I'm not sure. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 1, 2005, at 12:50 PM, Pedro wrote: > > > What kind of advanced thing do Dave Orser do? Man, solving a cube > > blindfolded in less than 1:30 is really incredible! Sometimes I *just > > memorise* the cube in 1:10 or 1:20...I really want to know how to get > > faster... > > > > Pedro > > > > Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> escreveu: > > Hi Jeff, > > > > I think my method for solving the 3x3x3 cube is exactly the same as > > most people out there. Uh, just 3-cycles. I orient the corners, > > orient the edges, permute the corners, permute the edges. I use the > > same method as Macky and Leyan. I don't really do anything advanced > > like Dave Orser or anything special. I have a very limited set of > > algorithms. > > > > My fast times are due to my memorization time which I can sometimes do > > under 40 seconds and also the smoothness of executing the algorithms. > > If the memorization is solid, then I don't ever have to sit and "think" > > about what the next set of moves are. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Nov 1, 2005, at 9:59 AM, Jeff Soesbe wrote: > > > >> Tyson -- > >> > >> Out of curiousity, what "method" do you use? I'm sure part of your > >> times is due to your fast times in 3x, but any special "speed" aspects > >> to your method (if you want to share)? > >> > >> Since you are the current world record holder and one of the top > >> blindfolders, I'm sure many would be interested in your approach. > >> > >> Thanks! > >> > >> yeff > >> > >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > >> wrote: > >>> > >>> My blindfold times have been quite poor lately so I've been trying > >> to > >>> practice a lot. I didn't get much practicing done in the last few > >>> weeks unfortunately. I think, though, after about 8 solves, my > >>> blindfold ability starts to decline as the mind gets tired... but > >>> that's just me. > >>> > >>> Tyson Mao > >>> MSC #631 > >>> California Institute of Technology > >> > >> > >>>>> had a look at Bill McGaugh's site before I went > >>>>> (http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh/) and then sat down on the > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> Yahoo! Groups Links > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle > > Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > > > --------------------------------- > > YAHOO! 83. help with the lars petrus method
From: "habbywall" <nick@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Nov 2005 12:38:03 -0000

i dont really understand anything after step three of the lars petrus method could
someone please explain it better?
i understand 1,2,3 but nothing after that





84. Re: [Speed cubing group] help with the lars petrus method
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 2 Nov 2005 08:29:54 -0800 (PST)

well the next step is to assemble 2 more edges and the corner that goes in between it, if you've flipped your edges right this is pretty easy to do. once u get your corner twisted the right way, if you put it in the layer with nothing built in it, when its pointed one way its the color of one edge sticking out and the other side will bring the other color out. so you find one of the edges that match one of the other colors and move it so that you can put it into position, then move the corner around to the side so its not affected by the edge's positioning turn, move the edge into place, then bring the corner back. its always really hard to explain things via text, but if this doesn't help i can probably make you a video tonite when i get home from work. then its putting the last corner edge pair together and putting it in place which just takes some practice. then the last layer has 3 steps, position corners, orient corners, permute edges. each of these last layer steps can be accomplished with 1 algorithm for each, niklas, sune, and allan respectively. --- habbywall <nick@...> wrote: > i dont really understand anything after step three > of the lars petrus method could > someone please explain it better? > i understand 1,2,3 but nothing after that > > > > __________________________________ Yahoo! FareChase: Search multiple travel sites in one click. http://farechase.yahoo.com
85. Re: 1978 cubes
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Nov 2005 17:31:21 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > Anyway, my 1978 cube was one of the first cubes in the USA. Because > of > > the stickers and the paperwork, you can tell that it's from an > earlier > > batch than Ton's 1978. As you might expect it's #1 in my collection. > > Hi David, > > could you show us a picture of your cube and that "paperwork"? As I > wrote in my earlier reply, I totally agree with Ton as well, I like > these old cubes a lot, too. > > Thanks, > Stefan Hi Stefan, I don't have a photo of the cube, or a scan of the paperwork, yet. I'll give you two small quotes from the paperwork. "The unit pieces are actually hollow with a cover plate which can come loose and impede turning." ".... With new cubes, anticlockwise turning may cause this [the centre of the face] to unscrew. If so, peel off the colour from the face-centre piece and you will find a tightly fitting cover plate. Pressing the screw up into the piece will push off the plate..." Cheers, David J
86. Re: 1978 cubes
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Nov 2005 17:35:30 -0000

Hi Chris P., The color scheme is Red opposite Orange, Yellow opposite White, Blue opposite Green - with Blue Yellow Orange clockwise, so it's BYO not the BOY arrangement. The Red is lighter, the Yellow is more Gold, and the Orange is brighter than nowadays. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "christopher_pelley" <christopher_pelley@y...> wrote: > > Yes this is a fascinating topic. I would be interested to know the > exact color scheme. I saw an early cube back in the 80s and it seemed > to have different colors (i.e. blue, green, and white on one corner, > and a lighter shade of green). > > Chris Pelley > > > > Hi David, > > > > could you show us a picture of your cube and that "paperwork"? As I > > wrote in my earlier reply, I totally agree with Ton as well, I like > > these old cubes a lot, too. > > > > Thanks, > > Stefan > > >
87. Where at Pop Century?
From: "christopher_pelley" <christopher_pelley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Nov 2005 17:41:16 -0000

Does anyone know precisely where within the Pop Century resort the
competition will be held? I assume there is some kind of events
building, or will it be outdoors?

For those who haven't seen the resort, there are giant Rubik's Cubes
you can actually walk inside of. The cubes have the 1980 style logo
and are accurately colored and in various states of scramble. When
you check in, make sure to request the 80s/90s section to be near the
cubes.

Chris Pelley






88. Re: Blindfold solving
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Nov 2005 17:45:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > So, where are your systems? I'm really interested on accelerating my CO... > > Pedro Check message 17059. Please remember not to overload the maths server though.
89. Re: 1978 cubes
From: "christopher_pelley" <christopher_pelley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Nov 2005 18:14:53 -0000

Interesting... From what I can make out of Ton's cube in the video, it has red opposite white, yellow opposite orange, and blue opposite green. The orange and green are much brighter (paler shades) as you mention. This scheme was also used on Meffert's assembly cubes a few years ago, although the BOY-BYO are reversed from Ton's cube. Thanks for the info. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi Chris P., > > The color scheme is Red opposite Orange, Yellow opposite White, Blue > opposite Green - with Blue Yellow Orange clockwise, so it's BYO not > the BOY arrangement. The Red is lighter, the Yellow is more Gold, and > the Orange is brighter than nowadays. > > Cheers, > > David J

Date: Wed, 02 Nov 2005 20:55:10 -0000

91. Re: 1978 cubes
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Nov 2005 22:24:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > ".... With new cubes, anticlockwise turning may cause this [the centre > of the face] to unscrew. If so, peel off the colour from the > face-centre piece and you will find a tightly fitting cover plate. > Pressing the screw up into the piece will push off the plate..." Hi David, thanks for the info. If you can some day take pictures of the cube and papers it'd still be great. But that quote of pushing off the plate is a completely mean joke. This kind of center/centercap is by far the worst I've seen: http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/old_center.jpg The cap fits into a hole and it touches its sides and bottom. And what a surprise, it's glued rock hard. No way to get it out nicely. I have another cube which has the same pieces except the edges and corners don't have caps. The way I opened the centers was to cut through the cap with a dremel clone, taking out a square piece of it and replacing it with a new piece of polystyrol sheet. That was a lot of hard annoying work and it's not perfect but good enough... Cheers! Stefan

clock in 12.66s. What competition are we talking about? Just wondering.
Franï¿½ois

95. newspaper articles
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Nov 2005 23:34:59 -0000

The new issue of my university newspaper has a page devoted to Rubik's
cube:
http://www.tu-darmstadt.de/aktuell/hoch3/

It's on page 12. It's German, though. On the left there's an article
about the cube and its history, on the bottom is one that shows how
the cube is a mathematical group, and the middle is about me, they
interviewed me half a year ago.

It's quite nice, no annoying errors and the author apparently put some
thought into it and tried to really understand things (what you should
expect from a university newspaper, I guess). He told me he had great
fun writing it :-)

Cheers!
Stefan

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 03 Nov 2005 00:40:05 -0000

If you can some day take pictures of the cube and > papers it'd still be great. > > But that quote of pushing off the plate is a completely mean joke. > This kind of center/centercap is by far the worst I've seen: > > http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/old_center.jpg > > The cap fits into a hole and it touches its sides and bottom. I believe that first year or so saw a lot of experimentation. Many things were tried, some discarded, some kept. I know the stickers went though changes. I think there was an earlier run than the batch my 1978 cube is from. Cheers, David J
101. OH MY GOD! Sub-20!!
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 03 Nov 2005 01:36:39 -0000

Hey all... I wanted to share some very very exciting news (for me!). :)

I started cubing in 2001, switched to Fridrich in February and started
cubing seriously then, and tonight it happened:

(13.34) 18.29 17.52 22.01 18.88 20.97 (22.42) 18.76 18.37 20.52 18.26
19.90 => 19.35

There were no lucky times. ;)

I was very excited when this happened! :D It was my goal to achieve
this before WC. I cut it very close, but did it with style. :)
Thanks to everybody who has given me advice in this group since I
started cubing.

~ Bob

113. Re: my new auctions
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 03 Nov 2005 13:36:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > Howcome you sell so much stuff, Stefan?? Is it things that you find > boring to solve or what? Hehe, well... I don't think any of them are boring on their own, but I have many puzzles so I just don't have the time to play with all of them even though I do spend nearly all my time with cubing. So you could say some are less interesting for me than others. But at some point I was interested in each of them, otherwise I wouldn't have bought them. And I have solved all puzzles I'm selling, I wouldn't want to give one away that I can't solve yet. Also, I noticed I'm more of a solver than a collector, so I don't have to keep all puzzles I have. Except puzzles from childhood, I won't give those away because of the emotional connection and some memories. Other reasons are that I have many duplicates and I really don't need all of them, and that my room is filled with puzzles which is somewhat a burden and I want to get some free space again, and last but not least it'll help getting a positive bank account balance again. Cheers! Stefan
114. Re: OH MY GOD! Sub-20!!
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

121. Re: blast from the past: ancient puzzles return!
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 03 Nov 2005 22:56:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Speaking of weights...did you weigh your cubes for that bet you made? > > ~ Bob Yes I did! I bought a digital scale the Monday afterwards (cause I need it for weighing postal packages anyway). And they differed by about 3 grams, about 132.5 versus 135.5 grams. But... the other way around, not like Mr T. thought :-). I remember I thought if they differ at all I'd expect it the other one to be heavier cause it's filled with more silicone, otherwise they should be pretty much identical. Cheers! Stefan

127. WC2005 media coverage? (one from sacramento, ca)
From: "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Nov 2005 22:27:47 -0000

Hi All --

Thought I'd start a thread on any media coverage for WC2005.

One from Sacramento, CA: Channel 58 had a short video item, mostly
likely taken from another station, talking about a competitor going to
the world championships who was going to be doing the cube with his
feet.

It was Chris Szlatenyi, who I see is listed in the unofficial world
records for 3x w/feet (second in both fastest time, average).

That's the only coverage I've seen so far. Others??

yeff

I am disappointed and deeply hurt.

I would be very happy if the results are posted immediately.

with deeply hurt heart,
J.Bernett Orlando

139. Finished with Fridrich
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Nov 2005 22:01:13 -0000

I know that there's no one here but I thought I'd announce it cause
it's kind of exciting: I finished learning the Fridrich method, and
just about 1 year from when I started.

What I plan to do next:
1. Solidify what I already know (no-brainer)
2. Improve some of my algorithms
3. Learn more advanced F2L
4. Learn COLL

I know I'm a slow algorithm learner, but do you guys think I have my
future priorities straight?

-Ben.

143. [Speed cubing group] Contest times better than ever
From: Mark Longridge <cubeman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 6 Nov 2005 05:37:22 -0500

Wow, I just checked out the top 36 on rubiks.com and
the top 33 all were under 20 seconds at least once.

Looks like Bob Peters didn't go but there are a few
new names like Matt Walter who was in the top 36.
I guess 16.39 s is the new national record for Canada
unless Matt breaks his own record on Sunday.

Jean Pons solved all three of his cubes in less than
15 seconds...

top 5 all under 15 seconds.

Only 1st generation cubists I could see were Lars Petrus
and Chris Pelley.

Mark

I had dinner with him just before he left for Orlando.
He had sub-15'' times even after some beers.

His F2L (after cross on top) is just 100% amazing.

Now that he had the opportunity to train on stackmat
the month before Orlando, I guess he might become
dangerous also in competition.

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Nov 2005 13:25:40 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@f...> wrote: > His F2L (after cross on top) is just 100% amazing. I guess I should track down a video to answer this, but where does he put the cross during F2L? Mike
149. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Contest times better than ever
From: "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 6 Nov 2005 15:18:58 +0100

----- Original Message ----- From: "mike_go_uk" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Sunday, November 06, 2005 2:25 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Contest times better than ever > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "FD-Rubik" > <fdrubik@f...> wrote: > > His F2L (after cross on top) is just 100% amazing. > > I guess I should track down a video to answer this, but where does he > put the cross during F2L? On bottom. He solves 3 edges on top, then usually turns the cube upside-down while inserting the 4th one, and doing some [D,D',D2] in the process. I have the impression that he usually only needs 2 seconds to insert the 2 last pairs, averaging 8'' for the whole F2L, "quand il est chaud". -- FD.
150. Re: Contest times better than ever
From: sgowal <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Nov 2005 15:48:58 -0000

Yeah, his world record is so amazing (I watch that video over and over again). BTW I also do the cross on top (and switch sides when inserting last edge), but I'm no where near any record :-): I "only" average 50 seconds (after 2 months) "quand je suis chaud". Sven --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@f...> wrote: > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "mike_go_uk" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Sunday, November 06, 2005 2:25 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Contest times better than ever > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "FD-Rubik" > > <fdrubik@f...> wrote: > > > His F2L (after cross on top) is just 100% amazing. > > > > I guess I should track down a video to answer this, but where does he > > put the cross during F2L? > > On bottom. > He solves 3 edges on top, then usually turns the cube > upside-down while inserting the 4th one, and doing some > [D,D',D2] in the process. > I have the impression that he usually only needs 2 seconds > to insert the 2 last pairs, averaging 8'' for the whole > F2L, "quand il est chaud". > -- > FD. >
151. Rubik Database Again
From: sgowal <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Nov 2005 16:19:52 -0000

I was finally able to get some professionnal hosting for my database.
I know that some people were interested by it, so I'm posting here its
new http link: http://rubik.talk-sep.net/

>From that address, you can have a look at the documentation and decide
whether you would like a login for it (or not). If you do, you can
mail me.

Sven





152. something
From: "mahtianssi" <mahtianssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Nov 2005 17:19:58 -0000

I have broken my foottcubing records again:
BT: 1:09.64
BA: 1:30.50
And I should get Stackmat next week.
Reasons why I started footcubing:
1. My wrists were hurting
2. No much competition =)
By the way, I haven't been speedcubing for a week,
but my wrists and fingers are still hurting quite much.

156. Re: calm before the storm
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Nov 2005 20:26:13 -0000

Wowowow. All kinds of worms here. 1) The competition is just plain STIFF. Four people missed the cutoff by less than 0.1 seconds - ouch!!! The two names right after that are Petrus and Knights...two of yesteryear's giants. 2) I must admit a bit of disappointment that Jessica Fridrich is not there. Besides being the world's #1 female cubist, she perhaps more than anyone has helped bring about this current revival of cubing. Ah well. 3) The top 5 should be no surprise at all. In fact among the top 25 there's just a couple of names I don't recognize (the guy from Canada and Spain). I'm expecting a full-on duel between Jean and Macky, but don't count the others out. 4) Bob Burton did better on all his 3x3 solves than on his second 2x2 solve. There aren't any results for the clock or magic, I would love to see those. Well anyways GOOD LUCK to everyone...the final showdown begins in 20 minutes!!! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "alejandro_lamas" <alejandro_lamas@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "goodxy2002" > <goodxy2002@y...> wrote: > > > > I don't think ill be under 20th place anymore ... oh well.. caltech > > winter tourny > > > > The link to the QUALIFYING ROUNDS: > > http://www.rubiks.com/lvl4/commun/cbeclb/wc2005/results.html > > ;) > > Jan >

160. Re: Homemade timers ideas?
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Nov 2005 05:13:11 -0000

If you look in the "files" section of the group under "hand timer" you'll see the one that I made/use with schematics. Total cost was about $5.00 US, though could've been as much as $8.00 or so if I didn't already have the transistors. I can make a slightly more complete write up of the how-to if you'd like. -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, smgfreak_dk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Any tutorials on how to make a good, cheap, homemade timer? thanks! >

162. Awesome time at the WC2005!
From: "N8" <collegenathan@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Nov 2005 07:55:42 -0000

Hello all! I just wanted to say that it was an honor and a pleasure to
meet so many of you at this year's world championship. This event has
definitely sparked my interest in cubing again. I've never been around
anyone physically who was faster than myself (24-30ish average) and
seeing practically everyone there smoke me psyched me up. I'm going to
get active in the community again as much as I can, including actually
updating my web page and adding new content! Final Fantasy online
stole my passion for cubing for like 1.5 years, but I've vanquished
that demon and ready to improve my skills more.

I want to thank everyone who shared their tips to me and once again
say how cool it was meeting the folks I've only known online for a few
years. That event was awesome! I don't think I'll be able to wait for
the next one!

Nathan Christie

P.S. Will people post their pictures/videos from the event, as I
didn't get to take any.

177. Re: Homemade timers ideas?
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Nov 2005 16:52:14 -0000

You are correct. As soon as you touch both foil pads, the timer starts and then stops when you touch them again. I haven't yet had time (and lets be honest, the know how) to develop a logic circuit to make it actually work like the stackmats. I do feel that it prepared me quite well for the Dallas tournament though, very little adaptation from my method with this timer was needed to do decently at the competition. Basically all thats happening is that the transistor can tell when the circuit is completed by you touching both pads. When this happens, it allows more current to flow through the start/stop switch circuit. That's the gist anyway. I believe a young man on the group came up with a very effective little timer that doesn't bother with these pesky transistors though... Might have a look in the archives for his post. -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, smgfreak_dk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > ah-ha! i was googling for a guide.. i saw this one a few months ago > but forgot where. hm, so the instant both foils are touched, the > timer starts? i was hoping for one that would function like a > stackmat timer. i'm not too sure how it these touch pads work. an > elaboration would be greatly appreciated =) thanks! > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" > <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > > > If you look in the "files" section of the group under "hand timer" > > you'll see the one that I made/use with schematics. Total cost was > > about $5.00 US, though could've been as much as $8.00 or so if I > > didn't already have the transistors. > > > > I can make a slightly more complete write up of the how-to if > you'd like. > > > > -Daniel > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, smgfreak_dk > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Any tutorials on how to make a good, cheap, homemade timer? > thanks! > > > > > >
