To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Nov 2005 18:17:11 -0000

J'ai décidé d'écrire à un seul des 3 participants français afin d'optimiser sa préparation psychologique et j'ai choisi Jean !..... >Crois-tu avoir eu tord d'avoir postulé ta moyenne chez speedcubing.com PEU >de temps avant le championnat de France? Oui j'ai eu tord car je me suis mis une pression ENORME juste avant le championnat. L'erreur >est humaine et le désir est si grand. Être un aspirant sans être un >favori porte un certain avantage. J'ai déjà entendu ça d'un instructeur et sa >recrue. >Moi je pense que tu vas te présenter en Floride Chose faite puisque Winning Moves m'offre le voyage pour disputer ces mondiaux ( a la place du prix de 300 euros !) :d Tu as tout résumé , c'est exactement ce qui s'est passé : le désir est si grand ... > > > >Bonne chance Merci. > >Gaétan > Ton site est tres bon ! et les videos aussi .. A+ Jean. > Je ne sais pas combien de français participeront au WC 2005 mais si Chambon souhaite que Pons gagne avant lui-même et vice versa lors du grand moment, alors le stress sera mieux contrôlé et vos chances ne seront que meilleures Tu as raison, le stress sera moins conséquent, je pense qu'avec chambon ya moyen d'assurer le podium. A+ Jean Congradulation for Jean !!! Happy cubing, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@f...> wrote: > > > > Wow, I just checked out the top 36 on rubiks.com and > > the top 33 all were under 20 seconds at least once. > > > > Looks like Bob Peters didn't go but there are a few > > new names like Matt Walter who was in the top 36. > > I guess 16.39 s is the new national record for Canada > > unless Matt breaks his own record on Sunday. > > > > Jean Pons solved all three of his cubes in less than > > 15 seconds... > > I had dinner with him just before he left for Orlando. > He had sub-15'' times even after some beers. > > His F2L (after cross on top) is just 100% amazing. > > Now that he had the opportunity to train on stackmat > the month before Orlando, I guess he might become > dangerous also in competition. > -- > FD. >
179. Congratulations to Jean !
From: "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 7 Nov 2005 19:51:46 +0100

I'm feeling very happy for Jean Pons today. He worked
very hard on "staying focus" and "handling the pressure"
after the disappointment of the french nationals, where
he performed badly (!) compared to his unoffical times.

This "mind"-work, his great cubing talent, and probably a
bit of luck have helped him to win the WC, and confirm all
the UWR he has set on www.speedcubing.com. Classy.

Congrats to Edouard and Macky too, their performance in
such a high-pressure event are also outstanding.

I can't wait to see the vids and reports !
--
FD.

182. Shaking hands
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 07 Nov 2005 11:54:54 -0800



This was a weird phenomenon I had at worlds. I was perfectly calm, felt good
about what I was about to do, but when the judge lifted the box off of my
cube, my hands started shaking like crazy. I wasn't nervous at all, and yet
here are my hands, shaking like crazy, which is something they've never done
before. All I could think about was "why are my hands shaking" and I
completely forgot the cross all three of my solves XD. Did this happen to
anyone else? Any thoughts as to why it happens? Maybe its subconscious
nervousness that I can't suppress o.0



-James Stuber



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



183. Re: Awesome time at the WC2005!
From: "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Nov 2005 19:55:22 -0000

Rubiks.com... Sorry to say but they really should hire a new webmaster. The site never reflected the way the community experiences the cube craze imho. - Koen --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@e...> wrote: > > The results are finally on Rubiks.com. Unfortunately they did away > with the nice sheet detailing the prelim round...and never reported > anything about the clock or magic. We'll have to wait for the full > monty on speedcubing.com. > > > Good to have the news, but Bah! -- why no details on the Rubik's > site?! > > We wouldn't be left guessing if this were a golf or volleyball > > championship... > > > > Mike > > >
184. Re: Shaking hands
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Nov 2005 20:22:03 -0000

This has happened to me as well, though not in the context of a cubing contest. Usually when I have to do something nervewracking, I feel pretty good until I actually start, at which point the nervousness just EXPLODES. As with you, I don't necessarily feel it in my emotions, but it may come out in some other way. For example, I remember one time when I was performing a skit in front of a crowd of 30-40 people. Emotionally I felt absolutely fine even during the skit, but a few minutes into it my stomach started cramping like crazy. It got so bad that I had to make a creative exit and leave my skitmates to improvise why I left. :P So in my experience, your emotions may be able to avoid the nervousness, but your body will take the hit instead. Sounds like you are similar in that regard? Sorry it had to be your hands :( --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@v...> wrote: > > > > This was a weird phenomenon I had at worlds. I was perfectly calm, felt good > about what I was about to do, but when the judge lifted the box off of my > cube, my hands started shaking like crazy. I wasn't nervous at all, and yet > here are my hands, shaking like crazy, which is something they've never done > before. All I could think about was "why are my hands shaking" and I > completely forgot the cross all three of my solves XD. Did this happen to > anyone else? Any thoughts as to why it happens? Maybe its subconscious > nervousness that I can't suppress o.0 > > > > -James Stuber > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] >

189. RWC 05'
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Nov 2005 22:24:41 -0000

Definetly the best tournament I've been to so far. It was great to
meet so many of you. The tournament ran smoothly as far as I could
tell, though I didn't get to see any 'behind the scenes' panic that may
have occured. Many thanks to the organizers.

I'm happy with my results in all categories :) Except for my 2nd round
(3x3) results. A 23.53 average? What was I doing?? And of course for
5x5 I had a monsterous pop, and didn't recover all the pieces. Grant
and Betty were kind enough to let me use a spare 5x5 cube for my second
attempt. I was surprised anyone let me borrow one after I blew 25
pieces out.

I hope to get a report up soon. Happy cubing everyone :)

-Richard

recovering...but there are some people out here that have been dying to
see the full results. (or maybe I am blind and they are around
somewhere)...

Could anyone out there post something in any format? It doesn't
have to be pretty ;-) I like names and numbers ;-)

Thanks,
Bill








191. Cubing on ESPN on Wednesday
From: "rubiks1938" <rubiks1938@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Nov 2005 23:55:55 -0000

Hey everyone,

I returned to Boston from Disney World at about 11:30 a.m. I had a great time over the
weekend seeing people I haven't seen in two years and meeting new people for the first time.
I had fun competing though an outside competition isn't as good as an indoor one.

On Wednesday morning between 8 and 10 a.m. Cory Laviglio, Chris Szlatenyi, and I will
appear on a show on ESPN2 called Cold Pizza (www.coldpizza.tv). We will be on two times for
about 10 seconds during the early part of the show. Then between 9:30 and 10 we will
compete against each other and talk about the cube and the competition for about 5
minutes.

I will post pictures later this week when I get a chance.

Andy Camann

http://andyscubepage.tk

200. [Speed cubing group] Re: Homemade timers ideas?
From: smgfreak_dk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 04:40:18 -0000

201. Re: [Speed cubing group] Website
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 2005 00:12:21 -0600

202. WC2005 experience
From: Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 7 Nov 2005 23:26:35 -0800 (PST)


Hey Everyone,

Indeed this was an awesome tournament. I do thank the organizers as it went pretty smoothly. Congrats to all the people who did well and broke some records- and congrats for those who even showed up! It was pretty awesome meeting some of the people I chat with online; unfortunately I didn't speak to some of you after the tournament, I had a plane to catch ;). Yeah I had to leave right after the 3x3 final round apparently, which was kind of unexpected. I had a 3x3 shirt that I wanted to everyone to sign, like I did wc2003. Nonetheless, I had fun and it was cool to meet some cool people.

Also to thank everyone else that was there. It seems there's gonna be a wc2007?...hm. ~peace

-Brent Morgan



:)
--Brent

203. Re: [Speed cubing group] Contest times better than ever
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 2005 00:35:53 -0800

Can anyone translate this? I do not think my translator does justice to the grammar. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Nov 7, 2005, at 10:17 AM, Gaétan Guimond wrote: > J'ai décidé d'écrire à un seul des 3 participants français afin > d'optimiser sa préparation psychologique et j'ai choisi Jean !..... > > >> Crois-tu avoir eu tord d'avoir postulé ta moyenne chez > speedcubing.com PEU >> de temps avant le championnat de France? > > > Oui j'ai eu tord car je me suis mis une pression ENORME juste avant > le championnat. > > L'erreur >> est humaine et le désir est si grand. Être un aspirant sans être un >> favori porte un certain avantage. J'ai déjà entendu ça d'un > instructeur et sa >> recrue. > >> Moi je pense que tu vas te présenter en Floride > > Chose faite puisque Winning Moves m'offre le voyage pour disputer > ces > mondiaux ( a la place du prix de 300 euros !) :d > > Tu as tout résumé , c'est exactement ce qui s'est passé : le désir > est si > grand ... > >> >> >> >> Bonne chance > > Merci. > >> >> Gaétan >> > > Ton site est tres bon ! et les videos aussi .. > > > A+ > > Jean. > >> Je ne sais pas combien de français participeront au WC 2005 mais > si Chambon souhaite que Pons gagne avant lui-même et vice versa lors > du grand moment, alors le stress sera mieux contrôlé et vos chances > ne seront que meilleures > > Tu as raison, le stress sera moins conséquent, je pense qu'avec > chambon ya moyen d'assurer le podium. > > A+ > > Jean > > > > Congradulation for Jean !!! > > Happy cubing, > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "FD-Rubik" > <fdrubik@f...> wrote: >> >> >>> Wow, I just checked out the top 36 on rubiks.com and >>> the top 33 all were under 20 seconds at least once. >>> >>> Looks like Bob Peters didn't go but there are a few >>> new names like Matt Walter who was in the top 36. >>> I guess 16.39 s is the new national record for Canada >>> unless Matt breaks his own record on Sunday. >>> >>> Jean Pons solved all three of his cubes in less than >>> 15 seconds... >> >> I had dinner with him just before he left for Orlando. >> He had sub-15'' times even after some beers. >> >> His F2L (after cross on top) is just 100% amazing. >> >> Now that he had the opportunity to train on stackmat >> the month before Orlando, I guess he might become >> dangerous also in competition. >> -- >> FD. >> > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >

205. Re: [Speed cubing group] Contest times better than ever
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 10:14:03 +0100

Typical Guimond stuff. Not interesting at all. And my English isn't alot better than your translator's, but I think you'll get the idea. "I decided to write to only one of the 3 French guys so I could optimize hismetnal preparation, and I chose Jean. then follows I think parts of the mail he wrote to Jean, and Jean's answer: GG: do you think you did a mistake by posting you average on speedcubing.com shortly before the French Champs? JP: Yes it was a mistake because I had to handle lots of pressure during the championship. GG: blah blah blah but I think you'll go to Florida. JP: yes, Winning moves sent me there (instead of paying me the money prize of 300EUR) GG: good luck JP: thanks GG: I don't know how many of you will be there, but if Chambon wants Pons to win and vice versa, then the pressure will be easier to handle and you'll have better chances. JP: yes you're right, I think it'll be easier that way and I guess we can make it to the top 3, with Chambon. very, very rough translation, but it doesn't deserve a lot better. François Tyson Mao a écrit : > Can anyone translate this? I do not think my translator does justice > to the grammar. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 7, 2005, at 10:17 AM, Gaétan Guimond wrote: > > > J'ai décidé d'écrire à un seul des 3 participants français afin > > d'optimiser sa préparation psychologique et j'ai choisi Jean !..... > > > > > >> Crois-tu avoir eu tord d'avoir postulé ta moyenne chez > > speedcubing.com PEU > >> de temps avant le championnat de France? > > > > > > Oui j'ai eu tord car je me suis mis une pression ENORME juste avant > > le championnat. > > > > L'erreur > >> est humaine et le désir est si grand. Être un aspirant sans être un > >> favori porte un certain avantage. J'ai déjà entendu ça d'un > > instructeur et sa > >> recrue. > > > >> Moi je pense que tu vas te présenter en Floride > > > > Chose faite puisque Winning Moves m'offre le voyage pour disputer > > ces > > mondiaux ( a la place du prix de 300 euros !) :d > > > > Tu as tout résumé , c'est exactement ce qui s'est passé : le désir > > est si > > grand ... > > > >> > >> > >> > >> Bonne chance > > > > Merci. > > > >> > >> Gaétan > >> > > > > Ton site est tres bon ! et les videos aussi .. > > > > > > A+ > > > > Jean. > > > >> Je ne sais pas combien de français participeront au WC 2005 mais > > si Chambon souhaite que Pons gagne avant lui-même et vice versa lors > > du grand moment, alors le stress sera mieux contrôlé et vos chances > > ne seront que meilleures > > > > Tu as raison, le stress sera moins conséquent, je pense qu'avec > > chambon ya moyen d'assurer le podium. > > > > A+ > > > > Jean > > > > > > > > Congradulation for Jean !!! > > > > Happy cubing, > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "FD-Rubik" > > <fdrubik@f...> wrote: > >> > >> > >>> Wow, I just checked out the top 36 on rubiks.com and > >>> the top 33 all were under 20 seconds at least once. > >>> > >>> Looks like Bob Peters didn't go but there are a few > >>> new names like Matt Walter who was in the top 36. > >>> I guess 16.39 s is the new national record for Canada > >>> unless Matt breaks his own record on Sunday. > >>> > >>> Jean Pons solved all three of his cubes in less than > >>> 15 seconds... > >> > >> I had dinner with him just before he left for Orlando. > >> He had sub-15'' times even after some beers. > >> > >> His F2L (after cross on top) is just 100% amazing. > >> > >> Now that he had the opportunity to train on stackmat > >> the month before Orlando, I guess he might become > >> dangerous also in competition. > >> -- > >> FD. > >> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 211. My perspective on the WC05
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 13:19:46 -0000

Hi everyone!

I just arrived home, and I am feeling pretty sad now that it is all
over. I had such a fantastic time it was unbelievable. I can't
really sum up in words everything that I am feeling right now, but I
really feel sorry for the guys who couldnt make it because you
really did miss out on an awesome weekend.

I can't mention everybody here of course, so I won't even try, but I
had a really brilliant time with you all.

I feel fairly happy with my performances, I set yet another NR for
the 3x3x3 and also captured the Megaminx NR! So not too bad :) But I
feel very humble to be placed so highly (17th out of 150 or so),
against such world class competition. Naturally Congratulations to
Jean, who did a great job, and to Edouard, whom it was a real
pleasure to finally meet for the first time. Also Macky, who did so
well to come third place with the huge pressure of cameras following
his every move, I'm sure at one point they even followed him to
the "restroom"...

Also Congratulations to Chris Hardwick, who had the toughest job
when it came to getting the fasetst time for your country, I salute
you! I must mention Lars V and Frank as well, who proved dominant on
the larger cubes (Lars on Square-1 also), and of course Yuki whose
fantastic talent at the 4x4x4 has inspired me to improve my times
even more.

Finally, thank you to Ron, Ton, and Tyson, without your behind the
scenes organisation we would not have had half as much fun.

It is a bit of a shame that the competition was held outdoors in
such strong, direct sunlight. Of course, the light made it hard for
all competitors, but I'm sure that some people coped with the heat
much better than others. Maybe that's the home advantage? I don't
think that it would be a good idea to have another competition
outdoors, but that's not to say that it wasn't a great event.

One final request, I want to make a page on my site with all the
pictures that people have taken from the Worlds, organised day by
day. If you took some pictures, and do not have the capability of
uploading them to a website, then please send them to
dan@... - I would love to see them and get them
online. Also, if you can get pics online, still send them to me! I
really love to see all your media.

I am definitely going to spend more time working hard on improving
my puzzles, and I hope that I will be able to give the French a good
run for their money next time! :) And Stefan, I will beat you on the
clock next time for sure...

Thanks everyone for such an amazing time, I have so many great
memories already.

See you soon!

Dan H :)






212. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Shaking hands
From: Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 2005 07:39:39 -0600

when i picked up the cube, my whole body shaked, more so my leg. It was like
shaking like mad. wow
it was an odd feeling. i got 35 seconds tho, so im not too dissapointed

213. Textured stickers
From: Marco Garbelini <garbelini@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 2005 16:10:37 +0200

I just got my new textured stickers thanks to a friend's family from California who mailed them to me. Although the stickers are light-years better than the rubiks.com<http://rubiks.com>ones I found them kinda slippery. Does anyone else find that the cubesmith's textured stickers have actually less grip than the regular ones? Do they get more grip with use? Cheers, Marco Garbelini [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
214. Re: My perspective on the WC05
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 14:27:34 -0000

I'll do my little write up in a bit...but I have one question Dan... Did you and Joel ever figure out who was saying my name right??? For all of you who have no idea what that means...Joel Van Noort and Dan were having the biggestargument on how to Say my name...I believe they were pronouncing it the same, but with dan's accent it came out differently...but w/e...My write up to come when I have the time to write it... 215. Some results
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 14:35:05 -0000

For those who are curious, Alexander Ooms won the Magic with an
average of 1.44 (I think) in the final round. Stefan was 2nd with
1.88 (I think), and I came 3rd with 2.0x. Quinn Lewis set the world
record in the first round with 1.14 seconds. Stefan broke the WR for
Master Magic with 2.79. I came in 2nd with 3.00 and Alexander was 3rd
with 3.2x. I did the magic one-handed in 3.89 seconds, though only
three of us participated in one-handed magic. :P

To no surprise, Stefan won the Clock and broke the WR with 8.29
seconds (or something close to that) for single solve. He also broke
the Megaminx WR with 1:41. Lars won Square-1. There is a new WR for
4x4 by Yuki. Ryan P. won the 3x3x3 one-handed and I am pretty sure
Frank Morris won the 5x5x5. Masayuki Akimoto won the 2x2x2 cube with
a 8.xx average (very impressive for a Rubik's brand!)

~ Bob

~ Bob

Jon
http://www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001






219. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Homemade timers ideas?
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 2005 12:51:32 -0300 (ART)

hmm...I don't know...maybe it could work. I'll try this. Pedro smgfreak_dk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: nice =) i wonder.. maybe a reverse mechanism would work. have it in contact at rest position.. then pushing down would take it out of contact.. and releasing would trigger the contact to start it.. then stopping would require a quick (to avoid delays) press.. does this sound like it'd work? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > sorry...try this. > > www.geocities.com/cubomagicobrasil/cronometro.JPG > > Pedro > > Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> escreveu: > You can take a look on my one... > www.geocities.com/cubomagicobrasil/cronometro.jpg > > A short video > www.geocities.com/cubomagicobrasil/timer.WMV > > smgfreak_dk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: > ah-ha! i was googling for a guide.. i saw this one a few months ago > but forgot where. hm, so the instant both foils are touched, the > timer starts? i was hoping for one that would function like a > stackmat timer. i'm not too sure how it these touch pads work. an > elaboration would be greatly appreciated =) thanks! > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" > <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > > > If you look in the "files" section of the group under "hand timer" > > you'll see the one that I made/use with schematics. 220. WC2005
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 16:18:41 -0000

Hey everyone,

I don't know about you guys, but I am going stir crazy waiting for the
results! I don't even know my placement in a couple of the events I
competed in! I e-mailed the rubiks.com contact section about the
results, but I think they are all out and about still in Orlando until
the 9th.

Anyway I had a wonderful time, I'd rather save all my comments
memories for a report, which I will write once I get the pictures from
Becky's camera, which should happen later today.

Anyway I had such a wonderful time meeting everyone, from old friends
to new faces. I hope to see everyone again, and more new faces, in
2007 (which I really hope will be in Europe) :-D

Will soon have a report up with my take on WC2005.

Chris






221. Re: [Speed cubing group] Some results
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 2005 16:23:34 +0000 (GMT)

Thanks bob and well done. By the way who won 4*4*4 and 5*5*5 blindfolded ? John Louis Bob Burton <bob@...> wrote: For those who are curious, Alexander Ooms won the Magic with an average of 1.44 (I think) in the final round. Stefan was 2nd with 1.88 (I think), and I came 3rd with 2.0x. Quinn Lewis set the world record in the first round with 1.14 seconds. Stefan broke the WR for Master Magic with 2.79. I came in 2nd with 3.00 and Alexander was 3rd with 3.2x. I did the magic one-handed in 3.89 seconds, though only three of us participated in one-handed magic. :P To no surprise, Stefan won the Clock and broke the WR with 8.29 seconds (or something close to that) for single solve. He also broke the Megaminx WR with 1:41. Lars won Square-1. There is a new WR for 4x4 by Yuki. Ryan P. won the 3x3x3 one-handed and I am pretty sure Frank Morris won the 5x5x5. Masayuki Akimoto won the 2x2x2 cube with a 8.xx average (very impressive for a Rubik's brand!) ~ Bob ~ Bob --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- --------------------------------- Enjoy this Diwali with Y! 231. blindfold cubing algorithms
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 2005 09:42:31 -0800

Hi Everyone,

Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD edges? If
it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. It pops
up every now and then and I'm tired of flipping two, flipping the cube,
and then flipping another two.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology



232. Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 17:47:33 -0000

How about D L2 R2 (M' U)*4 (M U)*4 L2 R2 D' ? ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > Hi Everyone, > > Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD edges? If > it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. It pops > up every now and then and I'm tired of flipping two, flipping the cube, > and then flipping another two. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology >

234. Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 17:58:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > Hi Everyone, > > Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD edges? If > it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. It pops > up every now and then and I'm tired of flipping two, flipping the cube, > and then flipping another two. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > Hi Tyson, This is from my intermediate method. Does it work for you. U(FB)2U(FB)2R2BF'U2R'U2B'FR2U' 16 moves in HTM - it's optimal for that metric.
235. Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 18:03:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > > > Hi Everyone, > > > > Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD > edges? If > > it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. It > pops > > up every now and then and I'm tired of flipping two, flipping the > cube, > > and then flipping another two. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > Hi Tyson, > > This is from my intermediate method. Does it work for you. > > U(FB)2U(FB)2R2BF'U2R'U2B'FR2U' > > 16 moves in HTM - it's optimal for that metric. > For anyone who has the document (I referenced the link a few days ago), it's algorithm 4.3.7 (single ring flip, although I didn't call it that in this document) from page 15. You can get the double ring flip from 4.5.7 (page 31).
236. [Speed cubing group] Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 18:04:47 -0000

How about u' M' U (M U)*3 (M' U)*4 M2 u? ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > It works, but I was hoping for something that was just M and U moves > (possibly a D). > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 8, 2005, at 9:47 AM, Bob Burton wrote: > > > How about D L2 R2 (M' U)*4 (M U)*4 L2 R2 D' ? > > > > ~ Bob > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@...m, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > >> > >> Hi Everyone, > >> > >> Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD edges? > >> If > >> it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. 237. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 2005 10:09:14 -0800

That works. I'll have to play around with it to see if it's worth it as opposed to setup moves + the 4-flip algorithm. Oh, Leyan came up with a good method of stopping the timer on a Generation 2. Basically start your hands from the outside and slide them in. It works very quickly and you won't miss and you won't hit the reset button. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Nov 8, 2005, at 9:58 AM, GameOfDeath2 wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> >> Hi Everyone, >> >> Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD > edges? 238. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 2005 23:42:42 +0530

Well for those who dont want to go thru the document here it is : U B2 F2 U B2 F2 R2 B F' U2 R' U2 B' F R2 U' Sachin. On 11/8/05, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > > > > > > Hi Everyone, > > > > > > Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD > > edges? If > > > it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. > It > > pops > > > up every now and then and I'm tired of flipping two, flipping > the > > cube, > > > and then flipping another two. > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > Hi Tyson, > > > > This is from my intermediate method. Does it work for you. > > > > U(FB)2U(FB)2R2BF'U2R'U2B'FR2U' > > > > 16 moves in HTM - it's optimal for that metric. > > > > For anyone who has the document (I referenced the link a few days > ago), it's algorithm 4.3.7 (single ring flip, although I didn't call > it that in this document) from page 15. > You can get the double ring flip from 4.5.7 (page 31). > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 239. Re: [Speed cubing group] blindfold cubing algorithms
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 19:16:52 +0100

Found by JACube. First is a bunch optimized in HTM and then in STM.
Using U R and M-turns only. The last two sets uses U and M only. No
proof reading or testing done. I suspect this contains a lot of duplicates.

U R and M in HTM
U R U R' U M U M U M U R M U' R' U' (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U R U R' M' U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R U' R' U' (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U R U' R' U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R M' U R' U' (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U R U' R' M U M U M U M U R U R' U' (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U R2 U R2 U M U M U M U R2 M U' R2 U' (24q, 20f*, 16s)
U R2 U R2 M' U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R2 U' R2 U' (24q, 20f*, 16s)
U R2 U' R2 U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R2 M' U R2 U' (24q, 20f*, 16s)
U R2 U' R2 M U M U M U M U R2 U R2 U' (24q, 20f*, 16s)
U R' U R U M U M U M U R' M U' R U' (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U R' U R M' U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R' U' R U' (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U R' U' R U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R' M' U R U' (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U R' U' R M U M U M U M U R' U R U' (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R U R' U M U M U M U R M U' R' U (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R U R' M' U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R U' R' U (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R U' R' U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R M' U R' U (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R U' R' M U M U M U M U R U R' U (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R2 U R2 U M U M U M U R2 M U' R2 U (24q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R2 U R2 M' U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R2 U' R2 U (24q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R2 U' R2 U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R2 M' U R2 U (24q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R2 U' R2 M U M U M U M U R2 U R2 U (24q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R' U R U M U M U M U R' M U' R U (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R' U R M' U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R' U' R U (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R' U' R U' M' U' M' U' M' U' R' M' U R U (20q, 20f*, 16s)
U' R' U' R M U M U M U M U R' U R U (20q, 20f*, 16s)

U R and M in STM
U M U M2 U' M' U' M' U' M' U' M U' M' U' (24q, 22f, 15s*)
U M U M' U M U M U M U M2 U' M' U' (24q, 22f, 15s*)
U M U M' U M' U M2 U' M' U' M' U' M U' (24q, 22f, 15s*)
U M U2 M U2 M' U M U2 M' U2 M U' M2 U' (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M U2 M U2 M' U' M U2 M' U2 M U M2 U' (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M U2 M' U2 M' U M' U2 M U2 M' U M2 U (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M U2 M' U2 M' U' M' U2 M U2 M' U' M2 U (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M U' M2 U M' U M' U M' U M U M' U' (24q, 22f, 15s*)
U M U' M' U' M U' M U' M U' M2 U M' U' (24q, 22f, 15s*)
U M U' M' U' M' U' M2 U M' U M' U M U' (24q, 22f, 15s*)
U M2 U M U2 M' U2 M U M U2 M U2 M' U (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M2 U M U2 M' U2 M U' M' U2 M U2 M U' (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M2 U M' U2 M U2 M' U M' U2 M' U2 M U (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M2 U M' U2 M U2 M' U' M U2 M' U2 M' U' (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M2 U' M U2 M' U2 M U M' U2 M U2 M U' (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M2 U' M U2 M' U2 M U' M U2 M U2 M' U (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M2 U' M' U2 M U2 M' U M U2 M' U2 M' U' (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M2 U' M' U2 M U2 M' U' M' U2 M' U2 M U (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M' U M U M U M2 U' M U' M U' M' U' (24q, 22f, 15s*)
U M' U M U M' U M' U M' U M2 U' M U' (24q, 22f, 15s*)
U M' U M2 U' M U' M U' M U' M' U' M U' (24q, 22f, 15s*)
U M' U2 M U2 M U M U2 M' U2 M U M2 U (28q, 22f, 15s*)
U M' U2 M U2 M U' M U2 M' U2 M U' M2 U (28q, 22f, 15s*)

>Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD edges? If
>it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. It pops
>up every now and then and I'm tired of flipping two, flipping the cube,
>and then flipping another two.

242. Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: "christopher_pelley" <christopher_pelley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 18:52:13 -0000

For FU,BU,FD,BD edges I use: F' L' F (M U)*4 F' L F Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > >> > >> Hi Everyone, > >> > >> Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD > > edges? If > >> it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. It > > pops > >> up every now and then and I'm tired of flipping two, flipping the > > cube, > >> and then flipping another two.
243. [Speed cubing group] Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: Gaétan Guimond <rubiks99ca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 19:03:13 -0000

I don't use the htm or generator program but my personnal agorythm is fun 1 (U M U2 M U2 M U) + 2 ( M2) + 3 (repeat 1) = easier to memorize :) The no name --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > > Well for those who dont want to go thru the document here it is : > > U B2 F2 U B2 F2 R2 B F' U2 R' U2 B' F R2 U' > > Sachin. > > On 11/8/05, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > > <tmao@i...> > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > Hi Everyone, > > > > > > > > Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD > > > edges? If > > > > it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. > > It > > > pops > > > > up every now and then and I'm tired of flipping two, flipping > > the > > > cube, > > > > and then flipping another two. > > > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > > MSC #631 > > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > > > > Hi Tyson, > > > > > > This is from my intermediate method. Does it work for you. > > > > > > U(FB)2U(FB)2R2BF'U2R'U2B'FR2U' > > > > > > 16 moves in HTM - it's optimal for that metric. > > > > > > > For anyone who has the document (I referenced the link a few days > > ago), it's algorithm 4.3.7 (single ring flip, although I didn't call > > it that in this document) from page 15. > > You can get the double ring flip from 4.5.7 (page 31). > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

246. Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 20:00:36 -0000

I would do (B' U B) (M' U)x2 M' U2 (M U)x2 M U2 (B' U' B) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Duh. Why do u' and u when U' and U work? :P That would be all in M,U. :) > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > wrote: > > > > How about u' M' U (M U)*3 (M' U)*4 M2 u? > > > > ~ Bob > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > > > > > > It works, but I was hoping for something that was just M and U moves > > > (possibly a D). > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > On Nov 8, 2005, at 9:47 AM, Bob Burton wrote: > > > > > > > How about D L2 R2 (M' U)*4 (M U)*4 L2 R2 D' ? > > > > > > > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > > > wrote: > > > >> > > > >> Hi Everyone, > > > >> > > > >> Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD > edges? > > > >> If > > > >> it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. 247. [Speed cubing group] Re: blindfold cubing algorithms

250. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 12:50:25 -0800

For flipping edges: What I would use if I saw this in competition is: D L2 R2 (M U)*4 (M' U)*4 R2 L2 D' What I should use is: B' R' B (M U)*4 B' R B I need to work on optimizing my solutions for blindfolded. Hopefully by doing that I'll be able to pull my times down. And yeah, props to Generation 2 timers for blindfold solving! No more me randomly-pounding-the-table-after-the-solve-to-stop-the-timer. :-) Leyan Tyson Mao wrote: > That works. I'll have to play around with it to see if it's worth it > as opposed to setup moves + the 4-flip algorithm. Oh, Leyan came up > with a good method of stopping the timer on a Generation 2. Basically > start your hands from the outside and slide them in. It works very > quickly and you won't miss and you won't hit the reset button. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 8, 2005, at 9:58 AM, GameOfDeath2 wrote: > > >>--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> >>wrote: >> >>>Hi Everyone, >>> >>>Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD >> >>edges? If >> >>>it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. It >> >>pops >> >>>up every now and then and I'm tired of flipping two, flipping the >> >>cube, >> >>>and then flipping another two. >>> >>>Tyson Mao >>>MSC #631 >>>California Institute of Technology >>> >> >>Hi Tyson, >> >>This is from my intermediate method. Does it work for you. >> >>U(FB)2U(FB)2R2BF'U2R'U2B'FR2U' >> >>16 moves in HTM - it's optimal for that metric. >> >> >> >> >> >> >> >>Yahoo! Groups Links >> >> >> >> >> >> > > > > > > > Yahoo! 265. Re: my magic needs help.. :(
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Nov 2005 03:04:57 -0000

Thats an easy one. Heres what i would do: First, fold 2 tiles from the right and 2 tiles from the left behind the puzzle. Then turn the puzzle 90 degrees counter clockwise. Now fold out 2 tiles in the middle to the right and 2 to the left. now fold the puzzle in half away from you like a valley. Fld 2 tiles from the right down and 2 from the left down. you should have the puzzle stacked up. now peel off a tile from the top right side down. Peel one tile from the lower left up. Unfold the puzzle. Fold 2 tiles from the right and 2 from the left behind the puzzle (like the first time). Turn it 90 degrees again and unfold it. Fold the top half over the bottom. Then fold it out into a loop and slide the top half one tile to the right. Unfold the puzzle, and it should be fine. Be sure to read this (scroll down to "Getting back to the starting position"): http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/magic.htm Lastly, your welcome. :) Peter Greenwood --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@g...> wrote: > > front: > http://img452.imageshack.us/img452/2825/blackmagic16rb.jpg > > back: > http://img452.imageshack.us/img452/9539/blackmagic23kj.jpg > > > i don't know how to fix it from here... does anyone know how? thanks in advance. > > -- > -cubekid >

From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Nov 2005 03:37:25 -0000

Are promotional cubes allowed at competitions? I got one at worlds, and
it turns very nicely. If I resticker it so it has colors and not
pictures, is it going to be allowed at competitions?

Peter Greenwood





267. Re: Which Cubes are fair game?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Nov 2005 03:42:41 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Are promotional cubes allowed at competitions? I got one at worlds, and > it turns very nicely. If I resticker it so it has colors and not > pictures, is it going to be allowed at competitions? > > Peter Greenwood > I don't see why they wouldn't be. Those Jalapeno cubes are very similar to start with as my normal cube, which I used in Orlando. With a few grinding solves and a lot of lube, I think they'll be excellent. I'll just have to make sure to peel off the stickers carefully, so I can transplant them onto a cube that doesn't turn as well. Rivets aren't nearly as big a deal as a lot of people seem to think. -Mike Bennett
268. Good Times
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Nov 2005 04:21:57 -0000

I'm all kinds of tired from not getting much sleep in Orlando but I
just wanted to say that I had a blast hanging out with old friends and
making some new ones this weekend. Congrats to Jean and all the other
winners...there were some amazing times put up under pressure (and
under a blazing Florida sun!). A big thank you to Ron and Tyson and
the other organizers...great job, guys.

I'll post again once I put up my pictures and my write-up. Until
then, I'd like to dedicate two words to my buddy Dan Harris and his
posse: Push, Push.

Ian Winokur





269. Re: Good Times
From: "h4m573r1" <h4m573r1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Nov 2005 05:01:28 -0000

I second that notion; that was the best. It was great meeting everyone and associating new names with faces. Dan, it was great cubing with you, and Joel, it was equally awesome discussing methods. Finally meeting all the European cubers is a thrill, especially Ron and Jean Pons. I had the honor of racing Mr. Akimoto in a 3x3x3 solve. Twice. ;) Good times...good times. Oh, a special thanks to Mark Polinkovsky for being himself and to the Mark team for the hilarious full-contact competition. That right there was worth the trip. It was also great meeting up with everyone from US Nationals. Ton, Jasmine, Doug, Chris... Great seeing you all again! I'll post a link to a couple of pictures after I upload them. :) I hope everyone got some rest and are catching up with their lives. -Sunil --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ian" <iwinoky@y...> wrote: > > I'm all kinds of tired from not getting much sleep in Orlando but I > just wanted to say that I had a blast hanging out with old friends and > making some new ones this weekend. Congrats to Jean and all the other > winners...there were some amazing times put up under pressure (and > under a blazing Florida sun!). A big thank you to Ron and Tyson and > the other organizers...great job, guys. > > I'll post again once I put up my pictures and my write-up. Until > then, I'd like to dedicate two words to my buddy Dan Harris and his > posse: Push, Push. > > Ian Winokur >

271. 2x2x2
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 08 Nov 2005 22:02:41 -0800

So, I'm very seriously considering using the RH step 1, then finishing off
with the last c/e pair and OLL/PLL for my speedcubing. At a moderate speed
Im getting averaging around 27-28 moves every time for f2l which I think can
be sped up. My problem is that I suck at planning the 2x2x2 ahead of
solving. It seems very hard for me to be able to quickly pick which one is
the best to do and then be able to plan it out in 15 seconds. I nearly never
can. Any advice from 2x2x2 starters?



-James Stuber

Westview High School

Room: D115

3x3x3 Speed
3x3x3 OH

275. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: my magic needs help.. :(
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 9 Nov 2005 02:40:46 -0600

ah.... i feel kinda stupid :( but thanks a bunch! hopefully i'll start to see some of these things automatically as i get better On 11/8/05, pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > Thats an easy one. Heres what i would do: > > First, fold 2 tiles from the right and 2 tiles from the left behind > the puzzle. Then turn the puzzle 90 degrees counter clockwise. Now > fold out 2 tiles in the middle to the right and 2 to the left. now > fold the puzzle in half away from you like a valley. Fld 2 tiles from > the right down and 2 from the left down. you should have the puzzle > stacked up. now peel off a tile from the top right side down. Peel > one tile from the lower left up. Unfold the puzzle. Fold 2 tiles from > the right and 2 from the left behind the puzzle (like the first > time). Turn it 90 degrees again and unfold it. Fold the top half over > the bottom. Then fold it out into a loop and slide the top half one > tile to the right. Unfold the puzzle, and it should be fine. > > Be sure to read this (scroll down to "Getting back to the starting > position"): > http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/magic.htm > > Lastly, your welcome. :) > > Peter Greenwood > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay > <cubekid@g...> wrote: > > > > front: > > http://img452.imageshack.us/img452/2825/blackmagic16rb.jpg > > > > back: > > http://img452.imageshack.us/img452/9539/blackmagic23kj.jpg > > > > > > i don't know how to fix it from here... does anyone know how? > thanks in advance. > > > > -- > > -cubekid > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > -- -cubekid
276. Re: 2x2x2
From: "Johannes Laire" <johannes.laire@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Nov 2005 11:53:58 -0000

I started using the Petrus method 5 months ago and I think I'm quite good at starting with 2x2x2. First I usually create a c/e pair. If there exists one already, I will use it. After I have a c/e pair I'll use it to create a 1x2x2-block. It is quite simple to do, at least after some practice. Then I just finish the 2x2x2 by solving the edge that doesn't belong to the 1x2x2-block and after solving it I place the 1x2x2 with one move. Usually the whole thing takes less than 8 moves. Well, this how I do it. I don't know does it help. Anyway, the best advice I can give is just pracitce, practice, practice. 2x2x2 is a lot more complicated to create than cross. http://lar5.com/cube/fas1.html (this is an excellent page) http://www.freewebs.com/johannes91/cube/method1.htm (this one sucks) - Johannes --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@v...> wrote: > > So, I'm very seriously considering using the RH step 1, then finishing off > with the last c/e pair and OLL/PLL for my speedcubing. At a moderate speed > Im getting averaging around 27-28 moves every time for f2l which I think can > be sped up. My problem is that I suck at planning the 2x2x2 ahead of > solving. It seems very hard for me to be able to quickly pick which one is > the best to do and then be able to plan it out in 15 seconds. I nearly never > can. Any advice from 2x2x2 starters? > > > > -James Stuber > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] >

281. Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Nov 2005 15:53:47 -0000

Hey Tyson, Plenty of algs to choose from now, but anyhow, this is what I always used: FRF' (M'U')*4 FR'F' -Dave --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > Hi Everyone, > > Does anyone know an algorithm to flip the FU, BU, FD, and BD edges? If > it's the FL, FR, BL, BR, that would work too or any variation. It pops > up every now and then and I'm tired of flipping two, flipping the cube, > and then flipping another two. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology >

285. Re: Full results are up
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Nov 2005 18:09:40 -0000

Regarding the results - it's astounding how level the playing field
is. Practically anyone from the top 25 or so could have come out on
top. Chambon went all the way from 13th to 2nd. Jean Pons was in 7th
place in the semis and won it all. The lesson here is NEVER give up -
there's always a chance!

Looks like Macky also cleaned up - third place, fastest solve, second
place one-handed. That's a nice bit of spending money...for use on
more cubes, of course. :P





286. Statistics WC2005
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Nov 2005 18:38:38 -0000

Hi friends,

It was great meeting you all in Florida!
Happy to have been part of WC 2005.
Proud to have been part of the organization.

Yes, competing outside was different. It was hot, and it was hard to
see the times on the displays. But the best have won, so no excuses.
Congrats to Jean, Yuki, Frank, Leyan and all the others.

Here some statistics from WC 2005:

1) average age of competitors: 23 years 10 months
2) average age of 3x3 finalists: 18 years 9 months (Jon being 30!)

I am getting too old for this. :-)

3) average solve in 1st round: 37.29 seconds
4) average solve in semi final: 20.14 seconds
5) average solve in final: 16.93 seconds...

Don't miss the next WC!!!

Have fun,

Ron

288. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Full results are up
From: "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 9 Nov 2005 20:22:20 +0100


> Regarding the results - it's astounding how level the playing field
> is. Practically anyone from the top 25 or so could have come out on
> top. Chambon went all the way from 13th to 2nd. Jean Pons was in 7th
> place in the semis and won it all. The lesson here is NEVER give up -
> there's always a chance!

In any high-level sport, at top level, the difference between
winning and losing is epsilon.

"Never give up, it ain't over till it's over" is one of the N
commandments of competition. There are many more. Understand
all of them, adapt them to ur personality, and you'll be more
than a skilled cuber : you'll be a tough competitor.

Amen :-).
--
FD.

Now > > fold out 2 tiles in the middle to the right and 2 to the left. now > > fold the puzzle in half away from you like a valley. 296. Re: Which Cubes are fair game?
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Nov 2005 23:08:03 -0000

Personally i found those jalapeno stickers rather annoying, nothing i would ever play with. But the cube turns rather nicely. Ill trust you and resticker it. Thanks for the help. :) Peter Greenwood --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > Are promotional cubes allowed at competitions? I got one at worlds, and > > it turns very nicely. If I resticker it so it has colors and not > > pictures, is it going to be allowed at competitions? > > > > Peter Greenwood > > > > > I don't see why they wouldn't be. > > Those Jalapeno cubes are very similar to start with as my normal cube, > which I used in Orlando. With a few grinding solves and a lot of > lube, I think they'll be excellent. I'll just have to make sure to > peel off the stickers carefully, so I can transplant them onto a cube > that doesn't turn as well. Rivets aren't nearly as big a deal as a > lot of people seem to think. > > -Mike Bennett >
297. Re: blindfold cubing algorithms
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 00:54:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > *sigh* > > And by that I mean (B' U B) (M'U)x4 (B' U' B) > > I tried to write the alg twice without a cube handy. Bad idea.. That's no excuse. Always check algs here: http://thearufam.brinkster.net/cube/wrapplet.asp Cheers! Stefan

303. Re: Good Times
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 01:54:41 -0000

I concur. I had very much fun meeting all the cubers...and there were so many! It's great to see that our object of obsession is starting to gain popularity. =) Congratulations to Jean, Edouard, Yuki, Frank, Leyan, and all the other winners and finalists. It's amazing how the times have improved since Toronto! Jean and Edouard put up impressive times in the final. I had no big mistake, so I have no excuse for the 16 average. They simply performed better under the competition condition. The funny thing is, Saturday night at dinner, all the Japanese cubers, Jean, and Edouard were racing, and the three of us sat in the same order as we did for the picture of the three top finishers. I also had the opportunity to talk to Jean and Edouard a little in French (I'll have to practice quite a bit now). Very nice meeting you two! I started listing everyone's name but then decided that it would take too long. So, everyone I'd met before, it was nice to see you again; everyone I hadn't met before, it was nice meeting you. I wish that I hadn't had so much homework to do. There were a lot of people I wanted to talk to, and I feel that I didn't get to do that very much. I look forward to meeting you all again in the future. Of course, much thanks to Ron, Tyson, judges, scramblers, and the organizers for putting together a great competition. And a bad news: it looks like I left my camera outside the main building on Monday morning, just before I left. Anyone seen a silver Nikon Coolpix in a gray cover? If I promised to send you a picture, sorry! I might just have to steal mr. hamster's camera. Macky --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "h4m573r1" <h4m573r1@y...> wrote: > > I second that notion; that was the best. It was great meeting > everyone and associating new names with faces. Dan, it was great > cubing with you, and Joel, it was equally awesome discussing > methods. Finally meeting all the European cubers is a thrill, > especially Ron and Jean Pons. I had the honor of racing Mr. Akimoto > in a 3x3x3 solve. Twice. ;) Good times...good times. Oh, a special > thanks to Mark Polinkovsky for being himself and to the Mark team > for the hilarious full-contact competition. That right there was > worth the trip. It was also great meeting up with everyone from US > Nationals. Ton, Jasmine, Doug, Chris... Great seeing you all again! > I'll post a link to a couple of pictures after I upload them. :) I > hope everyone got some rest and are catching up with their lives. > > -Sunil > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ian" <iwinoky@y...> > wrote: > > > > I'm all kinds of tired from not getting much sleep in Orlando but > I > > just wanted to say that I had a blast hanging out with old friends > and > > making some new ones this weekend. Congrats to Jean and all the > other > > winners...there were some amazing times put up under pressure (and > > under a blazing Florida sun!). A big thank you to Ron and Tyson > and > > the other organizers...great job, guys. > > > > I'll post again once I put up my pictures and my write-up. Until > > then, I'd like to dedicate two words to my buddy Dan Harris and > his > > posse: Push, Push. > > > > Ian Winokur > > >

I'm looking at getting an original 3x3 cube (from the '80s) and i was
wondering if anyone could give me some advice on it. I've heard that
the ones from hungary are the best. Why? Also, are the american
cubes from the '80s similar to the hungarian cubes?

~John~





305. ZB method group
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 04:15:09 -0000

Hey everyone,

I know there have been groups in the past for corners-first, blindfold
solving, etc. Well I created a ZB method group here at:

http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/zbmethod/

I am going to get very serious about learning ZBLL algs again. I
already know 1 COLL case for the U orientation, and will be trying to
finish it in less than 5 months. Then I want to learn the L
orientation (names come from Dan Harris' page). After that I want to
take averages, as I think those three orientation cases, plus the no
OLL case orientation, will be enough to average sub-16 fairly often
with ZB.

Anyway, as far as I am concerned this method is an experiment, but it
sounds like there are others interested in learning.

In order to make it easier for us to share ideas, if you are
interested in learning please join the group so we can discuss ideas
and things.

Even if you're a skeptic, please feel free to join the group. Again
this method is an experiment, so I think it would be best to have
people for and against it feel free to discuss how they feel about the
method.

I'm just going to post here about the creation of this group, I will
try to contain my discussion of ZB to the ZB group in the future.

Chris

307. Re: Good Times
From: "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 09:28:15 -0000

Macky, we found your camera in the restaurant. We handed it over at the reception desk and we told them it was yours, so you can have it picked up or sent to you. Once again I had another great time meeting you all also. And it is truely amazing how much the standard has risen. I felt quite bad about just missing out on the 3x3 final (I finished 13th in the semis) but if I look at all those wonderful averages that other people set, I should be quite proud of my placing. This was certainly the best Rubik's competition I've been to and I hope there will be many more. 309. Re: Good Times
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 13:40:22 -0000

Well, I guess it is time to put my two cents in...I'll write a report sometime. It was amazing meeting everyone for the first time. I never expected everyone to as nice as they were. Some of the people didn't look like I expected, but that's given when you are making assumptions. Thank you everyone who taught me something new, and to everyone that was there and I got to talk to and hang out with thank you too. I can't wait until I go to another tournament. Congratulations to all the winners of the different events and congratulations on all the world records that were broken, you guys are amazing at what you do. Craig P.S. - I did a magic average of 100 last night, got 1.56, best average of 10 (12 dropping fastest and slowest) was 1.44, and Bob...I broke my 1.40 PB soooo many times, and I got one sub-1.3 solve, which tied your old world record. I am coming to get you all in the magic...watch out... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@t...> wrote: > > Macky, > > we found your camera in the restaurant. 310. Pepper and Sugar ;-)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 14:20:09 -0000

Hi guys (and guyesses ...) :D

Many great things have been said about the WC in Orlando and i agree
with what has been said. It's amazing to see so many fast cubers
when there is about zilch (nil) in Norway taking cubing seriously.
12 guys in the final without Lars Vandenbergh or Ron van Bruchem or
Joël van Noort in it. Well, that looks weird to me ... hehehe ...
And a bunch of world and national records were set.

But im not really too happy with the organisation of the event. My
main complaints are :

- should be outdoor to provide fairness and better atmosphere for
the contestants

- poor result service, not very good use of the large monitor
provided ... no info about "side events"

- discrimination of the "side events" - non rubiks puzles, and also
dicrimination of these as only the winners were called, not 3rd, 2nd
and 1st like for the other events

- very bad conditions for fewest moves, first day inside in a small
room, second day even worse ... outside sitting by a small table
only ... also first day the scramble was not provided on a sheet
like second day ... and i really hope we can use stickers next
time ... i always end up with cycles in the end .. with no stickers
i can't optimise anything :-( ... i gonna propose changes to the
rules fo fewest moves :-)

Ok, now for some positive feedback. I spoke to Dave Hedley Jones. I
suggested some improvments for the 5x5x5 cube. And actually they are
now doing some re-engineering, so now is a good time to come up with
ideas for improving their puzzles :-) I will send Dave an email to
remind him and then we will see how it goes ...

It was really great to see the faces behind all the names that i
knew beforehand :-D

Cheers!

-Per





311. speedcubing.com has been slashdotted
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 09:52:58 -0500

Take a look at http://slashdot.org. There's a story about the world
championship on the front page. This site gets about 3 million page
views per day, so that's some pretty good publicity.


312. Re: speedcubing.com has been slashdotted
From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 15:05:11 -0000

Haha David, I just got on here to post a message about that, since I just checked slashdot. You beat me to it. One of the interesting things I noticed while reading through the comments is that there are far more people who are amazed rather than skeptical. Whenever a speedcubing video gets posted to a site (I remember one on fazed.org), a lot of people instantly assume its a fake, and try to think about how they made the fake video. I think since people can see that there is a world championships, it adds a lot of credibility in their minds. I hope speedcubing.com can handle the slashdotting. Was the poster a member of the group, or was it an outsider? Chris Parlette --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > > Take a look at http://slashdot.org. There's a story about the world > championship on the front page. This site gets about 3 million page > views per day, so that's some pretty good publicity. >
313. Dan has a problem :-S
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 15:24:22 -0000

Hi guys,

I have a problem... The login details for the CubeStation Webspace
have changed, and I haven't been told the new login/password.

I can't get hold of the guy who owns the webspace, because he won't
answer the most current email address I have for him. I don't have a
phone number, but I have a name, Chris Maggs, and he is from Wales, UK.

This means I can't make any updates to CubeStation, the FMC, Pictures,
Reports, anything, until I am able to re-access the webspace :( I also
don't have an exact copy of the website structure on my hard-drive, so
it would be extremely hard to replicate the directory structure
exactly elsewhere.

Any ideas?????????

Dan :)

317. VERY VERY FAST Z-perm
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 16:38:03 -0000

Gilles van den Peereboom showed me an absolutely fantastic Z-perm that
he came up with that uses only M' and U (not even U' or M!). I have
only been practicing it a little bit, but I did manage to get one in
1.600 seconds (video analysis). Take a look:

http://www.cubewhiz.com/temp/fastzperm.avi

The file is 536 KB and requires DivX. For those interested in trying
out the alg, here it is:

[U2] M2' U M2' U M' U2 M2' U2 M'. The U2 adjustment works great
before the alg because it is quite easy to recognize this case from U2
(more so than from U or U', for me). You could also do the U2 at the
end if you insist on first moving all the corners to their solved
position.

~ Bob






318. Re: original cubes
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 16:55:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, giraffeboy13 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I'm looking at getting an original 3x3 cube (from the '80s) and i was > wondering if anyone could give me some advice on it. I've heard that > the ones from hungary are the best. Why? Also, are the american > cubes from the '80s similar to the hungarian cubes? > > ~John~ > Hi John, What do you mean by "American" cubes? Ideal made some cubes in America and Logical Games made the "American Cube" before Ideal made any cubes. I haven't tried to make a speedcube out of either, though apparently the "American Cube" cam lubed with silicone! For speedcubing I rate the cubes: 1. Ideal Tiled Deluxe Edition Best all around, no other cube comes close. It has adjusting screws and is arched underneath the centers - the hard, slick plastic is thicker than others and is faster unlubed than all the other cubes lubed. It is a bit heavier than other cubes. Rarely pops or locks up. Takes silicon spray lube very well, but not Rubiks.com lube. No need for stickers. The Rubik's Game/Challenge has Deluxe cubes with peg holes. I takes about 5 minutes to get used to the peg holes which can make for better grip. 2. The new cubes from Seven Towns (Rubiks.com, Hasbro, Winning Moves and Hessport) Comes with arched centers, can be ordered with screws as a DIY. These never pop. Lighter than the Deluxe, it takes rubiks.com lube well. Tends to lock up more than the Deluxe. They come with terrible stickers. Averages 1 1/2 seconds slower than Deluxe for 30 second solve. 3. Ideal cubes circa 1980-1983. The ones made in Hungary, England, and Hong Kong are the best. I have heard that the ones made in Korea are good, too. Avoid the Taiwan-made cubes. These have adjustable screws, and excellent stickers. Very few have arches, but the arched version is the lightest official cube. Without arches they tend to pop instead of locking up. Averages 2 1/2 second slower than the Deluxe for a 30 second solve. 4. Rubik's studio cubes. Has the best plastic of cubes made nowadays. Comes with screws but not arches. Pops quite a lot. Averages nearly three second slower than the Deluxe for a 30 second solve. I have't used the three I have enough to know the sticker wear. 5. Older Hasbro (etc) cube (before 2000) had screws, but not arches. A friends older Hasbro speedcube is fairly quick, but I have little experience with this one. The one I have is terrible. 6. Wonderful Puzzler. Well made knock-off, came with arches. Never tried to make one into a speed cube. I don't know if they have screws. 7. C*4 cube Made by Matchbox in the late 80s, with Rubik's silkouette and signature. Lousy plastic. Not a very good cube. 8. Mefferts These are terrible because they have no pressure and you must stop a turn with effort. Constantly locks up. Decent plastic, but no springs or screws. There are lots of tiled cubes out there which are terrible, leading the list is the "Old Brand Magic Square" (though Stefan likes the springs). The only high quality tiled knock-off was called Gyro Cube, and it has flat centers. Regards, David J
319. Re: Dan has a problem :-S
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 16:57:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n. ..> wrote: > > I have a problem... The login details for the CubeStation Webspace > have changed, and I haven't been told the new login/password. > > Any ideas????????? Go to Wales and beat the guy up. Why don't you have your own webspace? It got real cheap by now. There are also websites that list good hosts, with tests for speed and availability, and user feedback. Well, I'm only assuming there's one for UK. Here's one for Germany so you know what I'm talking about: http://www.hostsuche.de/top10_bew_all.php You can see the #1 in the list has 306 positive feedbacks and 0 negative. Feedback is what I mainly care about besides the price. If you look at their website you'll see you can get for example 1GB webspace with unlimited traffic for about 3.50 GBP per month. Cheers! Stefan
320. Metric question
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 17:01:29 -0000

Hi Guys and Gals,

In the notation I use, where lower case means a slice, instead of
taking the long way around, like L2 R2 D2 L2 F2 L2 R2 B2 R2 D2 which
is 10 moves, or L2 R2 D U' B2 F2 D U' which is 8 moves, my 4-spot
pattern is four moves: r2 u r2 u'.

The 6-spot pattern is four moves, too: r f r' f'.

I'm interested in the fewest moves needed to solve the cube using this
notation. What metric should these be classified within? What would
the upper and lower bounds be?

Thanks,

David J






321. Re: original cubes
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 17:11:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > For speedcubing I rate the cubes: Hi David, when are you going to include the "averages X seconds slower than Deluxe for Y second solve" stats for Y less than 30? With 30 it's not really interesting since you don't need fast turning or good look ahead for that at all. I'd be more interested in Y=15. Cheers! Stefan

324. Re: VERY VERY FAST Z-perm
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 17:29:18 -0000

...or M2UM2UF2M2F2M2 or M2UM2U'E2M'E2M'... (I let you find the fingertricks). This permutation is just a case in a "6 edges 4 centers"-last strategy, where edges are already oriented (insert UL/UR-edges, permute M-edges). (the other) Gilles. PS: many 6E4C cases are faster than this one ;-) PS2: I don't have a DivX decoder right now, but 1.6s is FAST! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Gilles van den Peereboom showed me an absolutely fantastic Z-perm that > he came up with that uses only M' and U (not even U' or M!). I have > only been practicing it a little bit, but I did manage to get one in > 1.600 seconds (video analysis). Take a look: > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/temp/fastzperm.avi > > The file is 536 KB and requires DivX. For those interested in trying > out the alg, here it is: > > [U2] M2' U M2' U M' U2 M2' U2 M'. The U2 adjustment works great > before the alg because it is quite easy to recognize this case from U2 > (more so than from U or U', for me). You could also do the U2 at the > end if you insist on first moving all the corners to their solved > position. > > ~ Bob >

328. Re: original cubes
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 17:56:47 -0000

Very thorough analysis. I would add a few minor points. 1) The Ideal tiled model is MAJORLY expensive (I think $300 is not unheard of)! 2) I would also caution against the Korean cubes which appear to be hit or miss. The ones I got already came with some nasty lube that looked like earwax. It was impossible to get it all off and when I added silicone...the cube was toast. It would not turn without sticking. 3) Virtually all Ideal cubes, except maybe the Hungarian ones, have a color scheme of white-opp-blue, yellow-opp-green. If you get a tiled or game cube I'm not sure how easy it is to switch over to the "standard" white-yellow. Stickers are not much of a problem thanks to Cubesmith, though you may need some extra solvents to get all the gunk off from the old ones. BTW, I am now forcing myself to use white-yellow. A new convert after 20+ years of doing it the 'wrong' way. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > For speedcubing I rate the cubes: > > 1. Ideal Tiled Deluxe Edition > Best all around, no other cube comes close. It has adjusting screws > and is arched underneath the centers - the hard, slick plastic is > thicker than others and is faster unlubed than all the other cubes > lubed. It is a bit heavier than other cubes. Rarely pops or locks up. > Takes silicon spray lube very well, but not Rubiks.com lube. No need > for stickers. > > The Rubik's Game/Challenge has Deluxe cubes with peg holes. I takes > about 5 minutes to get used to the peg holes which can make for better > grip. > > 2. The new cubes from Seven Towns (Rubiks.com, Hasbro, Winning Moves > and Hessport) > Comes with arched centers, can be ordered with screws as a DIY. These > never pop. Lighter than the Deluxe, it takes rubiks.com lube well. > Tends to lock up more than the Deluxe. They come with terrible > stickers. Averages 1 1/2 seconds slower than Deluxe for 30 second solve. > > 3. Ideal cubes circa 1980-1983. > The ones made in Hungary, England, and Hong Kong are the best. I have > heard that the ones made in Korea are good, too. Avoid the Taiwan- made > cubes. These have adjustable screws, and excellent stickers. Very few > have arches, but the arched version is the lightest official cube. > Without arches they tend to pop instead of locking up. Averages 2 1/2 > second slower than the Deluxe for a 30 second solve. > > 4. Rubik's studio cubes. Has the best plastic of cubes made nowadays. > Comes with screws but not arches. Pops quite a lot. Averages nearly > three second slower than the Deluxe for a 30 second solve. I have't > used the three I have enough to know the sticker wear. > > 5. Older Hasbro (etc) cube (before 2000) had screws, but not arches. A > friends older Hasbro speedcube is fairly quick, but I have little > experience with this one. The one I have is terrible. > > 6. Mefferts > These are terrible because they have no pressure and you must stop a > turn with effort. Constantly locks up. 329. Re: original cubes

330. Re: Metric question
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 18:03:13 -0000

Hi David --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > I'm interested in the fewest moves needed to solve the cube using this > notation. What metric should these be classified within? Slice HTM, surely. > What would > the upper and lower bounds be? Well.. the upper bound cannot /exceed/ Mike Reid's figure of 29, which is the current upper bound in HTM. Presumably this could be reduced, but you'd have to persuade someone to repeat Reid's calculations for your new metric. As for the lower bound, I don't currently have the energy to do the standard counting argument, taking into account commutation of moves on the same axis -- but you almost certainly know how to do this anyway. Since it is the argument that gives 18 (rather than 20) as the lower bound for HTM, you probably wanted something better than that. Unfortunately, I don't have an optimal solver for this metric, so I can't try likely-looking candidates... Regards Mike

From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 18:56:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > Hi guys, > > I have a problem... The login details for the CubeStation Webspace > have changed, and I haven't been told the new login/password. > > I can't get hold of the guy who owns the webspace, because he won't > answer the most current email address I have for him. I don't have a > phone number, but I have a name, Chris Maggs, and he is from Wales, UK. > > This means I can't make any updates to CubeStation, the FMC, Pictures, > Reports, anything, until I am able to re-access the webspace :( I also > don't have an exact copy of the website structure on my hard-drive, so > it would be extremely hard to replicate the directory structure > exactly elsewhere. > > Any ideas????????? > > Dan :) > I just checked up, he's not registered with a BT phone line, or he isn't in their database, it's hard to tell. Tryed 07801939130? Surly he's able to change your login details or tell you the new ones. ~Thom
