333. Re: VERY VERY FAST Z-perm
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 19:37:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > [U2] M2' U M2' U M' U2 M2' U2 M'. The U2 adjustment works great > before the alg because it is quite easy to recognize this case from U2 > (more so than from U or U', for me). You could also do the U2 at the > end if you insist on first moving all the corners to their solved > position. > > ~ Bob > Since we talked about this on Sunday, I've switched to this as my primary alg for the case, but I do it in reverse. M' U2 M2 U2 M' U M2 U M2 U2. I think this is actually the same alg that I posted a while back, but abandoned because I couldn't get fast with it. After practicing this time for perhaps 50 repetitions it's slightly faster than my old alg, and still improving. I really like M U algs for the edge perms, because I can do them quickly. -Mike Bennett
334. Re: VERY VERY FAST Z-perm
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 19:57:00 -0000

Ah, yes. You are right: http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/18660 I didn't realize you posted both algorithms. I only remembered the one you got from SCC. That is indeed the algorithm I am using. :) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > wrote: > > > > > [U2] M2' U M2' U M' U2 M2' U2 M'. The U2 adjustment works great > > before the alg because it is quite easy to recognize this case from U2 > > (more so than from U or U', for me). You could also do the U2 at the > > end if you insist on first moving all the corners to their solved > > position. > > > > ~ Bob > > > > Since we talked about this on Sunday, I've switched to this as my > primary alg for the case, but I do it in reverse. M' U2 M2 U2 M' U M2 > U M2 U2. > > I think this is actually the same alg that I posted a while back, but > abandoned because I couldn't get fast with it. > > After practicing this time for perhaps 50 repetitions it's slightly > faster than my old alg, and still improving. I really like M U algs > for the edge perms, because I can do them quickly. > > -Mike Bennett >
335. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: VERY VERY FAST Z-perm
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 21:04:56 +0100

Hehe, I'm happy to see that some of my ideas are not so bad. :-) Unfortunately I was pretty sure that someone else had found that alg, but I'm happy 'cause I've found it too :-). (Bob, getting better using your ring finger / middle finger use for the M move :D) I can't wait for the next tournament :-) Gilles. 2005/11/10, Bob Burton <bob@...>: > Ah, yes. You are right: > > http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/18660 > > I didn't realize you posted both algorithms. I only remembered the > one you got from SCC. That is indeed the algorithm I am using. :) > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > > wrote: > > > > > > > > [U2] M2' U M2' U M' U2 M2' U2 M'. The U2 adjustment works great > > > before the alg because it is quite easy to recognize this case from U2 > > > (more so than from U or U', for me). You could also do the U2 at the > > > end if you insist on first moving all the corners to their solved > > > position. > > > > > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > Since we talked about this on Sunday, I've switched to this as my > > primary alg for the case, but I do it in reverse. M' U2 M2 U2 M' U M2 > > U M2 U2. > > > > I think this is actually the same alg that I posted a while back, but > > abandoned because I couldn't get fast with it. > > > > After practicing this time for perhaps 50 repetitions it's slightly > > faster than my old alg, and still improving. I really like M U algs > > for the edge perms, because I can do them quickly. > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
336. Re: link request
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 20:07:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > If you have a program that generates ZBLL or ZBF2L cases for > practicing purposes could you please send me the link at chris [at] > speedcubing [dot] com? > > I'm collecting the links for the ZB group and I don't remember all the > URLs > > Thanks, > Chris > You need to talk to Ian Winokur. He was telling me about his brother's program. I thought he said the link was www.jwinyeh.com, but I tried that and it didn't exist. I guess I really should have written it down... Anyway, you upload whatever algs you want into the program, and it gives you cases to practice based off the algs. You can customize it to give you OLLs, PLLs, ZBLL, etc. -Mike Bennett

With 30 it's not > really interesting since you don't need fast turning or good look > ahead for that at all. I'd be more interested in Y=15. > > Cheers! > Stefan > Those stats were accurate for me when I took them about two years ago. In the Spring tournament in 2004 I loaned Macky one of my Deluxe cubes and he did a "Champion's Solve" 12.29 IIRC. When I got home I found that I had given him the wrong cube and the one he used, though adjusted nicely, was not lubed. I'd need to get someone quicker than I to get you sub fifteen numbers. 340. Re: original cubes
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 20:43:17 -0000

I kwickykanny, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@e...> wrote: > > Very thorough analysis. Thanks. > I would add a few minor points. > > 1) The Ideal tiled model is MAJORLY expensive (I think $300 is not > unheard of)! yes, but that's for a sealed one. The Game cube is the same quality and isn't expensive. > 2) I would also caution against the Korean cubes which appear to be > hit or miss. The ones I got already came with some nasty lube that > looked like earwax. It was impossible to get it all off and when I > added silicone...the cube was toast. It would not turn without > sticking. OK, thanks. > 3) Virtually all Ideal cubes, except maybe the Hungarian ones, have a > color scheme of white-opp-blue, yellow-opp-green. If you get a tiled > or game cube I'm not sure how easy it is to switch over to > the "standard" white-yellow. This was the first Official Color Scheme back the, The old 4x4x4s and 2x2x2'a were that color too. As for switching to the newer Official Color Scheme, BOY, ask Stefan. > Stickers are not much of a problem > thanks to Cubesmith, though you may need some extra solvents to get > all the gunk off from the old ones. Yeah, the next person who tells me that they solved the cube by switching stickers I'm going to invite home to help me change stickers on a few cubes! > BTW, I am now forcing myself to use white-yellow. A new convert > after 20+ years of doing it the 'wrong' way. Cool. I prefer the old standard. What color do you use for the Last Level? I use Red for the Last Level, but I don't use the cross. Cheers, David J > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > For speedcubing I rate the cubes: > > > > 1. Ideal Tiled Deluxe Edition > > Best all around, no other cube comes close. It has adjusting screws > > and is arched underneath the centers - the hard, slick plastic is > > thicker than others and is faster unlubed than all the other cubes > > lubed. It is a bit heavier than other cubes. Rarely pops or locks > up. > > Takes silicon spray lube very well, but not Rubiks.com lube. No need > > for stickers. > > > > The Rubik's Game/Challenge has Deluxe cubes with peg holes. I takes > > about 5 minutes to get used to the peg holes which can make for > better > > grip. > > > > 2. The new cubes from Seven Towns (Rubiks.com, Hasbro, Winning Moves > > and Hessport) > > Comes with arched centers, can be ordered with screws as a DIY. > These > > never pop. Lighter than the Deluxe, it takes rubiks.com lube well. > > Tends to lock up more than the Deluxe. They come with terrible > > stickers. Averages 1 1/2 seconds slower than Deluxe for 30 second > solve. > > > > 3. Ideal cubes circa 1980-1983. > > The ones made in Hungary, England, and Hong Kong are the best. I > have > > heard that the ones made in Korea are good, too. Avoid the Taiwan- > made > > cubes. These have adjustable screws, and excellent stickers. Very > few > > have arches, but the arched version is the lightest official cube. > > Without arches they tend to pop instead of locking up. Averages 2 > 1/2 > > second slower than the Deluxe for a 30 second solve. > > > > 4. Rubik's studio cubes. Has the best plastic of cubes made > nowadays. > > Comes with screws but not arches. Pops quite a lot. Averages nearly > > three second slower than the Deluxe for a 30 second solve. I have't > > used the three I have enough to know the sticker wear. > > > > 5. Older Hasbro (etc) cube (before 2000) had screws, but not > arches. A > > friends older Hasbro speedcube is fairly quick, but I have little > > experience with this one. The one I have is terrible. > > > > 6. Wonderful Puzzler. > > Well made knock-off, came with arches. Never tried to make one into > a > > speed cube. I don't know if they have screws. > > > > 7. C*4 cube > > Made by Matchbox in the late 80s, with Rubik's silkouette and > > signature. Lousy plastic. Not a very good cube. > > > > 8. Mefferts > > These are terrible because they have no pressure and you must stop a > > turn with effort. Constantly locks up. Decent plastic, but no > springs > > or screws. > > > > There are lots of tiled cubes out there which are terrible, leading > > the list is the "Old Brand Magic Square" (though Stefan likes the > > springs). The only high quality tiled knock-off was called Gyro > Cube, > > and it has flat centers. > > > > Regards, > > > > David J
341. Re: Metric question
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 20:52:45 -0000

Hi Mike, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hi David > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > I'm interested in the fewest moves needed to solve the cube using this > > notation. What metric should these be classified within? > > Slice HTM, surely. Ah, a new metric. Thanks. > > What would > > the upper and lower bounds be? > > Well.. the upper bound cannot /exceed/ Mike Reid's figure of 29, which > is the current upper bound in HTM. I thought that was 26. > Presumably this could be reduced, > but you'd have to persuade someone to repeat Reid's calculations for > your new metric. Anybody? > As for the lower bound, I don't currently have the energy to do the > standard counting argument, taking into account commutation of moves on > the same axis -- but you almost certainly know how to do this anyway. > Since it is the argument that gives 18 (rather than 20) as the lower > bound for HTM, you probably wanted something better than that. Yes, that's implied. > Unfortunately, I don't have an optimal solver for this metric, so I > can't try likely-looking candidates... Does anyone? > Regards > Mike Thanks, Cheers, David J

346. WC2005: "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler"
From: "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 22:52:05 -0000

All --

Out of curiousity, I decided to use a "points system" to determine
the "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler" at WC2005. I've been thinking about
this as an extra category at competitions.

**** Quick Explanation:

"points system" = 10pts for first, 9 for second, etc, through top 10
or end of competitors or DNF/DNS. If final was only 8 people, I gave
points to #9/#10 from previous round.

"Top Cuber" = list people by most points based on cubing events listed
on main stage (2x, 3x, 4x, 5x, 3x-blind, 3x-onehand, 3x-feet, 3x-
fewestmoves, 4x-blind, 5x-blind)

"Top Puzzler" = list people by ost points based on all events
(includes "side" events aka Magic, Clock, Megaminx, Square1, Master
Magic, 3x-speed-blindfolded, Magic-onehand).

**** Results

Top Cuber
---------
Leyan Lo = 34 pts
Chris Hardwick = 27 pts
Yuki Hayashi = 22 pts
Shotaro Makisumi = 21 pts
Masayuki Akimoto = 20 pts

Leyan and Chris both placed top 10 in five events - very impressive!


Top Puzzler
-----------
Stefan Pochmann = 61 pts
Alexander Ooms = 36 pts
Leyan Lo = 34 pts
Chris Hardwick = 31 pts
Lars Vandenbergh = 30 pts

Stefan placed in every "side" event except 3x-speedblindfold, winning
three and placing second, third and sixth in the others - he is Puzzle-
Man.


I'll put the Excel spreadsheet on the site later and add the link.
Enjoy the info,

yeff

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@y...> wrote: > > All -- > > Out of curiousity, I decided to use a "points system" to determine > the "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler" at WC2005. 348. Re: [Speed cubing group] VERY VERY FAST Z-perm
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 00:41:40 +0100

That M' is mightily impressive. Do you have a slower video showing this
finger action? Do you have something similarly nice for M? Does anyone
else but Bob perform M' this way, at such blazing speed?

/Gustav

Bob Burton skrev:

>Gilles van den Peereboom showed me an absolutely fantastic Z-perm that
>he came up with that uses only M' and U (not even U' or M!). I have
>only been practicing it a little bit, but I did manage to get one in
>1.600 seconds (video analysis). Take a look:
>
>http://www.cubewhiz.com/temp/fastzperm.avi
>
>The file is 536 KB and requires DivX. For those interested in trying
>out the alg, here it is:
>
>[U2] M2' U M2' U M' U2 M2' U2 M'. The U2 adjustment works great
>before the alg because it is quite easy to recognize this case from U2
>(more so than from U or U', for me). You could also do the U2 at the
>end if you insist on first moving all the corners to their solved
>position.
>
>~ Bob

349. The UFO Puzzle
From: "maria_rivilis" <maryry@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 23:52:49 -0000

Good evening, For those of you who were at the world championships and got a UFO puzzle, this might be interesting. Wes and I wrote an interactive solver for it. You can find it at <http://www.terpstra.ca/puzzles/ufo.php> By clicking the pieces from the right UFO, you can move them (via the middle) to the left UFO. Once the left UFO is completely filled up, the program will find a move-optimal solution. Interesting facts about the puzzle include: There are exactly 11! distinct states (12* more if you hold it differently) - the included booklet is wrong by 800 states for whatever reason Every state is reachable (all moves are odd permutations, so even/odd are both reachable) The longest distance between any two states is 16 moves Interesting facts about the solver include: It only needs to explore 11 thousand states on average It's written in Standard ML (compiled by MLton.org) and PHP On a decent machine (not that webserver), it needs < 1s Some useful operations are: flip two neighbours <http://www.terpstra.ca/puzzles/ufo.php? gyr=0&grb=1&ggo=2&gbg=3&gop=4&gpy=5&bry=6&bbr=7&bgb=8&bog=9&bpo=10&b yp=11> flip top and bottom pieces <http://www.terpstra.ca/puzzles/ufo.php? gyr=0&grb=1&gbg=2&ggo=3&gop=4&byp=5&bry=6&bbr=7&bgb=8&bog=9&bpo=10&g py=11> ... notice that these are really far apart states. :-) Have fun, Maria
350. Re: link request
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 00:24:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ian" <iwinoky@y...> wrote: > > http://www.jaywinyeah.com/projects > > See Mike's comments below. > > Ian I've got the latest version of JRE, I downloaded the java3D program, and I installed the cube program. However, the shortcut does nothing, save open a box for about quarter of a second and close it again. The actual folder the program downloaded to is full of class files and some MS DOS batch files. Nothing I can use to actually run the program. Any help would be much appreciated. -Mike Bennett
351. Re: original cubes
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 00:35:30 -0000

> > BTW, I am now forcing myself to use white-yellow. A new convert
> > after 20+ years of doing it the 'wrong' way.
>
> Why would you do that? I can't imagine it would make you any faster.
>
> ~ Bob

You're right, I'm avging about 5s slower now. It's just part of a
general philosophy of mine to try to be more conventional, within the
realm of cubing and elsewhere. I think I'm too individualistic.





352. Re: original cubes
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 00:46:45 -0000

> > BTW, I am now forcing myself to use white-yellow. A new convert
> > after 20+ years of doing it the 'wrong' way.
>
> Cool. I prefer the old standard.
>
> What color do you use for the Last Level? I use Red for the Last
> Level, but I don't use the cross.
>
> Cheers,
>
> David J

Wow, I seldom run into folks who like the old scheme! There is one
other long-time cuber at my workplace and even he likes the new one.

For LL I was using blue on the old scheme and green on the new. Now I
am strictly using the new scheme with LL = yellow. I think that's what
most people do.





353. Re: [Speed cubing group] VERY VERY FAST Z-perm
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 00:48:37 -0000

I haven't made a slow demonstration of this particular algorithm yet, but I have made one for my H-perm. Check out: http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll05fast.avi (fast) http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll05slow.avi (slow) I use my ring and middle fingers for successive M'. All U is done with the right index and middle fingers. I am not so good at M, but I would like to be. ;) I showed Chris Hardwick how to do M' in this way and he also has a mighty fast H-perm. We sometimes race H-perms and he can certainly beat me sometimes. :) It is awkward at first, but practice makes perfect. ;) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@s...> wrote: > > That M' is mightily impressive. Do you have a slower video showing this > finger action? Do you have something similarly nice for M? Does anyone > else but Bob perform M' this way, at such blazing speed? > > /Gustav > > Bob Burton skrev: > > >Gilles van den Peereboom showed me an absolutely fantastic Z-perm that > >he came up with that uses only M' and U (not even U' or M!). I have > >only been practicing it a little bit, but I did manage to get one in > >1.600 seconds (video analysis). Take a look: > > > >http://www.cubewhiz.com/temp/fastzperm.avi > > > >The file is 536 KB and requires DivX. For those interested in trying > >out the alg, here it is: > > > >[U2] M2' U M2' U M' U2 M2' U2 M'. The U2 adjustment works great > >before the alg because it is quite easy to recognize this case from U2 > >(more so than from U or U', for me). You could also do the U2 at the > >end if you insist on first moving all the corners to their solved > >position. > > > >~ Bob > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >__________ NOD32 1.1282 (20051109) Information __________ > > > >This message was checked by NOD32 antivirus system. > >http://www.nod32.com > > > > > > > > > > >
354. 5x5x5 algorithm help
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 00:57:05 -0000

I've decided to better my 5x5 solving after my recent success with my
homemade 4x4 method. I've gotten my average down to about 9 minutes
this way, but I think that's mostly because it's a brand new 5x5 and
it doesn't turn very well at all yet.

Anyway, I solve what basically amounts to edges first, and one area
I'm having entirely too much trouble in is the center pieces on the
final 4 faces (all in a slice). I finish this step by swapping single
pieces between adjacent faces, and when I can see it, either rows of 3
pieces, or less frequently, groups of two.

My real problems stem from pieces being on opposite faces from where
they go. Currently, I have no choice but to move one piece to an
adjacent face, switch the piece into place moving the second piece
onto the adjacent face, and then fix the remaining pair. It's twice
as many moves as it should be, and I suspect there are good tricks for
pieces on opposite faces like on the 4x4.

Anyway, someone should reply with helpful moves quickly, as my poor
wrists won't last much longer. ;)

-Mike Bennett






355. Re: [Speed cubing group] VERY VERY FAST Z-perm
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 01:03:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > I use my ring and middle fingers for successive M'. All U is done > with the right index and middle fingers. > > I am not so good at M, but I would like to be. ;) I showed Chris > Hardwick how to do M' in this way and he also has a mighty fast > H-perm. We sometimes race H-perms and he can certainly beat me > sometimes. :) It is awkward at first, but practice makes perfect. ;) > > ~ Bob All the cool kids still do M' as rR'. ;P -Mike Bennett
356. (stickers) It's all in the logo
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 01:47:26 -0000

I like having a Rubiks logo on my cube because it just looks weird to
me when it's missing, but it appears that a lot of people go logo-
less. So I was wondering....

1) Why do you prefer logo/non-logo? Although I don't do this, I was
thinking maybe it could help you solve the cross, (mentally
remembering "The white-red piece is now at the top of the logo" or
something like that).

2) For 3x3 competitions, can you have a logo somewhere other than a
center? Can you have a logo on more than one square?





357. Re: original cubes
From: "keefdcuber" <keithrx3c@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 01:55:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, giraffeboy13 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > I'm looking at getting an original 3x3 cube (from the '80s) and i was > > wondering if anyone could give me some advice on it. I've heard that > > the ones from hungary are the best. Why? Also, are the american > > cubes from the '80s similar to the hungarian cubes? > > > > ~John~ > > > > Hi John, > > What do you mean by "American" cubes? Ideal made some cubes in America > and Logical Games made the "American Cube" before Ideal made any cubes. > I haven't tried to make a speedcube out of either, though apparently > the "American Cube" cam lubed with silicone! > > For speedcubing I rate the cubes: > > 1. Ideal Tiled Deluxe Edition > Best all around, no other cube comes close. It has adjusting screws > and is arched underneath the centers - the hard, slick plastic is > thicker than others and is faster unlubed than all the other cubes > lubed. It is a bit heavier than other cubes. Rarely pops or locks up. > Takes silicon spray lube very well, but not Rubiks.com lube. No need > for stickers. > > The Rubik's Game/Challenge has Deluxe cubes with peg holes. I takes > about 5 minutes to get used to the peg holes which can make for better > grip. > > 2. The new cubes from Seven Towns (Rubiks.com, Hasbro, Winning Moves > and Hessport) > Comes with arched centers, can be ordered with screws as a DIY. These > never pop. Lighter than the Deluxe, it takes rubiks.com lube well. > Tends to lock up more than the Deluxe. They come with terrible > stickers. Averages 1 1/2 seconds slower than Deluxe for 30 second solve. > > 3. Ideal cubes circa 1980-1983. > The ones made in Hungary, England, and Hong Kong are the best. I have > heard that the ones made in Korea are good, too. Avoid the Taiwan- made > cubes. These have adjustable screws, and excellent stickers. Very few > have arches, but the arched version is the lightest official cube. > Without arches they tend to pop instead of locking up. Averages 2 1/2 > second slower than the Deluxe for a 30 second solve. > > 4. Rubik's studio cubes. Has the best plastic of cubes made nowadays. > Comes with screws but not arches. Pops quite a lot. Averages nearly > three second slower than the Deluxe for a 30 second solve. I have't > used the three I have enough to know the sticker wear. > > 5. Older Hasbro (etc) cube (before 2000) had screws, but not arches. A > friends older Hasbro speedcube is fairly quick, but I have little > experience with this one. The one I have is terrible. > > 6. Wonderful Puzzler. > Well made knock-off, came with arches. Never tried to make one into a > speed cube. I don't know if they have screws. > > 7. C*4 cube > Made by Matchbox in the late 80s, with Rubik's silkouette and > signature. Lousy plastic. Not a very good cube. > > 8. Mefferts > These are terrible because they have no pressure and you must stop a > turn with effort. Constantly locks up. Decent plastic, but no springs > or screws. > > There are lots of tiled cubes out there which are terrible, leading > the list is the "Old Brand Magic Square" (though Stefan likes the > springs). The only high quality tiled knock-off was called Gyro Cube, > and it has flat centers. > > Regards, > > David J > Hey guys, I've been wanting to get my hands on an original Deluxe tiled cube (or 2) for ages and haven't been able to find any apart from the odd sealed ones that come up on ebay an sell for $300 plus! How rare are these cubes and what are the centre caps like? I've got 2 Game Cubes that are pretty good, the only problem is that the centre caps are a pain to take off to adjust the screws. I've actually drilled out the peg holes in the caps of one to make for quick adjustment (I don't if that would break any competition rules) and the screws have a wider thread which makes adjustment a bit tedious, but apart from that they are good cubes. What are the crews in the Deluxe Cubes like David? Keith.

359. BLD out loud solve
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 18:21:37 -0800

Hi Everyone,

People have been asked me what I mumble while doing a BLD solve so I
decided to say them a bit more clearly above mumbling volume.
Hopefully you can hear what's going on. The vocalization for me is a
good way to retrieve information.

http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/outloud.AVI

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

367. Competition rules for Representation
From: "dmacauley" <dmacauley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 04:25:34 -0000

Hi all:
Does anyone know what the competition rules are in regards to a
contestant's country of representation?. That is, can a contestant
choose to represent any country in competition or is there a formal
process of verification?

I sent an email with this question to the official Rubik's cube site
before WC05 but did not hear back. It is pertinent as the WCA also
lists records by countries.

D.





368. Re: [Speed cubing group] Competition rules for Representation
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 20:29:27 -0800

You have to have a valid passport for that country (citizenship). The
one exception is Puerto Rico because the passport for Puerto Rico is a
United States passport. In that case, you must be born in Puerto Rico.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Nov 10, 2005, at 8:25 PM, dmacauley wrote:

> Hi all:

> contestant's country of representation?. That is, can a contestant
> choose to represent any country in competition or is there a formal
> process of verification?
>

> D.

369. Re: how many use CF?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 04:34:39 -0000

> Jason Kovacic
> Kovacic81@y...
>
> PS is CLL faster than COLL?

It is, and especially so when using the Roux method. Even with
correctly oriented edges before CLL, you can often achieve fast times
with edge flipping CLL algs, simply because they're shorter and easier.

That said, a very good deal of CLL algs are really COLL algs in
disguise. Take whichever ones are fastest for you.

For good CLL or COLL alg sites, speedcubing.com, Gilles Roux's site,
Lars Vandenbergh's, Dan Harris', and Bernard Helmsletter's sites are
all great.

-Mike

374. ROUX METHOD
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 10:37:32 -0000

I have decided to switch to the ROUX method, but i am slow.
I used to do it every once in a while, if I could see a good start.
Doing a 2x3x1 block every scramble 12 times is harder.

I would like to hear from anybody who uses, or has experimentented
with this method. WHat are your averages, how many CLL cases do you
know? What do you use to flip the two edges in UF and UB?

I took my first Roux avg tonight. Avg = 33.85 Best time was 26.88.

Keep in mind, I haven't learned a single CLL alg. So Step 3 (Corners)
takes me about 6 sec.
The Last 6 Edges take me about 8-10 seconds right now, but I can cut
that down to 5-6 with a little practice. Step 4 (Edges) is comparable
to OLL/PLL.

Any advice or help
would be greatly appreciated

Jason Kovacic
Kovacic81@...

I'm also changing my M' moves to the ring finger/ middle finger strategy instead of rR'. By the way, I improved that alg, it has now 8 moves ( + setup move) instead of 9(+ setup) but uses the F face : (U2) M2 U M2 U F2 M2 F2 M2 Though I think the 9 move sequence without the F is faster. 2005/11/11, Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>: > Yeah... thats the way I do it too, but after seeing Bobs videos I'm not > so sure thats the cool way to do it anymore ;) > > /Gustav > > Mike Bennett skrev: > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > >wrote: > > > > > >>I use my ring and middle fingers for successive M'. 381. Re: Metric question (ACube)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 12:05:16 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@s...> wrote: > JACube can solve optimally in STM. True, indeed. But its pruning tables are too small for it to do this job in a reasonable time -- rememember that to get a good lower bound we'd be looking for problems whose optimal solutions were as long as possible. For example, try using ACube to solve the superflip optimally in HTM or QTM. ;) Mike

383. Re: 5x5x5 algorithm help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 12:46:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > I've finally figured out a move to swap only two corner pieces on > opposite sides No you haven't. Unless you're taking the cube apart for this. You probably have a 3-cycle including two pieces of the same color, and knowing which three pieces you cycle will help you find setup moves that have the same "swap two pieces" effect on other sides. Cheers! Stefan

394. Re: original cubes
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 17:09:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "keefdcuber" <keithrx3c@h...> wrote: [snip] > > > Hey guys, > > I've been wanting to get my hands on an original Deluxe tiled cube > (or 2) for ages and haven't been able to find any apart from the odd > sealed ones that come up on ebay an sell for $300 plus! How rare are > these cubes and what are the centre caps like? > > I've got 2 Game Cubes that are pretty good, the only problem is that > the centre caps are a pain to take off to adjust the screws. I've > actually drilled out the peg holes in the caps of one to make for > quick adjustment (I don't if that would break any competition rules) > and the screws have a wider thread which makes adjustment a bit > tedious, but apart from that they are good cubes. > > What are the crews in the Deluxe Cubes like David? > > > Keith. Hi Keith, How rare are Deluxes? I have no idea how many were made. They turn up regularly on ebay. It is only recently that sealed Deluxes have gone for that much (two years ago one went for $250 but that was an anomaly then). In the last 2 years about 5 sealed Deluxe cubes have sold for less than $70. Recently bidders who nibble have been raising the prices (by prompting others to bid against them). Earlier this year three times I almost won a sealed Deluxe under $70 but warring bidders drove the price way up. Nibbling costs the bidders a whole lot of money - in England a terrible cube that retails here for $1.00 went for over $180. Some of the used Deluxe cubes I've gotten have no wear on them. They cost me between a high of $39 and a low of $6. Several recent auctions contained a Deluxe among other things and the seller didn't know what he had, and few people recognized it. The Rubik's Game cubes are Deluxe cubes, so the screws are the same - there are no caps, the screws are beneath the center tiles. However, there is way you can use different screws. About 15 years ago I broke the spindle of a Deluxe and substituted the spindle of another cube with no problem. To remove the tiles and get at the screws I use a very sharp 5/8 inch wood chisel which requires wearing work gloves. I push the edge of the chisel under the tile as far as it can go, which really isn't very far but is important, before I begin gently rocking the tile back and forth. I find I need to be patient, and gradually the glue lets go. :) If you can determine which is the correct side to try to lever up then you won't be working against the structure of the tile and the trough it sits in. The underside of the tile has two straight edges across from each other, and two sloped edges across from each other. These edges are twice the depth of the visible tile thickness, and fit neatly in the trough. The straight edges lay flat against the trough in the cubie, and if you try to lever that way you would need to bend or break the plastic of the tile to free it. The sloped edges are where the glue is and the right place to pry up because in that direction the tile will move like on a rocker, with no resistance. You may see slight indentations on the top of the tile, those are the slanted edges. Examine the center cubie that the tile fits in and you may see an additional way to determine which edges are slanted. I hope this helps. Cheers, David J
395. Re: how many use CF?
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 17:19:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikorkow" <calcdude@h...> wrote: > > I have noticed that almost EVERYBODY used a EF LL. I am one of the > few, the proud, the CF users. How many *good* cubers are there that > actually use a CFLL. I don't think CF is any harder or longer, so I > wonder why so few people use it. > I don't know how *good* a cuber I am, but I do corners first. Besides there being fewer algorithms to remember, often by some small change you can flip edges over as well, and sometimes flipping edges over too is fewer moves. This also means that the edges can be solved in as little as 8, 7 or even 5 moves. Cheers, David J
396. Re: Metric question
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 17:29:16 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > Slice HTM, surely. > > > > Ah, a new metric. Thanks. > > > Hmm, sorry if I misunderstand something, but since when is STM new? It > has also won the poll in the FMC group half a year ago: > http://tinyurl.com/ce8fo > > > > > Unfortunately, I don't have an optimal solver for this metric, so > I > > > can't try likely-looking candidates... > > > > Does anyone? > > > Josef has: > http://software.rubikscube.info/ > > Cheers! > Stefan Hi Stefan, The email I was answering contained the line > > Presumably this could be reduced, > but you'd have to persuade someone to repeat Reid's calculations for > your new metric. < Being unfamiliar with metrics - after all, I was asking which metric it fit into - I took Mike at his word that it was a new metric. Thanks for the info. Regards, David J
397. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: BLD out loud solve
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 09:37:47 -0800

Hi Pedro, It's a standard cube from rubiks.com. The solve was slow in that I wouldn't normally be making that much noise. A good solve portion blindfolded for me should take about 60 seconds or less. My best solves are about 45 seconds long. Orienting the corners was a 5-twist algorithm. (R U2 R' U2 R U R' U)x2 with some cube rotation. The song at the end... http://www.albinoblacksheep.com/flash/llama.php The number scheme I use is... for corners... every corner starts off with value 1. If the corner has an orange sticker, add 1. If the corner has a blue sticker, add 2. If the corner has a yellow sticker, add 4. That'll give you the 8 numbers. For the edges, 1 to 12 goes... (with white on top, green on front) UF UR UL UB FR FL BR BL DF DR DL DB. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Nov 11, 2005, at 8:13 AM, Pedro wrote: > I think is a DIY cube... > oh, do you really think that that's a slow solve? > well, for me it's really fast...: ) > > Oh, and Tyson, I can't understand the start...I guess you're orienting > the corners, but I didn't get what you're doing... > > and, what's that song at the end? > > Pedro > > PS.:Another thing I don't understand...english is not my primary > language, so I can't understand what you (and other cubers) say when > saying F' or R' or L'... > > Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...> escreveu: > Hey tyson tell me one thing, which cube is that you are using? > It sounds quite different to my cubes, is it a Rubiks.com cube? > > Sachin. > > On 11/11/05, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...> wrote: >> The end part is hilarious! >> >> Thanks for the vid though, i always wanted a slow video of a blindfold >> solve, in which steps can be seen clearly, most of the vids are not >> too clear, so i'll use this one to practice now. Maybe i'll mute my >> speakers :) >> >> Sachin. >> >> >> On 11/11/05, goodxy2002 <goodxy2002@...> wrote: >>> now i know why you play violin >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> Yahoo! Groups Links >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >> > > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of > Service. > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! Acesso Grátis: Internet rápida e grátis. > Instale o discador agora! > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >

399. Re: 2x2x2 4x4x4 5x5x5
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 17:41:02 -0000

Hi:D The Eastsheens make the best 2x2x2, but they are not legal in seventowns-sponsored competitions like WC's. For 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 there are different opinions. But these days most of the fast cubers use rubiks.com cubes. Some however don't have the patience to break them in and will prefer Eastsheen here also. Some rubiks.com 5x5x5 are really stiff out of the box while others are "reasonable" or "fairly nice". Rubiks.com cubes u can buy directly from www.rubiks.com or from shops in many countries. For eastsheen cubes u can get them from www.puzzle- shop.de or from www.mefferts.com. I never saw these in shops, but i live in Norway so it may be different elsewhere :-) Cheers! -Per PS! Good news is that new versions os rubiks.com 5x5x5 might have an improved design for smoother "out-of-the-box" cubing :-) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "bballkid2076" <bballkid2076@y...> wrote: > > What brand makes the best 2x2x2 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 cubes and where can I > buy them > > > thanks >

402. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC2005: "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler"
From: Rune Wesström <rune.wesstrom@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 20:10:09 +0100

What´s the difference between "3x-blind" and "3x-speed-blindfolded"? ----- Original Message ----- From: "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Thursday, November 10, 2005 11:52 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] WC2005: "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler" > All -- > > Out of curiousity, I decided to use a "points system" to determine > the "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler" at WC2005. I've been thinking about > this as an extra category at competitions. > > **** Quick Explanation: > > "points system" = 10pts for first, 9 for second, etc, through top 10 > or end of competitors or DNF/DNS. If final was only 8 people, I gave > points to #9/#10 from previous round. > > "Top Cuber" = list people by most points based on cubing events listed > on main stage (2x, 3x, 4x, 5x, 3x-blind, 3x-onehand, 3x-feet, 3x- > fewestmoves, 4x-blind, 5x-blind) > > "Top Puzzler" = list people by ost points based on all events > (includes "side" events aka Magic, Clock, Megaminx, Square1, Master > Magic, 3x-speed-blindfolded, Magic-onehand). > > **** Results > > Top Cuber > --------- > Leyan Lo = 34 pts > Chris Hardwick = 27 pts > Yuki Hayashi = 22 pts > Shotaro Makisumi = 21 pts > Masayuki Akimoto = 20 pts > > Leyan and Chris both placed top 10 in five events - very impressive! > > > Top Puzzler > ----------- > Stefan Pochmann = 61 pts > Alexander Ooms = 36 pts > Leyan Lo = 34 pts > Chris Hardwick = 31 pts > Lars Vandenbergh = 30 pts > > Stefan placed in every "side" event except 3x-speedblindfold, winning > three and placing second, third and sixth in the others - he is Puzzle- > Man. > > > I'll put the Excel spreadsheet on the site later and add the link. > Enjoy the info, > > yeff > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > >
403. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC2005: "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler"
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 19:43:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Rune Wesström <rune. wesstrom@h...> wrote: > > What´s the difference between "3x-blind" and "3x-speed-blindfolded"? In "speed-blindfolded" the time for analysis/memorization doesn't count, only the twisting part does. So Geir usually takes around 3 hours to plan/memorize a solution using a normal speedsolving method (e.g. Fridrich) and then executes it blindfolded in about 30-40 seconds (from what I've seen in competitions so far). Cheers! Stefan

So it's more suitable for small children ;-) 2005/11/11, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...>: > Hi:D > > The Eastsheens make the best 2x2x2, but they are not legal in > seventowns-sponsored competitions like WC's. 406. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC2005: "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler"
From: "christopher_pelley" <christopher_pelley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 19:54:52 -0000

In 3x-blind, you total your combined study-time and solve-time. In 3x- speed-blind, the cube was studied for a few hours and only the solve was timed. Geir Ugelstad was the only one to participate in this unique event, and he got 31.36 on his first attempt. He also did an encore performance immediately afterward (same scramble) and got 28.xx seconds I believe. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Rune Wesström <rune.wesstrom@h...> wrote: > > What´s the difference between "3x-blind" and "3x-speed-blindfolded"?
407. [Speed cubing group] clock teamsolve
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 20:56:31 +0100

Hello,

At the WC, I've seen a bunch of new ideas for team solving.

And I came up with the idea of "teamsolving" the clock.

Here is a video of me and Alexander Ooms setting a time of 17.13 seconds.
However, our best time was 15.11 (and a very very lucky thanks to Dan
Harris 9.25 seconds)

I thought you would like to see that. :-)

http://gillesvdp.phpnet.org/RubiksWC05/Clock-Teamsolve-Alexander-Gilles.part1.rar
http://gillesvdp.phpnet.org/RubiksWC05/Clock-Teamsolve-Alexander-Gilles.part2.rar

I can't upload files larger than 5 MB so I had to split it up with
winrar. Also the video is in the .mov format.
If anyone wants to change the format, feel free to do so. ;-)

Gilles.


408. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC2005: "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler"
From: "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 20:10:33 -0000

I had wondered what method Geir was using to do this. So he probably memorizes the sub-sequences ("this, then seqA7, then H-perm, etc") and then performs them blindfolded. I took a look at Tyson's 1:58 blindfold from NorCal 2005 - he memorized for 49 seconds, then twisted for 69 seconds. I wonder how the "Fewest Moves" people would do in speed-blindfold - could they figure out the final 40-or-so move sequence, memorize it, then perform it in 30 or less seconds? Any FMC people want to give their thoughts? yeff --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "christopher_pelley" <christopher_pelley@y...> wrote: > > In 3x-blind, you total your combined study-time and solve-time. In 3x- > speed-blind, the cube was studied for a few hours and only the solve > was timed. Geir Ugelstad was the only one to participate in this > unique event, and he got 31.36 on his first attempt. From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 21:15:32 -0000

Just saw the news "USA was the best performing country at Rubik's
World Championship 2005" at SCC and saw that it only includes single
time normal 3x3, nothing else. So I counted Olympics-style but dang,
USA is still on top... well, what do you expect with 102 out of 145
competitors?

USA 4 5 6
Germany 4 1 1
Japan 2 1 1
Netherlands 1 2 4
Belgium 1 2 0
France 1 1 1
Norway 1 1 0
Sweden 1 0 0
South Korea 0 1 0
Spain 0 0 1

Cheers!
Stefan

413. Re: Bah...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 21:49:21 -0000

Ok ok... here's a statistic that works: average of best times of all
competitors in first 3x3 round. Not even counting the four USA DNFers
we get this result (country, competitors, average)

....... France ... 3 .. 15.92
........ Spain ... 1 .. 16.90
United Kingdom ... 1 .. 17.63
...... Belgium ... 2 .. 18.75
.. South Korea ... 1 .. 19.24
........ China ... 1 .. 20.40
....... Taiwan ... 1 .. 20.41
........ Japan ... 5 .. 20.56
...... Germany ... 4 .. 23.15
.. Netherlands ... 7 .. 25.06
....... Canada ... 6 .. 25.63
........ Aruba ... 1 .. 25.75
.... Australia ... 1 .. 27.96
....... Israel ... 1 .. 29.68
....... Norway ... 2 .. 30.16
....... Sweden ... 6 .. 32.95
.......... USA .. 98 .. 38.10

Ha!
Stefan

416. Re: ROUX METHOD
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 22:35:17 -0000

I averaged about 27 or so back just before I switched to CFOP again. Then, I didn't know any corner algs, so Step 3 was two substeps for me. I averaged a tad over 22 just now for an average of 30, and I haven't practiced the method in months, literally. That made my day. My best times with this method are just over 17. At present, I use COLL cases for the Step 3 corners, and I know all but the Bruno cases. Using the CLL cases instead, you can save a few moves/seconds here and there. An easy example is the U orientation, when all four corners are permuted incorrectly. I haven't learned any of the optimizations for placing edges or or anything fancy for Step 4, which I do using the second method described, if memory serves. I took an average for this step just now and got a bit under 6 seconds. If you work at it and learn the third method and some or all of the special cases, I don't see why you couldn't get faster than that. As for flipping UF and UB, I would orient them just like normal, unless the F2L happened to be finished, or only those two pieces incorrectly flipped, and perhaps an M slice edge shuffle left. In those cases, I would orient them with MUMUMU2M'UM'UM'U2 or the appropriate ELL alg, if I saw it. Anything else would be easier accomplished as M'UMU'M'UM' as normal. Hope this helps. -Mike --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > I have decided to switch to the ROUX method, but i am slow. > I used to do it every once in a while, if I could see a good start. > Doing a 2x3x1 block every scramble 12 times is harder. > > I would like to hear from anybody who uses, or has experimentented > with this method. WHat are your averages, how many CLL cases do you > know? What do you use to flip the two edges in UF and UB? > > I took my first Roux avg tonight. Avg = 33.85 Best time was 26.88. > > Keep in mind, I haven't learned a single CLL alg. So Step 3 (Corners) > takes me about 6 sec. > The Last 6 Edges take me about 8-10 seconds right now, but I can cut > that down to 5-6 with a little practice. Step 4 (Edges) is comparable > to OLL/PLL. > > Any advice or help > would be greatly appreciated > > Jason Kovacic > Kovacic81@y... >

420. Hey all! Need Some Help with Fridrich F2L...
From: "alexhassoap" <alexhassoap@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 03:20:07 -0000

Hi all, it's cool to see a cubing community on Yahoo, and a lot of
amazing cubers as well.
I've been cubing since the end of July, and starting 2 weeks ago, I'm
currently trying to learn the Fridrich method, with the 7
Sune/antisune COLL algs thrown in to replace the 57 OLL algs. I
currently average approx. 80 seconds with the method. However, I'm
running into problems.
I want to be able to average under a minute within a few weeks (I
know, hard!). But:
1. My F2L is 45-50 seconds on average, in my opinion way too long.
2. I just don't "get" how to look ahead in a solve! (Possible
explanation for #1) I will literally pause for up to 3 seconds between
each pair I complete.
I don't plan on learning all 41 F2L algs for a while, and for now I
know 10 of them. They are the ones from my old method (the vanilla
layer-by-layer method), a couple random and more easy ones, and all
the algs where the corner and edge are in the right slot, but not
oriented correctly. This way, I can just connect the corner and edge,
put it in the right slot, then do the respective algorithm.
My opinion is, I should learn the 12 algs in F2L that have the
corner-edge pair connected in the U-layer so that I don't have to
waste moves placing them in the right spot and solving, thus shaving
time. But then again, I can't tell whether that would be worth it if I
want to be able to solve under a minute by December (I average 80
seconds right now).
Furthermore, with my old method, where I did the first layer, then did
the 2nd layer, I can perform better. My question is, should I learn
those 12 corner-edge F2L algs, or should I stick with what I've got
and concentrate on those, or should I just go back to my old F2L method?

Finally, how can I practice looking ahead in any solve?

426. Re: [Speed cubing group] Hey all! Need Some Help with Fridrich F2L...
From: Marco Garbelini <garbelini@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 09:54:04 +0200

> 2. I just don't "get" how to look ahead in a solve! (Possible
> explanation for #1) I will literally pause for up to 3 seconds between
> each pair I complete.

Only practice will make you look ahead. Actually don't even think
about it, when you least expect you will be already doing it. This is
what happends in most cases I think. When your algs are fully on auto
your mind will naturally look for something to be ocupied with.

> I don't plan on learning all 41 F2L algs for a while, and for now I
> know 10 of them. They are the ones from my old method (the vanilla
> layer-by-layer method), a couple random and more easy ones, and all
> the algs where the corner and edge are in the right slot, but not
> oriented correctly. This way, I can just connect the corner and edge,
> put it in the right slot, then do the respective algorithm.
> My opinion is, I should learn the 12 algs in F2L that have the
> corner-edge pair connected in the U-layer so that I don't have to
> waste moves placing them in the right spot and solving, thus shaving
> time. But then again, I can't tell whether that would be worth it if I
> want to be able to solve under a minute by December (I average 80
> seconds right now).
> Furthermore, with my old method, where I did the first layer, then did
> the 2nd layer, I can perform better. My question is, should I learn
> those 12 corner-edge F2L algs, or should I stick with what I've got
> and concentrate on those, or should I just go back to my old F2L method?
>
> Finally, how can I practice looking ahead in any solve?


427. 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 08:05:55 -0000

Hi friends,

I had a nice talk with Frédérick Badie during WC 2005 about
improvements on 4x4x4.

One of the subjects was avoiding the orientation parity, as already
investigated by Chris Hardwick.
I really think there must be an easier way to check this parity,
than to count the cycles. Counting cycles takes quite a lot of time,
because you have to follow all pieces around the cube.

I am pretty convinced there must be an easier way. Something like
this:
Take the orientation of all edges according to blindfolded cubing.
For each edge pair, count whether the single cubies are oriented
according to that standard. The total number of flipped edge cubies
must have the factor 4.

I took some randomly scrambled cubes and it was correct, but I am
sure that in fact this hypothesis is not correct.
Factor 2 does not work (1 flipped edge pair has that...)

Anyway, please find a counter example of the factor 4.

Or better, please find an easy way to check the 4x4x4 orientation
parity. Maybe you can do this with diagonal cubies or whatever?

Or proof that the only way is to follow the cycles.

Thanks and have fun,

Ron








428. Old Book
From: "dontsimon" <dontsimon@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 08:51:51 -0000

Hi I recently picked up a Rubik's cubeafter over 20 years of not even
seeing one. At that time I was able to do it in about 60 seconds using
a method learned from a book.

A silly question this as I know it was a beginners method (and there
must be better methods), but I'd like to know what the book was.
Unfortunately all I can remember is that it had a picture of the
youngster who had written it in it or on it - maybe on the back, or
inside cover. He was a mousey haird, slightly geeky looking kid :) Not
much to go on, but if this rings any bells with anyone, do chirp up
and let me know.

The memory is a bad thing. I can't even get past the top layer :)

430. Re: Good Times
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 09:13:28 -0000

Lars, I feel very sorry for you because you sat in the most gutting position of all, 13th place. Perhaps it should have been 16 go through to the finals, especially since the finals were over in about 5 minutes. But perhaps not, since I was sitting in 17th place ;) Even though there were 12 places up for grabs, you can't fit 20 very decent cubers into it, so it really was a lottery as to who got which places at the end of the semis. As we all saw, it was decided by fractions of a second. So Ron, Lars, Joel, Michel, Stefan, and Taka, don't feel bad about not making the finals because you put up a stunning performance and showed yourself to be among the worlds speedcubing elite. And that's definitely something to be proud of. See you all next time :) Dan :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > Lars, thanks for letting me know. I'll contact the hotel. 433. Re: Old Book
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 10:57:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "dontsimon" <dontsimon@y...> wrote: > > Hi I recently picked up a Rubik's cubeafter over 20 years of not even > seeing one. At that time I was able to do it in about 60 seconds using > a method learned from a book. > > A silly question this as I know it was a beginners method (and there > must be better methods), but I'd like to know what the book was. > Unfortunately all I can remember is that it had a picture of the > youngster who had written it in it or on it - maybe on the back, or > inside cover. He was a mousey haird, slightly geeky looking kid :) Not > much to go on, but if this rings any bells with anyone, do chirp up > and let me know. > > The memory is a bad thing. 434. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC2005: "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler"
From: Rune Wesström <rune.wesstrom@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 13:25:22 +0100

Thank you. The "speed-blindfolded" is apparently regarded as more "puzzle oriented". Btw., are there any vids from the 3x-blind that could show the effective solving times? R ----- Original Message ----- From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Friday, November 11, 2005 8:43 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] WC2005: "Top Cuber" and "Top Puzzler" --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@...m, Rune Wesström <rune. wesstrom@h...> wrote: > > What´s the difference between "3x-blind" and "3x-speed-blindfolded"? In "speed-blindfolded" the time for analysis/memorization doesn't count, only the twisting part does. So Geir usually takes around 3 hours to plan/memorize a solution using a normal speedsolving method (e.g. Fridrich) and then executes it blindfolded in about 30-40 seconds (from what I've seen in competitions so far). Cheers! Stefan Yahoo! Groups Links

436. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 16:05:52 -0000

Hey Ron, I can't prove it, but I am almost 100% convinced that counting the full cycles is the only way. I also tried something like looking at each piece in terms of BLD cubing orientation. That reason this doesn't work is that you can switch two pieces that are oriented the same way using the parity alg + center rotater (so quite literally only those two pieces switch) and they both appear to be oriented. For every orientation case you invesitate, switching exactly two edges and still having it look the same way in terms of orientation is possible. So this method cannot identify parity in all cases. I think counting cycles, with a year or two of practice, could be done in the 15 second inspection maybe as much as 75% of the time. The problem is you would not have a good plan for starting your solve. The solve itself would start very nearly like a no-inspection solve. Plus, 25% of the time you would be very near completing the cycles counting right as the judge says "put your cube down". This can't be good for a concentration zone or solving rhythm. My next goal, and Ron I've already mentioned this to you, is to use a "one parity method". After using ZBLL for a while I came to realize that 5/6 of the COLL cases can be viewed as having switched only two corners (which is odd parity if you consider the F2L solved and the LL face turned correctly). So what I want to do is to memorize for each COLL case exactly which two corners are swapped (I already know this for the COLL cases I know for ZBLL, I just need to learn it for the rest). So 5/6 of the time I will have "odd parity", maybe not really but from my viewpoint of considering the corners I will. Then I look at the edge permtutation in relation to the two "solved" corners and see if it is also odd. I like this because 5/6 of the time I check for odd permutation of edges. The 1/6 is even becase that is the only case where the corners are fully solved (permutation) in relation to eachother. So I just memorize the 1/6 cases that are even and in those cases check for even edge permutation. I can do it now already but it is very slow. However, I believe it will speed up the method a small amount when fully practiced and here is why: Let's consider just the scenario where you have OLL parity, the no OLL parity situation is exactly the same for the "one parity" method or whatever you want to call it. Regular solving: (1/2)*(15) + (1/2)*(15 + 8) = 19 So it takes 19 moves on average to solve the OLL parity case with the regular method. This includes 1/2 the time just the OLL parity and 1/2 the time also the PLL parity using Stefan Pochmann's 8 move fixer. One-parity solving: (1/2)*(15) + (1/2)*(15) = 15 so you save 4 moves on average. Here is my idea on how it affects the time too: Regular solving: (1/2)*(5.25+2.75) + (1/2)*(5.25) = 6.63 seconds to solve parities on average One-parity solving: (1/2)*(5.25) + (1/2)*(4.75) = 5.00 seconds So you have up to 1.63 seconds to identify double parity without it affecting your average at all. If you spend 1.63 seconds every OLL parity solve just staring at your cube and not doing any turns, as long as you can always correctly guess double parity or not, then you will break even with one parity over executing 2 parity algs 1/4 your solves. This time difference only gets better the faster you can execute the double parity alg. So it won't save much time, but it saves time. And at top level solving for any puzzle any amount of time saved is good. Also, on the rare easy cases where you can identify double parity in .5 seconds you will save up to 3 seconds off that solve. That's a full second in a competition mean that comes off your times. So it's a lot of work, for very little gain. But it's gain nonetheless so I think it will be worth it to learn. Plus it's something that ZBLL would teach you anyway, so I might as well learn it now and be comfortable knowing the structure of my ZBLL algs even more, having already memorized the corner structure of each one. In short I want to learn it, but I realize that it is a lot of work for very little gain. I feel the cycles counting method is worse though in terms of lots of work for a disproportional amount of gain. But then again it would be a gain, so maybe it is worth it, who knows? Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Hi friends, > > I had a nice talk with Frédérick Badie during WC 2005 about > improvements on 4x4x4. > > One of the subjects was avoiding the orientation parity, as already > investigated by Chris Hardwick. > I really think there must be an easier way to check this parity, > than to count the cycles. Counting cycles takes quite a lot of time, > because you have to follow all pieces around the cube. > > I am pretty convinced there must be an easier way. Something like > this: > Take the orientation of all edges according to blindfolded cubing. > For each edge pair, count whether the single cubies are oriented > according to that standard. The total number of flipped edge cubies > must have the factor 4. > > I took some randomly scrambled cubes and it was correct, but I am > sure that in fact this hypothesis is not correct. > Factor 2 does not work (1 flipped edge pair has that...) > > Anyway, please find a counter example of the factor 4. > > Or better, please find an easy way to check the 4x4x4 orientation > parity. Maybe you can do this with diagonal cubies or whatever? > > Or proof that the only way is to follow the cycles. > > Thanks and have fun, > > Ron >

438. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>

You know, I think Yuki does the OLL even with a parity, and then he recognises whether the permutation parity is present too, and does both or just the one in the one step. 440. New speedcube and a new record!!!
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 18:40:02 -0000

My cube that I use for speedcubing has been terrible for a long time,
so for 1-2 weeks ago I started to use two new cubes for speedcubing
and they are already great. I used one of them while taking an average
today and it resulted in a new average record: 17.52!! :-)

This new cube isn't as loose as my old speedcube so I can go faster
during OLL and PLL, without risking a POP. I'm going to re-lube the
cube soon and with some more practice I think I'll get sub-17 quite
soon.

/Gunnar





441. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 18:40:26 -0000

Hi Ron, There's a point in the solve where I can tell edge parity. So that you might picture it, generally it follows my 3x3x3 solving method. Solve: 1 two opposing centers (for reference call them left and right centers) 2 pair up four specific edge pairs (comprising the middle level) 3 place two middle level edge pairs 4 place four FL corners (on the bottom) 5 place the other two middle level edge pairs 6 pair up two specific edge pairs (DL and DR) Although some of what remains may be solved, this usually leaves me with the following still scrambled: 1 Four centers in a line Down, Front, Up and Back 2 Six edge pairs DF UF UB DB UL and UR 3 Last Level corners At this point you can learn to see if you have and edge parity problem, and if you do turn r or l one quarter turn, then solve the rest with an even number of half turns. Have lots of fun, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Hi friends, > > I had a nice talk with Frédérick Badie during WC 2005 about > improvements on 4x4x4. > > One of the subjects was avoiding the orientation parity, as already > investigated by Chris Hardwick. > I really think there must be an easier way to check this parity, > than to count the cycles. Counting cycles takes quite a lot of time, > because you have to follow all pieces around the cube. > > I am pretty convinced there must be an easier way. Something like > this: > Take the orientation of all edges according to blindfolded cubing. > For each edge pair, count whether the single cubies are oriented > according to that standard. The total number of flipped edge cubies > must have the factor 4. > > I took some randomly scrambled cubes and it was correct, but I am > sure that in fact this hypothesis is not correct. > Factor 2 does not work (1 flipped edge pair has that...) > > Anyway, please find a counter example of the factor 4. > > Or better, please find an easy way to check the 4x4x4 orientation > parity. Maybe you can do this with diagonal cubies or whatever? > > Or proof that the only way is to follow the cycles. > > Thanks and have fun, > > Ron >

445. Re: Hey all! Need Some Help with Fridrich F2L...
From: aznseashell <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 19:03:37 -0000

I don't know if it's really necessary to memorize F2L algorithms. Once you know how to position a corner and its corresponding edge in order to place them in the first two layers, you can figure out how to reduce almost any other case to this position. Just play around with it for a while, and you'll end up knowing it without actually memorizing algorithms. The only F2L algorithms I actually memorized are the ones for cases that aren't quite so intuitive. As for looking ahead, just keep practicing. Eventually you'll start doing your F2L moves without really thinking about them, and you can use that time to start looking for the next F2L pair. I've dropped my cubing average from over a minute to low 30s without really learning any new algorithms. Shelley --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "alexhassoap" <alexhassoap@y...> wrote: > > Hi all, it's cool to see a cubing community on Yahoo, and a lot of > amazing cubers as well. > I've been cubing since the end of July, and starting 2 weeks ago, I'm > currently trying to learn the Fridrich method, with the 7 > Sune/antisune COLL algs thrown in to replace the 57 OLL algs. I > currently average approx. 80 seconds with the method. However, I'm > running into problems. > I want to be able to average under a minute within a few weeks (I > know, hard!). But: > 1. My F2L is 45-50 seconds on average, in my opinion way too long. > 2. I just don't "get" how to look ahead in a solve! (Possible > explanation for #1) I will literally pause for up to 3 seconds between > each pair I complete. > I don't plan on learning all 41 F2L algs for a while, and for now I > know 10 of them. They are the ones from my old method (the vanilla > layer-by-layer method), a couple random and more easy ones, and all > the algs where the corner and edge are in the right slot, but not > oriented correctly. This way, I can just connect the corner and edge, > put it in the right slot, then do the respective algorithm. > My opinion is, I should learn the 12 algs in F2L that have the > corner-edge pair connected in the U-layer so that I don't have to > waste moves placing them in the right spot and solving, thus shaving > time. But then again, I can't tell whether that would be worth it if I > want to be able to solve under a minute by December (I average 80 > seconds right now). > Furthermore, with my old method, where I did the first layer, then did > the 2nd layer, I can perform better. My question is, should I learn > those 12 corner-edge F2L algs, or should I stick with what I've got > and concentrate on those, or should I just go back to my old F2L method? > > Finally, how can I practice looking ahead in any solve? >

I'm pretty sure the ginat cubes are solvabe.(well > of course they're not solvable but you know what i mean) I was able to > duplicate the state of one of them (and no it wasn't the solved one) > with my old school 80s cube after a little while. > > --Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jello33" <chris@c...> > wrote: > > > > I'm not sure about all the cubes at the hotel, but the one directly > > behind the stage, had an edge piece with 2 blue sides. 448. God entering a contest
From: "uweren2000" <rune.wesstrom@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 21:24:17 -0000

Just a quotation from SCIENTIFIC AMERICAN, March 1981:
"If God were to enter a cube-solving contest, he might encounter some
rather stiff competition from a few prodigious mortals, even if they do
not know his algorithm. I am told there is a young Englishman from
Nottingham named Nicholas Hammond who has got his average down to close
to 30 seconds! Such a phenomenal performance calls for several
skills...".
Maybe God had better stay on that side of the Channel?
R





449. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: Frédérick BADIE <f_badie@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 21:26:53 -0000

> I can't prove it, but I am almost 100% convinced that counting the
> full cycles is the only way.

Hi, I think it is not necessary counting the full cycles with the 24
cubies, but we can calculate a combination between the cycle for the
12 pairs and the orientation for each 12 pairs separatly.

Here's the method:

Definition :
Current Pair : Any combinations of two edges cubies.
FirstEdge and SecondEdge are two edges cubies whith the two same
colors.
MyCounter values 0.

I take one pair.
It's my Current Pair.
I add 1 to MyCounter.

The left part of my Current Pair is my First Edge.
The pair where my Second Edge is becomes the Current Pair.

If the Second Edge is good oriented (according blindfold), I add 1
to my counter, else I add nothing.

The left part of my Current Pair is my First Edge.
The pair where my Second Edge is becomes the current pair.

If the Second Edge is good oriented (according blindfold), I add 1
to my counter, else I add nothing.

I do this until my Second Edge is on the first pair I choose at the
beginning.

The first pair must be twice the current pair.

When I finish one cycle, I choose for current pair one pair i have
not seen yet.ETC.....

Until the 12 pairs have been seen.

One example:

On a boy color sheme up/yellow face/blue.
I do an "f" and a b2 move and I flip the UL and UR edges( as we do
when we have 2 edges flipped in a blindfold resolution) . The
parity/signature will be odd.

I take the UR pair. the left part is yellow/orange.
I add one to my counter , it values 1.

The other yellow/orange is on the UL pair and good oriented . I add
1 to my counter = 2.
The other UL edge is White/red.

The other white/red is on the DL pair and not good oriented . I add
nothing and my counter = 2.
The other DL edge is Yellow/red.

The other yellow/red is on the DR pair and not good oriented . I add
nothing and my counter = 2.
The other DR edge is Yellow/orange.

The other yellow/orange is on the UR pair and good oriented . I add
1 and my counter = 3.

My counter = 3 , so the parity is odd.

Do this with all cycles if they are more cycle.
Don't forget the pair already "good paired" and add 1 if it is not
good oriented.

Let's suppose the cube solved with only the UL pair flipped.

I take this pair UL and add 1.
The left part is yellow/red. the other yellow/red is on UL pair and
not good oriented. I add nothing. The cycle is finish. the parity is
odd.

Have fun,
Frédérick.


























450. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 22:40:29 -0000

Hey! Like commented before, will this really save any time for a complete solve? Even if one determines the parity from the give scramble one must keep track of it from the outset if one wants to utilise the information. This means while doing the centers and also while pairing up the edges. Those clever tricks to track/eliminate the parity will slow down the solve, i guess more than simply solving normally and deal with it at the 3x3x3 stage. Well, that is my firm belief anyway. Those who want to prove me wrong, please do so :-) I know Chris Hardwick, Ron and yo Frederick at least are interested in it. My idea to deal w parity is to change my own cage method so that i would solve complete first layer then opposite layer. Then middle layers edges (with trivial inner layer quarter-turn parity fix) and no equivalent to the permutation parity of the pairing-up method. Then finally do the rest of the centers. One could also use empty "dedge"s on those first 2 layers while solving the middle layers edges. Im sure it can be fast, but a bit unusual :-) As for doing the last 4 centers im sure it can be fast. Once u reach the state where all unsolved centers are on opposite faces u need maximum 2 algs and u are done :-) And those algs are short. For the 5x5x5 cube im not really that convinced that this new approach will be more efficient than my current approach (or the pairing-up). Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Frédérick BADIE <f_badie@y...> wrote: > > > I can't prove it, but I am almost 100% convinced that counting the > > full cycles is the only way. > > Hi, I think it is not necessary counting the full cycles with the 24 > cubies, but we can calculate a combination between the cycle for the > 12 pairs and the orientation for each 12 pairs separatly. > > Here's the method: > > Definition : > Current Pair : Any combinations of two edges cubies. > FirstEdge and SecondEdge are two edges cubies whith the two same > colors. > MyCounter values 0. > > I take one pair. > It's my Current Pair. > I add 1 to MyCounter. > > The left part of my Current Pair is my First Edge. > The pair where my Second Edge is becomes the Current Pair. > > If the Second Edge is good oriented (according blindfold), I add 1 > to my counter, else I add nothing. > > The left part of my Current Pair is my First Edge. > The pair where my Second Edge is becomes the current pair. > > If the Second Edge is good oriented (according blindfold), I add 1 > to my counter, else I add nothing. > > I do this until my Second Edge is on the first pair I choose at the > beginning. > > The first pair must be twice the current pair. > > When I finish one cycle, I choose for current pair one pair i have > not seen yet.ETC..... > > Until the 12 pairs have been seen. > > One example: > > On a boy color sheme up/yellow face/blue. > I do an "f" and a b2 move and I flip the UL and UR edges( as we do > when we have 2 edges flipped in a blindfold resolution) . The > parity/signature will be odd. > > I take the UR pair. the left part is yellow/orange. > I add one to my counter , it values 1. > > The other yellow/orange is on the UL pair and good oriented . I add > 1 to my counter = 2. > The other UL edge is White/red. > > The other white/red is on the DL pair and not good oriented . I add > nothing and my counter = 2. > The other DL edge is Yellow/red. > > The other yellow/red is on the DR pair and not good oriented . I add > nothing and my counter = 2. > The other DR edge is Yellow/orange. > > The other yellow/orange is on the UR pair and good oriented . I add > 1 and my counter = 3. > > My counter = 3 , so the parity is odd. > > Do this with all cycles if they are more cycle. > Don't forget the pair already "good paired" and add 1 if it is not > good oriented. > > Let's suppose the cube solved with only the UL pair flipped. > > I take this pair UL and add 1. > The left part is yellow/red. the other yellow/red is on UL pair and > not good oriented. I add nothing. The cycle is finish. the parity is > odd. > > Have fun, > Frédérick. >

When I first heard the description, I was thinking it might be "Jeff Conquers the Cube (in 45 seconds)" which was my favorite "speed" solving book 25 years ago (for obvious reasons) and where I learned my main method. You'll find it on page 6 of the twistypuzzles link. yeff --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "dontsimon" > <dontsimon@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi I recently picked up a Rubik's cubeafter over 20 years of not even > > seeing one. At that time I was able to do it in about 60 seconds using > > a method learned from a book. > > > > A silly question this as I know it was a beginners method (and there > > must be better methods), but I'd like to know what the book was. > > Unfortunately all I can remember is that it had a picture of the > > youngster who had written it in it or on it - maybe on the back, or > > inside cover.
