452. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 23:14:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > My idea to deal w parity is to change my own cage method so that i > would solve complete first layer then opposite layer. Then middle > layers edges (with trivial inner layer quarter-turn parity fix) and > no equivalent to the permutation parity of the pairing-up method. > Then finally do the rest of the centers. One could also use > empty "dedge"s on those first 2 layers while solving the middle > layers edges. Im sure it can be fast, but a bit unusual :-) As for > doing the last 4 centers im sure it can be fast. Once u reach the > state where all unsolved centers are on opposite faces u need > maximum 2 algs and u are done :-) And those algs are short. For the > 5x5x5 cube im not really that convinced that this new approach will > be more efficient than my current approach (or the pairing-up). > > Cheers! > > -Per Hey now. It's not weird to do it that way. The only difference between my method and the one you described is that I leave out 1 edge group from each face, essentially turning my sovle into a Roux solve. The parity fix is easy to spot and takes 13 moves to fix. lU2l'U2lU2l'U2rU2rU2r' (U2). It shuffles also 3 blocks of centers in the M slice, as well as swapping the UB and DB edge pairs. I played around a lot with counting edges and things and eventually realized that discounting extremely special cases, it's quicker to just move on and finish the edge pairing, and use the parity fixer if it comes up. This saves time on solves without parity, and loses only a trivial amount of time on the solves with parity. -Mike Bennett
453. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 23:33:38 -0000

Umm ... Are u pairing up the middle layer "dedge"s or what. No need for such a lenghty parity-fixer otherwise. U fix the parity simply with l/l'/r/r'. Either will do. Doing one middle layer's edges first makes it really trivial to see the parity (parity-fix = bringing the remaining 4 edges into an even cycle configuration). Instead of doing an inner slice turn l/l'/r/r' it's possible to simply do : U2 (p' U2)*5 where p is l/l'/r/r'. This will preserve the centers and makes even a centers first approach possible when doing middle laters edges last. Have fun! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > My idea to deal w parity is to change my own cage method so that i > > would solve complete first layer then opposite layer. Then middle > > layers edges (with trivial inner layer quarter-turn parity fix) and > > no equivalent to the permutation parity of the pairing-up method. > > Then finally do the rest of the centers. One could also use > > empty "dedge"s on those first 2 layers while solving the middle > > layers edges. Im sure it can be fast, but a bit unusual :-) As for > > doing the last 4 centers im sure it can be fast. Once u reach the > > state where all unsolved centers are on opposite faces u need > > maximum 2 algs and u are done :-) And those algs are short. For the > > 5x5x5 cube im not really that convinced that this new approach will > > be more efficient than my current approach (or the pairing-up). > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > Hey now. It's not weird to do it that way. The only difference > between my method and the one you described is that I leave out 1 edge > group from each face, essentially turning my sovle into a Roux solve. > > The parity fix is easy to spot and takes 13 moves to fix. > lU2l'U2lU2l'U2rU2rU2r' (U2). It shuffles also 3 blocks of centers in > the M slice, as well as swapping the UB and DB edge pairs. > > I played around a lot with counting edges and things and eventually > realized that discounting extremely special cases, it's quicker to > just move on and finish the edge pairing, and use the parity fixer if > it comes up. This saves time on solves without parity, and loses only > a trivial amount of time on the solves with parity. > > -Mike Bennett >
454. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 23:55:36 -0000

Hey Frédérick, I actually tried something very similar to this over my Christmas break in 2004. I was able to get to around 25 seconds as a personal fastest time, but I averaged around 40-50 seconds to do this. Having one or more transpositions (cycles between two edge groups only) slows me down terribly. I personally was not able to get this method under 15 seconds to identify parity. If you find a way to speed it up I would love to hear how to do it. I gave up on this idea though, but of course maybe you have found some really nice modification to it as well. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Frédérick BADIE <f_badie@y...> wrote: > > > I can't prove it, but I am almost 100% convinced that counting the > > full cycles is the only way. > > Hi, I think it is not necessary counting the full cycles with the 24 > cubies, but we can calculate a combination between the cycle for the > 12 pairs and the orientation for each 12 pairs separatly. > > Here's the method: > > Definition : > Current Pair : Any combinations of two edges cubies. > FirstEdge and SecondEdge are two edges cubies whith the two same > colors. > MyCounter values 0. > > I take one pair. > It's my Current Pair. > I add 1 to MyCounter. > > The left part of my Current Pair is my First Edge. > The pair where my Second Edge is becomes the Current Pair. > > If the Second Edge is good oriented (according blindfold), I add 1 > to my counter, else I add nothing. > > The left part of my Current Pair is my First Edge. > The pair where my Second Edge is becomes the current pair. > > If the Second Edge is good oriented (according blindfold), I add 1 > to my counter, else I add nothing. > > I do this until my Second Edge is on the first pair I choose at the > beginning. > > The first pair must be twice the current pair. > > When I finish one cycle, I choose for current pair one pair i have > not seen yet.ETC..... > > Until the 12 pairs have been seen. > > One example: > > On a boy color sheme up/yellow face/blue. > I do an "f" and a b2 move and I flip the UL and UR edges( as we do > when we have 2 edges flipped in a blindfold resolution) . The > parity/signature will be odd. > > I take the UR pair. the left part is yellow/orange. > I add one to my counter , it values 1. > > The other yellow/orange is on the UL pair and good oriented . I add > 1 to my counter = 2. > The other UL edge is White/red. > > The other white/red is on the DL pair and not good oriented . I add > nothing and my counter = 2. > The other DL edge is Yellow/red. > > The other yellow/red is on the DR pair and not good oriented . I add > nothing and my counter = 2. > The other DR edge is Yellow/orange. > > The other yellow/orange is on the UR pair and good oriented . I add > 1 and my counter = 3. > > My counter = 3 , so the parity is odd. > > Do this with all cycles if they are more cycle. > Don't forget the pair already "good paired" and add 1 if it is not > good oriented. > > Let's suppose the cube solved with only the UL pair flipped. > > I take this pair UL and add 1. > The left part is yellow/red. the other yellow/red is on UL pair and > not good oriented. 455. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 00:06:51 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Umm ... > > Are u pairing up the middle layer "dedge"s or what. No need for such > a lenghty parity-fixer otherwise. U fix the parity simply with > l/l'/r/r'. Either will do. Doing one middle layer's edges first > makes it really trivial to see the parity (parity-fix = bringing the > remaining 4 edges into an even cycle configuration). Instead of > doing an inner slice turn l/l'/r/r' it's possible to simply do : U2 > (p' U2)*5 where p is l/l'/r/r'. This will preserve the centers and > makes even a centers first approach possible when doing middle > laters edges last. > > Have fun! > > -Per The advantage of doing it this way is that you can pair up the first 3 edge groups of the 6 left with just r/l turns and U. And finish the rest by pairing the UBl with the DFl edge and UBr with DFr just by doing rU2r'. The whole edge pairing scenario is very simple, intuitive, and best of all, fast. -Mike Bennett
456. Sub-30 ONE-HANDED!!!!!!!
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 00:23:09 -0000

I'm so excited right now!! I just did my first sub-30 solve one-
handed, and it was not lucky. The time was 29.30!!

I started off with a nice xcross in approx. 5 seconds and after that
every was just perfect. I got one of the 20 cases I now one-handed och
then my easiest PLL.

/Gunnar

459. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 03:08:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > One of the subjects was avoiding the orientation parity, as already > investigated by Chris Hardwick. > I really think there must be an easier way to check this parity, > than to count the cycles. Counting cycles takes quite a lot of time, > because you have to follow all pieces around the cube. I don't think there's an easy way out and like Per I don't think it would be worth it anyway unless maybe you can really see it in 5-10 seconds. Some in my opinion more realistic time-savers dealing with the parities in a centers>edges>3x3 method: - Do CLL->ELL, solving both parities as part of ELL. It's an easy 2-look LL. - Recognize and fix orientation parity before solving the last F2L pair. Chris should already be able to recognize it since he's doing ZBF2L and it's not hard to learn anyway. Now we just need a fast alg that exploits the unsolved slot. Should be shorter/faster than what we have so far. - While pairing up dedges, don't flip built dedges anymore (optimally don't change them at all) and count flipped dedges. Then you could fix the parity before starting the 3x3 step. An even shorter/faster alg should exist. Cheers! Stefan
460. Cold Pizza Pictures, My WC05 results
From: "rubiks1938" <rubiks1938@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 03:55:46 -0000

Hey everyone,

I posted my pictures from my appearance with Chris Szlatenyi and Cory Loviglio. Go to my
webpage here:

http://andyscubepage.tk

and click on "appearance" under the most recent news item.

I also added a table to the WC05 page, after the story and before the pictures. It includes
all the times I achieved during the competition and the overall average, best, and worst
solve. Go to the competition pictures page to see all of my results.

Andy

462. Re: Old Book
From: "dontsimon" <dontsimon@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 08:53:50 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@y...> wrote: > > When I first heard the description, I was thinking it might be "Jeff Conquers the Cube (in > 45 seconds)" which was my favorite "speed" solving book 25 years ago (for obvious > reasons) and where I learned my main method. > > You'll find it on page 6 of the twistypuzzles link. > > yeff > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "dontsimon" > > <dontsimon@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi I recently picked up a Rubik's cubeafter over 20 years of not even > > > seeing one. At that time I was able to do it in about 60 seconds using > > > a method learned from a book. > > > > > > A silly question this as I know it was a beginners method (and there > > > must be better methods), but I'd like to know what the book was. > > > Unfortunately all I can remember is that it had a picture of the > > > youngster who had written it in it or on it - maybe on the back, or > > > inside cover. He was a mousey haird, slightly geeky looking kid :) Not > > > much to go on, but if this rings any bells with anyone, do chirp up > > > and let me know. > > > > > > The memory is a bad thing. I can't even get past the top layer :) > > > > > > > That book might be found here: > > > > http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/pdb-search.cgi?act=sec&key=book > > > > or here > > > > http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/collection/Books%20and%20Collectibles/index.htm > > > > Regards, > > > > David J > > > I had two books at the time, and they both must have been out in England before the summer of 1981 because we moved house then and I'd already had them by then. One of them must have been 'You Can Do The Cube' because that kid's face is so familiar, although I don't recoginise the cover - maybe an earlier edition had a different cover?? The other one may have been 'Mastering Rubik's Cube' by Don Taylor, because the cover looks familiar. Or it also may have been 'SIMPLE SOLUTION TO RUBIK'S CUBE' by JAMES NOURSE - also looking familiar. What I do remember is having an argument in the playground with this other kid who could do the cube (we were the only two in the whole school) He said I was cheating because I didn't turn the cube upside down to finish the bottom layer??? Maybe this gives a clue about the different methods we were using. For about a month we stood in the yard doing cube after cube after cube for all the kids who had them (everyone in 80/81 whenever it was). My record was 59 seconds - which hilariously enough was just counted out loud by my brother without any kind of watch or timing device. Very scientific :)
463. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 10:07:27 +0100

Hi friends, Could Chris/Per/Stefan please explain why they think there cannot be a method other than counting cycles? I would love to see a proof! Or better, I would love to see a proof of a better method. :-) Yesterday I found a counter example of my factor 4 hypothesis: just swap the edge cubies UrF and URb. You have 0 flipped edge pieces, but you do have parity. When I started this solve the total number of flipped edge pieces was 14 (=parity, which was the indeed the case), so somewhere in the solve it changed to a factor of 4. CLL=>ELL is indeed an interesting approach. :-) Orientation parity during F2L was an idea I already had, and I asked Jaap to find an algorithm for it, using his program. At the moment he is still on tour in Florida. :-) Stefan, I don't understand what you mean with your idea about dedges. Doing both parities in one is interesting. At the moment I use two algorithms (the normal one by Chris, and the double parity one by Frédérick), but both twist corners because I use multislice moves. It would be great to have a fast algorithm that does not twist corners... It would be great to have a fast algorithm for the orientation parity anyhow. Yuki can do the parity algorithm amazingly fast. I need to train for that. :-) Is it true that once you solved 3 centers, you cannot change parity anymore when you keep these centers intact? Because then the center positions are fixed? In that case you only have to count the parity during the first three centers. Which is not a big task. Thanks and have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: Stefan Pochmann To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Sunday, November 13, 2005 4:08 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > One of the subjects was avoiding the orientation parity, as already > investigated by Chris Hardwick. > I really think there must be an easier way to check this parity, > than to count the cycles. Counting cycles takes quite a lot of time, > because you have to follow all pieces around the cube. I don't think there's an easy way out and like Per I don't think it would be worth it anyway unless maybe you can really see it in 5-10 seconds. Some in my opinion more realistic time-savers dealing with the parities in a centers>edges>3x3 method: - Do CLL->ELL, solving both parities as part of ELL. It's an easy 2-look LL. - Recognize and fix orientation parity before solving the last F2L pair. Chris should already be able to recognize it since he's doing ZBF2L and it's not hard to learn anyway. Now we just need a fast alg that exploits the unsolved slot. Should be shorter/faster than what we have so far. - While pairing up dedges, don't flip built dedges anymore (optimally don't change them at all) and count flipped dedges. Then you could fix the parity before starting the 3x3 step. An even shorter/faster alg should exist. Cheers! Stefan ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

465. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 10:42:15 -0000

Hi! Im not saying there isn't a way to see parity other than counting cycles. All i was saying is that im quite sure it wouldn't be worth the effort. In general im also sceptical about most kinds of tricks/anticipation to avoid "hard cases" later on. For that reason im also sceptical whether the ZB-method in one form or another can really be faster than pure Fridrich/CFOP. I don't think anyone has proven yet, timewise, the advantages of a more complex method than pure CFOP. Of course there are the occasional really fast solves with it, but i haven't seen averages with pure ZB/VH or similar that compare with the fastest pure CFOP averages. This could of course be simply because only a few people are really into zb, and also that so far they only master a part of it :-) I'm only happy to be proven wrong :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Hi friends, > > Could Chris/Per/Stefan please explain why they think there cannot be a method other than counting cycles? > I would love to see a proof! Or better, I would love to see a proof of a better method. :-) > > Yesterday I found a counter example of my factor 4 hypothesis: just swap the edge cubies UrF and URb. You have 0 flipped edge pieces, but you do have parity. > When I started this solve the total number of flipped edge pieces was 14 (=parity, which was the indeed the case), so somewhere in the solve it changed to a factor of 4. > > CLL=>ELL is indeed an interesting approach. :-) > > Orientation parity during F2L was an idea I already had, and I asked Jaap to find an algorithm for it, using his program. At the moment he is still on tour in Florida. :-) > > Stefan, I don't understand what you mean with your idea about dedges. > > Doing both parities in one is interesting. At the moment I use two algorithms (the normal one by Chris, and the double parity one by Frédérick), but both twist corners because I use multislice moves. It would be great to have a fast algorithm that does not twist corners... It would be great to have a fast algorithm for the orientation parity anyhow. Yuki can do the parity algorithm amazingly fast. I need to train for that. :-) > > Is it true that once you solved 3 centers, you cannot change parity anymore when you keep these centers intact? Because then the center positions are fixed? > In that case you only have to count the parity during the first three centers. Which is not a big task. > > Thanks and have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Stefan Pochmann > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Sunday, November 13, 2005 4:08 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > > > One of the subjects was avoiding the orientation parity, as already > > investigated by Chris Hardwick. > > I really think there must be an easier way to check this parity, > > than to count the cycles. Counting cycles takes quite a lot of time, > > because you have to follow all pieces around the cube. > > I don't think there's an easy way out and like Per I don't think it > would be worth it anyway unless maybe you can really see it in 5- 10 > seconds. > > Some in my opinion more realistic time-savers dealing with the > parities in a centers>edges>3x3 method: > > - Do CLL->ELL, solving both parities as part of ELL. It's an easy > 2-look LL. > > - Recognize and fix orientation parity before solving the last F2L > pair. 467. zb f2l
From: Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 07:19:31 -0600

Hey,
I had a question i was hoping someone could help me with. I was learning
about zbf2l and i thought it was really cool. would it be too ambitious to
just learn zbf2l, and then go into zbll ignoring OLL altogether? i know its
like 530+ algorithms, but i want to learn it in 2 years, so one alg a day,
and ill be set. i might do more than one a day in summer and winter break,
etc.
Oh also, i have another question. if there was a method where you finish
last f2l pair permute AND orient edges, and then have a set of COLL algs
that dont screw up edges, would that take more or lesss algs than zb and
2-look etc. I have a feeling it might take many more. i dunno tho.
And btw, makers of the ZB method, awesome. its a genius method.
your input would be very appreciated.
-parth


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



468. Re: [Speed cubing group] zb
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 15:59:46 +0100

Well, if you want to solve the edges while solving the last pair for the F2L, you'd have a lot more cases than the "basic" ZB-F2L. But, in the other hand, you'd have considerably less alg for finishing the LL because you'd only have to solve the corners, which is only the COLL. That would require a more mathematical approach, but your idea might not be meaningless ;-) 2005/11/13, Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@...>: > Hey, > I had a question i was hoping someone could help me with. I was learning > about zbf2l and i thought it was really cool. would it be too ambitious to > just learn zbf2l, and then go into zbll ignoring OLL altogether? i know its > like 530+ algorithms, but i want to learn it in 2 years, so one alg a day, > and ill be set. i might do more than one a day in summer and winter break, > etc. > Oh also, i have another question. if there was a method where you finish > last f2l pair permute AND orient edges, and then have a set of COLL algs > that dont screw up edges, would that take more or lesss algs than zb and > 2-look etc. I have a feeling it might take many more. i dunno tho. > And btw, makers of the ZB method, awesome. its a genius method. > your input would be very appreciated. > -parth > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
469. Re: [Speed cubing group] zb
From: Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 09:47:33 -0600

Ya, i agree. it would take more algs than zbf2l, but then last layer would
be like 400 less than zbll. im just wondering if the number of algs used in
solving last f2l pair and orienting/permuting corners is not too big.
Is there some way to figure out how many algs it would take to solve last
f2l pair and permute/orient corners, as well as the COLL cases?
because like if it would take 700 algorithms to do last f2l pair and edges,
its not worth it.
but like if it took say 200-300 or so algs, it might work.
neone's input would be appreciated very very much.
-parth

470. Re: [Speed cubing group] zb
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 15:56:22 -0000

Regular ZBF2L already requires 305 algorithms. If you take into account edge permutation, the number becomes much much much much greater. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@g...> wrote: > > Ya, i agree. it would take more algs than zbf2l, but then last layer would > be like 400 less than zbll. im just wondering if the number of algs used in > solving last f2l pair and orienting/permuting corners is not too big. > Is there some way to figure out how many algs it would take to solve last > f2l pair and permute/orient corners, as well as the COLL cases? > because like if it would take 700 algorithms to do last f2l pair and edges, > its not worth it. > but like if it took say 200-300 or so algs, it might work. > neone's input would be appreciated very very much. > -parth > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] >
471. [Speed cubing group] Re: something
From: "Chris Sz..." <s2chris2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 16:16:14 -0000

Re the color scheme change - it wasn't hard, just time consuming - it takes lots of prying, shaving, and gluing. I don't think footcubes need much preparation. In fact, I think a really loose lubed cube would be a disadvantage. The most important thing I'd say would be even tension on all sides. and if there's a better way to perform moves I'd like to know about it :) --Chris P.S. Megaminx w/ feet: 31:47.02 --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Simply amazing... > I have some questions (if you don't mind...): > - How do you prepare your cube for feet-cubing? > - There's a better way to perform the moves? > > Pedro > > darereck <darereck@g...> escreveu: > Hey Chris > > Amazing video. 472. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 17:29:00 -0000

Hey Ron, You don't need to count the 24 cycles, I had forgotten about the 12 cycle counting method that Frederick mentioned. That can absolutely detect parity every time. I personally still found it very difficult, it is a puzzle all by itself. Using it would be like solving two puzzles at once on stage. You have 15 seconds to frantically (and yes to get to even 25 seconds I had to frantically twist my cube around) discover parity, which I believe couldn't be done 100% of the time (who can solve the 3x3x3 in under 15 seconds 100% of the time?). But on the times you do discover it, with training, I think tracking the parity during the solve would not slow you down much at all. Any double turn does not change parity, and I had learned how specific sequences I use affected parity so I didn't have to count every move. I personally think that noticing parity early, say whether or not the zbf2l case is parity or not would work. You don't have to know ZBF2L, but you could learn to recognize it, and all the patterns are the same so it wouldn't take much work. Also, something I found interesting while doing some 4x4 math before the tournament. Sometimes the regular parity alg is very fast for me, but sometimes the double is fast for me. So I would like to use both but still want 50-50 odds of double parity and not more. Well call the frequency that you use the regular parity x (0<=x<=1) and call the frequency that you use the double parity alg (1-x) the number of moves on average that it takes you to correct parities this way is (1/2)*(15x+23(1-x)) + (1/2)*(23x+15(1-x)) (1/2)*[-8x+23 + 8x +15] 19 So no matter the frequency you switch between the algs, you average 19 moves to solve parities. That is the same as always using the same alg. This works since they are the same number of moves in length. Also about the centers, when I was practicing solves when I knew the parity, I would forget about the parity after the 4th center (but I solve the 3rd and 4th simultaneously always). They way I put them together I would correct parity if I needed to just before putting those 2 centers together. THe 5th and 6th solve using only conjugates which don't change parity. If you do solve 3 centers, and correct parity to even while doing so, then you can only solve in conjugates to finish the last 3, but yes parity wouldn't change after that. I personaly am very skeptical of the usefulness of coutning cycles, even with the 12 cycle method, since for me it was so terribly difficult to try to even get sub-30 seconds. I think noticing during the solve might work better personalyl, but I am open to learning newer or better ways to detect during inspection. Also what about doing what I saw someone mention in an earlier post, why not do the OLL when you have OLL parity such that you end with one flipped edge only. At this point it would be very easy to discover if you also had PLL parity. I'm sure if we had faster algs to flip just that one edge to either solve OLL or OLL and PLL parity then this method would save time. I average about 6 seconds to do OLL parity with inner slices and maybe 6-7 right now with OLL + PLL aprity alg using just inner slices. If we can make this fast, then why not try that route also? We would need better algs for inner slice only though in my opinion. Can we get somthing with lots of r and l' moves? You could perform those like Bob and I do M' for the H permutation? Just some thoughts, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Hi friends, > > Could Chris/Per/Stefan please explain why they think there cannot be a method other than counting cycles? > I would love to see a proof! Or better, I would love to see a proof of a better method. :-) > > Yesterday I found a counter example of my factor 4 hypothesis: just swap the edge cubies UrF and URb. You have 0 flipped edge pieces, but you do have parity. > When I started this solve the total number of flipped edge pieces was 14 (=parity, which was the indeed the case), so somewhere in the solve it changed to a factor of 4. > > CLL=>ELL is indeed an interesting approach. :-) > > Orientation parity during F2L was an idea I already had, and I asked Jaap to find an algorithm for it, using his program. At the moment he is still on tour in Florida. :-) > > Stefan, I don't understand what you mean with your idea about dedges. > > Doing both parities in one is interesting. At the moment I use two algorithms (the normal one by Chris, and the double parity one by Frédérick), but both twist corners because I use multislice moves. It would be great to have a fast algorithm that does not twist corners... It would be great to have a fast algorithm for the orientation parity anyhow. Yuki can do the parity algorithm amazingly fast. I need to train for that. :-) > > Is it true that once you solved 3 centers, you cannot change parity anymore when you keep these centers intact? Because then the center positions are fixed? > In that case you only have to count the parity during the first three centers. Which is not a big task. > > Thanks and have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Stefan Pochmann > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Sunday, November 13, 2005 4:08 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > > > One of the subjects was avoiding the orientation parity, as already > > investigated by Chris Hardwick. > > I really think there must be an easier way to check this parity, > > than to count the cycles. Counting cycles takes quite a lot of time, > > because you have to follow all pieces around the cube. > > I don't think there's an easy way out and like Per I don't think it > would be worth it anyway unless maybe you can really see it in 5-10 > seconds. > > Some in my opinion more realistic time-savers dealing with the > parities in a centers>edges>3x3 method: > > - Do CLL->ELL, solving both parities as part of ELL. It's an easy > 2-look LL. > > - Recognize and fix orientation parity before solving the last F2L > pair. Chris should already be able to recognize it since he's doing > ZBF2L and it's not hard to learn anyway. Now we just need a fast alg > that exploits the unsolved slot. Should be shorter/faster than what we > have so far. > > - While pairing up dedges, don't flip built dedges anymore (optimally > don't change them at all) and count flipped dedges. Then you could fix > the parity before starting the 3x3 step. An even shorter/faster alg > should exist. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] >
473. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 17:44:19 -0000

Hey Ron, One last thing, I didn't address your one question. I think some sort of cycle-ish strategy will be required, since you can switch two edge pieces literally without affecting anything else, not even centers. That seems like it would be very hard to detect in any type of orientation method for finding parity. Two edges can be switched that were both oriented that would still appear to be oriented. Just the sheer complexity of it seems to have to require at least the 12 cycle counting method. Again I have no idea how to prove that, but it seems like some sort of cycling has to be done. Just my hunch though :-( Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Hi friends, > > Could Chris/Per/Stefan please explain why they think there cannot be a method other than counting cycles? > I would love to see a proof! Or better, I would love to see a proof of a better method. :-) > > Yesterday I found a counter example of my factor 4 hypothesis: just swap the edge cubies UrF and URb. You have 0 flipped edge pieces, but you do have parity. > When I started this solve the total number of flipped edge pieces was 14 (=parity, which was the indeed the case), so somewhere in the solve it changed to a factor of 4. > > CLL=>ELL is indeed an interesting approach. :-) > > Orientation parity during F2L was an idea I already had, and I asked Jaap to find an algorithm for it, using his program. At the moment he is still on tour in Florida. :-) > > Stefan, I don't understand what you mean with your idea about dedges. > > Doing both parities in one is interesting. At the moment I use two algorithms (the normal one by Chris, and the double parity one by Frédérick), but both twist corners because I use multislice moves. It would be great to have a fast algorithm that does not twist corners... It would be great to have a fast algorithm for the orientation parity anyhow. Yuki can do the parity algorithm amazingly fast. I need to train for that. :-) > > Is it true that once you solved 3 centers, you cannot change parity anymore when you keep these centers intact? Because then the center positions are fixed? > In that case you only have to count the parity during the first three centers. Which is not a big task. > > Thanks and have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Stefan Pochmann > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Sunday, November 13, 2005 4:08 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > > > One of the subjects was avoiding the orientation parity, as already > > investigated by Chris Hardwick. > > I really think there must be an easier way to check this parity, > > than to count the cycles. Counting cycles takes quite a lot of time, > > because you have to follow all pieces around the cube. > > I don't think there's an easy way out and like Per I don't think it > would be worth it anyway unless maybe you can really see it in 5-10 > seconds. > > Some in my opinion more realistic time-savers dealing with the > parities in a centers>edges>3x3 method: > > - Do CLL->ELL, solving both parities as part of ELL. It's an easy > 2-look LL. > > - Recognize and fix orientation parity before solving the last F2L > pair. Chris should already be able to recognize it since he's doing > ZBF2L and it's not hard to learn anyway. Now we just need a fast alg > that exploits the unsolved slot. Should be shorter/faster than what we > have so far. > > - While pairing up dedges, don't flip built dedges anymore (optimally > don't change them at all) and count flipped dedges. Then you could fix > the parity before starting the 3x3 step. An even shorter/faster alg > should exist. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] >
474. feetsolvingrubikscube
From: "mahtianssi" <mahtianssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 18:13:39 -0000

I again improved feet-solving records:
BT: 1:01.96
BA: 1:18.77
1:09.97 1:29.58 1:18.71 1:24.47 1:24.64 1:08.33 1:18.93 (1:56.50)
1:17.66 1:16.85 1:18.59 (1:01.96)
I tried to upload 1:10.09 vid, but I had some problems. Sometime in the
future...
Tips:
Don't do U-turns. I usually use FRB in F2L.
Don't use too loose or greasy cube. POPs are about impossible to fix.
Practice. I got from about 5 min BT to 1:43.97 avg. in under two weeks.

480. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 20:12:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Stefan, I don't understand what you mean with your idea > about dedges. I meant that while you pair up the dedges, you count how many are oriented wrong, just like you'd count how many are wrong for 3x3 blindsolving. Somehow you'd need to take care that the dedges you've built and counted don't get flipped while building the remaining dedges. How about doing OLL + OrientationParity in one go? Chris already shows some setup moves for the parity fixer on his webpage. With a few more algs and more setup moves doing OLL including parity fix in one go seems not too bad to me. Oh, and try this alg (Frederick's alg with setup move) for just flipping one edge and swapping two corners: R' (Rr)2 B2 (Rr)' U2 (Rr)' U2 B2 (Rr)' B2 (Rr) B2 (Rr)' B2 (Rr)2 B2 U2 R Cheers! Stefan
481. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 21:27:05 +0100

Hi Stefan, I will try your idea about dedges. Yeah, I use that algorithm! Do you happen to know a similar algorithm (without inner slice moves) for the other orientation parity algorithm that preserves the corner twists and doesn't solve the permutation parity? We need a good 4x4 solver! Even with ACube4 I cannot find the algorithms. :-( ACube4 works well for other stuff. Have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: Stefan Pochmann To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Sunday, November 13, 2005 9:12 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Stefan, I don't understand what you mean with your idea > about dedges. I meant that while you pair up the dedges, you count how many are oriented wrong, just like you'd count how many are wrong for 3x3 blindsolving. Somehow you'd need to take care that the dedges you've built and counted don't get flipped while building the remaining dedges. How about doing OLL + OrientationParity in one go? Chris already shows some setup moves for the parity fixer on his webpage. With a few more algs and more setup moves doing OLL including parity fix in one go seems not too bad to me. Oh, and try this alg (Frederick's alg with setup move) for just flipping one edge and swapping two corners: R' (Rr)2 B2 (Rr)' U2 (Rr)' U2 B2 (Rr)' B2 (Rr) B2 (Rr)' B2 (Rr)2 B2 U2 R Cheers! Stefan ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. b.. 482. Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 20:42:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > How about doing OLL + OrientationParity in one go? Chris already shows > some setup moves for the parity fixer on his webpage. For example, look at the third case Chris describes here: http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/4speedsolve32.html Now try this on a scrambled cube: B' R' (Chris's orientation parity fixer) R B Saves four moves compared to Chris's suggestion :-) Btw I'd execute it a bit differently (I like pulling U2 with left index+middle fingers): x' U' R' (Rr)2 U2 x U2 (Ll) U2 (Rr)' U2 (Rr) U2 x U2 (Rr) U2 (Ll)' D2 (Ll)2 R U x Cheers! Stefan

fatser with this puzzle.

485. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 21:02:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > > We need a good 4x4 solver! Even with ACube4 I cannot find the algorithms. :-( > ACube4 works well for other stuff. Hi Ron, ACube4? Where do I get that? How about this alg in three steps: 1. (Rrl') R' F (Llr') y 2. Chris's orientation fixer 3. y' (Llr')' F' R (Rrl')' I know, I know... quite long... only my first idea that worked. Cheers! Stefan
486. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 parity without counting cycles
From: "olivsub20" <olivier_gaucher@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 21:12:46 -0000

I haven't read all the messages about the subject but I will give you my thought about the parity problems. I think that the easiest way to deal with them if to solve the cube until you arrive at the OLL. If the OLL exist, just do it and then if the PLL exist do it, or if it doesn't exist do the parity problem( for PLL) and do the PLL. On the case where the OLL doesnt exist you orient all exept one edge. Then you look if the PLL exist or not. If it does, do the parity problem (for OLL) and finish by the PLL. If the PLL doesn't exist do the arity problem (which fix both parity problem) and end with the PLL. I think this is not too difficult after some practice and you always do one algs for parity or zero. The only think wghich is not very good if that you have to do the parity algs with the inner slices which is a little slower. What do yiou think of that? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" > <ron@s...> wrote: > > > > We need a good 4x4 solver! Even with ACube4 I cannot find the > algorithms. :-( > > ACube4 works well for other stuff. > > Hi Ron, > > ACube4? Where do I get that? > > How about this alg in three steps: > > 1. (Rrl') R' F (Llr') y > 2. Chris's orientation fixer > 3. y' (Llr')' F' R (Rrl')' > > I know, I know... quite long... only my first idea that worked. > > Cheers! > Stefan >

492. Re: zb
From: "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2005 23:27:33 -0000

Yes, I know those are the figures listed on Zbigniew's site and I think they are wrong. Since the total of the first column adds up to 300, the figures he lists should include the solved cases, so the figure for the LL should be 494. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > > http://www.zborowski.republika.pl/expert3x3x3method.html > > "number of formulas > with reverse ones and > symmetrical ones" > > "306 (minus 1 solved)" for F2L > "493 (minus 1 solved)" for LL > > -E > > > > On 11/13/05, Jason Baum <speedrunningcuber@y...> wrote: > > I don't know about ZBF2L, but I'm pretty sure ZBLL is 493 not > > including the solved case. > > > > -Jason > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Lars > > Vandenbergh" > > > > <lars.vandenbergh@t...> wrote: > > > > > > I'm pretty certain it's 493 cases for ZBLL not including the solved > > case, so my guess is 798 > > > cases :p > > > > > > Anyone else? > > > > > > Lars > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob > > Burton" > > <bob@c...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Correction: that INCLUDES the solved state for F2L and for LL. 501. What Cube to Buy?
From: "alexhassoap" <alexhassoap@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 04:42:00 -0000

I just bought two cubes at Target, they were actually $7 since there
was a sale (orig. $10), but these cubes are really bad!
They're the 25th anniversary type, with the shiny white stickers. I'm
really frustrated, as I've actually slid playing cards into all the
slots and kept them there for a couple hours, and now I'm putting
cards to try stretching the springs too. If doing this, then lubing
the cube (for a 2nd time) doesn't work out (so far, it's better, but
not much), then I'm just gonna return the other one.
Do cubes of the same brand and type vary in quality, or are all of the
25th anniversary ones poor like this? I ask because the first cube I
bought was $14, and it was also a 25th anniversary edition, but the
white face was not shiny, it was pure white. I gotta say, it was also
about 100 times better for speedcubing, all I had to do was apply
silicone spray, and it was a bona fide speedcube.
I actually found a site online where they sell that exact same type
(the good one). Should I buy that kind exclusively? Or is there any
other type that's even better for speedcubing? It's just frustrating
to deal with this cube that's so poor for speedcubing.






502. Re: What Cube to Buy?
From: smgfreak_dk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 04:47:08 -0000

all those cubes vary in quality.. some are looser, some are tighter, some have more even spring tension some don't. but cubes usually take time to break in and get looser.. to get into the speedcubing condition.. say several weeks of intensive cubing.. if not a few months.. Darren Kwong --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "alexhassoap" <alexhassoap@y...> wrote: > > I just bought two cubes at Target, they were actually $7 since there > was a sale (orig. $10), but these cubes are really bad! > They're the 25th anniversary type, with the shiny white stickers. If doing this, then lubing > the cube (for a 2nd time) doesn't work out (so far, it's better, but > not much), then I'm just gonna return the other one. > Do cubes of the same brand and type vary in quality, or are all of the > 25th anniversary ones poor like this? I gotta say, it was also > about 100 times better for speedcubing, all I had to do was apply > silicone spray, and it was a bona fide speedcube. > I actually found a site online where they sell that exact same type > (the good one). Should I buy that kind exclusively? Or is there any > other type that's even better for speedcubing? It's just frustrating > to deal with this cube that's so poor for speedcubing. >

I'm not sure you answered the question I was asking, and I probably wasn't clear about it. What I was trying to say was, say I take the exact brand, say, the Oddzon Rubik's cube. Then say out of 100 of that exact cube, would the quality be the same (low) quality among all 100, or would there be some great ones, some okay ones, and some bad ones among them? I want to know if within one specific type, the quality varies. Or if we know that overall, all Oddzon cubes are bad and all Studio cubes are good. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, smgfreak_dk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > all those cubes vary in quality.. some are looser, some are tighter, > some have more even spring tension some don't. but cubes usually > take time to break in and get looser.. to get into the speedcubing > condition.. say several weeks of intensive cubing.. if not a few > months.. > > Darren Kwong >
505. Re: What Cube to Buy?
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 05:45:19 -0000

You're not alone. I have had very bad luck with all the cubes commonly available on the market today. To my knowledge, there are four: 1) 25th AV with white stickers, hexagon package 2) 25th AV with white stickers, on card 3) 25th AV with silver stickers, on card 4) a few leftover Oddzon cubes with a non-anniversary sticker. Of the first three, I have bought and bought and bought. Only about 1/4 of the ones I buy are acceptable for speedcubing with minimal preparation. The other 3/4 are so tight and uneven that I give up any hope of breaking them in. So no, I do not find that any one of the three is any better on average than the others. I have a small sample size on #4 (one cube) but it was so tight I could barely turn it. You'd think silicone would save the day, but it made it even WORSE. I've heard at least two posters say that if you are willing to work with tight cubes for long enough, eventually they will get looser. As for me, I try to find a store with a liberal return policy, because I can't wait that long! > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "alexhassoap" > <alexhassoap@y...> wrote: > > > > I just bought two cubes at Target, they were actually $7 since > there > > was a sale (orig. $10), but these cubes are really bad! > > They're the 25th anniversary type, with the shiny white stickers. > I'm > > really frustrated, as I've actually slid playing cards into all the > > slots and kept them there for a couple hours, and now I'm putting > > cards to try stretching the springs too. If doing this, then lubing > > the cube (for a 2nd time) doesn't work out (so far, it's better, > but > > not much), then I'm just gonna return the other one. > > Do cubes of the same brand and type vary in quality, or are all of > the > > 25th anniversary ones poor like this? I ask because the first cube > I > > bought was $14, and it was also a 25th anniversary edition, but the > > white face was not shiny, it was pure white. I gotta say, it was > also > > about 100 times better for speedcubing, all I had to do was apply > > silicone spray, and it was a bona fide speedcube. > > I actually found a site online where they sell that exact same type > > (the good one). Should I buy that kind exclusively? Or is there any > > other type that's even better for speedcubing? It's just > frustrating > > to deal with this cube that's so poor for speedcubing. > > >
506. Re: What Cube to Buy?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 06:01:09 -0000

Any normal Rubik's brand cube you can buy at a store these days that
has relatively even tension on the sides will be a great cube if
you're willing to wear it in enough.

The only cube I've had for good speedcubing was tight and terrible out
of the package. I played with it for a few weeks before lubing it,
doing a lot of grinding solves. Then, I slipped plastic butter knives
under the faces to loosen the tension on a few sides. More grinding
solves. Then lube. Lots and lots of lube. I use silicon spray, but
your preference may vary.

Several people at Orlando commented on how loose and nice my cube was.
Best $8 I ever spent.

-Mike

P.S. Anyone need tips on making a nice loose 4x4? ;)

509. Re: What Cube to Buy?
From: smgfreak_dk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 06:39:42 -0000

Agreed =) DIY cubes are nice as well. eventually, these pre- assembled cubes will get too loose and pop too much.. but i think DIY cubes will give you more flexibility in adjusting the tightness.. =) but i'm not sure, since i haven't used one before.. i still have one waiting to be assembled =X I personally think that the tighter cubes are better when compared to the loose ones.. i had one with a blue side that was just hanging loose (when i took it apart, the blue center piece had no tension).. can't speedcube with it.. the blue side would overturn! poor manufacturing process! anyway.. i think those tighter ones are nice cuz they give that "new cube" feeling =D as long as the spring tension is even, and it's not unbearably tight.. it gives me the feeling they'll last longer haha but yeah, they should be the same.. although the studio cubes are supposed to be superb.. they're supposed to have proper tension etc. and you can adjust it.. but i can't really say cuz i've never used one before Darren Kwong --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > Any normal Rubik's brand cube you can buy at a store these days that > has relatively even tension on the sides will be a great cube if > you're willing to wear it in enough. > > The only cube I've had for good speedcubing was tight and terrible out > of the package. I played with it for a few weeks before lubing it, > doing a lot of grinding solves. Then, I slipped plastic butter knives > under the faces to loosen the tension on a few sides. More grinding > solves. Then lube. Lots and lots of lube. I use silicon spray, but > your preference may vary. > > Several people at Orlando commented on how loose and nice my cube was. > Best $8 I ever spent. > > -Mike > > P.S. Anyone need tips on making a nice loose 4x4? ;) >
510. Re: What Cube to Buy?
From: smgfreak_dk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 06:45:04 -0000

for the ones at Target (Hasbro/MB or "Oddzon") it varies.. some good some okay some bad.. but bad is usually if it's ridiculously tight or ridiculously loose.. as long as it has good, even tension on all sides.. and obviously, all those imitation cubes are crap :D and all studio cubes SHOULD be good.. for their high price they better be! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "alexhassoap" <alexhassoap@y...> wrote: > > I'm not sure you answered the question I was asking, and I probably > wasn't clear about it. What I was trying to say was, say I take the > exact brand, say, the Oddzon Rubik's cube. Then say out of 100 of that > exact cube, would the quality be the same (low) quality among all 100, > or would there be some great ones, some okay ones, and some bad ones > among them? I want to know if within one specific type, the quality > varies. Or if we know that overall, all Oddzon cubes are bad and all > Studio cubes are good. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, smgfreak_dk > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > all those cubes vary in quality.. some are looser, some are tighter, > > some have more even spring tension some don't. but cubes usually > > take time to break in and get looser.. to get into the speedcubing > > condition.. say several weeks of intensive cubing.. if not a few > > months.. > > > > Darren Kwong > > >

512. Re: What Cube to Buy?
From: smgfreak_dk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 06:56:02 -0000

Oh, and from my observations.. it seems that they keep degrading in quality! As the newer ones come out, the quality is worse and worse.. My pre-anniversary edition cube is great... it has flat centers... but you can tell-the plastic is sturdier, thicker.. more even surfaces.. the corners don't have the stupid caps that let water leak in--they're visible but sealed.. horrible.. the old ones are much better... the white anniversary ones had the problems described above.. and the silver ones.. GOSH, what the hell?! the center pieces are like.. chipped where the caps are! maybe it's just mine though. and the plastic is much thinner! you cheapos! stop degrading in quality =( --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, smgfreak_dk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > for the ones at Target (Hasbro/MB or "Oddzon") it varies.. some good > some okay some bad.. but bad is usually if it's ridiculously tight > or ridiculously loose.. as long as it has good, even tension on all > sides.. and obviously, all those imitation cubes are crap :D and all > studio cubes SHOULD be good.. for their high price they better be! > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "alexhassoap" > <alexhassoap@y...> wrote: > > > > I'm not sure you answered the question I was asking, and I probably > > wasn't clear about it. 515. WC 2005 pics - Dan's galleries
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 10:10:14 -0000

Hi everyone,

For all those people who took pictures at the WC2005 or know people
who did, I would like to make an extensive gallery on my webpages
dedicated to making the most complete and detailed picture of what
being at the event was like for everyone.

If you can mail pictures to wc2005pics_at_cubestation.co.uk I would
be very grateful, or you could add me to MSN:
university_dan_at_hotmail.com or Yahoo!: hatadey - and file transfer
them to me that way.

Once I get my website back up and running properly, I plan to make a
lot of updates, including:

Pictures from WC2005 and report.
Media from Dutch Cube Day
Media from Hungarian Championships (which I will be attending)
Media from Puzzle meeting on December 3rd (which I am hosting)
Regenerated Profiles section
Regenerated Links Section
Regenerated FMC
More ZB Stuff
More methods stuff
Videos from TV appearances and other cube vids.

So check back soon!

DanH :)

From: David Barr <david20708@...>

What is a "grinding solve"? Just solving it without lube? On 11/14/05, Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...> wrote: > The only cube I've had for good speedcubing was tight and terrible out > of the package. I played with it for a few weeks before lubing it, > doing a lot of grinding solves. Then, I slipped plastic butter knives > under the faces to loosen the tension on a few sides. More grinding > solves. Then lube. Lots and lots of lube. I use silicon spray, but > your preference may vary.

529. RUBIK'S CUBE IN NYC TIME SQUARE - MUST SEE!!!
From: "mattvandzura" <mvandzura@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 16:33:08 -0000

+ Rubik's Cube  This November we'll be fueling a blast from the past
as our Rubik's Cube event launches in TRU's Time Square Location. The
in-store event has been in store the first 2 weekends of November and
will feature real-life Rubik's Masters as well as fun Rubik's
activities for kids. So if you're in NYC, grab your leg
warmers and headbands and have a little fun!!

November 19th & 20th.
1st floor Toys'r'us Time Square.
Time: 11-7

Be there.

531. Indiana?
From: "ericdstalter" <ericdstalter@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 19:09:40 -0000

Hello,

Anyone from Indiana cubing? I feel like I am the only one in Ft.
Wayne that enjoys cubing, anyone even in Indiana?

I am not extremely fast yet. About 2 months ago when I decided to
try to actually solve fast I was lucky to solve in about 5min usually
was 10. Then I tried a few actual methods, instead of my own, and got
to a consistent 3-4min, I have combined 2 forms and now average about
1:15 and will soon be under a min on my way to 30,20sec...who knows.

I think it would be easier and more fun if I had someone to cube
with. Let me know.

Eric

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > Congratulations, you're reaching level 3! > > 1- Learn a method. > 2- Being sub-20 consistently. > 3- Speedcubing. > > Gilles. > > > PS: New pb: 14.03s. My biggest flaw is the first two 1x2x3's which take on average 18-20 seconds for me. I think for the last corner-edge pair I'm going to have to learn some F2L-style algs. Doing it intinuitivly takes too long. I'm begging for more Roux method resources! :D The sites are all flooded with fridrich. Could also do with some tips from the pro's :) I also noticed Gilles, speedcubing tend to start at a faster time for eveyone whenever you yourself get faster at it :) ~Thom
535. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-19 :-D
From: Rune Wesström <rune.wesstrom@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 21:22:44 +0100

----- Original Message ----- From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, November 14, 2005 7:28 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-19 :-D --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Rune Wesström <rune. wesstrom@h...> wrote: > > > When I look at this other nice website, it seems that others never > > had the choice: > > > > http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/puzzle_past/ > > > > Poor guy :-) > > > > At least One consolation (for me); I would beat him in blitz-chess. Well, he surely improved when he got older... Is there an easy-to-use online chess page where we could try it? Cheers! Stefan There are some, but I don´t like them; in order to encrease the speed for a reply (in blitz) you have to learn how to manipulate the knobs on the keyboard, which more reminds on cubing than on chess. Blitz should be played with heavy, wooden pieces, where halv the victory is won by looking the opponent in his eys as saying: you are a fool! Moreover, I havn´t yet got my broad band and staying on line is too expensive for a poor man. Are my excuses too transparent? R PS. But after all, I was unconquered in Disney land! Yahoo! Groups Links

environment?

540. Re: [Speed cubing group] WCA's views on super powers
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 13:38:19 -0800

Hey Chris,

Well, you're secret has already been out. Due to special relativity,
if you run really fast while solving the cube, you'll get a faster
time. Why don't you think the faster runners win the race?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

541. Re: [Speed cubing group] WCA's views on super powers
From: Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 13:46:33 -0800

Tyson, I hope you didn't have any relativity questions on your GRE...

Running really fast while solving the cube will guarantee a slow time.
The only way to use special relativity to your advantage here is to send
the timer away on a rocketship and stop it after it gets back.

Leyan

543. Re: WCA's views on super powers
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 22:00:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chris Hunt <huntca@g...> wrote: > > If I took the next few months to figure out how to slow down time or step in > a parallel universe while cubing, would that be allowed in a competition > environment? > > -Chris > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > I know someone who wrote a paper on the effect of the shape of the universe on the limits of computation, but I don't recall the details too well. In particular, certain shapes allow for an infinite computation to be done in finite time (from the point of view of the observer) so that for instance problems like the Goldbach Conjecture could be proven (even if true) by thrashing them out, one case at a time. Conceivably this could be used to solve the cube quickly. In the infinite context (which I assume is countably infinite), the energy in the signal sent back by the slave would kill the master as it arrived so he'd only know the answer instantaneously but the cube is a finite problem so maybe this would be a theoretical method to get an optimal solution back and hence solve the cube in a really short time with only partial damage to the solver! Probably not too practicable.

546. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: What Cube to Buy?
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 17:50:01 -0600

well you could put sandpaper bits... i just did that today.. we'll see what happens On 11/14/05, mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > What is a "grinding solve"? Just solving it without lube? > > ...and has anyone tried using a /mild/ abrasive, such as tooth powder -- > assuming you can still get that product? I think someone (skeneegee, > maybe) suggested beach sand (!) once. > > Mike > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > -- -cubekid
547. [Speed cubing group] Re: What Cube to Buy?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 23:52:55 -0000

> On 11/14/05, mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr > > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > > What is a "grinding solve"? Just solving it without lube? Grinding solves are when you solve the cube normally, but pressing inward very hard on all of the faces as you turn them. Basically, you want each bit of the cube that rotates against another part to wear as much as possible in its natural pattern. -Mike

552. Not sure if Anyone will care...but...
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 00:32:34 -0000

This weekend coming up I am planning on locking myself in a room for a
few hours and tackling Fridrich, and only stopping to eat and drink,
until I have figured it all out...then I'll practice like crazy...and
in two weeks time you will see me posting sub-20 times :p

And I would also like to announce that I have switched the way I do my
4LLL. Alexander taught me a PLL corner 3Cycle, and so I don't do
corner perm first...i now do CO,EO,CP,EP...i like it and it will help
once I get to 2LLL...I guess those sub-20 times won't be in 2
weeks...cuz I'll have learn OLL and PLL first, maybe I'll learn 3LLL
first...but still, my times will "hopefully" drop a bit until I learn
2LLL...but just thought I'd let everyone know, and now everyone will
know why I am not here all day saturday, although I am such a
procrastinator and have been wanting to learn fridrich since august
and before WC...but it didn't happen...I REALLY wanna learn it
tho...so I am hoping this weekend :)

I'll Shut up now...

Craig

P.S. - Stefan go on Yahoo...

P.S.S - (for BOB) JESUS!!!

557. (what's yer type) Personality types
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 01:33:23 -0000

For those of you familiar with Myers-Briggs type - what personality
types do you think would be most drawn to speedcubing? My guess is
that the prototypical cuber would be ISTP or INTP. I think it would be
harder for an F or J to learn cubing, because I'd think being able to
analyze and adapt are primo considerations. I'm also thinking S's
would be more interested in speed per se, whereas N's would be more
interested in the mathematics of the cube and the like.

In my adult life I seem to have 'gelled' as an ISTP. I was ISFP but
after working in the business world for about 5 years, I got all
hard 'n' crusty. :P

If you don't know your type, take the test at:
http://www.humanmetrics.com/cgi-win/JTypes2.asp

559. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type...
From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 01:58:01 -0000

Actually, just the other day I found out they have full-blown world championships for RPS. Check out www.worldrps.com for some stuff about strategies and whatnot. At first, I was like "RPS? That's pretty wacky!" Then I realized that we all solve rubik's cubes as fast as we can, which outsiders view as crazy as RPS. I think it would be kinda cool if cubers started getting into RPS like they do cupstacking. I think it would be > > harder for an F or J to learn cubing, because I'd think being able to > > analyze and adapt are primo considerations. I'm also thinking S's > > would be more interested in speed per se, whereas N's would be more > > interested in the mathematics of the cube and the like. > > > > In my adult life I seem to have 'gelled' as an ISTP. I was ISFP but > > after working in the business world for about 5 years, I got all > > hard 'n' crusty. :P > > > > If you don't know your type, take the test at: > > http://www.humanmetrics.com/cgi-win/JTypes2.asp > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=irjrM9wdJDBnytECiSfUCw> Free > puzzle inlay games<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=5IEF0wvHk31uvuXI6ReWEw> Educational > game and puzzle<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=37T2K_4zOte4R94IVKMFNQ> Word > puzzle game<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Word+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=3DsIilZKH4dSS_WgIx9QRg> Kid > puzzle game<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Kid+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=2-DgzSlkRkTyIak1hdhkgQ> Puzzle > games<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=EJHY58oeC85Up2uB7KhBMA> > ------------------------------ > YAHOO! It says I am 67% introverted 88% intuitive 88% thinking 22% judging I don't know if that fits with your theory or not, but there are my stats :-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@e...> wrote: > > For those of you familiar with Myers-Briggs type - what personality > types do you think would be most drawn to speedcubing? My guess is > that the prototypical cuber would be ISTP or INTP. I think it would be > harder for an F or J to learn cubing, because I'd think being able to > analyze and adapt are primo considerations. I'm also thinking S's > would be more interested in speed per se, whereas N's would be more > interested in the mathematics of the cube and the like. > > In my adult life I seem to have 'gelled' as an ISTP. I was ISFP but > after working in the business world for about 5 years, I got all > hard 'n' crusty. :P > > If you don't know your type, take the test at: > http://www.humanmetrics.com/cgi-win/JTypes2.asp > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 565. Re: (what's yer type) Personality types
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 06:10:36 -0000

Interesting! I would not have expected J's to be as common as they appear to be at this point. Quick primer: basically the MBTI (Myers-Briggs Type Indicator) divides personality types into 4 "one or the other" scales, for a total of 16 combinations: * I (introvert) vs. E (extravert): pretty self-explanatory. * S (sensing) vs. N (intuition): Sensors are more concrete and detail- oriented; iNtuitives are more big-picture oriented. * T (thinking) vs. F (feeling): Thinkers tend to be more objective, Feelers more subjective. Basically are you more of a head person or a heart person. * J (judging) vs. P (perceiving): Has nothing to do with being judgmental or perceptive. Judgers tend to be better with structure and schedules; Perceivers tend to be better with the lack thereof. So maybe the N means you're better at seeing the whole cube as a whole, and the J is great for the structured logic of the cube and planning ahead. As an S, too often I'm thinking, "oh cool! that square is orange!" and as a P: "I think I'll do this next. No, how about this. No, that...wait, what was I doing??" INTJ's often make great scientists, so it looks like the cube is right up their alley. See if this description fits you: http://www.typelogic.com/intj.html --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > I am INTJ too... > 67% introverted > 25% intuitive (hmm...I think that's not good for cubing...) > 50% thinking > 44% judging > > is that good? > > Pedro > > cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: > My personality is INTJ off that test. I don't really know what that > means to be honest. It says I am > > 67% introverted > 88% intuitive > 88% thinking > 22% judging > > I don't know if that fits with your theory or not, but there are my > stats :-) > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" > <kwickykanny@e...> wrote: > > > > For those of you familiar with Myers-Briggs type - what personality > > types do you think would be most drawn to speedcubing? My guess is > > that the prototypical cuber would be ISTP or INTP. I think it would be > > harder for an F or J to learn cubing, because I'd think being able to > > analyze and adapt are primo considerations. I'm also thinking S's > > would be more interested in speed per se, whereas N's would be more > > interested in the mathematics of the cube and the like. > > > > In my adult life I seem to have 'gelled' as an ISTP. I was ISFP but > > after working in the business world for about 5 years, I got all > > hard 'n' crusty. :P > > > > If you don't know your type, take the test at: > > http://www.humanmetrics.com/cgi-win/JTypes2.asp

And about the world chapms i think its totally silly. It can in no way be compared to our cubing champs. After all the amout of luck involved in ours is much much less than for the RPS type. And Craig dont let out whats ur favourite, maybe someone at your schoolo maybe reading this and you'l be dethroned of your championship status in the next comp :) Sachin. 570. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: (what's yer type) Personality types
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 08:02:34 -0000

I've done Myers-Briggs many times and I'm an INFJ. As a mathemetician I agree that N's are more likely to be interested in the maths side (than S's are!) but doesn't stop us being competitive! I think J's tend to be more thoughtful and since a lot of cubing is in the preparation I don't see why there should be any particular preference for P or J. The most obvious preferenve would be a T over an F I suppose. I'me quite evenly balanced on these but always come out with a slight F preference. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Evan Gates" <evan.gates@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, November 15, 2005 7:11 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: (what's yer type) Personality types I'm INTJ as well. But I don't have the specific results, I took it a couple months ago at some other site. All i know is that I'm REALLY I, just barely N over S, REALLY T, and an alright amount J over P -E On 11/14/05, Vincent Le <vince1123581321@...> wrote: > > INTJ's often make great scientists, so it looks like the cube is > right up their alley. Looks like I'm INTP. Respectively 22, 12, 25, 22. All I can say is that it surely means I spend waaaaaay too much time doing useless stuff while I should be at work. Nah.
