Stefan
575. Re: I'm the competitive type...
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 12:20:22 -0000

I'll try to address everyone: Stefan - First competition 32 people, I think 6 rounds... Other people (sorry can't remember the name) - I don't have a favourite...I study my opponents. My first round opponent, a guy in my class who has been a rival of mine for about 5 years, I tricked into thinking I go paper every time, and then I went rock on his scissors...Destroyed him...There is some lucky, and noticing people's patterns or what they are going to throw. It is also knowing the person... Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" > <logitewty@h...> wrote: > > > > Well, > > > > You all here are competitive to some extent, and find small games > fun. > > I just thought I would announce that I am my school's Rock Paper > > Scissors Champion...thank you...and everyone says it is just luck, > but > > it SOOOOO isn't... > > > > Craig > > Two questions: > > - How many people competed? > - Was that your first attempt or did you participate in earlier > competitions? > > Cheers! > Stefan >
576. [Speed cubing group] Re: (what's yer type) Personality types
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 12:22:06 -0000

Just took that test...question 40 made me stop and think and I figured it would make or break the answers...but anyways... I am ENFP E N F P 78 62 12 33 # very expressed extrovert # distinctively expressed intuitive personality # slightly expressed feeling personality # moderately expressed perceiving personality Anyone know what that is trying to tell me??? Am I not meant to be a cuber??? Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, François Sechet <frsechet@y...> wrote: > > Looks like I'm INTP. Respectively 22, 12, 25, 22. All I can say is that > it surely means I spend waaaaaay too much time doing useless stuff while > I should be at work. Nah. > François > > Duncan Dicks a écrit : > > > I've done Myers-Briggs many times and I'm an INFJ. As a mathemetician I > > agree that N's are more likely to be interested in the maths side > > (than S's > > are!) but doesn't stop us being competitive! I think J's tend to be more > > thoughtful and since a lot of cubing is in the preparation I don't see > > why > > there should be any particular preference for P or J. The most obvious > > preferenve would be a T over an F I suppose. I'me quite evenly > > balanced on > > these but always come out with a slight F preference. > > > > Duncan > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Evan Gates" <evan.gates@g...> > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@...m> > > Sent: Tuesday, November 15, 2005 7:11 AM > > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: (what's yer type) Personality types > > > > > > I'm INTJ as well. But I don't have the specific results, I took it a > > couple > > months ago at some other site. > > All i know is that I'm REALLY I, just barely N over S, REALLY T, and an > > alright amount J over P > > -E > > > > On 11/14/05, Vincent Le <vince1123581321@g...> wrote: > > > > > > INTJ's often make great scientists, so it looks like the cube is > > > right up their alley. See if this description fits you: > > > http://www.typelogic.com/intj.html > > > > > > Hmm...I read a few of the types on the page. So far, it seems that I > > fit a > > > > > > little bit of each that I've read. I guess it's supposed to be like that > > > though, I just fit the most in INTJ. > > > > > > This is pretty interesting. I'll read about the rest of the other types > > > once > > > I have more time - I have a bio lab due tomorrow that I've been > > postponing > > > > > > all day. > > > > > > Vincent > > > > > > On 14/11/05, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Introverted 33 > > > > Intuitive 62 > > > > Feeling 12 > > > > Perceiving 56 > > > > > > > > > > > > INFP type of personality. > > > > > > > > Could anyone tell me what excatly this means? I got a slight idea that > > > > it says im 13rd introvert, quite a bit intutive, lil feelings and > > > > again quite perceving. I think maybe thats right for me. > > > > > > > > Btw i've noticed all the posts above me do contain some amount of > > > > introversy. So does that mean we all cubers are introverts to a large > > > > extent? > > > > > > > > Sachin. > > > > > > > > On 11/15/05, Pedro < pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > > > > I am INTJ too... > > > > > 67% introverted > > > > > 25% intuitive (hmm...I think that's not good for cubing...) > > > > > 50% thinking > > > > > 44% judging > > > > > > > > > > is that good? > > > > > > > > > > Pedro > > > > > > > > > > cmhardw < no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: > > > > > My personality is INTJ off that test. I don't really know what that > > > > > means to be honest. My guess is > > > > > > that the prototypical cuber would be ISTP or INTP. I think it > > would > > > be > > > > > > harder for an F or J to learn cubing, because I'd think being able > > > to > > > > > > analyze and adapt are primo considerations. I'm also thinking S's > > > > > > would be more interested in speed per se, whereas N's would be > > more > > > > > > interested in the mathematics of the cube and the like. > > > > > > > > > > > > In my adult life I seem to have 'gelled' as an ISTP. I was > > ISFP but > > > > > > after working in the business world for about 5 years, I got all > > > > > > hard 'n' crusty. :P > > > > > > > > > > > > If you don't know your type, take the test at: > > > > > > http://www.humanmetrics.com/cgi-win/JTypes2.asp > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > > > > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and > > puzzle > > > > > > > Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > YAHOO! 578. SV: [Speed cubing group] Re: (what's yer type) Personality types
From: "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 14:13:47 +0100

Looks like i'm an INTP, but quite a few of those questions was hard to answer Yes or No, but overall i guess it evens out. Your Type is INTP Introverted 78 Intuitive 38 Thinking 62 Perceiving 11 Are Craig the only Extrovert in the cube community ? ;-) Terje -----Opprinnelig melding----- Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Craig Bouchard Sendt: 15. november 2005 13:22 Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Emne: [Speed cubing group] Re: (what's yer type) Personality types Just took that test...question 40 made me stop and think and I figured it would make or break the answers...but anyways... I am ENFP E N F P 78 62 12 33 # very expressed extrovert # distinctively expressed intuitive personality # slightly expressed feeling personality # moderately expressed perceiving personality Anyone know what that is trying to tell me??? Am I not meant to be a cuber??? Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, François Sechet <frsechet@y...> wrote: > > Looks like I'm INTP. Respectively 22, 12, 25, 22. All I can say is that > it surely means I spend waaaaaay too much time doing useless stuff while > I should be at work. Nah. > François > > Duncan Dicks a écrit : > > > I've done Myers-Briggs many times and I'm an INFJ. As a mathemetician I > > agree that N's are more likely to be interested in the maths side > > (than S's > > are!) but doesn't stop us being competitive! I think J's tend to be more > > thoughtful and since a lot of cubing is in the preparation I don't see > > why > > there should be any particular preference for P or J. The most obvious > > preferenve would be a T over an F I suppose. I'me quite evenly > > balanced on > > these but always come out with a slight F preference. > > > > Duncan > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Evan Gates" <evan.gates@g...> > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > Sent: Tuesday, November 15, 2005 7:11 AM > > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: (what's yer type) Personality types > > > > > > I'm INTJ as well. But I don't have the specific results, I took it a > > couple > > months ago at some other site. > > All i know is that I'm REALLY I, just barely N over S, REALLY T, and an > > alright amount J over P > > -E > > > > On 11/14/05, Vincent Le <vince1123581321@g...> wrote: > > > > > > INTJ's often make great scientists, so it looks like the cube is > > > right up their alley. See if this description fits you: > > > http://www.typelogic.com/intj.html > > > > > > Hmm...I read a few of the types on the page. So far, it seems that I > > fit a > > > > > > little bit of each that I've read. I guess it's supposed to be like that > > > though, I just fit the most in INTJ. > > > > > > This is pretty interesting. I'll read about the rest of the other types > > > once > > > I have more time - I have a bio lab due tomorrow that I've been > > postponing > > > > > > all day. > > > > > > Vincent > > > > > > On 14/11/05, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Introverted 33 > > > > Intuitive 62 > > > > Feeling 12 > > > > Perceiving 56 > > > > > > > > > > > > INFP type of personality. > > > > > > > > Could anyone tell me what excatly this means? I got a slight idea that > > > > it says im 13rd introvert, quite a bit intutive, lil feelings and > > > > again quite perceving. I think maybe thats right for me. > > > > > > > > Btw i've noticed all the posts above me do contain some amount of > > > > introversy. So does that mean we all cubers are introverts to a large > > > > extent? > > > > > > > > Sachin. > > > > > > > > On 11/15/05, Pedro < pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > > > > I am INTJ too... > > > > > 67% introverted > > > > > 25% intuitive (hmm...I think that's not good for cubing...) > > > > > 50% thinking > > > > > 44% judging > > > > > > > > > > is that good? > > > > > > > > > > Pedro > > > > > > > > > > cmhardw < no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: > > > > > My personality is INTJ off that test. I don't really know what that > > > > > means to be honest. It says I am > > > > > > > > > > 67% introverted > > > > > 88% intuitive > > > > > 88% thinking > > > > > 22% judging > > > > > > > > > > I don't know if that fits with your theory or not, but there are my > > > > > stats :-) > > > > > > > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" > > > > > <kwickykanny@e ...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > For those of you familiar with Myers-Briggs type - what > > personality > > > > > > types do you think would be most drawn to speedcubing? My guess is > > > > > > that the prototypical cuber would be ISTP or INTP. I think it > > would > > > be > > > > > > harder for an F or J to learn cubing, because I'd think being able > > > to > > > > > > analyze and adapt are primo considerations. I'm also thinking S's > > > > > > would be more interested in speed per se, whereas N's would be > > more > > > > > > interested in the mathematics of the cube and the like. > > > > > > > > > > > > In my adult life I seem to have 'gelled' as an ISTP. I was > > ISFP but > > > > > > after working in the business world for about 5 years, I got all > > > > > > hard 'n' crusty. :P > > > > > > > > > > > > If you don't know your type, take the test at: > > > > > > http://www.humanmetrics.com/cgi-win/JTypes2.asp > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > > > > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and > > puzzle > > > > > > > Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > YAHOO! Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: > > Looks like i'm an INTP, but quite a few of those questions was hard to > answer Yes or No, but overall i guess it evens out. > > Your Type is > INTP > Introverted 78 > Intuitive 38 > Thinking 62 > Perceiving 11 > > > Are Craig the only Extrovert in the cube community ? ;-) > > Terje > > > -----Opprinnelig melding----- > Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Craig > Bouchard > Sendt: 15. november 2005 13:22 > Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Emne: [Speed cubing group] Re: (what's yer type) Personality types > > > > Just took that test...question 40 made me stop and think and I figured > it would make or break the answers...but anyways... > > I am ENFP > E N F P > 78 62 12 33 > > # very expressed extrovert > # distinctively expressed intuitive personality > # slightly expressed feeling personality > # moderately expressed perceiving personality > > Anyone know what that is trying to tell me??? Am I not meant to be a > cuber??? > > Craig > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, François Sechet > <frsechet@y...> wrote: > > > > Looks like I'm INTP. Respectively 22, 12, 25, 22. All I can say is > that > > it surely means I spend waaaaaay too much time doing useless stuff > while > > I should be at work. Nah. > > François > > > > Duncan Dicks a écrit : > > > > > I've done Myers-Briggs many times and I'm an INFJ. As a > mathemetician I > > > agree that N's are more likely to be interested in the maths side > > > (than S's > > > are!) but doesn't stop us being competitive! I think J's tend to > be more > > > thoughtful and since a lot of cubing is in the preparation I don't > see > > > why > > > there should be any particular preference for P or J. The most > obvious > > > preferenve would be a T over an F I suppose. I'me quite evenly > > > balanced on > > > these but always come out with a slight F preference. > > > > > > Duncan > > > > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > > From: "Evan Gates" <evan.gates@g...> > > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > > Sent: Tuesday, November 15, 2005 7:11 AM > > > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: (what's yer type) > Personality types > > > > > > > > > I'm INTJ as well. But I don't have the specific results, I took it a > > > > couple > > > months ago at some other site. > > > All i know is that I'm REALLY I, just barely N over S, REALLY T, > and an > > > alright amount J over P > > > -E > > > > > > On 11/14/05, Vincent Le <vince1123581321@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > INTJ's often make great scientists, so it looks like the cube is > > > > right up their alley. See if this description fits you: > > > > http://www.typelogic.com/intj.html > > > > > > > > Hmm...I read a few of the types on the page. So far, it seems > that I > > > fit a > > > > > > > > little bit of each that I've read. I guess it's supposed to be > like that > > > > though, I just fit the most in INTJ. > > > > > > > > This is pretty interesting. I'll read about the rest of the > other types > > > > once > > > > I have more time - I have a bio lab due tomorrow that I've been > > > postponing > > > > > > > > all day. > > > > > > > > Vincent > > > > > > > > On 14/11/05, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Introverted 33 > > > > > Intuitive 62 > > > > > Feeling 12 > > > > > Perceiving 56 > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > INFP type of personality. > > > > > > > > > > Could anyone tell me what excatly this means? I think maybe thats right for me. > > > > > > > > > > Btw i've noticed all the posts above me do contain some amount > of > > > > > introversy. My > guess is > > > > > > > that the prototypical cuber would be ISTP or INTP. I think > it > > > would > > > > be > > > > > > > harder for an F or J to learn cubing, because I'd think > being able > > > > to > > > > > > > analyze and adapt are primo considerations. 581. Question about commutators
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 14:24:10 -0000

Hey everybody,

I was just reading some stuff about commutators, and I found an
interesting one (not by myself, I found it in a document):

RBLF U F'L'B'R' U'

Maybe an interesting way for beginners to insert a middle layer
edge... Easy to remember :).

Anyway, the question is about how to explain why this commutator
works. In the document, there was a defenition, the support of P,
supp(P), is defined as the set of all pieces that are effected by
algorithm P. The proposition was, if the overlap of supp(P) and
supp(Q) is only 1 piece, than PQP'Q' will be a three cycle. Now I
understand why this works for P = R'D2R and Q = U. But I can't see why
this is a way to explain the
RBLF U F'L'B'R' U' three cycle :(. To me, it looks like RBLF effects
the whole cube... Can anyone please explain this to me? Maybe I got
the defenition of SUPP(P) wrong, or something :(...

Tnx,

Joel.

584. Corners First: Edges
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 16:08:20 +0100

I've been doing the 2x2x2 a bit lately and average around 6-7 seconds
using Guimond. Now I'm seriously considering switching from my 4 LL-look
Fridrich to a CF method. I'm mostly looking at a pure CF method so that
I can practice the 2x2x2 and 3x3x3 at the same time using my current
corners system. What I'm now is asking for is some suggestions regarding
solving the edges.

So far my idea has been to finish two 1x2x3 blocks after the corners.
This way I'll be left with a classical CF/Roux ending which is nice.At
the moment though I'm solving the 6 edges for the two 1x2x3's one by
one, which takes a little over 20 moves and to much time on average. Any
suggestions on how to lower the number of moves and steps here, without
reaching a ZB number of algorithms?

Any other tips/suggestions?

/Gustav




585. Re: [Speed cubing group] Question about commutators
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 20:40:35 +0530

Well to me also the cube looks scrambled after doing RBLF, but look closely and u'll see that on the top layer, all the corners are in their original positions only, only their orientation is affected...that too each one is rotated clockwise. And since the middle move is a U, we dont care what the rest part of the cube is like, since it'll get arranged anyway. So when you do a U move now, the top corners get rotated but since their relative position and orientation is the same, they will get arranged to their orig. config when u do the reverse moves F"L"B"R". The only thing remainin is the edges, those are the one which get affected as we want. Hope i could explain what i understood :) Sachin. On 11/15/05, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@yahoo.com> wrote: > Hey everybody, > > I was just reading some stuff about commutators, and I found an > interesting one (not by myself, I found it in a document): > > RBLF U F'L'B'R' U' > > Maybe an interesting way for beginners to insert a middle layer > edge... Easy to remember :). > > Anyway, the question is about how to explain why this commutator > works. In the document, there was a defenition, the support of P, > supp(P), is defined as the set of all pieces that are effected by > algorithm P. The proposition was, if the overlap of supp(P) and > supp(Q) is only 1 piece, than PQP'Q' will be a three cycle. Now I > understand why this works for P = R'D2R and Q = U. But I can't see why > this is a way to explain the > RBLF U F'L'B'R' U' three cycle :(. To me, it looks like RBLF effects > the whole cube... Can anyone please explain this to me? Maybe I got > the defenition of SUPP(P) wrong, or something :(... > > Tnx, > > Joel. > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >

My guess is > that the prototypical cuber would be ISTP or INTP. I think it would be > harder for an F or J to learn cubing, because I'd think being able to > analyze and adapt are primo considerations. I'm also thinking S's > would be more interested in speed per se, whereas N's would be more > interested in the mathematics of the cube and the like. > > In my adult life I seem to have 'gelled' as an ISTP. I was ISFP but > after working in the business world for about 5 years, I got all > hard 'n' crusty. :P > > If you don't know your type, take the test at: > http://www.humanmetrics.com/cgi-win/JTypes2.asp >

593. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type...
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 11:33:17 -0500

Well, if my opponents choices were truly random, then my strategy wouldn't matter at all. If I can detect a pattern in my opponents choices, then I can try to predict what he will show and pick something to beat him. Alternatively, I could try to fool my opponent by making choices that appear to have a pattern. And just when I think he has figured out the pattern and is about to counter successfully, I could change the pattern to beat him. Perhaps a good strategy for a tournament would be to memorize a "one time pad", or a sequence of truly random choices that no one knows about. If you used those choices in a tournament, no one could have an advantage over you. On the downside, you wouldn't have an advantage over anyone else, either. On 11/15/05, Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > Doesn't it all even out in the end to just random chance? All the > logic here and there? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
594. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type...
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 16:32:45 -0000

I thought the section about mental preferences was really interesting. The fact that rock is seen as more aggressive and paper as more passive. Unless you were really good at reading your opponent, or knew their history, I imagine it is mostly random chance, but maybe more like this: rock 40% scissors 36% paper 24% or something like that. So maybe it isn't 1/3 odds across the board, but more weighted to your preferences to the throws under pressure. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > Doesn't it all even out in the end to just random chance? All the > logic here and there? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
595. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type... RPS & computers
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 17:01:00 -0000

Not sure whether this has been posted before, but some people might be
interested in the results of two RPS programming contests, described
here:

http://www.cs.ualberta.ca/~darse/rsbpc.html

You'll see there that playing randomly is certainly not a good
strategy, if you actually want to /win/ tournaments!

You can play online against a strong program here:

http://chappie.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/roshambot

Apparently it is one of the programs from the contests. It's more fun
than you might imagine, if you're not a convert already. :D

Mike

I managed a strategy that resulted in many ties: Statistics for 36 games winning percentage*: -33.33% won : 8.33% lost: 41.67% tied: 50.00% (I went 10-8-8 on it before trying this) :) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Not sure whether this has been posted before, but some people might be > interested in the results of two RPS programming contests, described > here: > > http://www.cs.ualberta.ca/~darse/rsbpc.html > > You'll see there that playing randomly is certainly not a good > strategy, if you actually want to /win/ tournaments! > > You can play online against a strong program here: > > http://chappie.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/roshambot > > Apparently it is one of the programs from the contests. 601. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type... RPS & computers
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 18:00:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > That brings up the question, do people here have strategies for coin > flips? Sorry, what game is that? Obviously you cannot second-guess /random/ coin flips, any more than you can second-guess a random RPS player. (But remember that the random player won't win an RPS tournament.) Mike

Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Nov 15, 2005, at 10:00 AM, mike_go_uk wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> That brings up the question, do people here have strategies for coin >> flips? > > Sorry, what game is that? > > Obviously you cannot second-guess /random/ coin flips, any more than > you can second-guess a random RPS player. 605. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type... RPS & computers
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 18:11:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > But is a coin really 50-50 or does one side come up more often than the > other? Oh, I see what you mean. Really, I don't see that you can do better than to choose whichever has come up more frequently -- unless you suspect that the tosser (sorry to any speakers of British English) can control the outcome. [Btw, if you spin coins on their edges, rather than tossing them, the results can be surprisingly strongly biased in one direction.] Mike
606. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type... RPS & computers
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 10:19:30 -0800

RPS is not random at all because it is two /people/ playing against one another. In order to have competed in the RPS World Championship, you must have competed in a smaller event. This makes it so that every competitor at the world championship has past RPS data that other competitors can study. I guess people really good at RPS memorize their competitor's tendencies instead of algorithms. Playing mind games is the key so that you can get your opponent in their defensive state (which you studied before hand) and control the game! :) -Chris On 11/15/05, mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > > > But is a coin really 50-50 or does one side come up more often than > the > > other? > > Oh, I see what you mean. Really, I don't see that you can do better > than to choose whichever has come up more frequently -- unless you > suspect that the tosser (sorry to any speakers of British English) can > control the outcome. > > [Btw, if you spin coins on their edges, rather than tossing them, the > results can be surprisingly strongly biased in one direction.] > > Mike > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
607. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type... RPS & computers
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 18:20:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Really, I don't see that you can do better > than to choose whichever has come up more frequently -- unless you > suspect that the tosser (sorry to any speakers of British English) can > control the outcome. Hmmm... maybe I'm being hasty. The tosser could /inadvertently/ control the outcome: e.g., HT and TH might occur more frequently than HH and TT (or vice versa), if the coin is picked up and tossed in almost the same way every time. So maybe you'd have to look at those short-range correlations, even if the coin is "fair". Mike
608. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type... RPS & computers
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 18:31:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chris Hunt <huntca@g...> wrote: > RPS is not random at all because it is two /people/ playing against one > another. But the same is true also of the computer programs -- as the results of the competitions showed. That was the interesting thing about the programming task: to make a program able to exploit the weaknesses in an opponent's strategy, as revealed by the way it played. Mike

610. Re: Question about commutators
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 18:35:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hey everybody, > > I was just reading some stuff about commutators, and I found an > interesting one (not by myself, I found it in a document): > > RBLF U F'L'B'R' U' > > Maybe an interesting way for beginners to insert a middle layer > edge... Easy to remember :). > > Anyway, the question is about how to explain why this commutator > works. In the document, there was a defenition, the support of P, > supp(P), is defined as the set of all pieces that are effected by > algorithm P. The proposition was, if the overlap of supp(P) and > supp(Q) is only 1 piece, than PQP'Q' will be a three cycle. Now I > understand why this works for P = R'D2R and Q = U. But I can't see why > this is a way to explain the > RBLF U F'L'B'R' U' three cycle :(. To me, it looks like RBLF effects > the whole cube... Can anyone please explain this to me? Maybe I got > the defenition of SUPP(P) wrong, or something :(... > > Tnx, > > Joel. > Let x be the common piece of the support. Clearly for any piece z which is neither in supp(P) nor supp(Q), zPQP'Q'=zQP'Q'=zP'Q'=zQ'=z. There is some piece y with yP=x and some piece t with xQ=t. Clearly y is in supp(P) and t is in supp(Q). Moreover, x, y and t are all distinct (if x=y then x is not in supp(P), if x=t then x is not in supp(Q) and it y=t then this piece is also in supp(P) and supp(Q) so it has more than one piece). Note that yPQP'Q'=xQP'Q'=tP'Q'=tQ'=x (because t is not in supp(P)). For any piece w in supp(P) other than y, wP is not x (and hence is not in supp(Q)). Thus wP=wPQ and so wPQP'=w, whence wPQP'Q'=w (unless w=x). Thus PQP'Q' fixes all elements of supp(P) except y and x. (It can't fix x, otherwise x=xPQP'Q'yPQP'Q' implies y=x.) Let h=xP. Note h is in supp(P) and h isn't x (lest x is fixed by P and x is not in supp(P)) so h is not in supp(Q) - i.e. hQ=h. Thus xPQP'Q'=hQP'Q'=hP'Q'=xQ'=t. t=xQ' is in supp(Q) (t=(xQ^k)Q for some k) but t isn't x so t isn't in supp(P), i.e. tP=t. Thus tPQP'Q'=tQP'Q'=xQ'QP'Q'=xP'Q'=yQ'=y. Note tPQ=yQP=yP (as y is not in supp(Q))=x. Now let s be any element of supp(Q) other than t and x. Thus s is not in supp(P) and so sP=s. Since s is not t, we have sPQ isn't tPQ=x. Thus as sPQ is in supp(Q) but isn't x it is not in supp(P) and sPQP'=sPQ, so that sPQP'Q'=sPQQ'=sP=s and s is fixed. Thus PQP'Q' fixes all pieces other than t,x and y and further it moves y to x, x to t and t to y. So PQP'Q' is a 3-cycle.
611. Re: Corners First: Edges
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 18:56:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@s...> wrote: > > I've been doing the 2x2x2 a bit lately and average around 6-7 seconds > using Guimond. Now I'm seriously considering switching from my 4 LL-look > Fridrich to a CF method. I'm mostly looking at a pure CF method so that > I can practice the 2x2x2 and 3x3x3 at the same time using my current > corners system. What I'm now is asking for is some suggestions regarding > solving the edges. > > So far my idea has been to finish two 1x2x3 blocks after the corners. > This way I'll be left with a classical CF/Roux ending which is nice.At > the moment though I'm solving the 6 edges for the two 1x2x3's one by > one, which takes a little over 20 moves and to much time on average. Any > suggestions on how to lower the number of moves and steps here, without > reaching a ZB number of algorithms? > > Any other tips/suggestions? > > /Gustav Check out the methods on this page. http://rubikscube.info/ It's the best site I've found for corners first solutions, and it's got some great stuff. -Mike
612. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Corners First: Edges
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>

Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 20:46:26 +0100

I'll experiment with this more basic approach first though as I need to get some experience, especially on recognition. I haven't looked that much on Watermans method, but I'll probably test it a few times and see if it suits me. /Gustav Mike Bennett skrev: >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gustav Fredell ><gufr5747@s...> wrote: > > >>I've been doing the 2x2x2 a bit lately and average around 6-7 seconds >>using Guimond. I'm mostly looking at a pure CF method so that >>I can practice the 2x2x2 and 3x3x3 at the same time using my current >>corners system. What I'm now is asking for is some suggestions >> >> >regarding > > >>solving the edges. >> >>So far my idea has been to finish two 1x2x3 blocks after the corners. >>This way I'll be left with a classical CF/Roux ending which is nice.At >>the moment though I'm solving the 6 edges for the two 1x2x3's one by >>one, which takes a little over 20 moves and to much time on average. >> >> >Any > > >>suggestions on how to lower the number of moves and steps here, without >>reaching a ZB number of algorithms? >> >>Any other tips/suggestions? >> >>/Gustav >> >> > >Check out the methods on this page. http://rubikscube.info/ > >It's the best site I've found for corners first solutions, and it's >got some great stuff. > >-Mike > > > > > > > >Yahoo! 617. Re: Question about cube solvers
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 21:38:39 -0000

The traditional answer would be that it depends on the way the program checks when a cube is solved. Like if it compares it to something designated solved then all you'd have to do is manually change that. However that would require going into the source code. Moreover, I'm thinking that you want to be able to change the goal state as an option as well. Now thinking outside the box (or cube)... I'm going to apply a little bit of algbra here. Call your starting state A. Then what a program does is find an optimal A^(-1). Say f(x) = x^(-1), but optimally so. Then to get to the identity (solved state) you'd go A*f(A) = 1 (where we are composing in our usual sence/direction... it's actaully the other direction in most conventions, but then all our algs would have to be read backwards). So now say we have a goal state B. Then f(B^(-1)*A) should do the trick. Since A*f(B^(-1)*A) = A*A^(-1)*B = B (since inversion reverses order). Thus I assert that all that needs to be done is to have a pre-parser that takes A and B and passes B^(-1)*A into the program. This would then be a fairly routine cs exercise. It makes sence right? Also this should work for greyed-out stickering possiblities as well. -Doug (really, really behind on posts :(, sorry) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I have a question for your programmers. Would it be hard to take an > existing solver program (Ron's solver program, ACube, etc..) and > manually specify the desired final state rather than have it be > assumed to be the solved state? > > I was looking for good transformation algs from any OLL case into the > "T" orientation and thought that such a solver could come in handy. > > My method right now is just to start from the T and do the inverse of > various easy and fast moves that leave the edges oriented and when I > end up at an orientation I didn't know the transformation for yet I > would then know which alg I used to go from the T to that case, so I > can just do the reverse. > > Anyway I have no idea if a program feature like that is hard to do or > not, but I think it would be a cool option to have. > > I'm not really in dire need of a program like this, I was just curious > if it would be hard to do or not. Are there any others who would be > interested in such a feature, or am I just weird? ;-) > > Chris >

619. Re: Question about cube solvers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 22:07:40 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > Call your starting state A. Then what a program does is find an > optimal A^(-1). Say f(x) = x^(-1), but optimally so. > > So now say we have a goal state B. Then f(B^(-1)*A) should do the > trick. > > Thus I assert that all that needs to be done is to have a pre-parser > that takes A and B and passes B^(-1)*A into the program. Let start state algorithm A = R' F R B' R' F' R B Let goal state algorithm B = F U R U' R' F' Then B^(-1)*A is: F R U R' U' F' - R' F R B' R' F' R B A solution the program (ignoring permutation of course, since Chris was interested in OLLs) might find this: F U R U' R' F' Now apply A to a solved cube and then the alg the program found, you will not reach the goal state. Where's the mistake? Btw, somebody once showed me this OLL alg: R U R B' R' B U' R' Do that starting with a solved cube. I immediately replied "hey I know a 6-turn alg for that case so if I use the inverse of that I'll have a 6-turner for the same case you showed me an 8-turner for". Cheers! Stefan

Nah. Not quite. Franï¿½ois Koen Heltzel a ï¿½crit : > If you think standard RPS is boring, try this: > http://www.baseplace.nl/pics/rps15.jpg > > - Koen > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=irjrM9wdJDBnytECiSfUCw> > Free puzzle inlay games > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=5IEF0wvHk31uvuXI6ReWEw> > Educational game and puzzle > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=37T2K_4zOte4R94IVKMFNQ> > > Word puzzle game > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Word+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=3DsIilZKH4dSS_WgIx9QRg> > Kid puzzle game > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Kid+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=2-DgzSlkRkTyIak1hdhkgQ> > Puzzle games > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=EJHY58oeC85Up2uB7KhBMA> > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------ > YAHOO! 622. Re: coin flipping
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 22:45:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > That brings up the question, do people here have strategies for coin > flips? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology During a probablity exam the professor sees someone at the back flipping a coin and marking his answers. Toward the end of the time the student is flipping the coin faster and faster. The professor asks him what he's doing and he says that he's checking his answers. 80) DJ
623. Re: WC 2005 Report
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 23:13:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, nascarjon2001 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I don't normally write up reports on things, but for some reason > this time I felt like doing one. I hope that you enjoy it. > > http://www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001/wc2005.htm Hi Jon, nice report, thanks. Reminds me I still want to finish my own... One comment: Don't blame the magic rule, blame the judge. The magic is allowed to start and end two tiles higher than flat, i.e. about 0.45 inches off the table. Thus your 1/8 inch off should've been accepted. Cheers! Stefan

625. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: coin flipping
From: Vincent Le <vince1123581321@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 16:10:16 -0800

There's a way to always get the same side. Instead of flipping it, toss it in the air. As you toss it, make it rotate instead of flip. Then, make it oscillate slightly so it gives the illusion that it's flipping. If you do it properly then you can always get the same side. A friend showed this to me...it was pretty cool. Vincent On 15/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > > > That brings up the question, do people here have strategies for coin > > flips? > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > During a probablity exam the professor sees someone at the back > flipping a coin and marking his answers. Toward the end of the time > the student is flipping the coin faster and faster. The professor asks > him what he's doing and he says that he's checking his answers. 80) > > DJ > > > > > > > > ------------------------------ > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > - Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube>" > on the web. > - To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com<speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscribe> > - Your use of Yahoo! 627. Re: (what's yer type) Personality types
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 02:36:20 -0000

Exactly. The type test measures your preferences. Those preferences are OFTEN, but not ALWAYS, associated with certain skills or tendencies. You will always find exceptions. For example, I seem to be the only S so far. N's are just *generally* better at seeing patterns. So call me an exception. (Or don't, considering I'm probably one of the most pathetic cubers here....) My roommate in college was depressed after finding out he was INTP. He wanted to be a scientist so he thought he had to be INTJ. But the 16 types are not meant to be rigid boxes - only rough predictors. Well, long story short he gave up on science and majored in math instead. :P So don't worry about who you are. Oh yeah, and Craig - though I've not met you, I was prety sure of the E part...there are "not a few" posts by you! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@g...> wrote: > > well first of all... you don't have to be introverted to cube... so no > worries there > > second of all.... you don't need to conform to anyone's > expectations... just cuz all other cubes are introverted doesn't mean > you have to be introverted.. > > yea, that's pretty much it.

> posts by you!

Sachin.


629. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type... RPS & computers
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 19:52:47 -0800

It seems to me that a fully random RPS player would have exactly 50%
chance to win every game, and thus the same chance as any other player
to win a tournament. In other words, if 100 players enter a tournament,
a random player will have exactly 1% chance to win it. Or is that wrong
in some way??

I used to have an inactive link to a RPS page I planned to build on my
site, but after several years I abandoned the project. It would be very
cool to build something that tracked people's patterns and used them
against them, and I know that is very feasible, but OTOH, all that
brilliance can be semi-thwarted by such a simple counter strategy, and
that was part of why I lost interest.

Though actual human people are incapable of being 100% random, but
you'd probably have to play pretty long games to exploit unconscious
non randomness.

/Lars

On Nov 15, 2005, at 10:00, mike_go_uk wrote:

> Obviously you cannot second-guess /random/ coin flips, any more than
> you can second-guess a random RPS player. (But remember that the
> random player won't win an RPS tournament.)
>
- - - - - - - - - - - -
"He who refuses to do arithmetic is doomed to talk nonsense."
--- John McCarthy

Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

I think I'd say he's decent ;-)

Chris






631. Not Rubik's - but still a few cubes
From: "Frank Vedel" <frank.vedel@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 08:49:21 -0000

Hi,

This is an invitation to join Sudoku World, which is a yahoo based
international meeting place for Sudoku addicts.

Sudoku World was created on June, 25, and now we are 1198 members
from 46 countries.

The age of our Sudoku World members vary from 14 to 83!!! More than
40% of our members are female.

Sudoku World offers:

- useful information on the game and strategy,
- an active message board with more than 1.025 messages,
- lots of links to millions of Sudoku puzzles. A special section for
the Japanese Sudoku variants is very popular,
- lots of printable Sudoku puzzle files and helpful grids,
- 1 closed and 9 ongoing Sudoku related polls.
- photos with a recommended Sudoku literature section and many of
the new Japanese Sudoku puzzle variations including:
- samurai puzzles (also several hybrid puzzles!!),
- onsecutive numbers,
- sum Sudokus,
- product Sudoku,
- more or less Sudokus,
- arrow Sudokus
- irregular groups Sudokus,
- extra groups Sudokus,
- 8 and 12 number cube Sudokus
- hexagon Sudokus,
- total sum Sudoku,
- sum, difference, more or less Sudoku,
- more or less or equal Sudoku,
- demarcated Sudokus and
- colour Sudokus.

You will find Sudoku World here:

http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/Sudokuworld

You don't have to be a black belt Sudoku solver to become a member
of Sudoku World, because all ages, and all standards, beginners to
advanced Sudoku puzzlers, are welcome.

We all hope to meet you there!

Kind regards,

Frank Vedel - MY days are numbered - are yours?






632. Re: I'm the competitive type... RPS & computers
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 09:01:01 -0000

Hi Stefan, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Results so far > You have won 9, lost 3, and tied 4 games > Statistics for 16 games > winning percentage*: 37.50% > won : 56.25% > lost: 18.75% > tied: 25.00% I wouldn't be too surprised if you /can/ beat this program consistently, but you don't have much evidence here. Suppose we start from the hypothesis (1) that those win/lose/tie percentages really are an accurate reflection of what you would get in a very long run of games. Now compare the probability of getting the result (9,3,4) under that assumption (1) with the probability of getting (9,3,4) in purely random play: Ratio = (.5625)^9 * (.1875)^3 * (.25)^4 / (.3333)^16 = 6.2 This is not strong evidence in favour of (1), as compared with random play, and it will be weakened further if you were to make allowance for other hypotheses -- as we should: I deliberately chose (1) to be maximally favourable to /you/ -- i.e., to give the maximum possible value for the relative likelihoods of the 2 hypotheses. > That program is sooo bad. And my strategy was actually quite > repetitive. It was a short run. Try playing several hundred games to see if the program will pick up on your strategy. Yeah, it would be boring to do a proper test. ;) Mike

Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 01:01:46 -0800

Groups Links > > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
634. Re: [Speed cubing group] I'm the competitive type... RPS & computers
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 09:19:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@n...> wrote: > It seems to me that a fully random RPS player would have exactly 50% > chance to win every game, and thus the same chance as any other player > to win a tournament. In other words, if 100 players enter a tournament, > a random player will have exactly 1% chance to win it. Or is that wrong > in some way?? That sounds correct for one scenario: N players in a knockout competition of log N rounds (log to base 2), so there's a 50% chance of Mr Random progressing from one round to the next. But if everyone has to play everyone else, I suspect that the probability of Mr Random winning is much lower: the winner needs to get the highest overall score, and the strong programs that exploit patterns in the play of weak programs will be winning significantly more than half their games. Mike
635. (off-topic) 3d design
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

lles&.dnm=My+first+3D+cube.jpg&.src=gr&.view=t&.hires=t

I know there are 3d designers in this group, thanks if you can give me
some advice to make it as real as possible. Materials for plastic and
stickers, animation tips...

Gilles.

640. Re: (what's yer type) Personality types
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 12:35:14 -0000

Hi I don't know which one would be most drawn to speedcubing. I used to be obvious ENFP (yes Craig, that's right!) but I'd have to take the test again... Michiel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@e...> wrote: > > For those of you familiar with Myers-Briggs type - what personality > types do you think would be most drawn to speedcubing? My guess is > that the prototypical cuber would be ISTP or INTP. I think it would be > harder for an F or J to learn cubing, because I'd think being able to > analyze and adapt are primo considerations. I'm also thinking S's > would be more interested in speed per se, whereas N's would be more > interested in the mathematics of the cube and the like. > > In my adult life I seem to have 'gelled' as an ISTP. I was ISFP but > after working in the business world for about 5 years, I got all > hard 'n' crusty. :P > > If you don't know your type, take the test at: > http://www.humanmetrics.com/cgi-win/JTypes2.asp >

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 13:54:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > Hey... don't blame the judge. If there was a dispute, you should have > called over someone like me or Ron. Ok ok, so let's blame Jon for not knowing the rules better than the judge :-) Cheers! Stefan
646. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: WC 2005 Report
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 15:03:29 +0100

Hi friends, I was the judge... :-) Reading the report I still think the writer likes me. :-) Actually I consider this the same as an always popping cube: you should buy a new puzzle if you cannot follow the regulations with your puzzle. Yeah, it may sound a bit harsh, especially if you are not the record breaking type for a specific puzzle. But wasn't there a wise American who said that all people are equal? Any complaints about the regulations are welcome at the worldcubeassociation.org forum. We will work on the 2006 version in december 2005. Have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: Stefan Pochmann To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Wednesday, November 16, 2005 2:54 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: WC 2005 Report --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > Hey... don't blame the judge. If there was a dispute, you should have > called over someone like me or Ron. Ok ok, so let's blame Jon for not knowing the rules better than the judge :-) Cheers! Stefan ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. b.. 647. RWC magic event and general request
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 14:18:20 -0000

The thing that bothers me the most is that the tiles for the magics
are not the same thickness.

I inadvertently used two magics of different tile thickness to make my
master magic, which is why it hardly ever lays flat when solved
(unless I take a few seconds to work it flat). I got a DNF and a very
close but still ok solve at RWC because of this.

For us do it yourselfers who don't want to, and can't afford to, buy a
master magic on eBay, can we at least petition rubiks.com to either
standardize the tile thickness, or sell blank tiles (again
standardized to the same size) so that we can make our own?

I don't think they will reinstate the magic DIY kit. Mr. Rubik has
requested that it not be sold anymore (I was told this when I was
buying strings from rubiks.com). Also, and I hate to be mean, but I
think the cubesmith price of $6 for a bag of 16 strings is ridiculous.
If you need magic strings write to the people at rubiks.com. They
have been selling bags of 16 strings to me for $2 a bag for the past
couple months.

Anyway, is there a way that we can get the tiles standardized so that
do it yourselfers, who now can't buy a DIY kit, can make our own? Or
do I have to resort to eBay if I want to continue to compete in the
master magic?

Chris

649. Re: [Speed cubing group] (off-topic) 3d design
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 12:45:03 -0300 (ART)

But according to what Jon wrote (that is was off the table only by about 0.125 inches) he *did* follow the regulations. The rules allow about 0.45 inches (using an old black magic as reference). Parade. I'll be promoting the new season of Beauty and the Geek with
Richard and Lauren from the first season, along with another guy and
two girls from this season. If you're in the Los Angeles area, the
parade begins at 5 PM and will be broadcast on KTLA. I believe it
should be broadcast nationally as well. If you'd like to come and
laugh at me in person, the parade will be only about 15 minutes away
from Caltech.

to why I would be promoting the new season of Beauty and the Geek,
shoot me an e-mail. Below are a couple of links: two links for the
parade and another two links for the show, "Beauty and the Geek."

664. Re: [Speed cubing group] (off-topic) 3d design
From: "qwerty1110" <qwerty1110@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 19:18:06 -0000

Not bad for a start! <long post> Suggestions: Rendering 1. Raise the specularity and shininess on the stickers, they're almost reflective on new cubes. Perhaps add the logo to the white center. 2. look at a new cube, the reflections aren't perfect. Add a really light bump map to break up the reflections and specular highlights. 3. Get rid of ALL ambient light. If you need more light, turn on a point light. 4. Soften the spotlight. You have no decay around the edges of the light and that circle makes the image look CG. 5. Add more than one light. Usually I use a simple 3 light setup: Key light fill light and back light. Make sure that they're all not the same intensity. Key is usually .9 Fill is .5 or so, back is usually the brightest. I can see 2 lights in yours, so play around with them some more. Perhaps use area lights to soften the shaddows? 6. Get rid of the checkerboard table. As somebody who uses 3D programs, it stands out as a simple procedural texture that you just threw into the pic. Perhaps you could find a photo of a piece of wood and use that as a map? Or you could use a "use background" texture (I think that's what they're called in Max ... I usually use Maya) and make the background white. That gives you the effect of the white infinite room that you see so much on TV commercials, but you still get the shaddows. 7. If you can, try working with mental ray. It allows you to play with some really neat lighting stuff. For instance You can set it up to show bounced light. Set your cube on a white piece of paper red in front. Look at the paper. See the red? Mental ray can do that. Look for tutorials, they're everywhere. In general, your image is just too perfect. Real things aren't that perfect. Animation - I've tried animating a cube once, and it didn't turn out well. When I finally sit down to do it correctly, I want it to be fully scripted (IE select a center and the corresponding side turns no matter how many other twists have happened. Which you unfortunately can't do with just simple grouping) Anyway, back to you... the best way I found to move a cube is to move all the pivot points into the very center of the cube. That way when you select a side, the pivots are always directly below the center cubie. The problem I had was when a piece rotated more than 360. If that happens, the rotation value will go back to 0 when you key the frame, and when you play the animation, the piece will move in a strange fasion, so you pretty much have to fix that in the graph editor after you set the keyframes. </long post> *whew Hope I helped TBTTFox On 11/16/05, Gilles Roux <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > I tried to design a cube with 3ds Max: > > http://photos.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/vwp?.dir=/Gi > lles&.dnm=My+first+3D+cube.jpg&.src=gr&.view=t&.hires=t > > I know there are 3d designers in this group, thanks if you can give me > some advice to make it as real as possible. Materials for plastic and > stickers, animation tips... > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
665. Re: I'm the competitive type... SPSR SPSR RPRS RPRS SPSR...
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 19:34:14 -0000

> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > And my strategy: SPSR SPSR RPRS RPRS SPSR ... OK, I was really, /really/ bored, and tried this for 400 throws, i.e., 25 complete cycles of the Pochmann sequence: You have won 79, lost 164, and tied 157 games Statistics for 400 games winning percentage*: -21.25% won : 19.75% lost: 41.00% tied: 39.25% The percentage of wins for the program increased steadily (but slowly) after some tens of games. Here's the result of 300 throws of RRRRRRRR... You have won 1, lost 150, and tied 149 games Statistics for 300 games winning percentage*: -49.67% won : 0.33% lost: 50.00% tied: 49.67% As you can see, it threw scissors only once, and is rigged so that it won't win more than 50% of the games on average. Mike

The whole time it looks like you're just scrambling and then suddenly there's another cut and BOOM the cube is solved. So we don't even see you solve the cube at all! Anybody could've done that! I still like it for its style, though :-) Cheers! Stefan

672. Rutgers Fall 2005 competition
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Nov 2005 23:20:17 -0000

Hey all,

This is to announce that there will be an official WCA approved
competition at Rutgers University in Piscataway, New Jersey. This is
especially for all you East Coasters that rarely get a chance to
compete. ;) Registration is free and competitors will probably get
free pizza, so you have no excuse not to come. :)
The events will include 2x2, 3x3, 4x4, 5x5, 3x3 one-handed, 3x3
blindfolded, magic, and master magic. It is being sponsored by the
Rutgers University Rubik's Cube Club. If you have any questions,
please e-mail me: bob [at] cubewhiz.com and I will do my best to
answer them. I will create a database to see who is interested in
coming. This would help me when making a schedule of events.

I hope to see you there!
~ Bob

682. 2 very nice OLL algs
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 03:11:09 -0000

Hey everyone,

I recently found that one of my ZBLL algs ends in a really really nice
OLL alg that I have never seen before. The first half is a setup into
this OLL such that the OLL solves it.

Anyway I've been trying just the OLL itself and I really like it, and
am definitely switching to it.

To setup do: L R' U F U' F' L' U' R

To solve do: (R' U) L y' (R U R' U') (S)

Also the inverse is very nice and solves the inverse OLL case
To setup do: R' U L F U F' U' L' R

To solve do: x' (M' U) y' (R U' R') y (L' U') R

Again I'm sure these algs have already been discovered, but I had
never seen them before.

Hope someone likes them. The first one is definitely much faster than
my current alg, and I think with practice I get get the second one to
beat my current alg also.

Heh heh ZBLL can come in handy for Fridrich solving :-)

Chris

684. Re: 2 very nice OLL algs
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 03:55:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hope someone likes them. The first one is definitely much faster than > my current alg, and I think with practice I get get the second one to > beat my current alg also. What are your current algs for those? How about: > To setup do: L R' U F U' F' L' U' R To solve do: R' F R U R' U' F' U R > To setup do: R' U L F U F' U' L' R To solve do: R' U' F U R U' R' F' R Cheers! Stefan
685. Re: WC 2005 Report
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 04:01:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Well, before my solves at DCD, Ton flattened my magic completely > before the start, even though it is allowed to be one-tile thickness > above the mat at the start. Hmm... I thought it's two, but now I see it's actually indeed zero. Quote from the rules: > For Rubik's Magic the puzzle must be flat on the surface > when starting and ending the solve. > The maximum elevation of any part of the Magic at the end > of a solve is two tiles higher than flat. > The Magic may lie upside down at start and end. I thought the elevation rule was for both start and end. But it's only for the end. So at the start it must be completely flat (whatever that means ;-). Cheers! Stefan

687. Re: 2 very nice OLL algs
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 04:29:22 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > For my style though, that first new alg > is so much faster than my old one. But man, it has an S-turn !!! Don't you know that S stands for "sin" ??? Stefan
688. Re: 2 very nice OLL algs
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 04:41:15 -0000

>
> But man, it has an S-turn !!!
> Don't you know that S stands for "sin" ???
>
> Stefan
>

Well, it's sort of a half S turn and half M turn.

I guess to write it more exactly I would say

(R' U) L y (R U R' U') x S

The first y is only a half y turn. Turn the cube so that you don't
have a flat face in the front as an F face, but rather what started as
the FL edge. The FL edge should be the closest part of the cube to you.

Execute the (RUR'U') from this angle. Then do the x as if you were
doing regular x rotation, but rotate with that FL edge still closest
to you. Also only do it as a half turn. This way the S turn is
halfway between an M and an S.

I wish I had a camera and I could show you. I've gotten it in 1.5x
seconds several times though, so I mean it can be quite fast.

Chris

690. Re: I'm the competitive type... RPS & computers
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 10:26:32 -0000

(You would often get similar results by using the random number generator on your pocket calculator to choose your throws.) Instead, try to beat the Roshambot consistently over several hundred games... the program uses the game history to make its "predictions". Mike
691. An idea for Rubiks engineers
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 10:36:52 -0000

Embedded tiles could be cool.
Take a look at the 2 pictures I uploaded:

http://photos.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/lst?.dir=/
Gilles

My drawings are not accurate, real corner pieces are more
complicated,
it's just for the idea. The size and thickness of tiles should be
careful engineered.


- Thanks to the holes, you can remove the tiles by pushing them from
behind.
- Just put an adhesive sheet, and the tiles won't move.
- You can see the color only when facing the side (that's a problem
with thick tiles).
- Rubiks.com could sell fancy tiles sets, as they do with stickers.
- Waterproof.
- This beta version does not cure cancers.


Gilles.

696. Re: An idea for Rubiks engineers
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 14:35:22 -0000

Hi! I have always endorsed the idea about fused tiles. The tiles themselves do not necessarily have to be very thick. Slightly thincker than the ones found on the impossiball will be enough. On those tiles only a very small pin is enough to fix them firmly to the puzzle pieces (discs). Personally i would love to see those kinda tiles on regular cubes and for me i think i might prefer some hardened rubber of some kind and not plastic. This will ensure a better grip/hold of the cube. 2 kinds of tiles could eb supplied. Plastic and hardened rubber. But realistically i can't see it happening. Seventowns have already declined remaking the deluxe/game cubes. So i can't see why they would would be willing with such an extensive redesign of the cube either. And also these days one can get very good stickers and tiles from cubesmith. The days of really lousy stickers are gone already :- ) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > Embedded tiles could be cool. > Take a look at the 2 pictures I uploaded: > > http://photos.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/lst?.dir= / > Gilles > > My drawings are not accurate, real corner pieces are more > complicated, > it's just for the idea. The size and thickness of tiles should be > careful engineered. > > > - Thanks to the holes, you can remove the tiles by pushing them from > behind. > - Just put an adhesive sheet, and the tiles won't move. > - You can see the color only when facing the side (that's a problem > with thick tiles). > - Rubiks.com could sell fancy tiles sets, as they do with stickers. > - Waterproof. > - This beta version does not cure cancers. > > > Gilles. >

701. Re: 2 very nice OLL algs
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 18:16:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I wish I had a camera and I could show you. I've gotten it in 1.5x > seconds several times though, so I mean it can be quite fast. Hey, the other one is fast, too, I just did it 12 times in a row in 16.97 seconds, i.e. 1.41 on average... :-) Cheers! Stefan

Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 19:59:02 -0000

I hate paying too much for stuff also. Chris L. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I apologize for the harsh statement in the public forum here. I sent > an e-mail to Chris saying the same. I should have sent a private > e-mail rather than say something harsh on this group. > > I didn't mean to cause problems if it came across that way. > > As Ron says let's all have fun and just be friends here :-) > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jello33" <chris@c...> > wrote: > > > > Thanks cubekid, > > > > I'm definatly not making a ton on Magic strings. I also paid more > > than $2 a bag. In fact after shipping I'm closer to $3.50 my cost. > > I was honestly just trying to offer these as a conveinence, because > > people had asked for them. 703. Sub-20! (single solve)
From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 20:15:43 -0000

Holy crap! I just got a personal best of 19.86, which is my first
ever sub-20 solve! Thats about 2.5 seconds faster than my previous
personal best. It was also a part of my new best average of 28.13,
which is better than my previous best of 29.83. That seems like a big
jump in both areas, has anyone else experienced such big drops in times?

Also, for the record, I started cubing in May 2002 (I have the exact
dates at home), so it took me 3yrs 6mos to get a sub-20 solve. Now
we'll see how long it takes me to get a sub-20 average!

Man I was going to stop typing and hit send, but I'm on such a rush
right now. That solve felt so blazingly fast, with an easy OLL and
one of my best PLL's. I've really been working on looking ahead
during my F2L since Orlando, and it finally seems to be paying off. I
realized that I used to watch the pieces of my current CE pair while
putting them in, then look for the next one, which caused some major
gaps in the F2L.

I wish I could drop out of school and just cube all day.

-Chris Parlette





704. Re: An idea for Rubiks engineers
From: "Chris Sz..." <s2chris2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 20:21:20 -0000


> - You can see the color only when facing the side (that's a problem
> with thick tiles).

and why is that a problem? I'd much prefer tiles that stick out than
ones that sit flush

--Chris

709. Re: [Speed cubing group] Sub-20! (single solve)
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 13:53:52 -0800

I used to have a 22.xx average, then I stopped cubing for about a month because of school. When I picked it up again, I got a new pb average of 19.11 and have been sub-20 since. I'm not sure how it happened, but I wish I could apply the same technique for my classes. I would stop going to class for a month and show up for the final exam. -Chris On 11/17/05, Chris Parlette <cparlett@...> wrote: > > Holy crap! I just got a personal best of 19.86, which is my first > ever sub-20 solve! Thats about 2.5 seconds faster than my previous > personal best. Date: 17 Nov 2005 22:00:28 -0000

File : /RollingCubeTimer.exe Uploaded by : qqwref <mzrg@...> Description : A simple but practical Rubik's Cube timer with a rolling-average calculator. E-mail me at mzrgATverizonDOTnet if you want me to add any other features! You can access this file at the URL: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/files/RollingCubeTimer.exe To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit: http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files Regards, qqwref <mzrg@...>

713. Try this fast scramble!!!
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 22:29:56 -0000

I was doing me dayly cube traning when I got a non-lucky 14.60, which
is a very great time for me. Since it was non-lucky I thought I should
try to solve the same scramble again a few times and see what times my
skills could give me with a solve without ANY hesitation and stops. It
didn't take long before I did 10.06 and the solution is 50 moves. I
think thats quite fast. Try if you can beat my time. The scramble is:

U R2 F' R' U' L B U2 D R2 D L U2 F L2 B2 U L' F' U B U' R2 U2 D2





714. Re: 2 very nice OLL algs
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2005 22:54:47 -0000

Hi Chris, I don't know if you're interested in seeing how someone might find that on his or her own, but I thought Id tell you anyway. :) A long time a go I was looking for a new way to reverse the position of LL corners. Previously I had worked out R U R' U' which affects 4 corners and 3 edges and I thought I could adapt it the LL. The 4 corners were DR UR BR and BL. Since LU wasn't affected and DR was I added F to put LU where RU was and RU where DR was...beginning and ending with F so F R U R' U' F' which you probably recognize. Definitely one of my favorite algs. Later on with similar reasoning applied to its mirror inverse R' U' F' U F R, I added L to the beginning and U L' at the end... L R' U' F' U F R U L' L U' R F' U' F U r' Eight moves in my notation. It is one of my favorite algs. While I'm on favorite algs try F' U' L' U2 L F U R U2 R' now rotate the cube QU2 and do the alg again. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I recently found that one of my ZBLL algs ends in a really really nice > OLL alg that I have never seen before. The first half is a setup into > this OLL such that the OLL solves it. > > Anyway I've been trying just the OLL itself and I really like it, and > am definitely switching to it. > > To setup do: L R' U F U' F' L' U' R > > To solve do: (R' U) L y' (R U R' U') (S) > > Also the inverse is very nice and solves the inverse OLL case > To setup do: R' U L F U F' U' L' R > > To solve do: x' (M' U) y' (R U' R') y (L' U') R > > Again I'm sure these algs have already been discovered, but I had > never seen them before. > > Hope someone likes them. The first one is definitely much faster than > my current alg, and I think with practice I get get the second one to > beat my current alg also. > > Heh heh ZBLL can come in handy for Fridrich solving :-) > > Chris >

722. Re: Try this fast scramble!!!
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Nov 2005 10:14:18 -0000

Hi Dan! I start with an xcross, doing this: (y') U R' L' D'w L F' After that you are facing an easy pair, and when it's solved (I think most of you do it the same way as me) do U2 and the next easy pair is in FL. When that one is done you only need three moves to fix the last pair. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > Can you tell me your cross Gunnar? > > Dan :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" > <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > > > I was doing me dayly cube traning when I got a non-lucky 14.60, > which > > is a very great time for me. Since it was non-lucky I thought I > should > > try to solve the same scramble again a few times and see what times > my > > skills could give me with a solve without ANY hesitation and stops. > It > > didn't take long before I did 10.06 and the solution is 50 moves. I > > think thats quite fast. Try if you can beat my time. The scramble is: > > > > U R2 F' R' U' L B U2 D R2 D L U2 F L2 B2 U L' F' U B U' R2 U2 D2 > > >

Well, I'm not sure if the "y" count as a move, but, if not, my solution was 46 moves...if you count the y's, is 51... Pedro Jason Baum <speedrunningcuber@...> escreveu: My solution was also 50 moves. Maybe we did the same solve? I made an extended cross, got the 6 move B orientation, and a G permutation. Is this what your solve was like? -Jason --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > I was doing me dayly cube traning when I got a non-lucky 14.60, which > is a very great time for me. Since it was non-lucky I thought I should > try to solve the same scramble again a few times and see what times my > skills could give me with a solve without ANY hesitation and stops. It > didn't take long before I did 10.06 and the solution is 50 moves. I > think thats quite fast. Try if you can beat my time. The scramble is: > > U R2 F' R' U' L B U2 D R2 D L U2 F L2 B2 U L' F' U B U' R2 U2 D2 > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 725. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Try this fast scramble!!!
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Nov 2005 13:32:41 -0300 (ART)

I forgot to add this: I made an applet of my solve <applet code="RubikPlayer.class" archive="rubikplayer.jar" width="300" height="300"> <param name="scriptLanguage" value="HarrisENG"> <param name="script" value="(y' U R' L' d' L F') (y' U' R U2' R' U R U' R') (y2 L' U L U2' L' U L) (R U R' U2 R U' R') (y2 F U R U' R' F') (y' U' R2 U' R' U' R U R U R U' R) "> <param name="scriptProgress" value="0"> <param name="initScript" value="U R2 F' R' U' L B U2 D R2 D L U2 F L2 B2 U L' F' U B U' R2 U2 D2"> <param name="colorTable" value="0x00008B,0xcc1100,0xf8f8f8,0x00732f,0xff4600,0xffd200"> </applet> Pedro Jason Baum <speedrunningcuber@...> escreveu: My solution was also 50 moves. Maybe we did the same solve? I made an extended cross, got the 6 move B orientation, and a G permutation. Is this what your solve was like? -Jason --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > I was doing me dayly cube traning when I got a non-lucky 14.60, which > is a very great time for me. Since it was non-lucky I thought I should > try to solve the same scramble again a few times and see what times my > skills could give me with a solve without ANY hesitation and stops. It > didn't take long before I did 10.06 and the solution is 50 moves. I > think thats quite fast. Try if you can beat my time. The scramble is: > > U R2 F' R' U' L B U2 D R2 D L U2 F L2 B2 U L' F' U B U' R2 U2 D2 > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO!
