726. Re: Try this fast scramble!!!
From: a_ooms75 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Nov 2005 16:41:17 -0000

This was my solution 46 moves: [cross]D' L' D U' B' D2 R D2 [1pair]y' B' R U' R' B [2pair]y' R2 u R2 u' R2 [3pair]y2 R U R' U y' R U R' U R U R' [4pair]y U2 R U R' U R U' R' [oll]R B L' B' R' B L B' [pll]U my first time was a 20.xx second a 18.xx did not try any furder :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > Hi Dan! > > I start with an xcross, doing this: (y') U R' L' D'w L F' > After that you are facing an easy pair, and when it's solved (I > think most of you do it the same way as me) do U2 and the next easy > pair is in FL. When that one is done you only need three moves to > fix the last pair. > > /Gunnar > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > > > Can you tell me your cross Gunnar? > > > > Dan :) > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" > > <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > > > > > I was doing me dayly cube traning when I got a non-lucky 14.60, > > which > > > is a very great time for me. Since it was non-lucky I thought I > > should > > > try to solve the same scramble again a few times and see what > times > > my > > > skills could give me with a solve without ANY hesitation and > stops. > > It > > > didn't take long before I did 10.06 and the solution is 50 > moves. I > > > think thats quite fast. Try if you can beat my time. The > scramble is: > > > > > > U R2 F' R' U' L B U2 D R2 D L U2 F L2 B2 U L' F' U B U' R2 U2 D2 > > > > > >
727. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Try this fast scramble!!!
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Nov 2005 14:15:06 -0300 (ART)

Here's my solution: [x-cross] (y') U R' L' d' L F' [2nd pair] (y') U' R U2' R' U R U' R' [3rd pair] (y2) L' U L U2' L' U L [4th pair] R U R' U2 R U' R' [oll] (y2) F U R U' R' F' [pll] (y') U' R2 U' R' U' R U R U R U' R Oh, I tried 6 times, and made: 13.33, 13.25, 12.56, 11.67, 12.53, 12.33 I'm slow... Pedro a_ooms75 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: This was my solution 46 moves: [cross]D' L' D U' B' D2 R D2 [1pair]y' B' R U' R' B [2pair]y' R2 u R2 u' R2 [3pair]y2 R U R' U y' R U R' U R U R' [4pair]y U2 R U R' U R U' R' [oll]R B L' B' R' B L B' [pll]U my first time was a 20.xx second a 18.xx did not try any furder :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > Hi Dan! > > I start with an xcross, doing this: (y') U R' L' D'w L F' > After that you are facing an easy pair, and when it's solved (I > think most of you do it the same way as me) do U2 and the next easy > pair is in FL. 728. Re: (off-topic) 3d design
From: "qwerty1110" <qwerty1110@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Nov 2005 17:37:26 -0000

Ahh yes, much better! That looks really good! umm, some other things (yes I know I'm nitpicking, but the devil is in the details, but there are only 1 real one this time) Play with the lighting more - look at some still life photos some people have taken to get an idea of what I'm talking about. Lights usually aren't that close to the subject. Oh, And again, think about using area lights, they really do emulate the real world better. OOh! Idea! if you get REALLY bored, try making a used speedcube, peeling stickers, fading colors, chipped edges and all. Again, wonderful job TBTTFox --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, sgowal <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > It is almost real, very impressive art work ! > > Sven > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Ok, it almost looks like a cube: > > > > > > > > > http://photos.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/vwp?.dir=/Gilles&.dnm=Another+CG+cube.jpg&.src=gr&.view=t&.hires=t > > > > > > > > It's a 3ds Max object. 731. Timer Request
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Nov 2005 20:34:50 -0000

Hi everyone,

I'm looking for a good timer to train me for BLD on my stackmat. Is
there a timer that will warn me at 8,9, and 10 minutes? Or is there a
way to make another timer do that? I can't stand having my stackmat
turn off anymore and I gotta practice BLD before Rutger's competition.
Any help is appreciated. :)

Peter Greenwood





732. Re: [Speed cubing group] Timer Request
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Nov 2005 13:15:21 -0800

Hi Peter,

What about JNetCube? What exactly are you going to do when there's a
warning anyway? Maybe you should just keep a stop watch next to the
StackMat. I guess I'm not clear why you want a warning. Is the
warning so that you'll speed up or just so you know to start another
time? In BLD, if you don't have it memorized, there's nothing you can
really do so a warning isn't going to help.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Nov 18, 2005, at 12:34 PM, pjgat09 wrote:

> turn off anymore and I gotta practice BLD before Rutger's competition.

> Peter Greenwood

734. (notation) w?
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Nov 2005 21:44:52 -0000

Hi, I was going over Gunnar's solve and came to a "w" in the solution.
What does that mean? I'm familiar with x-y-z and M-E-S, but not w.
Are there other letters as well (other than UDLRFB)? Tanx






735. SV: [Speed cubing group] (notation) w?
From: "Dennis Nilssson" <massimo@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 18 Nov 2005 22:57:17 +0100

I believe that it is the Japanese scheme for d / d' i.e. two layer turn of D
/ D' or any other
Check out, e.g. http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/notation.html

// Dennis

-----Ursprungligt meddelande-----
Från: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
[mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] För kwickykanny
Skickat: den 18 november 2005 22:45
Till: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Ämne: [Speed cubing group] (notation) w?

Hi, I was going over Gunnar's solve and came to a "w" in the solution.
What does that mean? I'm familiar with x-y-z and M-E-S, but not w.
Are there other letters as well (other than UDLRFB)? Tanx

738. Swedish Cube Day 2005
From: "Anders Larsson" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Nov 2005 01:01:50 -0000

Cubing Friends,

I hereby have the privilege to announce the second Swedish Cube Day.

For details, registrations and directions, please contact me (anders
[at]svekub.se) or Gustav (gustav[at]svekub.se)

/Anders

---

Event: Swedish Cube Day 2005
Date: 11 December 2005
City: Uppsala, Sweden

Venue: Uthgård (http://www.utn.uu.se/index.php?id=22) at Uppsala
University (www.uu.se)
Events: 2-cube speed and one-handed, 3-cube speed (with and without
pre-inspection), one-handed, with feet and blindfolded, 4-cube
speed, 5-cube speed. Other events upon request.






739. Re: Timer Request
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Nov 2005 03:02:34 -0000

Yes, I created RubikTimerTalks. It's in the file section, and it tells you the time, so you don't have to look. It's Windows only, no linux/mac. I never tried more than 10 minutes but I think it should be no problem. Let me know if it works out. mail me at blonkm[at]gmail[dot]com Michiel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hi everyone, > > I'm looking for a good timer to train me for BLD on my stackmat. 746. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Embarking on a Journey...
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Nov 2005 11:50:56 -0600

I agree with Bob... learn how it works... it's much better that way. http://twistypuzzles.com/solutions/3x3x3-01.shtml has a good explanation of the f2l and, at least for me, was very good in teaching me f2l. it only gives the basic, but half the fun is learning how it works. memorization can come later... learn how it works first On 11/19/05, Bob Burton <bob@...m> wrote: > No! Do not memorize! ...unless it is too late :( > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" > <logitewty@h...> wrote: > > > > To my bedroom... > > > > In less than 20 minutes I am going to be moving up into my room, > > closing the door, and attacking F2L...I am hoping to have it all > > memorized and doable before the day is done...we will see, and that is > > the reason I will not be online for most of the day, unless I give up... > > > > Craig > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! (single solve) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@w...> wrote: > > Holy crap! I just got a personal best of 19.86, which is my first > ever sub-20 solve! Thats about 2.5 seconds faster than my previous > personal best. It was also a part of my new best average of 28.13, > which is better than my previous best of 29.83. That seems like a big > jump in both areas, has anyone else experienced such big drops in times? My best average went from 20.61 to 19.35. My best single solve went from 15.7ish to 13.34. It's not too uncommon. :) > I wish I could drop out of school and just cube all day. Me too. ~ Bob _____ YAHOO! 754. Algorithm in QTM
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Nov 2005 11:52:42 -0000


How long does this take in QTM?

L' F2 U2 B2 D F' U2 L D2 L2 B R F2 D2 U2 L' U2 F U' R'

It's 20 moves in HTM and at least 22 moves in QTM but my machine has been going for
several days now without deciding whether it can be done in 22 moves or not. The above
algorithm has a lot of half turns, so maybe it will take more than 22 moves in QTM. If so it
will take at least as many moves as superflip in both QTM and HTM (and maybe more in
QTM).

756. Posting unofficial records on speedcubing.com
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Nov 2005 15:28:30 -0000

Hi friends,

Today I installed a new record post page on speedcubing.com.

>From now on it should not be necessary anymore to send an e-mail
with a record post. The form should work in any browser, also if you
are using a web e-mail service like Hotmail.
If you accept the cookie from the record post page, your name and e-
mail address will be available next time you post a record.

This is the first step to automating the UWR record updates.
All records are posted into a database, from where I (still) handle
them manually.
Upcoming steps to be developed are:
1) after I approve a record, it will automatically appear on the
record lists (this would make a HUGE difference for me!) :-)
2) new page with 50 latest posted records (for visitors to see what
changed recently)
3) trusted posters can update their own records (yet even less work
for me)
4) one e-mail address + website reference across all pages (at the
moment all pages are handled separately)

All this great work is done by Lars Vandenbergh!
Thank you so much Lars! Visit his site at www.cubezone.be

Suggestions for the UWR pages are very welcome via e-mail.

Thanks and have fun,

Ron
PS: Tomorrow I will fly to India for a week, so no record updates...

761. Re: HEY GUYS.... I AM NEW HERE.... AND I NEED UR HELP
From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Nov 2005 20:28:56 -0000

Congratulations on getting down to 2 min. First of all, in short, yes you must learn to read notation if you ever want to learn any algorithms. It isn't hard and it's almost required if you want to get fast. If you want some great sites, check out the links section at speedcubing.com. You can get a genuine Rubik's cube from Wal-Mart or Target. good luck! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, shamsul khawaja <shamsus2010@y...> wrote: > > i can finnaly solve the rubiks cube .( yaaaaa!!! :P) well i have been practising and got from 15 min to 10 and now lowest is around 2 min (ya i stilll suck) > this is where u guys and ur experte come in .... > > i got into speed cubing nad wanna be atleast be able to get it in under a minuet.... not going for thoses record 12 secs yet > > i have been following lars beginner and some of Intermediate steps...at http://lar5.com/cube/ > > i am a visual guy and i like his java applets :D > > MY question to u all is that are there faster steps? and can u people help me out .... do i have to read tose F' R' AND STUFF LIKE THAT from other sites > > plz reply and help me out or give me excellent links.... As i understand it that is also the plan. To show best time as well as the most recent times. 766. New world record ?
From: "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 09:33:18 +0100

Just read an norwegian news article about a new world record in Hungary.
Apparently it broke the old record set in 1982 by 5 seconds. They are
obviously not up to speed on the recent development in the cubing
society.

link : http://pub.tv2.no/nettavisen/dagensbilde/article497181.ece

translation :


Broke the Rubik record.

Hungarian Prodanov Mitk (19) broke the world record of solving the
Rubiks cube Sunday, with a time of 18,5 seconds.

This is 5,5 seconds faster than the previous record, set in 1982 - when
there was a world wide Rubik "fever".

The new record was set in Budapest.



Terje


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



767. Re: Try this fast scramble!!!
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 11:19:58 -0000

That could be a new kind of competition. Give a scramble, let competitors find a good solution (FMC style, but optimized for speed), make them solve as fast as possible... mmhh... No. Try #1: 16s Ul'U'L2F RUr'U'R'r2UR2UM2UR U2RUR'URU2r' UM'U'M'U2M'U'xU2M'U2M' ... ... Try #20: 8.8s With this scramble, there's a 2x2x2 in 4 moves! Maybe Lars would have found F2L+OLL in 26 fast moves using his technique, leaving an easy permutation. UF'B'LRUR'U2R'F2RFRUR2U'RU2R'U'R2UR2U'RU+3-cycle -> 35 moves By the way, recently I did a very fast solve, I managed to keep the scramble and the solution: L F L' U B2 R' L2 F' U2 F B L D' F2 L' B' F U2 L' R' D B2 L2 F2 D2 z2FRURr2B' U'r'U'M'URU2R2UR' U'R'U'RUlU'R'Ux UMUM'U2M'U'MU2 Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > I was doing me dayly cube traning when I got a non-lucky 14.60, which > is a very great time for me. Since it was non-lucky I thought I should > try to solve the same scramble again a few times and see what times my > skills could give me with a solve without ANY hesitation and stops. It > didn't take long before I did 10.06 and the solution is 50 moves. I > think thats quite fast. Try if you can beat my time. The scramble is: > > U R2 F' R' U' L B U2 D R2 D L U2 F L2 B2 U L' F' U B U' R2 U2 D2 >

769. Wallpaper
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 11:32:31 -0000




http://photos.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/vwp?.dir=/Gilles&.dnm=Wallpaper.jpg&.src=gr&.view=t&.hires=t



Gilles.




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



770. OH-solving rules
From: "mahtianssi" <mahtianssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 12:03:06 -0000

Article C: One-handed Solving
See Article A. Additional/special regulations for One-handed Solving:

During the preinspection and solve the competitor may only use one
hand. No other body part or the table or any other available object
may touch the puzzle. Once a competitor touches the puzzle with one
hand, he may not touch the puzzle with the other hand.

So every solve should be DNF, coz when you start, the puzzle is on the
table =)





771. Re: Posting unofficial records on speedcubing.com
From: "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@...>

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 12:47:54 -0000

So i > > can see the need for 2 separate lists for those 2 different > > purposes. As i understand it that is also the plan. To show best > > time as well as the most recent times. Editing that urself is a > > great timesaver for Ron (and Chris) :-) > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" > > <allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > > > > > Very nice Ron and Lars! > > > > > > The only thing I'd like to add that we should encourage everybody > > to > > > keep their times updated... for the bigger cubes and other puzzles > > as > > > well. > > > The unofficial lists are (in theory) only useful if _everyone_ > > posts > > > and updates his/her times. > > > > > > Greets, Koen > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> > > wrote: > > > > > > > > Hi friends, > > > > > > > > Today I installed a new record post page on speedcubing.com. > > > > > > > > From now on it should not be necessary anymore to send an e-mail > > > > with a record post. Visit his site at www.cubezone.be > > > > > > > > Suggestions for the UWR pages are very welcome via e-mail. > > > > > > > > Thanks and have fun, > > > > > > > > Ron > > > > PS: Tomorrow I will fly to India for a week, so no record > > updates... > > > > > > > > > >

774. Re: OH-solving rules
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 15:18:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" <mahtianssi@y...> wrote: > > Article C: One-handed Solving > See Article A. Additional/special regulations for One-handed Solving: > > During the preinspection and solve the competitor may only use one > hand. No other body part or the table or any other available object > may touch the puzzle. Once a competitor touches the puzzle with one > hand, he may not touch the puzzle with the other hand. > > So every solve should be DNF, coz when you start, the puzzle is on the table =) The only thing I think that needs updating is the word "preinspection". It is presolve, and it is inspection. So preinspection would be the time before you actually start inspecting, would it not? But as long as you understand that the "preinspection" starts when you pick the cube up from the table and finishes when you put it back down on the table, then the issue is moot as you are not putting it on the table during your inspection as per this rule. I do wonder, however, if that means you are disqualified if you accidentally drop the cube because it will then touch the table during the solving portion. This is probably in the rules somewhere and someone else will undoubtedly enlighten me. -Dave Campbell

But as long as you understand that the "preinspection" starts when you pick the cube up from the table and finishes when you put it back down on the table, then the issue is moot as you are not putting it on the table during your inspection as per this rule. I do wonder, however, if that means you are disqualified if you accidentally drop the cube because it will then touch the table during the solving portion. This is probably in the rules somewhere and someone else will undoubtedly enlighten me. -Dave Campbell SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 778. Re: OH-solving rules
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 17:34:44 -0000

Hi Guys, This is a typical "letter of the law" versus "spirit of the law" type of thing. The spirit of the law is that the cube is to be solved by one hand, in this case, unaided by the table. Picking up the cube is not a violation of the spirit of the law; so it not should it be necessary to change the wording of the rule. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" > <mahtianssi@y...> wrote: > > > > Article C: One-handed Solving > > See Article A. Additional/special regulations for One-handed > Solving: > > > > During the preinspection and solve the competitor may only use one > > hand. No other body part or the table or any other available > object > > may touch the puzzle. Once a competitor touches the puzzle with > one > > hand, he may not touch the puzzle with the other hand. > > > > So every solve should be DNF, coz when you start, the puzzle is on > the table =) > > > The only thing I think that needs updating is the > word "preinspection". It is presolve, and it is inspection. So > preinspection would be the time before you actually start > inspecting, would it not? > > But as long as you understand that the "preinspection" starts when > you pick the cube up from the table and finishes when you put it > back down on the table, then the issue is moot as you are not > putting it on the table during your inspection as per this rule. > > I do wonder, however, if that means you are disqualified if you > accidentally drop the cube because it will then touch the table > during the solving portion. This is probably in the rules somewhere > and someone else will undoubtedly enlighten me. > > -Dave Campbell >
779. Re: OH-solving rules
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 17:39:03 -0000

Actually, I feel it would be better to say that no other part of the body nor the table may be used to manipulate the puzzle. That way, if you drop your cube, you are not breaking the rule. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi Guys, > > This is a typical "letter of the law" versus "spirit of the law" type > of thing. The spirit of the law is that the cube is to be solved by > one hand, in this case, unaided by the table. Picking up the cube is > not a violation of the spirit of the law; so it not should it be > necessary to change the wording of the rule. > > Cheers, > > David J > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" > > <mahtianssi@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Article C: One-handed Solving > > > See Article A. Additional/special regulations for One-handed > > Solving: > > > > > > During the preinspection and solve the competitor may only use one > > > hand. No other body part or the table or any other available > > object > > > may touch the puzzle. Once a competitor touches the puzzle with > > one > > > hand, he may not touch the puzzle with the other hand. > > > > > > So every solve should be DNF, coz when you start, the puzzle is on > > the table =) > > > > > > The only thing I think that needs updating is the > > word "preinspection". It is presolve, and it is inspection. So > > preinspection would be the time before you actually start > > inspecting, would it not? > > > > But as long as you understand that the "preinspection" starts when > > you pick the cube up from the table and finishes when you put it > > back down on the table, then the issue is moot as you are not > > putting it on the table during your inspection as per this rule. > > > > I do wonder, however, if that means you are disqualified if you > > accidentally drop the cube because it will then touch the table > > during the solving portion. 780. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: OH-solving rules
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 10:08:08 -0800

Hi Everyone, I don't really have much of a problem with it. It is a "spirit of the law" but the letter of the law is also clear. If you drop the cube on the table or if you drop the cube and it falls onto your chest or foot, you're not breaking the rule because you're not using the table or the body to manipulate the cube. Manipulate implies "making a turn" and so if you are using the table to apply a force to the cube which turns a side, then you're breaking the rule. If you use your armpit to hold the cube while your other hand turns the cube, that's not good either. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Nov 21, 2005, at 9:39 AM, Bob Burton wrote: > Actually, I feel it would be better to say that no other part of the > body nor the table may be used to manipulate the puzzle. That way, if > you drop your cube, you are not breaking the rule. > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: >> >> Hi Guys, >> >> This is a typical "letter of the law" versus "spirit of the law" type >> of thing. The spirit of the law is that the cube is to be solved by >> one hand, in this case, unaided by the table. Picking up the cube is >> not a violation of the spirit of the law; so it not should it be >> necessary to change the wording of the rule. >> >> Cheers, >> >> David J >> >> >> >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog >> <no_reply@y...> wrote: >>> >>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" >>> <mahtianssi@y...> wrote: >>>> >>>> Article C: One-handed Solving >>>> See Article A. Additional/special regulations for One-handed >>> Solving: >>>> >>>> During the preinspection and solve the competitor may only use one >>>> hand. No other body part or the table or any other available >>> object >>>> may touch the puzzle. Once a competitor touches the puzzle with >>> one >>>> hand, he may not touch the puzzle with the other hand. >>>> >>>> So every solve should be DNF, coz when you start, the puzzle is on >>> the table =) >>> >>> >>> The only thing I think that needs updating is the >>> word "preinspection". It is presolve, and it is inspection. So >>> preinspection would be the time before you actually start >>> inspecting, would it not? >>> >>> But as long as you understand that the "preinspection" starts when >>> you pick the cube up from the table and finishes when you put it >>> back down on the table, then the issue is moot as you are not >>> putting it on the table during your inspection as per this rule. >>> >>> I do wonder, however, if that means you are disqualified if you >>> accidentally drop the cube because it will then touch the table >>> during the solving portion. This is probably in the rules somewhere >>> and someone else will undoubtedly enlighten me. >>> >>> -Dave Campbell >>> >> > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > >

Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 18:16:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > Hi Everyone, > > I don't really have much of a problem with it. It is a "spirit of the > law" but the letter of the law is also clear. If you drop the cube on > the table or if you drop the cube and it falls onto your chest or foot, > you're not breaking the rule because you're not using the table or the > body to manipulate the cube. Manipulate implies "making a turn" and so > if you are using the table to apply a force to the cube which turns a > side, then you're breaking the rule. If you use your armpit to hold > the cube while your other hand turns the cube, that's not good either. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology I think that is the point here. Unless Anssi did not copy the entire section in question, the rule does not appear to have the word "manipulate" in it. It states "touch" as being the culprit. -Dave Campbell

783. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: OH-solving rules - question
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 10:38:20 -0800

Feet-solving is definitely a tricky one. It seems that the wording for feet-solving should allow the floor to be used because, in the words of Stefan, what's natural for a person to do with their feet is to anchor the cube on the floor and then make a turn. For one-handed, yes, we should use the word "manipulate" instead of "touch". Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Nov 21, 2005, at 10:21 AM, Gilles Roux wrote: > > Just a naïve question. > When you're a beginner, solving with the help of the table is much > easier. But when you're sub-30, is it still valid? > > > Gilles. > > > PS: I'm thinking about feet solving without the help of... argh > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <bob@c...> wrote: >> >> Actually, I feel it would be better to say that no other part of the >> body nor the table may be used to manipulate the puzzle. That way, > if >> you drop your cube, you are not breaking the rule. >> >> ~ Bob >> >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" >> <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: >>> >>> Hi Guys, >>> >>> This is a typical "letter of the law" versus "spirit of the law" > type >>> of thing. The spirit of the law is that the cube is to be solved > by >>> one hand, in this case, unaided by the table. Picking up the cube > is >>> not a violation of the spirit of the law; so it not should it be >>> necessary to change the wording of the rule. >>> >>> Cheers, >>> >>> David J >>> >>> >>> >>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog >>> <no_reply@y...> wrote: >>>> >>>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" >>>> <mahtianssi@y...> wrote: >>>>> >>>>> Article C: One-handed Solving >>>>> See Article A. 784. One-Handed Solving
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 10:47:09 -0800

On the subject of one-handed solving, why am I so bad at it? I was
looking at the results of the Westview Competition and I realized I
would have placed fourth or fifth! And my speed solve average can
occasionally get under 17. Why do I suck so much? Is there something
about moving a cube with one-hand that I just don't realize, or is the
inability to do my OLL and PLL algorithms really biting me in the butt,
or maybe... usually the answer is leprechauns.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology



785. Re: One-Handed Solving
From: aznseashell <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 19:39:46 -0000

It's the last layer algorithms that get me. I also attribute my lack of one-handed skill to the fact that my cube is a little stiffer and my hands are kind of small, so having to regrip the cube every couple of turns slows me down a lot. Shelley --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > On the subject of one-handed solving, why am I so bad at it? 786. Re: Stefan Pochmann in the paper
From: "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 19:48:15 -0000

Maybe you can scan it? I'm sure at least Stefan is interested in seeing it :P - Koen --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "bryanosaurus" <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > I was reading the newspaper today (New York Daily News, USA) and there's a rather large > picture of Stefan Pochmann 'trying to break the blindfolded record'. Just figured I'd pass on > the info... > > > bryanosaurus >

788. Re: [Speed cubing group] One-Handed Solving
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 20:03:37 +0000 (GMT)

Yeah, the same for me...I was wondering how people can do sub-30 times OH...I'm around 1 minute on avg, with a PB of 43.xx...Maybe their cubes are better, or they have fast hands...or maybe I's slow...don't know... Pedro Tyson Mao <tmao@...> escreveu: On the subject of one-handed solving, why am I so bad at it? I was looking at the results of the Westview Competition and I realized I would have placed fourth or fifth! And my speed solve average can occasionally get under 17. Why do I suck so much? Is there something about moving a cube with one-hand that I just don't realize, or is the inability to do my OLL and PLL algorithms really biting me in the butt, or maybe... usually the answer is leprechauns. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 789. Re: [Speed cubing group] ... stackman and other nebish questions....plz reply
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 12:05:51 -0800

Hi Khawaja,

You can purchase the StackMat here: http://www.speedstacks.com/ .

As for how many times a day you should solve a cube or if notation is
necessary, the amount of effort you put into cubing will directly
affect your success. If you choose not to learn notation, that's fine,
but you should know that you will have a difficult time sharing ideas
and also a difficult time learning new things as most of our
information is communicated in this manner.

You basically choose to study what you want. If your goal is to reach
1 minute, then you might not need notation, but you have to make sure
the method you're using is efficient and does not waste steps. If your
goal is to get under 60 seconds, then you'll probably want to learn
notation as it's unfair to the rest of us to describe visually to you
what to do when we took the effort to learn notation as to lessen the
burden of teaching from other cubers.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Nov 21, 2005, at 11:59 AM, shamsul khawaja wrote:

> I am still a newb at this and all this group is talking about is some
> advance things that i have no clue about :P
>
> I have seen this stack man and it look pretty cool.... where can i
> get one and how much does it go for ....
>
> and how many times should i be solving a cube per day? .... i cant
> seem to reach under the 2 mintes so what are ur suggestion,.... and is
> notations a REAL MUST?.... I am a visual peson and i find it very
> boring reading it... can i get under a minute with out it?
>
> ONE LAST QUESTION ....for now... THE PERSON (SRRY FORGOT UR NAME)
> that got like 25 to 30 seconds with petrus method .... did u study the
> advance moves or the notations to achieve that AMAZING 25 secs?
>
> plz reply
>
>
> SHAMSUL
>
> Khawaja

791. Re: [Speed cubing group] ... stackman and other nebish questions....plz reply
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 12:15:24 -0800 (PST)

yes i used notation, its not that hard, and its just kind of something you need to suck it up and do. i do use some more advanced techniques now, but i reached around 35 seconds with the basic petrus method, then i expanded to learn some other last layer techniques. if you wanted my advice on what to practice to get faster, it would be the first 2 steps of the method, building the 2x2x2 then the 2x2x3. try studying each corner and see how many moves you can make a 2x2x2 box with each one. once you know which one you think is the shortest, study it until you know the moves to make the box in your head (this is why notation is important) then execute building the 2x2x2 blindfolded. this will help you see the box to build, as well as helping you to be able to look ahead, because if you can build the 2x2x2 without looking at what you are doing, you can be searching for the next 3 pieces you need while doing the 2x2x2. and 25 seconds is far from amazing, but thanks for your compliment. it does take patience, you can't just go from 10 minutes to 1 minute in a day or two. it will come naturally, don't worry about speed, work on efficiency and the speed will come naturally. shamsul khawaja <shamsus2010@...> wrote: I am still a newb at this and all this group is talking about is some advance things that i have no clue about :P I have seen this stack man and it look pretty cool.... where can i get one and how much does it go for .... and how many times should i be solving a cube per day? .... i cant seem to reach under the 2 mintes so what are ur suggestion,.... and is notations a REAL MUST?.... I am a visual peson and i find it very boring reading it... can i get under a minute with out it? ONE LAST QUESTION ....for now... THE PERSON (SRRY FORGOT UR NAME) that got like 25 to 30 seconds with petrus method .... did u study the advance moves or the notations to achieve that AMAZING 25 secs? plz reply SHAMSUL Khawaja --------------------------------- Find your next car at Yahoo! Canada Autos [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- --------------------------------- Yahoo! FareChase - Search multiple travel sites in one click. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
792. Re: [Speed cubing group] ... stackman and other nebish questions....plz reply
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 12:18:03 -0800

I was thinking about this a bit more. There is a certain agreement
between the student and the teacher. The teacher is expected to
further the education of his student without reservation. When I teach
people blindfolding, I tell them everything I know, even if it means
that they might beat me later on. I know Leyan and I share blindfold
ideas freely with the hope of pushing the human limits of blindfold
cubing. I don't hold any secrets back so that I can beat him.

The student, on the other hand, is expected to put forth an effort
equal or greater to that of the teacher's effort. You cannot expect me
to explain to you concept of the cube if you are not willing to put
forth the effort to learn something as simple as notation, which, I
might add, can be learned in about 2 minutes. If you are constantly
searching for short cuts in order to get by on cubing, your success
will surely be limited.

We're all willing to help you. I can tell you that an 18 second
average is possible with only OLL and PLL. (Takahito Domon) and that
Macky can probably solve the cube with a beginner's method in 23
seconds on average (no OLL, no PLL). However, these people have spent
a considerable effort studying the art of cubing.

All of us are friendly here. But we'll only put in as much effort to
teach you as you are willing to put in effort to learn.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Nov 21, 2005, at 12:05 PM, Tyson Mao wrote:

> Hi Khawaja,
>
> You can purchase the StackMat here: http://www.speedstacks.com/ .
>
> As for how many times a day you should solve a cube or if notation is
> necessary, the amount of effort you put into cubing will directly
> affect your success. If you choose not to learn notation, that's fine,
> but you should know that you will have a difficult time sharing ideas
> and also a difficult time learning new things as most of our
> information is communicated in this manner.
>
> You basically choose to study what you want. If your goal is to reach
> 1 minute, then you might not need notation, but you have to make sure
> the method you're using is efficient and does not waste steps. If your
> goal is to get under 60 seconds, then you'll probably want to learn
> notation as it's unfair to the rest of us to describe visually to you
> what to do when we took the effort to learn notation as to lessen the
> burden of teaching from other cubers.
>
> Tyson Mao
> MSC #631
> California Institute of Technology
>

795. Re: [Speed cubing group] ... stackman and other nebish questions....plz reply
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 13:31:16 -0800

I'm being tough, but I'm sure everyone here expects the same from any student. There's nothing you can do in cubing which will make you miraculously better. The people who are better than me have put in more time and studied the cube more. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Nov 21, 2005, at 1:17 PM, Clancy Cochran wrote: > this is totally fair, and 100% on in my opinion. you can only get > out what you put into it. no one has a secret that will make anyone > cube in 30 seconds everytime, its about personal effort. > > Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: I was thinking about > this a bit more. 796. Re: ... stackman and other nebish questions....plz reply
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 23:52:06 -0000

>The people who are better than me have put in
> more time and studied the cube more.
>
> Tyson Mao

Just to take a philisophical turn, I do believe that some people are
just meant to be better cubers for reasons like faster reflexes,
better visual spacial skills, etc. I mean not anyone can train to win
the 100m at the olympics, some people are just better built for it, so
if they train as much as you, you can't catch up.

I don't mean that to sound pessimistic, but it seems most disciplines
are this way, I guess we should also qualify? I just felt like asking
to see what others thought too.

Chris

801. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: ... stackman and other nebish questions....plz reply
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Nov 2005 16:24:07 -0800

Hi Chris,

Yes, I agree with you to a degree. In many sports, you can only work
so hard. Once you get to the elite level, physiology takes over. I
can train as hard as I want, and I might work my entire life off and
manage to run a mile in 4 minutes and 20 seconds, but the elite runners
do it in 3 minutes and 50 seconds, and there comes a point where body
type and things we cannot control are start to factor into our success
overwhelmingly.

However, with cubing, I think it affects us far less. Cubing is very
much a mental thing. The dexterity can be learned just as anyone can
learn to play the violin. I would believe that cubing is very much
like learning to play music and only a few people in the world have
innate abilities that help them. Otherwise, for the most part, pretty
much anyone can be sub-20. Sub-15... is another story, and is like the
3:50 mile.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Nov 21, 2005, at 3:52 PM, cmhardw wrote:

>> The people who are better than me have put in
>> more time and studied the cube more.
>>
>> Tyson Mao
>
> Just to take a philisophical turn, I do believe that some people are
> just meant to be better cubers for reasons like faster reflexes,
> better visual spacial skills, etc. I mean not anyone can train to win
> the 100m at the olympics, some people are just better built for it, so
> if they train as much as you, you can't catch up.
>
> I don't mean that to sound pessimistic, but it seems most disciplines
> are this way, I guess we should also qualify? I just felt like asking
> to see what others thought too.
>
> Chris
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>

803. [Speed cubing group] Re: ... stackman and other nebish questions....plz reply
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 00:44:22 -0000

I also agree, but I would like to point out that cubing is relatively new. We are probably quite far from the limits of cubing. Nobody devotes their entire life to solving the cube, though there are people who devote such time to running. The limits of speedcubing will be constantly pushed for this reason. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > Hi Chris, > > Yes, I agree with you to a degree. In many sports, you can only work > so hard. Once you get to the elite level, physiology takes over. I > can train as hard as I want, and I might work my entire life off and > manage to run a mile in 4 minutes and 20 seconds, but the elite runners > do it in 3 minutes and 50 seconds, and there comes a point where body > type and things we cannot control are start to factor into our success > overwhelmingly. > > However, with cubing, I think it affects us far less. Cubing is very > much a mental thing. The dexterity can be learned just as anyone can > learn to play the violin. I would believe that cubing is very much > like learning to play music and only a few people in the world have > innate abilities that help them. Otherwise, for the most part, pretty > much anyone can be sub-20. Sub-15... is another story, and is like the > 3:50 mile. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Nov 21, 2005, at 3:52 PM, cmhardw wrote: > > >> The people who are better than me have put in > >> more time and studied the cube more. > >> > >> Tyson Mao > > > > Just to take a philisophical turn, I do believe that some people are > > just meant to be better cubers for reasons like faster reflexes, > > better visual spacial skills, etc. I mean not anyone can train to win > > the 100m at the olympics, some people are just better built for it, so > > if they train as much as you, you can't catch up. > > > > I don't mean that to sound pessimistic, but it seems most disciplines > > are this way, I guess we should also qualify? I just felt like asking > > to see what others thought too. > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > >
804. [Speed cubing group] Re: ... stackman and other nebish questions....plz reply
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 03:11:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > I also agree, but I would like to point out that cubing is relatively > new. We are probably quite far from the limits of cubing. Nobody > devotes their entire life to solving the cube, though there are people > who devote such time to running. The limits of speedcubing will be > constantly pushed for this reason. > > ~ Bob On the contrary, I feel that we're already reasonably close to the possible limits of human execution. Think of it this way: If someone could conceivably use full ZB (or whatever method with few moves they choose) and manage between 40 and 45 moves per solve, along with a turn rate of around 5 turns per second, that's still something like 9 seconds on average. Sure, proportionately, we've got a long way to go, but with the rate of improvement, and the general refinement of the methods and processes, I believe cubing will soon reach a point where a sub-13 or even sub-12 average is not unheard of in competition. Of course, even that is leagues away from 9 seconds, but it's only a matter of time, really. I'm much more interested in the limits on the 4x4. -Mike Team [ZB]

I can't believe I "just" noticed this.

Tyson Mao

> Hungary.
> Apparently it broke the old record set in 1982 by 5 seconds. They are
> obviously not up to speed on the recent development in the cubing
> society.
>
> link : http://pub.tv2.no/nettavisen/dagensbilde/article497181.ece

>
>
> Broke the Rubik record.
>
> Hungarian Prodanov Mitk (19) broke the world record of solving the
> Rubiks cube Sunday, with a time of 18,5 seconds.
>
> This is 5,5 seconds faster than the previous record, set in 1982 - when
> there was a world wide Rubik "fever".
>
> The new record was set in Budapest.

811. Re: [Speed cubing group] New world record ?
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 11:07:56 -0000

Hi everyone!! The article is changed now and I don't remember what it said before. Now it says something like: Hungarian Prodanov Mitk solved the rubik's kub in an amazing time of 18.5 seconds this sunday. It's 5.5 seconds better than the WR was in 1982 when the Rubiks-fever was on its peak. But he is not the fastest cuber in the world. The official WR is 11.75 and is held by Jean Pons, France. That is the spirit of the article. I may have misunderstood some details because I'm swedish and it's a norwegian newspaper, but I think it's OK. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@f...> wrote: > > I had a look at this link and also saw a reference to "11,75 sekunder" > and "Jean Pons". 813. Hungarian Nationals
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 11:37:38 -0000

Hi all,

I just got back from the Hungarian Nationals which you may or may not
have seen media about.

It was a fantastically well organised event, and the aim of the
competition was to bring the cube back into peoples minds in Hungary,
and also to try and break the old Hungarian Record. The event
accomplished both goals, with several records broken and a best time
of 18.21 (I think thats right).

We then took part in the "Kocka Show" afterwards and showed off lots
of different skills, Stefan and I did team-blindfold solving, and also
blindfolded - where Stefan successfully solved followed by tumultuous
applause; and Jasmine, Stefan and I took part in lots of races of all
sorts with the Hungarians. I also beat Stefan by less than 0.5 seconds
on the 4x4x4, bad luck mate! My proudest moment was setting the
fastest time of the day on stage, 15.87.

I also set an 11.24 seconds solve while being solved by a TV news
crew, so I am looking forward to seeing the video of that. It was
scrambled by Stefan and timed on his stopwatch, so I guess the time
maybe inaccurate, but we will be able to tell from the video :)

The city was also beautiful (Budapest), and the Hungarians were very
friendly and welcoming to all.

If the European Championship of 2006 will be held in Budapest, then I
think it would be a superb event. Because the cube a national
treasure, there is SO SO much more interest within the Hungarian
public, the crowds that turned up were even bigger than at the World
Champs! And the media guys did a great job of publicising the event,
and making sure it ran smoothly.

I will definitely be voting for EC2006 in Hungary.

I've almost sorted my webhosting out now, so when it's back up I will
add pics from DCD2005, WC2005, and Hungarian Nationals as well as
reports for all, updated FMC and lots more stuff I promise!

Dan :)





814. Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
From: "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 11:45:34 -0000

Heya,

Looking at Olympic Cubes' site and messages on Twisty it won't take
very long anymore for the 6x6x6 to be available for the public.
Personally I'm very excited about trying it out.
Does anybody has an idea about how it's going to be released? Will we
be able to order it off the Olympic Cubes site?

Also will the upcoming tournaments have 6x6x6 events? What will the
top times be like for the 6x6x6 after say 2 months of it's release?

Discuss :D

Greets, Koen






815. Re: [Speed cubing group] Hungarian Nationals

Alberto.

----- Original Message -----
From: Dan
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, November 22, 2005 12:37 PM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Hungarian Nationals


Hi all,

I just got back from the Hungarian Nationals which you may or may not
have seen media about.

It was a fantastically well organised event, and the aim of the
competition was to bring the cube back into peoples minds in Hungary,
and also to try and break the old Hungarian Record. The event
accomplished both goals, with several records broken and a best time
of 18.21 (I think thats right).

We then took part in the "Kocka Show" afterwards and showed off lots
of different skills, Stefan and I did team-blindfold solving, and also
blindfolded - where Stefan successfully solved followed by tumultuous
applause; and Jasmine, Stefan and I took part in lots of races of all
sorts with the Hungarians. I also beat Stefan by less than 0.5 seconds
on the 4x4x4, bad luck mate! My proudest moment was setting the
fastest time of the day on stage, 15.87.

I also set an 11.24 seconds solve while being solved by a TV news
crew, so I am looking forward to seeing the video of that. It was
scrambled by Stefan and timed on his stopwatch, so I guess the time
maybe inaccurate, but we will be able to tell from the video :)

The city was also beautiful (Budapest), and the Hungarians were very
friendly and welcoming to all.

If the European Championship of 2006 will be held in Budapest, then I
think it would be a superb event. Because the cube a national
treasure, there is SO SO much more interest within the Hungarian
public, the crowds that turned up were even bigger than at the World
Champs! And the media guys did a great job of publicising the event,
and making sure it ran smoothly.

I will definitely be voting for EC2006 in Hungary.

I've almost sorted my webhosting out now, so when it's back up I will
add pics from DCD2005, WC2005, and Hungarian Nationals as well as
reports for all, updated FMC and lots more stuff I promise!

Dan :)

Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games

816. Re: BLD solve in 27 seconds?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 11:53:03 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > No, he wasn't there. > > Macky Well, so much for all the anticipatory gun-play... thanks for the update. Mike
817. EC 2006 ... some rumors :)
From: cycastel <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 13:07:47 -0000

Hi !
There have been some rumors about the next European championship on
the French forum. Here is a message from Mr Karpiel, president of
Winning Moves France group (they organised last french champs) :

"Il y aura bien un championnat de France 2006, comme d'habitude un
vendredi de la deuxième quinzaine d'avril au Novotel les Halles à
Paris (bloquez déjà ces vendredis).
Il y aura également un championnat d'Europe à Paris à l'automne 2006.
J'aimerais bien que ce soit à la Cité des Sciences à La Villette,
mais ce n'est pas encore acquis.
La date reste à préciser, entre début septembre et début novembre
2006. Ce sera un week-end."
T .KARPIEL, Président de Winning Moves .

I reported above the original french message, but here is a
translation :
"French championship will be organised in 2006, as usual on a Friday,
late April, in Novotel les Halles in Paris.
There will be as well European Championship in Paris (fall 2006). I
would like it to take place at the Cité des Sciences in La Villette,
but it has not been confirmed yet.
The date has not been fixed either, this will be a week-end between
early September and early November."
T. Karpiel, President of Winning Moves

here is a link to the cité des sciences http://www.cite-sciences.fr
Wait and see, we'll keep the community informed if anything is
confirmed :)

cyril





818. Re: [Speed cubing group] Hungarian Nationals
From: "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 13:12:29 +0000

It was definitely a great weekend. I had so much fun and I'm sure everyone else did too! I was impressed with how well organised the Hungarian competition was. There must have been quite a lot of pre-competition publicity as there were well over 100 competitors in total. I think I heard the number 130? This is far more than any other competition I've been to (other than Worlds 2005 of course). Also, as the competition and the cube show was staged in the middle of a shopping centre it meant that there were lots of general spectators, i.e. not just other cubers in the audience. BTW, my proudest moment was beating both Dan *and* Stefan in a 3x3x3 race on stage during the cube show! ;) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com On Tue, 22 Nov 2005 11:37:38 -0000, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...> said: > > Hi all, > I just got back from the Hungarian Nationals which you may or > may not > have seen media about. > It was a fantastically well organised event, and the aim of the > competition was to bring the cube back into peoples minds in > Hungary, > and also to try and break the old Hungarian Record. The event > accomplished both goals, with several records broken and a best > time > of 18.21 (I think thats right). > We then took part in the "Kocka Show" afterwards and showed off > lots > of different skills, Stefan and I did team-blindfold solving, > and also > blindfolded - where Stefan successfully solved followed by > tumultuous > applause; and Jasmine, Stefan and I took part in lots of races > of all > sorts with the Hungarians. I also beat Stefan by less than 0.5 > seconds > on the 4x4x4, bad luck mate! My proudest moment was setting the > fastest time of the day on stage, 15.87. > I also set an 11.24 seconds solve while being solved by a TV > news > crew, so I am looking forward to seeing the video of that. It > was > scrambled by Stefan and timed on his stopwatch, so I guess the > time > maybe inaccurate, but we will be able to tell from the video :) > The city was also beautiful (Budapest), and the Hungarians were > very friendly and welcoming to all. > If the European Championship of 2006 will be held in Budapest, > then I > think it would be a superb event. Because the cube a national > treasure, there is SO SO much more interest within the Hungarian > public, the crowds that turned up were even bigger than at the > World > Champs! And the media guys did a great job of publicising the > event, > and making sure it ran smoothly. > I will definitely be voting for EC2006 in Hungary. > I've almost sorted my webhosting out now, so when it's back up I > will > add pics from DCD2005, WC2005, and Hungarian Nationals as well > as > reports for all, updated FMC and lots more stuff I promise! > Dan :) > > SPONSORED LINKS > > [1]Jigsaw puzzle game [2]Free puzzle inlay games [3]Educational > game and puzzle > [4]Word puzzle game [5]Kid puzzle game [6]Puzzle games > ___________________________________________________________ > > YAHOO! Groups is subject to the [9]Yahoo! Terms > of Service. > ___________________________________________________________ > > References > > 1. > http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=irjrM9wdJDBnytECiSfUCw > 2. > http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=5IEF0wvHk31uvuXI6ReWEw > 3. > http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=37T2K_4zOte4R94IVKMFNQ > 4. > http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Word+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=3DsIilZKH4dSS_WgIx9QRg > 5. > http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Kid+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=2-DgzSlkRkTyIak1hdhkgQ > 6. > http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=EJHY58oeC85Up2uB7KhBMA > 7. http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube > 8. > mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscribe > 9. http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/ -- http://www.fastmail.fm - Same, same, but different

----- Original Message ----- From: "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, November 22, 2005 2:12 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Hungarian Nationals It was definitely a great weekend. I had so much fun and I'm sure everyone else did too! I was impressed with how well organised the Hungarian competition was. There must have been quite a lot of pre-competition publicity as there were well over 100 competitors in total. I think I heard the number 130? This is far more than any other competition I've been to (other than Worlds 2005 of course). BTW, my proudest moment was beating both Dan *and* Stefan in a 3x3x3 race on stage during the cube show! ;) O, sancta simpliticas! 823. Re: Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 16:13:13 -0000

I really think it would be fantastic if we could order some for Christmas, but that may be a bit too optimistic. Nonetheless, I'm going to have to get one ASAP. As for times, my gut feeling is to say that if the cubes turn well, 5 minutes will be hit by many of the top cubers pretty quickly. Just a quick look at the data suggests that if you compare fastest time to number of pieces, then extrapolate the number of pieces needed to be placed on the 6x6x6 cube, I get that a world record time may be around 4:02 . I would certainly not be surprised if this was high though! -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > Heya, > > Looking at Olympic Cubes' site and messages on Twisty it won't take > very long anymore for the 6x6x6 to be available for the public. > Personally I'm very excited about trying it out. > Does anybody has an idea about how it's going to be released? Will we > be able to order it off the Olympic Cubes site? > > Also will the upcoming tournaments have 6x6x6 events? What will the > top times be like for the 6x6x6 after say 2 months of it's release? > > Discuss :D > > Greets, Koen >
824. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
From: Douglas Reed <dougreed@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 10:24:16 -0600

This talk of potential world records on 6x6x6 cubes reminds me of a conversation I had with Per in Florida at the WC. Do most people who plan on buying 6x6x6 cubes plan on using the same method as they do for smaller cubes (4x4x4 and 5x5x4) on the 6x6x4? It seems to me that as the cubes get larger, the widely-accepted Centers-Edges-3x3x3-Parity approach gets less and less efficient. What does everyone else think? Doug Daniel Hayes wrote: >I really think it would be fantastic if we could order some for >Christmas, but that may be a bit too optimistic. Nonetheless, I'm >going to have to get one ASAP. As for times, my gut feeling is to say >that if the cubes turn well, 5 minutes will be hit by many of the top >cubers pretty quickly. Just a quick look at the data suggests that if >you compare fastest time to number of pieces, then extrapolate the >number of pieces needed to be placed on the 6x6x6 cube, I get that a >world record time may be around 4:02 . I would certainly not be >surprised if this was high though! > >-Daniel > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" ><allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > >>Heya, >> >>Looking at Olympic Cubes' site and messages on Twisty it won't take >>very long anymore for the 6x6x6 to be available for the public. >>Personally I'm very excited about trying it out. >>Does anybody has an idea about how it's going to be released? Will we >>be able to order it off the Olympic Cubes site? >> >>Also will the upcoming tournaments have 6x6x6 events? What will the >>top times be like for the 6x6x6 after say 2 months of it's release? >> >>Discuss :D >> >>Greets, Koen >> >> >> > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > >
825. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
From: Frank Morris <ephem825@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 08:40:48 -0800 (PST)

I imagine, that with time, the record for the 6x6x6 may get to be around 3 minutes. It looks as though the puzzles gain about a minute per solution as the sizes increase. Just my opinion though. As far as the popular solution method for the larger cubes, I don't believe that it gets any less efficient. There is still room for improvement with that method. Douglas Reed <dougreed@...> wrote: This talk of potential world records on 6x6x6 cubes reminds me of a conversation I had with Per in Florida at the WC. Do most people who plan on buying 6x6x6 cubes plan on using the same method as they do for smaller cubes (4x4x4 and 5x5x4) on the 6x6x4? It seems to me that as the cubes get larger, the widely-accepted Centers-Edges-3x3x3-Parity approach gets less and less efficient. What does everyone else think? Doug Daniel Hayes wrote: >I really think it would be fantastic if we could order some for >Christmas, but that may be a bit too optimistic. Nonetheless, I'm >going to have to get one ASAP. As for times, my gut feeling is to say >that if the cubes turn well, 5 minutes will be hit by many of the top >cubers pretty quickly. Just a quick look at the data suggests that if >you compare fastest time to number of pieces, then extrapolate the >number of pieces needed to be placed on the 6x6x6 cube, I get that a >world record time may be around 4:02 . I would certainly not be >surprised if this was high though! > >-Daniel > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" ><allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > >>Heya, >> >>Looking at Olympic Cubes' site and messages on Twisty it won't take >>very long anymore for the 6x6x6 to be available for the public. >>Personally I'm very excited about trying it out. >>Does anybody has an idea about how it's going to be released? Will we >>be able to order it off the Olympic Cubes site? >> >>Also will the upcoming tournaments have 6x6x6 events? What will the >>top times be like for the 6x6x6 after say 2 months of it's release? >> >>Discuss :D >> >>Greets, Koen >> >> >> > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 826. Questions about championships (US and World)
From: "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 16:52:26 -0000

All --

This might not be the right forum, but I have a couple curious
questions about the various championships.

- I saw various country championships that occurred before the WC2005,
with the country winners often getting a trip to WC2005. Was there a
US championship in 2005? (I see that there was one in 2004).

- Why are the world championships every other year? It seems like the
momentum around cubing is increasing, could having a WC every year
help grow the momentum? Especially if a TV deal (for WC and/or various
country championships) could eventually be worked out, but that's
another subject.

thanks for any info that helps sate my curiousity,

yeff

828. Re: [Speed cubing group] Hungarian Nationals
From: "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 18:43:04 +0000

Yeah, I was pretty surprised too! Basically I just had a really good smooth solve, and Dan and Stefan both had bad solves. I definitely remember Dan saying that he'd really stuffed something up during the solve (which is obviously true if I was beat him!). My normal average is ~30 seconds, but I was doing better than average last weekend and the majority of my solves on stage were sub-30s (ranging from 22s to 29s). Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com On Tue, 22 Nov 2005 20:23:02 +0530, "Sachin Shirwalkar" <sachinss@...> said: > Great hearing from all of u guys abt the hungarian nationals. > > Good to know that the cube is not being forgotten at its birthplace. > > And Jasmine how could you ever beat Dan and Stephen? Dont you avg like > 25 secs? What happened? Did those two doze off during the solve? :D > Congrats btw. > > Sachin. > > On 11/22/05, Jasmine Lee <speedcuber@...> wrote: > > It was definitely a great weekend. I had so much fun and I'm sure > > everyone else did too! > > > > I was impressed with how well organised the Hungarian competition was. > > There must have been quite a lot of pre-competition publicity as there > > were well over 100 competitors in total. I think I heard the number 130? > > This is far more than any other competition I've been to (other than > > Worlds 2005 of course). Also, as the competition and the cube show was > > staged in the middle of a shopping centre it meant that there were lots > > of general spectators, i.e. not just other cubers in the audience. > > > > BTW, my proudest moment was beating both Dan *and* Stefan in a 3x3x3 > > race on stage during the cube show! ;) > > > > Jasmine > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > > > > On Tue, 22 Nov 2005 11:37:38 -0000, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...> > > said: > > > > > > Hi all, > > > I just got back from the Hungarian Nationals which you may or > > > may not > > > have seen media about. > > > It was a fantastically well organised event, and the aim of the > > > competition was to bring the cube back into peoples minds in > > > Hungary, > > > and also to try and break the old Hungarian Record. The event > > > accomplished both goals, with several records broken and a best > > > time > > > of 18.21 (I think thats right). > > > We then took part in the "Kocka Show" afterwards and showed off > > > lots > > > of different skills, Stefan and I did team-blindfold solving, > > > and also > > > blindfolded - where Stefan successfully solved followed by > > > tumultuous > > > applause; and Jasmine, Stefan and I took part in lots of races > > > of all > > > sorts with the Hungarians. I also beat Stefan by less than 0.5 > > > seconds > > > on the 4x4x4, bad luck mate! My proudest moment was setting the > > > fastest time of the day on stage, 15.87. > > > I also set an 11.24 seconds solve while being solved by a TV > > > news > > > crew, so I am looking forward to seeing the video of that. It > > > was > > > scrambled by Stefan and timed on his stopwatch, so I guess the > > > time > > > maybe inaccurate, but we will be able to tell from the video :) > > > The city was also beautiful (Budapest), and the Hungarians were > > > very friendly and welcoming to all. > > > If the European Championship of 2006 will be held in Budapest, > > > then I > > > think it would be a superb event. Because the cube a national > > > treasure, there is SO SO much more interest within the Hungarian > > > public, the crowds that turned up were even bigger than at the > > > World > > > Champs! And the media guys did a great job of publicising the > > > event, > > > and making sure it ran smoothly. > > > I will definitely be voting for EC2006 in Hungary. > > > I've almost sorted my webhosting out now, so when it's back up I > > > will > > > add pics from DCD2005, WC2005, and Hungarian Nationals as well > > > as > > > reports for all, updated FMC and lots more stuff I promise! > > > Dan :) > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > > > > > [1]Jigsaw puzzle game [2]Free puzzle inlay games [3]Educational > > > game and puzzle > > > [4]Word puzzle game [5]Kid puzzle game [6]Puzzle games > > > ___________________________________________________________ > > > > > > YAHOO! From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@...>

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 19:02:47 -0000

I just saw a post on fazed.net about a guy who made a picture of mario
(as in super mario bros) using Rubik's cubes. The link to a
description is here:
http://www.boingboing.net/2005/10/22/pixelart_mario_made_.html
and a direct link to a picture is here:
http://www.sixspace.com/gallery/invader2005/preview/mariodiv.jpg

Pretty cool stuff!

831. Re: Algorithm in QTM
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 19:07:59 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > How long does this take in QTM? > > L' F2 U2 B2 D F' U2 L D2 L2 B R F2 D2 U2 L' U2 F U' R' > > It's 20 moves in HTM and at least 22 moves in QTM but my machine has been going for > several days now without deciding whether it can be done in 22 moves or not. The above > algorithm has a lot of half turns, so maybe it will take more than 22 moves in QTM. If so it > will take at least as many moves as superflip in both QTM and HTM (and maybe more in > QTM). > It's finally done testing 22 moves out and no solution so it's at least 24 moves (QTM). My machine is struggling now so I can't test it to 26 moves. Anyway, this is at least as far out as superflip in both QTM and HTM.
832. Cubing with Dan Knights

Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 19:19:02 -0000

Hey everyone,

I recently got to get together with Dan Knights at the Duke Math Meet,
where he had brought some of his students to compete.

We had a really cool time hanging out and cubing. Someone took a few
pictures of us while we were cubing too.

I wrote a short report, with a couple pictures too.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/cubing2005nov.html

Have fun,
Chris

Really ? I normally always watch "On a tout essayé" saturdays except the last week-end. I would also be interested in seeing it! Sven --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Hello, > > I've heard from many people that Jean Pons was on the French > television France 2 this week-end. > Has anybody got the video ? > I'd like to see it. > > Thank you :-) >
843. [Speed cubing group] Re: Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 21:44:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Frank Morris <ephem825@y...> wrote: > > I imagine, that with time, the record for the 6x6x6 may get to be around 3 minutes. It looks as though the puzzles gain about a minute per solution as the sizes increase. Just my opinion though. As far as the popular solution method for the larger cubes, I don't believe that it gets any less efficient. There is still room for improvement with that method. > There are two problems with this (as a general rule for larger cubes): 1. The number of pieces increases quadratically with the side length, not linearly, so it's not likely that the times would increase linearly (plus you only have 2 steps for this basis 3->4 and 4->5, unless you can solve the 2x2x2 in negative time!) The centres are the main limiting factor (the quadratic factor) - in the 3x3x3 there are 6*1^2 centres (but nothing to do if not marked) but in the 4x4x4 there are 6*2^2=24 centres in the 5x5x5 there are 6*3^2 centres (48 if you don't count the very centres) but ther's 6*4^2=96 centres in a 6x6x6. This is probably why centres first is often used on these puzzles. There's a higher degree of freedom for the longest part which gives more speed. The edges (linear) and corners (constant) require less time so it's best to do them with more constraints. Doing the centres last puts more constraints on the largest part of the puzzle. 2. It is harder to locate pieces. Admittedly, this isn't really an issue for 6x6x6 - it does become an issue in the really big cubes though. Try finding centre pieces on a cube of size 11x11x11 or bigger! This really slows things down on larger cubes. I'd imagine there's a further problem which is that the cube is probably less stable and more likely to break up/lock up at speed. The pieces will be smaller and even if the overlap problem is solved an increase in the number of slices means the cube is more likely to jam. If each slice is just a little off then things will build up quicker. This is only a problem for physical cubes, not computer cubes (for which the closest thing is a bad mouse) although 1, 2 apply equally to each. > Douglas Reed <dougreed@h...> wrote: This talk of potential world records on 6x6x6 cubes reminds me of a > conversation I had with Per in Florida at the WC. > > Do most people who plan on buying 6x6x6 cubes plan on using the same > method as they do for smaller cubes (4x4x4 and 5x5x4) on the 6x6x4? It > seems to me that as the cubes get larger, the widely-accepted > Centers-Edges-3x3x3-Parity approach gets less and less efficient. What > does everyone else think? > > Doug > > Daniel Hayes wrote: > > >I really think it would be fantastic if we could order some for > >Christmas, but that may be a bit too optimistic. Nonetheless, I'm > >going to have to get one ASAP. As for times, my gut feeling is to say > >that if the cubes turn well, 5 minutes will be hit by many of the top > >cubers pretty quickly. Just a quick look at the data suggests that if > >you compare fastest time to number of pieces, then extrapolate the > >number of pieces needed to be placed on the 6x6x6 cube, I get that a > >world record time may be around 4:02 . I would certainly not be > >surprised if this was high though! > > > >-Daniel > > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" > ><allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > > > > >>Heya, > >> > >>Looking at Olympic Cubes' site and messages on Twisty it won't take > >>very long anymore for the 6x6x6 to be available for the public. > >>Personally I'm very excited about trying it out. > >>Does anybody has an idea about how it's going to be released? Will we > >>be able to order it off the Olympic Cubes site? > >> > >>Also will the upcoming tournaments have 6x6x6 events? What will the > >>top times be like for the 6x6x6 after say 2 months of it's release? > >> > >>Discuss :D > >> > >>Greets, Koen > >> > >> > >> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! FareChase - Search multiple travel sites in one click. > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] >
844. [Speed cubing group] Re: Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
