845. Re: Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 21:52:03 -0000

There is another practical problem. If the cube is expensive, and replacement parts are not available, what happens if by speedcubing you break it? You would need to make replacement parts if the internals are as delicate as they sound, and if those are expensive you have a whole other issue. Either way I will buy a 6x6x6 as I hope they hold up for speedcubing. Also, will the 10 minute time limit be kept? If so, I imagine not many people would compete, other than top level big cube people who have a fast solution with lots of practice. The 6x6x6 isn't as open to new people who have just figured it out. I mean is that just the nature of the puzzle, or should we extend the time limits? Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Frank Morris <ephem825@y...> wrote: > > > > I imagine, that with time, the record for the 6x6x6 may get to be around 3 minutes. It > looks as though the puzzles gain about a minute per solution as the sizes increase. Just > my opinion though. As far as the popular solution method for the larger cubes, I don't > believe that it gets any less efficient. There is still room for improvement with that > method. > > > > There are two problems with this (as a general rule for larger cubes): > > 1. The number of pieces increases quadratically with the side length, not linearly, so it's > not likely that the times would increase linearly (plus you only have 2 steps for this basis > 3->4 and 4->5, unless you can solve the 2x2x2 in negative time!) The centres are the > main limiting factor (the quadratic factor) - in the 3x3x3 there are 6*1^2 centres (but > nothing to do if not marked) but in the 4x4x4 there are 6*2^2=24 centres in the 5x5x5 > there are 6*3^2 centres (48 if you don't count the very centres) but ther's 6*4^2=96 > centres in a 6x6x6. This is probably why centres first is often used on these puzzles. > There's a higher degree of freedom for the longest part which gives more speed. The > edges (linear) and corners (constant) require less time so it's best to do them with more > constraints. Doing the centres last puts more constraints on the largest part of the puzzle. > > 2. It is harder to locate pieces. Admittedly, this isn't really an issue for 6x6x6 - it does > become an issue in the really big cubes though. Try finding centre pieces on a cube of size > 11x11x11 or bigger! This really slows things down on larger cubes. > > I'd imagine there's a further problem which is that the cube is probably less stable and > more likely to break up/lock up at speed. The pieces will be smaller and even if the > overlap problem is solved an increase in the number of slices means the cube is more > likely to jam. If each slice is just a little off then things will build up quicker. This is only a > problem for physical cubes, not computer cubes (for which the closest thing is a bad > mouse) although 1, 2 apply equally to each. > > > Douglas Reed <dougreed@h...> wrote: This talk of potential world records on 6x6x6 > cubes reminds me of a > > conversation I had with Per in Florida at the WC. > > > > Do most people who plan on buying 6x6x6 cubes plan on using the same > > method as they do for smaller cubes (4x4x4 and 5x5x4) on the 6x6x4? It > > seems to me that as the cubes get larger, the widely-accepted > > Centers-Edges-3x3x3-Parity approach gets less and less efficient. What > > does everyone else think? > > > > Doug > > > > Daniel Hayes wrote: > > > > >I really think it would be fantastic if we could order some for > > >Christmas, but that may be a bit too optimistic. Nonetheless, I'm > > >going to have to get one ASAP. As for times, my gut feeling is to say > > >that if the cubes turn well, 5 minutes will be hit by many of the top > > >cubers pretty quickly. Just a quick look at the data suggests that if > > >you compare fastest time to number of pieces, then extrapolate the > > >number of pieces needed to be placed on the 6x6x6 cube, I get that a > > >world record time may be around 4:02 . I would certainly not be > > >surprised if this was high though! > > > > > >-Daniel > > > > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" > > ><allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > > > > > > > >>Heya, > > >> > > >>Looking at Olympic Cubes' site and messages on Twisty it won't take > > >>very long anymore for the 6x6x6 to be available for the public. > > >>Personally I'm very excited about trying it out. > > >>Does anybody has an idea about how it's going to be released? 848. Re: [Speed cubing group] Hungarian Nationals
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 00:04:10 -0000

Hehe ... Im sure it was a great time there in Hungary. The norwegian press also published that a new world record was set as u might have seen from a link in earlier post here :-P It's insane the lack of knowledge and interest the norwegian press shows with cubing. They claimed they just used the text they got with a photo from a news agency. So much for press research ;-) Half a minute w google would have told them otherwise. A good thing coming from my contact with the press after reading that is that they told me to contact them again if i should go to future competitions ;-) It seems to be the case that the "poorer" the country is hosting cubing competitions the greater the organisation actually is. Ron was very overwhelmed by the competition in Poland earlier this autumn. And now a great competition in Hungary. Well Hungary is the home of the inventor of the 3x3x3 Rubik's Cube so i guess it's only expected. Dan and Jasmine, were u sponsored to go to this event? If so i'm very jealous :-o Anyway, back to my writing up my thesis :D Have fun! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@f...> wrote: > > It was definitely a great weekend. I had so much fun and I'm sure > everyone else did too! > > I was impressed with how well organised the Hungarian competition was. > There must have been quite a lot of pre-competition publicity as there > were well over 100 competitors in total. I think I heard the number 130? > This is far more than any other competition I've been to (other than > Worlds 2005 of course). Also, as the competition and the cube show was > staged in the middle of a shopping centre it meant that there were lots > of general spectators, i.e. not just other cubers in the audience. > > BTW, my proudest moment was beating both Dan *and* Stefan in a 3x3x3 > race on stage during the cube show! ;) > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > On Tue, 22 Nov 2005 11:37:38 -0000, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> > said: > > > > Hi all, > > I just got back from the Hungarian Nationals which you may or > > may not > > have seen media about. > > It was a fantastically well organised event, and the aim of the > > competition was to bring the cube back into peoples minds in > > Hungary, > > and also to try and break the old Hungarian Record. The event > > accomplished both goals, with several records broken and a best > > time > > of 18.21 (I think thats right). > > We then took part in the "Kocka Show" afterwards and showed off > > lots > > of different skills, Stefan and I did team-blindfold solving, > > and also > > blindfolded - where Stefan successfully solved followed by > > tumultuous > > applause; and Jasmine, Stefan and I took part in lots of races > > of all > > sorts with the Hungarians. I also beat Stefan by less than 0.5 > > seconds > > on the 4x4x4, bad luck mate! My proudest moment was setting the > > fastest time of the day on stage, 15.87. > > I also set an 11.24 seconds solve while being solved by a TV > > news > > crew, so I am looking forward to seeing the video of that. It > > was > > scrambled by Stefan and timed on his stopwatch, so I guess the > > time > > maybe inaccurate, but we will be able to tell from the video :) > > The city was also beautiful (Budapest), and the Hungarians were > > very friendly and welcoming to all. > > If the European Championship of 2006 will be held in Budapest, > > then I > > think it would be a superb event. Because the cube a national > > treasure, there is SO SO much more interest within the Hungarian > > public, the crowds that turned up were even bigger than at the > > World > > Champs! And the media guys did a great job of publicising the > > event, > > and making sure it ran smoothly. > > I will definitely be voting for EC2006 in Hungary. > > I've almost sorted my webhosting out now, so when it's back up I > > will > > add pics from DCD2005, WC2005, and Hungarian Nationals as well > > as > > reports for all, updated FMC and lots more stuff I promise! > > Dan :) > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > > > [1]Jigsaw puzzle game [2]Free puzzle inlay games [3]Educational > > game and puzzle > > [4]Word puzzle game [5]Kid puzzle game [6]Puzzle games > > ___________________________________________________________ > > > > YAHOO! 850. Re: Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 00:25:35 -0000

Hi! if it will be possible to buy the 6x6x6 olympicube somewhere online i will buy 2pieces assuming price is less then $100. If the price is higher i have to consider how much i really need to have 2. Anyhow i'm afraid they won't be around for too long after release and will become collector's items. But i could be wrong also. Maybe it's actually a good idea to have Mefferts or Seventowns/Winning moves take over the manufacturing/distribution of the cube? These companies have quite a solid economy and will assure that the cube can be produced for a prolonged time. Anyhow i guess that if the cube turns well a single time of less than 3 minutes will be achieved after a while. I can see that might happen with my method if the blocks come up nicely :-) As for parity it pretty much depends on which method u are going to use. Treating edges "singularly" and not as "quedges" or "3x3x3 edges" i will have 2 parities for my method. For the common pairing-up method there will also be 2 parities after all the "quedges" have come together. Getting the last few quedges together might prove quite cumbersome though. I guess one needs to resort to pure 3-cycles or other tricks. A "quedge" can be flipped with the well know algorithm from the 4x4x4 cube simply treating the 6x6x6 cube as a 4x4x4 cube (1-2-2- 1). I hope that should make sense to everyone. This also means there will be algs fixing both parities in one go, again treating the cube 1-2-2-1. What i suspect becomes more cumbersome in general as cube size increases is to find (recognise) edges for pairing up. Again i could be wrong. Just because i find it awkward doesn't mean everyone finds it awkward. Anyhow it will be interesting to see how my method (cage) and the reductionist approach (centers first, pairing up edges) will compare timewise :-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > There is another practical problem. If the cube is expensive, and > replacement parts are not available, what happens if by speedcubing > you break it? > > You would need to make replacement parts if the internals are as > delicate as they sound, and if those are expensive you have a whole > other issue. > > Either way I will buy a 6x6x6 as I hope they hold up for speedcubing. > > Also, will the 10 minute time limit be kept? If so, I imagine not > many people would compete, other than top level big cube people who > have a fast solution with lots of practice. > > The 6x6x6 isn't as open to new people who have just figured it out. I > mean is that just the nature of the puzzle, or should we extend the > time limits? > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Frank Morris > <ephem825@y...> wrote: > > > > > > I imagine, that with time, the record for the 6x6x6 may get to be > around 3 minutes. It > > looks as though the puzzles gain about a minute per solution as the > sizes increase. Just > > my opinion though. As far as the popular solution method for the > larger cubes, I don't > > believe that it gets any less efficient. There is still room for > improvement with that > > method. > > > > > > > There are two problems with this (as a general rule for larger cubes): > > > > 1. The number of pieces increases quadratically with the side > length, not linearly, so it's > > not likely that the times would increase linearly (plus you only > have 2 steps for this basis > > 3->4 and 4->5, unless you can solve the 2x2x2 in negative time!) The > centres are the > > main limiting factor (the quadratic factor) - in the 3x3x3 there are > 6*1^2 centres (but > > nothing to do if not marked) but in the 4x4x4 there are 6*2^2=24 > centres in the 5x5x5 > > there are 6*3^2 centres (48 if you don't count the very centres) but > ther's 6*4^2=96 > > centres in a 6x6x6. This is probably why centres first is often used > on these puzzles. > > There's a higher degree of freedom for the longest part which gives > more speed. The > > edges (linear) and corners (constant) require less time so it's best > to do them with more > > constraints. Doing the centres last puts more constraints on the > largest part of the puzzle. > > > > 2. It is harder to locate pieces. Admittedly, this isn't really an > issue for 6x6x6 - it does > > become an issue in the really big cubes though. Try finding centre > pieces on a cube of size > > 11x11x11 or bigger! This really slows things down on larger cubes. > > > > I'd imagine there's a further problem which is that the cube is > probably less stable and > > more likely to break up/lock up at speed. The pieces will be smaller > and even if the > > overlap problem is solved an increase in the number of slices means > the cube is more > > likely to jam. If each slice is just a little off then things will > build up quicker. This is only a > > problem for physical cubes, not computer cubes (for which the > closest thing is a bad > > mouse) although 1, 2 apply equally to each. > > > > > Douglas Reed <dougreed@h...> wrote: This talk of potential world > records on 6x6x6 > > cubes reminds me of a > > > conversation I had with Per in Florida at the WC. > > > > > > Do most people who plan on buying 6x6x6 cubes plan on using the same > > > method as they do for smaller cubes (4x4x4 and 5x5x4) on the > 6x6x4? It > > > seems to me that as the cubes get larger, the widely-accepted > > > Centers-Edges-3x3x3-Parity approach gets less and less efficient. > What > > > does everyone else think? > > > > > > Doug > > > > > > Daniel Hayes wrote: > > > > > > >I really think it would be fantastic if we could order some for > > > >Christmas, but that may be a bit too optimistic. Nonetheless, I'm > > > >going to have to get one ASAP. As for times, my gut feeling is to say > > > >that if the cubes turn well, 5 minutes will be hit by many of the top > > > >cubers pretty quickly. Just a quick look at the data suggests > that if > > > >you compare fastest time to number of pieces, then extrapolate the > > > >number of pieces needed to be placed on the 6x6x6 cube, I get that a > > > >world record time may be around 4:02 . I would certainly not be > > > >surprised if this was high though! > > > > > > > >-Daniel > > > > > > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" > > > ><allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > >>Heya, > > > >> > > > >>Looking at Olympic Cubes' site and messages on Twisty it won't take > > > >>very long anymore for the 6x6x6 to be available for the public. > > > >>Personally I'm very excited about trying it out. > > > >>Does anybody has an idea about how it's going to be released? > Will we > > > >>be able to order it off the Olympic Cubes site? > > > >> > > > >>Also will the upcoming tournaments have 6x6x6 events? What will the > > > >>top times be like for the 6x6x6 after say 2 months of it's release? > > > >> > > > >>Discuss :D > > > >> > > > >>Greets, Koen > > > >> > > > >> > > > >> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational > game and puzzle > > Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > > > > > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of > Service. > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > > Yahoo! FareChase - Search multiple travel sites in one click. > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > >
851. 5x5x5 speed solving
From: "washyourmonkey" <washyourmonkey@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 04:20:39 -0000

Does anyone know how to make a 5x5x5 turn more easily? ive tried
lubing it and that helped a little but its still to hard to turn.





852. Re: 5x5x5 speed solving
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 05:07:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "washyourmonkey" <washyourmonkey@y...> wrote: > > Does anyone know how to make a 5x5x5 turn more easily? ive tried > lubing it and that helped a little but its still to hard to turn. Ask Per Fredlund to describe what exactly to sand. I think he mentioned Grant Tregay's method for sanding down the inside bits of the outer edge pieces. Wait for him to post to make sure, but I think that's it. -Mike team [zb]

Are there any cubers from Marin County? The Marin Independent Journal
is looking for someone to interview.

Tyson Mao

854. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC 2005 Report
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 05:25:10 -0000

Hi! Geocities has very low allocated bandwidths. Once a page there becomes really popular there it's as good as impossible to get access to it. Only good thing about geocities is that it is free and they have some tools to build ur homepage. But only use it if u don't expect many visitors ... sorry Jon :-o Cheers! -Per PS! Im not sure whether geocities has options to pay for more bandwidth. 857. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC 2005 Report
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 06:59:25 -0000

Umm ... On their site they say the following : "Furthermore, among many other great features, the Parcom 750 offers a generous amount of bandwidth--up to 30 gigabytes per month. Plus the setup is FREE!" This is not exactly unlimited but much higher than the geocities' free solution which offers 3 GB/month. Hosting pictures/galleries greatly increases the bandwidth. Use of thumbnails is a good idea :-) This makes me wonder what size webhosts consider to be unlimited bandwidth. Do domain hosts that offer TRUE unlimited bandwidths really exist?? I recall last yearr speedcubing.com hit the roof on its bandwidth due to hosting a rather large video. I think this was sorted out by deleting the video and opting for a more expensive package. Have fun! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > I use parcom.net. $3.95/month or so with 750MB file storage and > unlimited bandwith. > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Ok ... > > > > So they do offer Plus and Pro packages now. I get the same message if I > > try > > > to > > > > access it directly from your homepage. Have you moved the report? > > > > > > > > Jasmine > > > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > > > > > > > > > > On Tue, 15 Nov 2005 18:44:11 -0000, "nascarjon2001" > > > > <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> said: > > > > > > > > > > Hi all, > > > > > I don't normally write up reports on things, but for some > > > > > reason > > > > > this time I felt like doing one. 858. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC 2005 Report
From: "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 07:08:47 +0000

I don't think it's a bandwidth issue, it's a 'page cannot be found' issue. I use geocities too so I know that it has low bandwidth limits. If the problem is just that the page has exceeded the bandwidth limit then the error message says so and tells the user to try again later. Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com On Wed, 23 Nov 2005 05:25:10 -0000, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...> said: > > Hi! > Geocities has very low allocated bandwidths. From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 23:45:09 -0800

Not at anything like these prices. The "unlimited bandwidth" thing is a
bit of a sham. There is no official limit, but if you start using "too
much", bad things will happen.

/Lars

> bandwidth. Do domain hosts that offer TRUE unlimited bandwidths
> really exist??

"The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open."
--- Frank Zappa

Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com



860. Xcross and opposite cross compliment eachother so well
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 07:49:46 -0000

Hey everyone,

I've been doing some thinking lately on these two strategies and
wanted to post about it.

I'm going to even rewrite my Xcross page to include this, as I
really really like it. I think people who use Xcross need to
seriously consider also using opposite cross.

I learned about opposite cross from Richard Patterson, and basically
I solve either a white or yellow cross. I know people think this
could be slower, but one of my 14's and I'm pretty sure my 12.xx at
the RWC2005 were done with opposite cross (yellow for me).

Also, here is some math that is very promising.

I do Xcross on a single face probably about 25% of the time. Since
I now solve opposite cross though, my odds for an Xcross is 25% for
yellow and also 25% for white. So I have an overall chance of 1-
(3/4)^2 = 7/16 = 43.75% chance of getting an Xcross.

I had recently noticed that I was getting Xcross solves much more
often than I used to, and the reason is I now have a 43% chance of
getting one rather than only 25% or so.

I know opinions vary on solving other colors, but I like opposite
cross since it keeps your F2L edges the same. Also it almost
doubles my chances of an Xcross right now, and that is seriously
helping my times.

Also it works under pressure, I had I think 3 opposite cross solves
in competition at the RWC, and I've used it at Caltech Dallas as
well.

So anyway, I'm going to include this on my Xcross site, but I wanted
to post here as I have definitely become a convert to opposite
cross. I am now definitely an opposite cross and Xcross solver :-)
(Richard, thanks so much for the opposite cross idea!!!) :-D

Chris





861. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC 2005 Report
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 00:20:34 -0800

Strangepuzzle.com averages about 20GB a month, but I have a maximum of 400GB a month transfer. -Chris On 11/22/05, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...> wrote: > > Ok ... > > So they do offer Plus and Pro packages now. The Pro package give u > ur own domain name pluss 2GB file storage and 100 GB/month bandwidth > for $8.95 month. I guess that is not bad but there are cheaper ones > out there with unlimited bandwidth ... To have a clue what bandwidth > might be needed ask Ron how much traffic there is on > www.speedcubing.com or those with other cubing sites :-) > > -Per > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
862. [Speed cubing group] Re: ... stackman and other nebish questions....plz reply
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 08:42:21 -0000

> > Just to take a philisophical turn, I do believe that some people
are
> > just meant to be better cubers for reasons like faster reflexes,
> > better visual spacial skills, etc.
>
> Otherwise, for the most part, pretty
> much anyone can be sub-20. Sub-15... is another story, and is like
the
> 3:50 mile.

I do agree that some of us just have more of a natural knack than
others at certain types of activities. Me personally, I am much
better at verbal-type games than spatial ones. (I wish my interests
were in the same direction as my abilities!)

For me, psychology is the major blocking point. If you find yourself
like me, in the below-average category for learning speedcubing,
you'll need to have proportionately more perseverence. Probably much
more. I just don't seem to have it. After several 50+ second solves
in a row, my mind goes berzerk. "Slow as molasses!" "I'm getting
worse!" "I can't even beat some 6-year-old kid from Korea!" and
that's it, I'm done for the day. At this point, I don't have the
mindset of a speedcuber, even if the potential is there.





863. Re: Xcross and opposite cross compliment eachother so well
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 11:09:31 -0000

I'm not an expert with the cross, but starting from either white or yellow (opposite side) is a Good Idea, since it does not really change the rest of the algorithm. That's why the standard color scheme is interesting. I used it as a fallback strategy, now starting with white or yellow does not matter anymore. More and more, the problem is to find a cube that does not look lucky. Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I've been doing some thinking lately on these two strategies and > wanted to post about it. > > I'm going to even rewrite my Xcross page to include this, as I > really really like it. I think people who use Xcross need to > seriously consider also using opposite cross. > > I learned about opposite cross from Richard Patterson, and basically > I solve either a white or yellow cross. I know people think this > could be slower, but one of my 14's and I'm pretty sure my 12.xx at > the RWC2005 were done with opposite cross (yellow for me). > > Also, here is some math that is very promising. > > I do Xcross on a single face probably about 25% of the time. Since > I now solve opposite cross though, my odds for an Xcross is 25% for > yellow and also 25% for white. So I have an overall chance of 1- > (3/4)^2 = 7/16 = 43.75% chance of getting an Xcross. > > I had recently noticed that I was getting Xcross solves much more > often than I used to, and the reason is I now have a 43% chance of > getting one rather than only 25% or so. > > I know opinions vary on solving other colors, but I like opposite > cross since it keeps your F2L edges the same. Also it almost > doubles my chances of an Xcross right now, and that is seriously > helping my times. > > Also it works under pressure, I had I think 3 opposite cross solves > in competition at the RWC, and I've used it at Caltech Dallas as > well. > > So anyway, I'm going to include this on my Xcross site, but I wanted > to post here as I have definitely become a convert to opposite > cross. I am now definitely an opposite cross and Xcross solver :-) > (Richard, thanks so much for the opposite cross idea!!!) :-D > > Chris >
864. Re: 5x5x5 speed solving
From: "rubikorkow" <calcdude@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 14:40:46 -0000

Its really just a matter of "wearing it down". Play with it for a month or so, and it will turn great in no time. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "washyourmonkey" <washyourmonkey@y...> wrote: > > Does anyone know how to make a 5x5x5 turn more easily? ive tried > lubing it and that helped a little but its still to hard to turn. >
865. Re: Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 14:49:48 -0000

I'll be surprised if the price tops $100 USD, but I guess it depends on how many they make and how big the demand is. If they become rare, I'm sure they'll fetch that and more on Ebay. As for speedcubing with it, the video on their site demonstrates the ability to "shortcut" single-layer and double-layer twists (i.e. turn R while U and/or U1 are misaligned). They also depict using the index finger to quickly twist the U face, as well as the U1 layer. So it seems that speedcubing would certainly be possible. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi! > > if it will be possible to buy the 6x6x6 olympicube somewhere online > i will buy 2pieces assuming price is less then $100.
866. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC 2005 Report
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 15:30:32 -0000


I somehow deleted the page. It's fixed now.

Jon

868. Re: [Speed cubing group] I won't say anything...
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 10:41:30 -0600

opposite cross method , and after only an hour of practice, getting
the cross and one CE pair is *faster* then than the old way for me!!!

serious speed.

872. Re: is a 4th dimesion cube worth anything? (pic)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 18:27:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@g...> wrote: > you have a picture of it? i think all of us (or at least just me) > would be interested in seeing how it looks. http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=71 For several years this was my only cube. It wasn't much good: it had nasty paper stickers, over-strong springs, and it was /very/ difficult to adjust the spring tension. I eventually recycled some of the pieces to make a 3x2x2... 4th Dimension cubes appear fairly regularly on eBay, but I can't rememember what they typically sell for. Sorry! Mike

874. Re: cross

877. Combination of Techniques...
From: "ericdstalter" <ericdstalter@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 21:41:01 -0000

I am a newer cuber, about 2-3 ago I realized the world of
speedcubing, at that point I timed myself and couldn't get any
faster than 5min, when lucky - I was using my method, very slow.

After looking at corners first, Fridrich, 2x2x3 build, etc I decided
that for the amount of time I had available some were to complicated.

So I use an intuitive Fridrich to get a 2x2x3 block, then use Lars
to orientate the edges and finish the rest of the cube. Eventually
I will probably use Fridrich to finish the LL.

The reason I tell you is I just got 5 solves in a row under a
minute, 2 of which under 50sec., only one was a lucky solve. I
pause alot to figure out my next move, once recognition sets in I
know I will reach 30sec, maybe faster.

To move any faster, I will eventually have to stick with one method,
but 'till then...

Keep Cubing

ERic





878. Combo of tech...part 2
From: "ericdstalter" <ericdstalter@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 21:42:17 -0000

starting with a 2x2x3 block means I only have a 3 piece cross - much
quicker


ERic

880. ROUX METHOD/CLL ALGS...
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 22:10:53 -0000

Hello Everyone


After completely switching to Gilles Roux's method, I have achieved a
sub 30 average in my first 3 weeks of practice. My Best ROUX solve is
21.21 sec.

(25.00), 26.87, 33.70, 27.28, 25.00, 26.05, 33.56, 32.90, 29.48,
33.65, 30.15, (34.28) AVG 29.86

It took me like 7 months to get sub 30 with CFOP, so I am pretty happy
with how well this system is working for me.

If I had to start all over, I would not learn OLL/PLL at all. I
would either learn CLL/ELL or I might have done a 3 look LL.
OLL and PLL is 78 algorithms if memory serves correct.
THis approach would be less. 46 ALgs for last layer.

1. Orient Edges (2 algs, 5/6 of the time)
2. COLL ( 40 algs, if im not mistaken)
3. Permute edges (4 algs, 11/12 of the time)

with ZBF2L, you could eliminate the first look entirely, for a very
fast LL. But all you team[zb] guys will soon prove this method to be
better than OLL/PLL.

Another good option is Petrus with COLL. If the corners are already
positioned, there are many cases to learn to do the LL in one
Algorithm (Step 6/7 index). All of these cases are comprised of 2
smaller, familiar sequences, making them easy to learn.

As is turns out, Im gonna go with Roux's method. But dont know too
many CLL algs yet. I dont use any CLL in my solves yet, I want to
wait until I have them all down. I Need CLL algs from anybody who can
help me out. I want to look for the shortest algs for each case.

Thank you,
and Im so sorry for rambling on...

Jason Kovacic
Kovacic81@...

882. Re: ROUX METHOD/CLL ALGS...
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 22:22:56 -0000

Fantastic! More roux solvers! I've just hit sub-30 and I'm on the trail to sub-20, 18, 15, etc. My best roux solve is 20.60 though ;) I found that omsetimes, my averages would be all over the place, but I'm settling down now. CLL is nice and I have about 40% of CLL/COLL learnt. the reason I've learnt some COLL is because I wanted to use the COLL recognition system, so I learnt a load of COLL cases to get used to it. Eventually I'll be using A full CLL. But that a way off yet. Plus, some COLL algs are nicer. D's and L's arn't too nice :S Yeah, I've been comprising a big list of CLL/COLL algs I use/will be using if you want it. I'll finish it and send you a copy. Oh, I'd still recommend learning PLL. It comes in so handy for BLD cubing. (Well, 3-cycles anyway). What I need is help with the first two blocks :S Any tips? Even my pair and insert (the last bit of the second one) is quite bad). We need some kind of F2B algorithm tables ;) Apart from that, try and nag gilles to update his site :) ~ThomKirjava --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > Hello Everyone > > > After completely switching to Gilles Roux's method, I have achieved a > sub 30 average in my first 3 weeks of practice. I > would either learn CLL/ELL or I might have done a 3 look LL. > OLL and PLL is 78 algorithms if memory serves correct. > THis approach would be less. 46 ALgs for last layer. > > 1. Orient Edges (2 algs, 5/6 of the time) > 2. COLL ( 40 algs, if im not mistaken) > 3. Permute edges (4 algs, 11/12 of the time) > > with ZBF2L, you could eliminate the first look entirely, for a very > fast LL. But all you team[zb] guys will soon prove this method to be > better than OLL/PLL. > > Another good option is Petrus with COLL. If the corners are already > positioned, there are many cases to learn to do the LL in one > Algorithm (Step 6/7 index). 883. Re: Xcross and opposite cross compliment eachother so well
From: "rubikorkow" <calcdude@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 22:48:59 -0000

I personally think that this method should be called the "fat fish"
method rather than just the Xcross method. This is because the result
of this method is basically a two-layer "fish". Who's with me?

Korkow

886. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Xcross and opposite cross compliment eachother so well
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 15:19:19 -0800

The major problem I've found with doing opposite cross are the corners. I've been training myself for a long time to able to recognize a corner from only two stickers, and if I switch to opposite cross the color schemes of the corners are all backwards, which slows me down considerably. -James Stuber _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Gilles Roux Sent: Wednesday, November 23, 2005 3:10 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Xcross and opposite cross compliment eachother so well I'm not an expert with the cross, but starting from either white or yellow (opposite side) is a Good Idea, since it does not really change the rest of the algorithm. That's why the standard color scheme is interesting. I used it as a fallback strategy, now starting with white or yellow does not matter anymore. More and more, the problem is to find a cube that does not look lucky. Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I've been doing some thinking lately on these two strategies and > wanted to post about it. > > I'm going to even rewrite my Xcross page to include this, as I > really really like it. I think people who use Xcross need to > seriously consider also using opposite cross. > > I learned about opposite cross from Richard Patterson, and basically > I solve either a white or yellow cross. I know people think this > could be slower, but one of my 14's and I'm pretty sure my 12.xx at > the RWC2005 were done with opposite cross (yellow for me). > > Also, here is some math that is very promising. > > I do Xcross on a single face probably about 25% of the time. Since > I now solve opposite cross though, my odds for an Xcross is 25% for > yellow and also 25% for white. So I have an overall chance of 1- > (3/4)^2 = 7/16 = 43.75% chance of getting an Xcross. > > I had recently noticed that I was getting Xcross solves much more > often than I used to, and the reason is I now have a 43% chance of > getting one rather than only 25% or so. > > I know opinions vary on solving other colors, but I like opposite > cross since it keeps your F2L edges the same. Also it almost > doubles my chances of an Xcross right now, and that is seriously > helping my times. > > Also it works under pressure, I had I think 3 opposite cross solves > in competition at the RWC, and I've used it at Caltech Dallas as > well. > > So anyway, I'm going to include this on my Xcross site, but I wanted > to post here as I have definitely become a convert to opposite > cross. I am now definitely an opposite cross and Xcross solver :-) > (Richard, thanks so much for the opposite cross idea!!!) :-D > > Chris > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+gam e&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+g ame&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=irjrM9wdJDBnytECiSfUCw > puzzle game Free <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzl e+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puz zle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=5IEF0wvHk31uvuXI6 ReWEw> puzzle inlay games Educational <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w1=Jigsaw+p uzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word +puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=37T2K_4zOte4R 94IVKMFNQ> game and puzzle Word <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Word+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game& w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+gam e&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=3DsIilZKH4dSS_WgIx9QRg> puzzle game Kid <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Kid+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w 2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game &w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=2-DgzSlkRkTyIak1hdhkgQ> puzzle game Puzzle <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=F ree+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5 =Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=EJHY58oeC85Up2uB7KhBMA> games _____ YAHOO! 887. Profile section on CS.co.uk
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 23:23:34 -0000

Hi everyone,

I am soon going to regenerate the profiles section of
cubestation.co.uk, it's going to be a lot easier for you to post your
profiles on my site and share your cubing CV with the rest of the
world.

It will work similar to the new UWR format, you send in your details,
or update your details, I approve it, and then the page goes live.

So I'm just asking you, what categories would you like to see?
Hopefully I can put up fields for most puzzle categories, so you could
also use it as a way of keeping track of your progress in speedcubing.

Tell me what you would like to see in the profiles section!

Dan :)





888. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: ROUX METHOD/CLL ALGS...
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 23:31:12 +0000 (GMT)

So..what's the difference between CLL and COLL? Pedro Bob Burton <bob@...> escreveu: The only CLL algs I know are the COLL algs on my page :P ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > Hello Everyone > > > After completely switching to Gilles Roux's method, I have achieved a > sub 30 average in my first 3 weeks of practice. My Best ROUX solve is > 21.21 sec. > > (25.00), 26.87, 33.70, 27.28, 25.00, 26.05, 33.56, 32.90, 29.48, > 33.65, 30.15, (34.28) AVG 29.86 > > It took me like 7 months to get sub 30 with CFOP, so I am pretty happy > with how well this system is working for me. > > If I had to start all over, I would not learn OLL/PLL at all. I > would either learn CLL/ELL or I might have done a 3 look LL. > OLL and PLL is 78 algorithms if memory serves correct. > THis approach would be less. 46 ALgs for last layer. > > 1. Orient Edges (2 algs, 5/6 of the time) > 2. COLL ( 40 algs, if im not mistaken) > 3. Permute edges (4 algs, 11/12 of the time) > > with ZBF2L, you could eliminate the first look entirely, for a very > fast LL. But all you team[zb] guys will soon prove this method to be > better than OLL/PLL. > > Another good option is Petrus with COLL. If the corners are already > positioned, there are many cases to learn to do the LL in one > Algorithm (Step 6/7 index). All of these cases are comprised of 2 > smaller, familiar sequences, making them easy to learn. > > As is turns out, Im gonna go with Roux's method. But dont know too > many CLL algs yet. I dont use any CLL in my solves yet, I want to > wait until I have them all down. I Need CLL algs from anybody who can > help me out. I want to look for the shortest algs for each case. > > Thank you, > and Im so sorry for rambling on... > > Jason Kovacic > Kovacic81@y... > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! 890. Re: Profile section on CS.co.uk

891. Re: ROUX METHOD/CLL ALGS...
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 00:22:04 -0000

It's great that more people are beginning to take an interest in the
Roux method. It's got so much potential, it just doesn't seem widely
known, yet.

I've recently begun learning ZBF2L intuitively (for the most part) in
an effort to better my times. I only really have 3 or so cases down
for sure, but it really works wonders for your times. I've also
recently finished learning the rest of COLL, which is a fantastic
system. My normal average is now between 20 and 21, with my best
times in the 14's. I recognize the cases the same way as on Gilles
Roux's site, so hopefully my advice will apply to you guys some.

I decided to take a few days off from ZB learning and devote time to
the Roux method. And despite not really working on it in months,
earlier today I averaged 20.11 (so close! XP) with a new best time of
15.67. I'm still using the second method for orienting and placing
the final edges, and I haven't learned any of the special shortened
cases. Also, there's really only one case where I use a CLL instead
of the COLL, just because that's what I know. Anyway, here are the
tips I've got.

For the 1x2x3 blocks: GO SLOWLY. Especially at first. It's easy to
get a good pace going for the first block with inspection and forget
to slow down for the second. It's important. Work at it.

Also, try to have several tricks for doing each block. Know how to
match a corner and edge and insert. Know how to insert an edge in any
of the three spots on each block, and know how to use block starts
like in the Petrus method.

For the corners: Don't learn them in the order on the Roux site.
Learn the T and U and L cases first. There are 5+1 reflection for the
first two, and 4+2 reflections for the last. I think this covers the
bulk of cases you run into. After that, it's up to you, but it will
be smoother sailing because you're more used to it.

Also, try to use everything you've learned all the time during
solving. Even the things you've only learned an hour before. Don't
worry about how long it takes you to remember the alg. Just do it.
The more you force yourself to actively use them, the better you will
get at them. Practice.

The final six edges is a very important step. Learn the algs to
orient the cases as well as you possibly can. They should be second
nature. You need to be able to perform the ones for the longest cases
(all edges oriented wrong) in under 3 seconds. Also, work on finding
good ways to place the UR and UL edges as you're finishing orienting
so that it becomes one fluid step. This may take a while (it was the
hardest part for me).

After you've got all this down, move on to the third method for
recognizing the last six edges, and learn the special cases. There
are only 26 or so, so it shouldn't be too bad. But sub 20 is
definitely possible without them, so don't give up.

-Mike
team [zb]

P.S. Wow. That's a long post. Oops...





892. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: ROUX METHOD/CLL ALGS...
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 16:23:33 -0800 (PST)

cll ignores edge orientation, so you will probably end up with bad edges after some sequences, then ell flips and positions them. Pedro <pedrosino1@...> wrote: So..what's the difference between CLL and COLL? Pedro Bob Burton <bob@...> escreveu: The only CLL algs I know are the COLL algs on my page :P ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > Hello Everyone > > > After completely switching to Gilles Roux's method, I have achieved a > sub 30 average in my first 3 weeks of practice. My Best ROUX solve is > 21.21 sec. > > (25.00), 26.87, 33.70, 27.28, 25.00, 26.05, 33.56, 32.90, 29.48, > 33.65, 30.15, (34.28) AVG 29.86 > > It took me like 7 months to get sub 30 with CFOP, so I am pretty happy > with how well this system is working for me. > > If I had to start all over, I would not learn OLL/PLL at all. I > would either learn CLL/ELL or I might have done a 3 look LL. > OLL and PLL is 78 algorithms if memory serves correct. > THis approach would be less. 46 ALgs for last layer. > > 1. Orient Edges (2 algs, 5/6 of the time) > 2. COLL ( 40 algs, if im not mistaken) > 3. Permute edges (4 algs, 11/12 of the time) > > with ZBF2L, you could eliminate the first look entirely, for a very > fast LL. But all you team[zb] guys will soon prove this method to be > better than OLL/PLL. > > Another good option is Petrus with COLL. If the corners are already > positioned, there are many cases to learn to do the LL in one > Algorithm (Step 6/7 index). All of these cases are comprised of 2 > smaller, familiar sequences, making them easy to learn. > > As is turns out, Im gonna go with Roux's method. But dont know too > many CLL algs yet. I dont use any CLL in my solves yet, I want to > wait until I have them all down. I Need CLL algs from anybody who can > help me out. I want to look for the shortest algs for each case. > > Thank you, > and Im so sorry for rambling on... > > Jason Kovacic > Kovacic81@y... > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 893. Left hand dexterity
From: "mrraaw" <mrraaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 00:25:25 -0000

I just recently received an email with a bunch of intresting facts.
One of the facts was - "The average person's left hand does 56% of the
typing." I was wondering if that connected to one handed cubing.
Maybe typing built up our left hand's dexterity. I know a lot of
cubers including myself are right handed but they use their left hand
for one handed solving.


Another intresting fact was nothing cube related but neat. -
"Stewardesses" is the longest word typed with only the left hand
and "lollipop" with your right. "

MATT

Also, If you pay attention to what you do on a daily basis, your left hand does all of the little tiny intricit things, that wake finness, and your right hand does all the major things...just think about everything, I've done it sometimes, and it's true... 898. Roux Method / Extended Cross
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 04:19:08 -0000

I think that for CFOP, the extended cross is always the way to go.

I would pretty much always start with a 2x2 block and then finish the
Xcross. Usually I could see a 2x2x1 Block and build it, and then
insert the last edge to make the 2x2. ANd THEN find the remaining 2
edges and put them in to finish the X-cross.

With the Roux method, you take it one step further. You build a 2x2x1
block, but instead of looking for just one edge to insert, you have to
find 2 pieces. Find an edge and a corner and pair them up an insert,
to make a 3x2x1 block. Or you can insert an edge or corner right
away, and then find and insert the other piece. Though i think that
this is slower...

Cross 4 pieces
2x2 Block 4 pieces
Extended Cross 6 pieces
Gille's Block 5 pieces

Its harder than a cross or petrus block, but easier than DIRECTLy
solving for X-cross.

FOR ALL YOU ROUX SOLVERS


For the 2nd Block, I always find the DR edge and insert as quickly as
possible. Then I just solve the 2 CE pairs with an all too familiar
F2L strategy.
Howerver, There are MANY shortcuts you can find by using the M slice.
A F2L style chart with algorithms would be twice as big for this
method. There are many more places that a Corner and an edge can be
simultaneously. I never used F2L charts to learn F2L. In ROUX and
F2L, I think that Intuition is better.

1. What color scheme do you guys use for ROux? I use white and yellow
blocks always, with red or orange on bottom.

2. How fast can you guys do step 4? Gilles told me that he uses
Method 2 as his main method, and that a 4.5 sec avg is possible with
this method alone. Im at about 7-8 Sec..



Jason Kovacic
kovacic81@...

PS.. I still need lots and lots of CLL algs....

902. Re: Roux Method / Extended Cross
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 08:08:43 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote:> > > 1. What color scheme do you guys use for ROux? I use white and yellow > blocks always, with red or orange on bottom. > > 2. How fast can you guys do step 4? Gilles told me that he uses > Method 2 as his main method, and that a 4.5 sec avg is possible with > this method alone. Im at about 7-8 Sec.. > > Jason Kovacic > kovacic81@y... > > PS.. I still need lots and lots of CLL algs.... 1. I solve white on bottom, yellow LL for my normal solving, so I just carried that over with the Roux method. I use the red and orange sides for my blocks about 98% of the time. There needs to be a fantastic start on blue and green for me to use them. 2. I can do it in under 6 usually, but it all depends on the case. I'd like to know the number of possible cases for the final six edges once they're all oriented correctly, because I think that may be a way to speed up the method. 3. Use COLL algs from wherever you find them, the www.speedcubing.com algs, the Helmstetter algs, or from this site: http://satorujnoda.hp.infoseek.co.jp/step3.html -Mike team [zb]

906. Fooling around and found
From: a_ooms75 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 11:30:23 -0000

I was playing with a PLL i dont like it was:
R U R' B2 R U' R' U' B2 U B2 U B2

perform like this:
R U R' y R2 y' R U' R' U' y R2 U R2 U R2

Did is the little change:
R U R' y R2 y' R U' R' d' R2 U R2 U R2
then to:
R U l' D2 l U' R' d' R2 U R2 U R2

I saw stefan his demo vid with his T-perm and start playing with it.
with this OLL:
B' (R' U' R U) B y' B' (R' U' R U) B (12/12)

and changed it to:
(R U R' U') (R' F R F' U2) (R U R' U') (R' F R F')(17/18)
its a bit longer but for me its faster to execute.

just wanna share my findings :)
maybe someone will like them.

Greets AO

908. Flip three edges with parity fixer on 4x4
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 12:03:46 -0000

Hey guys..

I was just playing around with the 4x4, and I found a nice way to
flip three edges while fixing the OLL parity on the 4x4. It's just
the normal parity fix:

(Rr)2 B2 U2 (Ll) U2 (Rr)' U2 (Rr) U2 F2 (Rr) F2 (Ll)' B2 (Rr)2

But when you add B'R' at the beginning, and RB at the end,
you 'flip' three edge groups. I am probably not the first person to
think about this, but I've never seen this before..

Cyou,

Joël.


PS.: Oh, and by the way, I solved my UFO yesterday!! Whoei!!..







909. Re: ROUX METHOD/CLL ALGS...
From: a_ooms75 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 13:02:09 -0000

Hello Gilles, Is this what your are looking for: (r' d) (R2 d') (L U) (r' D2) (r U') x Greets Alexander --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" > <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > ... > > As is turns out, Im gonna go with Roux's method. But dont know too > > many CLL algs yet. I dont use any CLL in my solves yet, I want to > > wait until I have them all down. I Need CLL algs from anybody who can > > help me out. I want to look for the shortest algs for each case. > > ... > > There's a $5,000 reward if you can find a *really* fast and comfortable > sequence for the B2 case. > > Gilles. >
910. Re: Flip three edges with parity fixer on 4x4
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 13:03:45 -0000

That's a nice one Joël! :-) I will definitely use it from now on. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hey guys.. > > I was just playing around with the 4x4, and I found a nice way to > flip three edges while fixing the OLL parity on the 4x4. It's just > the normal parity fix: > > (Rr)2 B2 U2 (Ll) U2 (Rr)' U2 (Rr) U2 F2 (Rr) F2 (Ll)' B2 (Rr)2 > > But when you add B'R' at the beginning, and RB at the end, > you 'flip' three edge groups. I am probably not the first person to > think about this, but I've never seen this before.. > > Cyou, > > Joël. > > > PS.: Oh, and by the way, I solved my UFO yesterday!! Whoei!!.. >

Best time with the Alg i just post with little practise is: 2.26 but all are under 3.00 i think with this one 10 times in 20 is hard because of the x i think with some practice you get under 2 greets AO --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, a_ooms75 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Hello Gilles, > > > > Is this what your are looking for: > > (r' d) (R2 d') (L U) (r' D2) (r U') x > > > > > Thanks, > I'm looking for a sequence I can do 10 times in 20 seconds. > I've been trying this (R'FU2F'RFR'U2RF' or close friends) for years > but R'FRF'LUL'F'LU'L'F still looks faster. > > > > Greets Alexander > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" > > > <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > ... > > > > As is turns out, Im gonna go with Roux's method. 914. Re: Fooling around and found
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 14:02:26 -0000

Hey Alexander, I've been using that same alg for some time now, only backwards. Tell me what you think of this. I prefer this alg left handed, so I do it as: L2 U L2 U L2 U' F' U' F L2 F' U F And with finger tricks [(L')2 U (L')2 (U) L2 (U')] y (L' U' L) B2 (L' U L) That first trigger takes some explanation, do the first (L')2 U (L')2 exactly as you would do L' U L' only with double turns instead of quarter turns. Then do the next U with your right index finger. Then do the L2 clockwise and then the next U' with your left ring finger. This is all one long trigger, and is extraordinarily fast. The last part is pretty self explanatory. Here's an average for that alg (2.20) 2.38 3.11 2.25 2.92 2.63 3.24 3.11 (3.50) 2.53 2.54 3.16 = 2.79 Also I just timed that first trigger (6 moves) and I got 1.18, 1.35, 1.06, 1.44, 1.08 The alg is really good when it's done smoothly, and really bad when it's not done smoothly. If you do the first trigger well then you usually get a fast time. If you lockup though then your execution will be slow. So I guess it's not the best alg, but it's one that fits my hands pretty well. My two cents, :-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, a_ooms75 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I was playing with a PLL i dont like it was: > R U R' B2 R U' R' U' B2 U B2 U B2 > > perform like this: > R U R' y R2 y' R U' R' U' y R2 U R2 U R2 > > Did is the little change: > R U R' y R2 y' R U' R' d' R2 U R2 U R2 > then to: > R U l' D2 l U' R' d' R2 U R2 U R2 > > I saw stefan his demo vid with his T-perm and start playing with it. > with this OLL: > B' (R' U' R U) B y' B' (R' U' R U) B (12/12) > > and changed it to: > (R U R' U') (R' F R F' U2) (R U R' U') (R' F R F')(17/18) > its a bit longer but for me its faster to execute. > > just wanna share my findings :) > maybe someone will like them. > > Greets AO >

(U)R'U'RU'R'UR'D'RUR'DR²

920. opposite color solving
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 14:46:02 -0000

Hey everyone,

I really can't stress how important I think this should be to solving.
I know people have preferences for being able to recognize one color
to speed things up.

However, having said that I wrote a short page as an addendum to my
extended cross section. I feel the material on the page speaks for
itself, so the page is simple.

I just want to point out exactly why I am so strongly in favor of this
strategy. Even if you don't use extended cross I very strongly ask
you to consider still using opposite color solving.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/ec-oc.html

It helps the odds of a good solve so much, that I no longer feel the
color recognition gained from using the same color is enough. I feel
with practice, the slightly slower recognition could be overcome by
the odds of getting a better solve this way.

I will try not to be annoying about this, but please read the page and
consider.

Chris





921. Storage amount update
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 15:03:06 -0000

Hey everyone,

I think I remember people saying that they couldn't access this
information (is that true?) so here is an update.

I've recently been getting update e-mails about this, so here is the info.

Photos:
Storage Notice! Using 29.03 of 30 MB (96%) of your Photos/Briefcase quota.
You are running out of space.

Files:
We're using 89% of 20MB

If members are allowed to see this information let me know, I don't
remember whether or not people could see this.

Chris






922. Re: Storage amount update
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 15:34:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I think I remember people saying that they couldn't access this > information (is that true?) so here is an update. > > I've recently been getting update e-mails about this, so here is the info. > > Photos: > Storage Notice! Using 29.03 of 30 MB (96%) of your Photos/Briefcase quota. > You are running out of space. > > Files: > We're using 89% of 20MB > > If members are allowed to see this information let me know, I don't > remember whether or not people could see this. > > Chris Yes, members can see it. It is located at the bottom of the appropriate section, under the list of that section's data. I think a lot of this could be cleaned up. There are files in those sections of people solving, or a robot solving, and some are 5MB for one file. With the existence of strangepuzzle.com, I think we can move some of those file elsewhere and free up space for more appropriate material. Who can do that, only the admin, the owner, both? Just a thought, anyway. -Dave Campbell

927. Re: [Speed cubing group] ... stackman and other nebish questions....plz reply
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 17:59:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@y...> wrote: > > if you wanted my advice on what to practice to get faster, it would be the first 2 steps of the method, building the 2x2x2 then the 2x2x3. try studying each corner and see how many moves you can make a 2x2x2 box with each one. once you know which one you think is the shortest, study it until you know the moves to make the box in your head (this is why notation is important) then execute building the 2x2x2 blindfolded. Hmm, why is notation important for this? I know for team blindsolving it is, but when I solve alone, I "memorize" my cross just visually. Do you do "write" it down with the standard notation in your head? Cheers! Stefan

931. Re: Left hand dexterity
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 18:46:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mrraaw" <mrraaw@y...> wrote: > > I just recently received an email with a bunch of intresting facts. > One of the facts was - "The average person's left hand does 56% of the > typing." I was wondering if that connected to one handed cubing. > Maybe typing built up our left hand's dexterity. I know a lot of > cubers including myself are right handed but they use their left hand > for one handed solving. > > > Another intresting fact was nothing cube related but neat. - > "Stewardesses" is the longest word typed with only the left hand > and "lollipop" with your right. " > > MATT > Maybe because it was designed so the most used keys are on your weak hands side? Qwerty was to slow down typers, remember? Switch to dvorak. Be cool :) ~Thom
932. Re: Roux Method / Extended Cross
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 18:50:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > I think that for CFOP, the extended cross is always the way to go. > > I would pretty much always start with a 2x2 block and then finish the > Xcross. Usually I could see a 2x2x1 Block and build it, and then > insert the last edge to make the 2x2. ANd THEN find the remaining 2 > edges and put them in to finish the X-cross. > > With the Roux method, you take it one step further. You build a 2x2x1 > block, but instead of looking for just one edge to insert, you have to > find 2 pieces. Find an edge and a corner and pair them up an insert, > to make a 3x2x1 block. Or you can insert an edge or corner right > away, and then find and insert the other piece. Though i think that > this is slower... > > Cross 4 pieces > 2x2 Block 4 pieces > Extended Cross 6 pieces > Gille's Block 5 pieces > > Its harder than a cross or petrus block, but easier than DIRECTLy > solving for X-cross. > > FOR ALL YOU ROUX SOLVERS > > > For the 2nd Block, I always find the DR edge and insert as quickly as > possible. Then I just solve the 2 CE pairs with an all too familiar > F2L strategy. > Howerver, There are MANY shortcuts you can find by using the M slice. > A F2L style chart with algorithms would be twice as big for this > method. There are many more places that a Corner and an edge can be > simultaneously. I never used F2L charts to learn F2L. In ROUX and > F2L, I think that Intuition is better. > > 1. What color scheme do you guys use for ROux? I use white and yellow > blocks always, with red or orange on bottom. > > 2. How fast can you guys do step 4? Gilles told me that he uses > Method 2 as his main method, and that a 4.5 sec avg is possible with > this method alone. Im at about 7-8 Sec.. > > > > Jason Kovacic > kovacic81@y... > > PS.. I still need lots and lots of CLL algs.... > Start blocks with white or yellow on L and green on top. I'm learning CLL with COLL-style recognition. Even though Gilles says it's bad practise :P Woo! Come on you roux'rs! :D ~Thom
933. Re: Try this fast scramble!!!
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 19:42:52 -0000

That is much faster than my scramble. When I scramble "at random" (not concentrating on making it actually random), this happens: http://www.cubewhiz.com/temp/jayd926seconds.avi ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > That could be a new kind of competition. Give a scramble, let > competitors find a good solution (FMC style, but optimized for speed), > make them solve as fast as possible... mmhh... No. > > Mmhh... no, this would indeed not be new. This has been one of the > categories of the 100th Japanese weekly contest (or similar). Also, > watch this crazy video of Katsu: > > http://tinyurl.com/8sty3 > > Cheers! > Stefan >

937. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
From: KOSTAS VERDES <verdk2003@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 12:55:59 -0800 (PST)

Dear Friends,

First of all let me introduce my self.
My name is Konstantinos Verdes from Greece.
I am 30 years old and my profession is surveying engineering.

I am the son of Panayiotis Verdes who is the inventor of the Olympicube range,
or better the NxNxN Cube.
My father profession, also, is surveying engineering and for 2+1/2 years the cube-puzzle designs and construction.

For about 2 years i TRY to read your discussions about speedcubing.
I must tell that it was very difficult for me to catch you at the beginning.
You see i only Knew how to solve the 3x3x3 Rubiks Cube and that back to late 80s.
Now i can solve any size (2x2x2, 3x3x3, 4x4x4, 5x5x5, 6x6x6) but not in the sense of speedcubing.
As you can imagine when my father told me about his invention i begun to search over the internet and then i found your really interesting and hardcore discussion group.
I must admit that you are all fantastic and i really enjoy trying to follow your mind.

I think that i want to write sooooo much but I will try to answer as good as my poor English allows me, some subjects that this topic brings.

Koen writes:
> Looking at Olympic Cubes' site and messages on > Twisty it won't take very long anymore for the 6x6x6 > to be available for the public.Personally I'm very >excited about trying it out.
> Does anybody has an idea about how it's going to be >released? Will we be able to order it off the Olympic > Cubes site?
> Also will the upcoming tournaments have 6x6x6 events? >What will the
> top times be like for the 6x6x6 after say 2 months > of release?



You are right Koen. The OlympiCube No6a will be available for the public soon-during the 2006.
You will be able to order it through our web-site which by the way will change completely during the next 5-6 months. You will also be able to find it in many stores, that i cannot tell it yet.
I dont know yet if the OlympiCube No6a will be include in yours events but i am sure that in the future we will also organize same events-open to any kind of cube i.e Rubiks-Mefferts-Eastsheen-Olympicubes and let the athletes decide.
As far for the time i cannot tell much. I solve the OlympiCube No6a in about 15-20 minutes using beginners techniques.
I am sure that all of you laughing with that time.
Also i dont Know which cube will be better for speedcubing the No6a or the No6b because we havent constructed the last one YET.

Game of Death wrote:
> I'd imagine there's a further problem which is that > the cube is probably less stable and
> more likely to break up/lock up at speed. The pieces > will be smaller and even if the
> overlap problem is solved an increase in the number > of slices means the cube is more likely to jam.

> Chris wrote:
> There is another practical problem. If the cube is > expensive, and
> replacement parts are not available, what happens if > by speedcubing
> you break it?
> You would need to make replacement parts if the > internals are as
> delicate as they sound, and if those are expensive > you have a whole
> other issue.



The OlympiCube No 6a is very stable. Much more than all the Known cubes of any size. I know that you are crazy and the meaning of stability to you maybe is different than the other common people, but if i think the other cubes that i have in hands then the surprise directly when you open the box of the OlympiCube No6a will be huge.
As far as it depends the replacing parts we will discuss it when the time comes and we will sure find a solution. But I assure you that the internals are not fragile-delicates and i dont think that you will easily break a piece. The pops also dont happen while i speedscrambling the cube.
I must also want to tell in public that i already talked -off the record-with two Champions Frank Morris and Per Kristen Fredlund
and we will invite them to video-test the OlympiCube No5, the OlympiCube No6a and the OlympiCube No7 during 2006.
The price of these products will be quite reasonable and approachable for such monsters but i cant tell it yet.

The OlympiCube invention is patented in Greece and patented pending in 21 countries+European Union, that is the the three quarters of the Known world. We follow successfully all the necessary legal steps and we will also start the trademark procedure during the next month.
I may show you our logo soon.

Finally i would like to invite anyone who thinks that is able to write solutions ( for beginners, for intermediate and for experts) for the 5x5x5, 6x6x6 and the 7x7x7 for our webpage and for our packages-manuals to e-mail me in konstantinos@....
Of course we will pay him/them for the services and their names will appear in the website-manuals.
Please feel free to ask-answer me anything either in public, either in private.

Thanks
Konstantinos

942. Re: Posting unofficial records on speedcubing.com
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 21:19:52 -0000

Those improvements alone will already encourage me to keep my times more updated. You know, when I improved my master magic record from 2. 68 to 2.67 I didn't submit it because I thought this very small improvement is not worth bothering Ron with extra work. Thanks Lars and Ron! Some further suggestions: - Show all records of a certain person, including the rank in each category. - Make it show N last posts and let us choose N other than 50. - Show last N posts that got into the top T in their category and let us choose T. Because to be honest, I'm not interested in a guy I don't know who just broke 2 minutes with the 3x3. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > Very nice Ron and Lars! > > The only thing I'd like to add that we should encourage everybody to > keep their times updated... for the bigger cubes and other puzzles as > well. > The unofficial lists are (in theory) only useful if _everyone_ posts > and updates his/her times. > > Greets, Koen > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > > > Hi friends, > > > > Today I installed a new record post page on speedcubing.com. > > > > From now on it should not be necessary anymore to send an e-mail > > with a record post. The form should work in any browser, also if you > > are using a web e-mail service like Hotmail. > > If you accept the cookie from the record post page, your name and e- > > mail address will be available next time you post a record. > > > > This is the first step to automating the UWR record updates. > > All records are posted into a database, from where I (still) handle > > them manually. > > Upcoming steps to be developed are: > > 1) after I approve a record, it will automatically appear on the > > record lists (this would make a HUGE difference for me!) :-) > > 2) new page with 50 latest posted records (for visitors to see what > > changed recently) > > 3) trusted posters can update their own records (yet even less work > > for me) > > 4) one e-mail address + website reference across all pages (at the > > moment all pages are handled separately) > > > > All this great work is done by Lars Vandenbergh! > > Thank you so much Lars! Visit his site at www.cubezone.be > > > > Suggestions for the UWR pages are very welcome via e-mail. > > > > Thanks and have fun, > > > > Ron > > PS: Tomorrow I will fly to India for a week, so no record updates. .. > > >
943. [Speed cubing group] Re: Release of 6x6x6 and 6x6x6 speedcubing (speculation)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 21:41:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, KOSTAS VERDES <verdk2003@y...> wrote: > > Hi Stefan, > > maybe you forgot about the 23 years that noone couldn't even think to produce the 6x6x6 or the 7x7x7. > I don't try to find excuses but you can't even imagine what we faced against us these last 2 years > > Konstantinos Hi Konstantinos, No, it's just that last year I was very excited to hear about your new cubes and when you said we could buy them very soon I got even more excited, and then those dates passed by and we didn't hear much from you about the progress. Maybe you need to be a hardcore cuber to imagine how hard it is having to wait for such a puzzle ;-). And in those 23 years is was not hard because we weren't really waiting for it... So now I'm just a bit more realistic. I know from myself that I want to do so many things and optimally I'd finish and publish them yesterday, but everything always takes longer than expected. And in your case, it doesn't even depend only on you, since you probably have to wait for those patent stuff etc. I certainly want to be among the first who order your 6x6 and larger, watching the video and mechanism pictures they look very good, and I want to be the first who solves a 6x6 blindfolded :-) Cheers! Stefan
944. Re: Fooling around and found
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 21:50:41 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Here's an average for that alg > (2.20) 2.38 3.11 2.25 2.92 2.63 3.24 3.11 (3.50) 2.53 2.54 3.16 = 2. 79 Chris, general question: How do you time individual executions? I only do that with video analysis but that's too much work. Normally I just do several executions in a row and divide the time by the number of executions. Cheers! Stefan
945. ugly turned nice
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 22:18:15 -0000

I just did an uninspired slow F2L solve and came across something real
nice. Scramble with cross on bottom and L' U' R U R' L. Now this must
be the nicest special case to solve 2 pairs together...

Stefan






946. Re: Fooling around and found
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Nov 2005 22:57:31 -0000

Hey Stefan, I time like I do the magic sort of. I start with the cube in my hands and JNetcube set to 0 seconds countdown. I press and hold the spacebar and when I'm ready I let go, do the alg, then hit the spacebar again. So I start and end with the cube in my hand. It's fairly close to just timing the alg itself I think. I have tried to do the alg several times in a row and divide, but I tend to prefer timing it individually. I don't really know why. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > Here's an average for that alg > > (2.20) 2.38 3.11 2.25 2.92 2.63 3.24 3.11 (3.50) 2.53 2.54 3.16 = 2. > 79 > > Chris, general question: How do you time individual executions? > > I only do that with video analysis but that's too much work. Normally > I just do several executions in a row and divide the time by the > number of executions. > > Cheers! > Stefan >

I just now came back after meeting Ron. Of all the coincidences he had
some work related trip to Bombay and he was staying just minutes away
from my hostel. We met together and had quite fun.

I wrote a small report of the meeting it can be found here
http://www.civil.iitb.ac.in/~d3sachin/cubing/ron.html

It may be quite boring coz im no writer, but still read it and give ur
suggestions :)

Ron is a great guy! Hoping to meet you again!

Sachin.
