1135. Re: ROUX METHOD/ F2B
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2005 09:55:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I think that a 12 sec avg is a reasonably attainable goal. > > Hmm, there are people averaging like 9 seconds for full F2L, so 8 > seconds sounds like a reasonable goal for F2B, too, don't you think? > > Cheers! > Stefan I agree. With the same kind of mastery over F2B that people are beginning to show over F2L, I think 8 seconds is not unreasonable, and perhaps less, because it is so adaptable to accomodate more lucky cases. I just got curious enough after this debate to take an average (damn you Stefan! I need to get to bed), and I was somewhat surprised. I consider myself a mediocre F2B solver, with a lot to learn still, and very little work actually invested in the method. Still, I managed an 11.76 after 12 solves. The more I get motivated to work on ZBF2L, the more promising this method seems. They're teasing me, really. That's it. I just need two brains. -Mike team [zb]
1136. Re: ROUX METHOD/ F2B
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2005 10:08:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" > kovacic81@y... wrote: > > > > Similar to F2L, the F2B is the key to getting fast at the ROUX > method. > > I think that a 12 sec avg is a reasonably attainable goal. > > Hmm, there are people averaging like 9 seconds for full F2L, so 8 > seconds sounds like a reasonable goal for F2B, too, don't you think? > See http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/20033 [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1137. Re: Restoration Hardware retro cubes
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2005 12:25:25 -0000

Yes, I meant to post something here as well. I got a really nice cube
from there by "test-driving" one first. Check out the thread here for
photos:

http://twistypuzzles.com/forum/viewtopic.php?
t=4145&sid=d7721265a90c210e4c276be4e1f68948

Basically it's a replica of the old Ideal packaging. Even the
instructions look similar to the old style, but updated. They include
a reference to Macky's 12.11 second record in there, but the text and
graphics are similar to the original instructions.

Yes, the stickers will wear out quickly, but of course nowadays we
have the technology to remedy that easily enough.

Chris


> I've just learned via twistypuzzles that Restoration Hardware now
has
> the cube for $12. Evidently they are not shrinkwrapped. So go to
your
> local location, try them all out until they get mad at you, then
pick
> one that suits your needs.
>
> They are something of a replica of the old 80's Ideal cubes. But,
they
> are just the basic Winning Moves cubes with an 80's style package
and
> logo sticker. What gets my goat is they still use the paper
stickers.
> Were they vinyl, I would buy a ton of them.

1150. Re: slice moves
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2005 18:24:47 -0000

That's exacly what I needed to be told. MUM' with me is lightening fast now after your advice :) I've abandoned learning CLL at the moment and cut to the orientation of the last six edges. (OLSE?) I've found I can do "http://grrroux.free.fr/method/s4_m2a_3.gif" faster with (MUM') U' (MUM') that what I was doing before. I think I'll optimise the sequences for all the orientations and opposites to them tonight. This should knock 1-2 seconds off my times :) Oh, I got a 19.20 with Roux as a single solve record :) Go me. ~Thom --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > Yeah, I can learn to do that, but M on it own is bloody hard. > > > > M is tough, it's useless to optimize it alone, you should consider > optimizations of the sequences where it appears. > > If you need to do MUM' fast for example, just try l(L'UM') or > R(r'UM'). I don't like to try to write fingertricks, because in fact > it starts with (l/2)(R/2). > (r'UM) is so fast, it looks like 1 move. > > Gilles. >

1155. Re: Retro cubes
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2005 20:12:37 -0000

That's the only place I've seen them. Winning Moves doesn't even have it on their site yet. I wouldn't be surprised to see it show up in other places that specialize in retro gear... maybe Cracker Barrel for example. The price is more expensive (probably because of the bulkier packaging, or just Restoration Hardware's markup). I don't think these are any different physically than the 25th anniversary cubes, but they are a newer batch. The serial number on mine says M1005B, so I think they were just manufactured last month. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > also curious if these are only sold at Restoration Hardware. anyone > know? > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" > <kwickykanny@e...> wrote: > > > > Me neither. 1159. Re: F2L riddle

1160. sub-40 after 3 months
From: sgowal <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2005 22:27:08 -0000

To my surprise I finally went sub-40 today:

Average: 39.29 seconds
Individual Times: 38.94, 40.64, 42.55, 38.48, 39.23, 35.59, 43.81,
38.20, (43.98), 33.74, 41.69, (33.14)

During the week-end my times were around 42 seconds and suddenly it
dropped to 39 seconds (around 7% improvement), did this happend to
anyone of you before ?

I'm posting because it's a huge milestone for me (I remember someone
saying speedcubing started at 40 seconds :-)) !

It's not that it's terrible, it's just that I'm used to my cubes being very very good, so now that it is only kind of good, it bothers me a lot. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > wrote: > > > > It locks up and stopped turning smoothly. I even lubed it last week > > to try to revive it, but it is still acting up. It adds at least a > > few unnecessary seconds to every solve I take. :( I will take some > > last-chance measures to see if I can get it back up to speed, but > even > > if I can, I need to start preparing a new cube for the Caltech > winter > > competition. > > And what kind of cube is it? No speedcube should ever really wear out > that much, so you must've done something wrong :-). Uh, or maybe I > just never played enough with a single cube to wear it out... > > Cheers! > Stefan >

1167. [Speed cubing group] Re: Ow.
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 01:03:38 -0000

Ah, if only it were that easy! (If anyone finds a font that resembles the Rubik script, let us all know.) What I did was get a good high quality raster image (i.e. JPG) of the logo. Then I just started cutting and pasting to transform the R into a P, the b into two l's. The letter "e" can be gotten from the word "Cube" or "Revenge" on the old packaging. I had to improvise on the "y" although a modified "g" might work. Then you need a good program to conver the raster to a vector for the final cleanup. Adobe LiveTrace works well for this. My final product isn't perfect but looks good enough on a small printout. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@g...> wrote: > > man, that "pelley's cube" is awesome. what's the font? > > On 11/28/05, thomkirjava <snkenjoi@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y.. > > > .> wrote: > > > > > > > > Well, you can't say i didn't warn you about this. > > > > > > > > http://tinyurl.com/c62vz > > > > > > > > I feel like Stefan doing that. :) > > > > > > Doing what, using tinyurl to say "you oughta know"? :-) > > > > > > Hmm, I wonder what would happen if I could predict the next tinyurl > > > and let it forward to itself... > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan > > > > > > > while(1) {redirect();} > > > > :) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -- > -cubekid >

1169. F2B
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 04:05:50 -0000

Hello again

I'd like to start off by saying that I was just being sarcastic when I
said that there were not enough websites about cubing. There are a
lot. I do think that there are way to many about CFOP and not enough
about corners first, Petrus, Roux...

Also, I just meant that a 12s F2B was a good goal for me. Its crazy
to me that people can do F2L in 9 sec on average!

F2B

For the F2B, I think that 8 secs is attainable with color neutrality.
10 sec is possible with starting with same block every time


I think that even using the slower method for the 2nd block
(DR edge, 2 pairs), you can do the 2nd block in 5sec. On Gilles site
he says 5 sec is what you need. I figure 1 sec for DR edge and 2 sec
for each CE pair. SO 5 sec for 2nd Block.

So the real question is- how fast can the first block be done on average?

I think that for the same block every time, 4s is about right.
If you use some color neutrality, I think that this can be reduced to
sub 3. Lots of lucky cases for step 1.

So with the same block every time (4s) you end up with a 9s avg
with lucky blocks (2-3s?) you can be sub 8.

As i said earlier, F2B is defenitely the key to speedsolving with this
method.

Block 1 4s
Block 2 5s
CLL 3s
Step 4 5s
Total 17s avg

And also, does everyone think that it is easier to learn CLL/COLL by
"reading" 4 stickers? Or to recognize which 2 corners need to switch?

Do you think that learning more than one color for CLL/COLL is a lot
harder? Im trying to decide if I should just do red on top, or red
and orange...

What do you guys think?

Jason Kovacic





1170. Re: F2B
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 04:49:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > Hello again > > I'd like to start off by saying that I was just being sarcastic when I > said that there were not enough websites about cubing. There are a > lot. I do think that there are way to many about CFOP and not enough > about corners first, Petrus, Roux... I concur wholehandedly. > For the F2B, I think that 8 secs is attainable with color neutrality. > 10 sec is possible with starting with same block every time But why? Even always creating the same two blocks, you retain color recognition but gain double chances for lucky starts. > I think that even using the slower method for the 2nd block > (DR edge, 2 pairs), you can do the 2nd block in 5sec. On Gilles site > he says 5 sec is what you need. I figure 1 sec for DR edge and 2 sec > for each CE pair. SO 5 sec for 2nd Block. Try solving the c/e pairs first or first and third in whichever block if you happen to find good cases for them before the edge. It takes no time, really, and often saves moves. Consider the scramble: (S) R (S') R U2 R2 Notice how the inverse solves the position easily. The best you can hope for with the rigid method is several moves longer and much less fun. > So the real question is- how fast can the first block be done on average? > > I think that for the same block every time, 4s is about right. > If you use some color neutrality, I think that this can be reduced to > sub 3. Lots of lucky cases for step 1. > > So with the same block every time (4s) you end up with a 9s avg > with lucky blocks (2-3s?) you can be sub 8. I definitely think 4 seconds is a reasonably attainable goal, but it requires flexibility. Good starts with Roux are much easier to see than, for example, X-cross, but I think that with enough practice, the recognition becomes easier and the solutions just pop out to you quicker. I can find myself planning out solutions involving three or more pairs sometimes, just because the blocks are nice. Practice is key. > As i said earlier, F2B is defenitely the key to speedsolving with this > method. > > Block 1 4s > Block 2 5s > CLL 3s > Step 4 5s > Total 17s avg I think that 4 + 5 + 2.5 + 5 = 16.5 should be fairly doable by anyone willing to put forth enough effort. I posted a couple of things on the ZB group recently about a thought I had that intrigued me. If people can learn nearly 800 sequences for full ZB, why can't we apply a similar technique to this method? The obvious places to apply it are on steps 3 and 4. There are a couple of possibilities I'd like to examine. One is learning both CLL and COLL cases for each of the step 3 cases. If you happen to notice the edges are all correctly oriented after step 2, you could apply a slightly slower COLL case and maintain the orientation after step 3, giving you a better case for step 4. The other option involves learning how to finish every possible case from step 4, once all the edges are correctly oriented. I think that it's between 14 and 30 cases + mirrors. And because they can all be solved using M U L R they can all be solved very quickly. I'm curious what the actual case count and average move number for this is. Both of these taken together could lead to ZB type LL's for what is quickly earning a place in my mind as a very competitive method, but at a fraction of the number of algs. > And also, does everyone think that it is easier to learn CLL/COLL by > "reading" 4 stickers? Or to recognize which 2 corners need to switch? > > Do you think that learning more than one color for CLL/COLL is a lot > harder? Im trying to decide if I should just do red on top, or red > and orange... Well, I'm partial to recognizing them by which corners need to switch. The sticker method is more abstract. It puts an extra layer between you and understanding what exactly is going on with the cube. The other way, there are no patterns to remember. Only the OLL case and which corners need to switch. > What do you guys think? > > Jason Kovacic I think I've got way too much to learn still. :P -Mike team [zb]

Richard





1172. Re: F2B
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 04:58:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > > Do you think that learning more than one color for CLL/COLL is a lot > > harder? Im trying to decide if I should just do red on top, or red > > and orange... And because I forgot this part a minute ago, here it is. I use white on bottom and yellow for my LL. However, if I see a nice enough yellow start, I go with it. I've noticed my times for when I use white LL aren't too bad. In fact, the white is nice and bright, so it's actually somewhat helpful. The only real problem I have is not being able to track the yellow pieces at the beginning as well for the same reason. Chris Hardwick and others have shown the benefits of opposite color solving. I think it's worth the extra effort. > -Mike > team [zb]

1176. Roux Method Average
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 08:21:09 -0000

I bet you guys are sick of me talking about the roux method...

But I cant stop

HEre's todays average, 3 weeks and 1 day after Switching to Roux, no CLL

27.03, 24.15, 25.56, (21.10), 26.76, 27.40, 26.33, POP, 30.81,
(33.47), 30.18, 24.80, 25.19 Avg 26.82

My SUnday contest average yesterday was almost the same (26.something)

In Orlando, I did alright for my standards (25s cuber), but didn't
make the 2nd round in anything. I had a 24.89s 3x3 solve, a 1m47s 4x4
solve, and 10 and 11 sec 2x2 solves. The 2nd day in Orlando, I
started doing all Roux solves. So I switched on Nov 6th. Im hoping
for a sub 25 average within the first month. PB with ROUX - 17.84s
(today)

Jason Kovacic
Kovacic81@...







1177. ROUX METHOD Step 4
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 08:35:51 -0000

Also

I have made an average of Step 4. I do a brief preinspection, since
you can spot all of the edges during step 3.
This step is comparable to OLL/PLL, b/c it has orientation and
permutation substeps.

5.15, 4.86, (10.41), 2.73, 8.24, 9.24, (2.40), 6.37, 5.64, 7.84, 7.41,
7.33 Step 4 Avg 6.48s


I use method 2 on Gilles site. Orient all 6 edges, pair up Ledge and
Redge and insert, and an easy 4 move PLL. You kind of just figure
things out on your own; Its pretty intuitive, and you have a lot of
freedom. Averaging about 15 moves, its a pretty good system and its
all I use for now.

Jason Kovacic







1178. Re: Gabbasoft Demo

This could be disastrous for various games or other software that use directx9 automatically when it finds that version of directx installed. Oh well, if u are not a gamer i guess u should be fine :-) -Per PS! Uninstalling (or downgrading) directx is not an easy task. 1179. ROUX METHOD Step 4 Possible Improvements
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 09:04:09 -0000

Here are my thoughts on possible improvements for step 4

keep in mind that I do not claim these ideas as my own.
I am just organizing some methods.

Possible improvements for Step 4

1. Learn COLL in addition to CLL for cases where edges are already
oriented correctly

2. Orient Edges 1st and only learn COLL (?_)

3. If Bottom 2 edges are oriented correctly, and the ledge and redge
are somewhere in top layer, Then ELL could solve all cases in 1
Algorithm, leaving you with a 4 move PLL.

4. Learn the 8 algorithms in Ming Thai's method.
FOr cases where a redge or ledge is already in place, you can
insert final edge and orient midges. I never learned these, but they
could be useful in certain cases



Mike-
Where is there a table of ZBLL like cases for step 4? Or do we have
to make one? I don't really like method 3 on gilles site if thats
what youre talking about. But i am in favor of exploring the options.

If all edges are Oriented, then Its just a matter of permuting 6
oriented cubies. That should be able to be done with a single
algorithm. How many cases could there possible be?

Jason Kovacic
Kovacic81@...


















1180. Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 10:03:34 -0000

Hi Chris, I have a few goals for RWC2007 - which I also vote for to be in London. I mean Europe. :) I also want to be using a good set of ZB algorithms, for now I am focussing on the cases which can be solved using a 2-generator algorithm (which is of course one COLL case per orientation). I want to be able to know those inside out, and I also want to be solving at least 2 of the orientations fully using ZB. Of course, I would love to be using full ZB, but I think that would take too much time, which as you get older you find you don't have so much of! That's why I'm already envying the 14-18 age range in our group ;) I want to be averaging 14 seconds over an average of 5 cubes, because I feel this will be the winning target at RWC2007. This won't only be an improvement in technique, but also an improvement in the total physical and mental regime which you now need to have to be successful in a high pressure competition. I want to be averaging at least 1 min 10 for the 4x4x4, and I want to dramatically improve my times for the 5x5x5. I will also practice hard at the Magic, buy myself a Master Magic and learn that, and I will also beat Stefan at the Clock like I have promised him for ages. I will also have fully mastered blindfold solving and I hope to be one of the best in the world by RWC 2007. I have already solved once or twice blindfolded, and using my system for memorisation I have already "made" a solution in 3 minutes. By this I mean I have memorised edges and solved them, stopped the timer, then started again with memorising corners and solving. Once I get the hang of putting it all together, and get the hang of automating setup moves or learning the new algorithms Stefan and I have been talking about, it would be very fast. The limiting factor would be actually finding the pieces to remember! AND I will take part on the Fewest Moves Competition! These are my primary goals. On the side, I would very dearly love to get the hang of square-1, but at the moment it is taking me too long to learn, as the techniques required are very different to speedsolving a cube, particularly if you approach it blindly by just learning the algorithms, as I am free to admit that I do as far as the sq-1 is concerned. I am sure that I will also practice hard at the Megaminx, the key lies in finding the pieces which just comes from practice I think, and also learning a good system. So, unlike a lot of people these days, I have chosen not to focus in on one puzzle. This is going to be a lot of hard work, but it will also be very satisfying to see improvements in my puzzles. I admire the cubers who are very fast at all of the cube sizes, such as yourself Chris, or Lars, Ron, Frank, and many others of course, and I always look up to you for sources of inspiration. Good Luck to everyone in their practice for competitions, not only RWC2007 of course! Dan Harris :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > Of course this assume that we have a RWC2007 (which I for one vote for > to be in Europe), but what are your goals? > > I for one have really neglected blindfold cubing, and have > rediscovered that I like it very much. I want to learn BLD cubing > better, and hopefully be using some ZB techniques on easy cases that I > will have known for 2-3 years by 2007 for speedsolving. > > What are everyone else's goals? Anyone rediscover a category they > like, or discover a category? > > Just wanted to ask a general question. I'm curious what everyone > likes/wants to pursue after RWC2005 :-) > > Chris >
1181. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 10:21:06 +0000

Hi Dan and Chris, My goals for RWC2007 are significantly less ambitious than yours. :) My primary goal for RWC2005 was to get a sub-30s solve, which I did (27.96s). RWV2007 is so far away that I'm not really sure what is a realistic goal for me. I'm still using a 3-look LL, so an obvious goal would be to have learnt all OLLs and be fluent at them. I think this is achieveable, but if I say it here then it means I'll have to do it! ;) I'd like to compete in the 4x4x4 again. I competed in that at RWC2003, but for some reason haven't entered it again at any other competitions. Actually, I know why, it's because I preferred the Eastsheen 4x4x4s. :( The Rubik's 4x4x4 I have now is actually okay, so maybe I will enter that event at RWC2007. I think I should aim to get my 5x5x5 times down to something reasonable so I can enter that event. I've never competed in the 5x5x5 because I'm never sure if I'm going to finish it before the stackmat times out! ;) I entered one-handed 3x3x3 for the first time at RWC2005. It was more fun than I expected so I'd be interested in giving that another go. Hopefully faster as well since my current average is a little over 2 minutes one-handed! Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com On Tue, 29 Nov 2005 10:03:34 -0000, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...> said: > > Hi Chris, > I have a few goals for RWC2007 - which I also vote for to be in > London. I mean Europe. :) > I also want to be using a good set of ZB algorithms, for now I > am > focussing on the cases which can be solved using a 2-generator > algorithm (which is of course one COLL case per orientation). I > want > to be able to know those inside out, and I also want to be > solving > at least 2 of the orientations fully using ZB. Of course, I > would > love to be using full ZB, but I think that would take too much > time, > which as you get older you find you don't have so much of! > That's > why I'm already envying the 14-18 age range in our group ;) > I want to be averaging 14 seconds over an average of 5 cubes, > because I feel this will be the winning target at RWC2007. This > won't only be an improvement in technique, but also an > improvement > in the total physical and mental regime which you now need to > have > to be successful in a high pressure competition. I want to be > averaging at least 1 min 10 for the 4x4x4, and I want to > dramatically improve my times for the 5x5x5. I will also > practice > hard at the Magic, buy myself a Master Magic and learn that, and > I > will also beat Stefan at the Clock like I have promised him for > ages. > I will also have fully mastered blindfold solving and I hope to > be > one of the best in the world by RWC 2007. I have already solved > once > or twice blindfolded, and using my system for memorisation I > have > already "made" a solution in 3 minutes. By this I mean I have > memorised edges and solved them, stopped the timer, then started > again with memorising corners and solving. Once I get the hang > of > putting it all together, and get the hang of automating setup > moves > or learning the new algorithms Stefan and I have been talking > about, > it would be very fast. The limiting factor would be actually > finding > the pieces to remember! > AND I will take part on the Fewest Moves Competition! > These are my primary goals. On the side, I would very dearly > love to > get the hang of square-1, but at the moment it is taking me too > long > to learn, as the techniques required are very different to > speedsolving a cube, particularly if you approach it blindly by > just > learning the algorithms, as I am free to admit that I do as far > as > the sq-1 is concerned. I am sure that I will also practice hard > at > the Megaminx, the key lies in finding the pieces which just > comes > from practice I think, and also learning a good system. > So, unlike a lot of people these days, I have chosen not to > focus in > on one puzzle. This is going to be a lot of hard work, but it > will > also be very satisfying to see improvements in my puzzles. I > admire > the cubers who are very fast at all of the cube sizes, such as > yourself Chris, or Lars, Ron, Frank, and many others of course, > and > I always look up to you for sources of inspiration. > Good Luck to everyone in their practice for competitions, not > only > RWC2007 of course! > Dan Harris :) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > Of course this assume that we have a RWC2007 (which I for one > vote > for > > to be in Europe), but what are your goals? > > > > I for one have really neglected blindfold cubing, and have > > rediscovered that I like it very much. 1182. [Speed cubing group] Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 11:00:32 -0000

Hi! My goal is to win everything next time! I aim for sub 13 avg on 3x3x3, sub 1:00 avg on 4x4x4 and sub 2:00 avg on 5x5x5. Pluss win clock, megaminx, magic, OH, BLD, fewest moves and also feet competition :-P Nah, seriously i hope to keep improving on the 5x5x5 and be so calm that i can do my normal times. And i do aim for winning fewest moves! I really hope stickers will be allowed next time. That's my serious goals. Im not gonna waste my time trying to learn fridrich or more advanced systems for 3x3x3. Even if i do so, competition is way too tough. I solely do speed 3x3x3 out of decency ... lol ... Sub 30 secs is impressive for 99.95% of the population ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@f...> wrote: > > Hi Dan and Chris, > > My goals for RWC2007 are significantly less ambitious than yours. :) > > My primary goal for RWC2005 was to get a sub-30s solve, which I did > (27.96s). 1183. Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 11:48:08 -0000

Cool topic! I plan to get more into the one-handed solving. I didn't compete in that event at WC05, because I had never really even tried a OH solve before. However, once I tried it, I realized I wasn't bad at it. So I'm going to work on that. The other big thing is perfecting some finger tricks. I've been solving for many years using full hand-twisting motions. I made the decision prior to WC05 to stick with that rather than learn a whole new style. However, in the last three weeks I've been studying sites like N8's and Yuki's and I've improved several of my algorithms' speed by applying FSC's. I especially like the "Zoku" contest that Macky posted a link to. This is a whole new side of speedcubing (for me), and I'm really enjoying the learning experience. Aside from that, I really should focus on speedsolving Megaminx and Square-1. I sat out those events this time to focus solely on the regular cubes. But next time I'd like to compete in more categories. Oh, I also plan to enter the 6x6x6 category! Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > Of course this assume that we have a RWC2007 (which I for one vote for > to be in Europe), but what are your goals?

Well, I've finally decided to sit down and finish learning OLL. I've
got less than half down now, but hopefully this means I will be more
consistent by 2007. Sub 16 (at home) should be possible once I get them
all down, so Sub-17 avg at the RWC2007 would be nice :-)

I also hope to get more competative on the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5, although I
have not been doing much lately with either of them. And of course, I
plan on setting the WR on the 6x6x6, as well ;-)

Doug

1187. Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 15:42:54 -0000

This is a tough question. Okay, here are my goals: AR for clock (with the only intention being to annoy Craig) 1st place for the magic, hopefully sub-1 second. 1st place for the master magic, probably sub-2.5 seconds. 1st place for the super magic. (Hopefully by then it's an event). Certainly make the 3x3x3 semi-finals. It depends on how long it takes me to finish learning ZB for me to decide on any time goals. Do respectable on the 4x4, 5x5, megaminx, and square-1. That means I actually have to learn how to finish the square-1, but I do have 2 years, right? :) I also want to be top-5 in the one-handed category. I know I can do this because I did it in the first round. I suppose I should start practicing that again. And I want a damn successful blindsolve. I don't practice it all, but I at least want something other than DNF! I will eventually have to break down and practice it more :( I want to make the finals for the 2x2 category, also. I just missed it last time. :( My vote is also for Europe. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > Of course this assume that we have a RWC2007 (which I for one vote for > to be in Europe), but what are your goals? > > I for one have really neglected blindfold cubing, and have > rediscovered that I like it very much. 1188. [Speed cubing group] Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 15:51:05 -0000

Hi!! My primary goal is to get a sub-15 average. I'm focusing on the 3*3*3 right now. Regular and one-handed solving. I'd be very proud to be in the "top-20 in the world"-list or beating Devid Wesleys swedish record of 15.91. I have practiced a bit one-handed lately and my average is 42.68 at the moment. My goal there is to achive a sub-30 average. By the way, I haven't been able to cube with my hands lately because I have an inflamed muscle in my left lower arm, so I've done some footcubing. 2:19,71 is my best time so far. I'll very soon reach sub- 2 minutes!! /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@f...> wrote: > > Hi Dan and Chris, > > My goals for RWC2007 are significantly less ambitious than yours. :) > > My primary goal for RWC2005 was to get a sub-30s solve, which I did > (27.96s). RWV2007 is so far away that I'm not really sure what is a > realistic goal for me. I'm still using a 3-look LL, so an obvious goal > would be to have learnt all OLLs and be fluent at them. I think this is > achieveable, but if I say it here then it means I'll have to do it! ;) > > I'd like to compete in the 4x4x4 again. I competed in that at RWC2003, > but for some reason haven't entered it again at any other competitions. > Actually, I know why, it's because I preferred the Eastsheen 4x4x4s. :( > The Rubik's 4x4x4 I have now is actually okay, so maybe I will enter > that event at RWC2007. > > I think I should aim to get my 5x5x5 times down to something reasonable > so I can enter that event. I've never competed in the 5x5x5 because I'm > never sure if I'm going to finish it before the stackmat times out! ;) > > I entered one-handed 3x3x3 for the first time at RWC2005. It was more > fun than I expected so I'd be interested in giving that another go. > Hopefully faster as well since my current average is a little over 2 > minutes one-handed! > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > On Tue, 29 Nov 2005 10:03:34 -0000, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> > said: > > > > Hi Chris, > > I have a few goals for RWC2007 - which I also vote for to be in > > London. I mean Europe. :) > > I also want to be using a good set of ZB algorithms, for now I > > am > > focussing on the cases which can be solved using a 2-generator > > algorithm (which is of course one COLL case per orientation). I > > want > > to be able to know those inside out, and I also want to be > > solving > > at least 2 of the orientations fully using ZB. Of course, I > > would > > love to be using full ZB, but I think that would take too much > > time, > > which as you get older you find you don't have so much of! > > That's > > why I'm already envying the 14-18 age range in our group ;) > > I want to be averaging 14 seconds over an average of 5 cubes, > > because I feel this will be the winning target at RWC2007. This > > won't only be an improvement in technique, but also an > > improvement > > in the total physical and mental regime which you now need to > > have > > to be successful in a high pressure competition. I want to be > > averaging at least 1 min 10 for the 4x4x4, and I want to > > dramatically improve my times for the 5x5x5. I will also > > practice > > hard at the Magic, buy myself a Master Magic and learn that, and > > I > > will also beat Stefan at the Clock like I have promised him for > > ages. > > I will also have fully mastered blindfold solving and I hope to > > be > > one of the best in the world by RWC 2007. I have already solved > > once > > or twice blindfolded, and using my system for memorisation I > > have > > already "made" a solution in 3 minutes. By this I mean I have > > memorised edges and solved them, stopped the timer, then started > > again with memorising corners and solving. Once I get the hang > > of > > putting it all together, and get the hang of automating setup > > moves > > or learning the new algorithms Stefan and I have been talking > > about, > > it would be very fast. The limiting factor would be actually > > finding > > the pieces to remember! > > AND I will take part on the Fewest Moves Competition! > > These are my primary goals. On the side, I would very dearly > > love to > > get the hang of square-1, but at the moment it is taking me too > > long > > to learn, as the techniques required are very different to > > speedsolving a cube, particularly if you approach it blindly by > > just > > learning the algorithms, as I am free to admit that I do as far > > as > > the sq-1 is concerned. I am sure that I will also practice hard > > at > > the Megaminx, the key lies in finding the pieces which just > > comes > > from practice I think, and also learning a good system. > > So, unlike a lot of people these days, I have chosen not to > > focus in > > on one puzzle. This is going to be a lot of hard work, but it > > will > > also be very satisfying to see improvements in my puzzles. I > > admire > > the cubers who are very fast at all of the cube sizes, such as > > yourself Chris, or Lars, Ron, Frank, and many others of course, > > and > > I always look up to you for sources of inspiration. > > Good Luck to everyone in their practice for competitions, not > > only > > RWC2007 of course! > > Dan Harris :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > > > Of course this assume that we have a RWC2007 (which I for one > > vote > > for > > > to be in Europe), but what are your goals? > > > > > > I for one have really neglected blindfold cubing, and have > > > rediscovered that I like it very much. I want to learn BLD > > cubing > > > better, and hopefully be using some ZB techniques on easy > > cases > > that I > > > will have known for 2-3 years by 2007 for speedsolving. > > > > > > What are everyone else's goals? Anyone rediscover a category > > they > > > like, or discover a category? > > > > > > Just wanted to ask a general question. I'm curious what > > everyone > > > likes/wants to pursue after RWC2005 :-) > > > > > > Chris > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > > > [1]Jigsaw puzzle game [2]Free puzzle inlay games [3]Educational > > game and puzzle > > [4]Word puzzle game [5]Kid puzzle game [6]Puzzle games > > ___________________________________________________________ > > > > YAHOO! 1189. Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 16:43:57 -0000

Hey everyone, Wow, I'm glad this topic took off and I guess I should answer with a little more thought also. Dan I'm starting to think like you, I don't want to focus on just one puzzle. Every time I try to focus on one, I feel bad for not practicing something else I really enjoy. My goals for RWC2007 would most likely be to improve my blindfolded rank (which I've neglected the most this year), and also to successfully do the 4x4x4 BLD. I will attempt the 5x5x5, and I guess in two years I might be ok at it, but my goal is the 4x4x4 record right now, sorry Dror :-( I also want to just stay competitive at all my favorite puzzles. I will of course buy a 6x6x6 and hope to be in the top-10 for that, but I imagine that puzzle will take some work of course. I guess I would be happy just to compete in the 6x6x6. I also want to either use ZB, or use it to train for Fridrich and hopefully improve my 3x3x3 rank, but with the competition as stiff as it is now I will just approach that category to hope to do well, but to have fun either way. Everyone keep posting your goals, they are really fun to read! It's really cool to see how our little hobby is evolving into more of a serious "quirky sport" ;-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > Hi Chris, > > I have a few goals for RWC2007 - which I also vote for to be in > London. I mean Europe. :) > > I also want to be using a good set of ZB algorithms, for now I am > focussing on the cases which can be solved using a 2-generator > algorithm (which is of course one COLL case per orientation). I want > to be able to know those inside out, and I also want to be solving > at least 2 of the orientations fully using ZB. Of course, I would > love to be using full ZB, but I think that would take too much time, > which as you get older you find you don't have so much of! That's > why I'm already envying the 14-18 age range in our group ;) > > I want to be averaging 14 seconds over an average of 5 cubes, > because I feel this will be the winning target at RWC2007. This > won't only be an improvement in technique, but also an improvement > in the total physical and mental regime which you now need to have > to be successful in a high pressure competition. I want to be > averaging at least 1 min 10 for the 4x4x4, and I want to > dramatically improve my times for the 5x5x5. I will also practice > hard at the Magic, buy myself a Master Magic and learn that, and I > will also beat Stefan at the Clock like I have promised him for ages. > > I will also have fully mastered blindfold solving and I hope to be > one of the best in the world by RWC 2007. I have already solved once > or twice blindfolded, and using my system for memorisation I have > already "made" a solution in 3 minutes. By this I mean I have > memorised edges and solved them, stopped the timer, then started > again with memorising corners and solving. Once I get the hang of > putting it all together, and get the hang of automating setup moves > or learning the new algorithms Stefan and I have been talking about, > it would be very fast. The limiting factor would be actually finding > the pieces to remember! > > AND I will take part on the Fewest Moves Competition! > > These are my primary goals. On the side, I would very dearly love to > get the hang of square-1, but at the moment it is taking me too long > to learn, as the techniques required are very different to > speedsolving a cube, particularly if you approach it blindly by just > learning the algorithms, as I am free to admit that I do as far as > the sq-1 is concerned. I am sure that I will also practice hard at > the Megaminx, the key lies in finding the pieces which just comes > from practice I think, and also learning a good system. > > So, unlike a lot of people these days, I have chosen not to focus in > on one puzzle. This is going to be a lot of hard work, but it will > also be very satisfying to see improvements in my puzzles. I admire > the cubers who are very fast at all of the cube sizes, such as > yourself Chris, or Lars, Ron, Frank, and many others of course, and > I always look up to you for sources of inspiration. > > Good Luck to everyone in their practice for competitions, not only > RWC2007 of course! > > Dan Harris :)
1190. Re: ROUX METHOD Step 4 Possible Improvements
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 17:34:42 -0000

You should look at this baby. http://rubikscube.info/lastsix2look.html Last Six Edges in 6 looks :) ~Thom --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > Here are my thoughts on possible improvements for step 4 > > keep in mind that I do not claim these ideas as my own. > I am just organizing some methods. > > Possible improvements for Step 4 > > 1. Learn COLL in addition to CLL for cases where edges are already > oriented correctly > > 2. Orient Edges 1st and only learn COLL (?_) > > 3. If Bottom 2 edges are oriented correctly, and the ledge and redge > are somewhere in top layer, Then ELL could solve all cases in 1 > Algorithm, leaving you with a 4 move PLL. > > 4. Learn the 8 algorithms in Ming Thai's method. > FOr cases where a redge or ledge is already in place, you can > insert final edge and orient midges. I never learned these, but they > could be useful in certain cases > > > > Mike- > Where is there a table of ZBLL like cases for step 4? Or do we have > to make one? I don't really like method 3 on gilles site if thats > what youre talking about. But i am in favor of exploring the options. > > If all edges are Oriented, then Its just a matter of permuting 6 > oriented cubies. That should be able to be done with a single > algorithm. How many cases could there possible be? > > Jason Kovacic > Kovacic81@y... >
1191. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 15:29:20 -0300 (ART)

Well, I'm not too ambitious. I hope to be around 16-17 seconds for 3x3x3 and around 30 for one-handed. Maybe buy a 4x4x4 and do it in less than 5 minutes...hehe. Also the magic looks cool, and maybe I practice it and beat Bob, Stefan and Quinn...who knows? Well, maybe I'll be en Europe in 2007, so it will be cool to have the WC there Pedro cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: Hey everyone, Wow, I'm glad this topic took off and I guess I should answer with a little more thought also. Dan I'm starting to think like you, I don't want to focus on just one puzzle. Every time I try to focus on one, I feel bad for not practicing something else I really enjoy. My goals for RWC2007 would most likely be to improve my blindfolded rank (which I've neglected the most this year), and also to successfully do the 4x4x4 BLD. I will attempt the 5x5x5, and I guess in two years I might be ok at it, but my goal is the 4x4x4 record right now, sorry Dror :-( I also want to just stay competitive at all my favorite puzzles. I will of course buy a 6x6x6 and hope to be in the top-10 for that, but I imagine that puzzle will take some work of course. I guess I would be happy just to compete in the 6x6x6. I also want to either use ZB, or use it to train for Fridrich and hopefully improve my 3x3x3 rank, but with the competition as stiff as it is now I will just approach that category to hope to do well, but to have fun either way. Everyone keep posting your goals, they are really fun to read! It's really cool to see how our little hobby is evolving into more of a serious "quirky sport" ;-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > Hi Chris, > > I have a few goals for RWC2007 - which I also vote for to be in > London. I mean Europe. :) > > I also want to be using a good set of ZB algorithms, for now I am > focussing on the cases which can be solved using a 2-generator > algorithm (which is of course one COLL case per orientation). I want > to be able to know those inside out, and I also want to be solving > at least 2 of the orientations fully using ZB. Of course, I would > love to be using full ZB, but I think that would take too much time, > which as you get older you find you don't have so much of! That's > why I'm already envying the 14-18 age range in our group ;) > > I want to be averaging 14 seconds over an average of 5 cubes, > because I feel this will be the winning target at RWC2007. This > won't only be an improvement in technique, but also an improvement > in the total physical and mental regime which you now need to have > to be successful in a high pressure competition. I want to be > averaging at least 1 min 10 for the 4x4x4, and I want to > dramatically improve my times for the 5x5x5. I will also practice > hard at the Magic, buy myself a Master Magic and learn that, and I > will also beat Stefan at the Clock like I have promised him for ages. > > I will also have fully mastered blindfold solving and I hope to be > one of the best in the world by RWC 2007. I have already solved once > or twice blindfolded, and using my system for memorisation I have > already "made" a solution in 3 minutes. By this I mean I have > memorised edges and solved them, stopped the timer, then started > again with memorising corners and solving. Once I get the hang of > putting it all together, and get the hang of automating setup moves > or learning the new algorithms Stefan and I have been talking about, > it would be very fast. The limiting factor would be actually finding > the pieces to remember! > > AND I will take part on the Fewest Moves Competition! > > These are my primary goals. On the side, I would very dearly love to > get the hang of square-1, but at the moment it is taking me too long > to learn, as the techniques required are very different to > speedsolving a cube, particularly if you approach it blindly by just > learning the algorithms, as I am free to admit that I do as far as > the sq-1 is concerned. I am sure that I will also practice hard at > the Megaminx, the key lies in finding the pieces which just comes > from practice I think, and also learning a good system. > > So, unlike a lot of people these days, I have chosen not to focus in > on one puzzle. This is going to be a lot of hard work, but it will > also be very satisfying to see improvements in my puzzles. I admire > the cubers who are very fast at all of the cube sizes, such as > yourself Chris, or Lars, Ron, Frank, and many others of course, and > I always look up to you for sources of inspiration. > > Good Luck to everyone in their practice for competitions, not only > RWC2007 of course! > > Dan Harris :) --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1192. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: ROUX METHOD Step 4 Possible Improvements
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 19:40:11 +0100

Wow... in 6 looks. That doesn't sound good at all. I bet 2 looks would be much faster ;) /Gustav thomkirjava skrev: >You should look at this baby. > >http://rubikscube.info/lastsix2look.html > >Last Six Edges in 6 looks :) > >~Thom > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" ><kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > >>Here are my thoughts on possible improvements for step 4 >> >>keep in mind that I do not claim these ideas as my own. >>I am just organizing some methods. >> >>Possible improvements for Step 4 >> >>1. Learn COLL in addition to CLL for cases where edges are already >>oriented correctly >> >>2. Orient Edges 1st and only learn COLL (?_) >> >>3. If Bottom 2 edges are oriented correctly, and the ledge and redge >>are somewhere in top layer, Then ELL could solve all cases in 1 >>Algorithm, leaving you with a 4 move PLL. >> >>4. Learn the 8 algorithms in Ming Thai's method. >> FOr cases where a redge or ledge is already in place, you can >>insert final edge and orient midges. I never learned these, but they >> could be useful in certain cases >> >> >> >>Mike- >>Where is there a table of ZBLL like cases for step 4? Or do we have >>to make one? I don't really like method 3 on gilles site if thats >>what youre talking about. But i am in favor of exploring the >> >> >options. > > >>If all edges are Oriented, then Its just a matter of permuting 6 >>oriented cubies. That should be able to be done with a single >>algorithm. How many cases could there possible be? >> >>Jason Kovacic >>Kovacic81@y... >> >> >> > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! 1194. Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 19:33:41 -0000

Goals for RWC 2007:

3x3: I want to be able to average in the 15's. Right now I'm using
VHF2L and COLL, but I would like it to be more ZBLL by then. I would
also like to average similarly with the Roux method.

3x3 OH: It would be nice to be under 40 on average, but I don't know
how realistic that is because I've never really practiced it much. My
average at that the last time I checked a few months ago was more like
1:10. :(

4x4: I want to consistently average under 70 for sure. My best times
right now are just above that, but my average is still in the 90's. I
need to get better at my method, and maybe learn some more 3 cycles
for directly solving edges. With practice, I think that could be fast.

5x5: It would be cool to actually be fast enough to compete at that.
With the terrible cube I've got with no lube, my best time is 6:40,
but I think I can get my method down to under half of that with a good
cube and practice. Sub-4 for sure but I'm really shooting for sub-3.

Square1: I need to find mine in the attic and relearn how to solve it.
That first part could take the whole two years...

Team blindfold: I really hope there's an even for this. Heidi and I
really enjoy it. Plus, we have a way better naming system than Ian
does. ;P

Blindfold: I want to have a successful solve by then instead of just
DNF's, and I would like to be well under 3 minutes. I just need to
actually work on it.

2x2: I can do well with my 4x4 scrambled as a 2x2, but I don't
actually own a decent real 2x2. I should work on that, and then get good.

-Mike
team [zb]

Plus, we have a way better naming system than Ian > does. ;P No way! What can be better than A, C, kicks, fish, and ice cream cone!?! ~ Bob

1197. Re: ROUX METHOD/ F2B
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 20:31:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" > > kovacic81@y... wrote: > > > > > > Similar to F2L, the F2B is the key to getting fast at the ROUX > > method. > > > I think that a 12 sec avg is a reasonably attainable goal. > > > > Hmm, there are people averaging like 9 seconds for full F2L, so 8 > > seconds sounds like a reasonable goal for F2B, too, don't you think? > > > > > See http://games.groups.yahoo. com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/20033 Gilles, forgive us, it's just so strange that the inventor of a method is actually the fastest user of it :-) Cheers! Stefan

1200. Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 20:46:27 -0000

Well...I've put this off long enough and I Will now chime in with my
thoughts...

LEARN FRIDRICH FULL FRIDRICH!!! Huge goal...obvious goal, obviously
going to happen within 2 years...

2x2 - Average under 20 consistently, maybe once I learn Fridrich(and
COLL maybe) I'll hit sub-10???

3x3 - With Fridrich, once I get it down, I think I'll be sub-20, and
with a lot of practice maybe better...

3x3 OH - Again, dependant on Fridrich, I've got a decent cube, and i'm
not bad at OH, I just have a bad method...Aiming for sub-45 average

3x3 Feet - Fridrich, Some people are amazed I can get 4:xx.xx with my
feet...I'll aim sub-3 for now...may need to update this later

3x3 BLD - Chris Hardwick, that lovely man, is partway through teaching
me...I'll learn how to do it, then let you know my goals...

4x4 - You know it...Fridrich, and centers and pairing up need to be
faster, just recognition and and turning speed...Aiming for sub-1:30...

5x5 - This is just a matter of time...it isn't dependant on Fridrich,
I use a version of Per's Method and I believe I will someday be able
to hit sub-3, but it will take a good amount of practice...

6x6 - The forsaken cube...Hopefully top 5...will be one of the top
cubers for this off the start, may get completely destroyed once
people get good methods...Sub-10 minute single solve within a
day...sub-5 final...sub-4 will probably be nearing WR...

Magic - This is just practice practice practice...I will get near a
second someday...don't know when...I've got 2 years...

Master Magic - I want one of the real ones...that are heavy...I love
the one I have now (Thank you Peter for making it) but...It is a bit
light to control, my fault because of the tiles I supplied...Aiming
around 3 seconds???With my MM, maybe sub-3 with a heavy one...

Super Magic - I might get one...before the end of the year...Bob-Watch
out for me on this puzzle...

Clock - Get a better one...Those of you who have tried my clock
understand...and I need to get better overall...I am hoping with a new
clock average sub-12, maybe better

Megaminx - Should be getting one within the next month, may suck cuz
of it's inards but I will talk to Stefan about that...really easy
puzzle actually...Maybe hit sub-5 once I get and practice it...

Sqaure-1 - Learn how to do it...I was planning on doing it before this
WC, but I didn't...really isn't too hard of a puzzle, but it looks
intimidating, avg-sub-60 on this by 2007...

Pyraminx - Use a better method than the one I came up with...Avg sub-15

UFO??? This is interesting...maybe an event one day???hmmmmmmmm...Soon
the world championships will have to be a week long event to do all
needed events and do everyone who wants to compete, or there will be
qualifying from home countries.

Cup-Stacking...Yah yah, not cubing related, but still...after trying
this at WC I am planning on buying some, mom said she'd let me borrow
her credit card later...:)

I don't focus on any one puzzle, I practice everything all the time,
and my dad is always telling me to practice just one puzzle...but I'm
never gunna do that...Any questions, you know where to find
me...probably forgot something...but meh...

Craig

1202. Re: ROUX METHOD Step 4 Possible Improvements
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 21:00:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@g...> wrote: > > You should look at this baby. > > http://rubikscube.info/lastsix2look.html Ok, now the obvious question: How does it compare to Gilles's way? Both ways first orient all six edges and place the LU and RU edges, but they place them at different places. Do we know average number of moves for these two methods? Cheers! Stefan

1205. Re: Ow.
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 21:10:32 -0000

Any idea what has changed? Someone once mentioned his plastic washers have disappeared over time, are yours still intact? If they're gone and the spring is maybe even already eating through the center piece, then the tension of course gets weaker cause the spring gets less and less compressed. Also, I'm assuming you tried screwing the screw in deeper? Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > It's a black DIY. Maybe i can show it to you the next time i see you. > maybe over the summer? It's not that it's terrible, it's just that > I'm used to my cubes being very very good, so now that it is only kind > of good, it bothers me a lot. > > ~ Bob

Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 16:36:04 -0600

On 11/29/05, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...> wrote: > Ah ok ... > > Then i guess u have somehow installed that directx version by some > mistake. It looks like ur card doesn't support the directx 9a API. > This could be disastrous for various games or other software that > use directx9 automatically when it finds that version of directx > installed. Oh well, if u are not a gamer i guess u should be fine :-) > > -Per > > PS! Uninstalling (or downgrading) directx is not an easy task. It > cannot be done from the control panel :-( > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > > > I have directx 9.0, maybe my graphics card is just too weak. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" > > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi Richard :-) > > > > > > From Start/Run type DxDiag + (enter). The diagnostic tool should > > show > > > you anything u would like to know about your DirectX version. U > > need > > > version 9a in order to run the demo. I guess many pC's still > only > > have > > > version 7 or 8. It depends amongst other things on ur graphics > > card. > > > And yes it's overkill with directx 9 for that demo. A much lower > > > version would have been enough. > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" > > > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > I just installed the gabbasoft demo on my laptop, and when I > try > > to > > > run > > > > it, it says: "Null Ref Device Cannot Render" > > > > > > > > Any ideas on what the problem is and how I should fix it? > > > > > > > > Many thanks, > > > > > > > > Richard > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1209. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: What are your goals for 2007RWC?
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Nov 2005 17:15:56 -0600

Well after rwc2005... i'm really inspired to cube better.. i realized that i dont practice a lot and that my technique is quite poor. but here are my more practical goals -learn to solve BLD and compete in all sizes (and finish) -learn OLL, COLL, xcross, opposite cross, perfect my PLL algs, get sub 10sec F2L every time -get into big cubes (4x4x4 and up) -get into magic, master magic, and super magic, along with OH in all -okay, this one is new, but i tried it once and it was fun. OH 4x4x4 solving. it hurts if you try to do more than one (well, at least for me), but its a much more physically challenging puzzle. -3x3x3 OH... get better and for the actual competition: -get top 3 for 4x4x4 obviously there's more... but homework is calling me :-/ rwc2007... bring it. 1221. L/J perm
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Nov 2005 01:53:48 -0000

Try this alg for the L perm! :)

F R U R' U' S R U R' U' f' R U R' U' R U R' y L' U2 L2 F' L' F2 U2 F'

~ Bob





1222. Re: L/J perm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Nov 2005 02:16:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Try this alg for the L perm! :) > > F R U R' U' S R U R' U' f' R U R' U' R U R' y L' U2 L2 F' L' F2 U2 F' But... why? Btw, you should switch to R U2 R' U' R U2 L' U R' U' L for the mirror case. Cheers! Stefan

don't understand how it coulda got there by accident...Anyone got a
challenge??? I have pictures of a good MM one I had...

1226. Re: L/J perm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Nov 2005 03:51:41 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@e...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c.. .> > wrote: > > > > Try this alg for the L perm! :) > > > > F R U R' U' S R U R' U' f' R U R' U' R U R' y L' U2 L2 F' L' F2 U2 F' > > > > ~ Bob > > Took me about 15 seconds to execute, plus I ended up with a bowl full > of mush. What does f' stand for? Is that (F'S')? Or is it (B S')? > or something else.... That's a perfect question for this applet: http://thearufam.brinkster.net/cube/wrapplet.asp Copy & paste the alg, immediately see what the result is, and watch it step by step if anything is unclear. Very useful page, better bookmark it. Cheers! Stefan

1232. INteresting CHallenge - FL
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Nov 2005 07:56:04 -0000

I want to know how fast some of you can solve the first layer

Just the white layer, not F2L

I think that for 1 layer, solving 4 corners first and then doing edges
is the way to do it (Waterman Method). Or you could do cross and 4
corners, but I think that would be slower.

For F2L, 10 sec is a good goal.
For FL, I think 7 sec is a good goal.

For a 3x2x1 Block, I think that 4 sec is a good goal. Its like 2/3 of
one layer.

How fast can you guys do FL?

Jason Kovacic
kovacic81@...

1234. Re: [Speed cubing group] INteresting CHallenge - FL
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 30 Nov 2005 08:28:32 -0000

My method for doing this is to put one edge in and then pair up a corner-edge pair adjacent to it and work around the FL that way. 16 moves is a good goal. I really expect with practice that 7 seconds could seem quite slow (well I hope so!). Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, November 30, 2005 7:56 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] INteresting CHallenge - FL >I want to know how fast some of you can solve the first layer > > Just the white layer, not F2L > > I think that for 1 layer, solving 4 corners first and then doing edges > is the way to do it (Waterman Method). Or you could do cross and 4 > corners, but I think that would be slower. > > For F2L, 10 sec is a good goal. > For FL, I think 7 sec is a good goal. > > For a 3x2x1 Block, I think that 4 sec is a good goal. Its like 2/3 of > one layer. > > How fast can you guys do FL? > > Jason Kovacic > kovacic81@... > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
1235. Re: INteresting CHallenge - FL
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Nov 2005 09:16:51 -0000


> > How fast can you guys do FL?
> >
> > Jason Kovacic
> > kovacic81@y...

8.15 on average. Probably a little better when I'm mostly awake. I
did all of the decent solves cross followed by 4 corners.

I'm sure I'm not doing anything optimally, but I think cross first may
be fewer moves, especially if you're counting in QTM. The worst case
scenario for a corner to be in is either in the top layer with the
bottom side on the U face or in the wrong spot or orientation on the
first layer. Both of these are easy to fix and generally with two
generators, which are quite fast. Corners first, you would need to
make sure to get a good corner case followed by very quick edge
placement. The worst case scenarios for edges are in the wrong spots
and wrongly oriented. Granted, you can often fix these with only MUF,
but I think this is still slower than two generators, no matter how
much I like M turns.

I don't see the usefulness of FL really, because F2L places pieces
very efficiently. FL places 4 fewer pieces in slightly fewer moves
and makes it more difficult to actually place those 4 pieces. The
only way I can think of that FL might be useful is if you solve Roux
style with the FL as your first 1x2x3, but I think it's hard to solve
that way quickly and maintain the correct colors for your blocks.

-Mike
team [zb]





1236. Re: INteresting CHallenge - FL
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Nov 2005 10:22:52 -0000

Hi! FL (or F1L rather?) is of course useful for beginners who start out his/her cubing career by using a very basic layer by layer method. Since this step of a very basic method is also supposed to be intuitive (unless forcing cross + 4C or something) i consider it important to be fast with this step for the overall speed :-) I would say that a beginner using a beginners layer by layer method should aim for something like the following breakdown: - First layer (FL) : 10-15 secs - Middle layer (E-edges) : 15-20 secs - Last layer (4 steps somehow) : 20-30 secs This makes a total of 45-65 secs for a beginner. I believe this is realistic. The faster the recognition the closer to 45 secs one should get. With more advanced tricks and combining steps here it's possible to move below 30 secs even with pure layer by layer :-) Of course only Fnl (fist n layers) practice is *really* useful for the nxnxn cube, since there are so many approaches to solving (different steps) :-P (Yes it is and isn't a joke ;-) ) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > > > > How fast can you guys do FL? > > > > > > Jason Kovacic > > > kovacic81@y... > > 8.15 on average. Probably a little better when I'm mostly awake. I > did all of the decent solves cross followed by 4 corners. > > I'm sure I'm not doing anything optimally, but I think cross first may > be fewer moves, especially if you're counting in QTM. The worst case > scenario for a corner to be in is either in the top layer with the > bottom side on the U face or in the wrong spot or orientation on the > first layer. Both of these are easy to fix and generally with two > generators, which are quite fast. Corners first, you would need to > make sure to get a good corner case followed by very quick edge > placement. The worst case scenarios for edges are in the wrong spots > and wrongly oriented. Granted, you can often fix these with only MUF, > but I think this is still slower than two generators, no matter how > much I like M turns. > > I don't see the usefulness of FL really, because F2L places pieces > very efficiently. FL places 4 fewer pieces in slightly fewer moves > and makes it more difficult to actually place those 4 pieces. The > only way I can think of that FL might be useful is if you solve Roux > style with the FL as your first 1x2x3, but I think it's hard to solve > that way quickly and maintain the correct colors for your blocks. > > -Mike > team [zb] >

1238. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: INteresting CHallenge - FL
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 30 Nov 2005 11:38:51 -0000

Hi Per, F1L (nice name!) is an integral part of the L2L4 method which is anything but a beginners method (should be possible to average 50-52 moves maybe under 50). I believe this is > realistic. The faster the recognition the closer to 45 secs one > should get. With more advanced tricks and combining steps here it's > possible to move below 30 secs even with pure layer by layer :-) > > Of course only Fnl (fist n layers) practice is *really* useful for > the nxnxn cube, since there are so many approaches to solving > (different steps) :-P (Yes it is and isn't a joke ;-) ) > > Cheers! > > -Per > >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: >> >> >> > > How fast can you guys do FL? >> > > >> > > Jason Kovacic >> > > kovacic81@y... >> >> 8.15 on average. Probably a little better when I'm mostly awake. > I >> did all of the decent solves cross followed by 4 corners. >> >> I'm sure I'm not doing anything optimally, but I think cross first > may >> be fewer moves, especially if you're counting in QTM. The worst > case >> scenario for a corner to be in is either in the top layer with the >> bottom side on the U face or in the wrong spot or orientation on > the >> first layer. Both of these are easy to fix and generally with two >> generators, which are quite fast. Corners first, you would need to >> make sure to get a good corner case followed by very quick edge >> placement. The worst case scenarios for edges are in the wrong > spots >> and wrongly oriented. Granted, you can often fix these with only > MUF, >> but I think this is still slower than two generators, no matter how >> much I like M turns. >> >> I don't see the usefulness of FL really, because F2L places pieces >> very efficiently. FL places 4 fewer pieces in slightly fewer moves >> and makes it more difficult to actually place those 4 pieces. The >> only way I can think of that FL might be useful is if you solve > Roux >> style with the FL as your first 1x2x3, but I think it's hard to > solve >> that way quickly and maintain the correct colors for your blocks. >> >> -Mike >> team [zb] >> > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- --------------------------------- Yahoo! doce lar. Faça do Yahoo! sua homepage. ----- JNetCube Best Average for Wed Nov 30 18:06:43 PST 2005 ----- Average: 06.59 Fastest Time: 04.16 Slowest Time: 08.94 Standard Deviation: 01.09 Individual Times: 1) (04.16) B' L' D' L' F' B2 R F D2 R' U2 L F2 L' D U2 F' R F' R' F2 L2 D2 R' F' 2) 05.94 F' D2 U2 B L2 U2 R L' F' R2 L U B2 F D' F D U B U2 D2 L F B2 L' 3) 07.61 R' D' L' B2 D2 U2 F U' D B L' D2 L D' L U2 R' L2 B L U2 D' B2 R' U' 4) 08.52 F' R' L2 D2 F2 L D U' B' D' R U' D R2 F' R D2 F' R B R D2 B U B' 5) 06.36 F' R' B2 R2 D2 R B2 F2 D2 U B L2 D B' R2 U' B' F L F D' L' F L2 R2 6) 05.09 D2 R L' F' U2 L D U F U2 F2 B2 D2 B D2 U2 B' F' R' U2 R' U R2 U2 R 7) 07.44 F' U2 F B' R2 F' R B' U B L' B' U2 B' R2 D' F L U F D F' D R U 8) 06.05 F L2 R F2 L U' B2 D' U F' B R2 D' F' B U2 D' L F' U2 R2 D B' L D' 9) 05.20 B2 F2 D2 B2 F2 L2 D2 U' B L' F' L2 U' B' L R B L2 F2 U R U' D F R' 10) (08.94) B' L D' B' U2 R B2 R2 F D' R' F D R B D' L2 F2 L F2 D L B2 R2 U 11) 06.67 F2 B D2 L' F U2 B' F2 U2 L B U D' L' F' B' R2 D' R2 B' L U2 L' B2 D2 12) 07.06 U L' B' F' R D' F D2 B2 L F2 B R B' U L' B' F' R B' D' F2 D2 L2 D =) Macky > Duncan Dicks <duncan@d...> escreveu: > Hi Per, > F1L (nice name!) is an integral part of the L2L4 method which is anything > but a beginners method (should be possible to average 50-52 moves maybe > under 50). > Duncan > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Wednesday, November 30, 2005 10:22 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: INteresting CHallenge - FL > > > > Hi! > > > > FL (or F1L rather?) is of course useful for beginners who start out > > his/her cubing career by using a very basic layer by layer method. > > Since this step of a very basic method is also supposed to be > > intuitive (unless forcing cross + 4C or something) i consider it > > important to be fast with this step for the overall speed :-) > > > > I would say that a beginner using a beginners layer by layer method > > should aim for something like the following breakdown: > > > > - First layer (FL) : 10-15 secs > > - Middle layer (E-edges) : 15-20 secs > > - Last layer (4 steps somehow) : 20-30 secs > > > > This makes a total of 45-65 secs for a beginner. I believe this is > > realistic. The faster the recognition the closer to 45 secs one > > should get. With more advanced tricks and combining steps here it's > > possible to move below 30 secs even with pure layer by layer :-) > > > > Of course only Fnl (fist n layers) practice is *really* useful for > > the nxnxn cube, since there are so many approaches to solving > > (different steps) :-P (Yes it is and isn't a joke ;-) ) > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > >> > >> > >> > > How fast can you guys do FL? > >> > > > >> > > Jason Kovacic > >> > > kovacic81@y... > >> > >> 8.15 on average. Probably a little better when I'm mostly awake. > > I > >> did all of the decent solves cross followed by 4 corners. > >> > >> I'm sure I'm not doing anything optimally, but I think cross first > > may > >> be fewer moves, especially if you're counting in QTM. The worst > > case > >> scenario for a corner to be in is either in the top layer with the > >> bottom side on the U face or in the wrong spot or orientation on > > the > >> first layer. Both of these are easy to fix and generally with two > >> generators, which are quite fast. Corners first, you would need to > >> make sure to get a good corner case followed by very quick edge > >> placement. The worst case scenarios for edges are in the wrong > > spots > >> and wrongly oriented. Granted, you can often fix these with only > > MUF, > >> but I think this is still slower than two generators, no matter how > >> much I like M turns. > >> > >> I don't see the usefulness of FL really, because F2L places pieces > >> very efficiently. FL places 4 fewer pieces in slightly fewer moves > >> and makes it more difficult to actually place those 4 pieces. The > >> only way I can think of that FL might be useful is if you solve > > Roux > >> style with the FL as your first 1x2x3, but I think it's hard to > > solve > >> that way quickly and maintain the correct colors for your blocks. > >> > >> -Mike > >> team [zb]

1253. [Speed cubing group] Re: INteresting CHallenge - FL
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Dec 2005 04:07:57 -0000

Hi Macky :-) 4.16 secs is extremely fast for F1L ... Did u simply do cross pluss 4C ? Or you did F1L completely intuitively (solve what u see first) ?? Have fun! -Per PS! Now that you have done this on 3x3x3 try the same on 4x4x4 and 5x5x5. If you can do those fast also you qualify for using the cage method ;-) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > ----- JNetCube Best Average for Wed Nov 30 18:06:43 PST 2005 ----- > > Average: 06.59 > > Fastest Time: 04.16 > Slowest Time: 08.94 > Standard Deviation: 01.09 > > Individual Times: > 1) (04.16) B' L' D' L' F' B2 R F D2 R' U2 L F2 L' D > U2 F' R F' R' F2 L2 D2 R' F' > 2) 05.94 F' D2 U2 B L2 U2 R L' F' R2 L U B2 F D' F > D U B U2 D2 L F B2 L' > 3) 07.61 R' D' L' B2 D2 U2 F U' D B L' D2 L D' L U2 > R' L2 B L U2 D' B2 R' U' > 4) 08.52 F' R' L2 D2 F2 L D U' B' D' R U' D R2 F' R > D2 F' R B R D2 B U B' > 5) 06.36 F' R' B2 R2 D2 R B2 F2 D2 U B L2 D B' R2 > U' B' F L F D' L' F L2 R2 > 6) 05.09 D2 R L' F' U2 L D U F U2 F2 B2 D2 B D2 U2 > B' F' R' U2 R' U R2 U2 R > 7) 07.44 F' U2 F B' R2 F' R B' U B L' B' U2 B' R2 > D' F L U F D F' D R U > 8) 06.05 F L2 R F2 L U' B2 D' U F' B R2 D' F' B U2 > D' L F' U2 R2 D B' L D' > 9) 05.20 B2 F2 D2 B2 F2 L2 D2 U' B L' F' L2 U' B' L > R B L2 F2 U R U' D F R' > 10) (08.94) B' L D' B' U2 R B2 R2 F D' R' F D R B > D' L2 F2 L F2 D L B2 R2 U > 11) 06.67 F2 B D2 L' F U2 B' F2 U2 L B U D' L' F' > B' R2 D' R2 B' L U2 L' B2 D2 > 12) 07.06 U L' B' F' R D' F D2 B2 L F2 B R B' U L' > B' F' R B' D' F2 D2 L2 D > > =) > > Macky > > > Duncan Dicks <duncan@d...> escreveu: > > Hi Per, > > F1L (nice name!) is an integral part of the L2L4 method which is > anything > > but a beginners method (should be possible to average 50-52 moves > maybe > > under 50). > > Duncan > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > Sent: Wednesday, November 30, 2005 10:22 AM > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: INteresting CHallenge - FL > > > > > > > Hi! I believe this is > > > realistic. The faster the recognition the closer to 45 secs one > > > should get. Probably a little better when I'm mostly awake. > > > I > > >> did all of the decent solves cross followed by 4 corners. > > >> > > >> I'm sure I'm not doing anything optimally, but I think cross > first > > > may > > >> be fewer moves, especially if you're counting in QTM. The worst > > > case > > >> scenario for a corner to be in is either in the top layer with > the > > >> bottom side on the U face or in the wrong spot or orientation on > > > the > > >> first layer. Both of these are easy to fix and generally with > two > > >> generators, which are quite fast. Corners first, you would need > to > > >> make sure to get a good corner case followed by very quick edge > > >> placement. The worst case scenarios for edges are in the wrong > > > spots > > >> and wrongly oriented.
