1254. Re: L/J perm
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Dec 2005 04:41:05 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Let me guess, you just can't decide which of the two OLLs is better > and because you don't want to practice one more often than the other, > you practice them alternatingly. Right? Not quite, but close. When I practice ZBF2L algs, if I want to practice the case when all edges must be flipped, I first flip them all (that's the first OLL), then setup the case using the 2-gen so I don't affect the flipped edges (thats the RUR'U'RUR') and then solve using the ZBF2L alg (the rest). I didn't learn the inverse yet, so this is how I have to practice. > Hey, aren't you embarrassed about your 2.20 seconds video on your > page? Compare to 1.26: > http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/Jperm126.wmv Yes. What algorithm are you using for that case? It looks like I have to switch. :P ~ Bob
1255. World ranking is updated!!!
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Dec 2005 09:13:28 -0000

Just noticed that the world ranking list has been updated with the
results from the world championship. The times are so awesome when you
see 'em all together!!

sub-13 5 guys
sub-15 25 guys
sub-20 88 guys!!!!
sub-30 196 guys
Finished 481 guys

It's amazing that as many as 481 people has competed only this year!!
And it will be a few more names after the swedish competition next
week.

1264. Re: ROUX METHOD Step 4 Possible Improvements
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Dec 2005 16:19:06 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "thomkirjava" > <snkenjoi@g...> wrote: > > > > You should look at this baby. > > > > http://rubikscube.info/lastsix2look.html > > Ok, now the obvious question: How does it compare to Gilles's way? > > Both ways first orient all six edges and place the LU and RU edges, > but they place them at different places. > > Do we know average number of moves for these two methods? > Josef's sequences should give you better results. Various ideas about the last 6 edges and 4 centers: - If you want to solve in less than 12 moves (using sequences mostly based on <M, U>), it's extremely difficult (impossible?). - With many methods you can average about 15 moves. - Josef wanted a 2-look method. In my opinion, it's not quite 2-look, because you need to position UL/UR first. - There's another possibility: Use standard corner-first strategy that inserts the last L/R-edge and orients M-edges, but without taking care of corners positions, and look where you are before the last M/M' move (you're in the middle of UL/UR insertion after orientation). - After orientation or with Josef's technique, instead of solving UL/UR, you can work with UF/UB. Mmmhh.. no. You could save 2 moves, but it makes recognition much more difficult. - With the orientation-first strategy (averaging about 14 moves), inspection does not take more than 2.3 microseconds. Very few things to learn, and you can solve very efficently >70% of cases. Add the standard corners-first technique, a few optimizations, and you reach 90%. Gilles.
1265. Re: L/J perm
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Dec 2005 16:45:18 -0000

Hi Stefan, Bob, Can I play? Gee, R U2 R' U' R U2 L' U R' U' L. Where have I seen that before? http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/2684 Ten moves often being quicker than 11 moves, nowadays I use R U' L U2 R' U R U2 R' L' You've fast fingers, Stefan. Does anyone have software that will show a clip like that one frame at a time? Windows media player used to but that was 6 or 7 versions ago. 1269. 5x5x5 modifications :-)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Dec 2005 17:39:24 -0000

I have sent some recommendations for improving the 5x5x5 cube to
Seventowns. I am now in a dialogue with Steve Perrin, Director of
Design and Production at Seventowns. What i have suggested is to
modify the wings of the outer edges to make the edge-centers glide
over them much more easily. According to Grant Tregay this fix will
make the turning of inner layers a whole lot better and still leave
the cube fairly tight. Anyway, i have tried his modified cube and i
must say it was really awesome. A tight cube eliminates many other
problems, like popping and rotation of the corner centers. I have also
suggested using machine screws and not centers. And i have mentioned
the appalling stickers too.

We will see what comes out of this. I made a diagram (picture) in
order to show him what the problem is and where to modify the outer
edges. If anyone wants to see this drop me a private mail and i will
send it. On popular request i can post it in the photo section also ;-)

Cheers!

-Per





1270. Re: L/J perm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Dec 2005 17:40:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Can I play? Gee, R U2 R' U' R U2 L' U R' U' L. Where have I seen that > before? > > http://games.groups.yahoo. com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/2684 Hehe, same explanation Jasmine gave me when she showed me the alg recently. Then again, she did it somewhat upside down and with wrist turns :-). Hey Jasmine, did you change that by now? I prefer this explanation, though: Start with an easy conjugated commutator 3-cycling corner/edge pairs, followed by U': R [L d2 L', U'] R' U' Replace d2 with (U2 y2) and adjust L/R moves: R L U2 R' U' R U2 L' U R' U' And since the L layer is not changed we can do the L move at the end instead of the awkward start: R U2 R' U' R U2 L' U R' U' L Can someone help me understand/develop this OLL, maybe similarly as I did with the J-perm above? M U R U R' U' M2 U R U' M R' > Ten moves often being quicker than 11 moves, nowadays I use R U' L U2 > R' U R U2 R' L' Hmm, I don't think that would work for me. I don't know how to do the first U2 without regripping and I have problem with R' L' though I might be able to get that right with practice. > You've fast fingers, Stefan. Does anyone have software that will show > a clip like that one frame at a time? Windows media player used to but > that was 6 or 7 versions ago. I use Windows Movie Maker for that (and for creating my videos in the first place). Cheers! Stefan

1272. Re: L/J perm
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Dec 2005 18:06:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Hehe, I hope you're not thinking now that I'm the PLL master... far > from that... there are just 2 or 3 I'm really happy with: T, J and R > (and J/R only the right hand versions). The F perm is slow for me. I > use: > R' U R U' R2 y' R' U' R U (x z') R U R' U' R2 > > Cheers! > Stefan No, I don't think that, but I had seen the videos of the algs you just mentioned and all were extremely fast, so I figured you may have a good one for the F perm. That one you use is very similar to the one I use; only I don't rotate the cube. Well, okay maybe a little. :) It is just that I go from an F to a U that requires my index finger to get over too far that it slows me down at that point. I am experimenting with using my ring finger on my right hand for the U instead (if it is even called your "ring finger" when it is on your right hand). But I can only do that on my competition cube that is very smooth as I don't have the strength in that finger as I do in my index finger. -Dave Campbell

1279. Re: [Speed cubing group] Hey its me...Shamsul...need to ask more questions (REPLY PLZ)
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 1 Dec 2005 16:36:44 -0600

well... a lot of people cube to trance/techno/electronic type music... mainly because the accelerated beats make you want to go faster... but that's purely up to you. i mean, you could use baroque classical music for all i care, and it would still be okay. and about combining cross and petrus... isn't that xcross? On 12/1/05, shamsul khawaja <shamsus2010@...> wrote: > > Srry i havent been on for a long time...just opened my mail (liked the teacher student story) > i learned the notations if u were wondering :D > > now.... > i was gonna make a clip and was wondering where i could get some rubiks cube solving music(some good musice for solving the cube).... can anyone send me some plz?...like the ones u use for ur solving when u record ur self.. > > and i was just starting the other method with the cross... is there a way for me to combine the petrus method with that one since i know that one already.... now i got my average down to 1 min and 50 sec.... still gotta buy a better cube (SO BUSYY NOW A DAYS ) > so plz reply (sooo much mail ...never knew this group sent that much :X) > > > SHAMSUL > > Khawaja > > > > --------------------------------- > Find your next car at Yahoo! Where have I > seen > that > > before? > > > > [1]http://games.groups.yahoo. > com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/2684 > Hehe, same explanation Jasmine gave me when she showed me the > alg > recently. 1281. Re: L/J perm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Dec 2005 23:23:06 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > Can someone help me understand/develop this OLL, maybe similarly as I > did with the J-perm above? > M U R U R' U' M2 U R U' M R' > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > You can start by changing the M R' at the end to an L' ;) Well yeah, I should rewrite the end... but differently. Ok, here's what I mainly think so far. First I add a U' to make the alg "complete", I want to keep the side effects (on the centers) out: M U (R U R' U') M2 (U R U' R') M U' Then rewrite the inner part as a commutator: (M U) [R U R' U', M2] (M' U') Actually I have two commutators there, the inner one is inside [M,U]. The outer one is a bit heavy, but the inner one is easy to understand. So let me build a different alg that achieves the same result: (M U) [R' U R U', M2] (M' U') Or written out and without the U' at the end: M (U R' U R U') M2 (U R' U' R) M Yeah ok, the original was better, (R'M) is nicer than (RM)... But about the [M,U] again. The first M "flips" the UB edge, then U replaces it by another edge which gets flipped with M', then U' restores the corners. Apart from those two flipped edges, two more were "flipped", but on the B side. Same game, the M turns flip and the U turns replace. A fifth edge was involved, too. To fix the latter three edges, the inner commutator is used. Alright, enough with this alg for tonight. Cheers! Stefan

I am now in a dialogue with Steve Perrin, Director of > > Design and Production at Seventowns. What i have suggested is to > > modify the wings of the outer edges to make the edge-centers glide > > over them much more easily. According to Grant Tregay this fix will > > make the turning of inner layers a whole lot better and still leave > > the cube fairly tight. Anyway, i have tried his modified cube and i > > must say it was really awesome. A tight cube eliminates many other > > problems, like popping and rotation of the corner centers. I have also > > suggested using machine screws and not centers. And i have mentioned > > the appalling stickers too. > > > > We will see what comes out of this. I made a diagram (picture) in > > order to show him what the problem is and where to modify the outer > > edges. If anyone wants to see this drop me a private mail and i will > > send it. On popular request i can post it in the photo section also ;-) > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -- > -cubekid >

1284. 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: giraffeboy13 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 00:17:49 -0000

Hey,

I was practicing my 5x5 solves tonight and i can't seem to pull down a
time under 5 minutes. I'm consistently in 5:30 range of times for my
average. I'm using the method given at

http://jjorg.chem.unc.edu/personal/monroe/cube/5by5cube.html

and using an eastsheen cube. I've been consistently in this area for
about 3 weeks now seeing no real improvement or digression. Can
anyone help me out with maybe a few pointers?

Thanks,
John

P.S. Could anyone maybe post a 5x5, 2-3 minute solve video?

1290. Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 01:59:14 -0000

Brand? BRAND?!??!? You young'uns got yerselves too many choices. Why, back in my day, we didn't have any stinkin' brands. We had to chisel our own cubes out of rocks. And there was no silicone, so we had to use spit. And they popped on every turn, resulting in a useless pile of gravel. WE didn't whine. (Sorry, but I'm a little cranky because my speedcube went sour today, resulting in some amazingly unsavory times....) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, eric hatch <washyourmonkey@y...> wrote: > > what cube brand do most people recommend

1294. CLL algs
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 06:39:12 -0000

Hello Everyone,

Please send me CLL Algs!

So far, I have looked at cubewhiz.com (COLL), speedcubing.com,
Masayaki Akimoto's page, Gilles Page (of course), and Lars Petrus'
site (COLL).

I would Ideally like to have a bunch to pick from for each case.
I want to have a complete set of algorithms that I like. With CFOP, I
learned a lot of algorithms (for OLL and PLL), that I didn't really
like and couldn't do fast. I ended up having to learn better algs, or
just stick with mediocre algs. This time around, I want to do it right.

Also, a bunch of Algs I have seen for CLL are also COLL. Im thinking
that there might be shorter sequences for each COLL case Ive seen.
Edge Orientation is not a factor.


Please send anything you have to kovacic81@...

Thank You

Jason Kovacic

1299. Re: CLL algs
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 12:02:07 -0000

OMG :-O Is all i can say to that page. That is crazy! Does one have to learn all the algs for each case ? :-P CLL + OE however is much more than just the CLL. One might need some advice for picking best alg for a CLL case from this page. I'm sure a more user-friendly complete CLL page must exist :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > > Hello Everyone, > > > > Please send me CLL Algs! > > If I were going to try to learn CLL, this is the page I'd use to do it. > > http://satorujnoda.hp.infoseek.co.jp/step3.html > > -Mike > team [zb] > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] >
1300. Re: [Speed cubing group] CLL algs
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>

Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 13:39:40 +0100

What kind of CLL algs are you looking for? Preserving no edges?
Preserving first layer edges? Preserving left and right 1x2x3-edges?
Preserving F2L edges?

/Gustav

>Masayaki Akimoto's page, Gilles Page (of course), and Lars Petrus'
>site (COLL).

>I would Ideally like to have a bunch to pick from for each case.
>I want to have a complete set of algorithms that I like. With CFOP, I
>learned a lot of algorithms (for OLL and PLL), that I didn't really
>like and couldn't do fast. I ended up having to learn better algs, or
>just stick with mediocre algs. This time around, I want to do it right.

>that there might be shorter sequences for each COLL case Ive seen.

1301. Lucky solve, or not?
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 12:50:26 -0000

Hey everybody,

Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L U
F2 B2 D2

Solution: D R2 D' L2 B' U2 R' U' R2 U R' y2 u U L' U' L u' U2 R U R'
U' B' R' F R F' B R2 U R U R' U' R' U' R' U R'

Applet: http://www.math.leidenuniv.nl/~jnoort/solve.htm

Do you guys think this is a lucky solve or not? The two easy factors
are: a very easy X-cross, and a very easy non-matching pair.

So... Lucky, or not? Pretty hard to tell... But if I compare to the
records list, there are also a lot of easy X-crosses and stuff like
that.. Anyway, I'd like to hear your opinion on this.

Cyou!

Joël.

1303. Re: Lucky solve, or not?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 15:00:12 -0000

Hi! I quickly found this solution : U F2 U' L2 R2 U2 B U B' R2 B2 F' U' B' F D R D' R D R2 D' B2 L' B R2 B' L B R2 B (31) Not by using fridrich though ;-) Easy scramble ... -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hey everybody, > > Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L U > F2 B2 D2 > > Solution: D R2 D' L2 B' U2 R' U' R2 U R' y2 u U L' U' L u' U2 R U R' > U' B' R' F R F' B R2 U R U R' U' R' U' R' U R' > > Applet: http://www.math.leidenuniv.nl/~jnoort/solve.htm > > Do you guys think this is a lucky solve or not? 1304. Re: Lucky solve, or not?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 15:11:48 -0000

Hey Joel, I would say not lucky. I mean you planned for every step, and had to know about non-matching pairs and Xcross to do it. The more you know, the more often you get easy cases for the things you know and can get a super nice solve. I'd say non-lucky. My two cents, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hey everybody, > > Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L U > F2 B2 D2 > > Solution: D R2 D' L2 B' U2 R' U' R2 U R' y2 u U L' U' L u' U2 R U R' > U' B' R' F R F' B R2 U R U R' U' R' U' R' U R' > > Applet: http://www.math.leidenuniv.nl/~jnoort/solve.htm > > Do you guys think this is a lucky solve or not? The two easy factors > are: a very easy X-cross, and a very easy non-matching pair. > > So... Lucky, or not? Pretty hard to tell... But if I compare to the > records list, there are also a lot of easy X-crosses and stuff like > that.. Anyway, I'd like to hear your opinion on this. > > Cyou! > > Joël. >
1305. Lucky cases on UWR
From: "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 15:54:25 -0000

I'm speaking specifically about BLD solving, but...

Yesterday I broke my PB for BLD solving. I scrambled with NetCube,
memorised, solved, and looked at the time: 2:24.08. Well, I was pretty
happy with that. But, during my solve, I had just 2 corners wrongly
oriented. So, technically, it's a lucky case. But I was thinking:
I can be lucky on a competition...or not? If Oficcial World Records can
contain lucky cases, why not UWR can list them? Of course there are
cases that are *very* lucky, like skipping OLL or PLL, or having no
corners or no edges to orient (on BLD). But there are cases that are
just a bit lucky. So, why not listing them? And another thing: how is a
case defined as lucky to someone who uses Stefan's method?

Well, just my humble opinion, but...

Pedro





1306. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky solve, or not?
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Dec 2005 16:17:12 +0000 (GMT)

Well, I would solve it this way: U F' U' F' L2 B2 U2 y L' U L U' y L' U' L U2 R U' R' U R U R' F R' F' R U R U' R' U2 R' U' R y R2 u R' U R U' R u' R2 which is 43 moves (without couting cube rotations). Well, actually, this was not the way I solved as soon as I scrambled, but is a good way. :-) And I don't think it's lucky. I agree with Chris, if you didn't know about x-cross and non-matching pairs, you won't solve it that way. Oh, and btw, how was your time for that solve? Pedro cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: Hey Joel, I would say not lucky. I mean you planned for every step, and had to know about non-matching pairs and Xcross to do it. The more you know, the more often you get easy cases for the things you know and can get a super nice solve. I'd say non-lucky. My two cents, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hey everybody, > > Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L U > F2 B2 D2 > > Solution: D R2 D' L2 B' U2 R' U' R2 U R' y2 u U L' U' L u' U2 R U R' > U' B' R' F R F' B R2 U R U R' U' R' U' R' U R' > > Applet: http://www.math.leidenuniv.nl/~jnoort/solve.htm > > Do you guys think this is a lucky solve or not? The two easy factors > are: a very easy X-cross, and a very easy non-matching pair. > > So... Lucky, or not? Pretty hard to tell... But if I compare to the > records list, there are also a lot of easy X-crosses and stuff like > that.. Anyway, I'd like to hear your opinion on this. > > Cyou! > > Joël. > --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. 1307. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky solve, or not?
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Dec 2005 13:29:52 -0300 (ART)

Oh, there's a better way to do that... x-cross: U F' U' F' L2 U' B2 2nd pair: R U R' U' y R U' R' 3rd pair: R' U R 4th pair: U2 L' U L OLL: (U2) F U R U' R' F' PLL: (U') x' R U' R' Ua R' e R' U R D2 F Total: which is (I'm not sure about the Ua) 40 moves! Wow! This is cool! What a good scramble, Joël! Pedro Pedro <pedrosino1@....br> escreveu: Well, I would solve it this way: U F' U' F' L2 B2 U2 y L' U L U' y L' U' L U2 R U' R' U R U R' F R' F' R U R U' R' U2 R' U' R y R2 u R' U R U' R u' R2 which is 43 moves (without couting cube rotations). Well, actually, this was not the way I solved as soon as I scrambled, but is a good way. :-) And I don't think it's lucky. I agree with Chris, if you didn't know about x-cross and non-matching pairs, you won't solve it that way. Oh, and btw, how was your time for that solve? 1309. Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 18:04:12 -0000

I had an idea about something you could do for UWR, but I don't know
if it is lucky or not.

You know how sometimes someone posts a scramble from their 9-12 second
solve on speedcubing.com, or someone posts on their site "try this
scramble, it's fast." Well what if you saved up 13 of them, and took
an average?

You could have 12 extraordinarily easy solves (13 if you pop one),
that would all be random cases and computer scrambled.

Would this be against the rules or not? Obviously this is a moot
point for official competitions, but for the UWP how does this work?

The reason I ask is that I've actually considered doing this, but it
just somehow seems like cheating to me.

Just curious what others think,
Chris

1312. Re: Lucky solve, or not?
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 18:24:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi Joel, > > Definitely lucky. I did it in 34 moves, and I don't solve the cross first. > > Cheers, > > David J I think most people are answering if the scramble is lucky, and not if the solve is lucky  which is what Joël asked. Of course there is a different way to solve it. If you knew God's Algorithm, you would solve every scramble in a lot less moves. If you take his scramble and apply a different method to the solution, you will get a different result. This is changing the solve portion. I think, given the scramble and Joël's solution, I agree with Chris H. It is not lucky as he didn't skip an OLL or PLL by chance; he skipped one CE pair because he knew what to do to preserve it. Someone that didn't do the cross that way may not have saved the CE pair and thus, resulted in a longer solution. What was the time, Joël? If I had to guess, I would say you did that sub 12? -Dave Campbell
1313. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Dec 2005 19:29:48 +0100

The thing is that the number of easy solves that are computer generated have increased since more and more people solve computer generated scrambles and of course, some of them are easy. That's why you now have on the UWR Single solve list a list of easy solves done by very fast people. Although this doesn't reflect the "true value" or "real performance" of a cuber. I have had a few very easy solves also, some of them under 13 seconds. Although I'm really not someone who can solve the cube very very fast (although I start to have more and more sub-10 F2L :D), so I really can't consider that as a good image of my cubing abilities. That's why I don't even look at that UWR of single solves. I mean it's a good thing to be able to solve one cube fast, but I definitely prefer to have a 15 sec average without any sub-13 than a 20 sec average with some sub-13 solves.. Now the big question : if you had to choose, would you prefer to have the single solve of the average world record ? :D 2005/12/2, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>: > I had an idea about something you could do for UWR, but I don't know > if it is lucky or not. > > You know how sometimes someone posts a scramble from their 9-12 second > solve on speedcubing.com, or someone posts on their site "try this > scramble, it's fast." Well what if you saved up 13 of them, and took > an average? > > You could have 12 extraordinarily easy solves (13 if you pop one), > that would all be random cases and computer scrambled. > > Would this be against the rules or not? Obviously this is a moot > point for official competitions, but for the UWP how does this work? > > The reason I ask is that I've actually considered doing this, but it > just somehow seems like cheating to me. > > Just curious what others think, > Chris > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1314. [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 18:38:19 -0000

Hey Gilles, I agree that the average record is a much better indicator of a cuber's skill. But, my question is, what if you compile the scrambles for your average all from super easy solves when other cubers provide the scramble? In that case every solve in your average is a super easy scramble. Is that a "true" average for a person's abilities? Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > The thing is that the number of easy solves that are computer > generated have increased since more and more people solve computer > generated scrambles and of course, some of them are easy. > That's why you now have on the UWR Single solve list a list of easy > solves done by very fast people. Although this doesn't reflect the > "true value" or "real performance" of a cuber. > I have had a few very easy solves also, some of them under 13 seconds. > Although I'm really not someone who can solve the cube very very fast > (although I start to have more and more sub-10 F2L :D), so I really > can't consider that as a good image of my cubing abilities. > > That's why I don't even look at that UWR of single solves. > I mean it's a good thing to be able to solve one cube fast, but I > definitely prefer to have a 15 sec average without any sub-13 than a > 20 sec average with some sub-13 solves.. > > Now the big question : if you had to choose, would you prefer to have > the single solve of the average world record ? :D > > 2005/12/2, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>: > > I had an idea about something you could do for UWR, but I don't know > > if it is lucky or not. > > > > You know how sometimes someone posts a scramble from their 9-12 second > > solve on speedcubing.com, or someone posts on their site "try this > > scramble, it's fast." Well what if you saved up 13 of them, and took > > an average? > > > > You could have 12 extraordinarily easy solves (13 if you pop one), > > that would all be random cases and computer scrambled. > > > > Would this be against the rules or not? Obviously this is a moot > > point for official competitions, but for the UWP how does this work? > > > > The reason I ask is that I've actually considered doing this, but it > > just somehow seems like cheating to me. > > > > Just curious what others think, > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1315. Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 18:42:55 -0000

I would say that depends on what the probability of you having a case as lucky as this is, and also what proportion of your solution it saves. Do you know this information? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > I'm speaking specifically about BLD solving, but... > > Yesterday I broke my PB for BLD solving. I scrambled with NetCube, > memorised, solved, and looked at the time: 2:24.08. Well, I was pretty > happy with that. But, during my solve, I had just 2 corners wrongly > oriented. So, technically, it's a lucky case. But I was thinking: > I can be lucky on a competition...or not? If Oficcial World Records can > contain lucky cases, why not UWR can list them? Of course there are > cases that are *very* lucky, like skipping OLL or PLL, or having no > corners or no edges to orient (on BLD). But there are cases that are > just a bit lucky. So, why not listing them? And another thing: how is a > case defined as lucky to someone who uses Stefan's method? > > Well, just my humble opinion, but... > > Pedro >
1316. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Dec 2005 19:45:57 +0100

Chris, I guess it's not. I mean, if you want to have a perfect idea of the average speed of a cuber : the average should be taken on all the possible configurations of the cube. But everyone knows that it's impossible. So the best answer I can give is : Use a series of computer generated scrambles to do an average. Don't select any that has already be done by someone else. Gilles. 2005/12/2, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>: > Hey Gilles, > > I agree that the average record is a much better indicator of a > cuber's skill. > > But, my question is, what if you compile the scrambles for your > average all from super easy solves when other cubers provide the scramble? > > In that case every solve in your average is a super easy scramble. Is > that a "true" average for a person's abilities? > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > The thing is that the number of easy solves that are computer > > generated have increased since more and more people solve computer > > generated scrambles and of course, some of them are easy. > > That's why you now have on the UWR Single solve list a list of easy > > solves done by very fast people. Although this doesn't reflect the > > "true value" or "real performance" of a cuber. > > I have had a few very easy solves also, some of them under 13 seconds. > > Although I'm really not someone who can solve the cube very very fast > > (although I start to have more and more sub-10 F2L :D), so I really > > can't consider that as a good image of my cubing abilities. > > > > That's why I don't even look at that UWR of single solves. > > I mean it's a good thing to be able to solve one cube fast, but I > > definitely prefer to have a 15 sec average without any sub-13 than a > > 20 sec average with some sub-13 solves.. > > > > Now the big question : if you had to choose, would you prefer to have > > the single solve of the average world record ? :D > > > > 2005/12/2, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>: > > > I had an idea about something you could do for UWR, but I don't know > > > if it is lucky or not. > > > > > > You know how sometimes someone posts a scramble from their 9-12 second > > > solve on speedcubing.com, or someone posts on their site "try this > > > scramble, it's fast." Well what if you saved up 13 of them, and took > > > an average? > > > > > > You could have 12 extraordinarily easy solves (13 if you pop one), > > > that would all be random cases and computer scrambled. > > > > > > Would this be against the rules or not? Obviously this is a moot > > > point for official competitions, but for the UWP how does this work? > > > > > > The reason I ask is that I've actually considered doing this, but it > > > just somehow seems like cheating to me. > > > > > > Just curious what others think, > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
1317. Re: Lucky solve, or not?
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 18:45:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi Joel, > > > > Definitely lucky. I did it in 34 moves, and I don't solve the > cross first. > > > > Cheers, > > > > David J > > > I think most people are answering if the scramble is lucky, and not > if the solve is lucky ? which is what Joël asked. Of course there > is a different way to solve it. If you knew God's Algorithm, you > would solve every scramble in a lot less moves. If you take his > scramble and apply a different method to the solution, you will get > a different result. This is changing the solve portion. > > I think, given the scramble and Joël's solution, I agree with Chris > H. It is not lucky as he didn't skip an OLL or PLL by chance; he > skipped one CE pair because he knew what to do to preserve it. > Someone that didn't do the cross that way may not have saved the CE > pair and thus, resulted in a longer solution. > > What was the time, Joël? If I had to guess, I would say you did > that sub 12? > > -Dave Campbell Your point is taken, however, if the scramble is easily solved then lucky solves are more likely. This may be more easily seen depending on the solving method used. If a short solve occurs in more than one method, then virtually any short solve is lucky. Regards, David J
1318. Re: Buying a StackMat in Europe
From: sgowal <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 19:02:11 -0000

> It's really weird that speedstacks.de doesn't ship anything to
switzerland.
> They did a really good job to send it to Belgium :-)
>
> What's the reason they give you ?

>From what I understood, it's because Switzerland is not in the
European Comminity and thus it is expensive to ship to it.

Sven





1319. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: L/J perm
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Dec 2005 14:29:55 -0500

I was able to look at it with Tmpgenc. Select it as your video source, then File menu/Preview will open a window that you can step through frame by frame. On 12/1/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...> wrote: > You've fast fingers, Stefan. Does anyone have software that will show > a clip like that one frame at a time? Windows media player used to but > that was 6 or 7 versions ago. > > Cheers, > > David J
1320. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Dec 2005 16:46:22 -0300 (ART)

Well, I'm not a probabilites expert, but let's try... You can't have just 1 or 3 or 5 or 7 corners correctly (or incorrectly) oriented. Always even numbers. So, assuming that the probability of one corner being oriented is 1/3, you have 1/9 of probability of having 2 correct corners. The probability of having 4 correct ones is 1/81. For 6 correct corners is 1/729. And for all 8 corners correct is 1/6561. So, the probability of having a case like I had is 1/729. I don't know what proportion of the solve it saved. People solve the cube BLD differently. I use commutators for solving the CO. Really don't know the proportion...: ( Pedro Bob Burton <bob@cubewhiz.com> escreveu: I would say that depends on what the probability of you having a case as lucky as this is, and also what proportion of your solution it saves. Do you know this information? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > I'm speaking specifically about BLD solving, but... > > Yesterday I broke my PB for BLD solving. I scrambled with NetCube, > memorised, solved, and looked at the time: 2:24.08. Well, I was pretty > happy with that. But, during my solve, I had just 2 corners wrongly > oriented. So, technically, it's a lucky case. But I was thinking: > I can be lucky on a competition...or not? If Oficcial World Records can > contain lucky cases, why not UWR can list them? Of course there are > cases that are *very* lucky, like skipping OLL or PLL, or having no > corners or no edges to orient (on BLD). But there are cases that are > just a bit lucky. So, why not listing them? And another thing: how is a > case defined as lucky to someone who uses Stefan's method? > > Well, just my humble opinion, but... > > Pedro > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- --------------------------------- Yahoo! doce lar. Faça do Yahoo! sua homepage. 1323. [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 19:59:39 -0000

You can't have 3 corners incorrectly oriented? R U R' U R U2 R' ? Right? What I meant about the proportion is that for example, if the average number of twisted corners is 6 (which it should be), and you only have to twist two of them, if you normally do two at a time, then you are saving 67% of your CO step for execution, and then saving an additional amount of time by memorizing less. I don't use that BLD method, though, so I'm not sure if this is right. This is based on what I THINK I know. :) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Well, I'm not a probabilites expert, but let's try... > > You can't have just 1 or 3 or 5 or 7 corners correctly (or incorrectly) oriented. For 6 correct corners is 1/729. And for all 8 corners correct is 1/6561. So, the probability of having a case like I had is 1/729. > I don't know what proportion of the solve it saved. People solve the cube BLD differently. I use commutators for solving the CO. 1327. Best... scramble... ever!
From: "Jason Baum" <speedrunningcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 21:14:54 -0000

Hi guys,

Check out this scramble:

R' F B R2 F' R' U D B L' U' B U' B' R F B U2 D' R L' D' F' R' U

7 move double extended cross?!

When I was solving this it felt like it would be a new PR for me after
F2L, but then I got super nervous and messed up the LL like crazy, and
the solve ended up being 12.98. I solved it again and got a 9.9! Too
bad I couldn't do that when it actually mattered :(

My solution:

y' U L2 U R' F R B2 y2 R U' R' U2 R U' R' U R' U R U R' U' R U2 R' U'
R U' F R U R' U' F' M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2

Total number of moves: 40

Try it!

-Jason





1328. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Dec 2005 21:24:36 +0000 (GMT)

Oh, btw, the probabilities I posted were wrong...I forgot to consider that each corner can be on 8 positions (one at a time, of course). So, the correct is: (from Richard Carr's BCFTSS) 0 corners to orient (8 correct) -> 1/2187 (about 0,046%) 2 corners to orient (6 correct) -> 56/2187 (about 2,6%) 3 corners to orient (5 correct) -> 112/2187 (about 5%) 4 corners to orient (you know) -> 420/2187 (about 19,2%) 5 corners to orient ( ... ) -> 560/2187 (about 25,6%) 6 corners to orient ( ... ) -> 616/2187 (about 28,2%) 7 corners to orient ( ... ) -> 336/2187 (about 15,4%) 8 corners to orient ( ... ) -> 86/2187 (about 4%) Well, 2,6% is a low probability, but is just for CO, and what this means on the entire solve I don't know... Pedro Pedro <pedrosino1@yahoo.com.br> escreveu: Yeah, you're right...hehe...you just can't have 1 corner incorrectly oriented. Well, I usually have 4-6 corners to twist.... I'm getting confused...hehe But, like I said, and for the people who use Stefan's method? What's a lucky case? Pedro Bob Burton <bob@cubewhiz.com> escreveu: You can't have 3 corners incorrectly oriented? R U R' U R U2 R' ? Right? What I meant about the proportion is that for example, if the average number of twisted corners is 6 (which it should be), and you only have to twist two of them, if you normally do two at a time, then you are saving 67% of your CO step for execution, and then saving an additional amount of time by memorizing less. I don't use that BLD method, though, so I'm not sure if this is right. This is based on what I THINK I know. :) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Well, I'm not a probabilites expert, but let's try... > > You can't have just 1 or 3 or 5 or 7 corners correctly (or incorrectly) oriented. Always even numbers. So, assuming that the probability of one corner being oriented is 1/3, you have 1/9 of probability of having 2 correct corners. The probability of having 4 correct ones is 1/81. For 6 correct corners is 1/729. And for all 8 corners correct is 1/6561. So, the probability of having a case like I had is 1/729. > I don't know what proportion of the solve it saved. People solve the cube BLD differently. I use commutators for solving the CO. Really don't know the proportion...: ( > > Pedro > > Bob Burton <bob@c...> escreveu: > I would say that depends on what the probability of you having a case > as lucky as this is, and also what proportion of your solution it > saves. Do you know this information? > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" > <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > > > I'm speaking specifically about BLD solving, but... > > > > Yesterday I broke my PB for BLD solving. I scrambled with NetCube, > > memorised, solved, and looked at the time: 2:24.08. Well, I was pretty > > happy with that. But, during my solve, I had just 2 corners wrongly > > oriented. So, technically, it's a lucky case. But I was thinking: > > I can be lucky on a competition...or not? If Oficcial World Records can > > contain lucky cases, why not UWR can list them? Of course there are > > cases that are *very* lucky, like skipping OLL or PLL, or having no > > corners or no edges to orient (on BLD). But there are cases that are > > just a bit lucky. So, why not listing them? And another thing: how is a > > case defined as lucky to someone who uses Stefan's method? > > > > Well, just my humble opinion, but... > > > > Pedro > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! 1330. Re: [Speed cubing group] Best... scramble... ever!
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Dec 2005 18:42:20 -0300 (ART)

I think I'll never find that double-extended cross in 15 seconds...but...your solution was really good. Well, here's what I'll do (after your cross): (y' U L2 U R' F R B2) (L' U' L U2 L' U L) (L U' L' U2 L U' L') (U2 R' F R F' R U2' R' d' L' U L) (R2 U' R' U' R U R U R U' R) Hm...is 44 moves...well, your solution is shorter, but I guess my is faster for me...hehe...every cuber is different, a scramble that is super-easy for me could not be for another person. And that's good. If people were all equal, the world will be veeeeeeeeeeeeery boring... Pedro Jason Baum <speedrunningcuber@...> escreveu: Hi guys, Check out this scramble: R' F B R2 F' R' U D B L' U' B U' B' R F B U2 D' R L' D' F' R' U 7 move double extended cross?! When I was solving this it felt like it would be a new PR for me after F2L, but then I got super nervous and messed up the LL like crazy, and the solve ended up being 12.98. I solved it again and got a 9.9! Too bad I couldn't do that when it actually mattered :( My solution: y' U L2 U R' F R B2 y2 R U' R' U2 R U' R' U R' U R U R' U' R U2 R' U' R U' F R U R' U' F' M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2 Total number of moves: 40 Try it! -Jason SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1331. Re: [Speed cubing group] Best... scramble... ever!
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Dec 2005 21:51:17 +0000 (GMT)

Oh, btw, try this scramble, was my PB of 16.75 U' L' F L2 B2 U F U2 F' L' B R' L' F L U R B R' U' F2 R2 L2 U2 F2 ... ... ... My solution: [cross] (y2) U R F L2 D2 [1st pair] (y) U' R U' R' [2nd pair] (y3) U' L' U' L U' L' U' L [3rd pair] U2' R U R' U R U R' [4th pair] (y2) R U R' U' R U R' [OLL] F R U R' U' F' [PLL] y2 x' L' U L' D2 L U' L' D2 L2 Total: 47 moves. Time: 16.75 seconds Average speed: 2,8 moves/second...yeah, I'm slow Pedro Pedro <pedrosino1@...> escreveu: I think I'll never find that double-extended cross in 15 seconds...but...your solution was really good. Well, here's what I'll do (after your cross): (y' U L2 U R' F R B2) (L' U' L U2 L' U L) (L U' L' U2 L U' L') (U2 R' F R F' R U2' R' d' L' U L) (R2 U' R' U' R U R U R U' R) Hm...is 44 moves...well, your solution is shorter, but I guess my is faster for me...hehe...every cuber is different, a scramble that is super-easy for me could not be for another person. And that's good. If people were all equal, the world will be veeeeeeeeeeeeery boring... When I was solving this it felt like it would be a new PR for me after F2L, but then I got super nervous and messed up the LL like crazy, and the solve ended up being 12.98. I solved it again and got a 9.9! Too bad I couldn't do that when it actually mattered :( My solution: y' U L2 U R' F R B2 y2 R U' R' U2 R U' R' U R' U R U R' U' R U2 R' U' R U' F R U R' U' F' M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2 Total number of moves: 40 Try it! -Jason SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1333. Re: Best... scramble... ever!
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 23:05:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Baum" <speedrunningcuber@y...> wrote: > > Check out this scramble: > R' F B R2 F' R' U D B L' U' B U' B' R F B U2 D' R L' D' F' R' U > > My solution: > y' U L2 U R' F R B2 y2 R U' R' U2 R U' R' U R' U R U R' U' R U2 R' U' > R U' F R U R' U' F' M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2 > > Total number of moves: 40 But that's only in STM :-) Solving the fourth F2L pair with a shorter alg also results in a 6-move OLL and then an edge-3-cycle: y' U L2 U R' F R B2 y2 R U' R' U2 R U' R' U' R2 U2 R U R' U R2 U' F' U' L' U L F y R2 U' R' U' R U R U R U' R 40 HTM Cheers! Stefan

1337. Re: Scrambles
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 23:34:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L U > > F2 B2 D2 > > (1*2*3 in 2 moves? incredible!) What, it doesn't end there! Hey Gilles, try this F2B solve: (l' R') U' r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' L' That's not only short, it also feels great to execute. I bet with some practice one could do this F2B under 2 seconds. Gilles, can you extend this to a short/fast complete Roux solution? Oh, and no, this time I didn't use the computer, I found that myself : -) Cheers! Stefan

1341. Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Dec 2005 23:53:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > You know how sometimes someone posts a scramble from their 9-12 second > solve on speedcubing.com, or someone posts on their site "try this > scramble, it's fast." Well what if you saved up 13 of them, and took > an average? I wouldn't consider these truly "random". With real random scrambles I bet you'd *never* get the same scramble as anybody else anytime anywhere, so if you get 13 in a row that have appeared for someone else, that has nothing to do with randomness. And for the other nitpicker math geeks who already want to type birthday paradox, with "you" I meant Chris alone. Cheers! Stefan

1343. Re: Scrambles
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 00:05:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L U > > F2 B2 D2 > > (1*2*3 in 2 moves? incredible!) > > Once again, easy scrambles that end with many half-turns. I often noticed this fact. Curious. Doesn't necessarily mean much. Look at these scrambles: L2 B2 U L2 R2 U2 F2 R' D R F U2 L B2 D' R D2 L2 U' (19f) L2 B2 D B2 U L2 B2 D2 L' U2 R D B L' R' B' R2 B' D B2 (20f) R2 U2 B2 D F2 U F2 D2 B2 L F D2 U2 F' R' D' U2 F' U' B (20f) That's what you get when you let Cube Explorer make and solve random states. Actually these are what it saves to a file, they're the inverses of what it shows me on its screen when it's running. My point is that its solutions end in <U,D,L2,R2,F2,B2> so that many half-turns at the end aren't surprising, yet these scrambles are even more random than those cheap 25-move-spitters. Cheers! Stefan
1344. [Speed cubing group] Re: L/J perm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 00:16:55 -0000

Hmm, there seem to be several different websites for Tmpgenc, and at least on one of them several different programs with that name (as prefix). Where should I go and which program should I get? Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > > I was able to look at it with Tmpgenc. Select it as your video > source, then File menu/Preview will open a window that you can step > through frame by frame. > > On 12/1/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > You've fast fingers, Stefan. Does anyone have software that will show > > a clip like that one frame at a time? Windows media player used to but > > that was 6 or 7 versions ago. > > > > Cheers, > > > > David J >
1345. [Speed cubing group] Re: L/J perm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 00:38:01 -0000

Ha, I remembered the look and found the program on my computer, had installed it a while ago. Thanks for mentioning it, it's great! Stupid Windows Movie Maker only jumps in 15 fps steps for 30 fps videos and Tmpgenc shows all frames so I can measure more exactly now. I found out that my J-perm video was actually 1.20 seconds (in reality probably even a bit less) and this T-perm was 1.30 seconds, not 1.33: http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/Tperm130.wmv It also loads faster than Movie Maker and it seems to show better quality. I have a new favourite video analysis program :-) Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Hmm, there seem to be several different websites for Tmpgenc, and at > least on one of them several different programs with that name (as > prefix). Where should I go and which program should I get? > > Cheers! > Stefan > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > > > I was able to look at it with Tmpgenc. Select it as your video > > source, then File menu/Preview will open a window that you can step > > through frame by frame. > > > > On 12/1/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > You've fast fingers, Stefan. Does anyone have software that will > show > > > a clip like that one frame at a time? Windows media player used to > but > > > that was 6 or 7 versions ago. > > > > > > Cheers, > > > > > > David J > > >

1347. Re: Scrambles
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 01:04:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > > Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L U > > > F2 B2 D2 > > > > (1*2*3 in 2 moves? incredible!) > > What, it doesn't end there! Hey Gilles, try this F2B solve: > (l' R') U' r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' L' Ok, your step 3 table is easy to understand so I included step 3 as well, though with the alg rotated. And I replaced the L' with l' at the end of F2B. Here are my first three steps: (l' R') U' r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' l' R' F R F' U2 F' U2 F U Some combinations result in: x R2 U' r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' R2 x F R F' U2 F' U2 F U 20 moves HTM and you're at step 4 with 6 edges left. But your step 4 page scares me :-) Cheers! Stefan
1348. Re: Scrambles
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 01:30:22 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > > Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L U > > > F2 B2 D2 > > > > (1*2*3 in 2 moves? incredible!) > > What, it doesn't end there! Hey Gilles, try this F2B solve: > (l' R') U' r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' L' > > That's not only short, it also feels great to execute. I bet with some > practice one could do this F2B under 2 seconds. > > Gilles, can you extend this to a short/fast complete Roux solution? With this start, I didn't find a *very* short solution, but look at this one: [F2B] xRrU'r2U2M'Ur2 [CMLL] y'U2RU'R'yL'U'R [6E4C] U2MUz2U2M'U2M' 22 moves, my best (Speed-)FMC. Sub-5s ? Dr Roux
1349. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: L/J perm
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Dec 2005 20:40:32 -0500

I got it here: http://www.tmpgenc.net/e_download.html On 12/2/05, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> wrote: > Hmm, there seem to be several different websites for Tmpgenc, and at > least on one of them several different programs with that name (as > prefix). Where should I go and which program should I get? > > Cheers! > Stefan
1350. Re: Scrambles
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 01:48:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > > Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L U > > > F2 B2 D2 > > > > (1*2*3 in 2 moves? incredible!) > > What, it doesn't end there! Hey Gilles, try this F2B solve: > (l' R') U' r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' L' > > That's not only short, it also feels great to execute. I bet with some > practice one could do this F2B under 2 seconds. > > Gilles, can you extend this to a short/fast complete Roux solution? > > Oh, and no, this time I didn't use the computer, I found that myself : > -) > > Cheers! > Stefan You should change the (l'R') at the beginning of your solve to x R2. It saves a move and flows a little better. Finish with y R d (L'U'L) B' U'(L'U2 L) U M' U2 M' U M u' M' D2 M D2 for a typical end. I think the total in STM winds up as 33 that way. Not bad at all. I've gotten sub 11 on this solve this way. However, if you finish with y R d (L'U'L) B' U'(L'U2 L) U M' U2 M' U, but continue with r R d' M' U2 M' d' R2 it's a little easier to perform. I've tried finishing this solve with every possible orientation trick and placement trick I know, but I can't seem to find anything better than that. :( -Mike team [zb]
1351. Re: Scrambles
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 02:10:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L > U > > > > F2 B2 D2 > > > > > > (1*2*3 in 2 moves? incredible!) > > > > What, it doesn't end there! Hey Gilles, try this F2B solve: > > (l' R') U' r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' L' > > Ok, your step 3 table is easy to understand so I included step 3 as > well, though with the alg rotated. And I replaced the L' with l' at > the end of F2B. Here are my first three steps: > > (l' R') U' > r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' l' > R' F R F' U2 F' U2 F U > > Some combinations result in: > > x R2 U' r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' R2 x F R F' U2 F' U2 F U > > 20 moves HTM and you're at step 4 with 6 edges left. But your step 4 > page scares me :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan
1352. Re: Scrambles
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 02:52:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Scramble: F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L > U > > > > F2 B2 D2 > > > > > > (1*2*3 in 2 moves? incredible!) > > > > What, it doesn't end there! Hey Gilles, try this F2B solve: > > (l' R') U' r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' L' > > Ok, your step 3 table is easy to understand so I included step 3 as > well, though with the alg rotated. And I replaced the L' with l' at > the end of F2B. Here are my first three steps: > > (l' R') U' > r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' l' > R' F R F' U2 F' U2 F U > > Some combinations result in: > > x R2 U' r2 U' r' R' F U F r U' R2 x F R F' U2 F' U2 F U > > 20 moves HTM and you're at step 4 with 6 edges left. But your step 4 > page scares me :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan With the start x R2 U' r2 U' r' R' you can follow U R U' l2 L y' U' (L'U'L) for the complete F2L in 15 moves. I couldn't find a decent way to end this, even using a ZB alg. Still a 30+ move solve. Or you can start with x R2 U' r2 U' R' U L' U' r' U R U' M2 to solve F2l in 13, finishing with y2 (R' F R) F' d' (L' U L) U' L2 d' M U2 M' d' R2 for a nice 29 move solve, including OLL and PLL steps. -Mike team [zb]

From: kvvickykanny <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 08:09:45 -0000

Greetings.

With the avg. time of 50 seconds, and not improving over the last many
month. The time has come to give up finally on the speed cubing, and
I say goodbye to Group S.S.R.C. We wish all of you, the very best. I
knew that speed cubing will not be my sport. Farewell.

Farewell,
K. Kanny

1358. Re: [Speed cubing group] 5x5x5 speed solving
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 3 Dec 2005 10:27:23 +0100

For the 4x4 : I prefer the Rubik's one because it's very easy to see the pieces ant it's a bit bigger. For the 5x5 : It depends on the part of the cube I solve: If I solve the centers and the edges : I prefer the eastsheen one If I solve it as a 3x3 : I prefer the Rubik's one The biggest issue for the eastsheen 5x5 is that you really need to have the layers aligned to be able to turn it, which is not exactly the case for the Rubik's 5x5. Gilles. 2005/12/3, washyourmonkey <washyourmonkey@...>: > which or the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 cubes do most of you prefer and why? > eastsheen or rubiks? > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >

From: giraffeboy13 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 14:02:17 -0000

Yeah, I totally agree. I really enjoy solving my eastsheen cube but my times just aren't as fast as they are with the rubiks cube (not that they're all that fast really... need to work on that) My only issue with rubiks is that i need to figure out a way to make it turn better. Mine's reall stiff, and when i lubed it last night, it actually seemed to get stiffer... anyone know if rubik's 5x5s have screws? Any speed 5x5ers have any recommendations on loosening up a rubik's model? ~John~ --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > For the 4x4 : I prefer the Rubik's one because it's very easy to see > the pieces ant it's a bit bigger. > > For the 5x5 : > It depends on the part of the cube I solve: > If I solve the centers and the edges : I prefer the eastsheen one > If I solve it as a 3x3 : I prefer the Rubik's one > > The biggest issue for the eastsheen 5x5 is that you really need to > have the layers aligned to be able to turn it, which is not exactly > the case for the Rubik's 5x5. > > Gilles.

1361. Re: [Speed cubing group] 5x5x5 speed solving
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 14:21:36 -0000

Recemmendations: - Use the cube a lot (im serious, this helps!) - If the cube is really tight, wait some weeks (50-100 solves) before lubing for the first time. - It is possible to use a flat knife to bend the layers. Im very uncertain if this has any effect on the rivets though. - Disassemble the cube many times over. I know this helps. It helps loosening any puzzle. - Sand down the wings of outer edges, like mentioned in my earlier post, and suggested to me by Grant Tregay. Good luck ! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, giraffeboy13 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Yeah, I totally agree. I really enjoy solving my eastsheen cube but > my times just aren't as fast as they are with the rubiks cube (not > that they're all that fast really... need to work on that) My only > issue with rubiks is that i need to figure out a way to make it turn > better. Mine's reall stiff, and when i lubed it last night, it > actually seemed to get stiffer... anyone know if rubik's 5x5s have > screws? Any speed 5x5ers have any recommendations on loosening up a > rubik's model? > > ~John~ > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > For the 4x4 : I prefer the Rubik's one because it's very easy to see > > the pieces ant it's a bit bigger. > > > > For the 5x5 : > > It depends on the part of the cube I solve: > > If I solve the centers and the edges : I prefer the eastsheen one > > If I solve it as a 3x3 : I prefer the Rubik's one > > > > The biggest issue for the eastsheen 5x5 is that you really need to > > have the layers aligned to be able to turn it, which is not exactly > > the case for the Rubik's 5x5. > > > > Gilles. >

1363. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: L/J perm
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 3 Dec 2005 12:05:54 -0300 (ART)

Have you tried FrameShots? It's really good, you can play at 40 fps...(each frame as 0.025 seconds) http://www.frame-shots.com/ Indicated to me by Joël Thanks, Joël Pedro Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@gmx.de> escreveu: Ha, I remembered the look and found the program on my computer, had installed it a while ago. Thanks for mentioning it, it's great! Stupid Windows Movie Maker only jumps in 15 fps steps for 30 fps videos and Tmpgenc shows all frames so I can measure more exactly now. I found out that my J-perm video was actually 1.20 seconds (in reality probably even a bit less) and this T-perm was 1.30 seconds, not 1.33: http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/Tperm130.wmv It also loads faster than Movie Maker and it seems to show better quality. I have a new favourite video analysis program :-) Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Hmm, there seem to be several different websites for Tmpgenc, and at > least on one of them several different programs with that name (as > prefix). 1367. Re: Scrambles
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 15:48:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > Scramble: > F2 L2 B' U' D R2 L2 U2 D F R2 B R L' F' L' R' F D2 B L U F2 B2 D2 > > Or you can start with x R2 U' r2 U' R' U L' U' r' U R U' M2 to solve > F2l in 13, finishing with y2 (R' F R) F' d' (L' U L) U' L2 d' M U2 M' > d' R2 for a nice 29 move solve, including OLL and PLL steps. Heh, I solve that OLL differently, resulting in this: x R2 U' r2 U' R' U L' U' r' U R U' M2 y2 F R' F' R U R U' R' R U2 R' U' R U2 L' U R' U' L It's the J-perm :-). Cancelling moves and doing the y2 at the start you get this: x y2 L2 U' l2 U' L' U R' U' l' U L U' M2 F R' F' R U R U R' U' R U2 L' U R' U' L 29 STM, 30 HTM! Gonna practice this and make a video... Cheers! Stefan

It only shows me 20 fps. Also, how can it show 40 fps when the video only has 30 fps? Thanks, Stefan
1369. [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 16:17:03 -0000

Bah, I feel like nobody even saw my typo-joke :-( Ok, now about lucky cases with my method. Well, the rules say: For blindfold solving a lucky case is defined by: 1) more than 5 corners are correctly oriented, or 2) more than 8 edges are correctly oriented, or 3) more than 3 corners are correctly positioned, or 4) more than 4 edges are correctly positioned. Obviously the writer didn't know my method :-). I don't consider 1) or 2) lucky since correct orientation doesn't help me at at all, actually "orientation" doesn't even exist for me unless a piece is correctly positioned. For 3) and 4) I don't count correctly positioned pieces with bad orientation, since these are just as hard as "normal", i.e. mispositioned pieces. For me I'd say a lucky case is defined by: 1) more than 2 corners are correctly positioned and oriented, or 2) more than 3 edges are correctly positioned and oriented. Those are the only cases that really save work. I lowered the number a bit, though. Not sure they're good now, I don't know where the original numbers came from, but I think these rules come very close to what it optimally should be. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Ok, ok, sorry... > > you can't have *just 1 corner incorrectly oriented*. > > But, you didn't answer my question...about the lucky cases... Stefan, what do you consider a lucky case with you BLD method? > > Pedro > > thomkirjava <snkenjoi@g...> escreveu: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> > > wrote: > > > > > > You can't have just 1 or 3 or 5 or 7 corners correctly > > > (or incorrectly) oriented. > > > > Are you sune? > > > > (ok ok, so that joke came too late... leave me alone) > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > You can in BLD, can't you? > > You have a Sune shape on top and a Bruno on the bottom. Surly that's > only one corner correct. > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! doce lar. 1371. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: L/J perm
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 3 Dec 2005 13:28:53 -0300 (ART)



Hmm, how do you make it play 40 fps? It only shows me 20 fps. Also,
how can it show 40 fps when the video only has 30 fps?

>Well, I don't know. hehe. It just goes at 0.025 seconds when I press the right arrow. To choose the frame rate, just put the "skip amount" bar at the very left. Then, press the right arrow. It will show: position 00:00:00.025, then 00:00:00.050, and so.

Pedro

Thanks,
Stefan

1373. Re: Scrambles
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 17:45:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > but watching a more realistic speedsolve is also nice. Ok, a much more realistic example of speedcubing. - Inspection (Too) Easy 1st block, let's try to look ahead. You can see that if you finish the block in a very simple way, RFD and RF will be aligned, and DR's place in R-layer will be preserved. - 1st bloc Seq: xR2U - 2nd bloc Seq:r2U'R'Ul'U'M2R'UR Comment: Solve the 1x2x2 prepared during inspection with r2U'R'Ul'. For the last pair, align BDR with BR (U'), and solve it. The last move is a R and not a r to preserve centers orientation. - Corners Seq: U2lULU'R'UL'U'x Comment: The first U2 aligns U-layer to match my way of analyzing this orientation pattern. - 6 edges + 4 centers Seq:M'UMUMUMU2M'UM'U2M2 Comment:At this end of the previous step, before the last x, I've located the positions of UL and UR. In this configuration, do an M' move and 3 wrongly oriented edges will appear on top. Then, I do UMUM and not UMUM' because having both UL and UR in U-layer is not what I want. UMU2M'UM'U2M2 solves UL+UR and permutes M-edges. Gilles.
1374. Sudoku World update
From: "Frank Vedel" <frank.vedel@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 18:22:06 -0000

Hi,

This is an invitation to join Sudoku World, which is a yahoo based
international meeting place for Sudoku addicts.

Sudoku World was created on June, 25, and now we are 1307 members
from 47 countries.

The age of our Sudoku World members vary from 14 to 83!!! More than
43% of our members are female.

Sudoku World offers:

- useful information on the game and strategy,
- an active message board with more than 1.215 messages,
- lots of links to millions of Sudoku puzzles. A special section for
the Japanese Sudoku variants is very popular,
- links to many different Sudoku forums
- lots of printable Sudoku puzzle files and help grids,
- 1 closed and 9 ongoing Sudoku related polls.
- 143 photos with a recommended Sudoku literature section and many
of the new Japanese Sudoku puzzle variations including:
- samurai puzzles (also several hybrid puzzles!!),
- onsecutive numbers,
- sum Sudokus,
- product Sudoku,
- more or less Sudokus,
- arrow Sudokus
- irregular groups Sudokus,
- extra groups Sudokus,
- 8 and 12 number cube Sudokus
- hexagon Sudokus,
- total sum Sudoku,
- sum, difference, more or less Sudoku,
- more or less or equal Sudoku,
- demarcated Sudokus,
- sequential sudokus and
- colour Sudokus
- wordoku and
- brick Sudokus.

You will find Sudoku World here:

http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/Sudokuworld

You don't have to be a black belt Sudoku solver to become a member
of Sudoku World, because all ages, and all standards, beginners to
advanced Sudoku puzzlers, are welcome.

We all hope to meet you there!

Kind regards,

Frank Vedel - MY days are numbered - are yours?

PS! We even have a small kakuro section

1377. Re: [Speed cubing group] Congratulation.
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 20:38:57 -0000

Hey, I agree, don't give up just because you're improvement has slowed. My times were also around 50 seconds for a few months straight. Don't get frustrated by the times you see from others, remember that everyone used to be at 50 seconds because everyone who can solve it used to not be able to solve it. What got me past 50 seconds was learning a better method. The method I was using at the time was a beginner method, and I switched to a more speedcubing style method. There are lots of methods to choose from, all of which are fast, so just find the one you like. Don't get frustrated, not everyone who cubes is super fast at improving their times. You can get fast times too, just remember that the method you use and the finger tricks and styles you use all influence your time. If you are already using a speedcubing method framework, try learning more algs. All the methods have lots of additional algs you can learn that help speed up your times. How do you solve and how many algs do you use in general? Try new things, and experiment too. Maybe you'll find that you like the 2x2x2, or 4x4x4, or fewest moves cubing more than speedcubing. Don't give up though, not everyone improves super quickly. It took me over 4 years just to get a sub-20 average, whereas most people do it in under a year. We normal people do in fact exist, and I'm still convinced that all the others are cubing robots :-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I agree w/ Sachin; don't just give it up. You don't have to get > sub 20 times to enjoy the cube. and there are always walls you have > to get over where sometimes your times just don't drop but then you > stick with it and then they do. sometimes even after a little > break, ironically. Hang in there! > --Kirk > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar > <sachinss@g...> wrote: > > > > Hey you are not serious are you? > > > > Please dont give up on cubing. I am sure you must be very desperate > > right now to improve your times but giving up altogether is not the > > option. Do take a break of a couple of weeks and then resume > again. I > > also had many times where i wanted to giveup on cubing altogether > but > > i kept my cool, took a break and again i find it interesting. > > > > Plz dont give up > > Sachin. > > > > > > On 12/3/05, kvvickykanny <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > > Greetings. > > > > > > With the avg. time of 50 seconds, and not improving over the > last many > > > month. The time has come to give up finally on the speed > cubing, and > > > I say goodbye to Group S.S.R.C. We wish all of you, the very > best. I > > > knew that speed cubing will not be my sport. Farewell. > > > > > > Farewell, > > > K. Kanny > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

1379. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 3 Dec 2005 21:26:27 +0000 (GMT)

Oh, and there's one more thing:

A while ago, Stefan posted something to people who use cycle method for BLD. You can manipulate the centers to have a better CO. So, suppose I have a bad CO, like 7 corners to flip. But, if I do that center cycling, I can have just 2 or 3. So, I transformed a non-lucky case into a lucky one. Or not? Is this accepted on UWR?

Pedro
