1380. Re: [Speed cubing group] 5x5x5 speed solving
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 3 Dec 2005 22:45:26 +0100

This might seem stupid, but my Rubik's 5x5 was put in a cold place just after I lubed it. And the result is that it turned a lot more better than before. So maybe you could try to lube it and then put it in the fridge for the night (I'm serious) Gilles. 2005/12/3, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...>: > Recemmendations: > > - Use the cube a lot (im serious, this helps!) > > - If the cube is really tight, wait some weeks (50-100 solves) > before lubing for the first time. > > - It is possible to use a flat knife to bend the layers. Im very > uncertain if this has any effect on the rivets though. > > - Disassemble the cube many times over. I know this helps. It helps > loosening any puzzle. > > - Sand down the wings of outer edges, like mentioned in my earlier > post, and suggested to me by Grant Tregay. > > Good luck ! > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, giraffeboy13 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Yeah, I totally agree. I really enjoy solving my eastsheen cube > but > > my times just aren't as fast as they are with the rubiks cube (not > > that they're all that fast really... need to work on that) My only > > issue with rubiks is that i need to figure out a way to make it > turn > > better. Mine's reall stiff, and when i lubed it last night, it > > actually seemed to get stiffer... anyone know if rubik's 5x5s have > > screws? Any speed 5x5ers have any recommendations on loosening up > a > > rubik's model? > > > > ~John~ > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > For the 4x4 : I prefer the Rubik's one because it's very easy to > see > > > the pieces ant it's a bit bigger. > > > > > > For the 5x5 : > > > It depends on the part of the cube I solve: > > > If I solve the centers and the edges : I prefer the eastsheen one > > > If I solve it as a 3x3 : I prefer the Rubik's one > > > > > > The biggest issue for the eastsheen 5x5 is that you really need > to > > > have the layers aligned to be able to turn it, which is not > exactly > > > the case for the Rubik's 5x5. > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1381. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 3 Dec 2005 22:51:51 +0100

This is the definition of a lucky case (according to speedcubing.com) : --- A lucky record is any solve of a puzzle where a step of your normal solution is skipped. There are three exceptions: 1) You worked for it, f.i. by anticipating the next step. 2) The chance to skip the step is 20 percent or more. 3) The skipped step represents 3 percent or less of the total moves of the complete solution. Example: if you use the cross/F2L/OLL/PLL system, then there are 7 steps, and skipping one of the steps would be a lucky case. For blindfold solving a lucky case is defined by: 1) more than 5 corners are correctly oriented, or 2) more than 8 edges are correctly oriented, or 3) more than 3 corners are correctly positioned, or 4) more than 4 edges are correctly positioned. --- So if you do that center cycling intentionally, I would say you are in the first exception "You worked for it" = Non-Lucky, even though it's contrary to the definition of a lucky case definition for a blindfold solve. But that's just my opinion. And talking about lucky cases is just silly by the way. I mean you can always win a lottery, but what if you can find a way to win all the times ? I'll try not to talk anymore about lucky cases. Gilles. 2005/12/3, Pedro <pedrosino1@....br>: > Oh, and there's one more thing: > > A while ago, Stefan posted something to people who use cycle method for BLD. You can manipulate the centers to have a better CO. So, suppose I have a bad CO, like 7 corners to flip. But, if I do that center cycling, I can have just 2 or 3. So, I transformed a non-lucky case into a lucky one. Or not? Is this accepted on UWR? > > Pedro > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! doce lar. Faça do Yahoo! sua homepage. > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1382. [Speed cubing group] solving a virtual cube sing a keyboard
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>

Date: Sat, 3 Dec 2005 23:06:44 +0100

Hello,

I'm looking for a program like Gabbasoft Cube Demo (basically a
virtual cube) that I can control by using the keyboard.
Eventually I'd like to use that as a password system to logon to my computer :p

Do you know any program that could do it ? (being solved with a
keyboard, the logon system is not important lol).

Thanks,
Gilles.


1383. Re: [Speed cubing group] solving a virtual cube sing a keyboard
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 22:33:58 -0000

Speaking of cool cube locking mechanisms, is it possible to fashion some sort of locking mechanism out of a 3x3x3 keychain cube? Or if that would require working with pieces that are too small, a regular 3x3x3 cube? I just think it would be cool to lock up a cabinet or locker or something with a scrambled cube. You could even set the opening combination of the lock to a cool pattern, so even people who know how to solve the cube can't open it, unless they know which pattern :-) Ok maybe this is a little too out there, but I thought it would be cool. Gilles I think that is a very cool idea to have a computer logon be solving a cube. Perhaps you should set the combination to the superflip or something, so you can even trick people who know how to solve the cube ;-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Hello, > > I'm looking for a program like Gabbasoft Cube Demo (basically a > virtual cube) that I can control by using the keyboard. > Eventually I'd like to use that as a password system to logon to my computer :p > > Do you know any program that could do it ? Date: Sat, 3 Dec 2005 15:11:51 -0800

I beleive Lars Petrus' cube applet has the option of mouse or keys. -E On 12/3/05, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...> wrote: > > haha... that would be frickin awesome.... can't wait to see that happen > > On 12/3/05, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > Speaking of cool cube locking mechanisms, is it possible to fashion > > some sort of locking mechanism out of a 3x3x3 keychain cube? Or if > > that would require working with pieces that are too small, a regular > > 3x3x3 cube? > > > > I just think it would be cool to lock up a cabinet or locker or > > something with a scrambled cube. You could even set the opening > > combination of the lock to a cool pattern, so even people who know how > > to solve the cube can't open it, unless they know which pattern :-) > > > > Ok maybe this is a little too out there, but I thought it would be cool. > > > > Gilles I think that is a very cool idea to have a computer logon be > > solving a cube. 1387. [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Dec 2005 23:52:41 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Oh, and there's one more thing: > > A while ago, Stefan posted something to people who use cycle > method for BLD. You can manipulate the centers to have a better CO. Little correction: that was intended for *any* 3x3 BLD method. I just see a larger advantage for those who orient and permute separately. I don't see a big advantage for my own method, which, btw, *is* a cycle method, too. As far as I know, only Dave Orser and Richard Carr might be doing something different than cycle-methods, but they do orient first, so my idea certainly applied to their method, too! Cheers! Stefan

Maybe maybe that might work in the peaceful hidden area of the math department, but in the real world you'd need at least a hard metal cube to make that work... Cheers! Stefan

Yeah, I know your method is a cycle method...but, you didn't answer my question...With that thing, you can take a non-lucky case and make it be a lucky case. And is that considered lucky? Pedro Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> escreveu: --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Oh, and there's one more thing: > > A while ago, Stefan posted something to people who use cycle > method for BLD. You can manipulate the centers to have a better CO. Little correction: that was intended for *any* 3x3 BLD method. I just see a larger advantage for those who orient and permute separately. I don't see a big advantage for my own method, which, btw, *is* a cycle method, too. As far as I know, only Dave Orser and Richard Carr might be doing something different than cycle-methods, but they do orient first, so my idea certainly applied to their method, too! Cheers! 1390. Re: Scrambles
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 00:05:49 -0000

Hi Gilles, thanks a lot for the detailed analysis! You should put that example (including the scramble) on your website. Haha, I was about to say you had no example solves on your site. To be sure I looked closer again and found some, but they're hidden and hard to find :-). Also, there's no explanation so I'd still recommend putting this one on your site. Oh, and can you split the 6x1 block of applets into a 3x2 block? At least my browser (Opera) shows them in one long line, widening the page and making the texts harder to read cause I have to scroll left and right... Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > but watching a more realistic speedsolve is also nice. > > > Ok, a much more realistic example of speedcubing. > > - Inspection > > (Too) Easy 1st block, let's try to look ahead. You can see that if you > finish the block in a very simple way, RFD and RF will be aligned, and > DR's place in R-layer will be preserved. > > - 1st bloc > > Seq: xR2U > > - 2nd bloc > > Seq:r2U'R'Ul'U'M2R'UR > Comment: Solve the 1x2x2 prepared during inspection with r2U'R'Ul'. > For the last pair, align BDR with BR (U'), and solve it. The last move > is a R and not a r to preserve centers orientation. > > - Corners > > Seq: U2lULU'R'UL'U'x > Comment: The first U2 aligns U-layer to match my way of analyzing this > orientation pattern. > > - 6 edges + 4 centers > > Seq:M'UMUMUMU2M'UM'U2M2 > Comment:At this end of the previous step, before the last x, I've > located the positions of UL and UR. In this configuration, do an M' > move and 3 wrongly oriented edges will appear on top. Then, I do UMUM > and not UMUM' because having both UL and UR in U-layer is not what I > want. UMU2M'UM'U2M2 solves UL+UR and permutes M-edges. > > Gilles. >
1391. [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 00:11:59 -0000

Hi Gilles, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > This is the definition of a lucky case (according to speedcubing.com) : > > [SNIP (ADEE DO DAH)] > > And talking about lucky cases is just silly by the way. > I mean you can always win a lottery, but what if you can find a way to > win all the times ? > I'll try not to talk anymore about lucky cases. > > Gilles. If you can understand the cube well enough and look ahead well enough there are no lucky cubes. Cheers, David J
1392. [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 00:14:06 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Yeah, I know your method is a cycle method...but, you didn't answer my question...With that thing, you can take a non-lucky case and make it be a lucky case. And is that considered lucky? Main reason why I didn't answer is I don't really know what to say. I think it depends on the method and how you see it. If you use that centers technique as a normal part of your method, i.e. you don't have a fixed cube orientation, then you can't even tell what is oriented and what is not. The further you go away from the "standard" method the rules author had in mind, the harder it gets to apply those rules. Don't worry too much about it. In official competitions it doesn't matter whether you're lucky, and in the UWR lists the single records aren't worth much. So just do an average. Cheers! Stefan
1393. Re: [Speed cubing group] solving a virtual cube sing a keyboard
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 00:16:55 -0000

Hi Chris, Have a circuit inside the cube which is only completed when the cube is in a particular configuration. When it gets there it sends out a signal which unlocks the safe. This is not hard at all, and could be done with technology available. Cheers! David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Speaking of cool cube locking mechanisms, is it possible to fashion > some sort of locking mechanism out of a 3x3x3 keychain cube? Or if > that would require working with pieces that are too small, a regular > 3x3x3 cube? > > I just think it would be cool to lock up a cabinet or locker or > something with a scrambled cube. You could even set the opening > combination of the lock to a cool pattern, so even people who know how > to solve the cube can't open it, unless they know which pattern :-) > > Ok maybe this is a little too out there, but I thought it would be cool. > > Gilles I think that is a very cool idea to have a computer logon be > solving a cube. Perhaps you should set the combination to the > superflip or something, so you can even trick people who know how to > solve the cube ;-) > > Chris >
1394. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 3 Dec 2005 21:24:07 -0300 (ART)

Well, doing an average of BLD solves is not so easy... but, what do you think? should I post that record? or just wait until I make a better time? Pedro Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> escreveu: --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Yeah, I know your method is a cycle method...but, you didn't answer my question...With that thing, you can take a non-lucky case and make it be a lucky case. And is that considered lucky? Main reason why I didn't answer is I don't really know what to say. I think it depends on the method and how you see it. If you use that centers technique as a normal part of your method, i.e. you don't have a fixed cube orientation, then you can't even tell what is oriented and what is not. The further you go away from the "standard" method the rules author had in mind, the harder it gets to apply those rules. Don't worry too much about it. In official competitions it doesn't matter whether you're lucky, and in the UWR lists the single records aren't worth much. So just do an average. Cheers! Stefan SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1395. [Speed cubing group] Re: Lucky cases on UWR
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 01:19:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Well, doing an average of BLD solves is not so easy... > but, what do you think? should I post that record? The one where six corners were correctly oriented, right? Depends on your method, I'd say. If for example you use my method then unless those pieces were correctly placed as well, I think it shouldn't be considered lucky. If however your method involves first orienting all pieces (particularly the corners) then the rules are made for you and thus it's a lucky case which you shouldn't post. Similarly in speedcubing, what if you're a Fridrich solver and the cross is already solved after scrambling? Definitely lucky. The same cube, for a pure corners-first solver? Probably not lucky (at least not because of the solved cross). It always depends on your method, and also the actual solve in case you have choices. Blindsolving 3x3 for example does not offer many choices, you almost "read" the solution deterministically, and even the choices you make usually don't change the difficulty of the solve much. In speedsolving this is more important, since already for example how you build the cross has large effects on the rest of the solve. Cheers! Stefan
1396. Hard evidence for opposite color + Xcross combo solving
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 08:50:03 -0000

Hey everyone,

I am by no means an expert at the F2L. I think I used to average
around 11-12 seconds before switching to opposite color + Xcross combo
solving.

Well I took an F2L average tonight and am now sub-10! All I changed
from my 11-12 second averages was to add in opposite color solving.

Now I am pretty nearly 1-(1-x)^2 times more likely to get good solves
(where x is my good solve frequency on one color) as I used to be.
That is very, very noticeable!! Of course I can't always notice well
setup Xcross's on my opposite color, but I can always spot a good
cross. I hope to change that soon with more practice and always spot
the good opposite color Xcross solves.

Anyway here was the average:
11.50, 8.86, 9.69, 10.18, 10.78, (7.20), 9.41, (12.68), 11.20, 7.94,
9.62, 8.36 = 9.75 seconds

The thing is, I am not a sub-10 F2L solver if I solve the same color
every time. However, with the combination of opposite color as well
as Xcross, and not just Xcross, I can now call myself a sub-10 F2L
solver :-)

Think what you already sub-10 solvers could do with opposite color
solving ;-)

Chris





1397. Spreading the Cube
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 11:55:07 -0000

Hi all,

The holidays are coming up soon, which means some free time for most
cubers! With this extra time, not only could we improve ourselves, we
could teach others how much fun the cube really is. Lets each make a
goal to teach at least one person to solve the cube before the new
year. There are plenty of people around us all the time that may be
curious about the cube, but are too shy or intimidated to ask about it!

Happy Cubing Always,

Richard

1401. my 3x3 algs
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 13:26:56 -0000

I've found and posted some algs I found myself (mostly with help of ACube) in the past and every time somebody asked for one I had to recreate it slowly. So finally I now created a page to collect them at one place: http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/speedsolving/3x3/ There are 2 or 3 that I haven't posted yet, there's a new F perm and the way I used to create it might work for your current F perm as well. There are also two short Y perms in <U,R,L>, one of them the one I use for one-handed cubing. And a short E-perm in <U,R,L,D> which I don't use myself but maybe someone else can do it better than me. It's only 14 quarter turns, that's probably at least shorter than what you use right now. Cheers! Stefan
1402. [Speed cubing group] Re: Hard evidence for opposite color + Xcross combo solving
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 13:46:55 -0000

x-cross stnads for extended cross and means that you build the cross and the first pair in one go. I usually build a 2*2*2 and then finish with the two last edges while I'm looking for pair #2. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Just a question : > What is the difference between a cross and an x-cross ? > > > 2005/12/4, Gunnar Krig <gunkr520@s...>: > > It seems pretty onteresting indeed. I've done 10.42 on average for > > F2L, but my biggest problem is the cross that often takes ~3 > > seconds. If I can choose among two different start I will probably > > get easy crosses and x-crosses much more often, and I think I can > > lower my avg alot, just like you Chris. > > > > I'll definitely give it a try!! > > > > /Gunnar > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > > > It's pretty interesting, Chris. Maybe I'll give it a go :). > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > > > > > I am by no means an expert at the F2L. I think I used to average > > > > around 11-12 seconds before switching to opposite color + Xcross > > > combo > > > > solving. > > > > > > > > Well I took an F2L average tonight and am now sub-10! All I > > > changed > > > > from my 11-12 second averages was to add in opposite color > > solving. > > > > > > > > Now I am pretty nearly 1-(1-x)^2 times more likely to get good > > > solves > > > > (where x is my good solve frequency on one color) as I used to > > be. > > > > That is very, very noticeable!! Of course I can't always notice > > > well > > > > setup Xcross's on my opposite color, but I can always spot a good > > > > cross. I hope to change that soon with more practice and always > > > spot > > > > the good opposite color Xcross solves. > > > > > > > > Anyway here was the average: > > > > 11.50, 8.86, 9.69, 10.18, 10.78, (7.20), 9.41, (12.68), 11.20, > > > 7.94, > > > > 9.62, 8.36 = 9.75 seconds > > > > > > > > The thing is, I am not a sub-10 F2L solver if I solve the same > > > color > > > > every time. However, with the combination of opposite color as > > > well > > > > as Xcross, and not just Xcross, I can now call myself a sub- 10 > > F2L > > > > solver :-) > > > > > > > > Think what you already sub-10 solvers could do with opposite > > color > > > > solving ;-) > > > > > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
1403. Re: my 3x3 algs
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 14:30:25 -0000

Nice page, but it looks like you have a rogue <u> in there somewhere. (&lt;<U,L,R><) ~Thom --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I've found and posted some algs I found myself (mostly with help of > ACube) in the past and every time somebody asked for one I had to > recreate it slowly. So finally I now created a page to collect them at > one place: > http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/speedsolving/3x3/ > > There are 2 or 3 that I haven't posted yet, there's a new F perm and > the way I used to create it might work for your current F perm as > well. There are also two short Y perms in <U,R,L>, one of them the one > I use for one-handed cubing. And a short E-perm in <U,R,L,D> which I > don't use myself but maybe someone else can do it better than me. It's > only 14 quarter turns, that's probably at least shorter than what you > use right now. > > Cheers! > Stefan >

1409. [Speed cubing group] Re: Hard evidence for opposite color + Xcross combo solving(reply to this reply plz:D)
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 17:30:09 -0000

For F2L start off by learning all the cases. You should be able to instantly know what to do for each case. It's all about PRACTICE. A LOT. I estimate that I solve the cube more than 50 times every day. I don't time every solve, but I'm always trying to look ahead during F2L. Practice in ~80% of your maximum speed and you'll soon be able to increase speed and still look ahead. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, shamsul khawaja <shamsus2010@y...> wrote: > > I also started F2l and left the petrus method but i have such a big delay .... it take me like 50 sec on the f2l > how do u ppl do it so fast?..... there are all these pieces i have to look at and i am not lookin for 1 peace on more > > if u ppl are real experts .... can u help me achieve atleast a 30sec average :D and give me pointers and ideas to how to fo f2l faster :D > > Gunnar Krig <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > It seems pretty onteresting indeed. I've done 10.42 on average for > F2L, but my biggest problem is the cross that often takes ~3 > seconds. If I can choose among two different start I will probably > get easy crosses and x-crosses much more often, and I think I can > lower my avg alot, just like you Chris. > > I'll definitely give it a try!! > > /Gunnar > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > It's pretty interesting, Chris. Maybe I'll give it a go :). > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > > > I am by no means an expert at the F2L. I think I used to average > > > around 11-12 seconds before switching to opposite color + Xcross > > combo > > > solving. > > > > > > Well I took an F2L average tonight and am now sub-10! All I > > changed > > > from my 11-12 second averages was to add in opposite color > solving. > > > > > > Now I am pretty nearly 1-(1-x)^2 times more likely to get good > > solves > > > (where x is my good solve frequency on one color) as I used to > be. > > > That is very, very noticeable!! Of course I can't always notice > > well > > > setup Xcross's on my opposite color, but I can always spot a good > > > cross. I hope to change that soon with more practice and always > > spot > > > the good opposite color Xcross solves. > > > > > > Anyway here was the average: > > > 11.50, 8.86, 9.69, 10.18, 10.78, (7.20), 9.41, (12.68), 11.20, > > 7.94, > > > 9.62, 8.36 = 9.75 seconds > > > > > > The thing is, I am not a sub-10 F2L solver if I solve the same > > color > > > every time. However, with the combination of opposite color as > > well > > > as Xcross, and not just Xcross, I can now call myself a sub-10 > F2L > > > solver :-) > > > > > > Think what you already sub-10 solvers could do with opposite > color > > > solving ;-) > > > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! 1410. I broke some records...
From: "mahtianssi" <mahtianssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 17:38:08 -0000

My new 3x3x3 avg record:
14.50 15.49 13.40 14.83 13.35 16.04 14.00 (11.80) 12.20 (17.25) 16.92
14.50 => 14.52
I also did 10.27 single solve yesterday. I think it wasn't lucky.
I never do planned x-crosses or use ZBF2L or COLL. I also do quite much
Y-rotations on F2L. And Jean Pons does cross on top. So, is that stuff
really usefull?

P.S. Congrats to Johannes for sub-20 average!

1412. Re: Hard evidence for opposite color + Xcross combo solving
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 18:05:33 -0000

Hi :-) It could be that im stupid ;-) But what is really the difference between multi-cross solving and the old discussion about whether to solve with the cross on same face (same color) or not ?? When it comes to it, you choose ONE cross that you solve first, and that's it! Having to consider too many possible cross-starts, doesn't that make it impossible to use the 15 secs beyond simply study how to do the cross. Choosing a cross early (fixed color) it is possible to use the 15 secs seeing beyond the cross i guess. By the way, im not a fridrich/cross solver ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > It seems pretty onteresting indeed. I've done 10.42 on average for > F2L, but my biggest problem is the cross that often takes ~3 > seconds. 1413. Re: I broke some records...
From: "Johannes Laire" <johannes.laire@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 18:20:36 -0000

> P.S. Congrats to Johannes for sub-20 average!

Thanks! My goal was to average sub-20 before Christmas and I achieved
it, though it was a very lucky average. Times were: 18.63 22.68 16.02
15.38 21.58 21.00 (14.96) POP (24.06) 20.10 18.02 22.36 23.53.
15.38 and 14.96 were lucky, and one time had also a PLL-skip. That
16.02 wasn't lucky, just very easy.
I usually average maybe 23-25 seconds, so this average was
unbelievable... I want to prove that Petrus method is very fast, I
just have to practice more. Btw my cube is awful... It pops very
often, during that 20.10 one or two pieces popped out and I lost some
time because of that.


-
Johannes

1416. Re: Hard evidence for opposite color + Xcross combo solving
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 18:34:27 -0000

Hey Per, I've noticed that I can get a "feel" for whether white is good or bad. Basically I've been solving white for years so my strategy for a while (which I'm trying to change) is to examine white first. If white is "bad" I then examine yellow. What I've been working on lately is taking a quick scan of both sides (1-2 seconds) and seeing a) are there any blocks for an Xcross and b) is this color "good" or "bad"? I then always choose the best cross or if I see a block or two with a promising setup for an Xcross on either color I choose that one. I've actually been training myself for a while to not use the full inspection time, so that in a competition 15 seconds will seem like a LOT. I try to always inspect and put the cube down in 6-7 seconds or less. So now when I use all 15 it's like 2 inspections for me, and is enough time to look at both white and yellow. Basically if you get yourself used to inspecting very quickly, then 15 seconds will actually feel like a lot, and you can definitely inspect two colors during that time. But again that takes practice to get used to inspecting in 6-7 every time. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi :-) > > It could be that im stupid ;-) > > But what is really the difference between multi-cross solving and > the old discussion about whether to solve with the cross on same > face (same color) or not ?? > > When it comes to it, you choose ONE cross that you solve first, and > that's it! Having to consider too many possible cross-starts, > doesn't that make it impossible to use the 15 secs beyond simply > study how to do the cross. Choosing a cross early (fixed color) it > is possible to use the 15 secs seeing beyond the cross i guess. > > By the way, im not a fridrich/cross solver ;-) > > Cheers! > > -Per

Hello, If you want a timer just like the ones that are used in competitions : you should look for stackmats (timer used in speedstacking). www.speedstacks.com if I'm not wrong. Have fun ! Gilles. 2005/12/4, Derek Lee <numark87@...>: > Where can I buy a rubiks timer? Not a program on a computer, an actual > rubiks timer like the use in competitions. I already saw the one on > rubiks.com > > -Derek > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >

I think I used to > > average > > > > > > around 11-12 seconds before switching to opposite color + > > Xcross > > > > > combo > > > > > > solving. > > > > > > > > > > > > Well I took an F2L average tonight and am now sub-10! All I > > > > > changed > > > > > > from my 11-12 second averages was to add in opposite color > > > > solving. > > > > > > > > > > > > Now I am pretty nearly 1-(1-x)^2 times more likely to get > > good > > > > > solves > > > > > > (where x is my good solve frequency on one color) as I used > > to > > > > be. > > > > > > That is very, very noticeable!! Of course I can't always > > notice > > > > > well > > > > > > setup Xcross's on my opposite color, but I can always spot a > > good > > > > > > cross. I hope to change that soon with more practice and > > always > > > > > spot > > > > > > the good opposite color Xcross solves. > > > > > > > > > > > > Anyway here was the average: > > > > > > 11.50, 8.86, 9.69, 10.18, 10.78, (7.20), 9.41, (12.68), > > 11.20, > > > > > 7.94, > > > > > > 9.62, 8.36 = 9.75 seconds > > > > > > > > > > > > The thing is, I am not a sub-10 F2L solver if I solve the > > same > > > > > color > > > > > > every time. However, with the combination of opposite color > > as > > > > > well > > > > > > as Xcross, and not just Xcross, I can now call myself a sub- > > 10 > > > > F2L > > > > > > solver :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > Think what you already sub-10 solvers could do with opposite > > > > color > > > > > > solving ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
1420. [Speed cubing group] Re: Hard evidence for opposite color + Xcross combo solving
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Dec 2005 22:41:18 -0000

I think as long as people know what you're talking about then whatever name you call it works for me ;-) I guess I'm personally partial to "extended cross" since that's just what I've always called it. I did think about calling it some sort of "fish" name when I first posted about it though (since it does look like a fish), but thought extended cross sounded more "official" :-P Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > fyi, someone recently suggested calling x-cross the "fat fish" > because it sort of looks like that when you're done with that step. > --Kirk
1421. Achievements
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 00:43:20 -0000

Some current notices:

3x3 Average - 29.71 (sub-30) ALL RIGHT!!! It was just perfect...I dunno...
5x5 Single - 5:00.19 - Yes I was completely pissed with myself that it
wasn't sub-5...but it will happen some day...
Speedstacks and Megaminx are on their way so expect some times being
posted by me on those soon.
Pyraminx - 13.43...Yay...
ummm...Can't think of anything else special...If I do, you will all be
the first to know...

Oh...random question...Can anyone check to see if they have a 1969
Canadian Dime??? If so please let me know...

Craig

1425. ZBF2L page
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 01:58:09 -0000

Hey all,

I posted a page that lists the ZBF2L algorithms I have learned in
fingertrick notation so that you can see exactly how I would perform
the algorithm. For anybody who is tackling those 306 algorithms, you
can find this page here:

http://www.cubewhiz.com/zbf2l/

50% through ZBF2L, only about 150 algs to go! ;) I will add more
algorithms as I learn them.

~ Bob

Date: Mon, 5 Dec 2005 16:16:29 +0530

Hey ppl. Why does everyone have to ues the flv formats? Why not just post the video files for download so that they can be available offline? ofcourse i do keep them offline, but just i need to spend some extra time on that. But for others who dont know some comp stuff, they are in trouble. So plz ppl keep the video files free for download. Or maybe i'll write a tutorial for the real n00bs as to how to download the flv files themselves and view them offline. but its really no use playing cat-and-mouse here, afterall you are doing this for the community itself. The only reason i can think of is that everyone wants more visitors to their site. I really see no point in that. Sachin. 1434. Re: [Speed cubing group] Finger trick section
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 15:05:21 -0000

I think you mean R U R' U' R' U', as in R2'U R U R' U' R' U' R' U R'. I do the RUR'U' part the same way as in the R-permutation movie (the last U' with left index finger), and the R'U' part the same as in the R'U'R (the one where I push U' with the thumb). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > I know, but...I still didn't find a good way to do R' U R' U' R' U'..but ok. just if you have some time... > > Pedro > > Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> escreveu: > Hey Pedro, > > Why should I add my U? 1435. funny
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 15:13:10 -0000

Take a solved cube and do this:

L' R' U R U' L R' U'

Then do its F<->B mirror, i.e.:

L R U' R' U L' R U

Cheers!
Stefan






1436. Re: funny
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 15:21:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Take a solved cube and do this: > > L' R' U R U' L R' U' > > Then do its F<->B mirror, i.e.: > > L R U' R' U L' R U > > Cheers! > Stefan > Actually it feels much better rearranged like this: L' (R' U R U' R') (L U' L) (R U' R' U R) (L' U) Cheers! Stefan

1438. Re: funny
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 15:41:58 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Actually it feels much better rearranged like this: > > L' (R' U R U' R') (L U' L) (R U' R' U R) (L' U) Ok, one more adjustment, after a few minutes practice I can already do 4 times in a row under 12 seconds: (U L') (R' U R U' R') (L U' L) (R U' R' U R r') Hey Joel, how do you like that for finger tricks? :-) Cheers! Stefan
1439. Re: funny
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 15:48:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Actually it feels much better rearranged like this: > > > > L' (R' U R U' R') (L U' L) (R U' R' U R) (L' U) > > Ok, one more adjustment, after a few minutes practice I can already do > 4 times in a row under 12 seconds: > > (U L') (R' U R U' R') (L U' L) (R U' R' U R r') > > Hey Joel, how do you like that for finger tricks? :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan Oh, and the F<->B mirror for the "other" case, with a bonus M' for the ring finger pullers among us: (U' L) (R U' R' U R) (L' U L') (R' U R U' M') Cheers! Stefan
1440. 20x20 supercube method
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 15:52:32 -0000

Hi all,

It's been long enough since I solved the 20x20 supercube that I'm
wanting to solve it again. (Yes I did say before that my first solve
would be my last...I guess I lied) Hopefully this time I do better
than 19+ hours.

Lately I've just been trying to get better at solving the first
center, and I think soon I will be sub-20(minutes) on that. I think
after applying some new tricks and achieving better efficiency ~15
minutes on average for the first center will be possible.

The opposite center is kind of a pain honestly. I haven't dedicated
much work to this, but my current method is building vertical rows in
the middle layer and inserting them on their target side. There must
be a better way.

For the 3rd and 4th center I use the same method as I just
mentioned,, but with horizontal rows. This also tends to be
painfully slow, but not as bad as the 2nd center, as I know all my
pieces will be in the middle layer. Of course as I move on finding
pieces is easier.

The 5th and 6th center are kind of a pain. As I seperate the two in
the middle layer, I direct solve one, and leave the other in chaos to
be fixed later. Surely there's a way to direct solve both? This
would probably save 45-60 minutes(!) as cycling centers on a single
face takes much too long. Keep in mind this is cycling 3 centers at
once...I'm not Per who'd probably just solve the last center in one
go..:P (Just kidding Per...I know you're human...two algs to fix
right? ;) Seriously though, there is a lot of time lost here so any
suggestions would be welcome

Initially I was solving the 6th center very last, so I could use it
as a breaking ground for my parity algs, which mess with the center
it's applied over. If I do learn a way of solving the 5th and 6th
center together, I'm going to need center preserving parity algs.
Doug Li found a couple for me, but I've lost them since then (sorry
Doug!)

Everything from this point on would be standard. Supercubing doesn't
mess up edge pairing approaches and solving as a 3x3 isn't too
difficult. For those of you who will help me, thanks in advance.
For those of you who don't like supercubing...sorry for the post :P

Happy Cubing

-Richard





1441. Re: [Speed cubing group] Finger trick section

1445. Re: Achievements
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 17:14:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > 5x5 Single - 5:00.19 - Yes I was completely pissed with myself that it > wasn't sub-5...but it will happen some day... More pissed than I am about my Magic Balls average coming out to 8.01 and my Master Magic average coming out to 3.03 and my Magic single best being 1.05, 1.16 average (okay, so sub-1 is a little hard for that one), and my 2x2x2 best being 5.12? My best clock solve is 24.00, too. The topper is my fastest official Master Magic time being 3.00 seconds. :P Though, admittedly, it didn't bother me that it wasn't sub-3 until Stefan beat it. ;) Round numbers are just there to bother you. ~ Bob
1446. Re: Achievements
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 18:47:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Round numbers are just there to bother you. The whole concept of "round numbers" is flawed already, in my opinion these don't even exist. For example, you might consider "10.00" to be a round number, but that's not really the number, only one out of infinitely many representations of it. In binary it would already look like "1010" and just imagine what happens if you take for example Pi as base. Or the representation where you'd write "XXXXXXXXXX", which doesn't look any rounder than "XXXXXXXXX". Or... etc. Not even 0 (zero), which looks the same and "round" in many used representations, looks like a round number anymore when I represent numbers by writing them the "normal" way after subtracting 42. Cheers! Stefan
1447. top left crossers?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 18:55:37 -0000

I guess most people who made it to the world finals used Fridrich.
During F2L, where do they hold the cross? Anybody with cross at left?
I know at places 13-18 there are three: Lars, Michel, me. How about
top 12?

Cheers!
Stefan






1448. Re: [Speed cubing group] ZBF2L page
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 5 Dec 2005 20:35:27 +0100

This is really impressive Bob, I admire all the people who want to try the ZB Adventure. I've tried to learn some ZB LL cases but at the moment I don't really find any improvement for me. As I am very bad at recognition for special cases. (8 seconds to recognise and execute 2 algs for the LL is really really bad), I don't think that recognisiong a ZB case will be any easier. + I still see all the possible improvements I can do on how I use the Fridrich Method (more fluency, faster execution of OLL and PLL, faster recognition for the OLL and PLL, X-Cross, ...) Really, ZB is not for me. And btw, congratulations for your improvements on your times thx to ZB :-) Gilles. 2005/12/5, Bob Burton <bob@...>: > Hey all, > > I posted a page that lists the ZBF2L algorithms I have learned in > fingertrick notation so that you can see exactly how I would perform > the algorithm. For anybody who is tackling those 306 algorithms, you > can find this page here: > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/zbf2l/ > > 50% through ZBF2L, only about 150 algs to go! ;) I will add more > algorithms as I learn them. > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
1449. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Achievements
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 5 Dec 2005 20:49:07 +0100

Mmm.. The concept of "round numbers" may not be a good thing, but we must admit that most of the people use that idea. So when you say to someone that you can solve it just in 3 seconds (whatever the puzzle is), it won't make a very big difference to someone outside the "Cube World" if it was actually a 2.99 or a 3.01. But in the contrary, even though it's really silly and maybe meaningless, 2.99 is much better than 3.01 :p Gilles. 2005/12/5, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...>: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > wrote: > > > > Round numbers are just there to bother you. > > The whole concept of "round numbers" is flawed already, in my opinion > these don't even exist. For example, you might consider "10.00" to be > a round number, but that's not really the number, only one out of > infinitely many representations of it. In binary it would already look > like "1010" and just imagine what happens if you take for example Pi > as base. Or the representation where you'd write "XXXXXXXXXX", which > doesn't look any rounder than "XXXXXXXXX". Or... etc. Not even 0 > (zero), which looks the same and "round" in many used representations, > looks like a round number anymore when I represent numbers by writing > them the "normal" way after subtracting 42. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >

1451. Re: Achievements
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 21:19:02 -0000

Hi Stefan ! Im trying to understand ur way of thinking but i think u are seriously mistaken. If u talk about rounding off errors that's another matter. The concept of integers is well founded in maths and in reality. U can indeed have exactly 10 stones or 42 apples or whatever. Measuring 10 seconds (10.00) on a computer won't mean that we know that there are infinitely many 0's after the comma. But noone says it does mean so either ;-) It is just the human mind that wants to simplify and say: hey 10.00 that's *exactly* 10 (the natural number 10). Oh well, this has nothing whatsoever to do with cubing ;-) Sorry guys ... (+ guyesses) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > wrote: > > > > Round numbers are just there to bother you. > > The whole concept of "round numbers" is flawed already, in my opinion > these don't even exist. For example, you might consider "10.00" to be > a round number, but that's not really the number, only one out of > infinitely many representations of it. In binary it would already look > like "1010" and just imagine what happens if you take for example Pi > as base. Or the representation where you'd write "XXXXXXXXXX", which > doesn't look any rounder than "XXXXXXXXX". Or... etc. Not even 0 > (zero), which looks the same and "round" in many used representations, > looks like a round number anymore when I represent numbers by writing > them the "normal" way after subtracting 42. > > Cheers! > Stefan >
1452. Number of moves to solve
From: "ericdstalter" <ericdstalter@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 21:21:57 -0000

Hello

I use a Lars/Fridrich style to solve and average about 70 moves to
solve the cube. I know recognition plays a big role in number of
moves, but my question is

How many moves do most speedcubers use to solve (3x3)?


ERic

1458. Re: [Speed cubing group] Number of moves to solve
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 5 Dec 2005 14:20:21 -0800

In a pure Fridrich method, the solver generally averages 57 moves. The
number of moves however can range significantly. Macky's 12.11 second
solve used 42 moves I think.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Dec 5, 2005, at 1:21 PM, ericdstalter wrote:

> Hello
>
> I use a Lars/Fridrich style to solve and average about 70 moves to
> solve the cube. I know recognition plays a big role in number of
> moves, but my question is
>
> How many moves do most speedcubers use to solve (3x3)?
>
>
> ERic

1460. Re: top left crossers?
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 22:28:44 -0000

Yeah.. Tyson Mao does cross left. And I think Ryan Patricio does cross on left too. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I guess most people who made it to the world finals used Fridrich. > During F2L, where do they hold the cross? Anybody with cross at left? > I know at places 13-18 there are three: Lars, Michel, me. How about > top 12? > > Cheers! > Stefan >
1461. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: top left crossers?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 5 Dec 2005 14:39:25 -0800

Leyan and my brother, Toby do it as well. My brother and I developed it as a result of not knowing what we were doing. We were very early in the speedcubing learning process and we were using Fridrich's site which gives algorithms for cross on top. The most natural translation of those algorithms was cross on left. If we had started off we Macky's site, we might all be cross on bottom cubers now. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Dec 5, 2005, at 2:28 PM, Joël van Noort wrote: > Yeah.. Tyson Mao does cross left. And I think Ryan Patricio does cross > on left too. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: >> >> I guess most people who made it to the world finals used Fridrich. >> During F2L, where do they hold the cross? Anybody with cross at > left? >> I know at places 13-18 there are three: Lars, Michel, me. How about >> top 12? >> >> Cheers! >> Stefan >> > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > >
1462. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: top left crossers?
From: Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 14:53:41 -0800

I actually switch around, cross on bottom and on left, depending on either (1) the F2L case, because sometimes I can execute the cross on bottom alg faster than the cross on left alg, or (2) how I end up holding the cube after solving a CE pair. I try not to waste time repositioning my grip when I don't have to. I would say that about 60-70% of the time, I am using cross on left algs, though. Leyan Tyson Mao wrote: > Leyan and my brother, Toby do it as well. My brother and I developed > it as a result of not knowing what we were doing. We were very early > in the speedcubing learning process and we were using Fridrich's site > which gives algorithms for cross on top. The most natural translation > of those algorithms was cross on left. If we had started off we > Macky's site, we might all be cross on bottom cubers now. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Dec 5, 2005, at 2:28 PM, Joï¿½l van Noort wrote: > > >>Yeah.. Tyson Mao does cross left. And I think Ryan Patricio does cross >>on left too. >> >>--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" >><pochmann@g...> wrote: >> >>>I guess most people who made it to the world finals used Fridrich. >>>During F2L, where do they hold the cross? 1464. Re: Achievements
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Dec 2005 23:26:29 -0000

Hi Per, no, the point is that a number and a representation of a number are not the same. You can't even write down or tell me a number - at all! Only a representation of the number you mean. For example, you write "10 seconds" and I can only *assume* that you mean "ten seconds", but maybe you're talking binary and mean "two seconds"? The *representation* of a number can look "round", never the number itself. Firstly because it doesn't look at all, and secondly because in different representations it can look differently. In some of them it might look "round", in others not. Got it now? Distinguish between numbers and their representations, that's all. Cheers! Stefan P.S. Even saying "two" or "ten" is not much better than "2" or "10", since maybe the word "two" means a different number for you than it does for me. Or if you're a weird alien from Mars and use the same notation as we humans but with the digit symbols '0' and '7' swapped, then "3.00" will not look round for you because it'll look to you like "3.77" looks to us which we wouldn't call "round". --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi Stefan ! > > Im trying to understand ur way of thinking but i think u are > seriously mistaken. If u talk about rounding off errors that's > another matter. The concept of integers is well founded in maths and > in reality. U can indeed have exactly 10 stones or 42 apples or > whatever. Measuring 10 seconds (10.00) on a computer won't mean that > we know that there are infinitely many 0's after the comma. But > noone says it does mean so either ;-) It is just the human mind that > wants to simplify and say: hey 10.00 that's *exactly* 10 (the > natural number 10). Oh well, this has nothing whatsoever to do with > cubing ;-) > > Sorry guys ... (+ guyesses) > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <bob@c...> > > wrote: > > > > > > Round numbers are just there to bother you. > > > > The whole concept of "round numbers" is flawed already, in my > opinion > > these don't even exist. For example, you might consider "10.00" to > be > > a round number, but that's not really the number, only one out of > > infinitely many representations of it. In binary it would already > look > > like "1010" and just imagine what happens if you take for example > Pi > > as base. Or the representation where you'd write "XXXXXXXXXX", > which > > doesn't look any rounder than "XXXXXXXXX". Or... etc. Not even 0 > > (zero), which looks the same and "round" in many used > representations, > > looks like a round number anymore when I represent numbers by > writing > > them the "normal" way after subtracting 42. > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > >

Hmm, is there something else about this auction that I missed? Or did you mean that in general? Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > It's pretty funny how some things (including some complicated stuff) > are so trivial to a cuber, but hard to see for non-cubers. I am not > only talking about the color scheme thing by the way :). > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > What do you think about the question and answer (about color > schemes) > > in this auction? > > > > http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=6017846874 > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > >
1474. Re: Number of moves to solve
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Dec 2005 01:17:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "ericdstalter" <ericdstalter@y...> wrote: > > Hello > > I use a Lars/Fridrich style to solve and average about 70 moves to > solve the cube. I know recognition plays a big role in number of > moves, but my question is > > How many moves do most speedcubers use to solve (3x3)? > > > ERic Hi Eric, Usually between 36 and 54 moves. Cheers, David J
1475. [Speed cubing group] Re: Finger trick section
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Dec 2005 02:04:39 -0000

Man, I know what you mean! I am much "faster" but it takes me twice as long to solve. It's definitely a case of brain over braun. Another cubist who has a very relaxed-looking style is Leyan Lo. Maybe it has something to do with the fluidity of motion. Some cubists have a very quick "jerky" motion that maybe just looks faster. Perhaps others seem to be slower-moving, but finish faster by having a total lack of hesitation? Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Watching this video of Ron I'm convinced that stackmat is broken: > http://www.math.leidenuniv.nl/~jnoort/videos/Ron_13.97.avi > > When I solve as fast as that, my timer always claims 18 or so. Well, > maybe *my* timer is broken :-). But seriously, he doesn't look all > that fast. Gotta watch myself on video and find where I waste so much > time. > > Cheers! > Stefan >
1476. Eternity Puzzle
From: "mrraaw" <mrraaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Dec 2005 04:22:55 -0000

I am curious to see if the cubing community had the potential to solve
this puzzle.

"The Eternity puzzle is a polygonal jigsaw puzzle (no picture on the
pieces to guide you) with an ingenious set of pieces, developed by
Christopher Monckton. There are 209 pieces(Each piece is different and
has no symmetry) to be fitted into an outline. A prize of £1,000,000
was offered for a solution. "

It has been solved a while ago. Check out this link..it's pretty
amazing: http://www.mathpuzzle.com/eternity.html

...And I thought this yahoo group was confusing and sometimes
gibberish...

MATT





1477. Re: 20x20 supercube method
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Dec 2005 04:23:37 -0000

Again, I should have known this wouldn't bring many posts...I must be the only one crazy enough to talk about it. At any rate, I solved my problem with solving the first two centers. With no practice on my new approach I achieved 67 minutes for the U and D centers. Sub60 is definetly possible for me, though I feel like 40-45 minutes is possible with a bit of practice. Still dreading the 5th and 6th centers though. Maybe if I discuss this issue with myself enough you all will get tired of it and have some ideas for me? :P Happy Cubing -Richard --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > Hi all, > > It's been long enough since I solved the 20x20 supercube that I'm > wanting to solve it again. (Yes I did say before that my first solve > would be my last...I guess I lied) Hopefully this time I do better > than 19+ hours. > > Lately I've just been trying to get better at solving the first > center, and I think soon I will be sub-20(minutes) on that. I think > after applying some new tricks and achieving better efficiency ~15 > minutes on average for the first center will be possible. > > The opposite center is kind of a pain honestly. I haven't dedicated > much work to this, but my current method is building vertical rows in > the middle layer and inserting them on their target side. There must > be a better way. > > For the 3rd and 4th center I use the same method as I just > mentioned,, but with horizontal rows. This also tends to be > painfully slow, but not as bad as the 2nd center, as I know all my > pieces will be in the middle layer. Of course as I move on finding > pieces is easier. > > The 5th and 6th center are kind of a pain. As I seperate the two in > the middle layer, I direct solve one, and leave the other in chaos to > be fixed later. Surely there's a way to direct solve both? This > would probably save 45-60 minutes(!) as cycling centers on a single > face takes much too long. Keep in mind this is cycling 3 centers at > once...I'm not Per who'd probably just solve the last center in one > go..:P (Just kidding Per...I know you're human...two algs to fix > right? ;) Seriously though, there is a lot of time lost here so any > suggestions would be welcome > > Initially I was solving the 6th center very last, so I could use it > as a breaking ground for my parity algs, which mess with the center > it's applied over. If I do learn a way of solving the 5th and 6th > center together, I'm going to need center preserving parity algs. > Doug Li found a couple for me, but I've lost them since then (sorry > Doug!) > > Everything from this point on would be standard. Supercubing doesn't > mess up edge pairing approaches and solving as a 3x3 isn't too > difficult. For those of you who will help me, thanks in advance. > For those of you who don't like supercubing...sorry for the post :P > > Happy Cubing > > -Richard >
1478. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Finger trick section
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 6 Dec 2005 07:19:43 +0100

The speed is very subjective. I feel like Ron's solve is very very fast. When I solve it in 18 seconds, it doesn't feel that fast. But if I watch it on video, I'm amazed. :p (and moreover if I watch some faster videos I did). In terms of number of move per second, this one was about 5 (Ron's). And there are a very few people who can handle such a speed. Gilles. 2005/12/6, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...>: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > No, that's not the reason. I thought having the videos on the > website > > would be convinient. Just click and play. For anyone who wants to > > download the videos: http://math.leidenuniv.nl/~jnoort/videos. > > Watching this video of Ron I'm convinced that stackmat is broken: > http://www.math.leidenuniv.nl/~jnoort/videos/Ron_13.97.avi > > When I solve as fast as that, my timer always claims 18 or so. From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>

Ya . Actually i also think that video's are very different than the real thing. Even when i saw my own video, i was amazed with myself! It feels very different when watching someones video, even if the someone is you! As for Ron, hes fast of course, but when i saw him solve in person, i noticed that hes very consistent with his speed...there were almost no lockups during all of his solves. Maybe he has a lot of practice looking ahead and that helps him a lot. Also knowing all the OLL and Pll algs also helps :) Sachin. 1481. How Fast is your Last Layer?
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Dec 2005 09:51:13 -0000

Hello Everyone

What is a good Avg for Last Layer?
I took an avg today for step 4 of Gilles MEthod. I haven't cubed a
lot this week, but I did pretty well.

(2.98), 3.39, 4.98, 5.78, 7.48, 6.58, 6.67, 3.53, 7.50, 5.34, (12.18),
7.48 Step 4 Avg 5.87 sec

This step is kind of like OLL/PLL. First you Orient 6 edges, then
Permute 6 edges. Step 4 averages only 15 moves, but there are a lot
of slice moves. If you can avg 3 moves a sec, you can do step 4 in
about 5 seconds.

CFOP
Cross - 7 moves
CE Pair - 7 moves
CE Pair - 7 moves
CE Pair - 7 moves
CE Pair - 7 moves
OLL - ?
PLL - ?

ROUX
B1 - 9 moves
B2 - 16 moves (2 for DR edge and 7 for each CE pair)
CLL - ?
Step 4 - 15 moves

So F2L is about 35 moves (11.67 sec at 3 moves/sec)
and F2B is about 25 moves (8.33 sec at 3 moves/sec)(10 sec at 2.5
moves/sec)

Step 4 is about 15 moves (5 sec at 3 moves/sec)(6 sec at 2.5 moves/sec)

I think due to slice moves it's hard to do 3 moves/sec for Step 4, so
2.5 moves/sec is a better estimate.
Todays avg of 5.87sec would be 2.56 moves/sec.


What are the HTM averages for OLL and PLL?

WHat about COLL and CLL? CLL must be less..

And What is a good Last Layer Time Average?

Thank you

Jason Kovacic
kovacic81@...

Some > cubists have a very quick "jerky" motion that maybe just looks > faster. Perhaps others seem to be slower-moving, but finish faster by > having a total lack of hesitation? > > Chris It sounds like you got the point. Speed isn't everything.
1483. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Achievements
From: "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Dec 2005 10:54:29 +0000

This discussion reminds me of a t-shirt I saw on thinkgeek.com: http://www.thinkgeek.com/tshirts/frustrations/5aa9/zoom/ Wouldn't this have been a good t-shirt for a certain cuber to wear on Beauty and the Geek? ;) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com On Mon, 05 Dec 2005 23:26:29 -0000, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> said: > > Hi Per, > no, the point is that a number and a representation of a number > are > not the same. You can't even write down or tell me a number - at > all! > Only a representation of the number you mean. For example, you > write > "10 seconds" and I can only *assume* that you mean "ten > seconds", but > maybe you're talking binary and mean "two seconds"? The > *representation* of a number can look "round", never the number > itself. Firstly because it doesn't look at all, and secondly > because > in different representations it can look differently. In some of > them > it might look "round", in others not. Got it now? Distinguish > between > numbers and their representations, that's all. > Cheers! > Stefan > P.S. Even saying "two" or "ten" is not much better than "2" or > "10", > since maybe the word "two" means a different number for you than > it > does for me. Or if you're a weird alien from Mars and use the > same > notation as we humans but with the digit symbols '0' and '7' > swapped, > then "3.00" will not look round for you because it'll look to > you like > "3.77" looks to us which we wouldn't call "round". > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi Stefan ! > > > > Im trying to understand ur way of thinking but i think u are > > seriously mistaken. If u talk about rounding off errors that's > > another matter. The concept of integers is well founded in > maths and > > in reality. U can indeed have exactly 10 stones or 42 apples > or > > whatever. Measuring 10 seconds (10.00) on a computer won't > mean that > > we know that there are infinitely many 0's after the comma. > But > > noone says it does mean so either ;-) It is just the human > mind that > > wants to simplify and say: hey 10.00 that's *exactly* 10 (the > > natural number 10). Oh well, this has nothing whatsoever to do > with > > cubing ;-) > > > > Sorry guys ... (+ guyesses) > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan > Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > > <bob@c...> > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > Round numbers are just there to bother you. > > > > > > The whole concept of "round numbers" is flawed already, in > my > > opinion > > > these don't even exist. For example, you might consider > "10.00" to > > be > > > a round number, but that's not really the number, only one > out of > > > infinitely many representations of it. In binary it would > already > > look > > > like "1010" and just imagine what happens if you take for > example > > Pi > > > as base. Or the representation where you'd write > "XXXXXXXXXX", > > which > > > doesn't look any rounder than "XXXXXXXXX". Or... etc. Not > even 0 > > > (zero), which looks the same and "round" in many used > > representations, > > > looks like a round number anymore when I represent numbers > by > > writing > > > them the "normal" way after subtracting 42. > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan > > > > > > ___________________________________________________________ > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > * Visit your group "[1]speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > [2]speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the [3]Yahoo! Terms > of Service. > ___________________________________________________________ > > References > > 1. http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube > 2. > mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscribe > 3. http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/ -- http://www.fastmail.fm - IMAP accessible web-mail

I guess it's a bit geeky, but then so am I :) http://www.thinkgeek.com/gadgets/watches/6a17/ Terje -----Opprinnelig melding----- Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Jasmine Lee Sendt: 6. desember 2005 11:54 Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Emne: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Achievements This discussion reminds me of a t-shirt I saw on thinkgeek.com: http://www.thinkgeek.com/tshirts/frustrations/5aa9/zoom/ Wouldn't this have been a good t-shirt for a certain cuber to wear on Beauty and the Geek? ;) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com On Mon, 05 Dec 2005 23:26:29 -0000, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> said: > > Hi Per, > no, the point is that a number and a representation of a number > are > not the same. You can't even write down or tell me a number - at > all! > Only a representation of the number you mean. For example, you > write > "10 seconds" and I can only *assume* that you mean "ten > seconds", but > maybe you're talking binary and mean "two seconds"? The > *representation* of a number can look "round", never the number > itself. Firstly because it doesn't look at all, and secondly > because > in different representations it can look differently. In some of > them > it might look "round", in others not. Got it now? Distinguish > between > numbers and their representations, that's all. > Cheers! > Stefan > P.S. Even saying "two" or "ten" is not much better than "2" or > "10", > since maybe the word "two" means a different number for you than > it > does for me. Or if you're a weird alien from Mars and use the > same > notation as we humans but with the digit symbols '0' and '7' > swapped, > then "3.00" will not look round for you because it'll look to > you like > "3.77" looks to us which we wouldn't call "round". > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi Stefan ! > > > > Im trying to understand ur way of thinking but i think u are > > seriously mistaken. If u talk about rounding off errors that's > > another matter. The concept of integers is well founded in > maths and > > in reality. U can indeed have exactly 10 stones or 42 apples > or > > whatever. Measuring 10 seconds (10.00) on a computer won't > mean that > > we know that there are infinitely many 0's after the comma. > But > > noone says it does mean so either ;-) It is just the human > mind that > > wants to simplify and say: hey 10.00 that's *exactly* 10 (the > > natural number 10). Oh well, this has nothing whatsoever to do > with > > cubing ;-) > > > > Sorry guys ... (+ guyesses) > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan > Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > > <bob@c...> > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > Round numbers are just there to bother you. > > > > > > The whole concept of "round numbers" is flawed already, in > my > > opinion > > > these don't even exist. For example, you might consider > "10.00" to > > be > > > a round number, but that's not really the number, only one > out of > > > infinitely many representations of it. In binary it would > already > > look > > > like "1010" and just imagine what happens if you take for > example > > Pi > > > as base. Or the representation where you'd write > "XXXXXXXXXX", > > which > > > doesn't look any rounder than "XXXXXXXXX". Or... etc. Not > even 0 > > > (zero), which looks the same and "round" in many used > > representations, > > > looks like a round number anymore when I represent numbers > by > > writing > > > them the "normal" way after subtracting 42. > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan > > > > > > ___________________________________________________________ > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > * Visit your group "[1]speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > [2]speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the [3]Yahoo! Terms > of Service. > ___________________________________________________________ > > References > > 1. http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube > 2. > mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubs cribe > 3. http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/ -- http://www.fastmail.fm - IMAP accessible web-mail _____ YAHOO! 1489. Re: How Fast is your Last Layer?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Dec 2005 15:24:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > What is a good Avg for Last Layer? > I took an avg today for step 4 of Gilles MEthod. I haven't cubed a > lot this week, but I did pretty well. > > (2.98), 3.39, 4.98, 5.78, 7.48, 6.58, 6.67, 3.53, 7.50, 5.34, (12.18), > 7.48 Step 4 Avg 5.87 sec Did you account for recognition in this average? If so, how did you do so? How did you time yourself, also? > > This step is kind of like OLL/PLL. First you Orient 6 edges, then > Permute 6 edges. Step 4 averages only 15 moves, but there are a lot > of slice moves. If you can avg 3 moves a sec, you can do step 4 in > about 5 seconds. But in OLL you orient EIGHT pieces and then in PLL you permute EIGHT pieces, so it seems to me you are doing 33% more work, right? Wouldn't that make Step 4 a little less equivalent to OLL/PLL? Even if you took a CLL -> ELL approach (which is equivalent to OLL/PLL in number of moves and in speed), then in the first step you are orienting AND permuting 4 pieces and then doing the same in the second step. It seems to me that no matter what, the last 6 edges should be faster than OLL/PLL. > CFOP > Cross - 7 moves > CE Pair - 7 moves > CE Pair - 7 moves > CE Pair - 7 moves > CE Pair - 7 moves > OLL - ? > PLL - ? Well, that's not really fair. The average F2L is approximately 30 moves for a good speedcuber. I think my average for F2L may actually be around 28-29 moves. The cross average should only be 6, but who doesn't use open slots, especially for the first couple pairs? I think 30 moves is a much more accurate representation. OLL averages are about 9 moves and PLL I believe is about 14 moves. That makes for approximately 51-53 moves for CFOP. > ROUX > B1 - 9 moves > B2 - 16 moves (2 for DR edge and 7 for each CE pair) > CLL - ? > Step 4 - 15 moves I think CLL is about 9 moves on average. This makes a total of about 49 or so moves. > So F2L is about 35 moves (11.67 sec at 3 moves/sec) > and F2B is about 25 moves (8.33 sec at 3 moves/sec)(10 sec at 2.5 > moves/sec) Again, I think 35 moves for F2L average is way too high. > Step 4 is about 15 moves (5 sec at 3 moves/sec)(6 sec at 2.5 moves/sec) > > I think due to slice moves it's hard to do 3 moves/sec for Step 4, so > 2.5 moves/sec is a better estimate. > Todays avg of 5.87sec would be 2.56 moves/sec. > What are the HTM averages for OLL and PLL? I believe 9 and 14 moves (approximately). > WHat about COLL and CLL? CLL must be less.. CLL should be around 9 moves and COLL probably around 12 or so. > And What is a good Last Layer Time Average? That depends on what you consider good. I think some of the faster guys have a LL around 4-5 seconds. I belive mine is about 5-6 seconds, slightly faster on a good day. When I set my sub-20 average, my F2L average was about 15 seconds, so I probably cut a bit of time off at the F2L and had a really good LL. My fastest time was 13.34, but I doubt I've ever had a sub-10 F2L solve. ;) ~ Bob
1490. What is your fastest time possible for LL??
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Dec 2005 17:15:19 -0000

I was timing myself doing my fastest OLL followed by my fastest PLL
just to see how fast LL is possible to finish. My fastest time so far
is 2.40!!! I do the following algs:

OLL: F R U R' U' F'
PLL: L' R' U2 L U L' U2 R U' L

/Gunnar

1508. How Fast is your Last Layer? 2
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Dec 2005 02:09:29 -0000

Hello Again

To answer your questions Bob,

I do preinspect, but only for 2 sec, as it only takes a fraction of a
second to recognize the orientation case for step 4. You can see all
6 edges when you're doing step 3, so It's like preinspection anyway.
In addition to that I always align my centers prior to doing step 3.


I use a stackmat, cube on the mat, hands on the "hand things." Just
like a normal solve

F2L
I thought that 35 was a good number to aim for. Thats what I had
heard . But 30 is an Ok number.
CROSS 6 moves
CE Pair 6 moves each
So in Theory
So F2L at 3moves/s is 10 sec
and F2B at 3 moves/s is 8.33 sec

OLL PLL
If OLL is 9 moves and PLL is 14 moves, then it is a 23 move avg for
LL. So to be Sub 6, you need 4 moves/sec. The point I was trying to
make is that even turning the cube at a rate of 2.5 moves/sec, you
can do Step 4 in sub 6. At 4 moves/sec, step 4 is sub 4 (3.75).

I don't see how 4 moves/sec is possible with slice moves though. =(
Try doing M U M U' 10 times in 10 seconds. Tough Stuff.

Jason Kovacic

1510. Re: How Fast is your Last Layer? 2
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Dec 2005 04:37:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > I don't see how 4 moves/sec is possible with slice moves though. =( > Try doing M U M U' 10 times in 10 seconds. Tough Stuff. Oh, come on! Haven't you seen my videos for the H-perm and Z-perms? http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll04.avi (1.6 second Z) http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll05.avi (1.1 second H) Both of these use nothing but M' and U (well, and M2 and U2) ;) Slices can be quite fast! :P ~ Bob

1512. Re: How Fast is your Last Layer? 2
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Dec 2005 05:39:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" > <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > I don't see how 4 moves/sec is possible with slice moves though. =( > > Try doing M U M U' 10 times in 10 seconds. Tough Stuff. I do slice turns as r'R and rR'. My first attempt, I got a 10.01. I averaged a little over 9 seconds for M U M U'. M' turns are much faster. I can average under 8 seconds for M' U M' U'. I can also average under 9 for M' U M U', which seems a little closer to actual Roux solving. That's ~4.4 moves per second. M and U turn algs are incredibly fast. That's one of the reasons his method is so quick. I'd really like to find out how many cases there are, and the average length of them for all the step 4 algs where the 6 edges are oriented correctly. If anyone wants to fire up Acube and get it to do this, I would much appreciate it. -Mike Bennett
