1514. Step 4
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Dec 2005 07:50:27 -0000

What are some other peoples averages for this step?

I think a sub 6 avg is pretty good.
But If you do the math, I'm only cubing at 2.5 moves/sec.
With 4 moves/sec you could make this sub 4. The recogintion time is
nothing once orientation is done.

5.87 avg 15 move avg 2.56 moves/sec

Recently I have been using My Left ring finger for M'. I think that it
is defenitely quicker.
(M'U2M') is pretty fast (PLL).
(M'U2M'U2)(M'UM') is also fast (4 bad Edges on top)

I always forget though. I used corners 1st 10 years ago, and have
been doing rR' and Rr' forever. I use r2R2 for M2 90% of the time.
With my Ring finger I use 2 movements of the finger to do it, like
doing M'M'. It seems to me that using your ring finger, only
sequences w/o M are good.

Jason Kovacic






1515. Step 4 Approach
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Dec 2005 08:24:36 -0000

This is how I do Step 4

1. Orient all 6 edges and pair up ledge and redge in DF and DB.
2. Do a U adjustment and Throw in the pair. Do your 4 move PLL.

2. is usually 7 moves. The 2nd part is basically the 2nd table on
Joseph's site about 6 edge solving. I think the 1st Table is the same
as 1. but center orientation is not a factor. I always put either the
red or orange center on top.

I always do it this way, unless after orientation, there is a ledge or
redge in place. Or if yellow is in whites place or vice versa.

I don't know if a ZB like table is worth doing. The whole step is
only about 15 moves, and very intuitive. However, PLL skips are nice,
and somewhat frequent. I think that avoiding PLL everytime is
possible somehow...

jason k

1517. Re: Step 4
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Dec 2005 09:29:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > What are some other peoples averages for this step? > > I think a sub 6 avg is pretty good. > But If you do the math, I'm only cubing at 2.5 moves/sec. > With 4 moves/sec you could make this sub 4. The recogintion time is > nothing once orientation is done. > > 5.87 avg 15 move avg 2.56 moves/sec > > Recently I have been using My Left ring finger for M'. I think that it > is defenitely quicker. > (M'U2M') is pretty fast (PLL). > (M'U2M'U2)(M'UM') is also fast (4 bad Edges on top) > > I always forget though. I used corners 1st 10 years ago, and have > been doing rR' and Rr' forever. I use r2R2 for M2 90% of the time. > With my Ring finger I use 2 movements of the finger to do it, like > doing M'M'. It seems to me that using your ring finger, only > sequences w/o M are good. > > Jason Kovacic First 12 solves I tried, I wound up with a 6.01 average for the step. My best was a 3.30 and worst was 8.55. It should have been about half that, but I locked up badly. Average number of moves was 13. The 3.30 case was one with correct orientation. Are the odds of this 1/28? Is there any way to try to help this at an earlier stage? I think learning all of the algs to simultaneously permute the final 6 edges once oriented would be a good idea. It should be <30. These ought to all be fast cases, using primarily M and U turns. You could use them after you orient the edges, or on the chance of an O6E skip. I would also advise learning the ELL algs, in the event that the F2L is completed after Step 3. This gives you a total alg count of something like 100. Not bad. Another idea that might help ease the L6E is to try to preserve correct orientation by using COLL algs, and to try to change bad orientation using CLL algs. You can get from most possible orientation cases to the 3 incorrect edges on top configuration or the correct orientation using COLL, or a CLL alg that flips DF and UL or R , and one for DF and UF. DF and UB would be unnecessary, because you could just do d2 and perform the DF and UF alg. Of course, this now gives us something like 160 algs for Step 3, instead of the normal 40, bringing the total alg number closer to 200. However, we would get correct or nearly correct edge orientation 25/28 of the time. This is where the single alg to place edges would come in very handy. For the other three cases (where an opposite pair of edges on U or D are incorrect), you could attempt to change the orientation, and then apply an alg, or just leave them and know ahead of time what you will get. You could also try using algs for the UD+DF cases that leave the UB and UF pieces where they are, so that you could do an M, followed by the UD+DF alg, and finish with another M. Of course, this is a far cry from the normal 50 or so algs this method uses, or even the 78 from CFOP. But it's still a much more sane number than the 797 for ZB. I can't find any way to help towards P6E skips yet, but I'll keep at it. -Mike

I assume you must be > doing > > some full cube rotations to achieve that. > > > > Chris > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@...m, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> > > wrote: > > > > > > Come on, you guys have to think outside the box :-) > > > > > > 1.93 for flipping two corners. 1523. 4-look LL order switch = more "lucky" solves?
From: "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Dec 2005 18:25:16 -0000

Hi All -

I'm in the process of switching my 4-look LL order from:

OE (Orient Edges) / PC (Permute Corners) / OC (Orient Corners) / PE
(Permute Edges)

to:

OE / OC / PC / PE

As I work through it, I'm finding that I'm getting more "lucky"
solves, where I end up skipping one of the above steps.

Thinking about it for a while, I came up with the following
analysis:

Once I OC, the four corners (A, B, C, D) are in some order. If
I "fix" A, then there are only 6 orders for B, C, D = BCD, BDC, CBD,
CDB, DBC, DCB (let's say I'm looking at them from the top). So, 1/6
of the time I get to skip PC. I also get a PE skip when the PC
routines I use also do the right PE (call this proto-PLL).

Sound like reasonable logic to others? I'm sure that with my old
order there were step skips as well, but it feels like more. An
average of two " step skips" in a set of 12 runs is a nice situation.

And, yes, I know the next statement: Learn PLL and you'll always
have one less step (4 to 3)! I'm working on it!

yeff







1524. Re: 4-look LL order switch = more "lucky" solves?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Dec 2005 19:27:51 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@y...> wrote: > > Hi All - > > I'm in the process of switching my 4-look LL order from: > > OE (Orient Edges) / PC (Permute Corners) / OC (Orient Corners) / PE > (Permute Edges) > > to: > > OE / OC / PC / PE > > As I work through it, I'm finding that I'm getting more "lucky" > solves, where I end up skipping one of the above steps. > > Thinking about it for a while, I came up with the following > analysis: > > Once I OC, the four corners (A, B, C, D) are in some order. If > I "fix" A, then there are only 6 orders for B, C, D = BCD, BDC, CBD, > CDB, DBC, DCB (let's say I'm looking at them from the top). So, 1/6 > of the time I get to skip PC. I also get a PE skip when the PC > routines I use also do the right PE (call this proto-PLL). > > Sound like reasonable logic to others? I'm sure that with my old > order there were step skips as well, but it feels like more. An > average of two " step skips" in a set of 12 runs is a nice situation. > > And, yes, I know the next statement: Learn PLL and you'll always > have one less step (4 to 3)! I'm working on it! > > yeff Odds to skip: Orient edges: 1/8 Orient corners: 1/27 Permute corners: 1/6 Permute edges: 1/12 Total odds to skip a step: about 41% These are the same no matter whether you orient or permute corners first. A 3 look LL with PLL gives you about a 17.5% chance to skip a step, usually the edge orientation. This is the usual way to turn a 4 look into a 3 look. It only requires 21 extra algs and improves your speed considerably. If you were to learn the algs to orient corners and permute edges together, that would work great as well, but be 71 or so extra algs to learn. Your odds to skip a step would be around 29%, though. It would be a nice lead in for a more advanced method, too. -Mike Bennett
1525. Making your own stickers
From: giraffeboy13 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Dec 2005 22:49:39 -0000

Anyone know how you make your own stickers on a computer? Preferably
to make a picture cube?

~John~






1526. Re: 4-look LL order switch = more "lucky" solves?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Dec 2005 23:52:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Odds to skip: > Orient edges: 1/8 > Orient corners: 1/27 > Permute corners: 1/6 > Permute edges: 1/12 > Total odds to skip a step: about 41% > > These are the same no matter whether you orient or permute corners > first. No, I dont agree with that! This is being very technical, of course. But, do M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2. You may consider this to be a CP skip if you do CP first or you can consider this to be a EP skip if you do EP first. But, if you do EP first, then you have 2/12 = 1/6 chance to skip the EP and a 1/12 chance to skip CP. It depends on how you classify that case. :) > A 3 look LL with PLL gives you about a 17.5% chance to skip a step, > usually the edge orientation. This is the usual way to turn a 4 look > into a 3 look. It only requires 21 extra algs and improves your > speed considerably. Well, if you have a 4-look, then you already know 7 of the PLL, so you only really need to learn 14 more. Of course, the J, R, N, and G account for 10 of these if you count mirrors and inverses, so it's not bad at all. :) > If you were to learn the algs to orient corners and permute edges > together, that would work great as well, but be 71 or so extra algs > to learn. Your odds to skip a step would be around 29%, though. > It would be a nice lead in for a more advanced method, too. What? Orient corners and permute edges together? Who does this? :P Are you suggesting learning 71 algs so that you had a 3-look LL? (OE -> OCPE -> PC) ? 71 algorithms to have a 3-look is terrible for only a 29% chance to skip a step! If you learn 78 algorithms total, you can have a 100% chance to skip step 3 (OLL -> PLL!) ~ Bob

1529. Re: 4-look LL order switch = more "lucky" solves?
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 01:59:58 -0000

Hi Jeff, At first I did four steps in this order. 1. permute corners 2. oriente corners 3. oriente edges 4. permute edges I've been combining two steps, three steps, and four steps, heading for a one look LL. Working this way you eventually get to skip quite a bit. Good luck, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@y...> wrote: > > Hi All - > > I'm in the process of switching my 4-look LL order from: > > OE (Orient Edges) / PC (Permute Corners) / OC (Orient Corners) / PE > (Permute Edges) > > to: > > OE / OC / PC / PE > > As I work through it, I'm finding that I'm getting more "lucky" > solves, where I end up skipping one of the above steps. > > Thinking about it for a while, I came up with the following > analysis: > > Once I OC, the four corners (A, B, C, D) are in some order. If > I "fix" A, then there are only 6 orders for B, C, D = BCD, BDC, CBD, > CDB, DBC, DCB (let's say I'm looking at them from the top). So, 1/6 > of the time I get to skip PC. I also get a PE skip when the PC > routines I use also do the right PE (call this proto-PLL). > > Sound like reasonable logic to others? I'm sure that with my old > order there were step skips as well, but it feels like more. An > average of two " step skips" in a set of 12 runs is a nice situation. > > And, yes, I know the next statement: Learn PLL and you'll always > have one less step (4 to 3)! I'm working on it! > > yeff >

1533. FAQ for getting started?
From: "stuarthall_ct" <stuart.a.hall@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 03:05:46 -0000

Sorry to intrude, but is there an FAQ for understanding how the
various algorithms work beyond a beginners method for solving? I look
at Dan Knight's site, or Jessica F.'s and get very much overwhelmed.

I am thinking that a) I need to practice and b) I need to memorize at
least one solution (currently using Jasmine's beginner page combined
with a single repeated alg for doing the last layer cross - R' U' F' U
F R). So I know I need to do these things... unfortunately it feels
like what it is so far - that is, just learning algorithms without
really understanding what they all do.

Did you all understand what the algorithms did as you began memorizing
them, or do you just do them with the full knowledge that they will
solve the cube for you?

p.s. Props to Jasmine.. this is the first time I have been able to
solve a cube in under 3 minutes, with most of the time looking at the
directions since I don't have it properly memorized just yet.





1534. Re: [Speed cubing group] FAQ for getting started?
From: eric hatch <washyourmonkey@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 7 Dec 2005 19:22:48 -0800 (PST)

i just memorized the algorithms and the understanding of them came after using them often. im just starting to. ive known a beginner method for solving the cube for years and just got turned on to speed cubing a month ago and now im getting low 40 averages. not very impressive i know but its much better then i was. so anyway what im saying is with dedication you will see dramatic improvements but master a beginning method first. dont overwhelm yourself with a lot of algs at once. stuarthall_ct <stuart.a.hall@...> wrote: Sorry to intrude, but is there an FAQ for understanding how the various algorithms work beyond a beginners method for solving? I look at Dan Knight's site, or Jessica F.'s and get very much overwhelmed. I am thinking that a) I need to practice and b) I need to memorize at least one solution (currently using Jasmine's beginner page combined with a single repeated alg for doing the last layer cross - R' U' F' U F R). So I know I need to do these things... unfortunately it feels like what it is so far - that is, just learning algorithms without really understanding what they all do. Did you all understand what the algorithms did as you began memorizing them, or do you just do them with the full knowledge that they will solve the cube for you? p.s. Props to Jasmine.. this is the first time I have been able to solve a cube in under 3 minutes, with most of the time looking at the directions since I don't have it properly memorized just yet. 1537. Step 3
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 04:21:47 -0000

Hello Everyone

For anyone who cares, I have decided to cut down on color neutrality
for the F2B. Instead of starting with 4 different Blocks, I will only
use 2.
White/Orange
Yellow/Orange
White/Red Cut
Yellow/Red CUt

The reason for this is to only have red corners for step 3. When I
learn full CLL/COLL, one color is easier to learn (red instead of red
and orange)

Step 3
I have decided to learn full COLL, and CLL. There are cases when I
can see that I want to change the edge orientations. Such as when I
have only 2 bad edges or 6 bad edges. And then there are cases where
I want to keep the edge orientations. Such as when I have no bad
edges, or if I have 3 bad on top and 1 on bottom already.

Here are 2 examples

F(RUR'U')2 F' or Bruno
Sune RUR'URU2R' or rUR'URU2r' (OLL)

I don't think its worth learning more than 2 algs for each case.
COLL to preserve EO, or if you see something you dont like, CLL to
change EO. Even with 2 algs for each case, there aren't that many to
learn. I have found many OLLs which are also CLLs, so I can use old algs.

Jason

1543. Step 4
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 05:18:28 -0000

Hello again everyone

Mike, you said you averaged 6.01 for step 4 with 13 moves avg?
Thats pretty much where I am. But we're both still doing it at 2.5
moves/sec...

STEP 4

For cases when 1 ledge/redge is already inserted, I need to learn Ming
Thai's algorithms. This could help me greatly. To learn this, do you
guys read the top 3 stickers? ICI, CCC, ICC and so on..
Or do you see bad edges, and know ways to flip certain bad edges?

For cases when both ledge and redge are already inserted, I need to
learn algs to flip 2 edges in M layer(besides (M'UM'UM'd2)2). Or a
faster one to flip 4 edged in M layer(besides F'L'F (M'U)4 F'LF).
Both of these are pure(preserve position).

For cases when ledge and redge are in DF and DB and good, you can use
1 of 3 ELLs to fix edges in upper layer. All are common OLLs.
(FR'F'R)(L'U)(RU')M'
(RUR'U')M'U(RU'r')
MU(RUR'U')M2U(RU'r')

For cases when DF and DB are good, and ledge and redge are in U layer,
full ELL can solve all cases. Even the aformentioned 3 can help.

These are all of my thoughts so far on step 4. It seems like a lot,
and I didn't even talk about the hypothetical ZBesque table for
permutation of 6 oriented cubies.

Jason Kovacic

PS. I need help with flipping 6 edges. There has to be a relatively
short alg to flip all 6. Position is not a factor. Im guessing Maybe
8 moves?






1544. Re: [Speed cubing group] linux users?
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

I too have been using Fedora for abt approx 2 yrs now. But still i have kept windows as i also play a lot of games. but now im going to switch to gentoo. Sachin. On 12/8/05, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...> wrote: > ahh... everything in the cubing world is a competition... > > and yea, ill switch as soon as my last high school finals ever are > finished (13 days and counting) > > On 12/7/05, Douglas Reed <dougreed@...> wrote: > > Douglas Reed wrote: > > > > >Okay... I've also used SUSE, Feather, Peanut, PCLinuxOS, and SymponyOS... > > > > > > > > Sorry, should be *Symphony* OS... By the way, does anyone else use the > > Dvorak keyboard layout? > > > > Doug > > > > >Now, who here uses BSD? :-) > > > > > >Doug > > > > > >Chris Hunt wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > >>Fine Doug, I've used Fedora and Knoppix too ;) > > >> > > >>I prefer Ubuntu on my laptop as well, but definitely Knoppix on the library > > >>computers :) > > >> > > >>-Chris > > >> > > >>On 12/7/05, Douglas Reed <dougreed@...> wrote: > > >> > > >> > > >> > > >> > > >>>I've used: Ubuntu, Kubuntu, Red Hat, Gentoo, Slackware, Debian, > > >>>Fedora, Mandrake, Lin4Win (based on Mandrake), College Linux, Knoppix, > > >>>Phlak, and Slax. 1545. Re: linux users?
From: sgowal <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 09:25:05 -0000

Although Gentoo might be the hardest distribution to install it is really one of my favorites. Once it is installed, it is very fast (as you compile everything from scratch) and it is actually easy to update (using the emerge command). For the window manager I would recommend either Fluxbox or Gnome. Just my 2 cents, Sven --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > > I too have been using Fedora for abt approx 2 yrs now. 1546. Re: Step 4
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 09:43:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > Hello again everyone > > Mike, you said you averaged 6.01 for step 4 with 13 moves avg? > Thats pretty much where I am. But we're both still doing it at 2.5 > moves/sec... > > STEP 4 > > For cases when 1 ledge/redge is already inserted, I need to learn Ming > Thai's algorithms. This could help me greatly. To learn this, do you > guys read the top 3 stickers? ICI, CCC, ICC and so on.. > Or do you see bad edges, and know ways to flip certain bad edges? > > For cases when both ledge and redge are already inserted, I need to > learn algs to flip 2 edges in M layer(besides (M'UM'UM'd2)2). Or a > faster one to flip 4 edged in M layer(besides F'L'F (M'U)4 F'LF). > Both of these are pure(preserve position). > > For cases when ledge and redge are in DF and DB and good, you can use > 1 of 3 ELLs to fix edges in upper layer. All are common OLLs. > (FR'F'R)(L'U)(RU')M' > (RUR'U')M'U(RU'r') > MU(RUR'U')M2U(RU'r') > > For cases when DF and DB are good, and ledge and redge are in U layer, > full ELL can solve all cases. Even the aformentioned 3 can help. > > These are all of my thoughts so far on step 4. It seems like a lot, > and I didn't even talk about the hypothetical ZBesque table for > permutation of 6 oriented cubies. > > Jason Kovacic > > PS. I need help with flipping 6 edges. There has to be a relatively > short alg to flip all 6. Position is not a factor. Im guessing Maybe > 8 moves? If you're learning Roux, I think adding the ELL and special cases like that in can only help. It's 29 algs for ELL, and the ZB type table would only have <30 algs, as well. Not too bad. I only notice which edges are bad, and flip accordingly. The recognization takes only fractions of a second. The shortest alg I can come up with for orienting all 6 edges is 11 moves, which is the same as doing it the normal Roux way. M' U M U M' U M' U2 M U M'. Basically, it's a move to flip the UF, DF, UL, and UR edges combined with one for the UF and UB edges. The normal way is M'UM' U2 MUM U M'UM'. I can do that one in about 2.3 seconds. The fastest other one I've found is 15 moves: (M'U)*4 MUM'U2MUM'. You should be able to do that one well under 3 seconds after a couple of tries. I can't complain about 5.35 moves/second. :) The normal way is still faster for me, but I've only practiced the new way for a minute. Time will tell. Still, you really only get this orientation (or the four incorrect edges on top, which solves the same way) 2/28 solves. As far as your first alg you posted, try doing those d2's as U2's. It's the same thing, really, but you can click U2 very quickly with an index finger twice, or follow with your middle finger. I definitely need to learn more of this method. -Mike team [zb]
1547. Re: Step 4
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 10:17:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > > > The shortest alg I can come up with for orienting all 6 edges is 11 > moves, which is the same as doing it the normal Roux way. M' U M U M' > U M' U2 M U M'. Basically, it's a move to flip the UF, DF, UL, and UR > edges combined with one for the UF and UB edges. The normal way is > M'UM' U2 MUM U M'UM'. I can do that one in about 2.3 seconds. The > fastest other one I've found is 15 moves: (M'U)*4 MUM'U2MUM'. You > should be able to do that one well under 3 seconds after a couple of > tries. That's a case where an optimization based on orientations with unconstrained centers is interesting. Quite often you can reduce the 11 moves to only 5 or 6. By the way, I did an average of twelve using only the "orientation + UL/UR + M-perm" strategy --> 3.9s. No ELL, no Ming, no Thaï, only M/U. Gilles.
1548. Re: [Speed cubing group] FAQ for getting started?
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 11:39:52 -0000

I think when most people start they are like you, and just want to solve a cube. When I first learned how to solve I just blindly learned algs and did them. Then I started to deconstruct them, see what they did to the other pieces on the cube, which helped me cut down time because I could set things up to do multiple things at once. Once you really get into cubing you will start to see what your algorithms do. Most are pretty straightforward...especially in a beginner solution. Anyways...off to badminton practice... Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, eric hatch <washyourmonkey@y...> wrote: > > i just memorized the algorithms and the understanding of them came after using them often. im just starting to. ive known a beginner method for solving the cube for years and just got turned on to speed cubing a month ago and now im getting low 40 averages. not very impressive i know but its much better then i was. so anyway what im saying is with dedication you will see dramatic improvements but master a beginning method first. dont overwhelm yourself with a lot of algs at once. > > stuarthall_ct <stuart.a.hall@g...> wrote: Sorry to intrude, but is there an FAQ for understanding how the > various algorithms work beyond a beginners method for solving? I look > at Dan Knight's site, or Jessica F.'s and get very much overwhelmed. > > I am thinking that a) I need to practice and b) I need to memorize at > least one solution (currently using Jasmine's beginner page combined > with a single repeated alg for doing the last layer cross - R' U' F' U > F R). So I know I need to do these things... unfortunately it feels > like what it is so far - that is, just learning algorithms without > really understanding what they all do. > > Did you all understand what the algorithms did as you began memorizing > them, or do you just do them with the full knowledge that they will > solve the cube for you? > > p.s. Props to Jasmine.. this is the first time I have been able to > solve a cube in under 3 minutes, with most of the time looking at the > directions since I don't have it properly memorized just yet. > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! 1549. Re: [Speed cubing group] linux users?
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 8 Dec 2005 10:11:20 -0500

I've used (roughly in this order): Theodore Tso's bootdisk/rootdisk,
SLS, Slackware, Redhat, Mandrake, Debian, Knoppix, Knoppmyth, Xebian,
and Gentoo. I don't remember when I started exactly, but it was in 91
or 92. Right now, I'm running Knoppmyth on my Mythtv server, Xebian
on my Xbox and Gentoo on my Laptop.


1550. Re: What is your fastest time possible for LL??
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 16:09:58 -0000

I see, just a right-hand Sune and a left-hand Sune that partially cancel each other out. That is slick! I see the rotated version is essentially the same idea. Thanks, guys! By the way, I know Lars Petrus named the Sune (and a few other algorithms). Is there any significance to the names, or were they more or less chosen at random? 1552. Re: FAQ for getting started?
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 17:59:23 -0000

Hi Stuart, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "stuarthall_ct" <stuart.a.hall@g...> wrote: > > Sorry to intrude, but is there an FAQ for understanding how the > various algorithms work beyond a beginners method for solving? I look > at Dan Knight's site, or Jessica F.'s and get very much overwhelmed. No FAQ that I know of. One organizing principle for movement in the first two layers is freedom of movement. > I am thinking that a) I need to practice and b) I need to memorize at > least one solution (currently using Jasmine's beginner page combined > with a single repeated alg for doing the last layer cross - R' U' F' U > F R). So I know I need to do these things... unfortunately it feels > like what it is so far - that is, just learning algorithms without > really understanding what they all do. If you start at the Last Level, and work backward from there, you can step through algorithms, starting from a solved cube, and watch what each algorithm does, this can give you insight as to why and how they work. > Did you all understand what the algorithms did as you began memorizing > them, or do you just do them with the full knowledge that they will > solve the cube for you? Yes I understood what each algorithms did before I started using it. Memory follows comprehension, so once I figured out an algorithm it was in my memory. Only recently have I attempted to write them down, for some odd reason this is difficult for me and I've only written down about 300 so far. I "memorize" an alg by using it, that's both muscle memory and following it in my mind. I never just sit there and do one over and over a hundred times. I'm trying to reorganize all my algs and when I'm done that I might sit down and try repetition type memorization. > p.s. Props to Jasmine.. this is the first time I have been able to > solve a cube in under 3 minutes, with most of the time looking at the > directions since I don't have it properly memorized just yet. You might want to look for efficient ways to coordinate your hands for each algorithm you choose to use before you practice it. Regards, David J
1553. Re: linux users?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 18:18:00 -0000

Hi Thom :-) Those who need to "fix" windows every day don't know how to protect the system. But sure, those who use Linux/Unix are lucky cause so far very few bother to hack/crack those systems. Im not sure if this is evidence that mostly Linux/Unix users are making code to attack windows, but the idea is not too far-fetched. According to some experts Linux/Unix has equally many security flaws as such. Oh well, the perfect OS will never exist ;-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@g...> wrote: > > I use slackware, always have. 1554. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: linux users?
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 9 Dec 2005 00:56:01 +0530

Of course your mail is on a lighter note, but i would like to add that the fact that windows is "closed source" is a big hindrence to the security guys. Since linux is opensourced, problems can be detected by good people well before they are started to be exploited. Whereas in the case of windows, first a virus has to exploit the vulnerability, which will tell us that such a bug exists and then the security experts have to patch it up. So its always a cat-and-mouse game here in windows. Hence i think linux is much secure overall. Ofcourse it may have millions of bugs right now but i believe they are getting fixed each day. Sachin. On 12/8/05, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...> wrote: > Hi Thom :-) > > Those who need to "fix" windows every day don't know how to protect > the system. But sure, those who use Linux/Unix are lucky cause so > far very few bother to hack/crack those systems. Im not sure if this > is evidence that mostly Linux/Unix users are making code to attack > windows, but the idea is not too far-fetched. According to some > experts Linux/Unix has equally many security flaws as such. Oh well, > the perfect OS will never exist ;-) > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "thomkirjava" > <snkenjoi@g...> wrote: > > > > I use slackware, always have. I hardly ever use windows, this > limit my > > video editing use, but greatly increases my ability to actually get > > things done as opposed to fixing my system everyday. > > > > Bit of low support for cubing apps though :( > > > > ~Thom > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikorkow" > > <calcdude@h...> wrote: > > > > > > Any of you guys nerdy enough to use linux? Im guessing a few of > you > > > guys do. If you do, which one do you use, and how long have you > been > > > using it? I used Kubuntu (The KDE version of Ubuntu) for about a > > year now. > > > > > > Korkow > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >

1556. More proof that opposite color solving works
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 20:19:30 -0000

Hey everyone,

Not to keep bringing this up, but I really am incredibly excited about
what Opposite color solving has been doing for my times. It took a
while for Richard Patterson to convince me to try it, but now I don't
think I'll ever go back to solving just one color.

My old average average used to be about 17.5-17.6 seconds. My best
100 cube average with one color solving was 17.55. Well I just did a
100 cube average now that I am fairly comfortable with inspecting both
colors in 15 seconds, and my new 100 cube average is 16.83 seconds!

I dropped about 0.7 second from my average, and I haven't changed any
new algs, nor have I been using any ZB tricks in my Fridrich solving
other than the occasional ZBF2L with all flipped edges (maybe 1/50
solves). The only major change is opposite color solving.

I know that for years the view has been that solving the same color
always provides enough color recognition to make your times superfast.
Well I think that is too restrictive. By solving opposite color you
always solve the same F2L edges, that is only restriction. I mean
think about it, does changing the the first layer sticker color on the
corner really change that much when looking for an F2L c/e pair? Well
I say no!

So anyway, I've gotten the feeling that some people are trying this,
let me know what you think! I've also gotten the feeling that people
think this is a weird thing to do since it is different from the
accepted belief that solving the same color is best.

Well I'm trying to break that belief! Try opposite color solving! It
is so amazing, that I will never switch back from it! Don't be afraid
of it being different, it is so amazingly worth it!

Just my views and opinions of course, but I sincerely hope everyone
gives it a try for a short time to at least see what you think.

Chris





1557. Re: [Speed cubing group] More proof that opposite color solving works
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 8 Dec 2005 12:29:25 -0800

You better stop posting stuff like this or I may actually try it :) My first attempts with opposite color cross were pretty bad, but I know this is probably improved with practice. I'll work on it for a couple days and see what happens. -Chris On 12/8/05, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > Not to keep bringing this up, but I really am incredibly excited about > what Opposite color solving has been doing for my times. It took a > while for Richard Patterson to convince me to try it, but now I don't > think I'll ever go back to solving just one color. > > My old average average used to be about 17.5-17.6 seconds. The only major change is opposite color solving. > > I know that for years the view has been that solving the same color > always provides enough color recognition to make your times superfast. > Well I think that is too restrictive. By solving opposite color you > always solve the same F2L edges, that is only restriction. I mean > think about it, does changing the the first layer sticker color on the > corner really change that much when looking for an F2L c/e pair? 1558. Megaminx Help

1559. Re: [Speed cubing group] More proof that opposite color solving works
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 8 Dec 2005 22:16:04 +0100

With opposite color, the hardest part is F2L. For the LL I event get better times with white than yellow on top :p But that can be arranged pretty fast. I'll work on that this weekend and post some results. (until now : I average about 23 seconds with opposite color while I average 19 with white at the bottom :p) Gilles. 2005/12/8, Chris Hunt <huntca@...>: > You better stop posting stuff like this or I may actually try it :) > > My first attempts with opposite color cross were pretty bad, but I know this > is probably improved with practice. I'll work on it for a couple days and > see what happens. > > -Chris > > On 12/8/05, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > Not to keep bringing this up, but I really am incredibly excited about > > what Opposite color solving has been doing for my times. It took a > > while for Richard Patterson to convince me to try it, but now I don't > > think I'll ever go back to solving just one color. > > > > My old average average used to be about 17.5-17.6 seconds. My best > > 100 cube average with one color solving was 17.55. Well I just did a > > 100 cube average now that I am fairly comfortable with inspecting both > > colors in 15 seconds, and my new 100 cube average is 16.83 seconds! > > > > I dropped about 0.7 second from my average, and I haven't changed any > > new algs, nor have I been using any ZB tricks in my Fridrich solving > > other than the occasional ZBF2L with all flipped edges (maybe 1/50 > > solves). The only major change is opposite color solving. > > > > I know that for years the view has been that solving the same color > > always provides enough color recognition to make your times superfast. > > Well I think that is too restrictive. By solving opposite color you > > always solve the same F2L edges, that is only restriction. I mean > > think about it, does changing the the first layer sticker color on the > > corner really change that much when looking for an F2L c/e pair? Well > > I say no! > > > > So anyway, I've gotten the feeling that some people are trying this, > > let me know what you think! I've also gotten the feeling that people > > think this is a weird thing to do since it is different from the > > accepted belief that solving the same color is best. > > > > Well I'm trying to break that belief! Try opposite color solving! It > > is so amazing, that I will never switch back from it! Don't be afraid > > of it being different, it is so amazingly worth it! > > > > Just my views and opinions of course, but I sincerely hope everyone > > gives it a try for a short time to at least see what you think. > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1560. Re: [Speed cubing group] More proof that opposite color solving works
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 8 Dec 2005 22:10:15 +0000 (GMT)

Some days ago I made a very good time using opposite color for the cross. I'm really convinced that is a good thing. Sometimes I have a square already formed on the opposite color, and a bad cross on my normal color. So, what to do? Solve with opposite color. It's cool, and I think I can get better with practice. Pedro Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...> escreveu: With opposite color, the hardest part is F2L. For the LL I event get better times with white than yellow on top :p But that can be arranged pretty fast. I'll work on that this weekend and post some results. (until now : I average about 23 seconds with opposite color while I average 19 with white at the bottom :p) Gilles. 2005/12/8, Chris Hunt <huntca@gmail.com>: > You better stop posting stuff like this or I may actually try it :) > > My first attempts with opposite color cross were pretty bad, but I know this > is probably improved with practice. My best > > 100 cube average with one color solving was 17.55. The only major change is opposite color solving. > > > > I know that for years the view has been that solving the same color > > always provides enough color recognition to make your times superfast. > > Well I think that is too restrictive. By solving opposite color you > > always solve the same F2L edges, that is only restriction. I mean > > think about it, does changing the the first layer sticker color on the > > corner really change that much when looking for an F2L c/e pair? 1561. Re: Step 4

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > That's a case where an optimization based on orientations with > unconstrained centers is interesting. No ELL, no Ming, no Thaï, only M/U. > > Gilles. I've tried and tried, but am missing something about this method. I can't make the third method with unconstrained centers work. Any suggestions? -Mike

charasteristic buildings, and more and of course I bought one. (Still
haven't opened it). Do you guys in the Netherlands know about this
one? Is it rare? Go get it if you haven't got one already.

1566. Re: More proof that opposite color solving works
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 01:00:30 -0000

For me, the question has never been wether it's a good a bad thing to start with either white or yellow. The question is, why don't all Fridrichians (who cube with such a color scheme) use it? Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > Not to keep bringing this up, but I really am incredibly excited about > what Opposite color solving has been doing for my times. It took a > while for Richard Patterson to convince me to try it, but now I don't > think I'll ever go back to solving just one color. > > My old average average used to be about 17.5-17.6 seconds. My best > 100 cube average with one color solving was 17.55. Well I just did a > 100 cube average now that I am fairly comfortable with inspecting both > colors in 15 seconds, and my new 100 cube average is 16.83 seconds! > > I dropped about 0.7 second from my average, and I haven't changed any > new algs, nor have I been using any ZB tricks in my Fridrich solving > other than the occasional ZBF2L with all flipped edges (maybe 1/50 > solves). The only major change is opposite color solving. > > I know that for years the view has been that solving the same color > always provides enough color recognition to make your times superfast. > Well I think that is too restrictive. By solving opposite color you > always solve the same F2L edges, that is only restriction. I mean > think about it, does changing the the first layer sticker color on the > corner really change that much when looking for an F2L c/e pair? Well > I say no! > > So anyway, I've gotten the feeling that some people are trying this, > let me know what you think! I've also gotten the feeling that people > think this is a weird thing to do since it is different from the > accepted belief that solving the same color is best. > > Well I'm trying to break that belief! Try opposite color solving! It > is so amazing, that I will never switch back from it! Don't be afraid > of it being different, it is so amazingly worth it! > > Just my views and opinions of course, but I sincerely hope everyone > gives it a try for a short time to at least see what you think. > > Chris >

1572. Re: Step 4
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 07:20:51 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > It's just matter of defining "orientations". > > Look at my site again, the page has been rewritten a few days ago. > > > > Gilles > > Thanks very much! I haven't been in a couple of weeks. I'm going to > spend the night working on this new way. Wish me luck. > > -Mike Wow. I've been trying to do this for months and had no luck whatsoever. It just clicked tonight. Of course, it still takes me forever to do, but I'm going to have to work on it a lot now. I've noticed, though, that when I get to the point where I need to place the UL+UR edges, the UF+UB edges are often already solved. This is really just one of the 4 PME cases, with a U adjustment at the end. I think I may try to incorporate this a little and see how it works. Does anyone else do this on a regular basis?
1573. Re: More proof that opposite color solving works
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 08:36:35 -0000

Hey Gilles, I guess my best response is "I don't know." I think full color neutrality would really make solving the cross easy. I actually used to do this in my first year of speedcubing and average about 5.5 moves for the cross (1 move less than 1 color very consistently). I switched to one color when that was the "cool" thing to do though. I guess I do like the benefit gained from always solving the same color(s) to some extent. I think I would have a harder time finding an Xcross if I was searching on any color (which is a huge part of my personal strategy) but maybe with practice it would work? I guess for myself I am trying to find a balance between improving my odds for an easy start, and having color familiarity. For me opposite color solving does that, since I always solve the same F2L edges. I guess for me personally I don't want to move back to full color neutrality, since I think I wouldn't use Xcross as often. Also I do like having the F2L edges always looking the same. Also, I do sometimes solve a non-white and non-yellow color if the cross is 2 moves or less, or the Xcross is 4 moves or so. This is very rare, but I do get fast solves with it sometimes. I guess the full color neutrality depends on the person. I personally don't want that much freedom, but more than just solving on color all the time. Just my 0.02 of course, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > At the WC, I met a japanese guy (I can't remember his name > unfortunately) who averages 16 seconds and starts on any color. > > Is that the ultimate goal ? "any color" ? :p > Gilles.
1574. [Speed cubing group] stickers to change the color scheme
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 9 Dec 2005 09:36:30 +0100

Hello,

I'm going to change one of my cube color scheme, but in order to save
some stickers, I would like to do a maximum by just changing the
position of some pieces.

I'd like to swap the 2 adjacent colors (white and red in my case) to
get back to a "normal" color scheme (yes I'm changing my stupid color
scheme I came up with at the WC :p)

At the moment the number of stickers I have to change is 10 (instead of 18).
I flipped manually one edge and swaped 2 corners (manually too) + I
permuted 4 edges with algorithms.

Is there a smaller number of stickers to change the color scheme ? or
is it already the maximum ?

Thx, Gilles.


1575. Re: Step 4
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 10:50:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I've noticed, though, that when I get to the point where I need to > place the UL+UR edges, the UF+UB edges are often already solved. This > is really just one of the 4 PME cases, with a U adjustment at the end. > I think I may try to incorporate this a little and see how it works. > Does anyone else do this on a regular basis? I was proposing it in http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/23314 That's one of the tricks that can be useful at slow speed, but I'm skeptical about using it for speed. Gilles.
1576. Re: Step 4
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 11:02:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > I was proposing it in http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/23314 > That's one of the tricks that can be useful at slow speed, but I'm skeptical about using it for speed. > > Gilles. After trying it several times, I only got one nice solve out of many. I think 1 out of 8 went well that way. The one was an 18.xx, but the rest were over 20. How on earth do you recognize the correct/incorrect edges with unconstrained centers so quickly? My fastest solve that way was still a 30+. -Mike
1577. Re: Step 4
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 11:21:52 -0000


> How on earth do you recognize the correct/incorrect edges with
> unconstrained centers so quickly? My fastest solve that way was still
> a 30+.

I think it's possible to anticipate the orientation pattern with
unconstrained centers, but since orienting them early is almost free,
don't bother with it. And you get the same chance of generating a
lucky case.

Oriented centers make fast recognition possible.
When you choose to use one of the proposed optimizations, U/D centers
go to F/B. But that's not a problem, since the orientation step is
almost over.

Gilles.






1578. Re: Step 4
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 11:33:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > I think it's possible to anticipate the orientation pattern with > unconstrained centers, but since orienting them early is almost free, > don't bother with it. And you get the same chance of generating a > lucky case. > > Oriented centers make fast recognition possible. > When you choose to use one of the proposed optimizations, U/D centers > go to F/B. But that's not a problem, since the orientation step is > almost over. > > Gilles. I've now gotten a few in the 28.xx range, but they were simple cases. Based on the number of moves you save, it looks like learning the special optimizations for the 4 and 6 incorrect edge cases should come first. I suppose I should probably try to do that tomorrow, though, what with work in 2.5 hours and all... -Mike
1579. Re: [Speed cubing group] stickers to change the color scheme
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 9 Dec 2005 11:46:25 +0000 (GMT)

I asked Stefan about this a while ago, and here is his answer: "But for the 3x3 it's better to take the cube apart. Hold yellow and blue on top and front (in your case, Gilles, is white and red...). Now imagine you take out the block of five pieces UF+UFL+UFR+U+F, rotate it 180 degrees and put it back in. Also, swap UL<->FL and UR<->FR, this can be done easily with algorithm (L2 S' E' L E L2 S L'). After you do all this, only 8 stickers will be on wrong sides: 3 yellow, 3 blue, 1 red, 1 orange.*" *For you, I think is 3 white, 3 red, 1 blue and 1 green... Good luck! Pedro Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...> escreveu: Hello, I'm going to change one of my cube color scheme, but in order to save some stickers, I would like to do a maximum by just changing the position of some pieces. I'd like to swap the 2 adjacent colors (white and red in my case) to get back to a "normal" color scheme (yes I'm changing my stupid color scheme I came up with at the WC :p) At the moment the number of stickers I have to change is 10 (instead of 18). I flipped manually one edge and swaped 2 corners (manually too) + I permuted 4 edges with algorithms. Is there a smaller number of stickers to change the color scheme ? or is it already the maximum ? Thx, Gilles. --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- --------------------------------- Yahoo! doce lar. Faça do Yahoo! sua homepage. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1580. Re: [Speed cubing group] stickers to change the color scheme
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 9 Dec 2005 08:04:30 -0500

That is assuming that your centers pieces aren't permanently attached. On 12/9/05, Pedro <pedrosino1@...> wrote: > I asked Stefan about this a while ago, and here is his answer: > > "But for the 3x3 it's better to take the cube apart. Hold yellow and > blue on top and front (in your case, Gilles, is white and red...). Now imagine you take out the block of five pieces UF+UFL+UFR+U+F, rotate it 180 degrees and put it back in. Also, swap UL<->FL and UR<->FR, this can be done easily with algorithm (L2 S' E' L E L2 S L'). > After you do all this, only 8 stickers will be on wrong sides: 3 > yellow, 3 > blue, 1 red, 1 orange.*"
1581. Re: FAQ for getting started?
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 13:17:21 -0000

Hey Stuart, I made a tutorial a while back that tries to explain how the moves work. Go to www.solvethecube.co.uk, and click through to 'Tutorials' and choose the second tutorial. It's a pretty big tutorial, but I hope you'll like it. - Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "stuarthall_ct" <stuart.a.hall@g...> wrote: > > Sorry to intrude, but is there an FAQ for understanding how the > various algorithms work beyond a beginners method for solving? I look > at Dan Knight's site, or Jessica F.'s and get very much overwhelmed. > > I am thinking that a) I need to practice and b) I need to memorize at > least one solution (currently using Jasmine's beginner page combined > with a single repeated alg for doing the last layer cross - R' U' F' U > F R). So I know I need to do these things... unfortunately it feels > like what it is so far - that is, just learning algorithms without > really understanding what they all do. > > Did you all understand what the algorithms did as you began memorizing > them, or do you just do them with the full knowledge that they will > solve the cube for you? > > p.s. Props to Jasmine.. this is the first time I have been able to > solve a cube in under 3 minutes, with most of the time looking at the > directions since I don't have it properly memorized just yet. >
1582. Re: [Speed cubing group] More proof that opposite color solving works
From: Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 06:25:01 -0800

I would do it, except my cross sucks and I don't know what to look for.
I guess I'll take a look at that and try figuring out how to do an
Xcross over winter break before trying my hand at opposite color solving.


cmhardw wrote:
> Hey everyone,
>
> Not to keep bringing this up, but I really am incredibly excited about
> what Opposite color solving has been doing for my times. It took a
> while for Richard Patterson to convince me to try it, but now I don't
> think I'll ever go back to solving just one color.
>
> My old average average used to be about 17.5-17.6 seconds. My best
> 100 cube average with one color solving was 17.55. Well I just did a
> 100 cube average now that I am fairly comfortable with inspecting both
> colors in 15 seconds, and my new 100 cube average is 16.83 seconds!
>
> I dropped about 0.7 second from my average, and I haven't changed any
> new algs, nor have I been using any ZB tricks in my Fridrich solving
> other than the occasional ZBF2L with all flipped edges (maybe 1/50
> solves). The only major change is opposite color solving.
>
> I know that for years the view has been that solving the same color
> always provides enough color recognition to make your times superfast.
> Well I think that is too restrictive. By solving opposite color you
> always solve the same F2L edges, that is only restriction. I mean
> think about it, does changing the the first layer sticker color on the
> corner really change that much when looking for an F2L c/e pair? Well
> I say no!
>
> So anyway, I've gotten the feeling that some people are trying this,
> let me know what you think! I've also gotten the feeling that people
> think this is a weird thing to do since it is different from the
> accepted belief that solving the same color is best.
>
> Well I'm trying to break that belief! Try opposite color solving! It
> is so amazing, that I will never switch back from it! Don't be afraid
> of it being different, it is so amazingly worth it!
>
> Just my views and opinions of course, but I sincerely hope everyone
> gives it a try for a short time to at least see what you think.
>
> Chris
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

1588. why did I do this?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 19:13:14 -0000

So yeah... I stayed up all night to finish a paper that is worth 100%
of my grade for my history class. I turned it in 3 hours ago, and
then went to class.

Now that I'm out of class, I figured I might as well try for the lack
of sleep fastest average.

Well, I don't know if this is a record, but I'm happy with it.

26.5 hours without sleep
Average: 15.66 seconds
Times: 18.12, 14.83, 15.07, 15.05, 16.16, (18.63), (13.98), 17.64,
14.07, 14.74, 16.93, 14.00 = 15.66

This is probably the most unhealthy category next to cubing while
drunk, but I figured I would go for it since I had stayed up all night
anyway.

Wow... lol seriously.. why did I do this?

Chris






1589. Re: [Speed cubing group] why did I do this?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 9 Dec 2005 11:24:38 -0800

Hey, that's better than me. I once pulled an all-nighter "just because
I hadn't done it before" and ended up staying awake for about 40
consecutive hours. I think I fell asleep for a little bit at 28 hours.
Actually, let's see, so my flight to Orlando was at 10 PM, but I
didn't sleep on the plane and I think I woke up at 10 that day, and I
ended up getting to sleep at about 1 AM EST two days later... you might
be able to tell I'm not the biggest fan of math.

The cubing while drunk record is very subjective. I remember seeing a
17-second record on there. Now, whereas 17 seconds might be very slow
while someone is drunk, it's nothing comparable to a +1 minute average
of a sub-20 cuber. That, my friend, is true following of the spirit of
the unofficial world records :-P.

So why do we do these things? Because we can! And we're awesome when
we try! 15.66 second average is generally enough for most people to
wet their pants to. If you check out http://www.beermile.com/, there's
this thing called the "Renaissance Mile". Unfortunately, I'm 5'6" and
I can't really dunk a basketball without standing on someone's
shoulders, a step ladder, or a springy trampoline, but the record for
the Renaissance Mile is unclaimed.

If you're done with finals, you know what to do.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

> 14.07, 14.74, 16.93, 14.00 = 15.66
>

> Wow... lol seriously.. why did I do this?

1590. SV: [Speed cubing group] why did I do this?
From: "Dennis Nilssson" <massimo@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 9 Dec 2005 21:59:50 +0100

Hey,
26.5 hours. That's nothing. Back in 94 I stayed up for 36h+ watching this
demo http://www.pouet.net/prod.php?which=99 and playing arcade games on my
Amiga 500 with some friend and drinking beer.... (Really good demo btw for
being made 1992, haven't seen it since then)

But, a couple of years ago, just before my final exam I remember I stayed up
for 50h+ programming C++ for my masters thesis "non-linear contact problems
with the finite element method". Fortunately, I had not found my old cube so
there where very small delays...

Nowadays, one may think why do we spend 1000h+ cubing (hopefully with
sleeping in between)? Well, for the fun of it!

Ok, just had to share my experience. Btw, opposite colour solving is really
good. After just a couple of solves (20 or so) I did not worse/better than
with my usual colour. Why DID'NT I do this before?

// Dennis www.cubeloop.com

1591. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] why did I do this?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 22:18:13 -0000

Back before I was into cubing, my record without sleep was 69.25 hours.

It was achieved with one night of intense studying and homework
completing, one of support for a friend doing the same (and boredom
because I'd finished all of my finals) and stayed up late the third
evening to see the premier of Return of the King with about 150
classmates.

I fell asleep on the bus home hard enough that they pelted me with
playing cards until I started bleeding, all without waking up. It was
an interesting finals week.

I was up a little over 24 hours a few days ago, but my averages stink
without sleep. I get good spike times, though. And I'm better at
x-cross and opposite color solving. My personal best average that way
is a marvelous 20.01. That's about where I average anyhow.

-Mike
team [zb]

1594. QUestion About Opposite COLOR cross solving..
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 23:10:43 -0000

Hello Everyone,


For Opposite color cross solving, It is just as easy to do OLL and PLL
on either side. But for COLL, Isn't it hard to recognize cases from
the opposite side?

FOr F2B, I use opposite color solving, doubling my chances for a good
3x2x1. When I get to step 3, and have to do the corners, I just do
OLL(7)and a PLL(2). Usually about 5 sec.

With opposite color solving This step is Easy, just like OLL and PLL
is easy for either Yellow or White. But CLL is hard to recognize from
either side. So I think I'm going to start using only 1 color.

Is opposite color solving good for CLL COLL systems?

Jason Kovacic

full turns without regripping made by Oliver Wolff.

I tried to reach it but the most I can do is 5.
I was wondering if anybody had any technique to be able to add a full
turn and twist your arms 6 times :p

as some of you will recognise), and I can assure you that it doesn't
work lol

Gilles.

1597. Re: QUestion About Opposite COLOR cross solving..
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 23:21:09 -0000

Hey Jason, I do use COLL when solving a yellow cross if the case is a fast one (or if I'm doing ZB stuff). It was very, very weird to get used to at first, but with some practice you do get used to seeing the CLL/COLL case on your opposite color. Again, everything about switching to also using your opposite color feels quite strange at first, but if you stick with it, you'll find that it really isn't all that different from solving your regular color. This may be a different case with the Roux method though, since you also have to take the centers into account and those would change orders too. As far as just CLL and COLL go though I can definitely say that over time you do get used to it, but it takes some adjusting. Hope this helps. Don't give up on opposite color just yet! Try it for a bit and see if the CLL gets better. Again I don't know if having to also worry about the changing of the centers orders makes it even harder for Roux method, but so far all the initial difficulties I've had from solving my opposite color I've now gotten over. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > Hello Everyone, > > > For Opposite color cross solving, It is just as easy to do OLL and PLL > on either side. But for COLL, Isn't it hard to recognize cases from > the opposite side? > > FOr F2B, I use opposite color solving, doubling my chances for a good > 3x2x1. When I get to step 3, and have to do the corners, I just do > OLL(7)and a PLL(2). Usually about 5 sec. > > With opposite color solving This step is Easy, just like OLL and PLL > is easy for either Yellow or White. But CLL is hard to recognize from > either side. So I think I'm going to start using only 1 color. > > Is opposite color solving good for CLL COLL systems? > > Jason Kovacic >

1601. avg move count for Gille's Roux Method
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 20:55:30 -0800

I was just wondering what the average move count for each step of the Roux
method is? (probably in STM). Also, does anyone start the first two blocks
by building a 2x2x1 on each side rather than a 2x3x1 on on side then the
other? It seems that would be much more efficient..



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1602. Re: avg move count for Gille's Roux Method
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Dec 2005 05:39:43 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@v...> wrote: > > I was just wondering what the average move count for each step of the Roux > method is? (probably in STM). Also, does anyone start the first two blocks > by building a 2x2x1 on each side rather than a 2x3x1 on on side then the > other? It seems that would be much more efficient.. Would it really be more efficient? How? I do whatever presents itself first, but I have a vague plan I usually follow. The method is incredibly flexible. Usually, I start out with a single c/e pair, and build from there. Inserting edges into a 1x2x3 is easy, and often very quick, because you can see the CLL case and recognize it while completing the last edge. Getting a c/e pair with the edge going in the DL or DR spots is fine, too, because inserting the other edge to make a 2x2x1 is quick. Generally, though, my solves follow the pattern (although I rotate the cube a lot, so the position of the 1x2x3's can be anywhere in the F2L): DL edge, c/e pair, c/e pair, DR edge, c/e pair, c/e pair. There is still a lot of variation, though. Often, to start, you get c/e pairs for opposite blocks you can solve easily, and just fill in the rest. There are also times when you get to solve the DL and DR edges easily, and you're left with c/e pairs only, like F2L. I average about 50-52 moves total for the method. (STM) -Mike team [zb]
1603. Re: QUestion About Opposite COLOR cross solving..
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Dec 2005 05:47:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > It was very, very weird to get used to at first, but with some > practice you do get used to seeing the CLL/COLL case on your opposite > color. I agree. If you practice enough with it, you really don't have a single cross color. You have two to choose from. I find that my usual cross color (white) actually makes my LL go easier, because the pieces are easier to see. Maybe I need two white sides... :P > Again, everything about switching to also using your opposite color > feels quite strange at first, but if you stick with it, you'll find > that it really isn't all that different from solving your regular > color. This may be a different case with the Roux method though, > since you also have to take the centers into account and those would > change orders too. Not really. If you orient centers prior to Step 4, you're left with the same recognition for either color. The only thing that changes is the single sticker on the UR and UL edges to its opposite color. If you don't orient centers first, it's the same thing, now that I think about it. The only two things that change are the U color on the UL and UR edges. > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" > <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > > Hello Everyone, > > > > > > For Opposite color cross solving, It is just as easy to do OLL and PLL > > on either side. But for COLL, Isn't it hard to recognize cases from > > the opposite side? > > > > FOr F2B, I use opposite color solving, doubling my chances for a good > > 3x2x1. When I get to step 3, and have to do the corners, I just do > > OLL(7)and a PLL(2). Usually about 5 sec. > > > > With opposite color solving This step is Easy, just like OLL and PLL > > is easy for either Yellow or White. But CLL is hard to recognize from > > either side. So I think I'm going to start using only 1 color. > > > > Is opposite color solving good for CLL COLL systems? > > > > Jason Kovacic If you're going to do corners in two steps, you should permute, then orient, especially if you'd like to learn Gilles' recognization method for CLL. You just see which two corners need to switch 5/6 of the time, and the orientation. If you're using a standard color scheme, which I believe you are, you should get similar colors as opposites. Do you use Red and Orange for your LL color now? I don't see why learning to do two colors is really any harder than getting good at one. The colors are similar, and if you can recognize the permutation, you shouldn't have any trouble. Like I mentioned above, I actually get better LL's with my usual D color as U, because white is brighter. If you practice it enough (more than an hour or two, really) you'll notice how easy it starts to be. Just keep at it. You won't regret it. -Mike team [zb]
1604. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: avg move count for Gille's Roux Method
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 21:56:04 -0800

Okay, it wouldn't be amazingly more efficient, but if you build the first 2x2x1 in the LBD area, F turns can be used without restriction to build the second 2x2x1 a little bit more efficiently. As for the move count, I was looking more for how in many moves the two 2x3x1s are built avg, and how many moves the edges are oriented in on average. -James Stuber _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Mike Bennett Sent: Friday, December 09, 2005 9:40 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: avg move count for Gille's Roux Method --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@v...> wrote: > > I was just wondering what the average move count for each step of the Roux > method is? (probably in STM). Also, does anyone start the first two blocks > by building a 2x2x1 on each side rather than a 2x3x1 on on side then the > other? It seems that would be much more efficient.. Would it really be more efficient? How? I do whatever presents itself first, but I have a vague plan I usually follow. The method is incredibly flexible. Usually, I start out with a single c/e pair, and build from there. Inserting edges into a 1x2x3 is easy, and often very quick, because you can see the CLL case and recognize it while completing the last edge. Getting a c/e pair with the edge going in the DL or DR spots is fine, too, because inserting the other edge to make a 2x2x1 is quick. Generally, though, my solves follow the pattern (although I rotate the cube a lot, so the position of the 1x2x3's can be anywhere in the F2L): DL edge, c/e pair, c/e pair, DR edge, c/e pair, c/e pair. There is still a lot of variation, though. Often, to start, you get c/e pairs for opposite blocks you can solve easily, and just fill in the rest. There are also times when you get to solve the DL and DR edges easily, and you're left with c/e pairs only, like F2L. I average about 50-52 moves total for the method. (STM) -Mike team [zb] SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+gam e&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+g ame&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=irjrM9wdJDBnytECiSfUCw > puzzle game Free <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzl e+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puz zle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=5IEF0wvHk31uvuXI6 ReWEw> puzzle inlay games Educational <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w1=Jigsaw+p uzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word +puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=37T2K_4zOte4R 94IVKMFNQ> game and puzzle Word <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Word+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game& w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+gam e&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=3DsIilZKH4dSS_WgIx9QRg> puzzle game Kid <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Kid+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w 2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game &w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=2-DgzSlkRkTyIak1hdhkgQ> puzzle game Puzzle <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=F ree+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5 =Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=EJHY58oeC85Up2uB7KhBMA> games _____ YAHOO! 1605. [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Dec 2005 10:11:43 +0100

Hello,

Yesterday when I was watching the drawing for the Football World Cup
in Germany, I was turning my cube and something came up in my mind :
What about using a cage method for the 3x3 ?

Some times when you solve the cross, you really have a bad time
(though it's usually not so hard :p) but what if the cross was already
solved, but not with the good center ? (or something close to that)

Wouldn't it be better to do F2L and then LL without the right centers
and then fix the centers afterwards ?

The thing is I don't see many advantages with that, but maybe you'll
see more than I do :-)

What do you think ?
Gilles.


1606. Re: avg move count for Gille's Roux Method
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Dec 2005 09:48:58 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@v...> wrote: >As for the move count, I was > looking more for how in many moves the two 2x3x1s are built avg, and how > many moves the edges are oriented in on average. > > -James Stuber It really depends on how efficiently you build 1x2x3 blocks, and how lucky your starts are. If you build well, you should average well under what you would for typical F2L. If you don't build so well, or you get bad cases, you'll average the same as you would for F2L. I'd peg it around 22-28 moves, depending. Of course, you could use more than that, if you use a lot of two generators, which are very fast. So it's hard to say, really. As for the edges, you should average under 6 moves, if you're not using any optimizations or unconstrained centers. Just the basics will get you that. It becomes less if you start to incorporate special cases. If anyone is feeling brave enough with ACube, would someone work out the algs, number of cases, and average number of moves to finish off the last 6 edges simultaneously once they're oriented correctly? I'd do it myself if I could get ACube to work on my computer. -Mike team [zb]
1607. Re: [Speed cubing group] most turns without regripping
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Dec 2005 11:35:22 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Hello, > > I was rethinking about that record that happenned during the WC : 6 > full turns without regripping made by Oliver Wolff. > > I tried to reach it but the most I can do is 5. > I was wondering if anybody had any technique to be able to add a full > turn and twist your arms 6 times :p > > Btw, here is a video of me trying a new technique (at the Pop Century > as some of you will recognise), and I can assure you that it doesn't > work lol > http://gillesvdp.phpnet.org/videos/RWC05-Most_turns.avi > > Gilles. > How about http://my.fit.edu/~dchristi/cube/spin.mpg ~Thom

Man, I can't believe that someone will ship a cube to another person solve and then pay the cost to ship back...you can just find the solution for yourself on the internet...this world is lost...
