1615. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Dec 2005 16:28:34 -0000

Hey Gilles, Interesting idea. I had never really thought to try that to be honest. Sometimes I do start with centers moves right after I pick up the cube though. Say I have two c/e pairs that connect correctly to the same corner, so sort of like a 2x2x1 block but the center is not the right one. If the center is in a bad spot, and I can't really use face turns effciently then I sometimes permute the center into the 2x2x1 block and finish from there. I do remember once, maybe twice, I actually have had a solved cross bu on the wrong face, and I permuted the center into that face and a super fast cross. That was very lucky to get that though. I think your idea will allow for always solving an easier cross (since you can choose to solve it almost anywhere. I say almost since half of the positions you could solve a cross into will give you a parity error. If you turn any middle layer on a cube where centers are indistinct then you perform an odd cycle on the edges but leave corners alone. Choosing to solve the cross on other faces will make this edge parity possible, so you would have to watch out for that. The F2L is a bit confusing, but you could get used to looking at the side color of the cross edge rather than the center to know where stuff goes, so that is not a big deal. I think the only real hump in such an approach is learning your color scheme well enough to always solve your cross sch as to avoid the parity error, but I think that would not take much work. I actually want to look into this, since for a solve where a cross is mostly or completely built on the wrong face, this could be fast. I'll definitely try it and see what I think ;-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Hello, > > Yesterday when I was watching the drawing for the Football World Cup > in Germany, I was turning my cube and something came up in my mind : > What about using a cage method for the 3x3 ? > > Some times when you solve the cross, you really have a bad time > (though it's usually not so hard :p) but what if the cross was already > solved, but not with the good center ? (or something close to that) > > Wouldn't it be better to do F2L and then LL without the right centers > and then fix the centers afterwards ? > > The thing is I don't see many advantages with that, but maybe you'll > see more than I do :-) > > What do you think ? > Gilles. >
1616. Re: Why did I do This?
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Dec 2005 17:22:49 -0000

Hi all, I don't feel like I've started something new, though it is exciting to see new ideas explored in the community. To be honest, when I solved with one color sometimes I would get crosses that would destroy my times. A few times I would just happen to see the opposite side and think "it's too bad I don't solve for that color!" After some thought I realized this restriction had to go. At first I only solved for opposite color if it was extremely obvious the cross was better (i.e. 6+ turn cross on normal color, 3-4 turns or simple xCross for opp. color) After a lot of work I'm sure the mental barriers for opposite color will fall, and "opposite" will be a relative term. How's dual solving sound? :P Seriously though, this approach makes too much sense. The only reason I can see people not doing it is because solving for one color has been stressed so much. Open your minds cubers :) Soon I will sell Chris on partial cross solving and you'll hear all about that :P -Richard --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Alright one more just before going to bed. Tried as hard as I could > to stay focused for all 12 solves. I'm definitely not going to do > this again any time soon, so I figured I might as well do one more > average before I go to sleep. > > update at 30.5 hours with no sleep > average: 16.87 seconds > times: 14.67, 18.02, 14.57, 16.88, (14.22), 17.82, 16.35, (20.97), > 19.28, 16.92, 16.76, 17.42 = 16.87 > > Chris > > P.S. It sounds like a lot of people are trying opposite color, that's > awesome! I hope it continues to work for everyone who's tried it and > liked it, I certainly think it is a cool method. Richard, are you > having any luck with opp. color lately? Seeing as how you are sort of > the arbitrator of all this? ;-) >
1617. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Dec 2005 17:50:04 -0000

One of the drawbacks of using making a 'cage' on the 3x3 (so doing centres last), is that you can get parity if you start with a wrong cross... :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey Gilles, > > Interesting idea. If the center is in a bad spot, and I can't really use face > turns effciently then I sometimes permute the center into the 2x2x1 > block and finish from there. > > I do remember once, maybe twice, I actually have had a solved cross bu > on the wrong face, and I permuted the center into that face and a > super fast cross. That was very lucky to get that though. > > I think your idea will allow for always solving an easier cross (since > you can choose to solve it almost anywhere. I say almost since half > of the positions you could solve a cross into will give you a parity > error. > > If you turn any middle layer on a cube where centers are indistinct > then you perform an odd cycle on the edges but leave corners alone. > Choosing to solve the cross on other faces will make this edge parity > possible, so you would have to watch out for that. > > The F2L is a bit confusing, but you could get used to looking at the > side color of the cross edge rather than the center to know where > stuff goes, so that is not a big deal. > > I think the only real hump in such an approach is learning your color > scheme well enough to always solve your cross sch as to avoid the > parity error, but I think that would not take much work. > > I actually want to look into this, since for a solve where a cross is > mostly or completely built on the wrong face, this could be fast. > > I'll definitely try it and see what I think ;-) > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > Hello, > > > > Yesterday when I was watching the drawing for the Football World Cup > > in Germany, I was turning my cube and something came up in my mind : > > What about using a cage method for the 3x3 ? > > > > Some times when you solve the cross, you really have a bad time > > (though it's usually not so hard :p) but what if the cross was already > > solved, but not with the good center ? 1619. Re: FAQ for getting started?

1620. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 00:31:28 +0100

Yes I practiced it a bit, and you can definitely get used to do the F2L without looking at the color of the center + the color scheme is not that hard to use (maybe if you try opposite color and cage method, it will be a bit hard at the beginning, but it's definitely possible). Btw I could do a sub 20 average using opposite color wisely (I must have used it about 4 times in that 19.5x average) So I'll work a bit more on opposite color to get completely used to it, but it's definitely not hard to switch from white to yellow. I'm going to look for some sort of parity fiw that swaps 2 edges + some centers. This might be an interesting extension too :-) Gilles. 2005/12/10, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>: > One of the drawbacks of using making a 'cage' on the 3x3 (so doing > centres last), is that you can get parity if you start with a wrong > cross... :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey Gilles, > > > > Interesting idea. I had never really thought to try that to be > honest. > > > > Sometimes I do start with centers moves right after I pick up the > cube > > though. Say I have two c/e pairs that connect correctly to the > same > > corner, so sort of like a 2x2x1 block but the center is not the > right > > one. If the center is in a bad spot, and I can't really use face > > turns effciently then I sometimes permute the center into the 2x2x1 > > block and finish from there. > > > > I do remember once, maybe twice, I actually have had a solved > cross bu > > on the wrong face, and I permuted the center into that face and a > > super fast cross. That was very lucky to get that though. > > > > I think your idea will allow for always solving an easier cross > (since > > you can choose to solve it almost anywhere. I say almost since > half > > of the positions you could solve a cross into will give you a > parity > > error. > > > > If you turn any middle layer on a cube where centers are indistinct > > then you perform an odd cycle on the edges but leave corners > alone. > > Choosing to solve the cross on other faces will make this edge > parity > > possible, so you would have to watch out for that. > > > > The F2L is a bit confusing, but you could get used to looking at > the > > side color of the cross edge rather than the center to know where > > stuff goes, so that is not a big deal. > > > > I think the only real hump in such an approach is learning your > color > > scheme well enough to always solve your cross sch as to avoid the > > parity error, but I think that would not take much work. > > > > I actually want to look into this, since for a solve where a cross > is > > mostly or completely built on the wrong face, this could be fast. > > > > I'll definitely try it and see what I think ;-) > > > > Chris > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > Hello, > > > > > > Yesterday when I was watching the drawing for the Football World > Cup > > > in Germany, I was turning my cube and something came up in my > mind : > > > What about using a cage method for the 3x3 ? > > > > > > Some times when you solve the cross, you really have a bad time > > > (though it's usually not so hard :p) but what if the cross was > already > > > solved, but not with the good center ? (or something close to > that) > > > > > > Wouldn't it be better to do F2L and then LL without the right > centers > > > and then fix the centers afterwards ? > > > > > > The thing is I don't see many advantages with that, but maybe > you'll > > > see more than I do :-) > > > > > > What do you think ? > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1621. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 and 5x5x5
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 00:33:12 +0100

The best answer I can give is that it depends on you. The best thing to do if you don't want to buy all of them (btw there is also a mefferts 5x5 ) is to try someone's cubes and see for yourself. Gilles. 2005/12/10, Pedro <pedrosino1@...>: > Hey, people > > I'm intending to buy a Revenge and a Professor cube, and need to know what do you great big cubers think. Which are the best ones? Rubik's or Eastsheen? and are the old 80's ones good? > Thanks > > Pedro > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! doce lar. Faça do Yahoo! sua homepage. > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1622. [Speed cubing group] 3 edges cycle (U permutation)
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 00:41:36 +0100

Hello again :-)

I was playing around with my cube at the cinema earlier today (instead
of watching the commercials) and I found an interesting 3 edges cycle.

Here is the algorithm :
11stm, 13 ftm, 14 qtm
r U M U R' U' M' U R U2 r'

and this is how I perform it : r U r' R U R' U' M' U R U2 r'

I'll add a video of it to my website probably tomorrow (www.belgiancubes.tk)

I don't know yet if I'm going to use it, but some of you who like
double layer turns + M' moves (you can also do it using the double
layer technique = r U r' R U R' U' r R' U R U2 r' ) might like it.

Tell me what you think :-)
Gilles.

1629. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 06:04:06 -0000

>
> I'm going to look for some sort of parity fiw that swaps 2 edges +
>some centers.

I like M' U M2 U M2 U M. It preserves orientation of corners and
edges and also permutation of corners.

Chris






1630. Possible Roux method improvements
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 09:32:02 -0000

Hello all,

I've been playing around with the Roux method a lot lately, and I've
decided it needs as much attention and perfecting as Fridrich and
company are getting. :)

To that end, I've been trying to find ways to speed the Last 6 edges
(and 4 centers) up, and thinking a lot about several variations of the
normal method.

First, there's unconstrained centers. This can shorten some of the
hardest orientation situations from 12 moves down to 5 or 6, but the
recognition seems akin to ZB to me. I need more practice with this,
definitely, but I think that it may take too much time, even with
mastery. (sorry, Gilles) The whole Step 4 method takes something like
18 moves on average, if my math is anywhere near correct.

Instead of orienting and permuting L6E, what if we were to finish off
DF and DB edges, then complete the cube with ELL? The hardest
situations for finishing the two edges should be around 7 moves, with
the average being somewhere around 6. ELL averages about 12 moves, so
that puts the method in similar standing to the normal way.

But what if we only finish off the DB edge? It can only be in 6
places, each place having 2 possible orientations. Thus, 12 simple
cases, 11 of which are 5 moves or fewer. The average move count should
be about 3.5, with the hardest situations at 7. You don't need to
orient centers prior to this step, either. And recognition is very
simple. The hardest case to spot is when the piece is already
correct. :) After this, we could use any of the 22 possible cases
found here: http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dlli/NewAlgSet.html

This would give us an average of under 7 moves to place the DF edge
and orient the LL edges, leaving us with an edge PLL step, as in COLL.
As edge PLL's average 7 moves, our previous step averages 6.5 or so,
and our first step at 3.5, this gives us around 17 again. The
benefits? Aside from the 1/12 chance for a PLL skip, and the
extremely easy to recognize and execute EPLL step, you never need to
change your grip, and after the DF and DB edges are placed, you never
need to adjust the M slice.

Also, there are a number of lucky cases to exploit. There are only 29
or so unique cases for when the edges come up correctly oriented after
placing DB. There are some very fast cases for when edges are
correctly placed but incorrectly oriented, and learning the ELL algs
can help out nicely for the 1/10 of cases where the DF edge completes
itself along with DB. The worst case scenario is 26 moves to finish,
and comes up roughly 1/2880 cases, while the odds for a 4 move or
fewer solution are 1/72.

When someone gets an OLL or PLL skip with Fridrich, the solve is
usually in the low 40's for the number of moves. A PLL skip with COLL
will probably be between 40 and 45. A very nice ZB solve may be in the
mid to high 30's. With good 1x2x3's and a nice CLL case (like
FRUR'U'F' or B' R'FR B R'F'R), a sub or low 30's move solve is a good
possibility. Something like 1/312 solves (more once I learn more
CLL's instead of slow COLL's :P)

If anyone is interested in hearing more about this, or helping me to
further this approach, please let me know. I could definitely use the
services of someone who is good with ACube.

Anyway, that's what's going through my head right now. Gilles, Jason,
and others, what do you think?

-Mike
team [zb]






1631. Re: Possible Roux method improvements
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 09:41:01 -0000

And, because I forgot to finish my thought, here's why I think this
approach has some potential, and you should all immediately help me
work on it:

>With good 1x2x3's and a nice CLL case (like
> FRUR'U'F' or B' R'FR B R'F'R), a sub or low 30's move solve is a good
> possibility. Something like 1/312 solves (more once I learn more
> CLL's instead of slow COLL's :P)

~30 moves @ 3 or more moves/second = sub-10 possible. How's that for
nice spike times? :D

> -Mike
> team [zb]





1632. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 11:42:24 +0100

I don't know why but it doesn't really please me. I'm rather looking for something that transforms an impossible center-cycle into a possible center-cycle (and swaps 2 LL edges at the same time). But it might be a rather long algorithm. (ACube found something in 22 moves, not good for a fridrich solve lol) Gilles. 2005/12/11, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>: > > > > I'm going to look for some sort of parity fiw that swaps 2 edges + > >some centers. > > I like M' U M2 U M2 U M. 1635. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 and 5x5x5
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 12:32:52 -0000

Umm .... I think that actually the Rubiks.com 5x5x5's are the best ones. Thy are more stable than the others. But of course the initial stiffness is a big setback. I hope that my correspondence with Seventowns will be fruitful. I have suggested some changes to the design. The reason many prefer mefferts or the old 80's wahn is cause they use screws and not rivets. I'd really love to see Seventowns switch to good machine screws so one can remove the tightness and also adjust the tension to ones liking easily. And also do those changes to the outer edges. Like i have seen on Grant Tregay's cube it makes the cube turn a whole lot nicer, probably eliminating many of the problems with twisting corner-centers and popping edge-centers and so on. Cause right now most ppl's worry w larger cubes is to get a good 5x5x5. A good 5x5x5 easily saves u 30 secs or more on a solve. I know this from experience. I could never get sub 3:00 consistently on my old Wahn even after balancing the tension. The molding of the pieces was not really good. Well, the kind of 5x5x5 really also depends a lot on cubing style. Im very dependent on a high turn-rate w my cage method. I gain solving time by faster recognition even if my solution is a bit longer than the pairing-up approach. Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > Hi Pedro, > > The old 5x5x5's are the best if you ask me ... also I'm a big fan of > Rubiks.com 4x4x4's. > > - Koen Heltzel > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> > wrote: > > > > Well, it will be good, but, unfortunately, there's nobody with a > 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 near me...: ( > > > > Chris Hardwick, Frank Morris, Ron, Olivier Gaucher, Per Kristen > Fredlund...please tell me which do you prefer and I can have a better > idea... > > > > Thanks > > > > Pedro > > > > Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> escreveu: > > The best answer I can give is that it depends on you. > > The best thing to do if you don't want to buy all of them (btw there > > is also a mefferts 5x5 ) is to try someone's cubes and see for > > yourself. > > > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/10, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...>: > > > Hey, people > > > > > > I'm intending to buy a Revenge and a Professor cube, and need to > know what do you great big cubers think. Which are the best ones? > Rubik's or Eastsheen? and are the old 80's ones good? > > > Thanks > > > > > > Pedro > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > > Yahoo! doce lar. 1636. Re: Possible Roux method improvements
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 12:46:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > To that end, I've been trying to find ways to speed the Last 6 edges > (and 4 centers) up, and thinking a lot about several variations of the > normal method. > > First, there's unconstrained centers. This can shorten some of the > hardest orientation situations from 12 moves down to 5 or 6, but the > recognition seems akin to ZB to me. I need more practice with this, > definitely, but I think that it may take too much time, even with > mastery. I wrote that some of them only are interesting. Case 3a for example, it would stupid to start a 7 moves orientation sequence (including two U2). M' is enough. And the case is rather easy to recognize, with UL and UR on top. If an "optimization" makes you loose time, just don't use it. As I said, sub-4 is possible without these optimizations. Look at this random solve: http://grrroux.free.fr/capcubeM2.avi Orientation: M'UM'UMUM' Insertion: U'M2U' Permutation: M'U2M'2U2M' A rather long finish, but it took only about 3s and my slices are not as fast as Bob's. > The whole Step 4 method takes something like > 18 moves on average, if my math is anywhere near correct. Wrong, it should be around 14 if you mix 4a+4b and 4b+4c. > Instead of orienting and permuting L6E, what if we were to finish off > DF and DB edges, then complete the cube with ELL? The hardest > situations for finishing the two edges should be around 7 moves, with > the average being somewhere around 6. ELL averages about 12 moves, so > that puts the method in similar standing to the normal way. > > But what if we only finish off the DB edge? It can only be in 6 > places, each place having 2 possible orientations. Thus, 12 simple > cases, 11 of which are 5 moves or fewer. The average move count should > be about 3.5, with the hardest situations at 7. You don't need to > orient centers prior to this step, either. And recognition is very > simple. The hardest case to spot is when the piece is already > correct. :) After this, we could use any of the 22 possible cases > found here: http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dlli/NewAlgSet.html > > This would give us an average of under 7 moves to place the DF edge > and orient the LL edges, leaving us with an edge PLL step, as in COLL. > As edge PLL's average 7 moves, our previous step averages 6.5 or so, > and our first step at 3.5, this gives us around 17 again. The > benefits? Aside from the 1/12 chance for a PLL skip, and the > extremely easy to recognize and execute EPLL step, you never need to > change your grip, and after the DF and DB edges are placed, you never > need to adjust the M slice. > > Also, there are a number of lucky cases to exploit. There are only 29 > or so unique cases for when the edges come up correctly oriented after > placing DB. There are some very fast cases for when edges are > correctly placed but incorrectly oriented, and learning the ELL algs > can help out nicely for the 1/10 of cases where the DF edge completes > itself along with DB. The worst case scenario is 26 moves to finish, > and comes up roughly 1/2880 cases, while the odds for a 4 move or > fewer solution are 1/72. I think that EPLL as the last step is not a very good idea, permuting M-edges is much faster. The standard corners-first approach that begins with solving UL or UR (instead of DB), before solving the other and orienting M-edges looks like a better idea to me. If the first piece (UL/UR) is a bit difficult to solve, just put it oriented in U (don't care wether it's inserted between the right corners or not), apply the standard CF orientation sequence without the last 2 moves, and you end up in the middle of step 4b. For this technique, you should need less than 15 moves on average too. > I could definitely use the > services of someone who is good with ACube. ACube is very nice and useful, but it's not the right tool when centers are moving parts. Thanks for contributing! Gilles. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1637. Re: [Speed cubing group] 3 edges cycle (U permutation)
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 13:01:33 -0000

Hey Gilles, Hehe.. Playing around in the cinema.. :) Reminds me of some people cubing during the shows in MGM studios :). Anyway, nice 3 cycle :). Looks good.. I just dont have a cube with me to try it out now... Can you do it in 1.42 seconds on the stackmat? :p - Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Hello again :-) > > I was playing around with my cube at the cinema earlier today (instead > of watching the commercials) and I found an interesting 3 edges cycle. > > Here is the algorithm : > 11stm, 13 ftm, 14 qtm > r U M U R' U' M' U R U2 r' > > and this is how I perform it : r U r' R U R' U' M' U R U2 r' > > I'll add a video of it to my website probably tomorrow (www.belgiancubes.tk) > > I don't know yet if I'm going to use it, but some of you who like > double layer turns + M' moves (you can also do it using the double > layer technique = r U r' R U R' U' r R' U R U2 r' ) might like it. > > Tell me what you think :-) > Gilles. >
1638. Re: may seem like a silly question
From: "Chris Sz..." <s2chris2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 14:20:36 -0000

I think it's a great substitute. Put on a couple layers of nail polish and then cover that with another couple layers of Hard as Nails or some other clear coat. I think it was Grant that recommnended this. I did it to my megaminx a while ago and got compliments about its glazed look at Rutgers. It also holds up very well and looks the same as the day it was painted. Another thing that I like (but many people don't) is that you can paint right to the edge of and even over the cubie a little so you can't even see the black plastic. --Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, tlceer <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > would nail polish be a good substitute for cube stickers? >
1639. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 and 5x5x5
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 12:18:18 -0300 (ART)

Hey Per, thanks for the answer. And which do you prefer on the 4x4x4? Current score: 4x4x4 - Rubik's: 1 vote Eastsheen: 0 vote 5x5x5 - Rubik's: 2 votes Eastsheen: 0 vote Pedro Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...> escreveu: Umm .... I think that actually the Rubiks.com 5x5x5's are the best ones. Thy are more stable than the others. But of course the initial stiffness is a big setback. I hope that my correspondence with Seventowns will be fruitful. I have suggested some changes to the design. The reason many prefer mefferts or the old 80's wahn is cause they use screws and not rivets. I'd really love to see Seventowns switch to good machine screws so one can remove the tightness and also adjust the tension to ones liking easily. And also do those changes to the outer edges. Like i have seen on Grant Tregay's cube it makes the cube turn a whole lot nicer, probably eliminating many of the problems with twisting corner-centers and popping edge-centers and so on. Cause right now most ppl's worry w larger cubes is to get a good 5x5x5. A good 5x5x5 easily saves u 30 secs or more on a solve. I know this from experience. I could never get sub 3:00 consistently on my old Wahn even after balancing the tension. The molding of the pieces was not really good. Well, the kind of 5x5x5 really also depends a lot on cubing style. Im very dependent on a high turn-rate w my cage method. I gain solving time by faster recognition even if my solution is a bit longer than the pairing-up approach. Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > Hi Pedro, > > The old 5x5x5's are the best if you ask me ... also I'm a big fan of > Rubiks.com 4x4x4's. > > - Koen Heltzel > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> > wrote: > > > > Well, it will be good, but, unfortunately, there's nobody with a > 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 near me...: ( > > > > Chris Hardwick, Frank Morris, Ron, Olivier Gaucher, Per Kristen > Fredlund...please tell me which do you prefer and I can have a better > idea... > > > > Thanks > > > > Pedro > > > > Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> escreveu: > > The best answer I can give is that it depends on you. > > The best thing to do if you don't want to buy all of them (btw there > > is also a mefferts 5x5 ) is to try someone's cubes and see for > > yourself. > > > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/10, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...>: > > > Hey, people > > > > > > I'm intending to buy a Revenge and a Professor cube, and need to > know what do you great big cubers think. From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>

Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 15:53:06 -0000

Hey all,

I need some advice. My N-perms are very clunky and they are the only
PLLs that I cannot do under 3 seconds. I hate this case. Can anybody
suggest any improvement to what I am doing? To see how badly I
perform this algorithm, check out my ("fast") videos:

http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll19.avi
http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll20.avi

~ Bob





1641. Re: N-perms

My N-perms are very clunky and they are the only > PLLs that I cannot do under 3 seconds. I hate this case. Can anybody > suggest any improvement to what I am doing? To see how badly I > perform this algorithm, check out my ("fast") videos: > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll19.avi > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll20.avi > > ~ Bob > Hi Bob I recommend making z first and then R [(U R' D) (R2 U' R D')]2 or R' [(U' R D') (R2 U R' D)]2 for the other case. I find these rather fast.

1646. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 19:15:31 -0000

Hi Gilles, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > [snip] > > I'm going to look for some sort of parity fiw that swaps 2 edges + some centers. This is a long way around, but it is a way to see what that parity is about. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' r' U2 (Which leaves an interesting pattern) r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f You should now have four middle centers shifted to the left one half turn and two edges on the LL, RU and LU swapped. Cheers, David J > > This might be an interesting extension too :-) > > Gilles. > > 2005/12/10, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...>: > > One of the drawbacks of using making a 'cage' on the 3x3 (so doing > > centres last), is that you can get parity if you start with a wrong > > cross... :) > >
1647. Re: Possible Roux method improvements
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 19:25:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > I wrote that some of them only are interesting. Case 3a for example, it would stupid to start a 7 moves orientation sequence (including two U2). M' is enough. And the case is rather easy to recognize, with UL and UR on top. > If an "optimization" makes you loose time, just don't use it. > > As I said, sub-4 is possible without these optimizations. > > Wrong, it should be around 14 if you mix 4a+4b and 4b+4c. My mistake. So far I'm averaging 18-20, but I'm not very efficient yet at mixing steps, and I can't use any of the special cases or the unconstrained centers. Not fast enough for speedsolving, anyway. :) > > > As edge PLL's average 7 moves, our previous step averages 6.5 or so, > > and our first step at 3.5, this gives us around 17 again. This is only my preliminary number, using the actual case counts and blindly applying the algs. I'm sure this can be less if we can find optimizations for it like you did for Step 4. > > Also, there are a number of lucky cases to exploit. There are only 29 > > or so unique cases for when the edges come up correctly oriented after > > placing DB. There are some very fast cases for when edges are > > correctly placed but incorrectly oriented, and learning the ELL algs > > can help out nicely for the 1/10 of cases where the DF edge completes > > itself along with DB. The worst case scenario is 26 moves to finish, > > and comes up roughly 1/2880 cases, while the odds for a 4 move or > > fewer solution are 1/72. I need some assistance finding nice optimizations as you did for Step 4. How did you come up with those? Perhaps a similar process would work well here. I know placing the last 5 edges once oriented should work out to 10 or fewer moves, and the ELL cases work out to around 12 on average, giving those cases fewer than 17 moves on average. But I'm certain there is a way to reduce the moves for the general cases. One good way is to try to orient edges when inserting the DB piece. Scramble with M U M' U2. To insert this with M U M', you leave two incorrect edges for the next step, which is not as nice to fix. Inserting it with the inverse of the scramble now costs you one move, but gives you a nice 3 move insertion for the second step, or possibly a finish for the final 5 simultaneously. > I think that EPLL as the last step is not a very good idea, permuting M-edges is much faster. I'm working on it. ;) > ACube is very nice and useful, but it's not the right tool when centers are moving parts. > > Thanks for contributing! > > Gilles. I know it's not very good for this, but it's better than me slowly attempting to find things by hand. If anyone still wants to help me out with this on ACube, I'm very interested. -Mike
1648. Re: N-perms
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 19:56:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, teemu_tiinanen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > wrote: > > > > Hey all, > > > > I need some advice. My N-perms are very clunky and they are the only > > PLLs that I cannot do under 3 seconds. I hate this case. Can anybody > > suggest any improvement to what I am doing? To see how badly I > > perform this algorithm, check out my ("fast") videos: > > > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll19.avi > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll20.avi > > > > ~ Bob > > > > Hi Bob > > I recommend making z first and then R [(U R' D) (R2 U' R D')]2 or R' > [(U' R D') (R2 U R' D)]2 for the other case. I find these rather fast. > Hi Stefan, Bob, teemu_tiinanen, Where QF means turning the whole cube the same way as F, try QF (F R' B R2 F' R B') 2 and QF (B' R D' R2 B R' F) 2 Cheers, David J
1649. Re: N-perms
From: teemu_tiinanen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 20:11:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, teemu_tiinanen > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > > wrote: > > > > > > Hey all, > > > > > > I need some advice. My N-perms are very clunky and they are the only > > > PLLs that I cannot do under 3 seconds. I hate this case. Can anybody > > > suggest any improvement to what I am doing? To see how badly I > > > perform this algorithm, check out my ("fast") videos: > > > > > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll19.avi > > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll20.avi > > > > > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > Hi Bob > > > > I recommend making z first and then R [(U R' D) (R2 U' R D')]2 or R' > > [(U' R D') (R2 U R' D)]2 for the other case. I find these rather fast. > > > > Hi Stefan, Bob, teemu_tiinanen, > > Where QF means turning the whole cube the same way as F, try > QF (F R' B R2 F' R B') 2 > and > QF (B' R D' R2 B R' F) 2 > > Cheers, > > David J > Those are they same algorithms as the ones I suggested but from a different position, and you use F and B instead of U and D, which is much more slower in my opinion.
1650. 42 Cube Marathon
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 20:22:10 -0000

What are the rules for the 42 cube Marathon? Do you just add up solve
times for 42 consecutive cubes? Do you preinspect?

Someone in the WC1982 mov said something about a 42 cube marathon in
15 minutes. Thats 21.43sec/cube. Where did this category come from?
And did 42 come from Douglas Adams' book?

Jason





1651. Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 Cube Marathon
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 21:28:49 +0100

Hi Jason,

What you normally do is:
1) take 2 or 3 cubes
2) have someone scramble them before you start
3) start the time and start solving
4) while solving cubes, the scrambler scrambles the solved cubes
5) stop the time when 42 are solved.

We normally do not use official scrambles for these unofficial records.
42 is the number of kilometers for a marathon.

The current unofficial record is held by Lars Vandenbergh:
http://www.speedcubing.com/records/recs_misc_marathon.html

Have fun,

Ron
----- Original Message -----
From: kovacic81
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, December 11, 2005 9:22 PM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] 42 Cube Marathon


What are the rules for the 42 cube Marathon? Do you just add up solve
times for 42 consecutive cubes? Do you preinspect?

Someone in the WC1982 mov said something about a 42 cube marathon in
15 minutes. Thats 21.43sec/cube. Where did this category come from?
And did 42 come from Douglas Adams' book?

Jason

1652. Re: [Speed cubing group] 3 edges cycle (U permutation)
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 20:34:34 -0000

Hmm.. From that angle, the video looks like you are doing some identity algorithm... Eh.. The 1.42 is just my record for my favourite U permutation from my favourite angle, which is cycling UR -> UB -> UL -> UR. I can do it on the stackmat sub 2 very consistenty, but I am sure a lot of sub20 cubers can do this too. Cheers! Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > I would do the U2 there with the index and then middle finger, instead > of using the same finger for both moves. > > Also, I re-made my 3-cycle videos. Wanna see? > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll06fast.avi (my slower one) and > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll07fast.avi (my faster one) > > Still slower than Joel I think, though. :P > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > Actually I tried to time myself on this one and I got a couple near 2 > > seconds (hands on the stackmat) while my previous version (using 2 > > generators) is still around 3 seconds. > > So I'm kind of thinking of using this one for this U permutation :p > > > > (Yes I'm a very poor alg performer :s) > > > > But the mirror of this one is awful, so I'm going to keep my > > 2-generator version (which I can do sub-2 hands on the stackmat). > > > > You can watch the videos on my website now ;-) > > (http://gillesvdp.phpnet.org/videos/Perm_U1.wmv) > > > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/11, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...>: > > > Hey Gilles, > > > > > > Hehe.. Playing around in the cinema.. :) Reminds me of some people > > > cubing during the shows in MGM studios :). Anyway, nice 3 cycle :). > > > Looks good.. I just dont have a cube with me to try it out now... > > > Can you do it in 1.42 seconds on the stackmat? :p > > > > > > - Joël. > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Hello again :-) > > > > > > > > I was playing around with my cube at the cinema earlier today > > > (instead > > > > of watching the commercials) and I found an interesting 3 edges > > > cycle. > > > > > > > > Here is the algorithm : > > > > 11stm, 13 ftm, 14 qtm > > > > r U M U R' U' M' U R U2 r' > > > > > > > > and this is how I perform it : r U r' R U R' U' M' U R U2 r' > > > > > > > > I'll add a video of it to my website probably tomorrow > > > (www.belgiancubes.tk) > > > > > > > > I don't know yet if I'm going to use it, but some of you who like > > > > double layer turns + M' moves (you can also do it using the double > > > > layer technique = r U r' R U R' U' r R' U R U2 r' ) might like it. > > > > > > > > Tell me what you think :-) > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1654. Re: [Speed cubing group] 3 edges cycle (U permutation)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 20:55:28 -0000

I did R2 U' R' U' R U R U R U' R on a stackmat in 1.18 seconds. I started with the cube in my hands though, so probably cheating a bit. It was witnessed by Tyson Mao and Ian Winokur too :-) I posted a while back about the 2gen edge 3 cycles I used, but I imgaine it's buried in the archives. I can put them on my page if anyone is interested. That one alg is my fastest edge three cycle out of all of them though. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hey Gilles, > > Hehe.. Playing around in the cinema.. :) Reminds me of some people > cubing during the shows in MGM studios :). Anyway, nice 3 cycle :). > Looks good.. I just dont have a cube with me to try it out now... > Can you do it in 1.42 seconds on the stackmat? :p > > - Joël.
1655. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 23:18:19 +0100

Thank you, That's I asked ACube to do but your solution is better. However it's still very very long and you can't resonably finish with such an algorithm on the 3x3x3. Another possibility is to fix the centers at the beginning. But then it just goes back to a normal Fridrich Solve. So I guess I won't look much more into that possibility, maybe I'll from time to time do the cross on one side and fix the center but it needs to be a very lucky case then. Thanks :-) Gilles. 2005/12/11, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...>: > Hi Gilles, > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > [snip] > > > > I'm going to look for some sort of parity fiw that swaps 2 edges + > some centers. > > This is a long way around, but it is a way to see what that parity is > about. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' r' U2 (Which leaves an > interesting pattern) > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > You should now have four middle centers shifted to the left one half > turn and two edges on the LL, RU and LU swapped. > > Cheers, > > David J > > > > > This might be an interesting extension too :-) > > > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/10, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...>: > > > One of the drawbacks of using making a 'cage' on the 3x3 (so doing > > > centres last), is that you can get parity if you start with a wrong > > > cross... :) > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1656. Re: N-perms
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 22:42:08 -0000

Hi teemu_tiinanen, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, teemu_tiinanen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, teemu_tiinanen > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > Hey all, > > > > > > > > I need some advice. My N-perms are very clunky and they are the > only > > > > PLLs that I cannot do under 3 seconds. I hate this case. Can > anybody > > > > suggest any improvement to what I am doing? To see how badly I > > > > perform this algorithm, check out my ("fast") videos: > > > > > > > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll19.avi > > > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll20.avi > > > > > > > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > > > > Hi Bob > > > > > > I recommend making z first and then R [(U R' D) (R2 U' R D')]2 or R' > > > [(U' R D') (R2 U R' D)]2 for the other case. I find these rather fast. > > > > > > > Hi Stefan, Bob, teemu_tiinanen, > > > > Where QF means turning the whole cube the same way as F, try > > QF (F R' B R2 F' R B') 2 > > and > > QF (B' R D' R2 B R' F) 2 > > > > Cheers, > > > > David J > > > > Those are they same algorithms as the ones I suggested but from a > different position, and you use F and B instead of U and D, which is > much more slower in my opinion. > Actually those are the same as the two I posted to Stefan a couple of months ago (R U' L U2 R' U L')*2 and it's mirror. Yours are good, but people have different styles. The main difference there between using F and B instead of U and D is the angle of the left wrist and with F and B you can see what happening. Cheers, David J

My N-perms are very clunky and they are the > > only > > > > > PLLs that I cannot do under 3 seconds. I hate this case. Can > > anybody > > > > > suggest any improvement to what I am doing? To see how badly I > > > > > perform this algorithm, check out my ("fast") videos: > > > > > > > > > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll19.avi > > > > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll20.avi > > > > > > > > > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi Bob > > > > > > > > I recommend making z first and then R [(U R' D) (R2 U' R D')]2 or R' > > > > [(U' R D') (R2 U R' D)]2 for the other case. I find these rather > fast. > > > > > > > > > > Hi Stefan, Bob, teemu_tiinanen, > > > > > > Where QF means turning the whole cube the same way as F, try > > > QF (F R' B R2 F' R B') 2 > > > and > > > QF (B' R D' R2 B R' F) 2 > > > > > > Cheers, > > > > > > David J > > > > > > > Those are they same algorithms as the ones I suggested but from a > > different position, and you use F and B instead of U and D, which is > > much more slower in my opinion. > > > > Actually those are the same as the two I posted to Stefan a couple of > months ago (R U' L U2 R' U L')*2 and it's mirror. Yours are good, but > people have different styles. The main difference there between using > F and B instead of U and D is the angle of the left wrist and with F > and B you can see what happening. > > Cheers, > > David J > Ah, yes I get it now, those are very nice indeed. I remember when I learnt that original (R U' L U2 R' U L')*2 and it's mirror and I didn't really like those algorithms. Then I found the version with U and D from Twistypuzzles' forum, and it was definitely faster for me. Your algorithms looks very promising, so maybe I have to update my algorithm repertoire ;)

From: "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 23:16:29 +0000

I know at least some of you are into Scrabble, so I thought I'd post
this link a friend sent me about the recent Scrabble World
Championships:
http://observer.guardian.co.uk/review/story/0,6903,1664334,00.html

Even if you're not into playing Scrabble, it's still an interesting
read. I noticed a few similarities between competitive Scrabble and
competitive speedcubing! :)

Jasmine

Then I found the version with U > and D from Twistypuzzles' forum, and it was definitely faster for me. > Your algorithms looks very promising, so maybe I have to update my > algorithm repertoire ;) The important thing is to find algs which suit your hands. If the version you first posted suits you better then stick with it. Generally speaking, if someone has a slow alg the solution might be to turn that alg on its ear. Cheers, David J
1662. Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 Cube Marathon
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 17:47:14 -0800

You know, I'm planning on running a marathon in March. I'd be totally up for it :-P It would be easier if there was a track that was 1000 meters in length. Maybe I'll do it with a 400 meter track just so I don't die. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Dec 11, 2005, at 2:47 PM, d_j_salvia wrote: > Hi Ron, > > Do you have to run a kilometer with each solve? > > Having fun, > > David J > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" > <ron@s...> wrote: >> >> Hi Jason, >> >> What you normally do is: >> 1) take 2 or 3 cubes >> 2) have someone scramble them before you start >> 3) start the time and start solving >> 4) while solving cubes, the scrambler scrambles the solved cubes >> 5) stop the time when 42 are solved. >> >> We normally do not use official scrambles for these unofficial >> records. >> 42 is the number of kilometers for a marathon. >> >> The current unofficial record is held by Lars Vandenbergh: >> http://www.speedcubing.com/records/recs_misc_marathon.html >> >> Have fun, >> >> Ron >> ----- Original Message ----- >> From: kovacic81 >> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >> Sent: Sunday, December 11, 2005 9:22 PM >> Subject: [Speed cubing group] 42 Cube Marathon >> >> >> What are the rules for the 42 cube Marathon? Do you just add up >> solve >> times for 42 consecutive cubes? Do you preinspect? >> >> Someone in the WC1982 mov said something about a 42 cube marathon >> in >> 15 minutes. Thats 21.43sec/cube. Where did this category come >> from? >> And did 42 come from Douglas Adams' book? >> >> Jason > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > >

cube fanatics would take their time to come and talk to me in the
chat. I would like to hear helping suggestions, and would also enjoy
to just have a casual, nice conversation about cubing. If anyone would

will mean you in the chat room

the "Eternity puzzle" it was 1 million pounds.

1669. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 03:59:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Thank you, > That's I asked ACube to do but your solution is better. > However it's still very very long and you can't resonably finish with > such an algorithm on the 3x3x3. > Another possibility is to fix the centers at the beginning. > But then it just goes back to a normal Fridrich Solve. > > So I guess I won't look much more into that possibility, maybe I'll > from time to time do the cross on one side and fix the center but it > needs to be a very lucky case then. > > Thanks :-) > Gilles. You could always use cases when the cross is already solved on the opposite side, and finish the solve with M'E2ME2. If there are any nice blocks or pairs, this may work better than F2R2B2L2. -Mike
1670. Big Post about Step 4
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 05:12:01 -0000

Hello Everyone

I wanted to know what I averaged on move count for step 4. Gille's
site says 15 is about right. Mike- you said you averaged 18-20? is
that right? I took an avg of 100 and here it is. I solved slow
enough to count my moves on all solves (1.5-2 moves/sec).

[13, 13, 12, 15, 12, (6), 20, 12, 13, 15, 11, 10, 16, 16, 14, 15, 14,
12, 13, 12 14, 15,12, 18, 14, 8, 14, 12, 13, 12, 10, 11, 11, 18, 13,
17, 16, 8, 14, 15, 19, 14, 18, 7, 13, 17, 16, 15, 14, 11, 12, 12,
13, (26), 18, 7, 16, 9, 9, 12, 10, 10, 15, 12, 16, 18, 10, 15, 11, 13,
11, 14, 8, 15, (6), 10, (19), 14, 15, (4), 8, 7, 10, (22), 13, 13, 5,
18, 17, 13, 15, 16, 17, 10, 17, 12, 17, 13, 8, 16]
AVG 13.2 moves per solve

I didn't know how many to omit so I just counted all 100 solves. I
bracketed the highest 3 and lowest 3 solves. High 3 were all 6 bad
edges. Low 3 were lucky, OLL skip, PLL skip.


5 Interesting Solves in a Row: [(26), 18, 7, 16, 9]
(26) was 6 bad edges, messed up orientation, had to orient twice. =(

On the 18, DB edge was done after orientation, so I decided to finish
F2L (Mike) and ended up with a Zperm.

On the 7, I oriented and inserted ledge and redge simultaneously, then
a 3 Move PLL. Lucky.

16 standard solve. 2 bad edges

On the 9 the ledge was already inserted, so I used the Ming Thai Alg
for CCC. Or you could say I changed the defenition of orientation,
did an M', and everything was oriented correctly. Scramble F2M'F2 U
MU2MUM.

Jason K






1671. More Step 4
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 05:33:27 -0000

I took 2 avgs after my 100 cube marathon.

6.18, 5.02, 6.31, 7.31, 6.68, 5.69, 6.56, 6.34, 5.09, 6.80, (4.23), (8.50)
Avg 6.20 sec

4.95, 6.62, 9.09, 7.61, 4.53, 5.80, 6.00, (1.85), (10.58), 5.72, 6.06,
5.87
Avg 6.23

I figured that 100 cubes is a pretty good warm up. It was Very
disappointing. I expected better times. I will say that I was very
consistent though, especially on the first avg. 2nd avg had six sub 6
solves, and then a 6.00 and a 6.06. Pretty good I guess.

I usually see an Orientation pattern, ACT, and then take a second
look, and permute all pieces. This time, I solved slower, and payed
attention to where the ledge and redge were going. You can then mesh
the Orientation and Permutation steps into 1. I always look for the
quickest way to pair up the ledge and redge while orienting.
Sometimes that means inserting the ledge into the redge's place
temporarily. Or not inserting a ledge during orientation, to give
yourself a better case.

It's all about looking ahead I think, just like F2L. You can be much
more efficient by going slower.


Jason K

PS If I timed this with the cube already in hand, I think my times
would drop a lot. I may start doing this, but it just feels weird.
How do you guys time LL avgs?

1675. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 08:01:48 +0100

The main thing with this method is that you have to be "adaptative"", you have to be able to put an orange sticker next to a red center at the beginning and not lose time because of that. This can be done with training :-) Gilles. 2005/12/12, Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...>: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > Thank you, > > That's I asked ACube to do but your solution is better. > > However it's still very very long and you can't resonably finish with > > such an algorithm on the 3x3x3. > > Another possibility is to fix the centers at the beginning. > > But then it just goes back to a normal Fridrich Solve. > > > > So I guess I won't look much more into that possibility, maybe I'll > > from time to time do the cross on one side and fix the center but it > > needs to be a very lucky case then. > > > > Thanks :-) > > Gilles. > > You could always use cases when the cross is already solved on the > opposite side, and finish the solve with M'E2ME2. If there are any > nice blocks or pairs, this may work better than F2R2B2L2. > > -Mike > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >

1677. Re: Big Post about Step 4
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 08:20:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > Hello Everyone > > I wanted to know what I averaged on move count for step 4. Gille's > site says 15 is about right. Mike- you said you averaged 18-20? is > that right? Apparently not. That's what I thought it was, but I took some averages just now. 5 sets of 12, but I didn't know how many to get rid of, either. 19 13 18 17 14 16 9 15 14 17 14 16 = 15.17 13 17 10 16 17 17 18 15 16 16 18 16 = 15.75 15 17 16 12 13 16 13 10 14 12 11 17 = 13.83 16 15 14 13 12 14 14 19 12 18 18 15 = 15.00 11 16 4 18 16 19 16 14 14 20 17 17 = 15.17 = 14.98 overall Out of curiosity, I decided to take some using what little I currently know of the strategy I proposed last night. I was somewhat surprised, considering how few ELL algs and F2l+orienting algs I know. Still, I did pretty well, and this only strengthens my suspicions that this is a viable method. 21 14 18 19 13 16 19 18 16 14 15 23 = 17.17 22 18 19 17 13 13*20 19 17 17 12 18 = 17.08 17 14 19 19 21 19 12 20 14 18 17 17 = 15.67 15 18 16 15 14 12 24 17 21 17 20 9 = 16.50 14 20 14 12 11 15 16 12 17 18 18 19 = 15.50 =16.7 overall Most of the solves were done DB edge, DF edge, orient U edges, place U edges. A few that I knew how were done DB edge, DF edge+orient U edges, place U edges. A few more were done with ELL after the DF edge, and some of them I did the DF and DB edges simultaneously. The 23 and 24 were both long edge orientations and Z perms. The 13* should have been 9, but I inserted DF and then pulled it right back out for the beginning of an easy ELL alg. I should have seen that coming. The 9 was an easy orientation with DB finished and left me with two pairs of edges to swap (R2F2R2F2R2F2). I did an average of 50 earlier 23.16 with a best average of 21.64. Considering that's only a little better than I generally do with standard Roux, and I've worked on that a lot lately and several months ago, I can't really complain for a first try. I'm very excited to see what times I'm capable of once I learn some more of the insertion and ELL algs. I'm still waiting for ACube volunteers, though. :) > Jason K -Mike

1679. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 and 5x5x5
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 07:44:43 -0300 (ART)

Come on, people...I need some more answers to have a better idea...please... Pedro Pedro <pedrosino1@...> escreveu: Hey Per, thanks for the answer. And which do you prefer on the 4x4x4? Current score: 4x4x4 - Rubik's: 1 vote Eastsheen: 0 vote 5x5x5 - Rubik's: 2 votes Eastsheen: 0 vote Pedro Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...> escreveu: Umm .... I think that actually the Rubiks.com 5x5x5's are the best ones. Thy are more stable than the others. But of course the initial stiffness is a big setback. I hope that my correspondence with Seventowns will be fruitful. I have suggested some changes to the design. The reason many prefer mefferts or the old 80's wahn is cause they use screws and not rivets. I'd really love to see Seventowns switch to good machine screws so one can remove the tightness and also adjust the tension to ones liking easily. And also do those changes to the outer edges. Like i have seen on Grant Tregay's cube it makes the cube turn a whole lot nicer, probably eliminating many of the problems with twisting corner-centers and popping edge-centers and so on. Cause right now most ppl's worry w larger cubes is to get a good 5x5x5. A good 5x5x5 easily saves u 30 secs or more on a solve. I know this from experience. I could never get sub 3:00 consistently on my old Wahn even after balancing the tension. The molding of the pieces was not really good. Well, the kind of 5x5x5 really also depends a lot on cubing style. Im very dependent on a high turn-rate w my cage method. I gain solving time by faster recognition even if my solution is a bit longer than the pairing-up approach. Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > Hi Pedro, > > The old 5x5x5's are the best if you ask me ... also I'm a big fan of > Rubiks.com 4x4x4's. > > - Koen Heltzel > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> > wrote: > > > > Well, it will be good, but, unfortunately, there's nobody with a > 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 near me...: ( > > > > Chris Hardwick, Frank Morris, Ron, Olivier Gaucher, Per Kristen > Fredlund...please tell me which do you prefer and I can have a better > idea... > > > > Thanks > > > > Pedro > > > > Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> escreveu: > > The best answer I can give is that it depends on you. > > The best thing to do if you don't want to buy all of them (btw there > > is also a mefferts 5x5 ) is to try someone's cubes and see for > > yourself. > > > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/10, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...>: > > > Hey, people > > > > > > I'm intending to buy a Revenge and a Professor cube, and need to > know what do you great big cubers think. Which are the best ones? > Rubik's or Eastsheen? and are the old 80's ones good? > > > Thanks > > > > > > Pedro > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > > Yahoo! doce lar. Faça do Yahoo! sua homepage. > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>

Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 10:08:10 -0300 (ART)

Hehe...I know...I think I'll buy the Eastsheen, 'cause they're cheaper. I found both 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 for 26 dollars + 12 dollars for shipping = 38 dollars the lowest I found for the Rubik's was 45 dollars for the cubes, excluding the shipping, that I don't know how much will be...well, I hope I'm lucky with the Eastsheen...Stefan told me they're pretty good, and Jon Morris said that he achieves the same times on both Rubik's and Eastsheen, so... 1689. Colored plastic 3x3x3 cubes at Cracker Barrel
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 13:15:43 -0000

Cracker Barrel is selling more of the "Magic Cube" 3x3x3, this time
with green, red and white colored plastic. Maybe they have other
colors, too, but that's all this store had. They cost $4.99. The
mechansim and stickers are junk, but they look neat.

The mechanism actually looks like it could be adapted to screws and
springs. The centers have arches and there is a standard burr for the
kernel. However they rotate about on plastic rivets. If you remove the
rivets you might be able to retrofit with a proper mech.

Photo here:
http://twistypuzzles.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=4176&start=0

Chris






1690. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 and 5x5x5
From: "Alberto Cuesta" <arcdraven@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 14:18:47 +0100

you cannot find 5x rubik studio, just 4x.

but I suspect that 4x studio is the same as 4x rubiks.com

now I have 5x rubiks.com 4x rubik studio, 4x mefferts, 5x mefferts.

in general, mefferts are a lot easier to operate. Specially I found that 5x rubiks is hard to rotate the outer layers. in the other hand, mefferts works 100% from the first minute if lubed. With rubiks, you must wait until internal pieced are 'self-sanded' with the use.

I have never timed myself with mefferts cubes so I cannot give you any point about that.

I like more the size of the rubik cubes than meffert's...

hope this helps!

Alberto

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1694. My new Toolkit ;-)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 14:19:55 -0000

Hi :-)

I just bought myself a cool kit of files that i will use for
modifying cubes. The files are only 100 mm, not including the blue
grip. Particularly, i gonna modify those wings/feet of the outer
edges on the 5x5x5 like i described in earlier post.

Modification:

http://vakt.idi.ntnu.no/apartment/Outer_edge_555_fit.jpg

Toolkit:

http://vakt.idi.ntnu.no/apartment/Fileset.jpg

I will keep u updated how it goes :-)

-Per

PS! The set of files only costed me about $5 (less than £3). In
Norway/Sweden/Finland this set is available from Biltema. I'm sure
Walmart and similar stores must have similar sets ...





1695. Re: Does anyone have the time to go into the group chat?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 15:22:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > It's from the introduction in Gulliver's Travels. Ha ha! Well, I guess it /might/ have been intentional (there are other naughty puns in Swift), but the verb is apparently not known in print before 1857. The related noun first appeared in 1766, which is also too late... but perhaps the word was current before then. Let's not get started on those terrible lies about Captain Pugwash. Mike
1696. Re: Are you in a good condition?
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 15:31:22 -0000

For such messages, please specify "off topic" in the subject. Unless you're cubing while running (or installing Linux, etc.). With 1300 messages/month, finding the 15 interesting posts when you come back from holydays is impossible, unless they're correctly labeled. Thanks, Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" <mahtianssi@y...> wrote: > > My record in Cooper's test (run 12 minutes) is 2200 meters. > Not very good... > How about you? >

From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 16:14:59 -0000

Well, last year when I was in shape, I could run 1 mile (1.6km) in 5:30-5:40 or so. 2 miles (3.2 km) certainly under 12 minutes). But, I'm not a runner; I'm a rower. The real question is how long does it take you to row 2000m on an ergometer? :P ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" <mahtianssi@y...> wrote: > > My record in Cooper's test (run 12 minutes) is 2200 meters. > Not very good... > How about you? >
1698. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 and 5x5x5

Rubiks studio 4x4 is NOT the same as 4x4 Rubiks.com Different plastic I think, and again I prefer Rubiks.com. Turns much smoother. 1702. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 17:15:21 -0500

Here's another way using your notation: F' U' F u' R u' R u' R u' R F' U F' u F2 D2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 On 12/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...> wrote: > This is a long way around, but it is a way to see what that parity is > about. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' r' U2 (Which leaves an > interesting pattern) > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f >
1703. Re: Congrats !! (Was: Are you in a good condition?)
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 22:25:20 -0000

Thanx Per!! I was really great to do a time like that. I can tell you that it was a little lucky. I got a U turn as the third and last step of my method but the time would probably have been around 5 seconds without luck, because I did the first to steps in like 2.5-3 seconds and then became a little confused when it almost was solved. I'm most happy with the european record for one-handed solving which was not a lucky case, just a very fast F2L. I'm also very satisfied that I managed to take back the swedish record for 3*3*3 single from Lars Petrus. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi Gunnar :-) > > Congratz with the sub 4.00 world record on the 2x2x2 cube! It must > have felt really good to break that barrier :-) > > Cheers! > > -Per

1706. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Are you in a good condition? (Off-topic)

Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 15:28:02 -0800

So we should all try the "Cube Mile". I think it would work well if it were like the "Beer Mile" (http://www.beermile.com/) but instead of drinking a beer before each lap, you solve a cube. I think sub-6 minutes should be possible (not by me.) I mean, you get slowed down by solving the cube, and so four cubes might take 80 seconds, but you can run faster because of the 20 seconds of rest between each 400. I'd be very happy to do sub-7. 1709. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 00:14:44 -0000

Hi David, Very nice. You made me look for another way. :) U L' B L b L' B' L b2 U2 b U b U b' U' r b' r' Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > > Here's another way using your notation: > > F' U' F u' R u' R u' R u' R F' U F' u F2 D2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 > > On 12/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > This is a long way around, but it is a way to see what that parity is > > about. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' r' U2 (Which leaves an > > interesting pattern) > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > >
1710. Re: Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 01:08:23 -0000

Hi :-) Much shorter in htm is the following : R L u R U' D' F (L2 U2)*3 F' U D L' R2 (based on : R L u R' L' + fixing the 4 last edges) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi David, > > Very nice. You made me look for another way. :) > > U L' B L b L' B' L b2 U2 b U b U b' U' r b' r' > > Cheers, > > David J > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > > > Here's another way using your notation: > > > > F' U' F u' R u' R u' R u' R F' U F' u F2 D2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 > > > > On 12/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > This is a long way around, but it is a way to see what that parity is > > > about. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. > > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' r' U2 (Which leaves an > > > interesting pattern) > > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > > > > >

1714. Re: (Another VERY) Big Post about Step 4
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 09:45:32 -0000

Ok. I've done some more experimenting, and I've come up with a few
new ideas. Because Gilles' method uses opposite color solving for the
F2B, and because we've heard so much from Chris Hardwick lately about
opposite color (and it works), I decided to try to apply this to my
new Step 4 idea. For the last step, you can start by either inserting
the DB pair, or use the DB pair for the opposite color, and finish
your solve with an M2.

I tried this a lot tonight, and it went much better than I was afraid
of. The only thing I really had problems with was recognizing which
pieces to permute with certain ELL cases, but since I only know a few
ELL cases anyway, I think I'll chalk it up to that. :) My best time
using this was a 16.42. Not lucky, in that I inserted one edge easier
using my opposite color, inserted the second, and finished with an ELL
case. All three substeps totalled about 14 moves, which is a little
better than average for that scenario.

There are really 4 separate scenarios for solves this way. The first
is when all the edges are oriented after inserting DB. Ideally, I
would like to learn the 16 or so cases to finish off the edges.
They're all relatively short and easy to accomplish using only MU
moves. They average under 7 moves per alg. All but 4 or so are very
easy to recognize, and the final 4 I have some ideas for. This should
come up nearly 15% of cases, if you can start with any of the 4 M
edges for DB. This is by far the nicest option, because of how short
and quick the algs are, but also the least frequent. Placing the DB
edge intelligently, though, we can get this more often.

The second special scenario is when the DF edge places itself, or is
very simple to place after the DB edge. This leaves you with an ELL
case to finish. I believe the ELL's average around 12 moves to
finish. Again, also this step uses only MU moves, and is incredibly
quick. Using the few ELL's I know, I managed a 15.02 and a 15.92,
neither of which were lucky at all. Both were 3 short substeps.
Considering my best non lucky is a 14.33 with a ZB case I know, I'd
say a 15.02 on my second day isn't too bad. :) That's actually .65
seconds faster than my fastest normal Roux time ever.

The third special case group is much less frequent than the first two,
and comprises all of the miscellaneous cases I've found that are
easier and faster than the other ways. Good examples are (M'U)*4 and
various others built from that. Speaking of which, Jason, what do you
think of U' (L U' l') U (M'U)*3 (L U L') U? Others that fall into
this category are M2U2M2U2, ME2M'E2, etc. This group will hopefully
be much more full once I figure out some nicer optimizations. Gilles,
I'd really like to know how you found your special cases for step 4.
I think I may be able to adapt some of them to this. There are
certainly some unpleasant cases that come up, and I'd like to see if I
can shorten them at all.

The last group is the normal group of solves. In these, you place DB,
then place DF and orient the remaining 5 edges, then finish the LL
edges. This is where the most difficult cases are, and also some of
the nicest. The first substep is placing the DB edge, and averages
3.5 moves, but if you start with any of the 4 possible DB edges, this
drops to under 3. Sometimes it works well to perform a d2 after this
step, if you actually have to place the edge to DF. Next, inserting
the DF edge while orienting edges averages 6.5 moves, but I have some
ideas about how to shorten that. When placing the DB edge, it's often
possible to either influence the orientation to your liking, either by
preserving a good one, or swapping a bad one. 50% of the time, this
only requires adjusting the U face to insert from the opposite side.
The cases I'm having trouble finding good ways to fix are when the DB
edge is properly oriented prior to insertion. The only good ways to
insert it also preserve orientation of the other 5 edges. This is
something I need to work on. Finally, you need only permute the LL
edges, averaging ~6.75 moves.

A possible route to take involves always achieving an easy orientation
with the DB edge, so that you can orient the remaining 5 and permute
them all at once. There are really only 6 possible orientations after
the DB edge is placed. 1 is correctly oriented, another is 3 edges on
top (the 'magical' orientation from Gilles' method). The first takes
zero moves, obviously, and the second takes 3 (or 4, if you need to
AUF). Incorrect adjacent edges takes at least 7 moves to orient,
incorrect opposite edges takes a minimum of 9. All 4 U edges incorrect
is an unfriendly case requiring at least 12, but for all of these
groups, the ELL's are about as good as it gets. The cases that are
tricky are the ones with DF and UF incorrect. These cases can be
changed to correct orientation in 7 moves, or inserted with correct
orientation in 8. This leaves you a L5E option with an average of 7,
but worse recognition, or an EPLL for 1 extra move and easier
recognition. Things to think about.

I spent most of work tonight figuring out average move counts for the
steps, and working out the odds of nice cases. With practice, you can
place any of the DB edges in under 3, finish the L5E if they're
oriented in under 7, finish with ELL if the F2L comes up solved in 12,
or finish the normal way in 13, but the latter two can be lessened
considerably if you wisely insert the DB edge, and choose the nicest
edge to start with.

Starting with any of the 4 possible DB edges gives you an almost 16%
chance for an O5E skip, a 34% chance for an easy F2L finish, and
leaves you with under half of the cases giving you a 'normal' solve,
because that option needs the most optimizing still. Going with these
odds, one can average around 15 moves quite easily with this method.

Going slowly (because I'm still learning most of the algs ;P) I took
some average move counts earlier.
13 17 16 12 17 13 20 17 20 7* = 15.2
10 12 18 11 16 18 17 15 15 13 = 14.5
12 12 16 13 17 16 17 11 18 18 = 15.0
= 14.9 overall
* was an OLL skip after placing DB.
With more ELL's and better P5E, I think this will drop nicely.

If nothing else, the 15.02 was exciting enough to convince me to press
on with this, even if it turns out to be less efficient or slower than
what's already out there. Still, I'm convinced this step can be sub-4
pretty well. At least....in theory. ;P

Anyone with ideas, criticism, suggestions, etc, please post. Gilles
and Jason especially. Don't be so quiet, guys.

-Mike

P.S. Ron's Cube solver sticker applet is a life saver.

1720. Re: Reports
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>

Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 15:08:43 -0000

1725. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 17:53:54 -0000

Hi :-) I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle before the u- turn, like this : R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) I guess that's my best shot ;-) -Per (PS! Lower case letters are inner slice turns here!!) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi :-) > > Maybe even nicer: > > R U' F u - L' f L' B2 L f' L' B2 L2 - F' U R' > > Have fun! (same htm as before, 19 - shorter stm, 16) > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi David, > > > > Very nice. You made me look for another way. :) > > > > U L' B L b L' B' L b2 U2 b U b U b' U' r b' r' > > > > Cheers, > > > > David J > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr > > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > > > > > Here's another way using your notation: > > > > > > F' U' F u' R u' R u' R u' R F' U F' u F2 D2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 > > > > > > On 12/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > This is a long way around, but it is a way to see what that > parity is > > > > about. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. > > > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' r' U2 (Which > leaves an > > > > interesting pattern) > > > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > > > > > > > > >
