1730. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 19:12:54 -0000

Hehe ... This is fun ! Another pattern along these lines is the following: F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18-htm, 17-stm) or F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14-stm) (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice turns...) I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search for me cause of course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving something close to a full > scramble :p > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this approach or not :s > > Gilles. > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > Hi :-) > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle before the u- > > turn, like this : > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > -Per > > > > (PS! Lower case letters are inner slice turns here!!) > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > Maybe even nicer: > > > > > > R U' F u - L' f L' B2 L f' L' B2 L2 - F' U R' > > > > > > Have fun! (same htm as before, 19 - shorter stm, 16) > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > > > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Hi David, > > > > > > > > Very nice. You made me look for another way. :) > > > > > > > > U L' B L b L' B' L b2 U2 b U b U b' U' r b' r' > > > > > > > > Cheers, > > > > > > > > David J > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr > > > > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Here's another way using your notation: > > > > > > > > > > F' U' F u' R u' R u' R u' R F' U F' u F2 D2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 > > > > > > > > > > On 12/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > This is a long way around, but it is a way to see what that > > > parity is > > > > > > about. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. > > > > > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' r' U2 (Which > > > leaves an > > > > > > interesting pattern) > > > > > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1734. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 22:29:38 +0100

It's funny that the centers are cycles clockwise (looking from the top), and the edges anti-clockwise. Now add an H permutation and you have a very nice pattern :p (swap the opposite edges on the top layer). it's some sort of 'Arc de Triomphe' (the monument in Paris):D Gilles 2005/12/13, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>: > Very nice algorithms Per :p > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > Gilles. > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...>: > > Hehe ... > > > > This is fun ! > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18-htm, 17-stm) > > > > or > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14-stm) > > > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice turns...) > > > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search for me cause of > > course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving something close to a > > full > > > scramble :p > > > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this approach or not :s > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle before the u- > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > > > > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > (PS! Lower case letters are inner slice turns here!!) > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > Maybe even nicer: > > > > > > > > > > R U' F u - L' f L' B2 L f' L' B2 L2 - F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! 1735. Re: [Speed cubing group] F2L page
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 22:34:19 +0100

Very nice tricks Bob :-) Oh I noticed a little mistake : you have to swap in case number 1 BR and BL ;-) Gilles. 2005/12/13, Bob Burton <bob@cubewhiz.com>: > Hey all, > > Finally, my F2L page has all the angles that I solve from. Once I add > the videos, the page is done! :) > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/f2l.html > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
1736. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 22:23:27 +0100

Very nice algorithms Per :p I'm amazed how you can find these. Gilles. 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...>: > Hehe ... > > This is fun ! > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18-htm, 17-stm) > > or > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14-stm) > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice turns...) > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search for me cause of > course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving something close to a > full > > scramble :p > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this approach or not :s > > > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle before the u- > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > (PS! 1737. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 22:14:46 -0000

Hi Gilles !! It's not hard find these if u understand the nature of inner slice turns. They cycle 4 centers and 4 edges. So u know how many edges that u have to "fix" after such a turn. And you insert edges into the slice as needed. Oh, and 25 yrs of cubing experience and fewest moves does help a lot :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Very nice algorithms Per :p > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > Gilles. > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > Hehe ... > > > > This is fun ! > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18-htm, 17-stm) > > > > or > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14-stm) > > > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice turns...) > > > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search for me cause of > > course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving something close to a > > full > > > scramble :p > > > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this approach or not :s > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle before the u- > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > > > > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > (PS! Lower case letters are inner slice turns here!!) > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > Maybe even nicer: > > > > > > > > > > R U' F u - L' f L' B2 L f' L' B2 L2 - F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! 1738. PELL move COunt
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 23:52:42 -0000

Hello Everyone.


PELLs I Use

R2 U (RUR'U')R'U'(R'UR') 11
R2 d'(M'U2M) d'r2 7
M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2 7
M2 U M2 U u2 M' E2 M' 8


>From Speedcubing.com, I read this in the Algorithms section

"- in 1 out of 12 cases you can solve the LL in one algorithm!
- in 8 out of 12 cases you leave an easy 3-cycle of edges
- in 2 out of 12 cases you leave the edges zigzag permutation
- in 1 out of 12 cases you leave the edges cross permutation"

So PELL Avg = (1(0) + 4(11) + 4(7) + 2(8) + 1(7))/12
= (44 + 28 + 16 + 7)/12
= 95/12
= 7.916666

Is this correct?

ELL Move Count 12?
PELL Move Count 8?
CLL Move Count 9?
COLL Move Count 14?

I wanted to again ask about these categories. The Only ones I know
for sure are PELL = 8 and Step 4 = 13.2, because I calculated myself.
Bob, you gave me 9 and 14 for CLL/COLL, I think.

Has anybody calculated CLL, COLL, OLL, PLL, ELL, PELL, but taking into
account the chance or occurance of each case? Have I done that
correctly with PELL?

Jason Kovacic





1739. Re: PELL move Count
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 01:17:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > So PELL Avg = (1(0) + 4(11) + 4(7) + 2(8) + 1(7))/12 > = (44 + 28 + 16 + 7)/12 > = 95/12 > = 7.916666 > > Is this correct? Yes, it is. If you used optimal algs, it would be 11(7)/12. ;) My PELLs though are [8(11) + 2(9) + 7]/12, so I have a 9.4 move average for this step. For me, PLL averages 11.9 moves (using the ones listed on my PLL page). However, this is a 75% chance of having to AUF after a PLL, so it is actually 12.65 moves on average for my PLL. My COLL move average (again, using the ones on my page) is 9.22 moves. This takes into the probabilities of each case and a 1/27 chance to skip OLL, assuming you orient all edges during F2L. > ELL Move Count 12? STM, right? > PELL Move Count 8? For me, 9.4 > CLL Move Count 9? Probably less > COLL Move Count 14? For me, 9 moves > I wanted to again ask about these categories. The Only ones I know > for sure are PELL = 8 and Step 4 = 13.2, because I calculated myself. > Bob, you gave me 9 and 14 for CLL/COLL, I think. No, those were my estimates for OLL/PLL. > Has anybody calculated CLL, COLL, OLL, PLL, ELL, PELL, but taking into > account the chance or occurance of each case? Have I done that > correctly with PELL? The figures I just gave take into account chance of occurance. I calculated my OLL algorithm average, too. Here is my summary: OLL - 9.68 moves PLL - 11.9 moves + .75 = 12.65 COLL - 9.22 moves EPLL - 9.4 moves + .75 = 10.15 Again, this is based on the algorithms I use, not optimal ones. ~ Bob

1741. Move Count w/ Gille's Method
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 03:04:10 -0000

Move Count W/ GILLES Method F2B 20 CLL 10 S4 16 F2B 20 CLL 11 S4 19 F2B 19 CLL 11 S4 5 F2B 17 CLL 13 S4 18 F2B 25 CLL 8 S4 9 F2B 24 CLL 14 S4 17 F2B 19 CLL 8 S4 11 F2B 27 CLL 12 S4 13 F2B 23 CLL 9 S4 15 F2B 19 CLL 11 S4 13 F2B 22 CLL 8 S4 9 F2B 25 CLL 9 S4 12 F2B AVG 21.6 CLL AVG 10.2 S4 AVG 13.3 ------------ 45.1 Low was 35 moves High was only 55 moves! On Gilles Site, under MISC, there is a page about Number of Moves. Depending on the amount of time you have, you can optimize more. From 48 to <28. I took probably about 1.5 min for each cube(including Preinspection, Recognition, Execution, Counting Moves, and Recording Moves for Each Step), So I was real pleased with 45 moves/cube. I was also psyched when I saw how closely the Step 4 avg matched my avg of 100. 13.3 compared to 13.2, respectively. I think that this is one of the most effecient systems out there, in terms of moves. Now I just need to figure out what's taking me so long to do it. Jason K Sorry about the HUGE POST...
1742. RE: [Speed cubing group] Possible Roux method improvements
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 13 Dec 2005 19:38:18 -0800

Instead of doing CLL and then the DB edge, I was thinking it might be better to: -Insert DB edge and orient edges -Insert DF edge and orient corners -PLL I don't use Gille's method AT ALL, but I've been messing around with methods that produce lower move counts. I don't actually know if this is lower, I haven't checked and I have waaay to much to do right now. I have about half of the algs for DF edge and corners orientation if you want them, they average around 10 moves, and a lot of them are mostly two generator. -James Stuber _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Mike Bennett Sent: Sunday, December 11, 2005 1:32 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Possible Roux method improvements Hello all, I've been playing around with the Roux method a lot lately, and I've decided it needs as much attention and perfecting as Fridrich and company are getting. :) To that end, I've been trying to find ways to speed the Last 6 edges (and 4 centers) up, and thinking a lot about several variations of the normal method. First, there's unconstrained centers. This can shorten some of the hardest orientation situations from 12 moves down to 5 or 6, but the recognition seems akin to ZB to me. I need more practice with this, definitely, but I think that it may take too much time, even with mastery. (sorry, Gilles) The whole Step 4 method takes something like 18 moves on average, if my math is anywhere near correct. Instead of orienting and permuting L6E, what if we were to finish off DF and DB edges, then complete the cube with ELL? The hardest situations for finishing the two edges should be around 7 moves, with the average being somewhere around 6. ELL averages about 12 moves, so that puts the method in similar standing to the normal way. But what if we only finish off the DB edge? It can only be in 6 places, each place having 2 possible orientations. Thus, 12 simple cases, 11 of which are 5 moves or fewer. The average move count should be about 3.5, with the hardest situations at 7. You don't need to orient centers prior to this step, either. And recognition is very simple. The hardest case to spot is when the piece is already correct. :) After this, we could use any of the 22 possible cases found here: http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dlli/NewAlgSet.html This would give us an average of under 7 moves to place the DF edge and orient the LL edges, leaving us with an edge PLL step, as in COLL. As edge PLL's average 7 moves, our previous step averages 6.5 or so, and our first step at 3.5, this gives us around 17 again. The benefits? Aside from the 1/12 chance for a PLL skip, and the extremely easy to recognize and execute EPLL step, you never need to change your grip, and after the DF and DB edges are placed, you never need to adjust the M slice. Also, there are a number of lucky cases to exploit. There are only 29 or so unique cases for when the edges come up correctly oriented after placing DB. There are some very fast cases for when edges are correctly placed but incorrectly oriented, and learning the ELL algs can help out nicely for the 1/10 of cases where the DF edge completes itself along with DB. The worst case scenario is 26 moves to finish, and comes up roughly 1/2880 cases, while the odds for a 4 move or fewer solution are 1/72. When someone gets an OLL or PLL skip with Fridrich, the solve is usually in the low 40's for the number of moves. A PLL skip with COLL will probably be between 40 and 45. A very nice ZB solve may be in the mid to high 30's. With good 1x2x3's and a nice CLL case (like FRUR'U'F' or B' R'FR B R'F'R), a sub or low 30's move solve is a good possibility. Something like 1/312 solves (more once I learn more CLL's instead of slow COLL's :P) If anyone is interested in hearing more about this, or helping me to further this approach, please let me know. I could definitely use the services of someone who is good with ACube. Anyway, that's what's going through my head right now. Gilles, Jason, and others, what do you think? -Mike team [zb] SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+gam e&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+g ame&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=irjrM9wdJDBnytECiSfUCw > puzzle game Free <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzl e+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puz zle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=5IEF0wvHk31uvuXI6 ReWEw> puzzle inlay games Educational <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w1=Jigsaw+p uzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word +puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=37T2K_4zOte4R 94IVKMFNQ> game and puzzle Word <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Word+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game& w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+gam e&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=3DsIilZKH4dSS_WgIx9QRg> puzzle game Kid <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Kid+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w 2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game &w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=2-DgzSlkRkTyIak1hdhkgQ> puzzle game Puzzle <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=F ree+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5 =Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=EJHY58oeC85Up2uB7KhBMA> games _____ YAHOO! 1743. Re: PELL move Count
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 04:11:34 -0000

My COLL
> move average (again, using the ones on my page) is 9.22 moves. This
> takes into the probabilities of each case and a 1/27 chance to skip
> OLL, assuming you orient all edges during F2L.
>
> OLL - 9.68 moves
> PLL - 11.9 moves + .75 = 12.65
> COLL - 9.22 moves
> EPLL - 9.4 moves + .75 = 10.15


Bob,
For Your 1/27 chance of skip OLL, Have you taken into account that
only 1/6 of these will be a true COLL skip? 1/162 chance of COLL
skips, is that right? If you're using OE, COLL, PELL, and you don't
know PLL, then an OLL skip doesn't help you unless it's a COLL skip.

Also, I averaged Just the 15 perfect sequences for COLL on Lars
Petrus' website and came up with 10.6666 moves avg. It's hard for me
to believe that COLL is only 9 moves avg. Seems like it should be more...

Jason K

1745. Re: PELL move COunt
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 05:23:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" > <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > So PELL Avg = (1(0) + 4(11) + 4(7) + 2(8) + 1(7))/12 > > = (44 + 28 + 16 + 7)/12 > > = 95/12 > > = 7.916666 > > > > Is this correct? For you yes, but I use the MU algs to cycle 3 edges, and a 9 move alg for the Z perm, so my average is (STM) ~7. I'm definitely going to try out your fewer move Z perm, though. > > ELL Move Count 12? Yep. > > > PELL Move Count 8? Depends on the algs. ~7 for me. > > CLL Move Count 9? Probably less, but that's a reasonably close guess. I would guess around 8. > > COLL Move Count 14? I average about 10.15 moves for this case, but I have a couple of suboptimal sequences in there bringing it down. I'll get back to you on CLL once I actually learn more of them. At the moment I'm really only using probably half a dozen of them, and using COLL for the vast majority of cases. I really should work on that. > > Has anybody calculated CLL, COLL, OLL, PLL, ELL, PELL, but taking into > > account the chance or occurance of each case? Have I done that > > correctly with PELL? To correctly weight them, you should take each case and count the average number of moves. Add all of them together except the Double Sune cases. Double that. Then add the Double Sune cases together, and quadruple that. Now, divide by the number of algs. It should be 88. This should work for both CLL and COLL. ELL should average about 12, if you use MU algs, and less if you use more optimal ones. And who cares about OLL algs? ;P -Mike
1746. Re: PELL move Count
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 05:32:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > Bob, > For Your 1/27 chance of skip OLL, Have you taken into account that > only 1/6 of these will be a true COLL skip? But since Bob knows PLL, it's just an OLL skip to him. 1/6 will be very easy PLL's, though. When I solve with COLL and get OLL skips, I do PLL. You can get some very nice times this way. >1/162 chance of COLL skips, is that right? Yes. But 1/6 you will have a nice no corner perm COLL, and 1/27 you will have just a PLL case. > Also, I averaged Just the 15 perfect sequences for COLL on Lars > Petrus' website and came up with 10.6666 moves avg. It's hard for me > to believe that COLL is only 9 moves avg. Seems like it should be more... Well, to find out my average, I looked at Lars Vandenbergh's COLL page, and went through each case. Many of them are 7 or 8 moves long. CLL's are even better. I <3 FRUR'U'F'. > Jason K -Mike

I can tell you that it > > was a little lucky. I got a U turn as the third and last step of > my > > method but the time would probably have been around 5 seconds > > without luck, because I did the first to steps in like 2.5-3 > seconds > > and then became a little confused when it almost was solved. > > > > I'm most happy with the european record for one-handed solving > which > > was not a lucky case, just a very fast F2L. I'm also very > satisfied > > that I managed to take back the swedish record for 3*3*3 single > from > > Lars Petrus. > > > > /Gunnar > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi Gunnar :-) > > > > > > Congratz with the sub 4.00 world record on the 2x2x2 cube! 1748. Re: Move Count w/ Gille's Method

Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 07:26:35 -0000

F2B 22
CLL 10
S4 10

F2B 30
CLL 10
S4 13

F2B 27
CLL 8
S4 17

F2B 26
CLL 14
S4 16

F2B 24
CLL 13
S4 11

F2B 27
CLL 15
S4 6

F2B 23
CLL 8
S4 13

F2B 24
CLL 11
S4 12

F2B 30
CLL 11
S4 15

F2B 31
CLL 13
S4 13

F2B 21
CLL 11
S4 15

F2B 27
CLL 9
S4 15


F2B AVG 26.0
CLL AVG 10.2
S4 AVG 13.0
-----------
49.2

Low was 42 moves
High was 57

All solves were done in under 35 seconds, including typing time. Most
done under 30.

There were only two solves with a connected pair to start with. A
rather unlucky average, really.

I definitely need to work on my F2B step. Bad.

-Mike






1749. EDGE ALGS Needed (SOMEThing That FLips 1,2,3,4,9,11)
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 09:26:31 -0000

Edge algs are very useful to me now. Here are all that I can think
of. Position is not really a factor, Im mostly concerned with
orientation.

If anyone is not familiar with this numbering system for edges, its
very simple. 1-4 is the U layer. 5-8 is the middle layer. 9-12 is the
D layer. 1, 5, and 9 Start on the F slice, and you move clockwise as
viewed from above. So UF-1 UL-2 UB-3 UR-4 DF-9 DB-11. These are the
only ones I'm really concerned with.



ELLs
14: (FR'F')lU RU'R
13: (RUR'U')(M'U)(RU'r')
1234: (MU)(RUR'U')(M2U)(RU'r')

Pure Flips
13: ((M'U)3 U (MU)3 U)
12911: (MU')4
23911: (M'U)4
34911: (M'U')4
14911: (MU)4
1234611:(RBR'U)5
135678911:(RruU)3
210: U'M (U2M2U')L2U(M2U2M'U) L2 <---OLD SCHOOL

My favorite of the pureflips is (RBR'U)5, and its so close to what I
need. I need a quick way to flip 1,2,3,5,9,11. Position is not a
factor, and I don't care if its all M and U. I'd actually prefer
something similar to (RBR'U)5...


Jason K







1750. Re: Move Count w/ Gille's Method
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 09:37:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > F2B 22 > CLL 10 > S4 10 > > F2B 30 > CLL 10 > S4 13 > > F2B 27 > CLL 8 > S4 17 > > F2B 26 > CLL 14 > S4 16 > > F2B 24 > CLL 13 > S4 11 > > F2B 27 > CLL 15 > S4 6 > > F2B 23 > CLL 8 > S4 13 > > F2B 24 > CLL 11 > S4 12 > > F2B 30 > CLL 11 > S4 15 > > F2B 31 > CLL 13 > S4 13 > > F2B 21 > CLL 11 > S4 15 > > F2B 27 > CLL 9 > S4 15 > > > F2B AVG 26.0 > CLL AVG 10.2 > S4 AVG 13.0 > ----------- > 49.2 > > Low was 42 moves > High was 57 > > All solves were done in under 35 seconds, including typing time. Most > done under 30. > > There were only two solves with a connected pair to start with. A > rather unlucky average, really. > > I definitely need to work on my F2B step. Bad. > > -Mike > Congrats on averaging 13 moves for step 4! Dont you love when you get a 6-7 move step 4? THats very Close to my Avgs, especially CLL and Step 4. I think that This whole system averages less moves than Petrus any variation of CFOP, for sure. Doing F2B in 25 is pretty easy, so 8-9 for CLL + 12-13 for Step 4, you're always in the 40s. Just hard to recognize everything quickly. Jason K

Here are some to pick from:

F L F' M F L' F' U M' (11q, 11f, 9s*)
F L F' M F L' F' U' M' (11q, 11f, 9s*)
F' R' F M F' R F U M' (11q, 11f, 9s*)
F' R' F M F' R F U' M' (11q, 11f, 9s*)
B R B' M' B R' B' U M (11q, 11f, 9s*)
B R B' M' B R' B' U' M (11q, 11f, 9s*)
B' L' B M' B' L B U M (11q, 11f, 9s*)
B' L' B M' B' L B U' M (11q, 11f, 9s*)

1752. Re: EDGE ALGS Needed (SOMEThing That FLips 1,2,3,4,9,11)
From: cycastel <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: >I need a quick way to flip 1,2,3,5,9,11. > Jason K Did you mean 1,2,3,4,9,11 like in your post title ? what about (M'UMU)2U MUM'U2 ? I'm not sure I fully understood what you were looking for, but that one flips the edges you want. It's not a pure flip however ... and you may find it too long ;-) That's the first one I came up with, built on the effect of M'UM, tell us if it fits your needs ;-) cyril
1753. Re: [Speed cubing group] EDGE ALGS Needed (SOMEThing That FLips 1,2,3,4,9,11)

Oh.. and heres som for the MU-lovers:

R U R' M' U M U' R M U' R' M'
R U' r' U' M' U r U r'
R M U R' M' U M' U' R M U' R'
r U' r' U' M U r U R'
R2 U R2 M' U M U' R2 M U' R2 M'
R2 U' R2 M U' M' U R2 M' U R2 M
R2 M U R2 M' U M' U' R2 M U' R2
R2 M' U' R2 M U' M U R2 M' U R2
R' U r U M U' r' U' r
R' U' R M U' M' U R' M' U R M
r' U r U M' U' r' U' R
R' M' U' R M U' M U R' M' U R
(U) R U R' M' U M U' R M U' R' M'
(U) R U' r' U' M' U r U r'
(U) R M U R' M' U M' U' R M U' R'
(U) r U' r' U' M U r U R'
(U) R2 U R2 M' U M U' R2 M U' R2 M'
(U) R2 U' R2 M U' M' U R2 M' U R2 M
(U) R2 M U R2 M' U M' U' R2 M U' R2
(U) R2 M' U' R2 M U' M U R2 M' U R2
(U) R' U r U M U' r' U' r
(U) R' U' R M U' M' U R' M' U R M
(U) r' U r U M' U' r' U' R
(U) R' M' U' R M U' M U R' M' U R
(U2) R U R' M' U M U' R M U' R' M'
(U2) R U' r' U' M' U r U r'
(U2) R M U R' M' U M' U' R M U' R'
(U2) r U' r' U' M U r U R'
(U2) R2 U R2 M' U M U' R2 M U' R2 M'

(U2) R' U r U M U' r' U' r
(U2) R' U' R M U' M' U R' M' U R M

(U') r U' r' U' M U r U R'
(U') R2 U R2 M' U M U' R2 M U' R2 M'

1754. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 17:14:07 +0100

We will see in 25 years, I'll be 45, hum hum. :p And you will be the grand old master of Fewest Moves haha. Gilles. 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...>: > Hi Gilles !! > > It's not hard find these if u understand the nature of inner slice > turns. They cycle 4 centers and 4 edges. So u know how many edges > that u have to "fix" after such a turn. And you insert edges into > the slice as needed. Oh, and 25 yrs of cubing experience and fewest > moves does help a lot :-) > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > Very nice algorithms Per :p > > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > Hehe ... > > > > > > This is fun ! > > > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18-htm, 17-stm) > > > > > > or > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14-stm) > > > > > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice turns...) > > > > > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search for me cause of > > > course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving something close to > a > > > full > > > > scramble :p > > > > > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this approach or > not :s > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle before > the u- > > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > > > > > > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > (PS! Lower case letters are inner slice turns here!!) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > Maybe even nicer: > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F u - L' f L' B2 L f' L' B2 L2 - F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! (same htm as before, 19 - shorter stm, 16) > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In > speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > > > > > > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi David, > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Very nice. You made me look for another way. :) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > U L' B L b L' B' L b2 U2 b U b U b' U' r b' r' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Cheers, > > > > > > > > > > > > > > David J > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr > > > > > > > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Here's another way using your notation: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' U' F u' R u' R u' R u' R F' U F' u F2 D2 R2 U2 R2 > U2 R2 > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > On 12/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > This is a long way around, but it is a way to see > what > > > that > > > > > > parity is > > > > > > > > > about. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. > > > > > > > > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' r' U2 > > > (Which > > > > > > leaves an > > > > > > > > > interesting pattern) > > > > > > > > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1755. Re: PELL move Count
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 17:12:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > Bob, > For Your 1/27 chance of skip OLL, Have you taken into account that > only 1/6 of these will be a true COLL skip? 1/162 chance of COLL > skips, is that right? If you're using OE, COLL, PELL, and you don't > know PLL, then an OLL skip doesn't help you unless it's a COLL skip. I realize that only 1/162 is a true COLL skip, but I went under the assumption that anybody who learned COLL did so after learning PLL, so they would use PLL for those 1/27 cases. > Also, I averaged Just the 15 perfect sequences for COLL on Lars > Petrus' website and came up with 10.6666 moves avg. It's hard for me > to believe that COLL is only 9 moves avg. Seems like it should be more... Well, if you don't trust my numbers, you can verify yourself. I list all of my COLL algorithms here: http://www.cubewhiz.com/coll.html Multiply the number of moves for every algorithm by 4 except the Double-sune (H) ones, those get multiplied by 2. Then add them up and divide by 162. I consider a PLL case to be a COLL skip using this method. Many of the COLL algorithms are only 7 or 8 moves, so I believe the number is right, but you can verify if you want. :) ~ Bob
1756. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 17:26:43 -0000

Hi! That 'Arc de Triomphe' is so well known that i didn't bother to post it yet. Even Stefan knows that one ;-) Here's my way of doing that one : F' R' B' F L' F' u F L F' B R F or F' R' f' D' F' r' F D f R F (14-htm, 11-stm) The first 5 moves are setup moves for what the r' does. [Actually i normally do it the first way. The second way is slice- turn optimised notation.] Have fun! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > It's funny that the centers are cycles clockwise (looking from the > top), and the edges anti-clockwise. > > Now add an H permutation and you have a very nice pattern :p (swap the > opposite edges on the top layer). > it's some sort of 'Arc de Triomphe' (the monument in Paris):D > > Gilles > > 2005/12/13, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...>: > > Very nice algorithms Per :p > > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > Hehe ... > > > > > > This is fun ! > > > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18-htm, 17-stm) > > > > > > or > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14-stm) > > > > > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice turns...) > > > > > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search for me cause of > > > course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving something close to a > > > full > > > > scramble :p > > > > > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this approach or not :s > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle before the u- > > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > > > > > > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > (PS! Lower case letters are inner slice turns here!!) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > Maybe even nicer: > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F u - L' f L' B2 L f' L' B2 L2 - F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! (same htm as before, 19 - shorter stm, 16) > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > > > > > > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi David, > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Very nice. You made me look for another way. :) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > U L' B L b L' B' L b2 U2 b U b U b' U' r b' r' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Cheers, > > > > > > > > > > > > > > David J > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr > > > > > > > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Here's another way using your notation: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' U' F u' R u' R u' R u' R F' U F' u F2 D2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > On 12/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > This is a long way around, but it is a way to see what > > > that > > > > > > parity is > > > > > > > > > about. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. > > > > > > > > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' r' U2 > > > (Which > > > > > > leaves an > > > > > > > > > interesting pattern) > > > > > > > > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1759. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 17:47:01 -0000

Yo! I realised only one case was left now so here it is : R F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' R' or (R r) F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' R' (13-htm, 11-stm) Cheers! -Per PS! Since lower case here are inner slice turns, (Rr) is the same as fingertrick r alone ;-) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi! > > That 'Arc de Triomphe' is so well known that i didn't bother to post > it yet. Even Stefan knows that one ;-) Here's my way of doing that > one : > > F' R' B' F L' F' u F L F' B R F > > or > > F' R' f' D' F' r' F D f R F (14-htm, 11-stm) > > The first 5 moves are setup moves for what the r' does. > > [Actually i normally do it the first way. The second way is slice- > turn optimised notation.] > > Have fun! > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > It's funny that the centers are cycles clockwise (looking from the > > top), and the edges anti-clockwise. > > > > Now add an H permutation and you have a very nice pattern :p (swap > the > > opposite edges on the top layer). > > it's some sort of 'Arc de Triomphe' (the monument in Paris):D > > > > Gilles > > > > 2005/12/13, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...>: > > > Very nice algorithms Per :p > > > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > Hehe ... > > > > > > > > This is fun ! > > > > > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18-htm, 17-stm) > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14-stm) > > > > > > > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice turns...) > > > > > > > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search for me cause > of > > > > course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving something close > to a > > > > full > > > > > scramble :p > > > > > > > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this approach or > not :s > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle before > the u- > > > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > (PS! Lower case letters are inner slice turns here!!) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per > Kristen > > > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Maybe even nicer: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F u - L' f L' B2 L f' L' B2 L2 - F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! 1760. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 18:54:01 +0100

Now what if the centers were cycled counter-clockwise ? :p Gilles. 2005/12/14, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...>: > Yo! > > I realised only one case was left now so here it is : > > R F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' R' > > or > > (R r) F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' R' (13-htm, 11-stm) > > Cheers! > > -Per > > PS! Since lower case here are inner slice turns, (Rr) is the same as > fingertrick r alone ;-) > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi! > > > > That 'Arc de Triomphe' is so well known that i didn't bother to > post > > it yet. Even Stefan knows that one ;-) Here's my way of doing that > > one : > > > > F' R' B' F L' F' u F L F' B R F > > > > or > > > > F' R' f' D' F' r' F D f R F (14-htm, 11-stm) > > > > The first 5 moves are setup moves for what the r' does. > > > > [Actually i normally do it the first way. The second way is slice- > > turn optimised notation.] > > > > Have fun! > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > It's funny that the centers are cycles clockwise (looking from > the > > > top), and the edges anti-clockwise. > > > > > > Now add an H permutation and you have a very nice pattern :p > (swap > > the > > > opposite edges on the top layer). > > > it's some sort of 'Arc de Triomphe' (the monument in Paris):D > > > > > > Gilles > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...>: > > > > Very nice algorithms Per :p > > > > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > Hehe ... > > > > > > > > > > This is fun ! > > > > > > > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > > > > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18-htm, 17-stm) > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14-stm) > > > > > > > > > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice > turns...) > > > > > > > > > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search for me > cause > > of > > > > > course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van > den > > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving something > close > > to a > > > > > full > > > > > > scramble :p > > > > > > > > > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this approach or > > not :s > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle > before > > the u- > > > > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > (PS! Lower case letters are inner slice turns here!!) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per > > Kristen > > > > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Maybe even nicer: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F u - L' f L' B2 L f' L' B2 L2 - F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! (same htm as before, 19 - shorter stm, 16) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In > > speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > > > > > > > > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi David, > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Very nice. You made me look for another way. :) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > U L' B L b L' B' L b2 U2 b U b U b' U' r b' r' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Cheers, > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > David J > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David > > Barr > > > > > > > > > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Here's another way using your notation: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' U' F u' R u' R u' R u' R F' U F' u F2 D2 R2 U2 > R2 > > U2 R2 > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > On 12/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > This is a long way around, but it is a way to > see > > what > > > > > that > > > > > > > > parity is > > > > > > > > > > > about. I use lower case letters to mean slices > > only. > > > > > > > > > > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' > r' > > U2 > > > > > (Which > > > > > > > > leaves an > > > > > > > > > > > interesting pattern) > > > > > > > > > > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1761. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 18:00:43 -0000

Haha Gilles :D Sacre bleu ;-) I'm sure u are aware of inverses right? So, go ahead inverse my algorithms. I'm not gonna charge you ... lol ... In fact, in all cases u can do some mirrored algorithm instead. But i know that u know that also :D But the axis of mirroring is not the same for all 4 cases ... -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Now what if the centers were cycled counter-clockwise ? > :p > > Gilles. > > 2005/12/14, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > Yo! > > > > I realised only one case was left now so here it is : > > > > R F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' R' > > > > or > > > > (R r) F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' R' (13-htm, 11-stm) > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > > PS! Since lower case here are inner slice turns, (Rr) is the same as > > fingertrick r alone ;-) > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi! > > > > > > That 'Arc de Triomphe' is so well known that i didn't bother to > > post > > > it yet. Even Stefan knows that one ;-) Here's my way of doing that > > > one : > > > > > > F' R' B' F L' F' u F L F' B R F > > > > > > or > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' r' F D f R F (14-htm, 11-stm) > > > > > > The first 5 moves are setup moves for what the r' does. > > > > > > [Actually i normally do it the first way. The second way is slice- > > > turn optimised notation.] > > > > > > Have fun! > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > It's funny that the centers are cycles clockwise (looking from > > the > > > > top), and the edges anti-clockwise. > > > > > > > > Now add an H permutation and you have a very nice pattern :p > > (swap > > > the > > > > opposite edges on the top layer). > > > > it's some sort of 'Arc de Triomphe' (the monument in Paris):D > > > > > > > > Gilles > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...>: > > > > > Very nice algorithms Per :p > > > > > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > Hehe ... > > > > > > > > > > > > This is fun ! > > > > > > > > > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > > > > > > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18-htm, 17- stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14-stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice > > turns...) > > > > > > > > > > > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search for me > > cause > > > of > > > > > > course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van > > den > > > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving something > > close > > > to a > > > > > > full > > > > > > > scramble :p > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this approach or > > > not :s > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle > > before > > > the u- > > > > > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > (PS! I use lower case letters to mean slices > > > only. > > > > > > > > > > > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' > > r' > > > U2 > > > > > > (Which > > > > > > > > > leaves an > > > > > > > > > > > > interesting pattern) > > > > > > > > > > > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! I use lower case letters to mean > slices > > > > only. > > > > > > > > > > > > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r > U' > > > r' > > > > U2 > > > > > > > (Which > > > > > > > > > > leaves an > > > > > > > > > > > > > interesting pattern) > > > > > > > > > > > > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1763. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 19:59:20 -0000

Oopssss ... Here is actually the last case. It's a bit odd, so no wonder i initially forgot about it : R F U' L B' U2 B u B' U2 B L' U F' R' (16-htm, 15-stm) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > How old am I again ? 20 ? > haha > > Gilles. > 2005/12/14, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > Haha Gilles :D > > > > Sacre bleu ;-) I'm sure u are aware of inverses right? So, go ahead > > inverse my algorithms. I'm not gonna charge you ... lol ... > > > > In fact, in all cases u can do some mirrored algorithm instead. But > > i know that u know that also :D But the axis of mirroring is not the > > same for all 4 cases ... > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > Now what if the centers were cycled counter-clockwise ? > > > :p > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > 2005/12/14, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > Yo! > > > > > > > > I realised only one case was left now so here it is : > > > > > > > > R F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' R' > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > (R r) F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' R' (13-htm, 11-stm) > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > PS! Since lower case here are inner slice turns, (Rr) is the > > same as > > > > fingertrick r alone ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Hi! > > > > > > > > > > That 'Arc de Triomphe' is so well known that i didn't bother to > > > > post > > > > > it yet. Even Stefan knows that one ;-) Here's my way of doing > > that > > > > > one : > > > > > > > > > > F' R' B' F L' F' u F L F' B R F > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' r' F D f R F (14-htm, 11-stm) > > > > > > > > > > The first 5 moves are setup moves for what the r' does. > > > > > > > > > > [Actually i normally do it the first way. The second way is > > slice- > > > > > turn optimised notation.] > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > It's funny that the centers are cycles clockwise (looking > > from > > > > the > > > > > > top), and the edges anti-clockwise. > > > > > > > > > > > > Now add an H permutation and you have a very nice pattern :p > > > > (swap > > > > > the > > > > > > opposite edges on the top layer). > > > > > > it's some sort of 'Arc de Triomphe' (the monument in Paris):D > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...>: > > > > > > > Very nice algorithms Per :p > > > > > > > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > > Hehe ... > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > This is fun ! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18- htm, 17- > > stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14-stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice > > > > turns...) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search for me > > > > cause > > > > > of > > > > > > > > course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles > > van > > > > den > > > > > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving something > > > > close > > > > > to a > > > > > > > > full > > > > > > > > > scramble :p > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this > > approach or > > > > > not :s > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund > > <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3- cycle > > > > before > > > > > the u- > > > > > > > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > (PS! Lower case letters are inner slice turns here!!) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per > > > > > Kristen > > > > > > > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Maybe even nicer: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F u - L' f L' B2 L f' L' B2 L2 - F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! (same htm as before, 19 - shorter stm, > > 16) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In > > > > > speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > > > > > > > > > > > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi David, > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Very nice. You made me look for another way. :) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > U L' B L b L' B' L b2 U2 b U b U b' U' r b' r' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Cheers, > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > David J > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > > David > > > > > Barr > > > > > > > > > > > > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Here's another way using your notation: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' U' F u' R u' R u' R u' R F' U F' u F2 D2 R2 > > U2 > > > > R2 > > > > > U2 R2 > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > On 12/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> > > wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > This is a long way around, but it is a way to > > > > see > > > > > what > > > > > > > > that > > > > > > > > > > > parity is > > > > > > > > > > > > > > about. I use lower case letters to mean > > slices > > > > > only. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r > > U' > > > > r' > > > > > U2 > > > > > > > > (Which > > > > > > > > > > > leaves an > > > > > > > > > > > > > > interesting pattern) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1764. US Nationals 2006
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 14:34:52 -0800

Before I start reserve dates, I'd like to know if the June 10-11
weekend or June 17-18 weekend is better? Is June good at all?

Now, I understand that everyone has their own personal preference, so
please voice an opinion if it applies in general terms. (Use your
discretion.) In other words, if a bunch of schools are still in
session June 10-11, then obviously, it's not a good week.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1768. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: [caltechrubiks] US Nationals 2006
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 16:22:53 -0800

There will be two competitions: The US Championships and an Open competition. US Citizens can compete for the United States Champion title. International competitors will be in the open bracket and can set official times, but cannot take the US Title. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Dec 14, 2005, at 3:56 PM, Craig Bouchard wrote: > Any chance Canadians can come down too??? But not win??? 1769. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: [caltechrubiks] US Nationals 2006
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 16:24:21 -0800

I don't want to close off the US 2006 competition because I'd like to encourage participation from everyone. Sure, the competition is about finding the fastest United States cuber, but there's no reason we can't let other people join in on the fun. We'll keep the competition results separate so that the media doesn't get confused. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Dec 14, 2005, at 4:18 PM, Bob Burton wrote: > I was wondering about this, too. 1770. Re: [caltechrubiks] US Nationals 2006
From: "mrraaw" <mrraaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 01:08:33 -0000

What about prize claim Tyson? Can international countries win top
prize?

MATT





1771. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: [caltechrubiks] US Nationals 2006
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Dec 2005 17:19:02 -0800

Hi Matt,

That hasn't been decided yet. It should be noted, however, that the
international competition will be probably much harder. There's this
guy, I don't know if you've heard of him, but his name is Macky, and
he's from Japan. Other than that, in the end, I'd be fine with
comparing all of the averages and awarding some type of prize to the
fastest final round average, but it should be noted the prizes won't be
cash prizes as we don't have that type of money. At most, Mark
Sullivan will take you on a ride in a pond in a swan boat. Or
something like that.

People may have gone to WC 2005 to win money or prizes, but I'm really
hoping that isn't the focus of our competition. US Nationals will
provide a very high level of competition and a very competitive
atmosphere while bringing in people certainly from all around the
United States—that's our main goal.

(I wish we had $10,000 to spare.)

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Dec 14, 2005, at 5:08 PM, mrraaw wrote:

> prize?
>
> MATT

1772. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 01:28:06 -0000

Hi Per, This is my best so far: r D' f' D r' U' B2 f' U f U2 f' U f' B2 U (19 htm, 16 stm) That "interesting pattern" which I mentioned in my first email in this thread - I call it "For You" :) It seems much easier to get to. In looking for the other I kept ending up there. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi :-) > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3-cycle before the u- > turn, like this : > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 stm) > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > -Per > > (PS! Lower case letters are inner slice turns here!!) > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi :-) > > > > Maybe even nicer: > > > > R U' F u - L' f L' B2 L f' L' B2 L2 - F' U R' > > > > Have fun! (same htm as before, 19 - shorter stm, 16) > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi David, > > > > > > Very nice. You made me look for another way. :) > > > > > > U L' B L b L' B' L b2 U2 b U b U b' U' r b' r' > > > > > > Cheers, > > > > > > David J > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr > > > <david20708@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Here's another way using your notation: > > > > > > > > F' U' F u' R u' R u' R u' R F' U F' u F2 D2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 > > > > > > > > On 12/11/05, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > This is a long way around, but it is a way to see what that > > parity is > > > > > about. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. > > > > > F B d' F' B' U r U r' U2 r' U2 r2 U' r' U2 r U' r' U2 (Which > > leaves an > > > > > interesting pattern) > > > > > r2 D' f2 D f' r2 f > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
1773. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 02:05:02 -0000

Hi David J :-) I guess ur alg should be : r D' f' D r' U' B2 f' U f U2 f' U f B2 U (21 htm, 16 stm) I count 21 htm, not 19 ... Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi Per, > > This is my best so far: > r D' f' D r' U' B2 f' U f U2 f' U f' B2 U (19 htm, 16 stm) > > That "interesting pattern" which I mentioned in my first email in this > thread - I call it "For You" :) It seems much easier to get to. 1774. [Speed cubing group] Re: [caltechrubiks] US Nationals 2006
From: "mrraaw" <mrraaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 02:02:53 -0000

Hey Tyson,

Hah. I was just curious. I am aware of the elite out there and their
abilty to destroy many people in competition...but you never know 5
lucky solves could happen...

Regardless, I hope that I can go on a ride in a swan boat! ha. I hope
to attend but I will never just go to a competition and isolate myself
from other cubers and sabotage them. I enjoyed metting all the cubers
at WC2005 and hope to meet evyone again. The time I spent with the
cubers in WC2005 was well...a few days compared to the few hours of
competing. The competition is a small part.

If I had a spare 10 grand, I think the cubing community would be the
first to know.

MATT





1775. Re: PELL move Count
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 03:11:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" > <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > Bob, > > For Your 1/27 chance of skip OLL, Have you taken into account that > > only 1/6 of these will be a true COLL skip? 1/162 chance of COLL > > skips, is that right? If you're using OE, COLL, PELL, and you don't > > know PLL, then an OLL skip doesn't help you unless it's a COLL skip. > > I realize that only 1/162 is a true COLL skip, but I went under the > assumption that anybody who learned COLL did so after learning PLL, so > they would use PLL for those 1/27 cases. > > > Also, I averaged Just the 15 perfect sequences for COLL on Lars > > Petrus' website and came up with 10.6666 moves avg. It's hard for me > > to believe that COLL is only 9 moves avg. Seems like it should be > more... > > Well, if you don't trust my numbers, you can verify yourself. I list > all of my COLL algorithms here: > http://www.cubewhiz.com/coll.html > > Multiply the number of moves for every algorithm by 4 except the > Double-sune (H) ones, those get multiplied by 2. Then add them up and > divide by 162. I consider a PLL case to be a COLL skip using this > method. Many of the COLL algorithms are only 7 or 8 moves, so I > believe the number is right, but you can verify if you want. :) > > ~ Bob > BOB I got really bored and did it. If you account for the True COLL skip then you have to add 0(1), 9(4), and 14(1) before you divide by 162. THis leaves you with a 9.777777777 move avg for COLL. Treating these cases as COLL skips, and adding nothing for these 6 cases, I got a 9.49 move avg for your COLL. Either way, it is pretty impressive. I thought for some reason that COLL was Longer. I will for sure learn COLL in addition to CLL(Probably from your pages) =) Jason Kovacic PS. How do I tell which 2 corners need to switch? Other than doing the inverse of the algs... I use Red on top.
1776. Oh wow
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 03:58:07 -0000

Hey everyone,

I haven't done this in a long time and figured I would try it again.

I was solving when I came across a good scramble and got a good time.

The scramble was:
L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D'

and my times was 12.69 which I am very happy with.

Well I then did a prepared solve average, where I did an average of 10
but using this same scramble for all 12 solves.

My average was 9.39 seconds:
(12.16) 09.67 09.53 08.39 09.02 (07.86) 10.12 10.35 07.92 09.94 09.62
09.29 = 9.39

I then continued for a best rolling average and got 8.09 seconds
08.53, (07.11), 08.00, (09.15), 08.89, 07.24, 08.67, 07.13, 07.48,
09.05, 08.02, 07.93 = 8.09

My best execution of my solution so far is 6.72 seconds.

My solution is 37 moves after cancellations from the end of one step
being the inverse move of the beginning of the next (which I didn't
catch in my first real solve). This solve is not lucky either, and
has a regular 2 look Fridrich LL (though a fast one).

If you know my solving style, you'll know how I started this solve,
and the rest is very obvious.

See what you guys can do, this scramble rocks!

Chris

1782. Re: [Speed cubing group] Oh wow
From: Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 07:04:43 -0600

hey, wow thats awesome. but whats a "prepared solve average"?

cya


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1783. Sub-20 average!!!
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: Lista Speed Cubing <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 10:31:40 -0300 (ART)

Hey people,

I just wanted to share with you my first sub-20 average. The result was 19.98, and the times were 18.80, 20.48, 18.45, 21.25, (21.83), 21.48, 19.95, 18.00, 21.48, 20.08, 19.86, (17.67). I'm sooooooooooo happy with this. Is like my gift for 6 months of cubing...hehe...

so, I want to thank all who helped me with algs, advices and all. Thank you very much!

Oh, and it's not the end...I'm coming to catch you all, you sub-15ers...(evil laugh...aHAahahahAhHAHahHahHHA)

Pedro


---------------------------------
Yahoo! doce lar. Faça do Yahoo! sua homepage.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1784. Re: Oh wow
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 13:45:15 -0000

Uh Hummmm...Chris...Did you forget to mention what you were doing at the time??? LOL...Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I haven't done this in a long time and figured I would try it again. > > I was solving when I came across a good scramble and got a good time. > > The scramble was: > L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D' > > and my times was 12.69 which I am very happy with. > > Well I then did a prepared solve average, where I did an average of 10 > but using this same scramble for all 12 solves. > > My average was 9.39 seconds: > (12.16) 09.67 09.53 08.39 09.02 (07.86) 10.12 10.35 07.92 09.94 09.62 > 09.29 = 9.39 > > I then continued for a best rolling average and got 8.09 seconds > 08.53, (07.11), 08.00, (09.15), 08.89, 07.24, 08.67, 07.13, 07.48, > 09.05, 08.02, 07.93 = 8.09 > > My best execution of my solution so far is 6.72 seconds. > > My solution is 37 moves after cancellations from the end of one step > being the inverse move of the beginning of the next (which I didn't > catch in my first real solve). This solve is not lucky either, and > has a regular 2 look Fridrich LL (though a fast one). > > If you know my solving style, you'll know how I started this solve, > and the rest is very obvious. > > See what you guys can do, this scramble rocks! > > Chris >

1787. Funny scramble
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 14:45:06 -0000

Jess Bonde's timer gave me this one:

F U' L2 D' B2 R' B F' D' U F' R B' U D' L F2 D2 B
U' D' L R' U' L

- Joël.

1792. Re: PELL move Count
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 16:48:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > BOB > I got really bored and did it. > > If you account for the True COLL skip then you have to add 0(1), > 9(4), and 14(1) before you divide by 162. THis leaves you with a > 9.777777777 move avg for COLL. > Treating these cases as COLL skips, and adding nothing for these 6 > cases, I got a 9.49 move avg for your COLL. Either way, it is pretty > impressive. I thought for some reason that COLL was Longer. COLL is nice and short. :) I calculated 9.22, but I could have made a mistake. I agree with you for adding that 9*4 + 14 first if you do not know PLL, but the original purpose of COLL was for the VH system (I think?), which is an extension of the Fridrich system. > I will for sure learn COLL in addition to CLL(Probably from your pages) =) Cool. Good luck. :) I believe a bunch of the cases are the same. > PS. How do I tell which 2 corners need to switch? Other than doing > the inverse of the algs... I use Red on top. Well, I don't actually look at which ones need to switch. I use a variant of the "sticker recognition" system. There are links to other COLL pages that describe it at the bottom of my COLL page. I describe the recognition I look for for every case on my page, too. If you already know CLL recognition, though, you can still use that. ~ Bob
1793. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 16:59:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi David J :-) > > I guess ur alg should be : > > r D' f' D r' U' B2 f' U f U2 f' U f B2 U (21 htm, 16 stm) > > I count 21 htm, not 19 ... > > Cheers! > > -Per Hi Per, How do you get 21 htm? r D' f' D r' U' B2 f' U f U2 f' U f' B2 U ---16 ----------------+1--------+1---------+1-----=19 Anyway, I like a lot of your sequences. Cheers, David J
1794. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 17:21:35 -0000

Hi David :-) The counting u do there is sqtm counting, not htm. In htm both B2 and B have length 1, but inner slice turns are length 2 in htm, unlike in stm or sqtm ;-) That would seem to make ur algorithm 23 moves, but B2 f' and f B2 are only 2 moves due to cancellation ;-) So F is 1 move in all metrics (htm,qtm,stm,sqtm). And f2 is 2 moves in htm, 4 moves in qtm, 1 in stm and 2 in sqtm. (Here f2 = S2) [htm = half turn metric stm = slice turn metric qtm = quarter turn metric sqtm = slice quarter turn metric] Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi David J :-) > > > > I guess ur alg should be : > > > > r D' f' D r' U' B2 f' U f U2 f' U f B2 U (21 htm, 16 stm) > > > > I count 21 htm, not 19 ... > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > Hi Per, > > How do you get 21 htm? > > r D' f' D r' U' B2 f' U f U2 f' U f' B2 U ---16 > ----------------+1--------+1---------+1-----=19 > > Anyway, I like a lot of your sequences. > > Cheers, > > David J >
