1797. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 18:21:03 -0000

Hi :-) Ok, here's a slightly different case: R2 u R' U D F' (L2 D2)*3 F U' D' R' (17-htm, 16-stm) With another u' at the end it's cool middle layer alg, but i like it better without it. Oh, and i can of course postpone the first R2 to have this one: u R' U D F' (L2 D2)*3 F U' D' R (16-htm, 15-stm) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Oopssss ... > > Here is actually the last case. It's a bit odd, so no wonder i > initially forgot about it : > > R F U' L B' U2 B u B' U2 B L' U F' R' (16-htm, 15-stm) > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > How old am I again ? 20 ? > > haha > > > > Gilles. > > 2005/12/14, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > Haha Gilles :D > > > > > > Sacre bleu ;-) I'm sure u are aware of inverses right? So, go > ahead > > > inverse my algorithms. I'm not gonna charge you ... lol ... > > > > > > In fact, in all cases u can do some mirrored algorithm instead. > But > > > i know that u know that also :D But the axis of mirroring is not > the > > > same for all 4 cases ... > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Now what if the centers were cycled counter-clockwise ? > > > > :p > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > 2005/12/14, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > Yo! > > > > > > > > > > I realised only one case was left now so here it is : > > > > > > > > > > R F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' R' > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > (R r) F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' R' (13-htm, 11-stm) > > > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > PS! Since lower case here are inner slice turns, (Rr) is the > > > same as > > > > > fingertrick r alone ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi! > > > > > > > > > > > > That 'Arc de Triomphe' is so well known that i didn't > bother to > > > > > post > > > > > > it yet. Even Stefan knows that one ;-) Here's my way of > doing > > > that > > > > > > one : > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' B' F L' F' u F L F' B R F > > > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' r' F D f R F (14-htm, 11-stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > The first 5 moves are setup moves for what the r' does. > > > > > > > > > > > > [Actually i normally do it the first way. The second way is > > > slice- > > > > > > turn optimised notation.] > > > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles > van den > > > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > It's funny that the centers are cycles clockwise (looking > > > from > > > > > the > > > > > > > top), and the edges anti-clockwise. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Now add an H permutation and you have a very nice > pattern :p > > > > > (swap > > > > > > the > > > > > > > opposite edges on the top layer). > > > > > > > it's some sort of 'Arc de Triomphe' (the monument in > Paris):D > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...>: > > > > > > > > Very nice algorithms Per :p > > > > > > > > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund > <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > > > Hehe ... > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > This is fun ! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18- > htm, 17- > > > stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14- stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner slice > > > > > turns...) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search > for me > > > > > cause > > > > > > of > > > > > > > > > course then my solutions don't look short anymore :-P > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > Gilles > > > van > > > > > den > > > > > > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving > something > > > > > close > > > > > > to a > > > > > > > > > full > > > > > > > > > > scramble :p > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this > > > approach or > > > > > > not :s > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund > > > <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3- > cycle > > > > > before > > > > > > the u- > > > > > > > > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat solution : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, 14 > stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I guess that's my best shot ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > (PS! Hi :-) Yes, Stonehenge is a good name. Now i have to see if i can improve it, lol. This time i guess there will be no slice turns :D Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Thanks, Per :) I really do need to keep my metrics straight. > > If the "For You" was called "Arc de Triomphe" then what would this be > called? > > R U' F U2 F' U L U2 L' R' B U'R U2 R' U B' > > It looks more like stonehenge. > > Cheers, > > David J > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi David :-) > > > > The counting u do there is sqtm counting, not htm. In htm both B2 > > and B have length 1, but inner slice turns are length 2 in htm, > > unlike in stm or sqtm ;-) That would seem to make ur algorithm 23 > > moves, but B2 f' and f B2 are only 2 moves due to cancellation ;- ) > > > > So F is 1 move in all metrics (htm,qtm,stm,sqtm). > > And f2 is 2 moves in htm, 4 moves in qtm, 1 in stm and 2 in sqtm. > > (Here f2 = S2) > > > > [htm = half turn metric > > stm = slice turn metric > > qtm = quarter turn metric > > sqtm = slice quarter turn metric] > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > Fredlund" > > > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Hi David J :-) > > > > > > > > I guess ur alg should be : > > > > > > > > r D' f' D r' U' B2 f' U f U2 f' U f B2 U (21 htm, 16 stm) > > > > > > > > I count 21 htm, not 19 ... > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > Hi Per, > > > > > > How do you get 21 htm? > > > > > > r D' f' D r' U' B2 f' U f U2 f' U f' B2 U ---16 > > > ----------------+1--------+1---------+1-----=19 > > > > > > Anyway, I like a lot of your sequences. > > > > > > Cheers, > > > > > > David J > > > > > >

1801. Re: Oh wow
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 19:17:52 -0000

Hi Chris! My "5 minute" solution is like this : B F2 L [B L L' B>] B2 R' B' L R B R B' F R D R' D' F' [U' U] B' D' B U' B' D B (R' B2 R F2 )*2 (32-htm,31-stm,38-qtm) This is ending with 5 corners, not insertion optimised in any way. What is your exact 37-move solution ?? Have fun! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I haven't done this in a long time and figured I would try it again. > > I was solving when I came across a good scramble and got a good time. > > The scramble was: > L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D' > > and my times was 12.69 which I am very happy with. > > Well I then did a prepared solve average, where I did an average of 10 > but using this same scramble for all 12 solves. > > My average was 9.39 seconds: > (12.16) 09.67 09.53 08.39 09.02 (07.86) 10.12 10.35 07.92 09.94 09.62 > 09.29 = 9.39 > > I then continued for a best rolling average and got 8.09 seconds > 08.53, (07.11), 08.00, (09.15), 08.89, 07.24, 08.67, 07.13, 07.48, > 09.05, 08.02, 07.93 = 8.09 > > My best execution of my solution so far is 6.72 seconds. > > My solution is 37 moves after cancellations from the end of one step > being the inverse move of the beginning of the next (which I didn't > catch in my first real solve). This solve is not lucky either, and > has a regular 2 look Fridrich LL (though a fast one). > > If you know my solving style, you'll know how I started this solve, > and the rest is very obvious. > > See what you guys can do, this scramble rocks! > > Chris >
1802. Re: Oh wow
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 20:45:14 -0000

HEllo Everyone Here is my 5min solution to the same scramble. I don't ever do fewest moves, but I think I'd like to start. B1 : x' BUDFDF' B2 : x' r' R' U r U' R' COLL: y' RU2R'U'RU'R' S4 : y' M U2 M' U' M U2 M2 U M2 U2 Rr 31 Moves (the way I count. I dont know all the metrics) Jason Kovacic Kovacic81@... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi Chris! > > My "5 minute" solution is like this : > > B F2 L [B L L' B>] B2 R' B' L R B R B' F R D R' D' F' [U' U] B' D' B > U' B' D B (R' B2 R F2 )*2 (32-htm,31-stm,38-qtm) > > This is ending with 5 corners, not insertion optimised in any way. > What is your exact 37-move solution ?? > > Have fun! > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > I haven't done this in a long time and figured I would try it > again. > > > > I was solving when I came across a good scramble and got a good > time. > > > > The scramble was: > > L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D' > > > > and my times was 12.69 which I am very happy with. > > > > Well I then did a prepared solve average, where I did an average > of 10 > > but using this same scramble for all 12 solves. > > > > My average was 9.39 seconds: > > (12.16) 09.67 09.53 08.39 09.02 (07.86) 10.12 10.35 07.92 09.94 > 09.62 > > 09.29 = 9.39 > > > > I then continued for a best rolling average and got 8.09 seconds > > 08.53, (07.11), 08.00, (09.15), 08.89, 07.24, 08.67, 07.13, 07.48, > > 09.05, 08.02, 07.93 = 8.09 > > > > My best execution of my solution so far is 6.72 seconds. > > > > My solution is 37 moves after cancellations from the end of one > step > > being the inverse move of the beginning of the next (which I didn't > > catch in my first real solve). This solve is not lucky either, and > > has a regular 2 look Fridrich LL (though a fast one). > > > > If you know my solving style, you'll know how I started this solve, > > and the rest is very obvious. > > > > See what you guys can do, this scramble rocks! > > > > Chris > > >
1803. Re: Oh wow
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 22:35:58 -0000

The Scramble for just to remember:
L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D'

Since my LL sucks, I'll do my F2L solution...

Xcross: B R' F D2 F L'
Second Pair (BL): U2 L' U L U' L'
Third Pair (BR): U' d' R U R'
Fourth Pair (FR): d R U' R'
(this was the solution I came up with (i'm still learning F2L) and
Chris (Hardwick) said that it was exactly how he solved it, to the
move, and yah...)

I count...21 using HTM (i think)

Now everyone can see how horrible my LL is :D And for everyone's
knowledge (and you can ask Chris if you doubt me) I found about 12
different ways of executing the LL here using my method...So I might
as well list as many as I can think of...

1: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' M' U' M U2 M' U' M U' y' x' R2 D2
R' U' R D2 R' U R' x' F2 D' L' R F2 R' L D' F2 (41 HTM)
Some of the parts in this can be done in different orders...it really
doesn't matter and it accounts for I believe 1 or 2 different ways...

2: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' U x' z2 R U' R D2 R' U R D2 R2 x y2
r U R' U' M U R U' R' x' R U' R' U D R' D U' R' U R D2 F (44 HTM)
why am i doing this ugh...

3: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' y' M' U M U2 M' U M U' x' R2 D2 R'
U' R D2 R' U R' x' y' F2 D L' R F2 R' L D F2 (42 HTM)

4: z x U' R2 U R U' R U x2 z y R' D' R D' R' D2 R x2 R U R' U' M' U R
U' r' U x' z2 R2 D2 R' U' R D2 R' U R' z' R U' R' U D R' D U' R' U R
D2 F (47 HTM)

I'll save you all the troubles of trying more and me the trouble of
typing them out...Could someone post a good LL to this solve for me to
try???(using my F2L)

Thanx Craig

I looked up an OLL and a PLL...and found that the best solution for me was 41 HTM: B R' F D2 F L' U2 L' U L U' L' U' d' R U R' d R U' R' f' L' U' L U f y R' U2 R U2' R' F R U R' U' R' F' R2 U' Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > > The Scramble for just to remember: > L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D' > > Since my LL sucks, I'll do my F2L solution... > > Xcross: B R' F D2 F L' > Second Pair (BL): U2 L' U L U' L' > Third Pair (BR): U' d' R U R' > Fourth Pair (FR): d R U' R' > (this was the solution I came up with (i'm still learning F2L) and > Chris (Hardwick) said that it was exactly how he solved it, to the > move, and yah...) > > I count...21 using HTM (i think) > > Now everyone can see how horrible my LL is :D And for everyone's > knowledge (and you can ask Chris if you doubt me) I found about 12 > different ways of executing the LL here using my method...So I might > as well list as many as I can think of... > > 1: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' M' U' M U2 M' U' M U' y' x' R2 D2 > R' U' R D2 R' U R' x' F2 D' L' R F2 R' L D' F2 (41 HTM) > Some of the parts in this can be done in different orders...it really > doesn't matter and it accounts for I believe 1 or 2 different ways... > > 2: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' U x' z2 R U' R D2 R' U R D2 R2 x y2 > r U R' U' M U R U' R' x' R U' R' U D R' D U' R' U R D2 F (44 HTM) > why am i doing this ugh... > > 3: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' y' M' U M U2 M' U M U' x' R2 D2 R' > U' R D2 R' U R' x' y' F2 D L' R F2 R' L D F2 (42 HTM) > > 4: z x U' R2 U R U' R U x2 z y R' D' R D' R' D2 R x2 R U R' U' M' U R > U' r' U x' z2 R2 D2 R' U' R D2 R' U R' z' R U' R' U D R' D U' R' U R > D2 F (47 HTM) > > I'll save you all the troubles of trying more and me the trouble of > typing them out...Could someone post a good LL to this solve for me to > try???(using my F2L) > > Thanx Craig >

1806. Re: [Speed cubing group] Funny scramble
From: cycastel <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 23:06:26 -0000

there is at least one way, using the idea you sure had for the X- cross: F'LF BUB' L' (quite self-explicit) oh, then from this start you can solve the two remaining pairs with a nice 2-gen 14-moves sequence, U2R'U'RUR'U2R2U'R'U'R'UR, but that was not the purpose of the post :-) wanna try a prepared solve record with that start ;) ? cyril --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > 7 move double x-cross? where? how? > > Pedro > > cycastel <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: > X-cross only ? 1807. Re: Oh wow
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 23:14:03 -0000

Hey everyone, Yeah Craig beat me to the punch :-D I was showing Craig some F2L tricks, and I speedsolved this scramble before we ran through it together so I could say what I realistically did while speedsolving. Watch out for Craig man, his F2L is getting very very nice :-) Yes that was my F2L, and the LL is a P OLL case and the 7 PLL case. Here is how I executed it to solve in 6.72 seconds: y' L (B') (R D2) R y (L' U2) (L' U L U' L') [U' d'] (R U R') d (R U' R2) d' (L' U L) [d U] (R U2) (R' F R U R' U') (R' F' R2 U') That's a sustained 5.5 moves per second turning rate :-D It surprised me that a Fridrich solve could be sub-7 seconds with practice. Though there's no way that could be done with a high-30 move solution as a real solve though. I was turning so fast I couldn't even follow the pieces, I was just acting on muscle memory. My 7 PLL is low 2.xx on a good execution, so often I was getting the F2L and OLL in 4 seconds, so I imagine I was doing F2L in 3 seconds sometimes :-D That is of course from muscle memory, but it was nice to have a horrible LL lockup, and still get an 8 second solve :-D I can definitely see how I can speed up my F2L after doing this though. Try executing it that way and see what you think, it's craaaaaazy fast. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > > The Scramble for just to remember: > L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D' > > Since my LL sucks, I'll do my F2L solution... > > Xcross: B R' F D2 F L' > Second Pair (BL): U2 L' U L U' L' > Third Pair (BR): U' d' R U R' > Fourth Pair (FR): d R U' R' > (this was the solution I came up with (i'm still learning F2L) and > Chris (Hardwick) said that it was exactly how he solved it, to the > move, and yah...) > > I count...21 using HTM (i think) > > Now everyone can see how horrible my LL is :D And for everyone's > knowledge (and you can ask Chris if you doubt me) I found about 12 > different ways of executing the LL here using my method...So I might > as well list as many as I can think of... > > 1: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' M' U' M U2 M' U' M U' y' x' R2 D2 > R' U' R D2 R' U R' x' F2 D' L' R F2 R' L D' F2 (41 HTM) > Some of the parts in this can be done in different orders...it really > doesn't matter and it accounts for I believe 1 or 2 different ways... > > 2: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' U x' z2 R U' R D2 R' U R D2 R2 x y2 > r U R' U' M U R U' R' x' R U' R' U D R' D U' R' U R D2 F (44 HTM) > why am i doing this ugh... > > 3: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' y' M' U M U2 M' U M U' x' R2 D2 R' > U' R D2 R' U R' x' y' F2 D L' R F2 R' L D F2 (42 HTM) > > 4: z x U' R2 U R U' R U x2 z y R' D' R D' R' D2 R x2 R U R' U' M' U R > U' r' U x' z2 R2 D2 R' U' R D2 R' U R' z' R U' R' U D R' D U' R' U R > D2 F (47 HTM) > > I'll save you all the troubles of trying more and me the trouble of > typing them out...Could someone post a good LL to this solve for me to > try???(using my F2L) > > Thanx Craig >
1808. Re: [Speed cubing group] Funny scramble
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 21:40:35 -0300 (ART)

Hmm...now I see...that's cool well, maybe I should start doing FMC to improve my F2L (specially the cross) Pedro cycastel <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: there is at least one way, using the idea you sure had for the X- cross: F'LF BUB' L' (quite self-explicit) oh, then from this start you can solve the two remaining pairs with a nice 2-gen 14-moves sequence, U2R'U'RUR'U2R2U'R'U'R'UR, but that was not the purpose of the post :-) wanna try a prepared solve record with that start ;) ? cyril --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > 7 move double x-cross? where? how? > > Pedro > > cycastel <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: > X-cross only ? 1809. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 01:01:10 -0000

Hi Per, OK. One shorter in stm. :) U r' U r U' r L F' L' f' L F L' f U' (20 htm, 15 stm) And there's another one that's all r and U. :) David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi :-) > > Ok, here's a slightly different case: > > R2 u R' U D F' (L2 D2)*3 F U' D' R' (17-htm, 16-stm) > > With another u' at the end it's cool middle layer alg, but i like it > better without it. > > Oh, and i can of course postpone the first R2 to have this one: > > u R' U D F' (L2 D2)*3 F U' D' R (16-htm, 15-stm) > > Cheers! > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Oopssss ... > > > > Here is actually the last case. It's a bit odd, so no wonder i > > initially forgot about it : > > > > R F U' L B' U2 B u B' U2 B L' U F' R' (16-htm, 15-stm) > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > How old am I again ? 20 ? > > > haha > > > > > > Gilles. > > > 2005/12/14, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > Haha Gilles :D > > > > > > > > Sacre bleu ;-) I'm sure u are aware of inverses right? So, go > > ahead > > > > inverse my algorithms. I'm not gonna charge you ... lol ... > > > > > > > > In fact, in all cases u can do some mirrored algorithm > instead. > > But > > > > i know that u know that also :D But the axis of mirroring is > not > > the > > > > same for all 4 cases ... > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Now what if the centers were cycled counter-clockwise ? > > > > > :p > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/14, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > Yo! > > > > > > > > > > > > I realised only one case was left now so here it is : > > > > > > > > > > > > R F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' R' > > > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > > > (R r) F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' R' (13-htm, 11-stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > PS! Since lower case here are inner slice turns, (Rr) is > the > > > > same as > > > > > > fingertrick r alone ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per > Kristen > > > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > That 'Arc de Triomphe' is so well known that i didn't > > bother to > > > > > > post > > > > > > > it yet. Even Stefan knows that one ;-) Here's my way of > > doing > > > > that > > > > > > > one : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' B' F L' F' u F L F' B R F > > > > > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' r' F D f R F (14-htm, 11-stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > The first 5 moves are setup moves for what the r' does. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > [Actually i normally do it the first way. The second way > is > > > > slice- > > > > > > > turn optimised notation.] > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles > > van den > > > > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > It's funny that the centers are cycles clockwise > (looking > > > > from > > > > > > the > > > > > > > > top), and the edges anti-clockwise. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Now add an H permutation and you have a very nice > > pattern :p > > > > > > (swap > > > > > > > the > > > > > > > > opposite edges on the top layer). > > > > > > > > it's some sort of 'Arc de Triomphe' (the monument in > > Paris):D > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...>: > > > > > > > > > Very nice algorithms Per :p > > > > > > > > > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund > > <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > > > > Hehe ... > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > This is fun ! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18- > > htm, 17- > > > > stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F (20-htm, 14- > stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > (Don't forget that here lower case means inner > slice > > > > > > turns...) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I don't dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search > > for me > > > > > > cause > > > > > > > of > > > <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3- > > cycle > > > > > > before > > > > > > > the u- > > > > > > > > > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat > solution : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' U R' (17 htm, > 14 > > stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I guess 1810. DIY CUBE QUESTIONS
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 04:39:13 -0000

Hello Everyone

I just got my DIY cubes via UPS today. I have been using my studio
cube and a 25th anniversary cube with cubesmith stickers forever.

1. The centers I got this time are different that the ones I got last
time. THere are no tabs, and the centers *almost* stay in on their
own. Is there any way to avoid Gluing them in there? I want to be
able to take them off.

2. For the plastic, black washers, there is a convex side and a
totally flat side. Which side should face the spring? These washers
are just for the bottom, right?

3. Some of my corner pieces came assembled, but a few came without a
certain piece. You have to put it in yourself. But I cant seem to
get the piece to be flush with the corner. Has anyone else
experienced this?

4. Final Question: What's a good ballpark guideline on how tight to
tighten the screws? 2 previous DIYs got loose really quickly, and I
couldn't adjust the tension, b/c i had superglued the caps on. I feel
like I should have started off making them super tight.





1811. Re: [Speed cubing group] DIY CUBE QUESTIONS
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 15 Dec 2005 21:04:47 -0800

I forgot where I read it, but instead of gluing the caps, you can use paper. Cut out a + of paper, such that you have one arm of the cross overhanging each side of the center. Push the center cap in, and the paper will be pushed down and create a tighter fit along the edges. Simple tear or cut any excess paper that is sticking out after you are done. Hope that helps, -Evan Until next time, Happy cubing http://www.deepcube.net On 12/15/05, kovacic81 <kovacic81@...> wrote: > > Hello Everyone > > I just got my DIY cubes via UPS today. I have been using my studio > cube and a 25th anniversary cube with cubesmith stickers forever. > > 1. The centers I got this time are different that the ones I got last > time. THere are no tabs, and the centers *almost* stay in on their > own. Is there any way to avoid Gluing them in there? I want to be > able to take them off. > > 2. For the plastic, black washers, there is a convex side and a > totally flat side. Which side should face the spring? These washers > are just for the bottom, right? > > 3. Some of my corner pieces came assembled, but a few came without a > certain piece. You have to put it in yourself. But I cant seem to > get the piece to be flush with the corner. Has anyone else > experienced this? > > 4. Final Question: What's a good ballpark guideline on how tight to > tighten the screws? 2 previous DIYs got loose really quickly, and I > couldn't adjust the tension, b/c i had superglued the caps on. I feel > like I should have started off making them super tight. > > > > > ------------------------------ > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > - Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube>" > on the web. > > - To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com<speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscribe> > > - Your use of Yahoo! 1814. Re: [Speed cubing group] Sub-20 average!!!
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 10:17:12 +0000 (GMT)

.Dear Mr.Pedro, This is excellent. High flyoing feelings, isn't it ? You have achieved this in 6 months!!! that is wonderful. Keep going and have fun. After a year of cubing I am so near and yet so far. J.Bernett Orlando Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...> wrote: I knew this was coming. Congrats very much indeed. Keep improving :) Sachin. 1815. Awesome one-handed average!!!
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 10:30:31 -0000

Hi everybody!!

I've only been practicing one-handed solving seriosly for like 6 weeks
and yesterday I broke my average record with almost 3 seconds and
reached 8th place in the world!!! I'm so exited!! :-D

Avg: 38.87
------
37.08, 35.83, (47.59), 40.13, 40.07, 40.96, (33.62), 39.55, 39.08,
42.06, 33.71, 40.26

I still only know how to execute about 20 OLL cases with one hand so
there is a LOT of room for improvement. I think that as soon as I
learn some more OLLs I may be able to average sub-35. I'm putting a
lot of effort into one-handed solving right now to be able to compete
with the fastest guys (not Ryan; his times are impossible to beat).

/Gunnar





1816. Re: [Speed cubing group] Awesome one-handed average!!!
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 10:55:10 -0000

Hi Gunnar, Congratulations! I've been one-handing for ever (!) and my best average is only a couple of seconds faster. I recently got my first sub-30seconds single solve - which given my two-handed average is only just under 30 seconds is quite surprising. I fear one day I may be faster with one hand than two! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Friday, December 16, 2005 10:30 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Awesome one-handed average!!! > Hi everybody!! > > I've only been practicing one-handed solving seriosly for like 6 weeks > and yesterday I broke my average record with almost 3 seconds and > reached 8th place in the world!!! 1817. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L2 solves
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 11:05:32 -0000

Hi All
Just a progress update. I am pretty much solving full time with my L2L2
strategy now. Although my times are still slower until I get faster at the
recognition/selection process, my average number of moves per solve is a lot
less now. I did 10 solves recently at 52-53 moves which is probably close
to the right figure. Number of moves is mostly reliant on getting the cross
plus two corners in as few moves as possible - or if you were to choose a
different approach for the start - F2L less two middle edges. There may
still be room for improvement in this - I've been thinking of spending some
time on Chris' X-cross work to see if anything is applicable. Also Paul
Nixon has tried starting with the Petrus 3x2x2 but got bogged down. I don't
know this but it may offer another way to start L2L solves. Any comments or
suggestions more than welcome :)

Duncan

1821. Re: Oh wow
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 12:47:57 -0000

Hi Chris! Now i been studying ur solution ... or rather been trying. Ur solution does not solve the scramble at all. I set it all up in the fmc companion :-( I'll see if i can spot the error in ur solution. Maybe it's simply en orientation error ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > Yeah Craig beat me to the punch :-D > > I was showing Craig some F2L tricks, and I speedsolved this scramble > before we ran through it together so I could say what I realistically > did while speedsolving. > > Watch out for Craig man, his F2L is getting very very nice :-) > > Yes that was my F2L, and the LL is a P OLL case and the 7 PLL case. > > Here is how I executed it to solve in 6.72 seconds: > > y' L (B') (R D2) R y (L' U2) (L' U L U' L') [U' d'] (R U R') d (R U' > R2) d' (L' U L) [d U] (R U2) (R' F R U R' U') (R' F' R2 U') > > That's a sustained 5.5 moves per second turning rate :-D > > It surprised me that a Fridrich solve could be sub-7 seconds with > practice. Though there's no way that could be done with a high-30 > move solution as a real solve though. I was turning so fast I > couldn't even follow the pieces, I was just acting on muscle memory. > > My 7 PLL is low 2.xx on a good execution, so often I was getting the > F2L and OLL in 4 seconds, so I imagine I was doing F2L in 3 seconds > sometimes :-D That is of course from muscle memory, but it was nice > to have a horrible LL lockup, and still get an 8 second solve :-D > > I can definitely see how I can speed up my F2L after doing this though. > > Try executing it that way and see what you think, it's craaaaaazy fast. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" > <logitewty@h...> wrote: > > > > The Scramble for just to remember: > > L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D' > > > > Since my LL sucks, I'll do my F2L solution... > > > > Xcross: B R' F D2 F L' > > Second Pair (BL): U2 L' U L U' L' > > Third Pair (BR): U' d' R U R' > > Fourth Pair (FR): d R U' R' > > (this was the solution I came up with (i'm still learning F2L) and > > Chris (Hardwick) said that it was exactly how he solved it, to the > > move, and yah...) > > > > I count...21 using HTM (i think) > > > > Now everyone can see how horrible my LL is :D And for everyone's > > knowledge (and you can ask Chris if you doubt me) I found about 12 > > different ways of executing the LL here using my method...So I might > > as well list as many as I can think of... > > > > 1: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' M' U' M U2 M' U' M U' y' x' R2 D2 > > R' U' R D2 R' U R' x' F2 D' L' R F2 R' L D' F2 (41 HTM) > > Some of the parts in this can be done in different orders...it really > > doesn't matter and it accounts for I believe 1 or 2 different ways... > > > > 2: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' U x' z2 R U' R D2 R' U R D2 R2 x y2 > > r U R' U' M U R U' R' x' R U' R' U D R' D U' R' U R D2 F (44 HTM) > > why am i doing this ugh... > > > > 3: z U' R U R F R2 F' R' U' R U z' y' M' U M U2 M' U M U' x' R2 D2 R' > > U' R D2 R' U R' x' y' F2 D L' R F2 R' L D F2 (42 HTM) > > > > 4: z x U' R2 U R U' R U x2 z y R' D' R D' R' D2 R x2 R U R' U' M' U R > > U' r' U x' z2 R2 D2 R' U' R D2 R' U R' z' R U' R' U D R' D U' R' U R > > D2 F (47 HTM) > > > > I'll save you all the troubles of trying more and me the trouble of > > typing them out...Could someone post a good LL to this solve for me to > > try???(using my F2L) > > > > Thanx Craig > > >

1824. Re: Oh wow
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 12:59:42 -0000

> y' L (B') (R D2) R y (L' U2) (L' U L U' L') [U' d'] (R U R') d (R U' > R2) d' (L' U L) [d U] (R U2) (R' F R U R' U') (R' F' R2 U') Hey Per I just tried it again and it worked for me. I did it on a regular cube though. The only thing I can think of is maybe the y' that starts it? Also the lower case d turns are really the D and E layers turned together, but I'm sure you already knew that. After the scramble, do the y' at the very beginning, and then the rest of the solve as written above. It worked for me when I tried it? I hope it was just the y' ? Let me know if it still doesn't work. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi Chris! > > Now i been studying ur solution ... or rather been trying. 1825. Could anyone help me?
From: "master_bater_0000" <master_bater_0000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 13:46:10 -0000

Ok, im 14, and ive been cubing for about a week, and i can solve the
cube using the layer by layer method. but that is a beginner solution,
so even though ive got that down good, i still cant get under one
minute. my average is about 1:30-1:45, and my fastest time is 1:09.
but ive been looking on the net for speedcubing techniques, but
couldnt find any that were good. they were all confusing and dificult
to understand (at least for me) so i was wondering if anyone has their
own solution, or knows a site with pictures and such to help me out.
id really appreciate it. thanks you.





1826. Re: Could anyone help me?
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 13:55:06 -0000

Only beginner solutions use pictures and the such, to learn speedcubing methods you must learn the notation. Many sites have applets to help, but the notation is key. Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "master_bater_0000" <master_bater_0000@y...> wrote: > > Ok, im 14, and ive been cubing for about a week, and i can solve the > cube using the layer by layer method. but that is a beginner solution, > so even though ive got that down good, i still cant get under one > minute. my average is about 1:30-1:45, and my fastest time is 1:09. > but ive been looking on the net for speedcubing techniques, but > couldnt find any that were good. they were all confusing and dificult > to understand (at least for me) so i was wondering if anyone has their > own solution, or knows a site with pictures and such to help me out. > id really appreciate it. thanks you. >
1827. Re: Could anyone help me?
From: "Johannes Laire" <johannes.laire@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 13:59:17 -0000

Have you tried the Petrus method? It's really fast, I have averaged sub-20 a few times. It's also quite simple and easy to understand. I learned it by myself from his site 6 months ago, when I was 13. http://lar5.com/cube/index.html - Johannes --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "master_bater_0000" <master_bater_0000@y...> wrote: > > Ok, im 14, and ive been cubing for about a week, and i can solve the > cube using the layer by layer method. but that is a beginner solution, > so even though ive got that down good, i still cant get under one > minute. my average is about 1:30-1:45, and my fastest time is 1:09. > but ive been looking on the net for speedcubing techniques, but > couldnt find any that were good. they were all confusing and dificult > to understand (at least for me) so i was wondering if anyone has their > own solution, or knows a site with pictures and such to help me out. > id really appreciate it. thanks you. >
1828. Re: Oh wow
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>

Hi :-) Hmm ... are we still talking bout this scramble: L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D' ?? I have now tried changing the y' with y or any other x,z in ur solution. Still ur solution does not solve that scramble. Can u write down ur solution without any x,y or z in it ?? Maybe the fmc companion is coded wrong? But i've yet to see that it is wrong actually. Hmm ... Take care! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > y' L (B') (R D2) R y (L' U2) (L' U L U' L') [U' d'] (R U R') d (R U' > > R2) d' (L' U L) [d U] (R U2) (R' F R U R' U') (R' F' R2 U') > > Hey Per I just tried it again and it worked for me. I did it on a > regular cube though. The only thing I can think of is maybe the y' > that starts it? Also the lower case d turns are really the D and E > layers turned together, but I'm sure you already knew that. > > After the scramble, do the y' at the very beginning, and then the rest > of the solve as written above. > > It worked for me when I tried it? I hope it was just the y' ? > > Let me know if it still doesn't work. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi Chris! > > > > Now i been studying ur solution ... or rather been trying. Ur > > solution does not solve the scramble at all. I set it all up in the > > fmc companion :-( > > I'll see if i can spot the error in ur solution. Maybe it's simply > > en orientation error ;-) > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per >

1830. [Speed cubing group] Re: Oh wow
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 14:34:27 -0000

Brilliant!! Haha, now i feel stupid, how come i didn't try that ... :-o Now it worked fine. But Chris, the solution is 39 moves not 37. It's the same as : B R' F D2 F L' U2 L' U L U' L' U' U' B U B' U R U' R2 U' F' U F U U R U2 R' F R U R' U' R' F' R2 U' (converted by the fmc companion). Aha!! And now i also see why it really is 37, not 39 :-P I really hate x,y,z :D Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Hmm...I think I know what's wrong...did you change the [ ] for ( )? 1831. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 14:45:26 -0000

Nice David!! All mine are actually htm-optimised since that's the FMC-metric ;-) I should try become better at stm-optimisation, cause that's the metric i really see as the most fair one. I honor inner slice turns as 1 turn only. And i can't see why half turns should be punished and considered to be of length 2 ;-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@...m, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi Per, > > OK. One shorter in stm. :) > > U r' U r U' r L F' L' f' L F L' f U' (20 htm, 15 stm) > > And there's another one that's all r and U. > > :) > > David J > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi :-) > > > > Ok, here's a slightly different case: > > > > R2 u R' U D F' (L2 D2)*3 F U' D' R' (17-htm, 16-stm) > > > > With another u' at the end it's cool middle layer alg, but i like it > > better without it. > > > > Oh, and i can of course postpone the first R2 to have this one: > > > > u R' U D F' (L2 D2)*3 F U' D' R (16-htm, 15-stm) > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Oopssss ... > > > > > > Here is actually the last case. It's a bit odd, so no wonder i > > > initially forgot about it : > > > > > > R F U' L B' U2 B u B' U2 B L' U F' R' (16-htm, 15-stm) > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > How old am I again ? 20 ? > > > > haha > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/14, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > Haha Gilles :D > > > > > > > > > > Sacre bleu ;-) I'm sure u are aware of inverses right? So, go > > > ahead > > > > > inverse my algorithms. I'm not gonna charge you ... lol ... > > > > > > > > > > In fact, in all cases u can do some mirrored algorithm > > instead. > > > But > > > > > i know that u know that also :D But the axis of mirroring is > > not > > > the > > > > > same for all 4 cases ... > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > Now what if the centers were cycled counter-clockwise ? > > > > > > :p > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/14, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > Yo! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I realised only one case was left now so here it is : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' R' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > > > > > (R r) F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 u F' R' (13-htm, 11-stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > PS! Since lower case here are inner slice turns, (Rr) is > > the > > > > > same as > > > > > > > fingertrick r alone ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per > > Kristen > > > > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > That 'Arc de Triomphe' is so well known that i didn't > > > bother to > > > > > > > post > > > > > > > > it yet. Even Stefan knows that one ;-) Here's my way of > > > doing > > > > > that > > > > > > > > one : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' B' F L' F' u F L F' B R F > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' r' F D f R F (14-htm, 11-stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > The first 5 moves are setup moves for what the r' does. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > [Actually i normally do it the first way. The second way > > is > > > > > slice- > > > > > > > > turn optimised notation.] > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Have fun! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles > > > van den > > > > > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > It's funny that the centers are cycles clockwise > > (looking > > > > > from > > > > > > > the > > > > > > > > > top), and the edges anti-clockwise. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Now add an H permutation and you have a very nice > > > pattern :p > > > > > > > (swap > > > > > > > > the > > > > > > > > > opposite edges on the top layer). > > > > > > > > > it's some sort of 'Arc de Triomphe' (the monument in > > > Paris):D > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...>: > > > > > > > > > > Very nice algorithms Per :p > > > > > > > > > > I'm amazed how you can find these. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund > > > <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > > > > > Hehe ... > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > This is fun ! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Another pattern along these lines is the following: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' U2 R' U2 B' L U2 L' u L U2 L' B U2 R U2 F (18- > > > htm, 17- > > > > > stm) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > or > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F' R' f' D' F' u2 r' u2 r2 F D f R F dare ask Cube Explorer or ACube to search > > > for me > > > > > > > cause > > > > > > > > of > > > > > > > > > > > course then my solutions don't look short > > anymore :-P > > > > > > > > > > > > > <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ah, I was wondering why your alg was giving > > > something > > > > > > > close > > > > > > > > to a > > > > > > > > > > > full > > > > > > > > > > > > scramble :p > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I'm still wondering about the interest of this > > > > > approach or > > > > > > > > not :s > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > 2005/12/13, Per Kristen Fredlund > > > > > <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > I just realised it's better to do the edge 3- > > > cycle > > > > > > > before > > > > > > > > the u- > > > > > > > > > > > > > turn, like this : > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > R U' F - F' r F' L2 F r' F' L2 F2 - u F' U R' > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > F - F' cancels to give this very neat > > solution : > > > > > > > > > > 1832. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 16:38:41 -0000

Hi Per, For the way I think about the cube, I agree with you that all turns and slices are equal. For the formal mathematical aspects of the cube I recognize the value of the quarter turn. Here's the r and U only version. Some would say the MU, version so this is for the cowboys among us. :) U r' U r U2 r U2 r' U' r' U r' U2 r U r2 U' Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Nice David!! > > All mine are actually htm-optimised since that's the FMC-metric ;-) > > I should try become better at stm-optimisation, cause that's the > metric i really see as the most fair one. I honor inner slice turns > as 1 turn only. And i can't see why half turns should be punished > and considered to be of length 2 ;-) > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi Per, > > > > OK. One shorter in stm. :) > > > > U r' U r U' r L F' L' f' L F L' f U' (20 htm, 15 stm) > > > > And there's another one that's all r and U. > > > > :) > > > > David J > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" > > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > Ok, here's a slightly different case: > > > > > > R2 u R' U D F' (L2 D2)*3 F U' D' R' (17-htm, 16-stm) > > > > > > With another u' at the end it's cool middle layer alg, but i > like it > > > better without it. > > > > > > Oh, and i can of course postpone the first R2 to have this one: > > > > > > u R' U D F' (L2 D2)*3 F U' D' R (16-htm, 15-stm) > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > -Per
1833. Re: Could anyone help me?
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 17:30:45 -0000

Hey there, You might want to take a look at the tutorials on my website... Especially the 3rd one might be interesting for you. www.solvethecube.co.uk (and click on tutorials). I hope you like it... Let me know what you think. Good luck! Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "master_bater_0000" <master_bater_0000@y...> wrote: > > Ok, im 14, and ive been cubing for about a week, and i can solve the > cube using the layer by layer method. but that is a beginner solution, > so even though ive got that down good, i still cant get under one > minute. my average is about 1:30-1:45, and my fastest time is 1:09. > but ive been looking on the net for speedcubing techniques, but > couldnt find any that were good. they were all confusing and dificult > to understand (at least for me) so i was wondering if anyone has their > own solution, or knows a site with pictures and such to help me out. > id really appreciate it. thanks you. >
1834. Re: Could anyone help me?
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 19:47:27 -0000

Lars' method is a professional approach and he doesn't use notation. ~Thom --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > > Only beginner solutions use pictures and the such, to learn > speedcubing methods you must learn the notation. Many sites have > applets to help, but the notation is key. > > Craig > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "master_bater_0000" > <master_bater_0000@y...> wrote: > > > > Ok, im 14, and ive been cubing for about a week, and i can solve the > > cube using the layer by layer method. but that is a beginner solution, > > so even though ive got that down good, i still cant get under one > > minute. my average is about 1:30-1:45, and my fastest time is 1:09. > > but ive been looking on the net for speedcubing techniques, but > > couldnt find any that were good. they were all confusing and dificult > > to understand (at least for me) so i was wondering if anyone has their > > own solution, or knows a site with pictures and such to help me out. > > id really appreciate it. thanks you. > > >
1835. Re: Could anyone help me?
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 20:38:18 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "master_bater_0000" <master_bater_0000@y...> wrote: > > Ok, im 14, and ive been cubing for about a week, and i can solve the > cube using the layer by layer method. but that is a beginner solution, > so even though ive got that down good, i still cant get under one > minute. my average is about 1:30-1:45, and my fastest time is 1:09. > but ive been looking on the net for speedcubing techniques, but > couldnt find any that were good. they were all confusing and dificult > to understand (at least for me) so i was wondering if anyone has their > own solution, or knows a site with pictures and such to help me out. > id really appreciate it. thanks you. > If you're new to the game, I would suggest trying many methods at first and then choose which one you would like to devote your time to. I started with Corners First when I was 14 (10 years ago) took an 8 year break 1.5 years ago learned Corners First Faster(about 35-40sec) 1 years ago I switched to CFOP (24.xx avg avg- best avg 23.88) 5 weeks ago I switched to Gilles Roux's method (27.xx avg avg) I also tried Petrus but the lack of notation made it hard for me to learn. Also, It seems that everything on the site is 'left handed.' Despite all this, I always start with a 2x2 (X cross) when doing CFOP. I have used 3 different systems now. ROUX method is my favorite just because of Move Count Efficiency. I averaged 45 moves/cube for 12 cubes. Best Solve so far 31 moves. take a look here if you want http://grrroux.free.fr/ Jason Kovacic kovacic81@yahoo.com
1836. 4x4 centers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

the 4x4, now it's online:

http://stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/speedsolving/4x4_centers

Feedback appreciated :-)

Cheers!
Stefan

1838. Standard notation
From: "Emanuele" <bw.project@...>

Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 23:16:44 +0100

Hi, everybody! My name is Emanuele and I'm from Italy. I'd like to know how to translate moves like "w", "M", and "E" for 3x3 cubes. Who can help me? Thanx!

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1839. Re: Standard notation
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 22:23:28 -0000

http://www.cubewhiz.com/notation.html Although, I don't use the "w". That is equivalent to lowercase letters. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Emanuele" <bw.project@t...> wrote: > > Hi, everybody! My name is Emanuele and I'm from Italy. I'd like to know how to translate moves like "w", "M", and "E" for 3x3 cubes. Who can help me? Thanx! > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] >
1840. Re: Standard notation
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 22:37:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Emanuele" <bw.project@t...> wrote: > > Hi, everybody! My name is Emanuele and I'm from Italy. I'd like to know how to translate moves like "w", "M", and "E" for 3x3 cubes. Who can help me? Thanx! > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > Hi Emanuele, I was long plagued by difficulty in remembering them (it's such a mess, so I use the mnemonics "Right Up Front," and "mess" Fortunately, the whole cube rotations used - x, y, and z are also "Right Up Front." Turn Side and Cube turn Right, R = M' = x Up, U = E' = y Front F = S = z Part of the mess is that the first two, M and E, are counterclockwise, the S is clockwise. Also "w" means "with" as in take the middle slice with that side. Regards, David J
1841. Re: Awesome one-handed average!!!
From: "master_bater_0000" <master_bater_0000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Dec 2005 22:43:01 -0000

really good job! could someone tell me where i could find a one-handed technique? or is it just the two handed technique? my one handed was 6 minutes, lol, pretty sad. great job --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > Hi everybody!! > > I've only been practicing one-handed solving seriosly for like 6 weeks > and yesterday I broke my average record with almost 3 seconds and > reached 8th place in the world!!! I'm so exited!! :-D > > Avg: 38.87 > ------ > 37.08, 35.83, (47.59), 40.13, 40.07, 40.96, (33.62), 39.55, 39.08, > 42.06, 33.71, 40.26 > > I still only know how to execute about 20 OLL cases with one hand so > there is a LOT of room for improvement. I think that as soon as I > learn some more OLLs I may be able to average sub-35. I'm putting a > lot of effort into one-handed solving right now to be able to compete > with the fastest guys (not Ryan; his times are impossible to beat). > > /Gunnar >

1847. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L2 solves
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 01:37:37 -0000

Hi Duncan, In the old days I averaged somewhere between 36 and 54 moves, with occasional forays above and below that, but I rarely tried to improve solely on the basis of fewer moves. You got me wondering about how many moves it takes me now. So I did 16 solves: 46, 44, 41, 38, 46, 44, 47, 46, 48, 46, 45, 35, 48, 49, 46, 45. I know I can look ahead better and understand more than I'm do now. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > > Hi All > Just a progress update. I am pretty much solving full time with my L2L2 > strategy now. Although my times are still slower until I get faster at the > recognition/selection process, my average number of moves per solve is a lot > less now. I did 10 solves recently at 52-53 moves which is probably close > to the right figure. Number of moves is mostly reliant on getting the cross > plus two corners in as few moves as possible - or if you were to choose a > different approach for the start - F2L less two middle edges. There may > still be room for improvement in this - I've been thinking of spending some > time on Chris' X-cross work to see if anything is applicable. Also Paul > Nixon has tried starting with the Petrus 3x2x2 but got bogged down. I don't > know this but it may offer another way to start L2L solves. Any comments or > suggestions more than welcome :) > > Duncan >

Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 12:39:07 -0000

Thanks for sharing Stefan! I wasn't familiar with this approach. I like how you use the 'yellow face' after solving the l slice. I'll try it some more, it'd be nice to give that phase of the 4x4 solution a bit more steadiness (sp?). Because I start with the easiest colors for preferably two centers, I don't know if this approach will be faster for me. 1855. Re: [Speed cubing group] blindfold record
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 15:17:59 -0000

1857. Re: 4x4 centers
From: "Rob Butler" <futuese@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 15:51:41 -0000

Hi Stefan, Very interesting and highly original approach. I just did a couple of solves and I really enjoyed using this approach. One small question for step 3 (shooting non-yellow centers from U into their proper home on u): "Each shot is either (Rr)' F (Rr) or (Ll) F' (Ll)" Why not (Rr) U' (Rr)'??? It is the same 'go and get' approach, still only three moves, but the middle move is U instead of F keeping the entire step in the (Ll), U, (Rr) gen category. I like your combination move for adjacent pairs in step 3 especially combined with the observation that diagonals will combine with any intervening shot. If stuck with a diagonal pair at the end it can also be quite elegantly combined into: (Rr) U' (Rr)' U (Ll)' U (Ll) [pieces in Ufl and Ubr] or (Ll)' U (Ll) U' (Rr) U' (Rr)' [pieces in Ubl and Ufr] Do you have any data on number of moves for your technique compared the 'usual' approach (opp centers, any 3rd face, adjacent 4th, simultanious adjacent 5th/6th)?? Interesting, original, and fun! Thanks, Rob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > On the train today I wrote about my method for solving the centers of > the 4x4, now it's online: > > http://stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/speedsolving/4x4_centers > > Feedback appreciated :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan >

1860. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 centers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 17:52:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Oh, I have a question: > > I was solving the l slice...the blue, orange and green pairs were solved...I had a red center on his place, but no red center on the r slice...so, what do you do on this case? shoot from the R face? turn the cube so that R becomes U and shoot? or what? > > Pedro Good question, thanks. In that case, I'd go to step 3 and first solve the 3 remaining red centers, for example with (Rr)' F2 (RrLl) F' (Ll) '. In the very rare case that all four of a color are opposite the white center, you can use (Rr)' F2 (RrLl) F2 (Ll)'. You can also (during a regular solve) shoot down a pair with F' (Rr)' F2 (Rr) but I don't like that, I prefer the (Rr)' F (RrLl) F' (Ll)'. Cheers! Stefan
1861. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 centers
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

I know this takes more time to make of course ;-) And maybe it's ur exam period also ... Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> > wrote: > > > > Oh, I have a question: > > > > I was solving the l slice...the blue, orange and green pairs were > solved...I had a red center on his place, but no red center on the r > slice...so, what do you do on this case? shoot from the R face? turn > the cube so that R becomes U and shoot? or what? > > > > Pedro > > Good question, thanks. In that case, I'd go to step 3 and first solve > the 3 remaining red centers, for example with (Rr)' F2 (RrLl) F' (Ll) > '. In the very rare case that all four of a color are opposite the > white center, you can use (Rr)' F2 (RrLl) F2 (Ll)'. You can also > (during a regular solve) shoot down a pair with F' (Rr)' F2 (Rr) but I > don't like that, I prefer the (Rr)' F (RrLl) F' (Ll)'. > > Cheers! > Stefan >
1862. Re: 4x4 centers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 18:30:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Rob Butler" <futuese@y...> wrote: > > "Each shot is either (Rr)' F (Rr) or (Ll) F' (Ll)" > > Why not (Rr) U' (Rr)'??? It is the same 'go and get' approach, > still only three moves, but the middle move is U instead of F > keeping the entire step in the (Ll), U, (Rr) gen category. Yes, you're right. Actually it's of course the same, just holding/rotating the cube differently. I actually do something in the "middle" I think. I've included this remark on my page now. I also fixed two mistakes in algorithms, made the page look a bit better, and added Pedro's issue and another suggestion how to hold your arms. > If stuck with a diagonal pair at the end it can also be quite > elegantly combined into: > > (Rr) U' (Rr)' U (Ll)' U (Ll) [pieces in Ufl and Ubr] > or (Ll)' U (Ll) U' (Rr) U' (Rr)' [pieces in Ubl and Ufr] Right. To be honest, I also use that in the middle of the solve. When the intervening shot would have to go to L or R, I'd have to rotate the cube first, so instead I solve the diagonal pair like you said. It's also good because it doesn't require any 'setup' move, you can use one of those two algs right away (this is something I only thought about right now). I'll add this to my page, too. > Do you have any data on number of moves for your technique compared > the 'usual' approach (opp centers, any 3rd face, adjacent 4th, > simultanious adjacent 5th/6th)?? I think both need about the same number of moves, around 30. I'm usually a bit over 30 but when I explained my method to Ron he soon told me he averages about 28-29 I think. Since I don't use that 'usual' approach, I don't exactly know the number of moves it requires, but I think it's about 30 as well. Thanks for the feedback and suggestions :-) Cheers! Stefan
1863. Re: 4x4 centers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 18:43:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > On the train today I wrote about my method for solving the centers of > the 4x4, now it's online: > > http://stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/speedsolving/4x4_centers > > Feedback appreciated :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan Thanks to feedback and some extra thoughts, I improved the page a now. Besides a little algorithm bugfix, all changes are in the "Improvements" section. And yes, an applet example solve or two might follow, but also yes, that takes much more time :-) Cheers! Stefan

1865. Re: a slice away...
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 19:36:18 -0000

Hi :-) Masayuki Akimoto got a DNF in Orlando on the 5x5x5 cause a center- corner was slightly twisted. I think that rule is ridiculous. It's not like he has willingly tried to benefit from it. It's just a bit of bad luck on his side. Sometimes one cannot even notice this unwanted rotation, unless turning some slice that has become harder to turn. So if it happens just at the very last turn or something u can have that twisting and not knowing it. A pop however of course u will notice and u have the chance to fix it. Well, i hope they will change that rule soon. The same if u have ONE broken center. U cannot benefit from it in any way whatsoever. TWO broken centers and u won't know which is which of course. Oh well ... -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > That would be a DNF... > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> > wrote: > > > > Well, this one is a good question... > > > > If one side is misaligned, you get a +2 penalty. But what if a > slice is misaligned? do you get +2? +4? or what? > > > > Pedro > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > Yahoo! doce lar. Faça do Yahoo! sua homepage. > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > >

1867. Re: 4x4 centers - [u'dD] and [ud'D'] 'shortcuts'
From: "Rob Butler" <futuese@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 20:07:28 -0000


>>S.P. RE: diagonal shots:

Right. To be honest, I also use that in the middle of the solve.
When the intervening shot would have to go to L or R, I'd have to
rotate the cube first, so instead I solve the diagonal pair like you
said.



Hello again Stefan,

For instances where the next shot needs to go to the L or R face I
sometimes find it comfortable / convenient to do a [u'dD] or [ud'D']
move. i.e. I hold the U face and send the bottom three layers to the
left or right. It is very similar concept to using [DE] and [D'E']
during F2L on a 3x3x3.

1869. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: a slice away...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 12:42:44 -0800

I think the issue is that a twisted center results from careless twisting. The main problem we have when writing regulations is where to draw the line. If the centers had been ejected from the cube into a high altitude orbit, then the cube would clearly not be solved. However, if the centers are in a lower altitude orbit, like the International Space Station, then it becomes less clear. So how much are the centers allowed to be out of the cube before it isn't solved anymore? Can we come up with a better answer to this question than we already have while still preserving the idea that the cube must be "solved"? In my opinion, for a 3x3x3, if an edge is hanging out of the cube, it's not solved. The cube must be fully assembled when it's finish—goal of the puzzle is ultimately to return it to its solved state which means that the colors are all the same on each side and preferably, all the piece are in place. For the 3x3x3, I think it's more clear. The lines start to get blurred for larger cubes which is why we've set the strict standard for now. If you're going to allow center pieces to be twisted, then you're going to have to specify very academically "how much." Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Dec 17, 2005, at 11:36 AM, Per Kristen Fredlund wrote: > Hi :-) > > Masayuki Akimoto got a DNF in Orlando on the 5x5x5 cause a center- > corner was slightly twisted. I think that rule is ridiculous. It's > not like he has willingly tried to benefit from it. It's just a bit > of bad luck on his side. Sometimes one cannot even notice this > unwanted rotation, unless turning some slice that has become harder > to turn. So if it happens just at the very last turn or something u > can have that twisting and not knowing it. A pop however of course u > will notice and u have the chance to fix it. Well, i hope they will > change that rule soon. The same if u have ONE broken center. U > cannot benefit from it in any way whatsoever. TWO broken centers and > u won't know which is which of course. > > Oh well ... > > -Per > >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: >> >> That would be a DNF... >> >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro > <pedrosino1@y...> >> wrote: >>> >>> Well, this one is a good question... >>> >>> If one side is misaligned, you get a +2 penalty. But what if a >> slice is misaligned? do you get +2? +4? or what? >>> >>> Pedro >>> >>> >>> --------------------------------- >>> Yahoo! doce lar. Faça do Yahoo! sua homepage. >>> >>> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] >>> >> > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >

1874. Re: Oh wow
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 22:53:28 -0000

Hi! Scramble: L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D' revisited. I started to have a look at inserting the last 5 corners for this solution : B F2 L [B L L' B>] B2 R' B' L R B R B' F R D R' D' F' [U' U] B' D' B U' B' D B (R' B2 R F2 )*2 So i start with the skeleton: B F2 L B2 R' B' L R B R B' F R D R' D' F' U' or actually i start from this (change order of L and R): B F2 L B2 R' B' R L B.R B' F R D R' D' F' U' Now i insert B' L' F2 L B L' F2:L at the dot and F L B L' F' L B' L' at the colon to get this final solution, cancelling 7 moves: B F2 L B2 R' B' R F2 L B L' F' L B L' F' L B' R {B' F} R D R' D' F' U' (27htm, 26stm, 30qtm, 29sqtm) I spent 5 mins for the 18 move skeleton and about 20-25 mins on the insertions. Quite nice for about half an hour work only. Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi Chris! > > My "5 minute" solution is like this : > > B F2 L [B L L' B>] B2 R' B' L R B R B' F R D R' D' F' [U' U] B' D' B > U' B' D B (R' B2 R F2 )*2 (32-htm,31-stm,38-qtm) > > This is ending with 5 corners, not insertion optimised in any way. > What is your exact 37-move solution ?? > > Have fun! > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > I haven't done this in a long time and figured I would try it > again. > > > > I was solving when I came across a good scramble and got a good > time. > > > > The scramble was: > > L2 D' B' U2 B L2 R2 D F D U R2 F R' F U' R U' L' D2 B2 L' B R D' > > > > and my times was 12.69 which I am very happy with. > > > > Well I then did a prepared solve average, where I did an average > of 10 > > but using this same scramble for all 12 solves. > > > > My average was 9.39 seconds: > > (12.16) 09.67 09.53 08.39 09.02 (07.86) 10.12 10.35 07.92 09.94 > 09.62 > > 09.29 = 9.39 > > > > I then continued for a best rolling average and got 8.09 seconds > > 08.53, (07.11), 08.00, (09.15), 08.89, 07.24, 08.67, 07.13, 07.48, > > 09.05, 08.02, 07.93 = 8.09 > > > > My best execution of my solution so far is 6.72 seconds. > > > > My solution is 37 moves after cancellations from the end of one > step > > being the inverse move of the beginning of the next (which I didn't > > catch in my first real solve). This solve is not lucky either, and > > has a regular 2 look Fridrich LL (though a fast one). > > > > If you know my solving style, you'll know how I started this solve, > > and the rest is very obvious. > > > > See what you guys can do, this scramble rocks! > > > > Chris > > >
1875. Re: [Speed cubing group] blindfold record
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

1876. Re: [Speed cubing group] blindfold record
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Dec 2005 15:27:00 -0800

On Dec 17, 2005, at 15:02, GameOfDeath2 wrote:

> You point out these but not "tracks monkeys with lasers"?! I can't say
> I've ever heard of
> anyone who does that; in fact, I've always thought that tracking of
> animals was done with
> electronic tags (birds, dolphins etc.) rather than lasers.

Well I for one am happy that monkeys with lasers are kept under
surveillance.

Call me old fashioned, but I just don't think simians and death rays
are a safe mix for the rest of society!

- - - - - - - - - - - -
"Build a man a fire, and he'll be warm for a day. Set a man on fire,
and he'll be warm for the rest of his life."
--- Terry Pratchett

Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com

1882. Re: Another Midwest Tournament?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 06:03:07 -0000

Cause > if there is, I think it should be in the St. Louis area and I'm not > just saying that because I'm from St.Louis, I just think it is a good > central location. My girlfriend is attempting to start a cube club at the University of Minnesota (she's taught a dozen or so people so far, some 4x4 and 5x5, too), and hopefully that will lead to a tournament. I believe Peter Babcock and Jake Rueth may be looking at starting one in Wisconsin in the spring. Any updates, guys? -Mike

1884. 5x5 method
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 10:07:17 -0000

Hello Everyone

I just bought a 5x5. This thing is hard to turn!
I use centers first to solve 4x4, but I would like to learn something
different for the 5x5. My first Attempt, I built a white and yellow
4x5x1 block. Then I fixed top 4 corners, just like gilles' method.
Then I managed to pair up 4 of the remaining 6 edges. So I have 10
Edges Oriented and Permuted. White and Yellow layer Completely done.
Centers are all messed up. 2 Edges are messed up. 1st attempt, and
my cube is still like this. How do I finish Edges? How do I do
Centers After that?

On the 4x4, I am experimenting with Mike Bennett's Method. If you Have
everything done but centers, How do you fix the centers?

I appreciate any help you can give me

Thank You

Jason Kovacic
kovacic81@...





1885. Re: [Speed cubing group] 5x5 method
From: eric hatch <washyourmonkey@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 02:20:07 -0800 (PST)

for fixing the last two edges on the 5x5 you can do it the same way you fix the flipped edge parity on the 4x4 but i prefer the centers first and i can do that one much faster than any other methods. and you dont get that edges prob with the centers first if you memorize the algs for the last two edges. kovacic81 <kovacic81@...> wrote: Hello Everyone I just bought a 5x5. This thing is hard to turn! I use centers first to solve 4x4, but I would like to learn something different for the 5x5. My first Attempt, I built a white and yellow 4x5x1 block. Then I fixed top 4 corners, just like gilles' method. Then I managed to pair up 4 of the remaining 6 edges. So I have 10 Edges Oriented and Permuted. White and Yellow layer Completely done. Centers are all messed up. 2 Edges are messed up. 1st attempt, and my cube is still like this. How do I finish Edges? How do I do Centers After that? On the 4x4, I am experimenting with Mike Bennett's Method. If you Have everything done but centers, How do you fix the centers? I appreciate any help you can give me Thank You Jason Kovacic kovacic81@... 1889. Swimming googles
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 20:29:33 +0530

Hello all.

I just had my friends video camera with me and thought that i would
make some bld videos before returning the cam back. Now the last time
i made a bld video, i used a hankerchief to cover my eyes. But it took
a lot of time to tie the hankerchief around my head, so i tht of using
some other method this time.

then i remembered i have some old swimming googles with me and decided
to use them as the blindfold :) With the help of some newspaper
clippings i had my blindfold ready.though it hurt a little at first :(
have a look at it here
http://www.civil.iitb.ac.in/~d3sachin/cubing/googles.jpg or if this is
not accessible then here
http://homepages.iitb.ac.in/~sachins/cubing/googles.jpg

They look quite silly.
:)

Btw the blindfold attempt was succesful with a time of 4 mins
38secs...quite my normal time. You can have a look at the video of
this attempt here
http://www.civil.iitb.ac.in/~d3sachin/cubing/videos.html or here
http://homepages.iitb.ac.in/~sachins/cubing/videos.html

Happy blding!
Sachin.
