1894. Random stuff
From: "mahtianssi" <mahtianssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 17:36:35 -0000

1. Slowest improver:
I think Rafael Algarin wins this category. Or maybe my cousin Mikael. I
taught him the cube one year ago and his times are still over 2 minutes
=P (Practices only when I'm around)
And my father will probably soon be sub-40 after (only?) 20 months of
cubing.
2. Where do you find so many cube-students?
I have taught only 3 and nobody of them got interested enough to go
even sub minute.
3. I think my cat cubes secretly. At least he tries to sleep on my
Stackmat.






1895. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4 centers
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 19:30:20 +0100

Hello, For some reason, I thought this was your blindfolded method for the 4x4 centers, which I found a very very hard method for blindfolded :p But this is a nice method I should consider practicing.. 2005/12/17, Koen Heltzel <allyourbase@...>: > Thanks for sharing Stefan! I wasn't familiar with this approach. I > like how you use the 'yellow face' after solving the l slice. I'll try > it some more, it'd be nice to give that phase of the 4x4 solution a > bit more steadiness (sp?). > > Because I start with the easiest colors for preferably two centers, I > don't know if this approach will be faster for me. > > Thanks again :) > > - Koen > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > On the train today I wrote about my method for solving the centers of > > the 4x4, now it's online: > > > > http://stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/speedsolving/4x4_centers > > > > Feedback appreciated :-) > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1896. Re: Aaack! A string (partially) came of on my Magic!
From: "rubikorkow" <calcdude@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 18:36:31 -0000

Help... 1901. FAO Schwarz - someone doing Rubiks cube demo... anyone on this list?
From: "stuart.a.hall" <stuart.a.hall@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 15:55:37 -0500

Hi all, thanks to everyone who posted a response back to my prior
question about intermediate next steps and learning the algorithms.

I became interested in doing the Rubiks again after a 25 year hiatus. I
was in FAO Schwarz in NY City a few weeks ago (picked up a Bedlam Box
puzzle as well) and saw they had a bunch of 25th anniversary cubes "on
sale" for $13. :-) There was a guy there solving the cube in about a
minute or so. Despite not being terribly speedy, I suppose since he was
talking while demonstrating the cube, I wondered if that person happened
to be on this list?

Does anyone else make a living or otherwise entertain folks during the
holiday shopping sprees this time of year?

1905. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L2 solves
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 22:19:58 -0000

Hi David, Those are pretty amazing move numbers for a speedcubing strategy! What method do you use that is so much more efficient than Fridrich? I know with fewest move methods one can get much lower but if this is a speedsolving method then it seem to be lower than just about anything I've heard of. The benefit of L2L is there are fewer algorithms to learn, and so also a less onerous recognition phase, than Fridrich - is the number of algorithms a problem with your method? i'd love to hear more. Best wishes Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, December 17, 2005 1:37 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L2 solves > Hi Duncan, > > In the old days I averaged somewhere between 36 and 54 moves, with > occasional forays above and below that, but I rarely tried to improve > solely on the basis of fewer moves. > > You got me wondering about how many moves it takes me now. So I did 16 > solves: 46, 44, 41, 38, 46, 44, 47, 46, 48, 46, 45, 35, 48, 49, 46, 45. > > I know I can look ahead better and understand more than I'm do now. > > Cheers, > > David J > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" > <duncan@d...> wrote: >> >> Hi All >> Just a progress update. I am pretty much solving full time with my > L2L2 >> strategy now. Although my times are still slower until I get faster > at the >> recognition/selection process, my average number of moves per solve > is a lot >> less now. I did 10 solves recently at 52-53 moves which is probably > close >> to the right figure. Number of moves is mostly reliant on getting > the cross >> plus two corners in as few moves as possible - or if you were to > choose a >> different approach for the start - F2L less two middle edges. There > may >> still be room for improvement in this - I've been thinking of > spending some >> time on Chris' X-cross work to see if anything is applicable. Also > Paul >> Nixon has tried starting with the Petrus 3x2x2 but got bogged down. > I don't >> know this but it may offer another way to start L2L solves. Any > comments or >> suggestions more than welcome :) >> >> Duncan >> > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >
1906. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L2 solves
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 22:59:53 -0000

Hmm... Gilles is even better :-) http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Miscellaneous.html If I remember correctly, David takes about 30 seconds, and with that speed, Gilles says he averages 43 moves. And I think he wrote that page a while ago, maybe he has improved further in the meantime? Cheers! 1907. Re: [Speed cubing group] Swimming googles
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Dec 2005 22:20:53 -0300 (ART)

I can't open any of the links... Pedro Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@gmail.com> escreveu: Hello all. I just had my friends video camera with me and thought that i would make some bld videos before returning the cam back. Now the last time i made a bld video, i used a hankerchief to cover my eyes. But it took a lot of time to tie the hankerchief around my head, so i tht of using some other method this time. then i remembered i have some old swimming googles with me and decided to use them as the blindfold :) With the help of some newspaper clippings i had my blindfold ready.though it hurt a little at first :( have a look at it here http://www.civil.iitb.ac.in/~d3sachin/cubing/googles.jpg or if this is not accessible then here http://homepages.iitb.ac.in/~sachins/cubing/googles.jpg They look quite silly. :) Btw the blindfold attempt was succesful with a time of 4 mins 38secs...quite my normal time. You can have a look at the video of this attempt here http://www.civil.iitb.ac.in/~d3sachin/cubing/videos.html or here http://homepages.iitb.ac.in/~sachins/cubing/videos.html Happy blding! Sachin. --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. 1908. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L2 solves
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 02:14:10 -0000

I just took an average. Cubes solved in 22s-40s. 15s inspection. Important: No take-backs. 39 42 36 (46) 44 (33) 46 37 44 37 43 42 --> 41 moves (it may rise to 44, and my best is 38) 43 is still valid, with a 30s time limit. Good night, Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Hmm... > > Gilles is even better :-) > http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Miscellaneous.html > > If I remember correctly, David takes about 30 seconds, and with that > speed, Gilles says he averages 43 moves. 1912. DIY cubes w/ DIY Corners? Please help
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 08:33:52 -0000

Hello Everyone

THe biggest problem I'm having is with the corner pieces. They did
not come assembled. There is the visibly hollow corner piece and then
a diamond shaped piece that fits into the bottom of the corner.
However, I cannot get the piece to sit flush in there. This piece
sticking up, even a little bit, will prevent the cube from turning
smoothly. Maybe I need to sand something or use a hammer to get it
flush. Has anyone else gotten (DIY cubes with DIY corners) like me?


For the plastic, black washers, there is a convex side and a
totally flat side. Which side should face the spring?

Final Question: What's a good ballpark guideline on how tight to
tighten the screws? 2 previous DIYs got loose really quickly, and I
couldn't adjust the tension, b/c i had superglued the caps on. I feel
like I should have started off making them super tight.

Thank You

Jason Kovacic
kovacic81@...

PS Best new Avg w/ Roux today 25.56 no CLL





1913. Dan Harris is back :)
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 10:13:19 -0000

Hi everyone,

I haven't been around recently as a few of you may know, because I
have recently been in hospital to have a major operation on my leg.

I've been pretty poorly over the last week or two but now I am
recovering and am feeling a lot better. I am walking about (slowly!)
on crutches, and I have to wear a metal frame thing around my leg to
stabilise it while it heals up.

So just to let you know that I am back on the scene, although I
doubt I will be able to catch up with all the messages left on the
group since my hospital stay. Thank goodness my hands/arms weren't
operated on so I can still cube ;) In fact, Stefan, I set 3:25.56 on
the Megaminx in hospital with my new method, and that's with only a
little practice. SO watch out, I am going to beat you soon!

On Friday I hope to launch the Xmas FMC if I feel well enough to
stay on the computer for a few hours, if not I'll post the scramble
and the categories to the group and apologise in advance for not
getting it on the site.

Hope to speak to you and hear from you all soon, keep in touch!

DanH :)





1914. Re: [Speed cubing group] Dan Harris is back :)
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 11:47:36 +0100

Good to have you back. Get well soon!

/Gustav

Dan skrev:

>Hi everyone,
>
>I haven't been around recently as a few of you may know, because I
>have recently been in hospital to have a major operation on my leg.
>
>I've been pretty poorly over the last week or two but now I am
>recovering and am feeling a lot better. I am walking about (slowly!)
>on crutches, and I have to wear a metal frame thing around my leg to
>stabilise it while it heals up.
>
>So just to let you know that I am back on the scene, although I
>doubt I will be able to catch up with all the messages left on the
>group since my hospital stay. Thank goodness my hands/arms weren't
>operated on so I can still cube ;) In fact, Stefan, I set 3:25.56 on
>the Megaminx in hospital with my new method, and that's with only a
>little practice. SO watch out, I am going to beat you soon!

1916. Re: DIY cubes w/ DIY Corners? Please help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 14:26:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > Final Question: What's a good ballpark guideline on how tight to > tighten the screws? No idea. Depends on you. > i had superglued the caps on. BAD idea.
1917. Re: DIY cubes w/ DIY Corners? Please help
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 15:00:20 -0000

Jason, the DIY caps are a real problem. You almost have to resort to at least a drop of glue to make them stay. The paper cross method only works well with the Studio-type centers, from my experience. The walls on the DIY centers are too thin. As for distance, the official recommendation is 1mm between burr and center post when the spring is pulled out. However because of tolerances you really just have to adjust by feel. The 1mm guieline is a good starting point though. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" > <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > > Final Question: What's a good ballpark guideline on how tight to > > tighten the screws? > > No idea. Depends on you. > > > i had superglued the caps on. > > BAD idea. >
1918. Re: DIY cubes w/ DIY Corners? Please help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 15:46:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, christopher_pelley <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Jason, the DIY caps are a real problem. You almost have to resort to > at least a drop of glue to make them stay. Yes, but only almost :-) Most importantly, first you should make the cap fit into place. That is, cut the parts that are in the way. And when it fits, you can make some "scratches" into the plastic. But so that you don't just press a hole into the plastic, but instead press it sidewards so that a bit sticks *out*. Do that on all four side and you should be fine. Cheers! Stefan
1919. Re: dropping magic upside-down

1923. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L2 solves
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 17:11:16 -0000

Hi Duncan, My method is based on freedom of movement. F2L I do the "cross last. The LL I do CLL ELL. A beginner version would look like this: 1. Place two edge pieces, i.e. one across-the-center-of-one-side pair, on the middle level, like RF and LF (right front and left front) The four middle level edge pieces do not have the colors of the centers of the first and last levels. In my case these four edge pieces have neither Orange nor Red. 2. Place four corners on the first level, (on top) 3. Place the other two edges on the middle level, 4. place the four edges of the first level; (first level now on bottom) There are lots of options If the first four corners can go in place easily the middle edges are next and are often very few moves. Most of the time I get to the last level with two edges flipped. It's usually quicker to solve the LL corners and flip two edges than solving the corners while flipping no edges. This leave the ELL of 7 moves, and often the first move is already done by the last sequence. When placing the last of the First Level corners there is the opportunity to solve the LL corners in one go. This allows you to solve the LL edges sometimes when placing the cross. Send me a scramble and I'll send you a typical solve. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > > Hi David, > Those are pretty amazing move numbers for a speedcubing strategy! What > method do you use that is so much more efficient than Fridrich? I know with > fewest move methods one can get much lower but if this is a speedsolving > method then it seem to be lower than just about anything I've heard of. The > benefit of L2L is there are fewer algorithms to learn, and so also a less > onerous recognition phase, than Fridrich - is the number of algorithms a > problem with your method? i'd love to hear more. > > Best wishes > > Duncan > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Saturday, December 17, 2005 1:37 AM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L2 solves > > > > Hi Duncan, > > > > In the old days I averaged somewhere between 36 and 54 moves, with > > occasional forays above and below that, but I rarely tried to improve > > solely on the basis of fewer moves. > > > > You got me wondering about how many moves it takes me now. So I did 16 > > solves: 46, 44, 41, 38, 46, 44, 47, 46, 48, 46, 45, 35, 48, 49, 46, 45. > > > > I know I can look ahead better and understand more than I'm do now. > > > > Cheers, > > > > David J > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" > > <duncan@d...> wrote: > >> > >> Hi All > >> Just a progress update. I am pretty much solving full time with my > > L2L2 > >> strategy now. Although my times are still slower until I get faster > > at the > >> recognition/selection process, my average number of moves per solve > > is a lot > >> less now. I did 10 solves recently at 52-53 moves which is probably > > close > >> to the right figure. Number of moves is mostly reliant on getting > > the cross > >> plus two corners in as few moves as possible - or if you were to > > choose a > >> different approach for the start - F2L less two middle edges. There > > may > >> still be room for improvement in this - I've been thinking of > > spending some > >> time on Chris' X-cross work to see if anything is applicable. Also > > Paul > >> Nixon has tried starting with the Petrus 3x2x2 but got bogged down. > > I don't > >> know this but it may offer another way to start L2L solves. Any > > comments or > >> suggestions more than welcome :) > >> > >> Duncan > >> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
1924. Re: Method efficiency WAS: L2L2 solves
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 17:29:00 -0000

Hi Stefan, First off, though I average between 25 and 32 seconds, most of my cubing time, which is fairly limited, goes into understanding the cube better rather than practicing for speed. Second, I am using only my own algorithms and haven't found a complete set yet. While my strategies are pretty well formed I'm not yet satisfied with all of my algorithms. As such, my method isn't complete, yet. Third, with the exception of the placement of the last four centers Gilles' method is an option within my method. Fourth for a speed comparison, my best time, from about six months ago, is 13.33 seconds. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@...m, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Hmm... > > Gilles is even better :-) > http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Miscellaneous.html > > If I remember correctly, David takes about 30 seconds, and with that > speed, Gilles says he averages 43 moves. And I think he wrote that > page a while ago, maybe he has improved further in the meantime? > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" > <duncan@d...> wrote: > > > > Hi David, > > Those are pretty amazing move numbers for a speedcubing strategy! > What > > method do you use that is so much more efficient than Fridrich? 1926. How do you know where to start?
From: "Eric" <maier@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 18:24:41 -0000

Hi,

For someone just getting to "speed cubing" how do you know where to
start? There seem to be a bunch of different methods out there but is
one better than another?

I really want to try this out but don't want to spent a bunch ot time
learning a certain method only find out that I should have been
concentrating on an entirely different way of solving the cube.

Thank for any input,

Eric





1927. Super-mini world cup-2005 0n 17th & 18th dec in Chennai, India
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 18:27:17 +0000 (GMT)

Dear Cubers,
Ron Van Bruchem uncle was in Chennai, India on 17th and 18th of dec-2005
I am very very happy to have spent the week-end happily with Ron uncle. I learnt a lot and had fun. He was very good, kind and simple.
Eventhough I lost all the events to a great cuber, I enjoyed the super-mini world cup-2005 held in Chennai on 17th and 18th. It is called super-mini because only 2 competed. My disappointment for not being allowed to usa to compete in wc-2005 in Orlando was very well compensated by the super mini world cup-2005 with Ron uncle last week end. What a wonderful gesture from him to compete with this little boy travelling a long way!!
I am greatly benefitted and enjoyed asif I had been in Orlando. Wow, how many good quality cubes he had presented to me - square-1, 2*2, 3*3, 4*4, 5*5 !!!
Wow! at last, I shook hands with one of the best cubers in the world , talked with him, stayed with him, learnt from him, had fun with him and finally competed with him. Looking forward to many more such meetings in 2006 with you all as well.
The mini world cup-2005 held in chennai last week end was a great success. Kudos to Ron uncle, my dad and his friends and relatives to make this mini world-cup-2005 a great success. Full results Ron uncle may post at the earliest possible.( I hit many 18.xx, 19.xx and 20.xx sec in stackmat).
I am inspired.

J.Bernett Orlando

Send instant messages to your online friends http://in.messenger.yahoo.com

1929. Re: How long have the centers been curved?
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 19:08:24 -0000

1931. Restoration hardware cubes
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 19:33:08 -0000

Just got some new cubes from Restoration hardware. The stickers
will probably wear out quickly, which is too bad becuase I like the
retro logo, but new stickers are abundant and inexpensive. But
right out of the box this one is very smooth and fast. I'm
optimistic it will turn out to be a great speedcube.

I went to the store in Mission Viejo California and they had about
12 or 15 out, so I tried them all and bought the only 3 that turned
well [keeping one for me, the other 2 are spoken for]. These 3 were
all about the same, but were far smoother than all of the others. I
still find that variability to be weird for something mass produced.

One clerk saw me playing with them and commented that the fastest
anyone had been able to solve it was four minutes. I said something
like you've got to be kididng me [thinking, of course, that there
must have been someone faster than that]. she replied no really, I
watched him do most of it and it was really cool. when I did it in
about 45 seconds, they were all blown away. too fun.

They did not seem to mind at all that I was taking them out of the
box and playing with them, and I saw other people doing the same
thing. The packaging is open [someone posted a picture on the
twistypuzzles site of the packaging]. That made it rather easy to
find the good ones.

they have arched centers, and are made by Winning Moves, so
internally they may just be the same as their other cubes, but the
packaging and stickers have the retro look, which is definitely
cool, imo.

hapy cubing,
Kirk






1932. Re: How long have the centers been curved?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 19:49:01 -0000

Hi :-) Short answer : since 1982 or thereabout. That's when the Deluxe (Game) cube first saw the light of day. Those cubes had arched centers unlike the original ones and most of the knock-off cubes. (Someone correct me if u have information contradicting this.) Even since then most cubes have been made with plain flat inside centers. I guess this is simply cause they are easier and cheaper to make. Like already mentioned, some prefer arched centers cause of stability, less popping. While some prefer normal flat centers cause they give less locking, more forgiving. -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > just a difference in some cubes--some have arched centers, some > don't. I suppose that's a good thing since some cubers like arched > centers, and some don't. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eric" <maier@d...> > wrote: > > > > How long have the insides of the center pieces been curved? I have 2 > > cubes both purchased around the same time. One has curved center > > pieces and one does not. > > > > Thanks, > > > > Eric > > >

1934. Re: Restoration hardware cubes
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 20:35:45 -0000

Can you post the manufacture dates (on the inside of one of the corners-- turn each face 45 degrees to locate it). The good cube that I got said "M1005" which I take to mean it was just produced in October of this year. It would be interesting to know whether these cubes are of higher production standards than earlier batches. Speaking of that, is there anyone who can solve the puzzle of how these cubes are manufactured vs. marketed? In other words, I know that currently you can get 3x3x3 cubes made by Winning Moves, Hasbro, or Rubiks.com. However they appear to be the same product from Kroeger of Canada. Yet they all claim to be Made in China. Are they made in China, imported by Kroeger, then packaged and sold by Winning Moves, Hasbro, and Rubiks.com respectively? Does Kroeger just do the final manufacturing (i.e. assembly and stickers)? I'm just trying to understand where the breakdown in quality actually occurs. It doesn't make sense on the surface that Winning Moves cubes are superior if they're all made at the same plant in China as the Hasbro cubes. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Just got some new cubes from Restoration hardware. The stickers > will probably wear out quickly, which is too bad becuase I like the > retro logo, but new stickers are abundant and inexpensive. But > right out of the box this one is very smooth and fast. I'm > optimistic it will turn out to be a great speedcube.
1935. Re: How long have the centers been curved?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 21:13:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Short answer : since 1982 or thereabout. That's when the Deluxe > (Game) cube first saw the light of day. Those cubes had arched > centers unlike the original ones and most of the knock-off cubes. > > (Someone correct me if u have information contradicting this.) Well, I know that my first Rubik's Cube had arched centres. It was bought in the UK in early March 1981. It wasn't a Deluxe or Game Cube. Mike
1936. 38 quarter turns confirmed sufficient
From: "Bruce Norskog" <brnorsk@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 16:30:02 -0500

Hi,

I can now report independent confirmation that Rubik's cube can always be
solved without using more than 38 quarter turns. This has been shown based
upon the following results.

Tom Rokicki posted a result on this forum in January, 2004, showing that the
edge cubies of Rubik's cube can always be solved in 18 quarter turns or
less. (See:
http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/8306) I
have just verified this result, doing my own independent analysis using a
Pentium 4-based PC.

Silviu Radu, who I understand is working on a Ph.D. thesis on Rubik's cube,
has done an analysis showing that the corners can always be solved without
any net change in the edge positions/orientations in 22 quarter turns or
less. Together, the above results show that Rubik's cube can always be
solved in two phases using no more than 40 quarter turns. I have verified
that Silviu's move sequences solve all of the relevant cube positions using
no more than 22 quarter turns.

Rokicki's analysis indicates there are 31 positions, considering just the
edges and centers, that require more than 16 moves to properly position and
orient the edges. This is only 4 symmetrically distinct positions. I have
generated move sequences for solving all the symmetrically distinct
positions of Rubik's cube having these edge configurations using no more
than 37 quarter turns. Silviu has confirmed that my solutions are correct
and account for all the relevant symmetrically distinct positions. All
remaining positions of Rubik's cube can be solved in 38 quarter turns or
less (at most 16 quarter turns to solve the edges, and then 22 quarter turns
or less to solve the corners while having no net effect on the edges).

Details have been posted on the cube-lovers forum at:
http://cubezzz.homelinux.org/drupal/

- Bruce Norskog




1937. Re: How long have the centers been curved?
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 22:23:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eric" <maier@d...> wrote: > > How long have the insides of the center pieces been curved? I have 2 > cubes both purchased around the same time. One has curved center > pieces and one does not. > > Thanks, > > Eric Hi Eric, Per, and All, The original design had arched centers. Ideal, from the very beginning in 1980, made cubes with both the flat centers and arched centers. The Deluxe versions, starting in 1980, all have the arches. When Ideal stopped making cubes I think that most of the production models were flat centered, but I'm not sure. The arched center pieces were reintroduced by Seven Towns about the beginning of 2003. Seven Towns controls all of the officially licensed cubes except for Rubik's Studio cubes. Their manufacturing plants are in China and they make all the cubes which are sold by Winning Moves, Hasbro and Milton Bradley. Regards, David J

Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 22:28:57 -0000

Hi :-) Well, then either the edge-step leaves corners untouched or the corner-step leaves edges untouched. Is this really the case for those separate analyses ?? 1940. Re: How long have the centers been curved?
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 00:27:57 -0000

Hi Chris, I think that some of the first plastics that were tried made the cubes hard to turn, so flat centers were introduced to reduce friction. When the plastics improved the arches came back. I think that since they already had the tooling for the flat centers and quite a bit more demand for cubes than they could meet, so they kept producing the flat centers. I have an early 1980 Ideal Cube in the white box, and a Politoys cube from the same time, both made in Hungary, with arches. What do you mean by "clone?" 1941. Re: Method efficiency WAS: L2L2 solves
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 00:35:39 -0000

Hi David, I was mainly trying to point out that you're counting in STM, because I think Duncan thought you used HTM. Using STM, Mark Waterman says he used 40-45 turns 20+ years ago already (http://www.rubikscube. info/waterman/index.html), so Duncan shouldn't have been so very amazed by your numbers unless he thinks you meant HTM. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi Stefan, > > First off, though I average between 25 and 32 seconds, most of my > cubing time, which is fairly limited, goes into understanding the cube > better rather than practicing for speed. > > Second, I am using only my own algorithms and haven't found a complete > set yet. While my strategies are pretty well formed I'm not yet > satisfied with all of my algorithms. As such, my method isn't > complete, yet. > > Third, with the exception of the placement of the last four centers > Gilles' method is an option within my method. > > Fourth for a speed comparison, my best time, from about six months > ago, is 13.33 seconds. > > Regards, > > David J

1943. Re: How do you know where to start?
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 02:28:28 -0000

Hello Eric, I have started 3 times. I have learned 3 different systems, and finally settled on Gilles Roux's Method. I started off w/ Corners 1st, and then switched to Fridrich/Petrus. I spent about 6 months on Corners 1st, and a year on Fridrich. 6 weeks ago switched to ROUX method, and have already achieved a best avg (so far) of 25.56sec, with a best time of 17.34. Roux http://grrroux.free.fr/ Petrus http://www.lar5.com/cube/index.html Fridrich http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/cube.html Corners 1st http://rubikscube.info/ Whatever you do, look at all of the methods and decide for yourself which one you want to go with. I like Roux because it has a low move count, and uses both Corners 1st and LBL strategies. Jason Kovacic kovacic81@... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eric" <maier@d...> wrote: > > Hi, > > For someone just getting to "speed cubing" how do you know where to > start? There seem to be a bunch of different methods out there but is > one better than another? > > I really want to try this out but don't want to spent a bunch ot time > learning a certain method only find out that I should have been > concentrating on an entirely different way of solving the cube. > > Thank for any input, > > Eric >
1944. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: How do you know where to start?
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 18:37:12 -0800

Also, don't get too intimidated when you read the methods. Don't choose one just because it seems easier. For all methods there are more beginner solutions, which can then be built upon, to reach the full method. There are also many more methods that you can find by scouring the web, or checking the links page at speedcubing.com. And lastly, don't forget the possibility of making your own method. Hope that helps, -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.net On 12/19/05, kovacic81 <kovacic81@...> wrote: > > Hello Eric, > > I have started 3 times. > I have learned 3 different systems, and finally settled on Gilles > Roux's Method. 1945. Re: 38 quarter turns confirmed sufficient
From: "Bruce Norskog" <brnorsk@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 04:13:59 -0000

The edges step totally ignores the corners. The corners step, however, leaves the edges "untouched." The edges move around during the moves to solve the corners, of course, but at the end they are restored to the exact same position, so if the edges are solved before doing the corners step, they will again be solved at the end of the corners step. Note that corners can always be solved with no more than 14 quarter turns if the edges are ignored. For the cube positions where this "edges first, then corners" strategy does not guarantee a solution in 38 quarter turns or less, I used a program I wrote in C++ which looks for a solution in two phases, where the goal of the first phase is to get the cube into a position within the Rubik's cube subgroup denoted by <U, D, F2, B2, R2, L2> (or symmetrical variations of that subgroup). To solve millions of positions, the solver needed to be very fast, but didn't need to produce particularly good solutions. So it only considered optimal solutions of each of the two separate phases. (In fact, it doesn't really use necessarily optimal solutions of the 2nd phase because of the way the lookup table for the 2nd phase is generated.) - Bruce Norskog --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi :-) > > Well, then either the edge-step leaves corners untouched or the > corner-step leaves edges untouched. Is this really the case for > those separate analyses ?? Ok, so im writing this before i have read > the full explanations so maybe the answers are to be found there. > > We also know from earlier that the cube is always solvable in 29 > half turns of the cube. So together this means that some positions > require at least 9 half turns for the "optimal" solution. Of course > solutions without half turns are possible, but those are not > necessarily "optimal". > > -Per > > PS! "Optimal" means optimal wrt proven minima, not wrt "gods > algorithm" :-) > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Norskog" > <brnorsk@v...> wrote: > > > > Hi, > > > > I can now report independent confirmation that Rubik's cube can > always be > > solved without using more than 38 quarter turns. This has been > shown based > > upon the following results. > > > > Tom Rokicki posted a result on this forum in January, 2004, > showing that the > > edge cubies of Rubik's cube can always be solved in 18 quarter > turns or > > less. (See: > > > http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/83 > 06) I > > have just verified this result, doing my own independent analysis > using a > > Pentium 4-based PC. > > > > Silviu Radu, who I understand is working on a Ph.D. thesis on > Rubik's cube, > > has done an analysis showing that the corners can always be solved > without > > any net change in the edge positions/orientations in 22 quarter > turns or > > less. Together, the above results show that Rubik's cube can > always be > > solved in two phases using no more than 40 quarter turns. I have > verified > > that Silviu's move sequences solve all of the relevant cube > positions using > > no more than 22 quarter turns. > > > > Rokicki's analysis indicates there are 31 positions, considering > just the > > edges and centers, that require more than 16 moves to properly > position and > > orient the edges. This is only 4 symmetrically distinct positions. > I have > > generated move sequences for solving all the symmetrically > distinct > > positions of Rubik's cube having these edge configurations using > no more > > than 37 quarter turns. Silviu has confirmed that my solutions are > correct > > and account for all the relevant symmetrically distinct positions. > All > > remaining positions of Rubik's cube can be solved in 38 quarter > turns or > > less (at most 16 quarter turns to solve the edges, and then 22 > quarter turns > > or less to solve the corners while having no net effect on the > edges). > > > > Details have been posted on the cube-lovers forum at: > > http://cubezzz.homelinux.org/drupal/ > > > > - Bruce Norskog > > >

1949. Re: Restoration hardware cubes
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 09:13:22 -0000

that's interesting--I have never noticed that code on the corner before. I glanced at a couple of my current cubes, and didn't see it on any of them. Did I just miss it, i.e. is that code on all cubes, or is that just something added recently? Anyone know if it is indeed a date stamp? seems logical... As for my Restoration Hardware cubes, all three I picked up read M1005B. Does yours have a B at the end? Is yours breaking in well? I still think this is as good of a new cube out of the box as I've bought [I probably have about 10, so I'm by no means an expert], but that coupled with the ease of trying out multiple cubes and the cool retro logo makes this a decent option imo for anyone who needs to pick up a new cube and can get to one of their stores. I didn't know to look for this code so have no idea if the ones I rejected had different codes. Also, I noticed the code was on different colored corners for each cube [another variability in a mass production process that I wouldn't have expected--I'm the type who would always make sure it was on the same color sticker, and I suspect that's a relativley common trait among cubers, but apparently not among cube manufacturers. obviously, it makes no difference in performance where it is, just seems a little off to me...] regards, Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, christopher_pelley <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Can you post the manufacture dates (on the inside of one of the > corners-- turn each face 45 degrees to locate it). The good cube that > I got said "M1005" which I take to mean it was just produced in > October of this year. It would be interesting to know whether these > cubes are of higher production standards than earlier batches. > > Speaking of that, is there anyone who can solve the puzzle of how > these cubes are manufactured vs. marketed? In other words, I know > that currently you can get 3x3x3 cubes made by Winning Moves, Hasbro, > or Rubiks.com. However they appear to be the same product from > Kroeger of Canada. Yet they all claim to be Made in China. Are they > made in China, imported by Kroeger, then packaged and sold by Winning > Moves, Hasbro, and Rubiks.com respectively? Does Kroeger just do the > final manufacturing (i.e. assembly and stickers)? > > I'm just trying to understand where the breakdown in quality actually > occurs. It doesn't make sense on the surface that Winning Moves cubes > are superior if they're all made at the same plant in China as the > Hasbro cubes. > > Chris > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Just got some new cubes from Restoration hardware. The stickers > > will probably wear out quickly, which is too bad becuase I like the > > retro logo, but new stickers are abundant and inexpensive. But > > right out of the box this one is very smooth and fast. I'm > > optimistic it will turn out to be a great speedcube. >
1950. Re: How do you know where to start?
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 09:37:54 -0000

Hey Eric, I wouldn't spend too much time worrying about this decision. All of the methods Jason mentioned are simply excellent, each with unique pros and cons, but each capable of producing very fast cubers. More importantly, even if you spend a lot of effort learning one method and then switch to another, that effort on the first method is definitely not wasted. Just training your fingers to move fast will also help you no matter which method you ultimately end up with. There's also a lot of overlap, and knowing more than one method can help your cubing, and once you know one method, picking up others is not so hard--similar to how if you know one of the romance languages, learing a second or third is easier than learning the first. If there is someone you know that uses a particular method, that may be enough to tilt the scales in favor of that method. While it's possible with all the info on the Internet to try to pick this all up on your own, for me at least, actually getting together with other cubers has helped tremendously. just my 2 cents' best of luck! --Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > Hello Eric, > > I have started 3 times. > I have learned 3 different systems, and finally settled on Gilles > Roux's Method. I started off w/ Corners 1st, and then switched to > Fridrich/Petrus. I spent about 6 months on Corners 1st, and a year on > Fridrich. > 6 weeks ago switched to ROUX method, and have already achieved a best > avg (so far) of 25.56sec, with a best time of 17.34. > > Roux > http://grrroux.free.fr/ > Petrus > http://www.lar5.com/cube/index.html > Fridrich > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/cube.html > Corners 1st > http://rubikscube.info/ > > Whatever you do, look at all of the methods and decide for yourself > which one you want to go with. I like Roux because it has a low move > count, and uses both Corners 1st and LBL strategies. > > Jason Kovacic > kovacic81@y... > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eric" <maier@d...> wrote: > > > > Hi, > > > > For someone just getting to "speed cubing" how do you know where to > > start? There seem to be a bunch of different methods out there but is > > one better than another? > > > > I really want to try this out but don't want to spent a bunch ot time > > learning a certain method only find out that I should have been > > concentrating on an entirely different way of solving the cube. > > > > Thank for any input, > > > > Eric > > >
1951. Re: [Speed cubing group] most turns without regripping
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 11:39:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Hello, > > I was rethinking about that record that happenned during the WC : 6 > full turns without regripping made by Oliver Wolff. > > I tried to reach it but the most I can do is 5. > I was wondering if anybody had any technique to be able to add a full > turn and twist your arms 6 times :p I heard about Oliver's 6 and tried it myself, all I can get is 5, too. Somehow I think Oliver and the people watching him all counted wrong : -) Did you see him do it? Did he do some weird behind-the-back stuff? Were there some rules? For myself, I made up this: Hold the cube with two fingers of each hand on opposite sides. I use thumb and middle finger. Cheers! Stefan

1953. Re: 4-look LL order switch = more "lucky" solves?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 11:51:43 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > > Odds to skip: > > Orient edges: 1/8 > > Orient corners: 1/27 > > Permute corners: 1/6 > > Permute edges: 1/12 > > Total odds to skip a step: about 41% > > > > These are the same no matter whether you orient or permute corners > > first. > > No, I dont agree with that! This is being very technical, of course. > But, do M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2. You may consider this to be a CP skip if > you do CP first or you can consider this to be a EP skip if you do EP > first. But, if you do EP first, then you have 2/12 = 1/6 chance to > skip the EP and a 1/12 chance to skip CP. It depends on how you > classify that case. :) Overall it's independent, i.e. the order doesn't change your chance/number of skips. Maybe it would be better to write it like this: Orient edges: 1/8 Orient corners: 1/27 Permute first of {corners,edges}: 1/6 Permute second of {corners,edges}: 1/12 Where I really disagree is only the 41%. That's what you get just adding the separate probabilities, which is wrong. The correct probability to skip a step (at least one) is about 35.6%. Cheers! Stefan
1954. Re: What is your fastest time possible for LL??
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 12:08:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > I also tried the Y-PLL on > the stackmat (1 attempt), btw, my record was 2.16... With Stefan > Pochmann's new alg :). You mean your (R2 U' R' U R U' z' y' L' U' R U' R' U' L U) modification, right? Man, still hard to believe I didn't see that myself :-) Hey, how about doing it these ways? R2 U' R' U R d' l' U' L U' L' U' R U R2 U' R' U l F' U' R' D R' D' R' U R Cheers! Stefan

(ACube found something in 22 > moves, not good for a fridrich solve lol) > > Gilles. > > 2005/12/11, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>: > > > > > > I'm going to look for some sort of parity fiw that swaps 2 edges + > > >some centers. > > > > I like M' U M2 U M2 U M. It preserves orientation of corners and > > edges and also permutation of corners. > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

1958. Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 Cube Marathon
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 13:04:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Hi Jason, > > What you normally do is: > 1) take 2 or 3 cubes > 2) have someone scramble them before you start > 3) start the time and start solving > 4) while solving cubes, the scrambler scrambles the solved cubes > 5) stop the time when 42 are solved. > > We normally do not use official scrambles for these unofficial records. > 42 is the number of kilometers for a marathon. > > The current unofficial record is held by Lars Vandenbergh: > http://www.speedcubing.com/records/recs_misc_marathon.html Similarly to the "no inspection" records I fear that some might always start with certain cube orientations (e.g. scrambler puts white center always on bottom) while others don't. Would be good (in both categories) to have a rule so that everybody does the same. Cheers! Stefan
1959. Re: Restoration hardware cubes
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 13:07:12 -0000

Yes, mine says M1005B also. And it's breaking in well. I left it unlubed for the first two weeks then sprayed it with silicon. It still turns very evenly. As for the codes, I think they started after the OddzOn cubes. It's a great feature. I'm almost certain that the first two numbers indicate the month, and the second two indicate the year. All the cubes I've bought in the past few years have consistently adhered to that scheme. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > that's interesting--I have never noticed that code on the corner > before. I glanced at a couple of my current cubes, and didn't see > it on any of them. Did I just miss it, i.e. is that code on all > cubes, or is that just something added recently? Anyone know if it > is indeed a date stamp? seems logical... > > As for my Restoration Hardware cubes, all three I picked up read > M1005B. Does yours have a B at the end? Is yours breaking in > well? > > I still think this is as good of a new cube out of the box as I've > bought [I probably have about 10, so I'm by no means an expert], but > that coupled with the ease of trying out multiple cubes and the cool > retro logo makes this a decent option imo for anyone who needs to > pick up a new cube and can get to one of their stores. > > I didn't know to look for this code so have no idea if the ones I > rejected had different codes. > > Also, I noticed the code was on different colored corners for each > cube [another variability in a mass production process that I > wouldn't have expected--I'm the type who would always make sure it > was on the same color sticker, and I suspect that's a relativley > common trait among cubers, but apparently not among cube > manufacturers. obviously, it makes no difference in performance > where it is, just seems a little off to me...] > > regards, > Kirk > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, christopher_pelley > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Can you post the manufacture dates (on the inside of one of the > > corners-- turn each face 45 degrees to locate it). The good cube > that > > I got said "M1005" which I take to mean it was just produced in > > October of this year. It would be interesting to know whether > these > > cubes are of higher production standards than earlier batches. > > > > Speaking of that, is there anyone who can solve the puzzle of how > > these cubes are manufactured vs. marketed? In other words, I know > > that currently you can get 3x3x3 cubes made by Winning Moves, > Hasbro, > > or Rubiks.com. However they appear to be the same product from > > Kroeger of Canada. Yet they all claim to be Made in China. Are > they > > made in China, imported by Kroeger, then packaged and sold by > Winning > > Moves, Hasbro, and Rubiks.com respectively? Does Kroeger just do > the > > final manufacturing (i.e. assembly and stickers)? > > > > I'm just trying to understand where the breakdown in quality > actually > > occurs. It doesn't make sense on the surface that Winning Moves > cubes > > are superior if they're all made at the same plant in China as the > > Hasbro cubes. > > > > Chris > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Just got some new cubes from Restoration hardware. The stickers > > > will probably wear out quickly, which is too bad becuase I like > the > > > retro logo, but new stickers are abundant and inexpensive. But > > > right out of the box this one is very smooth and fast. I'm > > > optimistic it will turn out to be a great speedcube. > > >
1960. Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 Cube Marathon
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 13:13:09 -0000

Hi Stefan :-) When Joel, Lars, Matt (Walter) and Ron tried the marathon after the World Championships the scrambler(s) tried as best as they could to put the cubes so that the cuber could see an easy cross. This is of course a bit subjective but i guess it gives the cuber more confidence to not get a cube where u have to search for a cross. As i know there are no official rules for the marathon, of course except that there is really no inspection time for each cube and u have to really solve 42 cubes with no pauses ... Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" > <ron@s...> wrote: > > > > Hi Jason, > > > > What you normally do is: > > 1) take 2 or 3 cubes > > 2) have someone scramble them before you start > > 3) start the time and start solving > > 4) while solving cubes, the scrambler scrambles the solved cubes > > 5) stop the time when 42 are solved. > > > > We normally do not use official scrambles for these unofficial > records. > > 42 is the number of kilometers for a marathon. > > > > The current unofficial record is held by Lars Vandenbergh: > > http://www.speedcubing.com/records/recs_misc_marathon.html > > Similarly to the "no inspection" records I fear that some might always > start with certain cube orientations (e.g. scrambler puts white center > always on bottom) while others don't. Would be good (in both > categories) to have a rule so that everybody does the same. > > Cheers! > Stefan >
1961. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4 centers
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 10:29:04 -0300 (ART)

Hey Stefan, just one more thing: if you find a very easy center, say, 3 pieces already complete and the other just a rR U (rR)' away, do you start with it or start with white (or yellow)? Pedro Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> escreveu: --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Rob Butler" <futuese@y...> wrote: > > "Each shot is either (Rr)' F (Rr) or (Ll) F' (Ll)" > > Why not (Rr) U' (Rr)'??? It is the same 'go and get' approach, > still only three moves, but the middle move is U instead of F > keeping the entire step in the (Ll), U, (Rr) gen category. Yes, you're right. Actually it's of course the same, just holding/rotating the cube differently. I actually do something in the "middle" I think. I've included this remark on my page now. I also fixed two mistakes in algorithms, made the page look a bit better, and added Pedro's issue and another suggestion how to hold your arms. > If stuck with a diagonal pair at the end it can also be quite > elegantly combined into: > > (Rr) U' (Rr)' U (Ll)' U (Ll) [pieces in Ufl and Ubr] > or (Ll)' U (Ll) U' (Rr) U' (Rr)' [pieces in Ubl and Ufr] Right. To be honest, I also use that in the middle of the solve. When the intervening shot would have to go to L or R, I'd have to rotate the cube first, so instead I solve the diagonal pair like you said. It's also good because it doesn't require any 'setup' move, you can use one of those two algs right away (this is something I only thought about right now). I'll add this to my page, too. > Do you have any data on number of moves for your technique compared > the 'usual' approach (opp centers, any 3rd face, adjacent 4th, > simultanious adjacent 5th/6th)?? I think both need about the same number of moves, around 30. I'm usually a bit over 30 but when I explained my method to Ron he soon told me he averages about 28-29 I think. Since I don't use that 'usual' approach, I don't exactly know the number of moves it requires, but I think it's about 30 as well. Thanks for the feedback and suggestions :-) Cheers! Stefan --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. More > importantly, even if you spend a lot of effort learning one method > and then switch to another, that effort on the first method is > definitely not wasted. Just training your fingers to move fast will > also help you no matter which method you ultimately end up with. > There's also a lot of overlap, and knowing more than one method can > help your cubing, and once you know one method, picking up others is > not so hard--similar to how if you know one of the romance > languages, learing a second or third is easier than learning the > first. > > If there is someone you know that uses a particular method, that may > be enough to tilt the scales in favor of that method. While it's > possible with all the info on the Internet to try to pick this all > up on your own, for me at least, actually getting together with > other cubers has helped tremendously. > > just my 2 cents' > best of luck! > --Kirk > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" > <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > > Hello Eric, > > > > I have started 3 times. > > I have learned 3 different systems, and finally settled on Gilles > > Roux's Method. 1970. magic... printouts?
From: "rubikorkow" <calcdude@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 16:24:32 -0000

OK, so I had this great idea. If you have an ugly red and yellow magic
like I do, and want a black and rainbow one, why couldn't you just...
print out the little pieces of paper, and replace them? this could
make getting good looking magics much cheaper. You could save about
$4, if you bought the "simpsons magic", and replace the picture!

If this idea would work, could someone make a printable page or
something for this?

Also, (this is completely unrelated), a string on my magic broke,
(literally snapped in half). Is there any way to, say, re-connect it
by heating it up or something?





1971. Re: magic... printouts?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 16:34:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikorkow" <calcdude@h...> wrote: > > OK, so I had this great idea. If you have an ugly red and yellow magic > like I do, and want a black and rainbow one, why couldn't you just... > print out the little pieces of paper, and replace them? this could > make getting good looking magics much cheaper. You could save about > $4, if you bought the "simpsons magic", and replace the picture! Sure, people do this to get Master Magics for less than $10 instead of more than 40. > Also, (this is completely unrelated), a string on my magic broke, > (literally snapped in half). Is there any way to, say, re-connect it > by heating it up or something? I don't think so, but even if you could, would you want that? I think the string would be more prone to breaking again, and the size may not be the same (ie - too loose or too tight, depending on how you reconnected it), so it would be more likely to snap again or to get tangled. I would say this is definitely not a good idea, even if it is possible. ~ Bob
1972. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 and 5x5x5
From: "rubikorkow" <calcdude@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 16:46:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann"

> Mmh... makes me think about people who claim the 25th anni cubes are
> great and others who claim they suck, the explanation being that
> they're not all equal. Could it be you just luckily got a good rubiks.
> com 4x4 and unluckily got a bad studio 4x4? Youre preference is based
> on experience with how many of each?
>
> Cheers!
> Stefan
>


Well, I have an original 1982 ideal 4x4, and a Rubiks.com 4x4, and I
think I got REALLY lucky with my 4x4. My Rubiks.com 4x4 almost turns
better than my 3x3 assembly cube with plently of lube. My 1982 4x4 is
teh suxors though. It's SOOO loud.







1973. WikiCube
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 16:47:01 -0000

WikiCube - The free encyclospeedia that anyone can edit.

I think it's about time we had a massive resource of anything you need
to know about cubing, proviously you'd have to hunt around the web for
something, but eventually, it'll all be here.

If you know how wikipedia works, you'll see just how good this is.
Otherwise....

Basically, WikiCube will have pages and pages of infomation about
different kinds of cubing. Don't see something there? Write a request
and someone will write a page about something. Just think, all the
cubing minds in teh world together in one place contributing
infomation, I hope this to because the number one source of infomation.

Handly, we could have for example a PLL pages explaining what PLL is
and some generic algs. Or a description of a method. No limits :)

The beta version is running on my webserver at the moment;

http://www.snkenjoi.com/wikicube/mediawiki-1.5.3/index.php?title=Main_Page

Feel free to add new articles or sign up and help expand the database.

Wikicode is pretty easy to use, and if you don't get it, gimmie a
shout and I'll fix up the page for you.

I've enabled image uploading and the like...

Any articles you write now will be carried over when it moves to it's
new home at cubemoves.com. This is just a sneak peek, but it'll be
here for a few months.

Also, another cool part of cubemoves (run by myself and paul nixon) is
a web interface for ACube. I've played around with it so far and it's
amazingly good. Which is fortunate since I can't get make cubesolvers
working on my linux box.

So, comments?

~Thom





1974. Re: WikiCube
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 17:12:31 -0000

Oh, I just threw a quick PLL page together, I hope bob doesn't mind. http://www.snkenjoi.com/wikicube/mediawiki-1.5.3/index.php?title=PLL :) The best thing about this is, it's less work for me. I wan't gonna bother putting my megaminx last layer method up, but now it's easy of course I'm going to, it's so easy to pick a new title and hit edit than making your own page, writing it, editing it, doing HTML, etc and uploading it. Yeah, have fun. Oh, I hope this'll motivate Per to create a page on his cage method for 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 now :D ~Thom --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@...m, "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@g...> wrote: > > WikiCube - The free encyclospeedia that anyone can edit. > > I think it's about time we had a massive resource of anything you need > to know about cubing, proviously you'd have to hunt around the web for > something, but eventually, it'll all be here. > > If you know how wikipedia works, you'll see just how good this is. > Otherwise.... > > Basically, WikiCube will have pages and pages of infomation about > different kinds of cubing. Don't see something there? Write a request > and someone will write a page about something. Just think, all the > cubing minds in teh world together in one place contributing > infomation, I hope this to because the number one source of infomation. > > Handly, we could have for example a PLL pages explaining what PLL is > and some generic algs. Or a description of a method. No limits :) > > The beta version is running on my webserver at the moment; > > http://www.snkenjoi.com/wikicube/mediawiki-1.5.3/index.php?title=Main_Page > > Feel free to add new articles or sign up and help expand the database. > > Wikicode is pretty easy to use, and if you don't get it, gimmie a > shout and I'll fix up the page for you. > > I've enabled image uploading and the like... > > Any articles you write now will be carried over when it moves to it's > new home at cubemoves.com. 1975. New UK cuber
From: "mantawrays" <matt.williams@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 17:25:07 -0000

Hi! A new cuber in the UK here. I used to play with the cube in the
80's when I was little(I used a really simple beginner layer method, I
think) and recently after playing with a 4 x 4 someone in the office
had got hooked again and bought a new cube in August.

I've been reading a lot of the people here's web pages and they have
all been a great help (esp. Jessica Fridrich's, Dan Harris', Joel Van
Noort, Chris Hardwick's). So thanks to everyone for making some great
webpages. I use the cross on the bottom. I am getting better at doing
F2L (it's taking a long time to be able to make fast decisions
though!) and have learnt the U, Z, H, E, J and F PLL algorithms (and
have forgotten the A one!). I guess I'm going to try to learn all the
PLL ones and then look at the OLL ones. Is that the general approach
to learning Fridrich? Since I learnt those PLL's I have found it
possible to solve the cube in around 50 seconds whereas before it was
around 1 minute 30 or something like that if I went flat out. Still
pretty slow compared to everyone here.

Still, I had a go with Chris H's 'oh wow' scramble and was shocked
when using my method after a few tries I solved it in 31 seconds.
Well, That was a big Oh wow for me, anyway! :)

I have two cubes, one I bought from a department store in August with
bright stickers on (which deteriorated really rapidly )- probably the
generic 3 x 3 Rubiks.com sell, and a Rubik's 3 x 3 DIY cube with PVC
stickers which I prefer. The DIY one seems to be easier to control
turns on and more suitable for doing fast solves (although it's
noisier according to my wife). Oh yes, and it has M0105B written on
one of the corners.

Does anyone have any opinions of the new anniversary cube? Is it the
same as the normal 3 x 3 but with a different centre white sticker? Is
it at all suitable for speedcubing? Are the stickers PVC or polypropelene?

That's it for now.

Cheers, Matt

Did he do some weird behind-the-back stuff? > Were there some rules? For myself, I made up this: Hold the cube with > two fingers of each hand on opposite sides. 1978. [Speed cubing group] Re: WikiCube
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 18:02:34 -0000

It's easy Click on one of the red links and press edit to create the article for that page. If it's not a red link, search for the page, and it'll say no page with 'that exact title' is avaliable. 'that exact title' acts as a red link and you can go from there to add the page. There's a way to do it in your user profile aswell, but this way is easyer. Or... you can do this http://www.snkenjoi.com/wikicube/mediawiki-1.5.3/index.php?title=[your page name here]&action=edit --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > How exactly can you add a page to such an interface ? > > Btw, I think it's a good idea, I'm not sure though if it will be a success. > But nice idea :-) > > Gilles. > > > 2005/12/20, thomkirjava <snkenjoi@g...>: > > Oh, I just threw a quick PLL page together, I hope bob doesn't mind. > > > > http://www.snkenjoi.com/wikicube/mediawiki-1.5.3/index.php?title=PLL > > > > :) > > > > The best thing about this is, it's less work for me. Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 18:32:03 -0000

I noticed there are different versions of the 25th anniversary cube.
I picked one up at Walmart yesterday and it was garbage. Very loose
and sloppy feeling. It was in a clear plastic "clamshell" style
packaging.

I just ordered one from here:
http://store.yahoo.com/seriouspuzzles/rubiks25th.html
which has a differnet packaging and hopefully it's from a different
manufacturer. Target ($6.99) is carrying the same version as Walmart.
Is there a current list of who has good cubes and what to look for?

Thanks,

Eric






1980. Re: [Speed cubing group] most turns without regripping
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 13:30:42 -0500

I remember seeing this. Maybe you're thinking of me. It was right after Oliver demonstrated how many times he could twist his arm with his palm on the table. We suggested he try turning the cube without releasing it. He started with his arms wrapped around each other and his fingers reaching as far around the cube as possible. I don't remember the exact turn count, but I remember it was a lot. :) On 12/20/05, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...> wrote: > I saw it but I was not very close. Ron was the one counting (and there > was a third person too, but I can't remember who it was). > And no, he didn't do anything weird such as starting in the back. > > I think the rules you say are correct and that's what I'm doing too. :-)
1981. Re: [Speed cubing group] Super-mini world cup-2005 0n 17th & 18th dec in Chennai, India
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 19:12:00 +0000 (GMT)

The days are not far off Mr.Sachin. Zee TV is shooting me on 24th dec in my home town and I will be coming to Bombay next month for an interview in TV studio. I shall definetly meet you. I have taught some of my friends here to cube and hope you too would have done so. Let us popularise this sport in India. Yes, I learnt some tips from Ron uncle and got some more ideas to improve myself. Having learnt PLL pairity in 4*4*4 my best time today is 1 min 26.42 sec and the avg of 10 is 1 min 41.86 sec. I am greatly benefitted after learning the tips to solve plus in 3*3. Finally, it was expensive for both Ron uncle and for my dad to make our meeting for 2 days. Hope to see you soon Mr.Sachin Bernett Orlando P.S : Any cuber going to India , plz let us know Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...> wrote: Hey, When i first saw the title i thought there was really some competition going to be held in chennai and i was instanly thinking about my travelling mode and all :) Anyways, good to know that you finally met Ron, ofcourse hes a great guy as i myself came to know after meeting him personally. But sadly there are no immediate plans for him coming to India again. Hey ron why dont you just say that the audit u did was a little "out-of-date" and keep coming here each month :) hehe Anyways keep cubing and congrats Bernett for ur great times! Sachin. On 12/19/05, JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...> wrote: > Dear Cubers, > Ron Van Bruchem uncle was in Chennai, India on 17th and 18th of dec-2005 > I am very very happy to have spent the week-end happily with Ron uncle. I learnt a lot and had fun. He was very good, kind and simple. > Eventhough I lost all the events to a great cuber, I enjoyed the super-mini world cup-2005 held in Chennai on 17th and 18th. It is called super-mini because only 2 competed. My disappointment for not being allowed to usa to compete in wc-2005 in Orlando was very well compensated by the super mini world cup-2005 with Ron uncle last week end. What a wonderful gesture from him to compete with this little boy travelling a long way!! > I am greatly benefitted and enjoyed asif I had been in Orlando. Wow, how many good quality cubes he had presented to me - square-1, 2*2, 3*3, 4*4, 5*5 !!! > Wow! at last, I shook hands with one of the best cubers in the world , talked with him, stayed with him, learnt from him, had fun with him and finally competed with him. Looking forward to many more such meetings in 2006 with you all as well. > The mini world cup-2005 held in chennai last week end was a great success. Kudos to Ron uncle, my dad and his friends and relatives to make this mini world-cup-2005 a great success. Full results Ron uncle may post at the earliest possible.( I hit many 18.xx, 19.xx and 20.xx sec in stackmat). > I am inspired. > > J.Bernett Orlando > > Send instant messages to your online friends http://in.messenger.yahoo.com > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > Yahoo! But the last two weeks I didn't wake up before noon. Today I did, and I violated the rule cause I've been processing the latest 500 or so messages most of the last 10 hours :-) > Thank goodness my hands/arms weren't > operated on so I can still cube ;) In fact, Stefan, I set 3:25.56 on > the Megaminx in hospital with my new method, and that's with only a > little practice. SO watch out, I am going to beat you soon! Great to hear that! Without competition it feels lonely :-). So I hope we can welcome you soon among us sub2-robots. Cheers! Stefan

1985. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4 centers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 19:50:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Hey Stefan, > just one more thing: > if you find a very easy center, say, 3 pieces already complete and the other just a rR U (rR)' away, do you start with it or start with white (or yellow)? So far I only start with white or yellow. Otherwise I get confused with the order of the four adjacent colors in step 2. I'd probably build white or yellow and try to preserve a pair of those other three for step 2. Cheers! Stefan
1986. Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 Cube Marathon
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 20:06:26 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi Stefan :-) > > When Joel, Lars, Matt (Walter) and Ron tried the marathon after the > World Championships the scrambler(s) tried as best as they could to > put the cubes so that the cuber could see an easy cross. Bah, that's so wrong. How about I tell the scrambler when I begin PLL, and he tells me the first few moves for next cube? There should be no help at all, the cubes should be as random as possible. But if the majority or the deciders decide that it should be allowed, I will accept it even though I don't like it. But it should be made clear that it's allowed, so that everybody knows and a meaningful comparison is possible. Cheers! Stefan
1987. [Speed cubing group] Re: Method efficiency WAS: L2L2 solves
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 20:08:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > > And you were right Stefan so thanks for the comment! I should work out my > solve numbers in STM for comparison. That probably won't save you much, though. Unless your method uses lots of slice turns in which case you would be more aware of STM :-) Cheers! Stefan
1988. Re: More proof that opposite color solving works
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 20:09:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > My old average average used to be about 17.5-17.6 seconds. My best > 100 cube average with one color solving was 17.55. Well I just did a > 100 cube average now that I am fairly comfortable with inspecting both > colors in 15 seconds, and my new 100 cube average is 16.83 seconds! > > I dropped about 0.7 second from my average, and I haven't changed any > new algs, nor have I been using any ZB tricks in my Fridrich solving > other than the occasional ZBF2L with all flipped edges (maybe 1/50 > solves). The only major change is opposite color solving. How long ago was that previous 100 cube average? Could it be you or your cubes improved in general? Cheers! Stefan
1989. Re: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 19:45:17 -0000

Hi Matt Welcome to the UK speedcubing community. Hopefully we will have another get together, perhaps in the summer. It would be great to see you there. It soudns like you are making good progress already - maybe you will be giving Dan a run for his money one day. Good luck and Happy Christmas Duncan (you can e-mail or messenger me at duncandicks@... direct if you fancy a UK chat) ----- Original Message ----- From: "mantawrays" <matt.williams@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, December 20, 2005 5:25 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber > Hi! A new cuber in the UK here. I used to play with the cube in the > 80's when I was little(I used a really simple beginner layer method, I > think) and recently after playing with a 4 x 4 someone in the office > had got hooked again and bought a new cube in August. > > I've been reading a lot of the people here's web pages and they have > all been a great help (esp. Jessica Fridrich's, Dan Harris', Joel Van > Noort, Chris Hardwick's). So thanks to everyone for making some great > webpages. I use the cross on the bottom. I am getting better at doing > F2L (it's taking a long time to be able to make fast decisions > though!) and have learnt the U, Z, H, E, J and F PLL algorithms (and > have forgotten the A one!). I guess I'm going to try to learn all the > PLL ones and then look at the OLL ones. Is that the general approach > to learning Fridrich? Since I learnt those PLL's I have found it > possible to solve the cube in around 50 seconds whereas before it was > around 1 minute 30 or something like that if I went flat out. Still > pretty slow compared to everyone here. > > Still, I had a go with Chris H's 'oh wow' scramble and was shocked > when using my method after a few tries I solved it in 31 seconds. > Well, That was a big Oh wow for me, anyway! :) > > I have two cubes, one I bought from a department store in August with > bright stickers on (which deteriorated really rapidly )- probably the > generic 3 x 3 Rubiks.com sell, and a Rubik's 3 x 3 DIY cube with PVC > stickers which I prefer. The DIY one seems to be easier to control > turns on and more suitable for doing fast solves (although it's > noisier according to my wife). Oh yes, and it has M0105B written on > one of the corners. > > Does anyone have any opinions of the new anniversary cube? Is it the > same as the normal 3 x 3 but with a different centre white sticker? Is > it at all suitable for speedcubing? Are the stickers PVC or polypropelene? > > That's it for now. > > Cheers, Matt > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >

I've been told that as a kid when we were on holidays, I god a cold and slept for a night, a day, and another night in a row. Then I was healthy again. Cheers! Stefan
