1992. new version of Jess Bonde's ultimate timer featuring scrambled applets
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 20:53:11 -0000

Hi I created a new version of Jess Bonde's ultimate timer even though I know he promised to rip my head off... No, in fact I did ask him to create a version that would contain an applet to immediately be able to check the scramble on your cube, but he said the code was so ugly he'd probably die from the mere shock of looking at it. I took my chances anyway, and it was only a couple of lines to be added. If you want to change the color scheme then you can search for it in the source code and do so, it's in one place only (hint: search for "<applet"). You can download it from the files section, or use it online here: http://vanderblonk.com/cube/timer.htm Make sure you put the rubikplayer.jar from www.randelshofer.ch in the same directory as the file, and Ron's your uncle! Michiel
1993. Re: Different versions of the 25th anniv. cube
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 21:04:10 -0000

see the posts about the cubes at restoration hardware. I know $12 may be a couple of bucks more than the cubes at wal-mart, but being able to try them all out makes it worth it [plus I like the retro logo]. I've heard of people opening up and trying out cubes at the other stores or buying 5 and returning 4, but I don't know how those retailers react to that--if they'll let you do it, great. As you've discovered, there is a wide range of initial quality on cubes. You could try to return and exchange it and see if they let you. If not, don't give up on the cube. If it's too tight, take it apart and wedge a credit card or two bewteen the center edges for a day or two to loosen up the tension in the springs. Silicon spray can really help. And even the stiffest cubes will wear in over time and heavy use. other options include the DIY cubes from rubiks.com where you can adjust the tension of the center springs, and I've heard some people prepare speedcubes and sell them on eBay. good luck! --Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eric" <maier@d...> wrote: > > I noticed there are different versions of the 25th anniversary cube. > I picked one up at Walmart yesterday and it was garbage. Very loose > and sloppy feeling. It was in a clear plastic "clamshell" style > packaging. > > I just ordered one from here: > http://store.yahoo.com/seriouspuzzles/rubiks25th.html > which has a differnet packaging and hopefully it's from a different > manufacturer. Target ($6.99) is carrying the same version as Walmart. > Is there a current list of who has good cubes and what to look for? > > Thanks, > > Eric >
1994. Re: Different versions of the 25th anniv. cube
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 21:38:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y.. .> wrote: > > If it's too tight, take it apart > and wedge a credit card or two bewteen the center edges for a day or > two to loosen up the tension in the springs. Does someone know where this advice comes from? The current rubiks.com cubes and equivalents have screws with large heads. These limit how far you can pull out a center. The limit is *not* defined by a fully compressed spring, like it is for the Studio cube and equivalent (i.e. most old Ideal). In the new cubes you can't fully compress springs because the screw head blocks earlier. I know you can shorten a spring by fully compressing it for a while, but I doubt it has any effect if you don't get at least quite near to full compression. Does anybody have proof this works for current rubiks.com cubes? I believe it for Studio cubes but I have doubts about rubiks.com ones... Cheers! Stefan
1995. an interesting Petrus/Zbigniew/Rubik combination
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 22:08:30 -0000

Check it out:
http://www.merlin.com.pl/images_big/11/9875753.jpg

Cheers!
Stefan

1997. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 and 5x5x5
From: "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 22:16:19 -0000

Of course you're right Stefan. But I always assume people don't take my word as the absolute truth :P I have 1 Rubiks.com and 2 Studio's. Ton told me the plastics were not the same. And I'm not complaining, since the studios were very cheap at the Dutch Cube Day - Koen --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" > <allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > > > Rubiks studio 4x4 is NOT the same as 4x4 Rubiks.com > > Different plastic I think, and again I prefer Rubiks.com. Turns much > > smoother. And yes I have both :P > > > > - Koen > > Mmh... makes me think about people who claim the 25th anni cubes are > great and others who claim they suck, the explanation being that > they're not all equal. Could it be you just luckily got a good rubiks. > com 4x4 and unluckily got a bad studio 4x4? Youre preference is based > on experience with how many of each? > > Cheers! > Stefan >

2000. Re: Different versions of the 25th anniv. cube
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 22:57:23 -0000

I think I read about it in a former post in here a long time ago. I haven't done it in a long time, but I recall getting some improvement in how tight the cube turned, but at the same time I was doing the credit card technique I was lubing the other pieces, so maybe that part was just a sugar pill. But if Stefan says it doesn't work, then I'd defer to him--he's definitely the spring king! best regards, Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y.. > .> wrote: > > > > If it's too tight, take it apart > > and wedge a credit card or two bewteen the center edges for a day or > > two to loosen up the tension in the springs. > > Does someone know where this advice comes from?
